Prelude: The Glorious Decades
(1972-1988)

May 14, 1988 - the absolute apex of human civilization. 43 years of continuous, unabated economic prosperity since the end of World War II in 1945. The world enjoys a splendor of opulence and luxury from the opening of free trade with the Shanghai Accords in 1972. The (in)famous Doomsday Clock shows that the world is at an outstanding 45 minutes to midnight as of 1987 - the farthest away it ever will be in human history. Thousands of Boeing 2707 and Lockheed L-2000 supersonic airliners connect the globe at over twice the speed of sound. The Station of International Cooperation and Friendship (SICF) - is approaching its first-year anniversary of operation - while the first joint Soviet-American mission to Outpost One is set to launch in two weeks time. All across the Western world in particular - the average person thrives in mega-houses, has a color TV in every bedroom, and makes routine vacations to far away, exotic locations. Yet observers from a place sideways in time would note that the glitz and glamor of the 1970s and 1980s appears… uncanny. Families breed like rabbits with reckless abandon - swelling the global population to unsustainable levels. Society and culture spin on an axis of shallow hyper-consumerism, cynicism and youth apathy. And worst of all - the cost of technological and societal progress is wreaking havoc and devastation on Earth’s ecology and environments. How did this world come about? How did the mania of unchecked progress spiral out of control?

A Transformative New Order (1945-1960)

Contrary to what most historians argue - the roots of the Glorious Decades go back NOT to the signing of the Shanghai and Tehran Accords in 1972 - NOR to the fateful assassination of Mao Zedong on September 11, 1971 - NOR to the triumph of Richard Nixon in the 1968 United States presidential election - NOR even the foundation of the Gaia Liberation Organization of Goddess’ Lament (GLOGL) in 1964.

Nay, the roots of the Glorious Decades date all the way back to the closing days of World War II (1939-45). As the days of the Third Reich and the Showa State were numbered by 1944-45, the groundwork for the post-war economic and geopolitical order for the next 4 decades were being laid out by the United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union, China and France.

World War II had caused immense economic and cultural destruction of Europe and Asia. Destruction that practically left almost every major Great Power in 1914 - the United Kingdom, France, the Soviet Union, Germany, Italy and Japan - utterly shattered. Destruction that the United States of America was nigh completely spared from.

Part 1
The American Twilight and the Second Civil War (2000-2023)

Excerpt from “The Dying Eagle: America in the Rotting Twenties”, by Anathi Yoyo, University of Isixeko Sokufunda Press, 970 ASJ 


New York, 2023. Wildfires and pollution have constantly drenched the cityscape in smog since the Red Decades.

https://youtu.be/x-o3CJytIPE?si=CWJqklywhO4tFfNO 

It's the year 2023... nothing works. Not the Government, not the Factories, and not the Irrigation systems. People are still the same. They'll do anything to get what they need. And they need just one more good day, one more reason to live. 

The crime rate was only increasing. Mob bosses, radical ecoterrorists, and even corporate espionage dominated the country’s over- and underworld and overwhelmed the scattered, underfed boys in faded blue, to say nothing of the ever present murder and rape cases. On a good day, the murder rate in New York City was estimated at only 243 per 24 hours, and that was before the FBI stopped even recording crimes. The Library of Crime Statistics had ‘Seen God’ in December 2022, and the Bureau has largely given up finding a Reader nihilistic enough to have the willpower to record it. 

The Black Winter of 2022 was hard all across the nation. The Universal Food Ration was pushed to the limit, even with the advent of Ration Omega to supplement the dwindling numbers. Researchers in the remains of famine and drought-stricken northern California noted that those with an extensive diet of Ration Omega tended to get sick easier and suffered from symptoms of malnourishment, though the corporation quickly suppressed these studies. The cramped conditions of many cities, the accelerating thawing and melting of ice and permafrost, and the severe crippling of the health service had caused a massive resurgence of previously eradicated diseases. This had culminated in a flood of viruses like the Chicago Fever, the Blue Flu and the Charleston Cough. The crown of these was known simply as “The Blight”, a mysterious disease that spread extremely rapidly throughout the world and US - or so the White House had said. The Department of Sanitation recommended that anyone suffering from even mild symptoms should Seek God. A list later published and distributed via word-of-mouth and chalk slate described the symptoms: mental fatigue, deteriorated cognition, reduced muscle mass, being unable to retain body heat, and a rejection of most foodstuffs. 

In February 2023, things had gotten so bad that President Sanderson got on radio and addressed the Blight as the greatest threat the United States has faced - a message that every president had given every year since 1989. He urged Americans showing symptoms to self-isolate, then Seek God. He compared it to a father sacrificing his life so that his kid could live, and even promised increases in death benefits. His final, tearful remark was a suggestion that Seeking God was the preferable alternative to “things to come”. 

The Republican Party seized this as a talking point, feigning outrage that the President had literally told the nation to “off themselves” and should be impeached immediately. The 11 Republican representatives in Congress signed articles of impeachment towards the President, however the Democratic supermajority ignored the notion. “The President, as a citizen of the United States, was merely exercising his First Amendment rights,” the Chairman of the DNC and Press Secretary, Harry Holden, said. 

As the Blight Scandal spiraled out of control, the Democratic Party announced sweeping agricultural legislation, called the “American Bounty Act”, which removed any environmental protections left and officially dismantled the National and State park system. The already scarce free land was replaced with even more new “superfarms”, the biggest expansion of the system since its creation. Overseen by the Food, Inc and endorsed by the Green Party, the Act promised to create millions of jobs and help reduce the strain and disease of the inner city. 

The few Republicans in Congress called the Act a “handout to Big Food” and simultaneously a human rights violation, scathingly criticizing it. However, the ten or so representatives in Congress could do nothing as the act quickly passed with a supermajority of Democrats and Greens.

Of course, the researchers and elites knew that there was no arable land remaining in the natural parks.

On the superfarms themselves, other problems arose. The massive, labor intensive industry had long been reliant on the bloated prison system of the United States, and indeed the latter had been refitted to serve the former. Crimes that 30 years ago had resulted in fines often now carried decades long sentences in various private labor programs. Conditions were in many cases deliberately kept poor enough that resistance, which now easily allowed for sentences to receive decades long extensions, was common. 

The United States had long been an agricultural giant, however, much of the best arable land was being cultivated for over a century prior to the climate crisis. As the demand for basic foodstuffs (by now only a handful of calorie dense grains) skyrocketed, sustainable crop rotation fell by the wayside, the soil being exhausted by unrelenting use. Various fertilizers could compensate, but by the 2020s nearly 40% of agricultural land was essentially unusable, even with night farming. 

Although the superfarms continued to carve into the last vestiges of undeveloped land to compensate, many of these areas had never been farmed for a reason. Some were arid deserts, useless as much of the Southwest was regularly experiencing temperatures in the 120F range for much of the summer. Other locations had no soil at all, or were so polluted that agriculture was obviously futile. Despite the number of superfarms continuing to climb, the total agricultural production of America had actually peaked in 2011. Much of what did grow was disease ridden (though largely free of pesticides as most insect populations had collapsed) toxic, and underground. Most of this was simply mashed and dried into a kind of paste, used to fortify Food, Inc products. 

The workers of these superfarms, mistreated and underfed, had a yearly mortality rate of nearly 7%. Those guarding them often lived in little better accommodations, and had little oversight to ensure they acted humanely. By 2022, the prisoners had unwittingly become part of Food, Inc's latest product, to whom the only warning sign was an inexplicable untick in the number of prisoners shot for ‘infractions’. The large scale use of prisoners was twofold, to reduce an increasingly unproductive and undesired group of people, and to ensure that the true origin of Ration Omega, if it ever came to light, might be more digestible if the people thought only the dead and the imprisoned were being used.

But the fact is, people don’t make a good choice of livestock. The average American’s body in 2022 contained 115,000 calories, enough to feed someone on minimum rationing for less than 3 months. Even with the prisoners adding to those who chose to Seek God, only a tiny fraction of the United States' caloric needs could be fulfilled through these measures. This was known to those who had facilitated the scheme, but the goal had never been to somehow feed the living with the dead for eternity. The hope was that Ration Omega would allow for disease, poverty, and crashing birth rate, to gradually wind the population down to a sustainable level, whatever that was now.

And in many areas, food wasn’t even a major issue.

Beyond the Plains, large parts of the nation were essentially depopulated. The south-west had long been struggling with intense heatwaves since the Hot Summer of 1990, and temperatures had rapidly grown to being unliveable, with heat and humidity proving a deadly killer. Phoenix was one such of them, with the city suffering from increasingly lethal summers, the situation not being helped by the abandonment of the suburbs to the overcrowded cities and heat absorbent properties of the road asphalt. People became packed in the city centre, and with housing being in increasingly short supply, were dying out in the streets in the summers, the endlessly growing cases of heatstroke overwhelming the city’s emergency services. More and more people, rich and poor, young and old, fled north and east for cooler temperatures and the prospect of not being threatened with death every year.

But the real killer was drought.

The Colorado River was rapidly drying up, and the consequences became obvious suddenly in the Hot Summer, where water reached dangerously low levels and emergency water rationing was declared across the cities in the deserts of the southwest. These measures quickly became permanent as temperatures continued to drastically increase and mitigation efforts became too costly for the debt-drowning state and federal governments to afford. The water rationing and heat quickly led to riots, as order in Phoenix quickly left and the cartels encroached. Riots led to massacres, as the police department desperately fought to maintain order in the crumbling city - one slip up or accident could lead to a hundred dead, the incident covered up by the government. In 2003, the government declared Phoenix to be an “unsustainable city” around the same times as Albuquerque, Los Angeles, and many others hit hard by the changing climate. This simply meant that government services and funding would be withdrawn imminently from the city, and the populace was “urgently advised” to evacuate (the government didn’t have the money for a large-scale program). The mass evacuations and depopulation accelerated, and the formal economy shut down to be replaced by cartels and drug lords ruling over the city’s ruins. By the 2010s, Phoenix was a ghost city, with only vagrants and homeless living there, employed by the cartels, fighting amongst the last few reserves of food and water.

Phoenix by 2020 is desolate - utterly abandoned, with rows upon rows of vacant, baking houses and towering apartments leering through the sky. It is an open-air oven, boiling alive those few who inhabit it, and unfortunately sharing the fate of many other cities not only in Arizona, but in neighbouring states and countries.

Los Angeles is another victim of this deadly combo. The “City of Angels” had been on a constant decline since the Red Decades, with the shutting down of Hollywood and the 1996 water riots crippling the city’s reputation and economy, the near-permanent state of martial law not helping. It was declared “unsustainable” slightly later than Phoenix, in 2006, as rioting and anarchy continued to grow and render the LAPD useless. As the rivers quickly dried up and the city became drenched in smoke from wildfires and pollution, people quickly left and it suffered the same fate as the rest of the west - abandoned by government, abandoned by God. The remaining inhabitants hide out away from the sun in decaying buildings and fight amongst themselves for the remaining resources. The Angels have left for the last time and will not return perhaps ever again.

(new image)
A photo of a desolate street in Los Angeles, circa 2002. The intense heat makes it impossible to go out.

Further east, Denver is not completely unliveable, but is rapidly reaching that point.

The city became packed with rural migrants following the Dust Bowl of 1995, which wrought havoc on rural farming communities and local agriculture, causing food prices to spike yet again. It’s population very rapidly increased and the government quickly crammed in new apartments and housing into the already cramped city centre. And with many more people comes a lot more heat - the worsening heatwaves of the 90s threatened to cripple the city, and water shortages brought it to the brink of total collapse in the ways Phoenix and Los Angeles were following.

Yet the government took a special interest in Denver compared to the other cities. As the food crisis intensified, massive superfarms were built on giant scales in the 2000s and 2010s to take advantage of whatever land there was left. Denver’s bloated population was considered too costly to evacuate and risked a giant humanitarian crisis that could spiral into rebellion, so the government did the next best thing they could think of - send them to the farms. Colorado’s infamous superfarms were powered with near-unlimited migrant labour from Denver, and many “internal refugees” from abandoned desert cities often stopped and were sent to work in Denver’s superfarms. The proximity to the farms caused Denver’s food prices to be decently lower than lots of the nation’s and they were able to get organic (if not weak and diseased) food for longer than most Americans. The rapid expansion also led to some suburbanisation - houses in the suburbs were demolished and replaced with cramped and packed apartment blocks to house Denver’s growing refugee population.

By the 2010s the heatwaves and further drought issues pushed the city more and more towards the breaking point. Washington couldn’t allow Denver to fall, lest it fall into a severe supply crisis. To avert this it helped divert more and more water from surrounding rivers to the city. Despite this, the situation continued to get worse and worse. Denver was a ticking time bomb, and everyone knew this. It would take one extra-strong heatwave, one sharp decrease in water supply for the bomb to explode.

And in summer 2022, it finally blew. A combination of Denver’s water supply dropping to near-zero and an intense dust bowl in the superfarms led to riots breaking out among the city’s now-unemployed. The riots rapidly grew violent and the police force was unable to contain them. The situation became untenable, and the government made the controversial decision to declare Denver “unsustainable” and conduct evacuations to neighbouring cities. The crisis was considered one of the major contributors to 2022’s “Black Winter” and agriculture never recovered following.

(new picture)
Denver in 1997. The influx of internal refugees from rural Colorado and the southwest led to many homeless shelters like this.

Up north, the Great Lakes were doing comparatively better.


Chicago, 2010. The proximity to Lake Illinois kept nature thriving until the heatwave of 2015. 

The rapid rise in universal free trade following 1972’s Shanghai Accords prompted massive deindustrialisation across America. Giant corporations, ever looking for ways to increase profit, shut down their factories in the midwest and opened new sweatshops throughout Asia, Africa and South America. American manufacturing was already in decline, but the advent of free trade accelerated the process dramatically, and the Rust Belt saw heavy deterioration as workers fled to the cities of the south and east. Wars in the Glorious Decades were not fought with bayonets and bullets but tariffs and trade negotiations. The New York Stock Exchange became the staging ground for many conflicts, with industrialists and financiers flocking to the ever-expanding towers of Manhattan as stocks skyrocketed ever higher. These trends looked unstoppable until the Middle East became covered with radioactive decay and free trade collapsed overnight. The crash and Graves’s protectionism led to a resurgence of manufacturing and the revival of the rusting factories of Detroit, Minneapolis and Chicago, spurred on by the American Industry Protection Act of 1994. 

The megalithic factories of the Midwest were refitted from producing automotives and luxury goods to producing essential supplies in post-1988 America. As many railroads and highways led to Chicago, it was chosen by the Graves administration to be the center of manufacturing in this new America. Sanitary products, face masks, and coarse uncomfortable clothing were all manufactured in Chicago, to be shipped out across the crumbling country. In the northernmost plains, the warming climate and huge repository of freshwater actually helped agriculture in a small production boom until the heatwave of 2015. Rows upon rows of corn were grown and carted by hand to the Twin Cities, located at the head of the murky Mississippi, then to be shipped down the river using tugboats. Detroit became the spearhead to rebuilding American industry: essential metalworks such as the manufacturing of pipes, tools, wrenches and other parts of machinery were used to refit the rest of the nation. There were even reports of secret bullet factories for the increasingly militant police forces of the nation. These decaying cities, once seemingly condemned to disrepair, were revived overnight as people fled to the cooler and more hospitable climates and more employable cities of the Midwest. They were not as flashy as the once neon-drenched New York City, Boston, Los Angeles, or Seattle, but they offered a commodity in increasingly short supply - hope. 

The pace was never fast enough though. Shirts were made so carelessly that most only lasted a year at most. Corn rotted in the humidity of the South before it could reach the starving workers of the Southern Superfarms. For every missing part that was manufactured, two more parts would be broken down. Even the Riot Gear made for the LAPD wouldn’t last, as intense civil unrest and budget cuts caused police to exhaust all forms of protection when the crowd went wild. 

Chicago was one such city affected by the rise and falls of “Made in America”. People flocked to Chicago following the record heat waves of 1990, 1991 and 1992, resulting in the city’s population more than doubling during the 1990s. The city was completely unprepared for this - as more and more moved in, overcrowding became a significant issue. Housing was in short supply, and giant apartment blocks were constructed over bulldozed houses, with each room containing the bare minimum of concubines and appliances and designed to contain as many people as possible (one room could hold three nuclear families). And even then, millions of people were forced to the streets and taken into the rapidly growing and strengthening criminal underworld, built up in the new alleyways and tunnels the police would never touch. And even though it was cooler than the south or southwest, Chicago, partly due to the abundance of people, still got very, very hot. Riots broke out regularly in the 1990s and only got worse in the 2000s. The government was forced to heavily militarise the Chicago Police Department and brutally suppress protests - in the riots following the 2004 Midwest Heatwave, the police opened fire on a group of protestors, leading to hundreds dead and continuing riots that stretched on until the heatwave calmed down in the winter.

Why did people flock to a city with such a formerly bad reputation? It was twofold - one was the cooler weather and proximity to the Great Lakes, where freshwater was more readily available, and the other was the rebirth of manufacturing. Millions of new job opportunities were created, and Chicago and Detroit and others were seen as places where one could easily get employed - that was partly true, as jobs were more readily available in the rust belt than other areas of the country (aside from the plains), and there was no real requirement for being hired. However, only so many factories could be rebuilt in a certain period of time, and so for the people coming there later, finding a job was a struggle, and the economy just continued to worsen. Many people came there and stayed unemployed, and the criminal underground only grew.

The unions, who were reinvigorated by the American Unions and Workers Act of 1989, were able to help keep wages and working conditions as amicable as they possibly could. However, as corporations gained more power and increasingly gained more power over the Democratic Party, their attitude towards unions gradually shifted. In 2000, the newly elected corporate Democrat governor of Illinois introduced the Industrial Preservation Act, which increased the requirement to form a union to 50% and limited strikes to a maximum of two days. This prompted outcry from the workers and unions, who launched a general strike to stop the Act from passing. An agreement was eventually made to remove the strike and other disagreeable provisions, but the damage was already done. More and more Democratic state governments implemented restrictions on unions, and in 2005 a general strike would be launched over the Labor and Work Reform Act, which as part of the earlier “crime reforms” introduced would abolish the prison system and mandate the use of penal labor as punishment for crimes. The strike went for a week before it was brutally suppressed by the National Guard, factories being burned down as punishment. Following this, the American Unions and Workers Act of 2005 was introduced to replace the old 1989 one, and passed with a supermajority of most Democrats and Republicans in Congress. All trade unions would be merged into one singular union - the American Labor Front, with President Sweeney disregarding the parallels to the Nazi equivalent. The union would be controlled and subsidised by the government, and the remaining ones knew exactly what that meant - extinction. 

Strikes rolled on in 2005 but underwent brutal suppression. Most unions folded - the leaders of the ones that didn’t were executed. The last remaining one holed themselves in a Chicago factory, determined to stay there and fight back until they were killed. The government then went and burned the factory down along with everyone in it, burning the remains again and again to make an example of them. Anyone opposing the “rebuilding” would be treated as a terrorist, a communist, an insurgent.

As internal migration controls were introduced, Chicago saw little change in the late 2000s aside from the ever-deadlier heatwaves. Manufacturing led to more and more pollution in the city. Available freshwater was continually polluted and disease was rife. The Great Heatwave of 2015 caused smoke to blanket the city, and water shortages led to a few days of intense and brutally suppressed rioting. Chicago in 2020 is a decaying, overcrowded ruin with the highest crime rate in the country above Denver, choking on pollution and built on the numerous corpses of the unionists and rioters that struggled and failed to resist the grasping hands of corporatism.


A picture of the factory the last free trade unionists were killed in, taken in 2005.


Excerpt from “The Eagle and the Snake: A History of the Second American Civil War”, by Gabriel Treviño León, Patagonia Press, New Buenos Aires, 934 ASJ


National Guardsmen in Chicago line up “Communists” for execution, 2002

The United States was determined to keep an image of stability around it. By the 2010s, most cities were essentially under martial law, with armed police patrolling the streets and the prison labor acted as a deterrent for any crime. Most departments of government were still active, if not working as a skeleton crew. However, on the inside it was crumbling. Internal opposition was rapidly building up as dissatisfaction among people grew against the ineffectual Democratic government, and with elections being bought out and delivering the same result each time, people were forced to move onto other methods.

Following the bloodbaths of 2004 and 2005, a vast majority of the nation, including many of the Democrats in the House of Representatives, were confused by the severe backlash. How did the party of the Common Man start to treat their workers this way? The Sweeney Administration, already attempting to stem the crime waves of the 1990s, claimed that subversives were trying to disrupt the hard-working men of America, that red-blooded American men would never ask for easier hours and better pay as they should be grateful they have a job in this glorious nation. 

“These strikes and demolitions are the work of Communists who are trying to destroy each American’s right to a roof over his head, a shirt on his back, and a decent meal after a hard day’s work,” President Sweeney said during a televised conference on September 23rd, 2005. “And I say to you, America: if you, as an employee, know a worker who is disrupting the rebuilding of our great nation, of anyone who is disrupting the esteemed business of the Lake Illinois Clothing Company, or of the reputable enterprise of 4M, or any other proudly American business, let your nearest police officer know, and they will be met with consequences most severe.” 

The newer generation, of those who had grown up knowing only bountiful products from China and the USSR, did not see the contradiction in the President’s speech. Few of the older generation made the connection and spoke out, risking their National Relief payments. Fewer still made the connection that 4M, Lake Illinois Clothing Company and other corporate goliaths like the Food, Inc were President Smith’s biggest donors.

https://youtu.be/FFJ6Vv7Sn6o?si=gGlQ_dnnV74CsegP 

The overwhelming repression did not stop extremists, however. The American Volunteer Army, a ragtag group of misguided anarchists, frequently protested at their own peril. Protests led to riots, riots led to bombings, and bombings led to guerilla warfare. These acts of terrorism were ironically used by the federal government to justify harsher and harsher conditions for the dwindling class of employed citizens. After the 2011 bombing of a Food, Inc Factory outside Madison, Wisconsin, the decision was made to use only unpaid prison labor for the manufacturing of all goods. The motives for the bombing were never publicly announced. Soon, the cities of the Midwest were just as oppressive and cramped as Denver or a Southern super farm.

In 2010, the city of Portland seceded from the United States, and declared itself the United Communes of Portland. Other counties in Oregon and Washington followed suit, and formed the new nation of Cascadia, with Portland as its capital. They dedicated their country to the ideals of sustainability, work ethic, and frugality. The Portlanders fought valiantly, but were overwhelmed by the sheer amount of soldiers the US government sent to the meat grinder. The leaders, including Ted Kaczynski and Edward Abbey, were executed by hanging on live television. The rest of the Portland Rebels were sent to be worked to death on the Idaho superfarms. This did not stop monkey-wrenchers and other eco-terrorists from acting, though, but they became a lot quieter. It was whispered throughout the northwest that the Canadian government was covertly funding and training an army of rebels to fight the shrinking administration in Washington. 

They weren’t the only rebels, however. Beginning in 1997, the Governor of Alabama tarnished Dr. Martin Luther King’s legacy and reinstated a twisted form of agricultural segregation by only employing African Americans as farm hands. Alabama, while working closely with the burgeoning Food, Inc, was not directed by their corporate partner to enact this policy. Food, Inc did not care, however: as long as their soy and lentil were still grown, the Governor could act how he wished. What they did not expect however was how harshly the farm hands were worked, and in turn, the increase in production. Food, Inc was so pleased that they started lobbying for the use of convicts to supplement the numbers of workers. The Governor immediately expanded the scrutiny of the law to make just about anything illegal and started working men to death by the hundreds. For this, Food, Inc rewarded him with a spot on the Board of Directors, making the Governor the richest man in the South. 

This was around the time when the line between government and corporation began to blur. As the Governor left for New York to live in a (relatively) opulent apartment, the Food, Inc effectively took over what was left of the South. Food, Inc, always thinking about the bottom line, gave their employees effective reign over how they dealt with their “volunteers”. Many of the farm directors embraced the discrimination, as they found it therapeutic taking out their frustrations on their workers - as long as someone was below them, they could tolerate the deteriorating conditions. After one rotgut binge, a certain farm director in Mississippi decided to bring back the ideals of the Confederacy. He later declared that the “Northern Yankees have tainted the world with their industrial rot and the agrarian Golden Circle must now be reformed”. 

https://youtu.be/5nCuz4qjTro?si=pEUYD6Hd6bBnosa2 

The second Confederacy was much smaller than its previous iteration. Much of the South was an arid desert by 2000, and the rest of it dedicated to intensive agriculture that was bleeding the land dry. After a slave revolt (for the workers by this point were essentially slaves in all but name), the Black Panther Party organized and started sabotaging the southern farms in the same way that the AVA was doing in the Rust Belt and the Cascadian armies in the Northwest. 


Klan members ambushing a Democratic representative outside Memphis, Tennessee. Date unknown. 

The Federal Government, officially treating the operation as a Civil War, rallied the unemployed and sent them off to fight the rebels, just as they were doing in the Rust Belt and the Northwest. However, by 2005, once it became clear that the agricultural value of the south had dried up and the two parties were fighting as a result of racial tension only, the support from Washington and New York dried up. 

By 2022, 99% of the land south of the Mason-Dixon Line was depopulated. Most of the south was now a dumping ground for the vast amounts of waste from the cities (The United States was not as desperate as China, thankfully). In 2023, the Klan, secretly funded by Food, Inc (as they were unknowingly providing them with a fresh supply of corpses) and supported by the GAR, was finally defeated by the Panthers, supported by Canada and the USSR. The Governor of Mississippi demanded that the state lines be redrawn and that the government help rebuild the south. 

There was no response. 

Internal forces were not the only threat the United States faced, however. An old ally and their longest trading partner, Mexico, had become a resurgent enemy. Mexico was a polite term for the loose confederation of Cartels that had effectively ruled all of Central America since 2012. Millions were crossing the border into the United States in an attempt to escape to Canada. “Esclavitud o muerte”, the refugees' cries fell upon deaf ears. 

There was no debate, not even a consideration in Congress that they should be let in. The nation’s population was 500 million and climbing, with more than half of that being unemployed, uneducated, starving poor. Why would they let in yet more? It’s a good thing that the Alliance of Nations was too busy dealing with meaningless debate on birth control, or lest they might have even given the United States a slap on the wrist for the El Paso Massacre. The Soviet Union sent a scathing letter to Washington, but it was immediately recycled, and its ink scrubbed to be used to draft an internal memo about how Jarret was a god among men. 

On the night of May 2nd, 2013, a group of a quarter million starving Mexican refugees were hiding in the ruined cities of El Paso. El Paso had been declared “unsustainable” in 2007 and had long since been abandoned. Early in the morning, before the deadly heat of the sun had appeared in the sky, a group of 30,000 National Guardsmen appeared and sealed all entrances to the town. Those that woke up and tried to escape were shot. Some of the more violent members of the army lynched the immigrants, others simply watched as they desperately tried to escape the rising heat. There were even rumors of cannibalism and the mutilation of a Mexican child. Since the city was declared abandoned, excessive force was used, with the city being destroyed by explosives two days later. The National Guardsmen were never tried for their crimes. 

Yet, the Massacre did little to stem the tide of desperate people looking for somewhere, anywhere to go. Groups of Klan members, fleeing the Panthers, took to torturing, killing, and eventually eating the fleeing Mexicans. They became like vampires: hunting for blood only during the cool hours of the night, and hiding in damp, humid caves by day. And yet, still they came. The Klan even started selling the refugees back to the cartels, which in turn gave the Klan access to the powerful drug known as Bromista that they used to escape from the harsh, bleak reality of a world gripped by disease, hunger and heat. 

Other groups began to coalesce in the marginally more hospitable Northeast. While New England was one of the most hospitable parts of the nation left, its economy had been in greater shambles than most regions since the Red Decades. Manufacturing had largely moved overseas or to other parts of the country in prior decades, and the service industry was decimated by the wide scale poverty of its swollen population. Boston, by 2005 a city of over 4 million people, had its shipping industry destroyed by biblical floods, that now happened multiple times a year. By the 2020s the region, still heavily leaning democrat, had one of the leading unemployment rates in the country. As some voices in the senate quietly whispered about how New England was a burden, many in the region decided to relieve the nation of said burden. The largest group, calling themselves ‘The Pilgrims’ aimed to achieve succession, either for their own sakes, or to join Canada, where conditions were perceived as much better. The Pilgrims were largely apolitical, in the sense that they required no major affiliation to join. Neo-Nazis and radical communists worked alongside Jewish libertarians and Republicans. 


Boston police arresting suspected Pilgrims outside a University in Cambridge, 2016

The group’s aim since its founding in 2014 had been to make New England more trouble than it was worth to the federal government. Rail lines to New York (strangely one of the largest employers by this time) were cut, the last forests of the northern states were burned, making a scarce energy source and building material even more rare. By 2020, with the Pilgrims growing but still largely a disregarded fringe group, they moved to ‘Tarring and feathering’, a euphemism for assassination of politicians. Here they enjoyed some success, managing to wound a governor and kill a Massachusetts representative in that year alone. But the government had long been a plutocracy in all but name, the wealthy could easily find hired help in a place where people making minimum wage were murdered to free up their positions. By 2022 the Pilgrims were forced back underground, the military having stamped out much of their leadership, while New England politicians now never left their mansions and penthouses without a small army of security. The last effort from the place where American independence had been born to enact political change was fizzled out.

Part 2-1
A Fractured World: The Starving Tiger
Section 1: The Grand Tragedy of Chenism
Excerpt from “Icarus: The Chinese Twilight” by K. Nakamura-Belov, published by Samurai Press, New Tokyo, 919 ASJ

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZYIqOAtgomQ&t=2801s 
By 2023, China was barely a nation. 

The once lush, fertile plains in East China had been corrupted by Chairman Chen’s industrial revolution. Taiwan had been invaded, squeezed for all it was worth, and then left to eat itself. Mongolia was turned into the new heart of China after agriculture became impossible. Korea had morphed into one massive weapons factory. Indochina had been gutted and left to dry. And on top of it all, China was eating itself to death. 

How did China get this way? 

In 1971, a plot by Lin Biao and several other prominent members of the Chinese elite led to Mao Zedong to be successfully assassinated on September 11th, 1971. Officially, it was to save the Chinese people from the madness of the Cultural Revolution. While Lin originally was poised to take control of China, Chen Qiang, one of the conspirators, carefully outmaneuvered Lin Biao and became the new Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party. What exactly he said to get Lin to step down is unknown, but afterwards, Lin was notably quiet in all of his public appearances. 

Chen Qiang was a mysterious individual, with some believing that he held a prominent and lofty position in the Beiyang Government, but never joined the KMT. He remained sympathetic to the CCP, though in the 1960s he did something to get on the wrong side of Mao and was wiped from history. His true life from before the 1971 coup was relatively unknown, though records did survive confirming a desk clerk in Beijing was named Chen Qiang. 

According to his official autobiography, Chen Qiang was born on August 8, 1908. He was the oldest of a family of nine kids, with his parents being a hard working farmer and a dutiful midwife. Chen worked hard throughout his life, eventually becoming a well-known entertainer in Shanghai, before being captured by the Japanese in 1940. He survived by dancing for his captors, and telling them intricate stories to spare him from being the plaything of a sadistic officer. On February 6, 1945, he was liberated by a group of CCP guerillas, who were coincidentally under Lin Biao’s command. Even his official autobiography glossed over the years between 1945 and 1965, where he was imprisoned for “speaking out against the madness of Mao Zedong”. Lin Biao, who was looking for allies in his struggle against Mao, “overturned every stone” until he found his “heaven-sent ally”. 

To date, no evidence has been found to corroborate these claims. 

This new leader would oversee the creation of the single most important document in the 20th century: the Shanghai Accords. It was the Shanghai Accords, negotiated by Chairman Chen Qiang and President Richard Nixon, that granted the world 16 years of unprecedented opulence and decadence… as long as you weren’t being worked to death in a Chinese Superfactory. 

Chinese Superfactories were incredibly dangerous places. Industrial output was their only goal. Safety was an afterthought, if it even was a thought at all. This is partly why Chairman Chen advocated for families to have as many kids as possible: the mortality rate in a Chinese Superfactory ensured that over a third of all Chinese wouldn’t make it past the age of thirty. What’s a few hundred thousand deaths when families had at least ten kids? Such a morbid mindset required a radical shift in cultural thinking. 1973 is traced back to the year that Chairman Chen began to reinvent the Cultural Revolution to suit his own purposes. One scholar in London called it a “cultural devolution”, though the scholar was quickly removed from the institution so as to not risk the unprecedented opulence of the Shanghai Accords.

This new Cultural Revolution demanded that if China was to take her rightful place, her people must be willing to devote themselves entirely to furthering her goals, and only by making Chairman Chen proud could they do that. One such way was having lots of kids, for while each kid was one more mouth to feed, it was two more hands to work the fields, or two more hands to operate machinery, or two more hands to hold a gun. There were some that were, in Chen’s own words, “slow” to adapt, but the Red Guard quickly put a stop to this. Reports of factories being burned to the ground for not meeting production quotas was Soviet propaganda, after all!

China would eventually set up 31 “Special Industrial Zones”, or areas completely dedicated to industrial Megafactories without any consideration for the environment, living conditions or safety. Each SIZ had at least 31 Megafactories, with each Megafactory employing over 100,000 workers. These SIZs also had dedicated, if cheaply made, housing for the workers, along with places for food and cheap entertainment. Trade schools existed in some SIZs to train the children of workers to be the next generation of industrial servants. 

At first, the Chinese People welcomed these changes: Chairman Mao was soon rebranded as an Enemy of the People much like how Stalin was denounced during the Khrushchev thaw. All of the starvation and misery that took place during the 50s and 60s, and even some of the atrocities committed by Japan in WW2, were laid squarely at his feet. “The Chairman is dead, long live the Chairman!”, the people cried. 

This was Chairman Chen’s first step to modernizing China and getting it the respect it deserved. He needed to change its image: to make China not only the most powerful nation on earth, but the most invaluable. He needed to make China essential to everyday life for everyone on Earth. 

There are some who say he did this too well. 

After Chiang Kai-Shek’s head mysteriously exploded from a totally-not-CIA-sniper bullet, Chairman Chen spent an entire year trying to woo Taiwan back into union with the mainland. Taiwan, bitter that they had been removed from the UN and its Security Council, refused. None would openly protest this, however, as the Shanghai Accords prohibited any nation from even mentioning Taiwan, or else permanently lose their access to cheap, ludicrously affordable Chinese goods. 

And so, Chairman Chen turned his attention back towards China in an attempt to reverse the damage done by his predecessor. Mao had executed landlords by the millions, and now over 90% of the country was owned by the peasants. This was good in theory, he thought, however a vast majority of these peasants had no experience in land ownership and the responsibilities that came with it. By 1974, 90% of the country was once again under control of the State, which began auctioning off land to startups and foreign businesses, though Chinese state-owned businesses were always given priority. Of these new businesses, the most prominent would be 人们的食物, or “People’s Food”[1], an instant noodle company that gained a contract with the Chinese Government so that only their food would be served in the dingy canteens of every Megafactory. 

Chairman Chen, kept a few things from his predecessor, though - anti-intellectualism was one of them. Peasants were deliberately kept uneducated, with scarce access to books outside of technical manuals for the machinery in Megafactories. Literacy rates fell to 7.5% in 1985. 


Stylized poster of Chairman Chen safeguarding the “Second Revolution”, circa 1977

Chairman Chen saw himself as the “architect” of China, and the workers were the tools. Did the tools ever design for the architect? No, it was the other way around, and any “tool” that asked too many questions seemed to mysteriously die in a Liveleak-style industrial accident, be accused as a rightist, or dead in a “riot”, and that was if they were feeling generous. If a worker was being particularly troublesome, a Red Guard would send them to one of the not-so-secret labor camps where they would be worked to death, used as target practice for the Army, and if one report is to be believed, used for organ harvesting in the Black Market. China used this method to exterminate ethnic minorities, with the Uyghurs being wiped out by 1982 and the Tibetans wiped out by 1999 after their failed uprising. Subversives being worked to death for free labor is a concept that a certain American company would be inspired by, finally putting it into practice in the 2000s. 

From 1971-1974 those that were smart enough, such as industrial technicians or university professors, immigrated to the USSR. The USSR, disgusted at what China was becoming, offered lauded positions to Chinese workers who still believed in Mao, Lenin and Marx - as long as they were educated, that is. These escaped intellectuals described the modern hellscape of China, some even saying it was worse than it was under Mao, with children being worked to death in factories for a cup of noodles. A United Nations investigation in 1976 would find that this would be shockingly true: however, China was only let off with a fine and promised to “not do it again”. 

One singular man leading a country, no matter how smart he thinks he is, is never a good idea. Chen kept another policy from Mao: forcing farmers to become factory workers and letting their knowledge on crops go to waste. In 1975, there was a minor famine (minor as in only less than a million died) and Chen realized that more farmhands were required. So rather than send the farmers back to their fields, unemployed city residents were sent to the countryside to toil in the fields being slowly corrupted by pollution. These ineffectual peasants would always produce less each year, and despite some of them being executed for “sabotaging the People’s Harvest”, their replacements were always worse. If the intellectuals were still around, they might suggest that moving the original farmers back from the factories would be more efficient, or even removing the communal steel forges that were used by blacksmiths. 

For every policy of Mao that Chen kept, another would be reversed. The Third Front, a concept championed by Mao, believed that having all of China’s industrial capacity on its coast opened it up to invasion. This was counterproductive to Chen’s vision of China: factories farther from the sea meant more money spent on transportation, and thus higher prices. Who cares if a few million acres of land became permanently polluted - China could always import more food after all, the Shanghai Accords went both ways. Instead, Chairman Chen built over 1000 military bases along their coast, mainly concentrated in areas closer to Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan. This bloated China’s military to obscene levels, with China having over 50 million active personnel in 2000, not to mention the 150 million workers required to keep the bases functioning. This created jobs for the rapidly growing Chinese population, which had adapted to the deadly work in the Megafactories and dropped their mortality rate to only 4% a year. 

Who would invade China? Everyone, said Chen, for everyone shall be jealous of our prosperity. His experiences during the Cultural Revolution and with overthrowing Mao had made him a deeply paranoid man - he always thought that someone would overthrow him. The Communist Party had been repeatedly purged and thinned every year. Lin Biao, his second in command, had no real power and simply rubber stamped all of his policies. It is said that China had a different ambassador every year. These frequent purges are blamed on “Taiwanese Spies”, as that became the most frequent excuse used by the CCP. The sabotage of the Three Gorges Dam? Taiwanese Spies. A Megafactory destroyed in a bombing, killing over 50,000 people? Taiwanese Spies! Previously arable land yielding much less crops? Taiwanese spies, again. 

In the 80s, China’s mentality had shifted to one of complete reverence for Chairman Chen. Those who did not bow to him were shot. Citizens were taught from birth that they owed their entire lives to Chairman Chen, who had saved them from being slaves at the hand of Chairman Mao. That if they worked hard, they could escape the factories and at one point even run their own factory. All they had to do was swear complete and total allegiance to Chairman Chen, who had a portrait in every room by 1983. Soldiers even prayed to Chairman Chen before battle. All the reports of dangerous conditions in factories? Taiwanese propaganda, and anyone who suggested otherwise were agents of Taiwan. The United States was, is, and will always be our stalwart ally and trading partner. China has always been in a trade war with the USSR. 


Richard Nixon and Chen Qiang signing the Shanghai Accords, February 28th, 1972. This is the only surviving photograph of Chen Qiang, being taken by Nixon’s press staff, as in 2026 Chairman Liang Guowei ordered all images of him to be destroyed. 

The rest of the world, of course, was silently watching the deteriorating condition of China. Scientists were loudly shouting to anyone who would listen about the increasing carbon emissions coming from the Megafactories. One report from West Germany even said that at this rate, China’s land would be unable to produce food by 2005. Many would ignore these warnings though, especially those in power in the West. But what could they do? American manufacturing had been declining for decades now. The factories that armed the allies in both world wars had been rusting since 1954. The easiest option was to stay the course, so that is what they did.

The United States and China began a close relationship, comparable to the relationship the US had with the UK. It is said in his state-approved autobiography that Chairman Chen Qiang and President Richard Nixon became close friends. While the Chairman could not attend Nixon’s second inauguration in 1973, as he was busy trying to negotiate with Taiwan, he did attend the inauguration of Winston Morgan in 1976 and Franklin King in 1984. China’s special relationship with the United States was touted as a “communism to capitalism success story”, and the hope was that even the evil Soviet Union could become a major producer on the world stage. At the pressure of both the West and China, the USSR reluctantly started opening up factories for trade in Eastern Europe. 

In a term now called “dollar diplomacy”, Chairman Chen began trading programs to grow China’s image. In 1974, China championed the World Prosperity Alliance, a trading bloc that focused on “spreading capitalism with Chinese Characteristics to nations around the world”. Using tariffs and trade route taxations as leverage, China helped negotiate peace in several countries such as ending the Vietnam War in 1975. These programs caused the world economy to skyrocket. Even as an industrial slave in China, the average quality of life went up. Money that previously went to the subsidization of factories and other industries now went to researching advanced medicines and space travel. Indeed, China became the biggest economy in 1987 worth $4.73 trillion, surpassing the United States[2]. Throughout the 1980s, China led a program of international cooperation to build the first space station. Many nations contributed, such as the United States, the EU, Brazil, Australia, Canada, India, and even the USSR reluctantly participated. The 国际合作与友谊站, or “Station of International Cooperation and Friendship”, was launched on May 16, 1987, a day celebrated as the “day mankind rose up together and touched the stars”. 

But all good things must come to an end. 

By all rights, the world should have ended on that fateful day of June 9th, 1988. Overnight, humankind woke up from the hedonistic dream of Chairman Chen. International trade dried up as a billion barrels of oil burned. The Tokyo Stock Exchange supposedly was the site of a mass suicide of businessmen, while the New York Stock Exchange was closed early as stocks dropped more than 30% in two days. Shanghai faced even worse problems. 

It was said that Chairman Chen did not sleep for a week. His whole plan hinged on the world trading with China, and now, all but the wealthiest countries did not have the money or fuel to transport their goods. If something was not done soon, then his people would be out of a job. If they were out of a job, they would starve. And if they starved, they would revolt. He had seen the brutality of the Chinese Civil War, and the Cultural Revolution, and he knew that soon, he would be on the losing end of the next revolution. 

So Chen turned to his backup plan. While the rest of the world was reeling from the aftermath of the war and the Crash of 1989, China forcibly transitioned to a command economy. Citizens were subsidized by their government to buy their own products, which worked in the short term until they ran out of space. 4M paper was left dumped in alleyways, FulTec microwaves were piled on street corners, and SAPK drugs were popped like candy by workers. He kept telling his people that it was temporary, that true prosperity was just around the corner, that soon the world would be buying Chinese products again. 

A growing number of peasants and party members alike began to feel tricked by Chairman Chen. They had suffered so much in the name of making China a world power, and now after the sudden resurgence of protectionism around the globe, they were treated like a leper. China was desperate to keep its economy running and its people employed. 

In October 1989, in one last hail mary, Chairman Chen was forced to turn to his oldest enemy: the Soviet Union. Sending a shipment of rice in good faith, Chairman Chen pleaded with the Politburo to implement buying their goods into their planned economy. General Secretary Gennady Yanayev laughed in his face. ”You have doomed your people by turning away from Marx, Lenin, and Mao. Your greed is your death,” was all he said. From then on until the Great Death, China and the USSR were bitter enemies, with China increasingly envious of their northern neighbor. 

A normally quiet Lin Biao regaled a frazzled Chairman Chen about the lessons of the past. Back during WW2, both the communists and the nationalists united against a common enemy and endured much hardship for this cause. Chen, who took the story the wrong way, decided to galvanize the Chinese army and forcibly take back Hong Kong and Macau. Because Portugal and the UK were busy dealing with the fallout of the Crash, there were no negotiations. In fact, in Chen’s autobiography, it was said that the citizens of Hong Kong welcomed their Chinese liberators with open arms. The battles were far too easy for the gargantuan Chinese military, with each city falling within a week. Lin Biao was made Supreme Marshal of the People’s Liberation Army for his work in the invasion of two tiny city states. 

It was not enough though. China had been dependent on foreign food imports, mainly from Mongolia and Indochina, and with the Shanghai Accords being just pieces of paper, soon the government was paying exorbitant sums for basic foodstuffs. It was decided that China had no other choice but to forcibly take these countries under their wing. The continuous war of expansion distracted the people long enough and galvanized them against a common enemy. Mongolia was taken over in June 1991, then Laos in November 1991. 

In 1992, the final Olympic Games were held in Beijing. Chairman Chen was excited - he hoped that he would display Chinese glory to the world and countries would resume trading with him again. Many countries did not attend, some out of protest for the Chinese invasions the year prior and some could not afford to go. Some countries did not even exist anymore. Any hope of trading resuming dried up when it was discovered that China had skimped out on a lot of the necessary infrastructure. On top of that, a smog storm from a nearby Megafactory and polluted ground water caused almost 30,000 cancer cases, with nearly 4000 deaths. The humanitarian crisis was unprecedented, and cemented that China’s 15 years of fame had come and gone. 

Then the anti-Taiwan sentiment got out of hand. The crumbling world was far too distracted to intervene in the Third Taiwan Strait Crisis. There was lots of shouting in the UN Headquarters in New York, but no troops could be spared. Over 20 million died in the invasion of Taiwan, and the Red Army routinely pillaged, raped, and massacred any who resisted. Taiwan was followed by Cambodia and Thailand in 1994, then both Vietnams in 1995, and Myanmar in 1996. Lastly, Korea had been turned into a client state in 1997. 

But it was still not enough. 

Even with all the extra resources, labor and land, China was on the verge of collapse. In 1997, the fracturing Chinese economy almost completely caved in. The last of the middle class was wiped out. The Beijing Super Collider Explosion in 1996, and lack of international support, proved without a doubt that China was now an international pariah hurtling towards being a failed state. 90% of the world’s oil supply was gone and China’s economy was running on fumes. Several hundred million had died taking over Indochina, Taiwan and Mongolia, but they were replaced by new births by 2000. China’s economy would break under the pressure unless new material and trade was found. 

And China looked to an area of the world that was quickly turning to anarchy: Africa and South America. In exchange for low prices, China would help industrialize the fragmenting nation states of Africa. With most of its intellectuals having moved to the USSR 20 years ago however, these new industrial sites were grossly inefficient and led to many accidents which in turn polluted Africa even more. Another side effect was that rival factions would fight for control over the production sites, with Chinese workers caught in the crossfire. China began sending troops overseas, starting with just a few soldiers, then squads, then fully armored divisions. In 2007, when an entire fleet disappeared in the Indian Ocean on route to the Congo, that was when the CCP decided to finally pull the plug on The African Plan. The ruins of India were retaliated against of course, but after the Indian-Pakistani war of 2002, there was not much left to retaliate against. 

Things were getting dire. Chairman Chen had passed away from a heart attack in 2003 at age 94, and with his death, the CCP leadership went into free fall. Protests in 2004 against ration reductions were met with martial law and tanks in the streets. The People’s Republic of China went through 14 paramount leaders between 2003 and 2027, each more corrupt and paranoid than the last. The fourth Paramount Leader was very anti-Japan and blamed them for putting China through this 70 year long mess. The second Sino-Japanese war lasted from 2007 to 2010 and had no goal other than to reduce the population. That was the purpose of the war against India, afterall - in a nation of over 3 Billion, the CCP believed they had no choice other than rounding up civilians and executing them… and they were getting close to that point. They had tried other methods, such as implementing a One Child policy in 2006, and spiking the drinking water with a chemical that caused the rate of miscarriages to skyrocket, but it was not enough - there were just too many people. 


A common scene on fields during the Chinese Twilight. Due to the mass die off of animals, the local government has created fake “livestock” to desperately cling to the illusion that China was still full of life. 

It was the start of 2011, under the fifth Paramount Leader, that China would begin to see the true horrors of the world that Chairman Chen had helped to create. In mainland China, the once fertile rice paddies had turned into a giant wasteland of radioactive chemicals and putrid sewage. No vegetation grew at all, the last of it being eaten in 2006. Indochina and Mongolia were struggling to provide food for the billions of ethnic Hans. China had at one point considered invading the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia, but climate change had left them much the same way as India, so there was no point. 

This was when the Fifth Chairman, who was notoriously anti-Taiwan, tried one last ditch effort to save resources for his people: the recycling of human feces as food. In Taiwan exclusively, human waste was recycled and used to feed the starving Taiwanese. This new Siliao went about as well as you could expect it to go. At the very least, Taiwan’s cities didn’t smell like shit for a few months. But after the largest E. Coli outbreak in recorded history occurred in Taipei, the jig was up. 

The Sixth Chairman was left with no choice. 

There was one method that everyone had considered but never actually wanted to do. No one wanted a repeat of the Guangxi Massacre. One last final option, other than starvation. An option that would reserve the Sixth Chairman his own circle in Hell. The oceans were dying, 99% of all wildlife was extinct, vast swathes of the world had been destroyed by forest fires, drought and the Siberian Blight. The poor were literally starving to death on the streets. It was as he watched a scrawny rat eat its own children did he realize what had to be done. 

The Sixth Chairman drafted up Project 444 that day, signed it, and put a bullet in his brain, and on January 1st, 2012, the new Siliao would be distributed and thus would begin the darkest years of humanity’s history. 

Throughout 2012, the CCP leadership would go through a record number of suicides as the party leaders could not live with themselves. Everything they had done, from betraying Mao in 1971, becoming a capitalist puppet state in the 70s and 80s, invading their neighbors and committing war crimes in Taiwan, couping Chen… and all for what? What was the point of it all? What had they gained? The country was literally eating itself to stay alive. This wasn’t life. The forced miscarriages were a mercy at this point. 

The Seventh Chairman also killed himself upon learning what Siliao was truly made out of, and the Eighth Chairman, a veteran of the Vietnam War, saw the pain in his people. It was then when he authorized 正义仁慈计划, or “Project Righteous Mercy”, the development of a biological weapon that would turn his people sterile. He was killed in late 2013, and the Ninth Chairman said there was still hope. That if the glorious People’s Liberation Army was to liberate Australia, they could build the true China. 

Australia, however, had seen the impending climate catastrophe coming all the way back in the 60s, and had prepared themselves better than any other country. Their fleet, long since having switched to nuclear, saw the Chinese attack force from miles away. It is said that the entire PLA Navy fleet is still at the bottom of the ocean, 50 miles from Sydney, Australia. 

After the Ninth Chairman was killed in a coup, each one of his successors would try to galvanize the country to conquer another one, each one failing more and more horribly than the last. In 2015, for the first time ever, China had seen a net decrease in population. 2.9 Billion isn’t a whole lot less than 3 Billion but it was progress. 

When the Truth got out on May 26th, 2019, that Siliao was made from human remains, the population was so jaded, so numb, that most simply didn’t care. A few chose to kill themselves, a few even volunteered to feed their children, but most were so malnourished that they had given up long ago. The CCP quickly assured the population that it was only made out of criminals and counter-revolutionaries, as if that made it any less morbid.

In 2022, it was the 12th Chairman who decided that Project Righteous Mercy didn’t go far enough. The dead had been recycled and consumed so many times now that people were now dying from mineral deficiencies. The only mercy they could receive would be death. However, it must still be merciful, painless, without suffering, for this world had enough suffering as it was. 天堂之眼计划, or “Project Eyes of Heaven”, as it was called, was to be made with great care to ensure that the mass euthanasia would be as quiet and painless as possible. 

As of 2023, Project Eyes of Heaven is still under way. Of the many SIZ China built, only two SIZ are still operating and 23 Megafactories still functioning. And what are they making? China’s final attempt at keeping its national identity. With its fleet lying on the sea bed near Australia, China’s last, best attempt at staying a nation is the invasion of their northern neighbor. The USSR has been extremely hostile towards China, creating a militarized border wall in 2007 and shooting anyone who tried to cross, no questions asked, over a kilometer from the wall. It was only through the swarming of 2.5 billion desperate, starving Chinese could they maybe reclaim their national spirit. Full-on collapse is imminent: many of the surviving nations believe China is partly to blame for the collapse of civilization, for tempting the world with their devilishly cheap goods. Already, parts of the PLA have rebelled and started executing civilians for just existing, mainly in Taiwan. China must make one last desperate push north or risk total collapse. 

[1]  By 2023, People’s Food would own over a third of China’s land. Land that had long lost its agricultural value. 
[2]  The Democrats would use this as a talking point during their 1988 campaign.
