Section 2: The Red Army Marches

China expanded its sphere of influence throughout the 1970s and 1980s, and in the 1990s, invaded their neighbors. In the 2000s, pointless wars of attrition were fought for the sole purpose of getting soldiers killed and freeing up resources. 

Mongolia

Mongolia remained closely allied to the USSR. Because the USSR was very anti-Chen until the late 80s, this caused tension with China over its refusal to industrialize. In 1989, Batmönkh stayed in power due to the Crash, and then in 1990, Mongolia tried to formally join the USSR as a republic. The USSR seriously considers letting them join, however they ultimately side against it as they don’t want to risk a war with China at this point, as Soviet troops were withdrawn in 1990 to deal with an uprising in the Balkans. The Invasion is portrayed as bringing Inner Mongolia back into the fold of China. The USSR is against this idea, and while they cannot directly intervene to defend Mongolia in the invasion, they do give aid to the Mongolian rebels. Mongolian rebels are being trained by the USSR to distract and bog down the PLA. 


Two soldiers, one Soviet and one Mongolian, standing in front of an anti-Chinese propaganda poster. Taken sometime in the 1980s. 

Two SIZ are made in Mongolia in the 90s. As the climate warms up, several party leaders make “summer homes” in the cooler climate of Mongolia. As the years progress, they spend more and more time there. Eventually a city is built that is solely for high-ranking administrators, turning into the unofficial capital of China after the unimaginable pollution of Beijing and the explosion of the supercollider. This city is referred to as “New Beijing”. Political dissents are sent across the border where they are executed by Soviet snipers. After 2012, however, they are turned into Siliao. Of the areas China has conquered, Mongolia has the best land for agriculture, as it has a similar climate to Canada and Siberia. By 2023, most of the CCP are operating out of bunkers on the Chinese/Mongolia border. 

Thailand

Thailand is a bit more vengeful about the land it lost in 1946. The 1973 democracy movement succeeds, and is resolved peacefully due to Nixon negotiating it. The new democratic government sought to eliminate the problems plaguing pre-1973 Thailand, including rampant political corruption, curtailed freedoms and income inequality. A series of reforms are passed that incentivize social and economic change. These reforms did little to actually help the population, and instead they traded one corruption for another. Led by greed, politicians were known to be extremely corrupt and easily swayed by bribes. Something as simple as road construction would require at least one bribe in order to be done in an adequate quality. In the 80s Thailand was ruled by a small cadre of elite merchants and politicians who lived an extremely opulent lifestyle. Everytime the people demanded fairer wages, or better working conditions, or any kind of public service, the ruling class would accuse them of being communists and the activists in question would always disappear by totally-not-CIA operatives. 

During this time, the USSR covertly trained communist insurgents and supplied them with weapons. Then comes the Crash of 1988, and the population explodes in a violent revolt led by the Communists. In 1993, the Civil War ended with the Communists in power. They sign a pact of mutual defense with China after the Taiwan invasion, however China invades them a year later to “ensure the people are never betrayed again”. 

China built 2 SIZ in Thailand, both at politically unstable locations. These factories employ a large number of conveniently placed political prisoners. Throughout the Chinese occupation, Thai workers have demonstrated and rebelled on a similar level to the civil unrest in the USA. Notable uprisings have been suppressed in 1998, 2004, 2013 and 2019. By 2023, Thailand is another breadbasket to supply the dying China. The communists in power have more in common with the businessmen in the 70s and 80s than they’d like to admit. Much like the rest of Indochina, the humidity makes it very hard to work during the day and most farmers check their crops at night. 

Taiwan

Taiwan was extremely corrupt, with only fears of Mao and Chen to keep it together. So much so that the government is almost comically corrupt, to the point that people are executed on the street for being ”communist sympathizers”, when actually they didn’t sell someone a hot dog. After the PRC is recognized as the sole heir to China after the Shanghai Accords of 1972, Taiwan is ignored on the world stage until China formally invades them. Even then, most countries only send their condolences. Chiang Kai-Shek was assassinated by an agent of Chen in 1972, but it is never proven. Part of the Shanghai Accords also formally disbar any countries from investigating it. Martial Law was never lifted in 1987, as the KMT were suspicious of Chen’s administration. 

From 1972 to its invasion, Taiwan was an extremely paranoid police state that ruthlessly exploited its citizens. Chairman Chen is equally paranoid of Taiwan, which is why he is so harsh against its population.The worst mega-factories are built in Taiwan as a way to pollute and damage Taiwan’s environment to keep the Taiwanese weak and feeble. 5 SIZ are located here, with one of them designed to pollute the environment as efficiently as possible in a unique form of environmental warfare. 25% of the coal that China used until 2009 came from Taiwan, and rare luxury foods like sugar cane were grown until a fire destroyed most plantations in 2007. The PRC views Taiwanese as corrupted by Japan and subhuman, all the way until 2023. In 2023, with most of its resources extracted, China believes that Taiwan is more trouble than it’s worth and simply kills all of its residents to turn them into Siliao for the mainland. 

Cambodia

In the 1960s, Cambodia sided with South Vietnam in the Vietnam war. However, as the bloodthirsty US started bombing VietCong communists hiding in Cambodia and accidentally killing many Cambodians (Called the Blood Tide Massacre), they shifted more towards the communists. The Khmer Rouge was installed, however the Shanghai Accords secured their sovereignty. This meant that there could be no South Vietnam/US incursion into Cambodia. 

Due to the lucrative nature of the Shanghai Accords, the world turned a blind eye to the Cambodian Genocide. Many Cambodians were worked to death in intensive farming plantations to feed the laborers in the Chinese Megafactories. Cambodia didn't get invaded by Vietnam in 1978. Instead, North Vietnam pressures Pol Pot to be less evil against his workers. This led to a peaceful revolution that removed Pol Pot from power in 1979. The workers are treated a bit better (in the sense that dead workers can’t produce anything). 

Throughout the 80s, Cambodia went through a series of liberal reforms that granted its workers better working conditions, healthcare, and less hours, however they were still paid the same to keep the price of their products down. One SIZ is built here in the 80s. Full on peace and reconciliation efforts began in 1988 in Paris, however they were cut short by the Crash of 1988, and Cambodia descended into a civil war between the remnants of the Khmer Rouge and the pro-North Vietnam liberals. Later on, the exiled King and other factions join. As the civil war goes on, more and more land is destroyed. China played all sides, funding and training troops for both the Conservative and Liberal communists. Finally, in 1994, China invades Cambodia on the basis of “internal stability”. 

After China’s invasion, the remnants of the country are reformed into what is essentially a giant plantation, earning it the name “The Banana Republic of the East.” By 2023, Cambodia has been worked to the bone. Only very small amounts of food can be produced now, all of it extremely diseased. Humidity is so bad that people have to work during the night. 


Laos

In 1972, part of the Shanghai Accords, Laos was granted sovereignty from North Vietnam. Both sides of Laos would align with each other and in exchange, US Military forces were to leave it. In 1973-1976, a UN peacekeeping operation engaged in the de-armament of dropped US bombs. While the US withdrew from militarily aiding Laos, they would support them in other ways, such as a lucrative .95:.95 trade deal in textiles. This created a hopeful atmosphere and Suvannaphūmā did not die of a heart attack due to receiving a life-saving medical procedure in 1975. Because of this, however, the communist forces in Laos remain, just underground. They are secretly funded by the USSR. 

Lots of US companies come to Laos to run plantations. There are even reports of corporate espionage between US and China-based companies, using Laos as a battleground. Because of its proximity to other “communist” countries, Laos became a center for western missionary groups. Throughout the 80s there are a series of hostage crises as Christian Missionaries are captured by communist rebels. As Laos became richer, the wealth gap increased dramatically. By the late 80s, the communist forces gained more sympathy. 

After the Crash of 1988, the communist party launched another attack on the government, supported by the USSR, and later in 1990, China. Because the majority of the population were farmers, they managed to survive the initial crash relatively smoothly. But because of this, China invaded them in 1991. By 2023, Laos remains a glorified plantation for China, much like Cambodia, however the food they grow is much healthier due to the lack of ground pollution. Now if only the food didn’t rot in the humidity before reaching the peasantry in mainland China… 

Vietnam

The Vietnam War continued as normal until 1972 where a gradual detente would cause the war to end in 1975. South Korea and other South-East Asian nations send more troops, along with higher morale from US troops, causing the war to continue into a stalemate much like the Korean War instead of a total loss. A group of Maoist loyalists escaped to North Vietnam in 1973, which caused the US to renew and revitalize their war efforts. The Nixon administration claims it is the last remnant of “true communism” and is determined to stamp it out, afterwards they can worry about fixing the Soviet Union. 


Richard Nixon rallies US troops for a renewed defence of Hanoi, photographed 1974

This new system of Two Vietnams were both heavily supported by China, but only after the Maoist insurgency ended. China builds one SIZ in each Vietnam and then opens up a port deal. Vietnam is touted as a “communist to capitalist” success story by the USA and China, though in China they refer to it as “capitalism with Chinese characteristics”. Because of the enormous success of Chenism in Vietnam, many more SIZs are built in both Vietnams. North Vietnam ends up with 7, while South Vietnam ends up with 4. Throughout the 80s, the two Vietnams are referred to as Little China, and as they work together to utilize their industrial capacity, they enter negotiations to reunify. On April 4th, 1987, Vietnam formally reunited in a ceremony overseen by President King, Former President Nixon, and Chairman Chen. 

Because Vietnam was so closely modeled on China, they were hit particularly hard in 1988. Overnight, their industry dried up and was replaced by a lackluster agricultural system in the south. In 1989, a civil war began once again between the North and the South, except this time it was about the distribution of arable land. 

This was a wake up call to China, who saw their future in Vietnam if they didn’t keep their factories running and people employed. They would need resources, and that is where the plan to revitalize Africa came in. 

As the Civil War progressed, the hardcore Maoist faction re-emerged which caused Chairman Chen to launch an invasion. Vietnam then suffered much like Taiwan, turning into a police state, and the little arable land it had was exploited until the rising sea took over 90% of its land. By 2023, Vietnam is as thin as Chile and has no agricultural value to China. Its Venice-style port towns are used to ship crops from Indochina to the rest of China. 

Myanmar

In 1973, China began trying to suggest Myanmar implement Chenist reforms to their path to Burmese Socialism. Unlike a lot of the other countries in Indochina, they ended up resisting the lure of Chenism. This caused much of Myanmar’s history to go more or less uneventfully. The leader of Myanmar, known as the General, ruled Myanmar all the way up to 1990, where he was killed by a group of angry peasants who felt that he wasn’t going far enough to help them during the Red Decades. After this, the army took over Myanmar and ruled it with an iron first for 6 years, rigorously exploiting the land with intensive farming. Unlike the other countries in Indochina, the war with Myanmar wasn’t strictly about resources but about distracting their population from the starvation, poverty and industrial pollution that was starting to plague China. The fact that Myanmar had some agricultural value was simply a bonus. 

(North) Korea

North Korea remained just as isolated as it always was. After the 1971 Coup, they form closer ties to the USSR. This means that North Korea never became Chenist. After the Crash of 1988, and seeing how weak the US’s response to USSR’s invasions of Iran and Afganistan, Kim Il-Sung launched an invasion into South Korea. In 1992, after Kim Il-Sung’s death, his successor was much weaker, and because of that, the KPA led a coup on November 13th, 1997. This new dictatorship gets support from China in exchange for North Korea’s vast supplies of natural gas and coal. China set up environmentally devastating mining operations in the 90s to access these resources, tearing up huge amounts of the countryside for access to rare minerals and coal. This caused huge famines throughout the early 2000s, but despite this, North Korea is still barely capable of agriculture. In 2023, North Korea is the closest thing to China at the height of Chenism in 1987. Its industry remains fully functional, with the worst air pollution in the world as of January 1, 2024. Three SIZ are located here, and as of 2023, all fully functioning factories are located here. During the Great Death, North Korea is bombarded with nukes by the USSR - an ironic end considering how they chose their northern neighbor over their western one.

(South) Korea

South Korea is extremely anti-communist and anti-Japan. So anti-Japan, in fact, that placing tariffs on Japanese products were some of the first laws passed by the government after the Korean War, all the way back in 1953. South Korean police squads would regularly patrol the streets to execute suspected “communists” with the full support of J. Edgar Hoover and Joseph McCarthy. This rabid anti-communist mentality caused many more people to enlist in the army to fight in South Vietnam during the Vietnam War, contributing to the Vietnam Stalemate of 1972. Presidential elections have been rigged by the CIA since 1948. Because of this, there was no reform in 1960 and Rhee was kept as president until his death in 1971. Trade unions were also outlawed in 1964. South Korea’s first Five Year Economic Plan, based on massive amounts of exports to industrialize the nation, is actually what inspired Chairman Chen to have a similar plan, just on an absolutely colossal scale. Education and industrialization was encouraged, as it was thought that an educated worker could bring the country out of its agrarian age.  Because of its staunch anti-communist views, it received extra support from the US until 1972 when the US became very lax with China. This was seen as a massive betrayal by South Korea and was the start of their anti-US sentiment. In 1974, a large rebellion broke out as the populace no longer views the Communist world as a threat. Nixon heads to Seoul to help negotiate and reaches an agreement to help protect South Korea from the North, in exchange for 1:1 trade deals on everything. The CIA would also help keep the new President in power. Lots of the extremely environmentally damaging chemicals used in the mass production of consumer goods were developed in South Korea in the 1970s. 

South Korea opposed Chenism: at first. But like Japan, they would give in during the 1980s and would have many factories set up in China to produce their products. In fact, in mainland China, an entire SIZ is dedicated just to South Korean products. In the 1980s, after South Korea negotiated with China on the building of several megafactories, there were widespread protests as the Korean people had felt they had been betrayed by the government. This led to martial law being declared on December 12th, 1980. The rest of the government of South Korea, all coincidently shareholders of the biggest corporations of Korea, did not impeach the president for this sudden change of heart. They did not even reprimand him when he lifted tariffs on Japanese products and entered trade negotiations with them. In 1983, South Korea and North Korea entered talks about re-unifying, entering a short-lived trading agreement where the North would give the South coal and the South would give the North farming equipment. The Crash of 1988 renewed fears of communism and the talks ceased. 

After the Crash and the US withdrawing support, the government doubled down on their authoritarian regime. Tariffs on Japanese products were reintroduced. Due to the price of transportation, trade with China dried up, and the current administration enacted policies to try to rebuild South Korea’s industry. None of this would have any effect, as South Korea fell to civil war and invasion by the North later that year. After the Chinese annexation, South Korea is still ruled by vengeful North Koreans. It is the second worst place in China after Taiwan (which says a lot). South Korea has a lot of mineral resources, which China uses for the production of weaponry. About half of South Korea’s arable land is damaged by the pollution. Only one SIZ is built here. By 2023, most male South Koreans have been worked to death by their resentful North Korean masters. In China most concubines are South Korean. 

India

China’s war with India was the first war that was solely for causing its soldiers to die. India’s huge population caused it to fracture into civil war in the late 90s, which caused large parts of the country to descend into anarchy and warlordism. The parts of the country that remained under control by the government, mainly centered along the Ganges river and the coast, were at constant odds with Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Pakistan over fishing rights. Bangladesh was annexed by India in 1999, and Sri Lanka the year after. In 2001, the Pakistani Navy torpedoed a civilian Indian fishing boat and claimed that it was a spy vessel. This escalated into full-blown conventional war, with Pakistani troops burning wheat fields and killing cows. India’s dictator, driven over the edge at the news of his family being burned alive in his mansion, flipped the switch and nuked Pakistan. Pakistan nuked them back, and while India was able to destroy a vast majority of the nukes in the initial strikes, the river Ganges was permanently tainted with radioactive particles. 

After the disappearance of an entire fleet of Chinese vessels in 2007 (suspected to be a result of Indian pirates), China invaded India and removed the aging dictator from power. India was plunged into absolute anarchy after that, with a small series of independent communities lining the coast and clustered in Sri Lanka. As the pollution and radioactivity caused more and more land to become unusable, more and more cancer cases, and more and more deaths from radiation poisoning, there was almost nothing that remained. China plundered what little resources India had left, then began sending soldiers out on deliberate suicide missions into the radioactive wasteland of India, Pakistan, and Bangledesh. The Fourth Chairman came up with the idea of using the remaining city-states as target practice for military exercises, and the survivors of the Indian-Pakistani war were routinely subject to war crimes that would make the Taiwanese jealous. 

In 2014, an unexpected fleet arrived: the US military, waving the Food, Inc flag. The Food, Inc, looking for materials to keep their factories running, had come to pick over the radioactive slag heap that was once India. They made a lucrative deal with the Indians: precious metals in exchange for their new revolutionary product. The higher ups of Food, Inc had long suspected what the true ingredient of Siliao was, and always looking to cut costs, had decided to test out the efficiency of using recycled human corpses as a filler. And India was where Ration Omega was originally tested. China had considered engaging in war with Food, Inc, as it would be a surefire way to get rid of a couple million surplus Chinese, however there was no telling if the USA still had functional nuclear weapons. A nuclear war would for sure reduce the population significantly, but this was still seen as too extreme at this point. The 10th Chairman felt that China could still survive if she held on just a little longer. 

Japan

The war with Japan was officially about fishing rights. Some in the PLA had even claimed it was revenge for WW2. Under the Fourth Chairman, China sent waves after waves of Chinese soldiers across the sea to die in the Japanese Islands. Japan was a very stubborn country - they were starving, but very slowly and politely. Many elders had voluntarily followed the Emperor’s example and had committed mass suicide in 2006 to free up resources for the younger generations, however with this sacrifice came a massive loss of knowledge. Japan was falling apart at the seams, with industrial accidents happening before the overworked and under-educated Steward Society could stop them. And this was on top of the almost incomprehensible pollution that occurred before the Crash of 1988: over a half of people under 25 had lost eyesight in one or both of their eyes from cataracts forming. 

But again, Japan was stubborn. Wave after wave of Chinese invaders crashed upon their shores, and many sacrificed themselves for the good of their countrymen. Japan had been slow to re-arm itself, so many defenders were left to fight hand-to-hand or with WW2-era officer swords. Japan developed a special martial art for fighting in the trenches: Tōtoki unagi no michi, or “The Way of the Honorable Eel”. These soldiers were treated with the utmost reverence by their fellow citizens, and were given special privileges regarding their calorie rations. As Japan began rearming itself, however, the Chinese began being pushed further back until finally being pushed out of the home islands by 2009. Throughout 2010, Chinese warships only managed to make three landings, the rest of the vessels were sunk at sea. In 2011, after Japan was hit by a devastating earthquake that ruined much of the fragile metropolitan landscape, the CCP considered a proper invasion, however that would defeat the entire purpose of the phoney war: to reduce China’s population and maintain their economy making war material. 

Australia

Australia was uniquely prepared for the gradual end of civilization. While other countries like Iceland, New Zealand, Canada, the Nordic Union and the USSR were hit the softest because of their low populations, small population densities and cool climates, Australia had been dealing with wildfires, droughts and desertification long before it was impacting the rest of the world. Australia had always been regarded as “that funny land down under”, as they were reluctant to trade with China after the advent of Chenism. They were also the only country to legalize birth control on a massive scale in 1975, and also the only major country to outlaw Chlorofluorocarbons during the 80s. After extensive research into the causes of the Three Mile Island disaster, they were also the only country to not outright ban nuclear power. 

When the Crash of 1988 came around, Australia was unfazed, aside from completely banning immigration. 

Throughout the Red Decades, Australia had developed a healthy trading relationship with New Zealand, and thus only suffered from a permanent recession rather than a full on depression. The government enacted a policy of completely abandoning the countryside for complete urbanization, much like the USA, however Australia did it in a much more deliberate and controlled manner. Internal migrants would only be allowed into the cities if there was space for them. As more and more citizens were displaced, massive 40-story tall apartment buildings, colloquially known as “Hawke-Blocs[1]”, were built. 

Years of wildfire and drought had forced Australian cities to have uniquely open and spacious designs using fire-retardant materials to reduce the risk of fires. They weren’t foolproof, however - Darwin was completely burnt to a crisp during the Great Fire of 2005. Irrigation was also integrated into cities to create “districts” from which water could be drawn from to create barriers against active fires. People’s lawns were turned into community gardens much like the wartime victory gardens of WW2. And slowly, wind and solar power was implemented into the cities. 


An Australian Hawke-Class Nuclear Dreadnaught being repaired and refueled at a Sydney drydock. Photo taken in 2014, immediately after the sinking of the PLA fleet.

As more and more of the Outback was overtaken by climate change, more and more citizens were internally displaced and by 2010, much of the country was abandoned. Australia had been concentrated into 15 “mega cities”, each one with about 3 million citizens. With so much of the population in such a small area, the government was worried they might be vulnerable to attack. The Australian Navy was one of the most efficient in the world (second only to the USSR’s), having adopted nuclear engines around the early 1990s. While initially small, they escorted merchant vessels to and from Perth and New Zealand. After a hostage situation of an Australian merchant in 2003 off the coast of Wellington, however, both the New Zealand and Australian governments adopted a “shoot first, ask questions later” policy. In 2010, the Australian Navy was massively increased and began routine patrols around the coast of Australia, with New Zealand following suit in 2011. 

It was then no surprise when the entire Chinese Navy was sunken off the coast of Sydney on April 4th, 2014. Both Australia and New Zealand’s militaries had been on high alert due to the increasing number of refugees fleeing from the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia. New Zealand’s Navy had been patrolling on the opposite side of New Zealand at the time, so Australia was alone. It was not a problem, however - the fleet of 150 dreadnaughts, staffed by 15,000 well-fed, well-educated and well-disciplined Australian sailors decimated the entire PLA Navy over the course of four hours. By the time that New Zealand reinforcements arrived, the battle was already over. 13 ships were lost on the Australian side, and it is because of that number that the Australians fought with such ferocity. There was no more room on the ship, so to speak, and Australia had long kept a policy of taking no prisoners. 

China

And so, with no options left, China turned inwards on itself. 

China had been struggling for almost two decades to keep its people fed and factories running, lest they risk total revolt, and that is exactly what ended up happening. In 2019, a factory in occupied Myanmar was burned down in an open declaration of war from the long-thought dead Maoist faction of the CCP. This was followed by waves of starving farmers taking up arms in Indochina and burning crop fields. 

The PLA, fractured and humiliated, was called in to regain order. However, more than half of the soldiers ended up defecting and joining the rebel faction. As the Maoist anarchy spread through Southeastern Asia, the terrible truth was revealed: Siliao was PEOPLE!!!!!!!! 

It took a while for the world to spread, but soon entire army divisions rose up in open rebellion. They were the only people in China who were properly fed, and thus had the energy to actually rebel. Even then, the rebel factions were outnumbered almost 5 to 1, and after a few weeks, the CCP was once again under control of the country. A statement was made that Siliao was only made from the flesh of subversives, that no hard working son of Chen was being recycled, but at this point, no one cared. 

[1] Named after the Prime Minister of Australia from 1983-1997, Bob Hawke.
Part 2-1
A Fractured World: The Starving Tiger
Section 1: The Grand Tragedy of Chenism
Excerpt from “Icarus: The Chinese Twilight” by K. Nakamura-Belov, published by Samurai Press, New Tokyo, 919 ASJ

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZYIqOAtgomQ&t=2801s 
By 2023, China was barely a nation. 

The once lush, fertile plains in East China had been corrupted by Chairman Chen’s industrial revolution. Taiwan had been invaded, squeezed for all it was worth, and then left to eat itself. Mongolia was turned into the new heart of China after agriculture became impossible. Korea had morphed into one massive weapons factory. Indochina had been gutted and left to dry. And on top of it all, China was eating itself to death. 

How did China get this way? 

In 1971, a plot by Lin Biao and several other prominent members of the Chinese elite led to Mao Zedong to be successfully assassinated on September 11th, 1971. Officially, it was to save the Chinese people from the madness of the Cultural Revolution. While Lin originally was poised to take control of China, Chen Qiang, one of the conspirators, carefully outmaneuvered Lin Biao and became the new Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party. What exactly he said to get Lin to step down is unknown, but afterwards, Lin was notably quiet in all of his public appearances. 

Chen Qiang was a mysterious individual, with some believing that he held a prominent and lofty position in the Beiyang Government, but never joined the KMT. He remained sympathetic to the CCP, though in the 1960s he did something to get on the wrong side of Mao and was wiped from history. His true life from before the 1971 coup was relatively unknown, though records did survive confirming a desk clerk in Beijing was named Chen Qiang. 

According to his official autobiography, Chen Qiang was born on August 8, 1908. He was the oldest of a family of nine kids, with his parents being a hard working farmer and a dutiful midwife. Chen worked hard throughout his life, eventually becoming a well-known entertainer in Shanghai, before being captured by the Japanese in 1940. He survived by dancing for his captors, and telling them intricate stories to spare him from being the plaything of a sadistic officer. On February 6, 1945, he was liberated by a group of CCP guerillas, who were coincidentally under Lin Biao’s command. Even his official autobiography glossed over the years between 1945 and 1965, where he was imprisoned for “speaking out against the madness of Mao Zedong”. Lin Biao, who was looking for allies in his struggle against Mao, “overturned every stone” until he found his “heaven-sent ally”. 

To date, no evidence has been found to corroborate these claims. 

This new leader would oversee the creation of the single most important document in the 20th century: the Shanghai Accords. It was the Shanghai Accords, negotiated by Chairman Chen Qiang and President Richard Nixon, that granted the world 16 years of unprecedented opulence and decadence… as long as you weren’t being worked to death in a Chinese Superfactory. 

Chinese Superfactories were incredibly dangerous places. Industrial output was their only goal. Safety was an afterthought, if it even was a thought at all. This is partly why Chairman Chen advocated for families to have as many kids as possible: the mortality rate in a Chinese Superfactory ensured that over a third of all Chinese wouldn’t make it past the age of thirty. What’s a few hundred thousand deaths when families had at least ten kids? Such a morbid mindset required a radical shift in cultural thinking. 1973 is traced back to the year that Chairman Chen began to reinvent the Cultural Revolution to suit his own purposes. One scholar in London called it a “cultural devolution”, though the scholar was quickly removed from the institution so as to not risk the unprecedented opulence of the Shanghai Accords.

This new Cultural Revolution demanded that if China was to take her rightful place, her people must be willing to devote themselves entirely to furthering her goals, and only by making Chairman Chen proud could they do that. One such way was having lots of kids, for while each kid was one more mouth to feed, it was two more hands to work the fields, or two more hands to operate machinery, or two more hands to hold a gun. There were some that were, in Chen’s own words, “slow” to adapt, but the Red Guard quickly put a stop to this. Reports of factories being burned to the ground for not meeting production quotas was Soviet propaganda, after all!

China would eventually set up 31 “Special Industrial Zones”, or areas completely dedicated to industrial Megafactories without any consideration for the environment, living conditions or safety. Each SIZ had at least 31 Megafactories, with each Megafactory employing over 100,000 workers. These SIZs also had dedicated, if cheaply made, housing for the workers, along with places for food and cheap entertainment. Trade schools existed in some SIZs to train the children of workers to be the next generation of industrial servants. 

At first, the Chinese People welcomed these changes: Chairman Mao was soon rebranded as an Enemy of the People much like how Stalin was denounced during the Khrushchev thaw. All of the starvation and misery that took place during the 50s and 60s, and even some of the atrocities committed by Japan in WW2, were laid squarely at his feet. “The Chairman is dead, long live the Chairman!”, the people cried. 

This was Chairman Chen’s first step to modernizing China and getting it the respect it deserved. He needed to change its image: to make China not only the most powerful nation on earth, but the most invaluable. He needed to make China essential to everyday life for everyone on Earth. 

There are some who say he did this too well. 

After Chiang Kai-Shek’s head mysteriously exploded from a totally-not-CIA-sniper bullet, Chairman Chen spent an entire year trying to woo Taiwan back into union with the mainland. Taiwan, bitter that they had been removed from the UN and its Security Council, refused. None would openly protest this, however, as the Shanghai Accords prohibited any nation from even mentioning Taiwan, or else permanently lose their access to cheap, ludicrously affordable Chinese goods. 

And so, Chairman Chen turned his attention back towards China in an attempt to reverse the damage done by his predecessor. Mao had executed landlords by the millions, and now over 90% of the country was owned by the peasants. This was good in theory, he thought, however a vast majority of these peasants had no experience in land ownership and the responsibilities that came with it. By 1974, 90% of the country was once again under control of the State, which began auctioning off land to startups and foreign businesses, though Chinese state-owned businesses were always given priority. Of these new businesses, the most prominent would be 人们的食物, or “People’s Food”[1], an instant noodle company that gained a contract with the Chinese Government so that only their food would be served in the dingy canteens of every Megafactory. 

Chairman Chen, kept a few things from his predecessor, though - anti-intellectualism was one of them. Peasants were deliberately kept uneducated, with scarce access to books outside of technical manuals for the machinery in Megafactories. Literacy rates fell to 7.5% in 1985. 


Stylized poster of Chairman Chen safeguarding the “Second Revolution”, circa 1977

Chairman Chen saw himself as the “architect” of China, and the workers were the tools. Did the tools ever design for the architect? No, it was the other way around, and any “tool” that asked too many questions seemed to mysteriously die in a Liveleak-style industrial accident, be accused as a rightist, or dead in a “riot”, and that was if they were feeling generous. If a worker was being particularly troublesome, a Red Guard would send them to one of the not-so-secret labor camps where they would be worked to death, used as target practice for the Army, and if one report is to be believed, used for organ harvesting in the Black Market. China used this method to exterminate ethnic minorities, with the Uyghurs being wiped out by 1982 and the Tibetans wiped out by 1999 after their failed uprising. Subversives being worked to death for free labor is a concept that a certain American company would be inspired by, finally putting it into practice in the 2000s. 

From 1971-1974 those that were smart enough, such as industrial technicians or university professors, immigrated to the USSR. The USSR, disgusted at what China was becoming, offered lauded positions to Chinese workers who still believed in Mao, Lenin and Marx - as long as they were educated, that is. These escaped intellectuals described the modern hellscape of China, some even saying it was worse than it was under Mao, with children being worked to death in factories for a cup of noodles. A United Nations investigation in 1976 would find that this would be shockingly true: however, China was only let off with a fine and promised to “not do it again”. 

One singular man leading a country, no matter how smart he thinks he is, is never a good idea. Chen kept another policy from Mao: forcing farmers to become factory workers and letting their knowledge on crops go to waste. In 1975, there was a minor famine (minor as in only less than a million died) and Chen realized that more farmhands were required. So rather than send the farmers back to their fields, unemployed city residents were sent to the countryside to toil in the fields being slowly corrupted by pollution. These ineffectual peasants would always produce less each year, and despite some of them being executed for “sabotaging the People’s Harvest”, their replacements were always worse. If the intellectuals were still around, they might suggest that moving the original farmers back from the factories would be more efficient, or even removing the communal steel forges that were used by blacksmiths. 

For every policy of Mao that Chen kept, another would be reversed. The Third Front, a concept championed by Mao, believed that having all of China’s industrial capacity on its coast opened it up to invasion. This was counterproductive to Chen’s vision of China: factories farther from the sea meant more money spent on transportation, and thus higher prices. Who cares if a few million acres of land became permanently polluted - China could always import more food after all, the Shanghai Accords went both ways. Instead, Chairman Chen built over 1000 military bases along their coast, mainly concentrated in areas closer to Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan. This bloated China’s military to obscene levels, with China having over 50 million active personnel in 2000, not to mention the 150 million workers required to keep the bases functioning. This created jobs for the rapidly growing Chinese population, which had adapted to the deadly work in the Megafactories and dropped their mortality rate to only 4% a year. 

Who would invade China? Everyone, said Chen, for everyone shall be jealous of our prosperity. His experiences during the Cultural Revolution and with overthrowing Mao had made him a deeply paranoid man - he always thought that someone would overthrow him. The Communist Party had been repeatedly purged and thinned every year. Lin Biao, his second in command, had no real power and simply rubber stamped all of his policies. It is said that China had a different ambassador every year. These frequent purges are blamed on “Taiwanese Spies”, as that became the most frequent excuse used by the CCP. The sabotage of the Three Gorges Dam? Taiwanese Spies. A Megafactory destroyed in a bombing, killing over 50,000 people? Taiwanese Spies! Previously arable land yielding much less crops? Taiwanese spies, again. 

In the 80s, China’s mentality had shifted to one of complete reverence for Chairman Chen. Those who did not bow to him were shot. Citizens were taught from birth that they owed their entire lives to Chairman Chen, who had saved them from being slaves at the hand of Chairman Mao. That if they worked hard, they could escape the factories and at one point even run their own factory. All they had to do was swear complete and total allegiance to Chairman Chen, who had a portrait in every room by 1983. Soldiers even prayed to Chairman Chen before battle. All the reports of dangerous conditions in factories? Taiwanese propaganda, and anyone who suggested otherwise were agents of Taiwan. The United States was, is, and will always be our stalwart ally and trading partner. China has always been in a trade war with the USSR. 


Richard Nixon and Chen Qiang signing the Shanghai Accords, February 28th, 1972. This is the only surviving photograph of Chen Qiang, being taken by Nixon’s press staff, as in 2026 Chairman Liang Guowei ordered all images of him to be destroyed. 

The rest of the world, of course, was silently watching the deteriorating condition of China. Scientists were loudly shouting to anyone who would listen about the increasing carbon emissions coming from the Megafactories. One report from West Germany even said that at this rate, China’s land would be unable to produce food by 2005. Many would ignore these warnings though, especially those in power in the West. But what could they do? American manufacturing had been declining for decades now. The factories that armed the allies in both world wars had been rusting since 1954. The easiest option was to stay the course, so that is what they did.

The United States and China began a close relationship, comparable to the relationship the US had with the UK. It is said in his state-approved autobiography that Chairman Chen Qiang and President Richard Nixon became close friends. While the Chairman could not attend Nixon’s second inauguration in 1973, as he was busy trying to negotiate with Taiwan, he did attend the inauguration of Winston Morgan in 1976 and Franklin King in 1984. China’s special relationship with the United States was touted as a “communism to capitalism success story”, and the hope was that even the evil Soviet Union could become a major producer on the world stage. At the pressure of both the West and China, the USSR reluctantly started opening up factories for trade in Eastern Europe. 

In a term now called “dollar diplomacy”, Chairman Chen began trading programs to grow China’s image. In 1974, China championed the World Prosperity Alliance, a trading bloc that focused on “spreading capitalism with Chinese Characteristics to nations around the world”. Using tariffs and trade route taxations as leverage, China helped negotiate peace in several countries such as ending the Vietnam War in 1975. These programs caused the world economy to skyrocket. Even as an industrial slave in China, the average quality of life went up. Money that previously went to the subsidization of factories and other industries now went to researching advanced medicines and space travel. Indeed, China became the biggest economy in 1987 worth $4.73 trillion, surpassing the United States[2]. Throughout the 1980s, China led a program of international cooperation to build the first space station. Many nations contributed, such as the United States, the EU, Brazil, Australia, Canada, India, and even the USSR reluctantly participated. The 国际合作与友谊站, or “Station of International Cooperation and Friendship”, was launched on May 16, 1987, a day celebrated as the “day mankind rose up together and touched the stars”. 

But all good things must come to an end. 

By all rights, the world should have ended on that fateful day of June 9th, 1988. Overnight, humankind woke up from the hedonistic dream of Chairman Chen. International trade dried up as a billion barrels of oil burned. The Tokyo Stock Exchange supposedly was the site of a mass suicide of businessmen, while the New York Stock Exchange was closed early as stocks dropped more than 30% in two days. Shanghai faced even worse problems. 

It was said that Chairman Chen did not sleep for a week. His whole plan hinged on the world trading with China, and now, all but the wealthiest countries did not have the money or fuel to transport their goods. If something was not done soon, then his people would be out of a job. If they were out of a job, they would starve. And if they starved, they would revolt. He had seen the brutality of the Chinese Civil War, and the Cultural Revolution, and he knew that soon, he would be on the losing end of the next revolution. 

So Chen turned to his backup plan. While the rest of the world was reeling from the aftermath of the war and the Crash of 1989, China forcibly transitioned to a command economy. Citizens were subsidized by their government to buy their own products, which worked in the short term until they ran out of space. 4M paper was left dumped in alleyways, FulTec microwaves were piled on street corners, and SAPK drugs were popped like candy by workers. He kept telling his people that it was temporary, that true prosperity was just around the corner, that soon the world would be buying Chinese products again. 

A growing number of peasants and party members alike began to feel tricked by Chairman Chen. They had suffered so much in the name of making China a world power, and now after the sudden resurgence of protectionism around the globe, they were treated like a leper. China was desperate to keep its economy running and its people employed. 

In October 1989, in one last hail mary, Chairman Chen was forced to turn to his oldest enemy: the Soviet Union. Sending a shipment of rice in good faith, Chairman Chen pleaded with the Politburo to implement buying their goods into their planned economy. General Secretary Gennady Yanayev laughed in his face. ”You have doomed your people by turning away from Marx, Lenin, and Mao. Your greed is your death,” was all he said. From then on until the Great Death, China and the USSR were bitter enemies, with China increasingly envious of their northern neighbor. 

A normally quiet Lin Biao regaled a frazzled Chairman Chen about the lessons of the past. Back during WW2, both the communists and the nationalists united against a common enemy and endured much hardship for this cause. Chen, who took the story the wrong way, decided to galvanize the Chinese army and forcibly take back Hong Kong and Macau. Because Portugal and the UK were busy dealing with the fallout of the Crash, there were no negotiations. In fact, in Chen’s autobiography, it was said that the citizens of Hong Kong welcomed their Chinese liberators with open arms. The battles were far too easy for the gargantuan Chinese military, with each city falling within a week. Lin Biao was made Supreme Marshal of the People’s Liberation Army for his work in the invasion of two tiny city states. 

It was not enough though. China had been dependent on foreign food imports, mainly from Mongolia and Indochina, and with the Shanghai Accords being just pieces of paper, soon the government was paying exorbitant sums for basic foodstuffs. It was decided that China had no other choice but to forcibly take these countries under their wing. The continuous war of expansion distracted the people long enough and galvanized them against a common enemy. Mongolia was taken over in June 1991, then Laos in November 1991. 

In 1992, the final Olympic Games were held in Beijing. Chairman Chen was excited - he hoped that he would display Chinese glory to the world and countries would resume trading with him again. Many countries did not attend, some out of protest for the Chinese invasions the year prior and some could not afford to go. Some countries did not even exist anymore. Any hope of trading resuming dried up when it was discovered that China had skimped out on a lot of the necessary infrastructure. On top of that, a smog storm from a nearby Megafactory and polluted ground water caused almost 30,000 cancer cases, with nearly 4000 deaths. The humanitarian crisis was unprecedented, and cemented that China’s 15 years of fame had come and gone. 

Then the anti-Taiwan sentiment got out of hand. The crumbling world was far too distracted to intervene in the Third Taiwan Strait Crisis. There was lots of shouting in the UN Headquarters in New York, but no troops could be spared. Over 20 million died in the invasion of Taiwan, and the Red Army routinely pillaged, raped, and massacred any who resisted. Taiwan was followed by Cambodia and Thailand in 1994, then both Vietnams in 1995, and Myanmar in 1996. Lastly, Korea had been turned into a client state in 1997. 

But it was still not enough. 

Even with all the extra resources, labor and land, China was on the verge of collapse. In 1997, the fracturing Chinese economy almost completely caved in. The last of the middle class was wiped out. The Beijing Super Collider Explosion in 1996, and lack of international support, proved without a doubt that China was now an international pariah hurtling towards being a failed state. 90% of the world’s oil supply was gone and China’s economy was running on fumes. Several hundred million had died taking over Indochina, Taiwan and Mongolia, but they were replaced by new births by 2000. China’s economy would break under the pressure unless new material and trade was found. 

And China looked to an area of the world that was quickly turning to anarchy: Africa and South America. In exchange for low prices, China would help industrialize the fragmenting nation states of Africa. With most of its intellectuals having moved to the USSR 20 years ago however, these new industrial sites were grossly inefficient and led to many accidents which in turn polluted Africa even more. Another side effect was that rival factions would fight for control over the production sites, with Chinese workers caught in the crossfire. China began sending troops overseas, starting with just a few soldiers, then squads, then fully armored divisions. In 2007, when an entire fleet disappeared in the Indian Ocean on route to the Congo, that was when the CCP decided to finally pull the plug on The African Plan. The ruins of India were retaliated against of course, but after the Indian-Pakistani war of 2002, there was not much left to retaliate against. 

Things were getting dire. Chairman Chen had passed away from a heart attack in 2003 at age 94, and with his death, the CCP leadership went into free fall. Protests in 2004 against ration reductions were met with martial law and tanks in the streets. The People’s Republic of China went through 14 paramount leaders between 2003 and 2027, each more corrupt and paranoid than the last. The fourth Paramount Leader was very anti-Japan and blamed them for putting China through this 70 year long mess. The second Sino-Japanese war lasted from 2007 to 2010 and had no goal other than to reduce the population. That was the purpose of the war against India, afterall - in a nation of over 3 Billion, the CCP believed they had no choice other than rounding up civilians and executing them… and they were getting close to that point. They had tried other methods, such as implementing a One Child policy in 2006, and spiking the drinking water with a chemical that caused the rate of miscarriages to skyrocket, but it was not enough - there were just too many people. 


A common scene on fields during the Chinese Twilight. Due to the mass die off of animals, the local government has created fake “livestock” to desperately cling to the illusion that China was still full of life. 

It was the start of 2011, under the fifth Paramount Leader, that China would begin to see the true horrors of the world that Chairman Chen had helped to create. In mainland China, the once fertile rice paddies had turned into a giant wasteland of radioactive chemicals and putrid sewage. No vegetation grew at all, the last of it being eaten in 2006. Indochina and Mongolia were struggling to provide food for the billions of ethnic Hans. China had at one point considered invading the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia, but climate change had left them much the same way as India, so there was no point. 

This was when the Fifth Chairman, who was notoriously anti-Taiwan, tried one last ditch effort to save resources for his people: the recycling of human feces as food. In Taiwan exclusively, human waste was recycled and used to feed the starving Taiwanese. This new Siliao went about as well as you could expect it to go. At the very least, Taiwan’s cities didn’t smell like shit for a few months. But after the largest E. Coli outbreak in recorded history occurred in Taipei, the jig was up. 

The Sixth Chairman was left with no choice. 

There was one method that everyone had considered but never actually wanted to do. No one wanted a repeat of the Guangxi Massacre. One last final option, other than starvation. An option that would reserve the Sixth Chairman his own circle in Hell. The oceans were dying, 99% of all wildlife was extinct, vast swathes of the world had been destroyed by forest fires, drought and the Siberian Blight. The poor were literally starving to death on the streets. It was as he watched a scrawny rat eat its own children did he realize what had to be done. 

The Sixth Chairman drafted up Project 444 that day, signed it, and put a bullet in his brain, and on January 1st, 2012, the new Siliao would be distributed and thus would begin the darkest years of humanity’s history. 

Throughout 2012, the CCP leadership would go through a record number of suicides as the party leaders could not live with themselves. Everything they had done, from betraying Mao in 1971, becoming a capitalist puppet state in the 70s and 80s, invading their neighbors and committing war crimes in Taiwan, couping Chen… and all for what? What was the point of it all? What had they gained? The country was literally eating itself to stay alive. This wasn’t life. The forced miscarriages were a mercy at this point. 

The Seventh Chairman also killed himself upon learning what Siliao was truly made out of, and the Eighth Chairman, a veteran of the Vietnam War, saw the pain in his people. It was then when he authorized 正义仁慈计划, or “Project Righteous Mercy”, the development of a biological weapon that would turn his people sterile. He was killed in late 2013, and the Ninth Chairman said there was still hope. That if the glorious People’s Liberation Army was to liberate Australia, they could build the true China. 

Australia, however, had seen the impending climate catastrophe coming all the way back in the 60s, and had prepared themselves better than any other country. Their fleet, long since having switched to nuclear, saw the Chinese attack force from miles away. It is said that the entire PLA Navy fleet is still at the bottom of the ocean, 50 miles from Sydney, Australia. 

After the Ninth Chairman was killed in a coup, each one of his successors would try to galvanize the country to conquer another one, each one failing more and more horribly than the last. In 2015, for the first time ever, China had seen a net decrease in population. 2.9 Billion isn’t a whole lot less than 3 Billion but it was progress. 

When the Truth got out on May 26th, 2019, that Siliao was made from human remains, the population was so jaded, so numb, that most simply didn’t care. A few chose to kill themselves, a few even volunteered to feed their children, but most were so malnourished that they had given up long ago. The CCP quickly assured the population that it was only made out of criminals and counter-revolutionaries, as if that made it any less morbid.

In 2022, it was the 12th Chairman who decided that Project Righteous Mercy didn’t go far enough. The dead had been recycled and consumed so many times now that people were now dying from mineral deficiencies. The only mercy they could receive would be death. However, it must still be merciful, painless, without suffering, for this world had enough suffering as it was. 天堂之眼计划, or “Project Eyes of Heaven”, as it was called, was to be made with great care to ensure that the mass euthanasia would be as quiet and painless as possible. 

As of 2023, Project Eyes of Heaven is still under way. Of the many SIZ China built, only two SIZ are still operating and 23 Megafactories still functioning. And what are they making? China’s final attempt at keeping its national identity. With its fleet lying on the sea bed near Australia, China’s last, best attempt at staying a nation is the invasion of their northern neighbor. The USSR has been extremely hostile towards China, creating a militarized border wall in 2007 and shooting anyone who tried to cross, no questions asked, over a kilometer from the wall. It was only through the swarming of 2.5 billion desperate, starving Chinese could they maybe reclaim their national spirit. Full-on collapse is imminent: many of the surviving nations believe China is partly to blame for the collapse of civilization, for tempting the world with their devilishly cheap goods. Already, parts of the PLA have rebelled and started executing civilians for just existing, mainly in Taiwan. China must make one last desperate push north or risk total collapse.
