Section 2: The Red Army Marches

China expanded its sphere of influence throughout the 1970s and 1980s, and in the 1990s, invaded their neighbors. In the 2000s, pointless wars of attrition were fought for the sole purpose of getting soldiers killed and freeing up resources. 

Mongolia

Mongolia remained closely allied to the USSR. Because the USSR was very anti-Chen until the late 80s, this caused tension with China over its refusal to industrialize. In 1989, Batmönkh stayed in power due to the Crash, and then in 1990, Mongolia tried to formally join the USSR as a republic. The USSR seriously considers letting them join, however they ultimately side against it as they don’t want to risk a war with China at this point, as Soviet troops were withdrawn in 1990 to deal with an uprising in the Balkans. The Invasion is portrayed as bringing Inner Mongolia back into the fold of China. The USSR is against this idea, and while they cannot directly intervene to defend Mongolia in the invasion, they do give aid to the Mongolian rebels. Mongolian rebels are being trained by the USSR to distract and bog down the PLA. 


Two soldiers, one Soviet and one Mongolian, standing in front of an anti-Chinese propaganda poster. Taken sometime in the 1980s. 

Two SIZ are made in Mongolia in the 90s. As the climate warms up, several party leaders make “summer homes” in the cooler climate of Mongolia. As the years progress, they spend more and more time there. Eventually a city is built that is solely for high-ranking administrators, turning into the unofficial capital of China after the unimaginable pollution of Beijing and the explosion of the supercollider. This city is referred to as “New Beijing”. Political dissents are sent across the border where they are executed by Soviet snipers. After 2012, however, they are turned into Siliao. Of the areas China has conquered, Mongolia has the best land for agriculture, as it has a similar climate to Canada and Siberia. By 2023, most of the CCP are operating out of bunkers on the Chinese/Mongolia border. 

Thailand

Thailand is a bit more vengeful about the land it lost in 1946. The 1973 democracy movement succeeds, and is resolved peacefully due to Nixon negotiating it. The new democratic government sought to eliminate the problems plaguing pre-1973 Thailand, including rampant political corruption, curtailed freedoms and income inequality. A series of reforms are passed that incentivize social and economic change. These reforms did little to actually help the population, and instead they traded one corruption for another. Led by greed, politicians were known to be extremely corrupt and easily swayed by bribes. Something as simple as road construction would require at least one bribe in order to be done in an adequate quality. In the 80s Thailand was ruled by a small cadre of elite merchants and politicians who lived an extremely opulent lifestyle. Everytime the people demanded fairer wages, or better working conditions, or any kind of public service, the ruling class would accuse them of being communists and the activists in question would always disappear by totally-not-CIA operatives. 

During this time, the USSR covertly trained communist insurgents and supplied them with weapons. Then comes the Crash of 1988, and the population explodes in a violent revolt led by the Communists. In 1993, the Civil War ended with the Communists in power. They sign a pact of mutual defense with China after the Taiwan invasion, however China invades them a year later to “ensure the people are never betrayed again”. 

China built 2 SIZ in Thailand, both at politically unstable locations. These factories employ a large number of conveniently placed political prisoners. Throughout the Chinese occupation, Thai workers have demonstrated and rebelled on a similar level to the civil unrest in the USA. Notable uprisings have been suppressed in 1998, 2004, 2013 and 2019. By 2023, Thailand is another breadbasket to supply the dying China. The communists in power have more in common with the businessmen in the 70s and 80s than they’d like to admit. Much like the rest of Indochina, the humidity makes it very hard to work during the day and most farmers check their crops at night. 

Taiwan

Taiwan was extremely corrupt, with only fears of Mao and Chen to keep it together. So much so that the government is almost comically corrupt, to the point that people are executed on the street for being ”communist sympathizers”, when actually they didn’t sell someone a hot dog. After the PRC is recognized as the sole heir to China after the Shanghai Accords of 1972, Taiwan is ignored on the world stage until China formally invades them. Even then, most countries only send their condolences. Chiang Kai-Shek was assassinated by an agent of Chen in 1972, but it is never proven. Part of the Shanghai Accords also formally disbar any countries from investigating it. Martial Law was never lifted in 1987, as the KMT were suspicious of Chen’s administration. 

From 1972 to its invasion, Taiwan was an extremely paranoid police state that ruthlessly exploited its citizens. Chairman Chen is equally paranoid of Taiwan, which is why he is so harsh against its population.The worst mega-factories are built in Taiwan as a way to pollute and damage Taiwan’s environment to keep the Taiwanese weak and feeble. 5 SIZ are located here, with one of them designed to pollute the environment as efficiently as possible in a unique form of environmental warfare. 25% of the coal that China used until 2009 came from Taiwan, and rare luxury foods like sugar cane were grown until a fire destroyed most plantations in 2007. The PRC views Taiwanese as corrupted by Japan and subhuman, all the way until 2023. In 2023, with most of its resources extracted, China believes that Taiwan is more trouble than it’s worth and simply kills all of its residents to turn them into Siliao for the mainland. 

Cambodia

In the 1960s, Cambodia sided with South Vietnam in the Vietnam war. However, as the bloodthirsty US started bombing VietCong communists hiding in Cambodia and accidentally killing many Cambodians (Called the Blood Tide Massacre), they shifted more towards the communists. The Khmer Rouge was installed, however the Shanghai Accords secured their sovereignty. This meant that there could be no South Vietnam/US incursion into Cambodia. 

Due to the lucrative nature of the Shanghai Accords, the world turned a blind eye to the Cambodian Genocide. Many Cambodians were worked to death in intensive farming plantations to feed the laborers in the Chinese Megafactories. Cambodia didn't get invaded by Vietnam in 1978. Instead, North Vietnam pressures Pol Pot to be less evil against his workers. This led to a peaceful revolution that removed Pol Pot from power in 1979. The workers are treated a bit better (in the sense that dead workers can’t produce anything). 

Throughout the 80s, Cambodia went through a series of liberal reforms that granted its workers better working conditions, healthcare, and less hours, however they were still paid the same to keep the price of their products down. One SIZ is built here in the 80s. Full on peace and reconciliation efforts began in 1988 in Paris, however they were cut short by the Crash of 1988, and Cambodia descended into a civil war between the remnants of the Khmer Rouge and the pro-North Vietnam liberals. Later on, the exiled King and other factions join. As the civil war goes on, more and more land is destroyed. China played all sides, funding and training troops for both the Conservative and Liberal communists. Finally, in 1994, China invades Cambodia on the basis of “internal stability”. 

After China’s invasion, the remnants of the country are reformed into what is essentially a giant plantation, earning it the name “The Banana Republic of the East.” By 2023, Cambodia has been worked to the bone. Only very small amounts of food can be produced now, all of it extremely diseased. Humidity is so bad that people have to work during the night. 


Laos

In 1972, part of the Shanghai Accords, Laos was granted sovereignty from North Vietnam. Both sides of Laos would align with each other and in exchange, US Military forces were to leave it. In 1973-1976, a UN peacekeeping operation engaged in the de-armament of dropped US bombs. While the US withdrew from militarily aiding Laos, they would support them in other ways, such as a lucrative .95:.95 trade deal in textiles. This created a hopeful atmosphere and Suvannaphūmā did not die of a heart attack due to receiving a life-saving medical procedure in 1975. Because of this, however, the communist forces in Laos remain, just underground. They are secretly funded by the USSR. 

Lots of US companies come to Laos to run plantations. There are even reports of corporate espionage between US and China-based companies, using Laos as a battleground. Because of its proximity to other “communist” countries, Laos became a center for western missionary groups. Throughout the 80s there are a series of hostage crises as Christian Missionaries are captured by communist rebels. As Laos became richer, the wealth gap increased dramatically. By the late 80s, the communist forces gained more sympathy. 

After the Crash of 1988, the communist party launched another attack on the government, supported by the USSR, and later in 1990, China. Because the majority of the population were farmers, they managed to survive the initial crash relatively smoothly. But because of this, China invaded them in 1991. By 2023, Laos remains a glorified plantation for China, much like Cambodia, however the food they grow is much healthier due to the lack of ground pollution. Now if only the food didn’t rot in the humidity before reaching the peasantry in mainland China… 

Vietnam

The Vietnam War continued as normal until 1972 where a gradual detente would cause the war to end in 1975. South Korea and other South-East Asian nations send more troops, along with higher morale from US troops, causing the war to continue into a stalemate much like the Korean War instead of a total loss. A group of Maoist loyalists escaped to North Vietnam in 1973, which caused the US to renew and revitalize their war efforts. The Nixon administration claims it is the last remnant of “true communism” and is determined to stamp it out, afterwards they can worry about fixing the Soviet Union. 


Richard Nixon rallies US troops for a renewed defence of Hanoi, photographed 1974

This new system of Two Vietnams were both heavily supported by China, but only after the Maoist insurgency ended. China builds one SIZ in each Vietnam and then opens up a port deal. Vietnam is touted as a “communist to capitalist” success story by the USA and China, though in China they refer to it as “capitalism with Chinese characteristics”. Because of the enormous success of Chenism in Vietnam, many more SIZs are built in both Vietnams. North Vietnam ends up with 7, while South Vietnam ends up with 4. Throughout the 80s, the two Vietnams are referred to as Little China, and as they work together to utilize their industrial capacity, they enter negotiations to reunify. On April 4th, 1987, Vietnam formally reunited in a ceremony overseen by President King, Former President Nixon, and Chairman Chen. 

Because Vietnam was so closely modeled on China, they were hit particularly hard in 1988. Overnight, their industry dried up and was replaced by a lackluster agricultural system in the south. In 1989, a civil war began once again between the North and the South, except this time it was about the distribution of arable land. 

This was a wake up call to China, who saw their future in Vietnam if they didn’t keep their factories running and people employed. They would need resources, and that is where the plan to revitalize Africa came in. 

As the Civil War progressed, the hardcore Maoist faction re-emerged which caused Chairman Chen to launch an invasion. Vietnam then suffered much like Taiwan, turning into a police state, and the little arable land it had was exploited until the rising sea took over 90% of its land. By 2023, Vietnam is as thin as Chile and has no agricultural value to China. Its Venice-style port towns are used to ship crops from Indochina to the rest of China. 

Myanmar

In 1973, China began trying to suggest Myanmar implement Chenist reforms to their path to Burmese Socialism. Unlike a lot of the other countries in Indochina, they ended up resisting the lure of Chenism. This caused much of Myanmar’s history to go more or less uneventfully. The leader of Myanmar, known as the General, ruled Myanmar all the way up to 1990, where he was killed by a group of angry peasants who felt that he wasn’t going far enough to help them during the Red Decades. After this, the army took over Myanmar and ruled it with an iron first for 6 years, rigorously exploiting the land with intensive farming. Unlike the other countries in Indochina, the war with Myanmar wasn’t strictly about resources but about distracting their population from the starvation, poverty and industrial pollution that was starting to plague China. The fact that Myanmar had some agricultural value was simply a bonus. 

(North) Korea

North Korea remained just as isolated as it always was. After the 1971 Coup, they form closer ties to the USSR. This means that North Korea never became Chenist. After the Crash of 1988, and seeing how weak the US’s response to USSR’s invasions of Iran and Afganistan, Kim Il-Sung launched an invasion into South Korea. In 1992, after Kim Il-Sung’s death, his successor was much weaker, and because of that, the KPA led a coup on November 13th, 1997. This new dictatorship gets support from China in exchange for North Korea’s vast supplies of natural gas and coal. China set up environmentally devastating mining operations in the 90s to access these resources, tearing up huge amounts of the countryside for access to rare minerals and coal. This caused huge famines throughout the early 2000s, but despite this, North Korea is still barely capable of agriculture. In 2023, North Korea is the closest thing to China at the height of Chenism in 1987. Its industry remains fully functional, with the worst air pollution in the world as of January 1, 2024. Three SIZ are located here, and as of 2023, all fully functioning factories are located here. During the Great Death, North Korea is bombarded with nukes by the USSR - an ironic end considering how they chose their northern neighbor over their western one.

(South) Korea

South Korea is extremely anti-communist and anti-Japan. So anti-Japan, in fact, that placing tariffs on Japanese products were some of the first laws passed by the government after the Korean War, all the way back in 1953. South Korean police squads would regularly patrol the streets to execute suspected “communists” with the full support of J. Edgar Hoover and Joseph McCarthy. This rabid anti-communist mentality caused many more people to enlist in the army to fight in South Vietnam during the Vietnam War, contributing to the Vietnam Stalemate of 1972. Presidential elections have been rigged by the CIA since 1948. Because of this, there was no reform in 1960 and Rhee was kept as president until his death in 1971. Trade unions were also outlawed in 1964. South Korea’s first Five Year Economic Plan, based on massive amounts of exports to industrialize the nation, is actually what inspired Chairman Chen to have a similar plan, just on an absolutely colossal scale. Education and industrialization was encouraged, as it was thought that an educated worker could bring the country out of its agrarian age.  Because of its staunch anti-communist views, it received extra support from the US until 1972 when the US became very lax with China. This was seen as a massive betrayal by South Korea and was the start of their anti-US sentiment. In 1974, a large rebellion broke out as the populace no longer views the Communist world as a threat. Nixon heads to Seoul to help negotiate and reaches an agreement to help protect South Korea from the North, in exchange for 1:1 trade deals on everything. The CIA would also help keep the new President in power. Lots of the extremely environmentally damaging chemicals used in the mass production of consumer goods were developed in South Korea in the 1970s. 

South Korea opposed Chenism: at first. But like Japan, they would give in during the 1980s and would have many factories set up in China to produce their products. In fact, in mainland China, an entire SIZ is dedicated just to South Korean products. In the 1980s, after South Korea negotiated with China on the building of several megafactories, there were widespread protests as the Korean people had felt they had been betrayed by the government. This led to martial law being declared on December 12th, 1980. The rest of the government of South Korea, all coincidently shareholders of the biggest corporations of Korea, did not impeach the president for this sudden change of heart. They did not even reprimand him when he lifted tariffs on Japanese products and entered trade negotiations with them. In 1983, South Korea and North Korea entered talks about re-unifying, entering a short-lived trading agreement where the North would give the South coal and the South would give the North farming equipment. The Crash of 1988 renewed fears of communism and the talks ceased. 

After the Crash and the US withdrawing support, the government doubled down on their authoritarian regime. Tariffs on Japanese products were reintroduced. Due to the price of transportation, trade with China dried up, and the current administration enacted policies to try to rebuild South Korea’s industry. None of this would have any effect, as South Korea fell to civil war and invasion by the North later that year. After the Chinese annexation, South Korea is still ruled by vengeful North Koreans. It is the second worst place in China after Taiwan (which says a lot). South Korea has a lot of mineral resources, which China uses for the production of weaponry. About half of South Korea’s arable land is damaged by the pollution. Only one SIZ is built here. By 2023, most male South Koreans have been worked to death by their resentful North Korean masters. In China most concubines are South Korean. 

India

China’s war with India was the first war that was solely for causing its soldiers to die. India’s huge population caused it to fracture into civil war in the late 90s, which caused large parts of the country to descend into anarchy and warlordism. The parts of the country that remained under control by the government, mainly centered along the Ganges river and the coast, were at constant odds with Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Pakistan over fishing rights. Bangladesh was annexed by India in 1999, and Sri Lanka the year after. In 2001, the Pakistani Navy torpedoed a civilian Indian fishing boat and claimed that it was a spy vessel. This escalated into full-blown conventional war, with Pakistani troops burning wheat fields and killing cows. India’s dictator, driven over the edge at the news of his family being burned alive in his mansion, flipped the switch and nuked Pakistan. Pakistan nuked them back, and while India was able to destroy a vast majority of the nukes in the initial strikes, the river Ganges was permanently tainted with radioactive particles. 

After the disappearance of an entire fleet of Chinese vessels in 2007 (suspected to be a result of Indian pirates), China invaded India and removed the aging dictator from power. India was plunged into absolute anarchy after that, with a small series of independent communities lining the coast and clustered in Sri Lanka. As the pollution and radioactivity caused more and more land to become unusable, more and more cancer cases, and more and more deaths from radiation poisoning, there was almost nothing that remained. China plundered what little resources India had left, then began sending soldiers out on deliberate suicide missions into the radioactive wasteland of India, Pakistan, and Bangledesh. The Fourth Chairman came up with the idea of using the remaining city-states as target practice for military exercises, and the survivors of the Indian-Pakistani war were routinely subject to war crimes that would make the Taiwanese jealous. 

In 2014, an unexpected fleet arrived: the US military, waving the Food, Inc flag. The Food, Inc, looking for materials to keep their factories running, had come to pick over the radioactive slag heap that was once India. They made a lucrative deal with the Indians: precious metals in exchange for their new revolutionary product. The higher ups of Food, Inc had long suspected what the true ingredient of Siliao was, and always looking to cut costs, had decided to test out the efficiency of using recycled human corpses as a filler. And India was where Ration Omega was originally tested. China had considered engaging in war with Food, Inc, as it would be a surefire way to get rid of a couple million surplus Chinese, however there was no telling if the USA still had functional nuclear weapons. A nuclear war would for sure reduce the population significantly, but this was still seen as too extreme at this point. The 10th Chairman felt that China could still survive if she held on just a little longer. 

Japan

The war with Japan was officially about fishing rights. Some in the PLA had even claimed it was revenge for WW2. Under the Fourth Chairman, China sent waves after waves of Chinese soldiers across the sea to die in the Japanese Islands. Japan was a very stubborn country - they were starving, but very slowly and politely. Many elders had voluntarily followed the Emperor’s example and had committed mass suicide in 2006 to free up resources for the younger generations, however with this sacrifice came a massive loss of knowledge. Japan was falling apart at the seams, with industrial accidents happening before the overworked and under-educated Steward Society could stop them. And this was on top of the almost incomprehensible pollution that occurred before the Crash of 1988: over a half of people under 25 had lost eyesight in one or both of their eyes from cataracts forming. 

But again, Japan was stubborn. Wave after wave of Chinese invaders crashed upon their shores, and many sacrificed themselves for the good of their countrymen. Japan had been slow to re-arm itself, so many defenders were left to fight hand-to-hand or with WW2-era officer swords. Japan developed a special martial art for fighting in the trenches: Tōtoki unagi no michi, or “The Way of the Honorable Eel”. These soldiers were treated with the utmost reverence by their fellow citizens, and were given special privileges regarding their calorie rations. As Japan began rearming itself, however, the Chinese began being pushed further back until finally being pushed out of the home islands by 2009. Throughout 2010, Chinese warships only managed to make three landings, the rest of the vessels were sunk at sea. In 2011, after Japan was hit by a devastating earthquake that ruined much of the fragile metropolitan landscape, the CCP considered a proper invasion, however that would defeat the entire purpose of the phoney war: to reduce China’s population and maintain their economy making war material. 

Australia

Australia was uniquely prepared for the gradual end of civilization. While other countries like Iceland, New Zealand, Canada, the Nordic Union and the USSR were hit the softest because of their low populations, small population densities and cool climates, Australia had been dealing with wildfires, droughts and desertification long before it was impacting the rest of the world. Australia had always been regarded as “that funny land down under”, as they were reluctant to trade with China after the advent of Chenism. They were also the only country to legalize birth control on a massive scale in 1975, and also the only major country to outlaw Chlorofluorocarbons during the 80s. After extensive research into the causes of the Three Mile Island disaster, they were also the only country to not outright ban nuclear power. 

When the Crash of 1988 came around, Australia was unfazed, aside from completely banning immigration. 

Throughout the Red Decades, Australia had developed a healthy trading relationship with New Zealand, and thus only suffered from a permanent recession rather than a full on depression. The government enacted a policy of completely abandoning the countryside for complete urbanization, much like the USA, however Australia did it in a much more deliberate and controlled manner. Internal migrants would only be allowed into the cities if there was space for them. As more and more citizens were displaced, massive 40-story tall apartment buildings, colloquially known as “Hawke-Blocs[1]”, were built. 

Years of wildfire and drought had forced Australian cities to have uniquely open and spacious designs using fire-retardant materials to reduce the risk of fires. They weren’t foolproof, however - Darwin was completely burnt to a crisp during the Great Fire of 2005. Irrigation was also integrated into cities to create “districts” from which water could be drawn from to create barriers against active fires. People’s lawns were turned into community gardens much like the wartime victory gardens of WW2. And slowly, wind and solar power was implemented into the cities. 


An Australian Hawke-Class Nuclear Dreadnaught being repaired and refueled at a Sydney drydock. Photo taken in 2014, immediately after the sinking of the PLA fleet.

As more and more of the Outback was overtaken by climate change, more and more citizens were internally displaced and by 2010, much of the country was abandoned. Australia had been concentrated into 15 “mega cities”, each one with about 3 million citizens. With so much of the population in such a small area, the government was worried they might be vulnerable to attack. The Australian Navy was one of the most efficient in the world (second only to the USSR’s), having adopted nuclear engines around the early 1990s. While initially small, they escorted merchant vessels to and from Perth and New Zealand. After a hostage situation of an Australian merchant in 2003 off the coast of Wellington, however, both the New Zealand and Australian governments adopted a “shoot first, ask questions later” policy. In 2010, the Australian Navy was massively increased and began routine patrols around the coast of Australia, with New Zealand following suit in 2011. 

It was then no surprise when the entire Chinese Navy was sunken off the coast of Sydney on April 4th, 2014. Both Australia and New Zealand’s militaries had been on high alert due to the increasing number of refugees fleeing from the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia. New Zealand’s Navy had been patrolling on the opposite side of New Zealand at the time, so Australia was alone. It was not a problem, however - the fleet of 150 dreadnaughts, staffed by 15,000 well-fed, well-educated and well-disciplined Australian sailors decimated the entire PLA Navy over the course of four hours. By the time that New Zealand reinforcements arrived, the battle was already over. 13 ships were lost on the Australian side, and it is because of that number that the Australians fought with such ferocity. There was no more room on the ship, so to speak, and Australia had long kept a policy of taking no prisoners. 

China

And so, with no options left, China turned inwards on itself. 

China had been struggling for almost two decades to keep its people fed and factories running, lest they risk total revolt, and that is exactly what ended up happening. In 2019, a factory in occupied Myanmar was burned down in an open declaration of war from the long-thought dead Maoist faction of the CCP. This was followed by waves of starving farmers taking up arms in Indochina and burning crop fields. 

The PLA, fractured and humiliated, was called in to regain order. However, more than half of the soldiers ended up defecting and joining the rebel faction. As the Maoist anarchy spread through Southeastern Asia, the terrible truth was revealed: Siliao was PEOPLE!!!!!!!! 

It took a while for the world to spread, but soon entire army divisions rose up in open rebellion. They were the only people in China who were properly fed, and thus had the energy to actually rebel. Even then, the rebel factions were outnumbered almost 5 to 1, and after a few weeks, the CCP was once again under control of the country. A statement was made that Siliao was only made from the flesh of subversives, that no hard working son of Chen was being recycled, but at this point, no one cared. 

[1] Named after the Prime Minister of Australia from 1983-1997, Bob Hawke.
Part 2-2
A Fractured World: A European Tragedy
Section 1: Freedom or Security

Excerpt from "Encyclopedia Europa: Europe before the Black Ages” by Cormac Eisenwald, Man from Mullingar Press, 919 ASJ


The historic Brussels meeting in 1993 where the European Federation was announced.

The early 90s hit Europe hard. Intense rationing began following the total devastation of the food supply in the Hot Summer. Europe’s energy grid was crumbling to the rapid rise of temperatures and ever more intense heatwaves. The fastest warming continent in the world was struggling to adapt to the rapid and constant change, and with their economies in continuous decline, the nations knew they would struggle to survive against the other superpowers if they went alone.

And so, on June 7th, 1993, the Brussels Conference ended with a historic announcement - the willing countries of the European Union would band together to form the European Federation the following year. The countries were as follows: Austria, Belgium, Denmark, France, (West) Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal, and Spain. The United Kingdom, Ireland, and Greece refused, mainly on the grounds of sovereignty and/or public backlash.

The new European Federation allowed its member states a fair degree of autonomy - they each had their own parliaments, premiers, control of education, healthcare, and taxation, among others. The Federal Government itself had more control over energy and immigration policy - immigration was for obvious reasons, but energy was decided upon to coordinate building efforts better and for projects to not get bogged down in the maze of local governance. It was a model similar to the federalism of the United States of America, if not slightly more centralised.

The model worked okay at first - it helped to somewhat appease the many nationalists opposing the federalisation. However, in this rapidly and unstoppably dying world, this model would very soon come across large issues. Most of the time, the state governments would elect left-wing ones amicable to the governing Party of European Socialists and with aligned policies, creating little conflict with the federal government. However, the dominant PES (or PSE, SPE, whatever the language) began to face significant challenges in the late 90s in the face of the far-right, or the rapidly growing National European Front. The far-right had already been causing mass social unrest in the cities of Europe as a result of the mass influx of immigrants from the desertifying Africa and radioactive Middle East. These concerns didn’t have as much of an impact on the electorate as the far-right would like to have believed, but as the 90s rolled on and the economic situation got ever worse, mass radicalisation occurred and thousands upon thousands of people joined extremist paramilitaries, such as the infamous Famille de Liberté in France, Bündnis für Heimat Deutschland (BHD) in Germany, and the Esercito del Popolo in Italy. The terrorism spawned by them wreaked havoc among Europe’s cities for years until their crackdown in the 2000s. They found their political wing in the NEF, which the PES tried to attack them with, to no avail.

The NEF continued to do better and better in state and federal elections, replacing the EPP as the dominant right-wing party. In 1998 Italy narrowly elected an NEF premier following massive locust swarms and increasing waves of anti-migrant sentiment. The new premier repeatedly clashed with the federal government, most notably on immigration where they directed the local military and EP branches to sink migrant boats and conduct mass deportations of “illegal migrants”, which ended up being considered anyone who looked non-European. The federal government was enraged and the federal Supreme Court ruled against it, threatening to replace the premier and hold new elections. The Italian premier backed down but continued to challenge federal policy, including by reintroducing the death penalty and criminalising homosexuality. This galvanised the NEF, and their unstoppable growth in local and state parliaments, as well as an overperformance in the 1999 federal election, scared the PES shitless and worried figures of a possible NEF government, which the PES was desperate to avoid. In 2000, following the takeover of the Netherlands and Portugal's’ parliaments by the NEF and brutal race riots in Marseilles and Barcelona, the Federation introduced two new laws - the Migration and Border Control Act, which suspended the admission of refugees indefinitely, and the National Security Act [1], which banned most far-right and far-left paramilitaries completely, labelled them as terror groups, and mandated excessive jail time for membership of one. This threatened to once again galvanise the NEF and the PES decided to finally take drastic action. On the 14th March 2001, a large NEF march was taking place in Brussels outside the European Parliament. A few gunshots and conveniently placed counter-protestors was all it took for the rally to get out of control and for the NEF to be banned a few days later under an emergency act.


The aftermath of the bombing of Bologna Central railway station as part of the 1997 Bologna attacks [2], the deadliest terrorist attack in the 90s. The far-right Esercito del Popolo group claimed responsibility for the attack soon after.

The NEF and far-right weren’t the only extremists active on federal Europe’s streets. The European Communists and Left (ECL) were a far-left party mainly consisting of communists and radical leftists, coming to prominence following the election of a Communist president in France in 1989. The far-left had its own paramilitaries and terror groups, such as Spain’s Frente de Acción Obrera (FAO) and the revival of Italy’s Red Brigades. Due to having more initial electoral and policy success they weren’t as prominent as their far-right counterparts, yet in response to the increasing authoritarianism of the PES they began to take more direct action. Bombings of government buildings and assassinations, such as the 1999 Seville bombing in which the FAO killed a Spanish MFP and two MSPs in one go [3], were getting more and more commonplace. These had the effect of drawing more attention to the far-left as was being drawn to the far-right, unfortunately for them most of it was negative. The National Security Act banned far-left paramilitaries as well as far-right ones, and relations quickly soured between the ECL and other parties due to their refusal to condemn the terror attacks. The ECL were the next party in the PES’s sights and would not get away lightly.

The far-left were rapidly gaining more support as former NEF voters voted for them as a protest vote against the PES establishment. They had two key assets on their side that the NEF didn’t. One was the presence of a stable support base among the working class and industrial workers, and the other was the power of the trade unions. The majority supported the PES in the 90s, whose governments relaxed labour laws and supported strikers in disputes. However, they became disillusioned and fearful of them over time, looking at their growing authoritarianism with worry and seeing big corporations gain more and more influence. The more radical ECL seemed like an increasingly viable alternative and as their endorsements shifted their methods shifted alongside. Strikes became larger and longer, attacks became more frequent, and the government and unions were coming to a head. The trade unions had the power to collapse the Federation itself and the government did not like that.

You may ask, what was influencing the growing authoritarianism and anti-unionism of the PES? Unsurprisingly, the culprit was the new foodstuffs industry, more specifically the growing megacorporation of FulTec.


The logo of FulTec’s German branch in the 90s. The slogan for other branches was in their respective languages. Note that FulTec became the official name in 1994, so the full name is not included.

FulTec (Funktionelle Technologien until 1994) was established in 1983 as firstly an R&D company based in Frankfurt, West Germany by businessman and engineer Dietmar Voss, who had spotted out automation as a key field that had great potential in the years to come with the decline of Germany’s manufacturing sector and the rise of the service economy. They ended up mainly working on home automation, designing systems for automating heating, lighting, and ventilation in homes and flats. The products were very successful due to their low costs (from making them from parts imported from China) and homeowners and landlords invested large amounts in them. Profits and stock values were reaching record highs, and the company was swiftly expanding and rising over its competitors.

The 1988 crash wiped out practically all their gains as consumer spending and demand collapsed, and China’s move towards protectionism in the 90s dealt a crippling blow to their profits. FulTec did not move on that quickly, as there was still a market to be made in energy efficiency appliances. As the effects of climate change began to be felt and bills skyrocketed ever higher, there was new demand for them from the struggling middle class to save up on costs. However, German manufacturing was slow to restart and importing parts was extraordinarily expensive, meaning their appliances were often too pricey for ordinary consumers to afford. Only the upper class would buy their products, but their number shrunk as the class divide ever widened, and FulTec struggled to turn a profit. Net loss after net loss sent them into dire straits and they seemed to be about to close down in 1992, when Voss stepped down and a new businessman, Klaus Riedel, became the CEO. Riedel had been working in FulTec since 1986 and rose rapidly up the ranks in those few years. He unsuccessfully warned them about the imminent economic depression when the Sinai War began escalating and had been in touch with many prominent climate scientists throughout the years, expressing deep concern over its possible impacts, mainly on the food supply. He was one of the first people to take note of the food crisis, and spying developments in America and China, quickly took to reinventing the company entirely, basing it entirely on foodstuffs and manufacturing. The move was incredibly risky and changing course was difficult and costly, but being the first to take initiative led to FulTec rising above and outproducing their competitors and becoming the dominant food supplier in Western Europe.

FulTec’s rapid expansion, however, soon faced challenges under the Federation’s new anti-monopoly laws introduced in 1995 by the federal government. They soon faced lawsuits and were threatened to either downsize or be split up into smaller companies. Riedel was strongly against this, believing too much competition would lead to inefficiency and higher food prices, and launched a large lobbying campaign to remove the laws. Conveniently enough, large amounts of the government were also against this, and with FulTec’s growing influence in the government, and its vast amounts of cash, the anti-monopoly laws were repealed just four years after their inception in 1999. With help from the government, FulTec was able to crush all its remaining competitors and became the Federation’s only food supplier by 2002.

FulTec, like other foodstuffs corporations in the world, gained immense amounts of money and power, and increasing influence in the federal and state governments. They would pay millions or billions of euros to create or repeal laws to their benefit and had “advisors” planted in governments to influence policy. The main in which FulTec would influence the government was their political wing (in all but name) - the Third Wave grouping in the PES. Born in 1997 from an Austrian MFP, they pushed for the PES to shift to the right and take a more authoritarian stance on the extremists and terrorists to “ensure the stability of Europe”. The movement gained more and more successes - in 1998 they prevented the NEF from taking Austria’s state parliament, and in 1999 got five of their members into the new cabinet. They elected more and more premiers and took control of more and more branches, and by 2002 they became the dominant wing of the PES and dictated most of their policy.

The far-right was split on FulTec’s rise - some believed FulTec was necessary to solve the food crisis and believed “illegal migrants” should be taken to work in their factories. Others believed they were a threat and a danger to them and should be nationalised or broken up before they became too powerful. Most were paid off by FulTec anyway, and the megacorp were strong opponents of the NEF, believing the far-right terrorism to be a threat to their stability, and supporting the NSA’s passing. The far-left was unanimously angered by these developments and vowed to fight viciously against them and the reformed PES. One of the biggest opponents of FulTec was the trade unions - those “pesky bugs” fighting for better workers rights and the dismantlement of the megacorp. The PES government and the Third Wave faction was also opposed to the far-left, and with more and more anti-union laws introduced locally and with strikes growing more and more numerous, a showdown loomed between the government and the workers. The only question was “who would strike first”.

And then the summer of 2003 arrived, and all hell broke loose.


Mass protests in Paris during the General Strike of 2003. Photograph taken in August that year.

The summer of 2003 was the hottest and deadliest summer ever recorded in Europe at the time, producing record-breaking temperatures of 54°C in Córdoba and Seville and 53 degrees in Sicily. Up north, Paris reached a scorching 46 degrees and Brussels 44 in August, with London further up north reaching an unprecedented 45 in July. Catastrophe emerged, as despite the ever-rising temperatures, Europe’s cities, which were already facing bankruptcy and stripped for cash, were completely unprepared to deal with it. The lack of AC and heat insulation in buildings led to hundreds of thousands of extra deaths as masses of unemployed and homeless were cooked alive in their homes and on the streets. Hectares of forests burned and wildfire smoke choked cities to death with pollution. Electricity prices skyrocketed to unaffordable highs and the remaining city lights shut down.

The heatwave had an even more damaging effect on the food supply. As the continent cooked, farms and fisheries, mainly in the south, simply stopped functioning. Irrigation systems stopped working, plants weren’t growing and animals were being baked alive in the suffocating heat, promising the food crisis to escalate further. The water situation was even worse - megadroughts began in Iberia, Italy, and Southern France and rivers and aquifers dried up, creating a severe water shortage in lots of Europe. More strict water rationing measures were implemented, but in many areas the crises became too much to handle, triggering mass exodus out of Andalusia and Southern Italy. FulTec was being hit as a result, too, with its profits in the second and third quarter of 2003 falling by a total of 18%, sparking panic among its executives. They had sort of prepared for such an event, building lots of their new farms and factories up north, but the heatwave still had an unexpectedly heavy effect, and they were soon in a dire financial state, despite government subsidies. To mitigate this, they were forced to withdraw or reduce operations in foreign European countries such as Greece, Scandinavia, and the UK in August that year, which soon created seismic political shifts across the continent.

Even then, they struggled to turn a profit, and food was in short supply across the country. The heat, the mass deaths, and the food shortage led to first unrest, then riots and bombings in many cities. Food riots, which were relatively uncommon previously, became much more frequent in 2003, and mayhem erupted in many large cities, which became clouded with smoke from burning buildings. Groups which were previously suppressed by the NSA saw an opportunity to rise up again, and the daily terror attacks of the late 90s returned in hotter climates as the police were quickly overwhelmed by the growing anarchy. The Federation desperately tried to control the situation, but it was decaying much faster than expected, and some figures warned of possible near-term collapse.

And in the midst of all this, the trade unions saw the opportunity of a lifetime.

On the 17th July 2003, a meeting of the major trade unions in Paris and representatives from the ECL ended in an announcement of a general strike, with the federal leader of the ECL blasting the socialist government for “leaving the workers and poor of Europe for dead” and declaring that “the revolution will come in short order”. The vast majority of trade unions took part and offices and factories soon emptied out as production took a freefall. The alarm in the government rapidly turned into utter panic as projections showed the combined effect of the general strike, the heatwave and crime wave could shrink Europe’s economy by up to 20% at the worst in two years, leading to total state collapse. Members of the government cursed themselves for not suppressing the unions earlier. FulTec theoretically wouldn’t be affected by the strike as none of its workers were unionised, however that did not stop workers from joining protests and skipping work days. They quickly began to crack down, promising “severe repercussions” on participating workers, and using their private militias to hunt down workers not attending. Despite the boiling temperatures, giant union-organised protests covered the streets. Many took place in the mornings and evenings to avoid the lethal sunlight.

The government took action quickly. A few days after the strike’s inception and the leader of the ECL’s “revolution” speech, his party was banned due to “inciting violence” and “threatening the Federation’s stability”, going the same way as the NEF two years before. Police were deployed to protests and ordered to try to hold them back, though the sheer scale of them meant the struggle was futile. The increasing spending given to the police instead of other areas worried many that the Federation was turning into a police state like many other countries had been forced to become, the ECL using that prominently in their messaging. Legislation was drafted to curtail the power of unions, but it was seen as “too little too late”, and the momentum of the strike was still going strong. And in other areas of the Federation, things were quickly deteriorating.

The region of Andalusia in southern Spain had been suffering under climate change, experiencing a severe drought from 1997-2002. After rain finally fell, the people were optimistic that the worst was finally over, however the summer of 2003 quickly took all that away and an even worse drought struck the region, which would end up permanent. Desertification was rapidly taking over the area and as food and water shortages rose and living in the cities became unsustainable, a mass exodus began taking place. Anti-government sentiment, which had been building up for a while, swiftly took over the area, and the already strong regional FAO took to act on those fears. On the 29th of July 2003, militias were deployed in the city of Seville, and the ensuing “March on Seville” ended in an FAO takeover of the city, with many other similar events happening over the following weeks. The local FAO declared independence from the Federation, forming the “Ejército Español Libre (EEL)” which promised to march on Madrid and “free Spain from the capitalist occupiers”. Similar movements rose up in Portugal which was similarly affected by the drought and heat, though a rival march on Lisbon failed and the city was placed under martial law. The Federation immediately declared war against the rival government and sent multiple divisions there. However, with conditions there nearing inhospitable and with the abundance of other issues, opinion on the war quickly soured and led to a backlash against the government, with many people believing they would collapse on their own given enough time.

The far-right saw the unfolding events and, seeing the FAO’s successes, believed they could replicate them easily with the government at their weakest. On the 12th of August 2003, the local underground Esercito del Popolo branch in Naples marched on the city and took over the local government, with similar events occurring in neighbouring towns. The local EP also declared independence and formed the “Fronte di Liberazione Italiano (FLI)”, threatening to march on Rome like Mussolini did 80 years ago and create a far-right rival Italian government. However, already prepared by the similar events in Spain and informed by an insider, the Federation quickly caught the newborn FLI offguard and deployed the army to retake occupied towns and crush it before it was born, storming through Naples and declaring martial law three days later. A similar attempt was tried in Sicily a week after but only had limited success and was soon destroyed.

The government looked at these events with immense concern - they showed that people were angry and dissatisfied to overthrow them, and if carried out on a large scale, could very possibly succeed. The ECL leader’s warnings about a revolution did not seem too far off, and as August was close to an end, the general strike, the uprisings and the bombings were showing no sign of stopping. If this kept up, the Federation would fall apart. On the 19th of August 2003, a private meeting was conducted by members of the government, lasting for five hours straight. There was much speculation as to what was discussed, but two days later, the answer was revealed.

The government had resorted to truly drastic measures this time.

---

21/08/2003
11:31AM
ROME, ITALY, EURO. FEDERATION

It was yet another searing summer day in Rome, as the crowds filling the streets below were blanketed in an immense, suffocating heat. The air was filled with smog that the people of the Italy, hell, the whole world, had experienced and grown used to on a daily basis. It was getting so dire that even old structures such as the Colosseum were getting damaged and decayed from the pollution. But it wasn’t as if anyone was visiting or attending these places anyway, after tourism fell apart in the last decade. Umbrellas and hats were a common sight as people tried in vain to withstand the encroaching heat and radiation, though for many that was not an option. The folla morta had become martyrs from the people marching daily in Rome, Paris, Madrid, on every city’s streets.

The sun was rising ever higher in the sky, however that did not deter the hordes of men, women, children marching down the street, waving colourful banners, flags of all kinds.

“VENDICARE I MORTI”

“ROTTURA DI FULTEC”

“ABBASSO LA DITTATURA E IL FASCISMO”

“NON ABBIAMO NULLA DA PERDERE SE NON LE NOSTRE CATENE!”

Alessandro didn’t have a flag nor a banner. Some people were holding a giant flag of the CGIL union. Another was holding a flag of the ECL. One was even flying the flag of the USSR. Idiot, he thought looking at it. They’ll get you for sure.

On a normal day, heavily armed police and soldiers would surround the crowds of protestors, threatening them, taking people out and blocking their path many times. Today, most of them were conspicuously absent, with only a few bordering them. Alessandro thought it was unusual. But he continued marching like everyone else. Maybe they had finally decided to back down.

Alessandro was like many of these people. He was 36 years old, growing up during the opulent 70s and 80s and was part of what was commonly called the “Betrayed Generation”, who had been born in that time [4], promised futures of post-scarcity and luxury, only to have them being burned down in the flames of nuclear war and grown up to live in a world of poverty and heat. Alessandro had not gone to university, and instead started work after he left school in 1985 as an electrician. The company he worked for closed down in 1989 and in a stroke of fortune found a job at Italy’s state electrical company, which he kept until 1998 when the constant electrical grid failures forced them to downsize and lay many off, including Alessandro. He was quickly taken in by FulTec, where he worked long hours and in terrible conditions in a factory in Rome. The conditions there radicalised him and he took part in a riot in May 2003, which burned down that factory. Since then he was forced to live on Rome’s streets, hiding out from nearby policemen and being helped by his fellow unemployed and communists, joining the daily protests that manifested on the roads.

All these people had to lose was their chains. And they would not stop marching until they were broken.

The strikers continued to march on, moving further centre and taking a right onto the Via dei fori imperiali, right at the heart of the city, connecting some of the most famous landmarks around. Today’s rally was especially large - there was due to be a speaker, an MFP from the Italian ECL, who would do a speech on the street and march with them down to the railway station. Many looked forward to that. The rally continued downwards, shaking off the heat, sticking together as the sun ominously shone down on them.

The speaker was due to appear at this point. He seemed to have not arrived yet. A disturbance was brewing in the crowd.

The government meeting reported two days ago was stuck in Alessandro’s mind. He was unable to shake the feeling that something big was going to happen.

The march came to a halt. Alessandro saw a wall of soldiers blocking their way. The crowd held each other’s arms and tentatively marched forward, coming head to head with the wall. Tanks and a giant device were rolled out onto the pavement. Worry began to spread. His mind screamed at him to run away.

One of the soldiers raised his voice.

“L'esercito vi ha ordinato di disperdervi immediatamente o apriremo il fuoco.”

Open fire? Bullshit. They wouldn’t dare try that.

An unmeasurably loud, piercing, shrieking noise ripped through the air and tore open Alessandro’s ear. In his last moments of hearing he heard the unmistakable ripping sound of gunfire and growing screaming. As his hearing shut off he saw the crowd turning around and madly sprinting towards him as a giant tank accelerated  and soldiers marched towards them. Desperate not to get crushed by the crowd, thoughts utterly incoherent, he ran away, anywhere, rightwards, hoping to get into another street and maybe hide out in the alleys or a house so the army wouldn't kill him.

But it was too late, as another tank rolled out of that street and may or may not have fired a round at the crowd, as a shockwave knocked Alessandro off his feet, and an endless deluge of hands and feet crushed and crumpled and mangled his body like he was a toy, a plaything. Bones were crushed under the weight and force of the masses and his lungs were smashed and suffocated, he couldn’t breathe and as the crowd dispersed a few heavy lumps maybe bullets hit him and tore through his skin and bone. As his last breaths were taken he looked back, remembered those precious old times, those days going out with friends to watch a movie at a cinema, those days when food wasn’t just shitty paste and wasn’t so expensive, those days when the Earth was somewhat cool and not a perpetually searing humid oven, those days that had been taken away by the forces of capitalism as they scoured the Earth red with blood and painted it black with the dirt of coal.

Just why did it have to be this way?

---


Tanks on the move to suppress protests in Brussels during the Crackdown, 21st August 2003

Many atrocities were committed that day.

Taking notes from previous incidents in the Soviet Union and China, the European Army fired thousands of rounds at protest groups and strikers, brought tanks to shell groups of protestors, and even fired artillery in some cases to disperse the groups. The Army had been investing heavily in research for a while to prepare for a possible war against the Soviet Union, and one of their developments was a variant of the LRAD - the Long-Range Acoustic Device developed by the USA in the 90s. These were designed for not only conflict but possible protest/riot suppression, being deployed firstly in the 2003 Crackdown and in later protests as well. Tens of thousands of protestors were killed in the Crackdown - the initial number is uncertain but estimates from human rights groups and the Council ranged from 10,000 to 70,000 at the very worst. Many died from the usage of bullets and the soldiers opening fire, some also died from tanks firing into crowds, but the vast majority died from crowd crushes, as the one major thing that the previous methods were designed to do was to spawn fear. And fear did they spawn. The internal response to the suppressions were varied - some rallies fled at the opening shots. Others tried to resist, and one crowd in Barcelona was able to overpower the deployed army and occupy the tanks, trying to ram them into the Barcelona local government building. They were later surrounded and massacred by a larger army deployment inside that building.

The world was shocked by the events occurring, no one expected Europe of all places to resort to this brutality and inhumanity, yet they did. The world had already been sliding towards authoritarianism, with China and the USSR becoming ever more totalitarian and the US slowly moving towards a dominant-party state, and it was evident that Europe was following the path of them, however with its democratic and progressive post-war history the sheer openness of the incident surprised many. The Alliance of Nations harshly condemned it, alongside the remaining human rights groups, but what were they to do to such a large nation? Europe claimed in its official statement regarding it to the AoN, “...despite what has unfolded may seem and perhaps is inhumane and vicious... ...had we not done this the death toll of the inevitable collapse of the Federation and civil war would have been far greater. We are only trying to protect our nation and have done what is necessary for our stability...”. The other superpowers didn’t necessarily react negatively, though. China and the Soviets had already been doing that for a while (in fact the Crackdown was likely inspired by this) and the USA was already passing harsher anti-crime laws, perhaps looking to Europe for ideas for if unrest got so large. The only major nations that displayed outrage were the Nordic Union and the United Kingdom, however they had no power over Europe, and Britain seemed hypocritical itself.

The initial Crackdown might have been good in the short term for suppressing unrest but was far from a long-term solution for ending it, as renewed anger was already developing and summers were bound to get even hotter in the future. The Federation soon forcibly passed [5] a slew of new laws designed to increase control and prevent such events from ever happening again. One of them was the Freedom of Information Act of 2003, which firstly officially banned extremist or “terror-supporting” newspapers (what that was was up to the discretion of the government), which were exempt from the NSA but still heavily suppressed. The act also created the “News and Communication Agency”, which was where any new newspaper (not that many were being created) would have to be proposed to be allowed to form. The Agency also reviewed newspaper articles and issues to detect “governmental security breaches”, which was basically anything that criticised the government and incites resistance. A similar act was passed shortly afterwards concerning radio and television was already highly regulated and government-controlled.

So goes the freedom of press in Free Europe.

Another one was the European Stability Act of 2003, whose primary function was to merge the police and local army into the “Local Protection Units”. The role of the LPUs were mainly to suppress unrest and rebellion, and were far more militarised and had many more powers than the original police, such as requiring no warrant to enter property, being able to detain anyone at will (although in rare cases if it was deemed there was no reason for their detaining they could be fined), and being freely able to disperse large gatherings or harshly suppress protests. They were given enough power that over time they essentially acted as their own government-backed militia, with little advice or control from the government on their actions, becoming a giant money sink as equipment was lost and unrest grew throughout the years. The European Stability Act also criminalised protesting and reintroduced the death penalty federally for the most severe crimes. It was never legally mandated, but LPUs soon began to advise people to report others for expressing anti-government views. It is unknown as to whether the government suggested that themselves, but it is implied that officers were desperate to meet arrest quotas and created the advice so they could fulfil them easier. The act was later amended in 2004, with pressure by FulTec, to replace firstly the harshest punishments, but later all, with penal labour, sending prisoners to work long, hot, and cruel hours on the expanding superfarms of FulTec, allowing them to significantly boost their workforce and expand their profits, saving them from bankruptcy and collapse.

So goes the freedom of expression in Free Europe.

Another one was the Trade Union Act of 2003, which aimed to prevent a general strike of that scale from repeating itself. The act put all trade unions under government control and limited their maximum strike time to just one day. Unions could only be formed if 70% of local workers voted in a ballot, and if the same percentage voted to form one, and even then, if the government gave permission. The government attempted to keep a veneer of lenience to them by not outright destroying them and giving them permission to strike, but in practice they were neutered, being immensely hard to form and only being allowed to strike with permission. To avoid a collapse in membership, the government subsidised the formation of them and allowed them to dispute with employers, occasionally siding with the employees. But if these disputes hardly succeeded in the first place, then what was the point of their existence?

So goes the freedom to unionise in Free Europe.

The measures led to a mass outcry of fear and revulsion. Lots of the remaining opposition politicians that weren’t threatened or bought out cried out against the draconian measures, stopping short of calling for a resistance movement and pleading for the government to at least relax some of them. The remaining left-wing PES politicians resigned and left the party as “Democratic Independents”. The intensity of protests suddenly spiked as protestors and the remaining extremist groups desperately tried to fight back against the new laws before they were wiped out. However, the Crackdown had already heavily exhausted them and not nearly enough tried to fight back. Many of the PES politicians that left disappeared soon after, and the opposition suddenly found itself faced with an influx of newcomers and unknown challengers to old politicians' seats, and large amounts of money coming from nowhere. The LPUs were unleashed on the remaining protestors and extremists, quickly shutting down the remaining groups and driving many into irrelevance. It seemed like there was nothing people could do.

The only major and somewhat successful resistance was coming from the devolved governments. All of the state governments aside from Luxembourg (which was controlled by the liberal ALDE) were governed by the PES, of which most were aligned with the Third Wave and the federal government. However, a few were still from different factions and held on against other challengers, most notable being the premiers of Denmark and Portugal, who along with Luxembourg, soon declared their opposition to the measures and their intention to oppose their implementation. This was all easier said than done, as the federal government launched numerous court cases to forcefully enforce the laws (as they were federal after all). However, the opposing governments were able to use loopholes and tried creating new state laws to negate the effects of the federal ones, surviving challengers and elections off of sheer organic and popular support against waves of big money from FulTec. For instance, Denmark’s premier passed numerous disguised pro-union laws and passed the LPU Security Guarantee Act which created a large and complex bureaucracy system for the LPUs to fill out if they wanted a search or arrest warrant, essentially making them unable to get them due to the large costs. However, this ended up backfiring immensely as on the same day a court ruling declared it illegitimate an LPU division broke into the premier’s home, tortured and killed him, and hung him up from a lamppost in Copenhagen, the federal government brushing it under the rug and claiming he retired to “take a break from politics”. Portugal’s premier got off easier and some relaxations were temporarily allowed before he was defeated the following election, disappeared, and replaced by a FulTec executive. Luxembourg’s premier suffered a similar fate.

Members of the federal government were seeing this and soon came to realise that the federalised structure of the nation was unnecessary and hostile to the nation’s stability, whatever that meant now. Local government was becoming a hotbed for resistance and most were controlled by the PES and had similar laws anyway. In February of 2005 the government published a proposal titled “The Future of the European Federation’s devolved structure and the influence of the Federal Government”, which called for the government to rapidly centralise and take power away from local and state governments to “streamline bureaucracy” and “save costs”, though everyone knew they were just scared of resistance building up and Denmark happening again. The following year, the State and Local Governance Act of 2006 was passed and abolished local government beyond the states and transferred many functions such as healthcare, education and transport from the states to the federal government, making the states essentially ceremonial. With practically all state government and most local governments exhausted, corporate-controlled and unable to resist, the act passed without a hitch despite the vast changes. Despite keeping the name, the European Federation was no longer a Federation.


A common sight in the drying countryside and plains of what was formerly known as Spain. Photograph taken and enhanced sometime in the late 2000s.

Europe in 2006 was fundamentally changed from what it was a decade ago. Resistance and anti-government sentiment was effectively banned. The Party of European Socialists was dominant and without significant opposition, with only the FulTec backed Greens and the now-minor conservative EPP and liberal ALDE, who would merge into the Democratic Alliance in 2011, acting as major but suppressed opposition. The LPUs spread fear and betrayal in the streets, eating up billions and billions of euros yearly, and unions collapsed en masse due to overly restrictive laws. “Food” was quickly turning into just “stuff” as desertification advanced, the nation fragmented and FulTec struggled to recover from 2003. The nation’s spirit was broken and rotting, and the government, reading the latest AoN climate reports, hurriedly prepared for the worst.

And things were going to get much worse than anyone would expect.

[1] The Migration and Border Control Act was voted for by a majority of the PES and all the NEF and EPP who hoped to see it as a vindication of their goals. The NSA was introduced later than the MBCA (near the end of the year) and was voted for by all parties that were not the far-right and left.
[2] The Piazza Maggiore and University of Bologna were also targeted.

     The politicians were coming there for a meeting about the growing water and desertification crises in Southern Spain. The bombing caused mass public backlash and soured public opinion on the ECL and far-left, being named the “Bologna moment” of the ECL.

There are no specific birth years, but they are considered to be from mainly the 60s and 70s and 80s if you stretch it. They were the main voting bloc that brought the left-wing to power among the democratic world and are more politically active and vote much more extreme than the average.

Section 2: When God Stumbles

Excerpt from “The Long Reach of Brussels: European War in the 21st Century”, by Marek Eisenwik, Oslo Press, 946 ASJ
