Introduction: The Fall of West Berlin and the End of the Cold War


The skyline of Berlin in 2000, suffocated by constant air pollution from nearby factories and wildfires. The Soviets placed many factories near the city’s border to increase pollution and ferment unrest in the city.

It was half past eleven at night in the city of West Berlin, on the 1st of August 2003. News of the general strike had spread here to the isolated enclave and many workers were skipping hours or not attending in protest. Soldiers stood guard by the newly rebuilt wall, on high alert as rumours of a Soviet invasion grew ever stronger and the wall became increasingly militarised. The once bustling city, a bright contrast to the dreary communist side, now looked indistinguishable, with heavy rationing and the general strike taking their immense toll, skyscrapers leering in the hot night. An oppressive atmosphere of dread and weariness pervasively hung around.

The city had fallen on hard times post-1988, as with the permanent oil shortage, transporting supplies to the city became vastly harder. The East German government was relatively friendly to the West German one, and initially assisted in transporting supplies and providing oil and trucks when things got dire, in exchange for extra funding and energy. Assistance stopped after the Federation was formed. West Berlin was one of the first cities to engage in rationing after the Crash, and the city suffered heavily, with food stocks being mostly depleted all the time and protests and riots being commonplace. At one point some West German officials considered even transferring the city to East Germany to use as a bargaining tool for possibly more resources, however with the Soviet Union becoming more totalitarian by the day and its increasing belligerence, they decided against it. The city, however, remained a weak point in Western Europe’s iron curtain and a key flashpoint for a great war to start, and there was no way for the European Federation to get rid of it. The only option was to continue supplying it and stop starvation from settling in, lest the Soviets gleefully seize the opportunity.

As a result of the food shortages and all the rioting, the police and army cracked down ever harder. With law enforcement jobs being relatively well-paying, the city’s economy hardly functioning, and the ever-present threat of a Soviet invasion, the police and army became by far the largest employers of West Berlin, making up 60% of jobs in the city by 2002. The city government became more separate and autonomous from the state and federal governments, and some people were choosing to recognise it as its own state in the Federation. It was becoming a police state as the government structure became ever more authoritarian and the city ever more militarised. By 2000, it was just a shadow, starving and dehydrated with limited food and water supplies, under frequent riots and with an increasingly militarised police force shadowing the streets, surrounded by an ever-growing border wall.

Everyone knew a Soviet invasion was imminent. More soldiers, tanks and artillery had been seen across the wall recently, and the local military was put on high alert. Ever since the incident of 1998, which accelerated the militarisation of the city, people had been on edge and the military had been ever-ready. With the ongoing general strike and looming collapse of the Federation, everyone thought it was the perfect time for the Soviets to strike if they wanted to, and take back this thorn in their side. And why would Europe, already in dire straits, risk a great war or nuclear catastrophe over this small enclave?

It was half past eleven at night, and the tanks rolled in.

In an instant, tanks blasted through every checkpoint on the Berlin Wall and explosions sounded across the city. Thousands of soldiers flooded through and overwhelmed the surprised and exhausted Western guards, gunning them down with ease and making their way through the unlit streets, encountering practically no resistance. In a few hours, beating even the Federation’s most pessimistic estimates, the city fell and the Wall was broken down in days. The once bright symbol of capitalism over communism and Western superiority had fallen and the Soviet flag was hung on Checkpoint Charlie and the old Reichstag.

International reactions were surprisingly muted considering the significance of the event. The United States released a strongly-worded statement condemning the Soviet use of “aggression and opportunism”, but took no actions aside, its relations with the Federation becoming increasingly frayed. The UK couldn’t be bothered to write a letter. The Federation itself couldn’t afford to take any action beyond writing a letter and giving an emotional speech in the Alliance of Nations - if it did, the consequences were very obvious. The Federation would never invoke Article 5, despite the invasion of their territory. Even with all the reasons and excuses given by NATO members on why they couldn’t do anything about the half-hearted calls for help, the true reason was blatantly obvious - lots of NATO’s members were crumbling at the seams already. Who would want to start a World War over the tiny and pitiful West Berlin? And so, despite a few calls from the more hawkish government members to try to retake the city, it never happened, and Berlin was united whole again, this time communist..

Five years ago, in 1998, a similar crisis occurred, but with quite a different resolution. On June 5, 1998, East Germany closed all land routes to the city and the Soviet Union piled up military forces on the border, leaving the city to be inefficiently supplied by plane for a few days. Panic quickly spread as fears of an imminent Soviet invasion rapidly developed, and NATO prepared for war. As tank standoffs developed and satellites caught images of giant military movements, the Federation, desperate to protect their territory and their reputation at the time of the Nordic War, took an option that few expected - they announced that any Warsaw Pact incursion into West Berlin would be met with a full-on nuclear strike. Worry and discussion spread in the USSR - were the Europeans bluffing? Their nuclear arsenal, which was a small size of around 500, would not cause nearly as much damage to the Soviets as they could do to them. However, there was the United States and their own colossal nuclear arsenal to worry about, and despite NATO relations becoming increasingly frayed, Cold War tensions had not gone away, and there was a good chance that NATO would collectively join in if Article 5 was invoked. For a few days, the world held its breath as both sides readied their nuclear arsenals and stood poised to blow up the world at any moment.

On June 12, 1998, sighs of relief blew as the European Federation and Soviet Union announced a deal to de-escalate the crisis - both sides would stand down their nuclear arsenals, in exchange for the European Federation removing their missiles from West Germany and Italy, and the Soviets promising to not invade West Berlin and withdraw missiles from East Germany, Poland and the former Czechoslovakia. Land borders to the enclave would also be reopened and Soviet foodstuffs were allowed to operate there at a small scale. The world had narrowly evaded nuclear disaster, still not knowing the horrors to come in the following years.

The ramifications of the events of 2003 would spread across the globe, broadcasting two new messages. NATO was practically dead, just a scrap of paper. And that the Cold War was finally coming to an end, to be replaced by something much worse in its stead.

---

The Red Summer of 2003 wrought devastation on FulTec. Farms across the nation failed, irrigation collapsed, protests and riots were breaking out every day and the Federation seemed to be hurtling face-first towards collapse. FulTec’s factories and farms were being burned to the ground by angry, exhausted workers who were sick of the oppressive and brutal work environment and lots of their workers simply did not turn up, or just escaped their living quarters. In the midst of all this, it was no surprise that profit projections for the second quarter of 2003 were catastrophic, showing a 30% loss - which ended up being wildly pessimistic, but showed the grim state they were in. In response, they were forced to rapidly downsize - and the first targets for cuts were their overseas departments - chiefly the UK, Scandinavia, and Greece.

The problem with this decision was that these countries, to varying scales, relied on FulTec’s products. FulTec sold large amounts of food there and was also pressured into manufacturing there, despite higher costs and restrictions due to stricter labour laws, to entrench their influence in the countries. In addition, they delivered water with help from the federal government to water-stressed areas, such as Greece, which was facing a growing water crisis by this time and relied on the Federation to help it survive. With the collapse of these connections and the overseas departments, thousands of workers lost their jobs overnight and countries lost lots of their food production, creating a small crisis for the summer. Superfarms were left unattended and valuable food supplies were stuck in warehouses or transport. The sudden withdrawal created large amounts of animosity in these countries towards the Federation that was never solved, and changed the politics and directions of these countries until their collapse. The UK had revived their foodstuffs industry and set themselves onto a collision course with the Federation. The Nordic Union suffered the same fate. Greece was set on a path of immense tragedy and collapse. For these countries, God had finally stumbled, and fate was crushed beneath it.

---

https://youtu.be/NeP-Zx7uqrE?si=B8MSmigyN9XTSd3E 

A Pawn on the Chess Board: Greece in the Red Decade, the Second Civil War, and Collapse


Athens, 1995. The city, facing severe water shortages and lethal levels of pollution, descended into crisis as the 90s rolled on. [1]

Almost twenty years of conservative dominance in Greece since the fall of the junta in 1972 [2] was wiped out in 1989 as the socialist PASOK gained almost a supermajority in the Greek parliament, with the radical left Synaspismos not far behind. The crash of 1988 had crushed Greece’s economy underfoot, as with over a quarter of its economy based on tourism, the collapse of the industry overnight wiped out lots of the Greek economy. During the Glorious Decades, the Greek economy stood to benefit massively from the surge in tourism and advancements in aerospace technology, and so based lots of its post-dictatorship growth around it. However, the country failed to diversify and its overreliance became its downfall as the Middle East went up in flames, and the new Konstantinos Karamanlis Airport near Athens became empty and abandoned.

The country would face yet more tribulation soon after as the Hot Summer of 1990 destroyed most of Greece’s forests and agriculture, blanketing Athens with a deluge of smoke. Food was quickly becoming unaffordable and as rationing began the country entered a major food crisis. Protests sprung up in the streets and the new Prime Minister’s claims that the previous government caused the crisis by not diversifying the economy and “letting pollution run free” only did so much. The crisis did not abate as more and more forest was destroyed with each passing year, the water ran dry, and as the science of the climate crisis became clear, the people realised that a major, perhaps catastrophic crisis was hitting Greece, one that it may never recover from.

In 1993, as one of the participants of the Brussels Conference and a member of the EU, Greece was given an opportunity to join the European Federation. The government was split on the issue - a large part believed the only way to save Greece from collapse was to join the richer Federation, but a large part remained skeptical of the EU and didn’t want Greece to “surrender itself” to the Federation. With large protests and surging extremism happening in the streets, the government, in a narrow vote, decided against joining the Federation, the consequences still being debated today.

Throughout the 90s, the food and water crisis kept getting worse, however, and things were reaching a tipping point. Political violence was growing and extremist parties were surging - the communist KKE kept performing increasingly well in elections and a cluster of far-right groups formed the AE (Independence and Freedom) party, which replaced New Democracy during the decade. Desperate for help and to avoid collapse, in 1997, as the infamous ‘Black Summers’ began, Greece reached out to the European Federation, practically begging them for help. The Federation, seeing great opportunity, agreed, and a trade deal was signed on June 1st. The Federation would provide Greece with large stocks of food and water, enough to stave off the food and water crises and keep the population satiated. In exchange, Greece would let Federation advisors into its government and allow European foodstuffs megacorps to operate mostly freely, the only major taker of this being FulTec. FulTec rapidly expanded, filling a wide-open hole in the Greek market and playing a key role in (temporarily) solving Greece’s food crisis. Manufacturing plants were opened as they pressured the Greek government into butchering their labour laws, prompting mass protests from the communists. Advisors pressured the government into adopting policies benefiting European companies, and the European Federation quickly took over the Greek government. “Political advisors” were sent over during election time and FulTec donated large amounts of money to the governing PASOK, pressuring it into passing laws severely restricting activities of opposition parties. PASOK went the same way as the PES in Europe, perhaps more extreme, as corporate donors and corporate-backed candidates flooded the party and changed its makeup in the span of a year. Greece was now a puppet, a dictatorship in all but name, too weak to rebel against its European overlords. The birthplace of democracy was now its grave. 

Why did the Federation do all this? Greece was a vastly poorer nation at this point, its economy shattered by the depression, and so the Federation saw it as an easy target to dominate, and it provided a perfect opportunity for its corporations such as FulTec to expand into. The other, perhaps larger, reason was that it was a great strategic point in the Mediterranean for the Federation to counter the expanding Soviets with. Greece had become simply a tool in the proxy wars.


A demonstration against the European Federation near the centre of Athens, photographed 1999.

The populace saw what was happening and got angry. Massive protests were held on the streets of Athens and other big cities daily. Extremist groups grew massively in membership and became armed, conducting terrorist attacks on European businesses in Athens and factories in the Pelopponnese. FulTec became a popular target and was forced to hire private militias to prevent the incredibly frequent attacks from succeeding. The people aimed to make Greece as inhospitable as possible for FulTec and Europe, to force them to see Greece as a burden and leave. Europe, however, would not let Greece go so easily. Dissent and extremists were brutally squashed, with members of extremist groups getting life sentences to newly-built megaprisons handed out like (now-extinct) candy, and even the death penalty at times. European and foreign businesses had gates built at the entrances and sometimes guards to stop them from being raided, although a boycotting campaign forced lots to leave in the coming years, and this highlighted clearly the colossal wealth disparity in Greece, with the Greek and European elite at the top lording over the masses of poor at the bottom huddled in Athens’s decaying suburbs. The Soviet Union was taking note of the events, and spotted Greece as a prime target for a revolution to occur shortly. It began funding the communist KKE, which had grown an unprecedented amount of support, and other affiliated communist groups, biding its time until the match was lit. The far-right saw less foreign support, but made up for it with popular support as more migrants washed up on Greece’s beaches, often to get to the Federation. The government was forced to pass legislation in 1999, like Europe did the following year, to ban the admittance of all refugees.

Despite all the unrest, things began to settle, and by the turn of the millennium, a status quo emerged, with extremism and bombings popular in the poorer areas, but being weak enough for the government to function properly. Greece had a steady supply of food and water, preventing the country from blowing up, and for a while, things carried on as normal. PASOK remained without significant opposition, with only the KKE and far-right AE as major opponents, and both had been discredited by scandals before - lots of the KKE’s leadership was arrested for connections to the Soviets and the burning down of a suburb in Thessaloniki, and AE was responsible for a massacre near the Acropolis which killed over 50 civilians. The government was finally somewhat stable.

And then the Summer of 2003 arrived.

With next to no notice, FulTec withdrew from Greece, evacuating its personnel and abandoning its factories and farms. The Greek government expected this to happen following the immense heatwave, which was already straining the country’s food and water production, but it was caught completely off guard by the timing and rapid pace of it. Farms were left rotting and factories were left abandoned, and the country suddenly lost a large chunk of its food output. A few days later, the Federation was forced to stop the majority of water exports, choosing to focus on conservation, and Greece was poised to enter a massive crisis. The Red Summer had not left Greece unscathed - a megadrought had started across the country and temperatures soared, leaving many people to die in the streets. Anti-Federation sentiment rocketed to record highs as people saw Europe to blame for the imminent “Κρίση των πάντων” and many people and extremist groups, who had been mocked before for hating the people that kept Greece alive, now felt validated. Just a week after FulTec left and exports stopped, Greece’s stockpiles ran out and food began to become scarce, and a month later inflation was surging to over 1000%. Unrest and mass demonstrations built up in the streets, and mass movements developed, spearheaded by the far-left and right, that grew to such a level that they threatened to overthrow the government. On the 23rd of July, the military marched in and, without a fight, took over the Greek government and declared martial law and extremely strict rationing laws. The protesting, and the violence continued, at an even larger rate than before, but now that the previous government was gone and as rationing was introduced, the people calmed down a bit, with many willing to wait until summer ended and exports resumed.

They never did.

Patience was low among the Greek populace, and a few months later, as Greece’s economy was on the brink of collapse and exports still hadn’t resumed, the truth dawned among everyone. The European Federation had been heavily impacted by the general strike and FulTec had taken giant losses. They were not in a position to continue to export to Greece for at least a year, despite promising exports to them would be a higher priority, hardly any came. Greece fell into chaos, as starvation took hold, rioting and looting took over the streets. Extremist groups ballooned and took over empty rural areas and towns destroyed by the heat and drought, and Greece’s economy and society was crumbling. The government could no longer maintain order, and became desperate. On the 9th of November, they begged the Federation for aid, warning of a Soviet invasion and the collapse of their country if this continued. The European government realised the risks and sent an “emergency aid package” to the country, consisting of (relatively) large amounts of food, water and money to delay the collapse, in exchange for even more European control and influence over it, such as the practical replacement of the Greek military with the European one, mainly with the addition of European Local Protection Units. The already humiliated Greek government accepted it without a second thought of the consequences, and relief was brought to millions of Greek citizens. For a month, the country held on, cautiously optimistic they would (barely) survive the crisis as Europe promised exports soon. That was until a government official, for whatever reason, left classified documents of Federation army integration on a bench on a warm day in December.

The backlash was immediate - while a few didn’t mind the deal as long as it saved their country, many were outraged, especially the extremists. The largest wave of violence yet came to Greece, and it was the straw that broke the junta’s back. Assassinations and bombings of government and civilian buildings became commonplace, and people panicked knowing a civil war was imminent. On Monday the 12th January 2004, a series of bombings took place across Athens, destroying many government buildings and killing the Ministers for Agriculture, Defence, and Finance, and almost the Head of State himself. The KKE soon claimed responsibility for the attack and announced the beginning of a “national revolution” against the government and Europeans. That same day, affiliated militias mobilised and in a coordinated and well-planned strike took over many towns and cities in the north of Greece, including Ioannina and Thessaloniki after a long fight and much of the region of Epirus. With a declaration of war, the Second Greek Civil War had officially begun. A day later, far-right militias, organised under the formerly political banner of Freedom and Independence, took over towns in the Pelopponese and parts of the north in a more rushed operation, declaring the formation of the Greek Homeland Army (ΕΣΠ) and also declaring war against the government and the communists. A few days later, Sparti was seized and Kalamata put under siege, held desperately by the government-aligned forces. Crete was taken over in weeks by communist militias who formed a “People’s Republic” there amid heavy resistance.

A week into the conflict, alarms blared on the Aegean Islands as Turkey marched into Chios, Lesvos, Rhodes and many others, with Greece unable to resist. The following week, soldiers landed on Cyprus and in an invasion lasting two days the island was seized and annexed by Turkey. No objections were made, as no one was in the state to make any. The long-awaited invasion had occurred and anticlimactically ended.


The Second Greek Civil War, January 28th, 2004, at the point where the frontlines start to become clear.

The Greek army was in a pitiful state - at first it had been ring fenced from cuts to protect against a likely Turkish or Soviet invasion, but as the financial crisis grew larger, cuts were forced to be made. The trade deals with Europe had created a false sense of security around the country, and so the government was more open to butchering its corpse, as well as the other branches of the Greek military. Equipment was never updated and often in disrepair. Corruption of all forms was endemic throughout the structure. The Europeans had also since November been integrating their units, including LPUs, which were ran very differently to most armies, and the process had caused intense division and conflict between the troops. All in all, it was an utter demoralised shitshow, and was anticipated to get razed against the less skilled but far more motivated communists and nationalists.

But surprisingly, they actually performed rather well.

Up north, on February 4th, the communists had launched an offensive, aiming to take the town of Kozani and move towards Thesalonniki to cut the government forces off there and link the communists in the city with them. The invasion had initially started well with large ground being made by the communists and panic in government forces. However, heavy rain, incorrect instructions being passed down the command chain, and a poor logistical operation led to the attack faltering and the government launching a successful counterattack, forcing the communists back down the decrepit E90, losing thousands of men in the process. The newly-formed Workers’ Revolutionary Alliance (ΕΕΣ) was overconfident with their recent gains, hoping that the opposing armies and the central government would collapse instantly once it began to threaten them, but the government did not do that. Their army mainly consisted of green volunteers and with the whole country already facing a severe food crisis it especially struggled to feed its troops, with many soldiers getting exhausted and collapsing, or deserting. The far-right ΕΣΠ suffered from similar problems and resorted to conscription in many areas. Many of the areas it controlled, however, especially in the south, were rural and depopulated as people flocked to Athens in the 90s, and were rapidly ageing, so as the war went on, manpower shortages developed on both sides.

The government forces suffered less of these problems and more of others. The European Federation was backing its army with fresh supplies - not enough for every one of the government’s men, but enough to give it a distinct advantage over its opponents. The Federation sent advisors over to help with logistics and organisation, and while rewards early on were limited, it began to pay off in later years as the other sides developed a supply crisis. However, a much greater crisis was developing in the government - legitimacy. The government was incredibly unpopular among the people, and despite the promises of a wage and three meals a day (whether that was given is debatable), it had trouble getting people to actually want to fight for them. Conscription efforts were often met with violence and lots of the major population centres had fallen to the communists, including much of Athens. The government also suffered from manpower shortages and its soldiers were often demotivated. The Federation was forced to help alleviate it by sending its own soldiers in and providing air support, which helped the government immensely, but there was bad blood between the Greek and European forces, and large unrest remained behind the lines. Citizens refused to help the war effort and sabotage attempts were common, with towns and villages banding together to defend the culprit.

Following the failed attack on Kozani, the communists tried a different approach. Later in February and throughout March, a large-scale attack was launched on Agrinio - the hope was to link the Epirus and Patras branches of the ΕΕΣ together. This attack was more successful - Agrinio was captured on March 16th and the government forces were forced to retreat into the mountains and down to Aitoliko and Missolonghi, facing encirclement of the communists crossed the Gulf of Patras (the bridge crossing it was blown up earlier that month). But the communists were overstretched, and an attempt to encircle and destroy the retreating government forces ended in failure as supply lines faced collapse. Many communist soldiers died and they were forced to retreat and hold out at Agrinio. Similar breakout attempts by the Patras branch, as they decided in April to march east towards Athens, but supply chain issues forced the attempt to be withdrawn later that month.

The Greek Homeland Army had little more success. In the south, government forces were desperately defending Kalamata from the ΕΣΠ’s relentless onslaught as brutal conflict took place on the E55. The ΕΣΠ aimed to take the highway and strangle the city to death, however that proved more difficult than anticipated, as their early conquests were relatively bloodless. It was suggested that the offensive be redirected towards Tripoli, however the suggestion was rejected and bodies piled up on the streets of Kalamata. On the 28th February 2004 Kalamata fell, but not with heavy casualties, mainly of the ΕΣΠ. Morale was quickly dropping - Kalamata had seemed like a pyrrhic victory, and so despite the successful linking of the south west and east of the ΕΣΠ, they needed more victories, and looked to Tripoli and Megalopolis for targets. Megalopolis was taken in late March relatively easily but Tripoli was well-defended by the government and bombings from the air forced the ΕΣΠ to retreat in early April. They were also fighting up north, and achieved far more success there. An operation was conducted in March to take Thessaloniki, as government forces were busy fighting the ragtag communist army in the city. The aim was to surround both the government and communists in Thessaloniki and cut their supplies, and for once, the operation was actually mostly successful, as by April, Thessaloniki was cut off. However, the ΕΣΠ lacked ships, and so supplies, though limited, were still transported to the city. Taking it proved harder than anticipated. Problems were occurring on the Eastern front, though. West Thrace had a strong garrison there anticipating a Turkish invasion, and their main opponent now came from the west instead of the east, as the ΕΣΠ attacked. But they had become overstretched, and after a few weeks of fighting against a far superior force the ΕΣΠ was forced to retreat, and an uneasy truce settled over the front.

The initial offensives had occurred, and the government held its ground. The ΕΕΣ and ΕΣΠ had been demoralised and the communists in the cities were fighting a losing battle. Athens in particular had turned into a warzone, with suburbs such as Exarchia [3] and the city of Piraeus being taken over by mainly anarchist militias. The government assigned Athens as high priority and the city was torn apart by brutal urban warfare as suburb by suburb the leftist camps and militias were destroyed and the army took control. In the process, fires started, and with the rushed and accelerated suburbanisation of the city, large portions of it completely burned down and became unlivable. It took until 2005 for resistance in Athens to be declared “extinguished” and for the city to be fully under government control, but by then only historical landmarks such as the Acropolis were spared, gazing over a city of fire, smoke and rubble.

Throughout the next few months limited gains were made on either side as unstable supply lines and frequent natural disasters compounded troop advances, with the only gains being made by the ΕΣΠ taking most of Thessaloniki at a high cost and the ΕΕΣ finally taking Kozani. Frequent fighting tore apart families, villages and livelihoods as all sides adopted a policy of scorched earth to prevent the other side from gaining ground. Europe continued to provide support for the government, escalating it in July as the war relentlessly dragged on, desperate for the Soviets to not get involved and for the communists to be defeated quickly. Large amounts of money and troops were sent into Greece, mainly to the north west. Old bombers blew up supposed military bases, which were more often not, and rumours of chemical weapon use spread. The government made gains in Epirus throughout the summer, threatening Ioannina, and the ΕΕΣ finally began to get worried. The USSR had offered initially to help them and quickly defeat the government before Europe intervened, but the leadership of the ΕΕΣ was old and arrogant and refused it, believing they could defeat them completely on their own. As the ΕΕΣ neared collapse, however, the proposal was first considered, and soon accepted as the ΕΕΣ leadership outright begged the Soviets for help. The Soviets were firstly unsure, worried the Federation would treat it as a declaration of war, and being not in the mood to start a nuclear war. But the Federation was already weak, Berlin was taken without a hitch, and their opportunity in Greece was about to fade, and on the 7th of September 2004, Soviet soldiers and tanks marched through Albania, Yugoslavia, and Bulgaria, all at once into Greece and the Federation started to panic. The Civil War had turned into a true Proxy War.


Government soldiers in Lamia defending a post, photographed December 2004

The first act of the Soviets following the invasion was to send soldiers into the ΕΕΣ headquarters and kill their leadership, replacing them with younger, more competent and opportunistic people, turning the organisation into a Soviet puppet. The USSR steamrolled into the north of Greece, wiping out the ΕΣΠ-North and the West Thrace Garrison before Turkey could act. Thessaloniki soon fell and the communist forces rapidly marched towards Athens, connecting the Epirus and Patras branches easily. The fall of the central government seemed imminent and the Federation panicked. In a moment reminiscent of the First Korean War and Vietnam War, the Federation passed the Greek Military Assistance Act of 2004, sending billions of euros and many more army divisions to land in Greece. A draft was enacted and hundreds of men were unwillingly sent to a nation they cared little for. Despite it being incredibly rushed, the  emergency deployment slowed and then stopped the Soviet advance in its tracks near Lamia. The Soviet advance was successful but lots of it was designed right before operation and ran off surprise and momentum, so the advance crumbled when faced with lots of resistance. A stalemate built in the northern front, vaguely comparable to the stalemate of the First World War.

Meanwhile, things were more optimistic for the government in the south. The ΕΣΠ had half of their forces and land destroyed and were financially and motivationally crippled. In the following few months European and Greek governmental forces took back Megalopolis and Kalamata, and took over the majority of the ΕΣΠ’s territory despite desperate resistance. The threat still remained, however - lots of the remaining ΕΣΠ forces fled into the countryside and out of view, working underground to sabotage the government. They were not truly expunged from Greece and would likely never be.

Both the government and communist sides were becoming entrenched, and with that the war became bloodier as 2004 became 2005. Costs piled up on both sides, as production costs for equipment, food and water costs, and others were continuously increasing and providing a drain to both Europe and the Soviets, and even more so the two opposing Greek governments. The war had stalemated, with both sides desperately trying to make tactical advances that would cripple the opposing side and force a surrender. Of course, that was incredibly wishful thinking and attacks were rebuffed by an equally well-equipped force on the other side, forcing a retreat and thousands of euros and rubles of lost equipment. Weapons of war were also changing, as with the immense global resource shortages, producing rifles and bullets were becoming increasingly expensive and so costs drained the finances of both superpowers. Infantry was the main tool, as tanks required too much oil and were too costly to run. Artillery was generally cheap enough to use, and so older 50s and 60s versions were operated on the battlefield, but one of the great tragedies of the war was the reintroduction of chemical weapons. They had already been used in the many conflicts of the developing world in the 90s and early 00s, including by China, but here was the first time outside of the invasion of Taiwan they were used on a large scale, as each side desperately tried to get an upper hand on the other. The attempt naturally failed and only led to far more death and suffering, but its use was never regulated and became more commonplace from there.

The other main stories were the growing anti-war movements as a result of the conflict. Protests in Russia against conscription were dealt with rather harshly (they were simply mowed down on the spot with a zeal previously unseen) but Europe hadn’t yet gotten into that level of depravity, and so anti-war and draft movements sprung up all over the place, in the cities, the political system and even the ruling government itself. The protests in 2005 and 2006, despite the deployment of the LPUs as a counter, were the largest since the strike of 2003, and rioting and draft dodging caused a great headache for the government. Many voices inside the government and establishment called for a de-escalation of the war, fearing mass unrest and a civil war in the Federation, and those numbers increased as the fighting continued. The Federation knew this was a losing battle, however, as Russia simply had more men, more factories and was just generally more powerful. Everyone in the government wanted a peace deal. But they knew the Soviets wouldn’t agree to one.

The trends continued throughout 2005 and 2006. The war had utterly stalemated and had turned into a repeat of World War 1. Both sides were becoming weakened and exhausted, with the Red Flu spreading to Greece in 2006 and causing mass deaths and desertion, and only in the middle of that year the two sides began to look for a peace deal. Negotiations took place firstly in Istanbul, then in Vienna and Warsaw. In all of those meetings, nothing was agreed, aside from maybe a reduction in nuclear weapon production that everyone knew wouldn’t be followed. Eventually, in November 2006 both sides, pressured with the spiralling costs and dissent, agreed to simply sign a truce. They would withdraw, and not interfere in the war at all. It was a tough pill to swallow for both, especially with Greece’s strategic importance, but both sides were forced to agree, and on January 28th, 2007 the Truce of Athens was signed, and Greece was left to itself. The Soviets and Europeans both withdrew all their military forces and aid spending from the country.

Greece, alone and abandoned, could only fight amongst itself. The country fell into ruin and with the constant megadrought it simply starved to death. The Civil War became not about ideology anymore, but about survival, as the government, the communists, the nationalists fractured and warlords took over the country. By 2010, the country was generally classified as a failed state, as the government only had a tenuous control of Athens and the surrounding area, with the rest being owned by militia groups or warlords in a state of constant fighting. The Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 16 destroyed the remaining organised governance that existed in the former nation as food and water ran out everywhere. The country, once famous for its history, culture and heritage sites, had lost it all to the destruction of imperialism and climate change, and became just another footnote in the Death of the Old World.

https://youtu.be/T9tdQROP8sA?si=TQX6dH4TihBtAhgU 

A Beacon of Democracy and Instability: Scandinavia in the 90s and the formation of the Nordic Union

Scandinavia [4] had weathered the climate apocalypse much better than most countries. Its climate was much cooler than the south of the continent, had a much lower frequency of natural disasters than lots of the world, and could grow food when much of the world couldn’t. The region as a result was far less unstable and less prone to corporations and strongmen seizing power and so kept its liberal and democratic traditions into the 2010s. There was of course lots of envy and people trying to reach it as a result, but an incredibly strict border policy since the late 90s prevented that from happening.

That did not mean its countries were not heavily affected by the Crash of 1988. Sweden, Denmark and Finland especially faced economic collapse as the price of oil surged and underwent rationing around the same time as the EU did.The Hot Summer affected them more than other countries in Europe as lots of their forest burned up and cities were drenched in wildfire smoke, causing a spike of respiratory illnesses. Norway, however, fared among the best of all the Nordic countries with its large oil reserves. They sold oil to many countries around the world, mainly the European Union, and despite the economic decline caused by the aftermath of the Sinai War and the collapse of its Sovereign Wealth Fund, they were one of the only economies to experience actual economic growth during the 90s. The country provided financial support to the other struggling Nordic countries and ties between them increased a lot as without being in any pact or alliance, they were forced to band together to survive.

Negotiations for a “Nordic Union” had started in the early 90s, at first about an economic alliance between the four countries to help them weather the depression. Negotiations were going well until the advent of the Brussels Conference in 1993, in which Denmark was invited as a participant. It was narrow, but the government of Denmark believed that joining the European Federation would be more beneficial than the Nordic Economic Union, and so bid farewell to the dream, completely unaware of what it had gotten itself into.

Discussions were initially economic, but as the Soviets and Chinese continued their wars of conquest across the world, and as the Soviet Army piled up on the Finnish border, discussion very quickly shifted to a defensive alliance alongside, and then a political one, with proposals being made for a complete union of the three countries. There was still strident opposition to it, the majority of it coming from the still-relatively-powerful right-wing forces and the growing far-left, so the proposal for a complete union didn’t get anywhere at first, most discussion being centred around a NATO-esque defensive alliance. In February 1996, the first of many agreements was signed in Stockholm, which was the formation of the “Nordic Economic Union” between Norway, Sweden and Finland, involving the formation of a free trade zone between those countries and a system to assist in development projects and transfer financial aid. The agreement produced optimism across the region, especially in Finland, whose people believed it was a stepping zone for a defence agreement which would save, or at least help protect the country from invasion.

A year and ten months later, these thoughts were brought to rest.


A Soviet tank division drives through roughly the south of Finland, photographed February 1998. Despite it being winter, hardly any snow fell, likely due to the effect of the Black Summers of 1997 and 98.

The Nordic War began on December 4th, 1997 as the Soviet Union invaded Finland without warning. Finland was ready, they had been ready for years now and already had experience fighting the Soviets in the 1939-40 Winter War. Tensions between the USSR and Finland were already incredibly high, the USSR had been distributing propaganda leaflets on the border encouraging soldiers and citizens to defect and join the richer and less starved Soviet Union. Finland had also been taking actions, and while they weren’t anywhere near as big as what the Soviets claimed, they had been performing troop maneuvers close to the border and broadcasting messages on loudspeakers. Negotiations for a defence agreement had taken longer than expected and became drawn out, with the Soviets seemingly seizing the opportunity to invade before the signing. Of course, Norway and Sweden still had the option to join the war and assist Finland, but in the end the governments decided against it, fearing occupation and the loss of their relative prosperity and men. They instead supported Finland financially, disguising their military aid packages as humanitarian aid and militarily, sending weapons alongside those packages.

The initial phase of the war was incredibly bloody, as Finland desperately tried to hold back the Soviet advance, with some success. At the southern border the Soviets were stopped past Lappeenranta, and limited progress was made up north. The major move of the Soviets, however, was an attack in the centre of the front, aiming to cut Finland off in the middle, distract their troops and launch a large strike downwards to take Helsinki. The plan worked as expected for the first few months of the war, with the Soviets making large gains, but those gains slowed as muddy terrain slowed down the Soviet Army. The war seemed to be set to drag on for a while. The USSR then made the decision to simply grind Finland down by attrition - after all, Finland was one nation, despite the help of Sweden and Norway - and the Warsaw Pact was many, and the Soviet Union much stronger. Taking Helsinki was given the utmost importance, as the Soviet troops on the south slowly marched west, taking enormous casualties in the process. The other strategy the USSR used was to blockade Finland. The main effect was to stop Sweden and Norway from sending support and intercepting their aid boats, which Finland, despite not admitting it, was generally relying on to stop the Soviets. After a Swedish merchant vessel was almost sunk off the coast of Gotland in July that year, both nations decided to stop sending aid for the fear of getting involved and sanctioned, or even possibly conquered.

Finland was unable to survive for long without Swedish and Norwegian aid and implemented strict rationing policies to hold on for as long as it could. However, dissent built up in the streets as a result and defections occurred in border towns to the more stable Soviet Union, where they at least could get a decent meal. Fearing revolution, in November 1998 the military stepped in and bloodlessly took over the government, enacting harsh conscription policies and sending every man they could to the frontline. However, the new and remaining soldiers were exhausted and unmotivated, and the Soviet advance to the capital quickened. On the 3rd June 1999, Helsinki fell to the Soviets and two weeks later, on the 19th, the Helsinki Treaty was signed, ending the war and transferring control of Finland to the Soviet Union. Initially it was under a communist Finnish-run government but on November 21st it was fully annexed by the Soviet Union, transforming it into the Finnish SSR.

The detractors of the idea of a complete union between the Nordic countries were utterly silent after the war.

Plans and talks were accelerated and Sweden and Norway made the formation of a true “Nordic Union” the first thing on their agenda. Negotiations were hard and it was often difficult to get the countries to agree to things but the threat and fear of a Soviet invasion like what was done to Finland helped them bypass these, and on the 9th July 1999, a month after the signing of the Helsinki Treaty, the governments of Norway and Sweden announced, by the turn of the millennium, the formation of the Nordic Union of Sweden and Norway, a formal uniting of the two countries. The country would basically be a loose federation, with the individual governments having large amounts of power. There would be not one singular leader, but two heads of government and state, one from Sweden and one from Norway. The heads of governments would be elected by each individual Parliament and the heads of states would be the monarchs of each individual country. It would be a very unique system born out of immense compromise in the fear of invasion - the only functions controlled by the nonpolitical federal government would be defence and related research and industry, and foreign affairs. In case of a “federal emergency” such as an invasion Article 4 of the Federal Constitution could be activated which would transfer most power to the nonpolitical federal government so that the emergency could be handled more effectively.

In the beginning there was vast optimism about the agreement, with the majority being in favour, and on September 2nd symbolic referendums were conducted in the two countries, with 63% being in favour in Norway and 68% in Sweden, which were narrower margins than expected, but still substantial victories and enough justification to unite. On the 20th February 2000, after some delays to finalise the agreement, the Nordic Union of Sweden and Norway was formed. Initial proceedings went smoothly - the heads of the Swedish and Norwegian militaries formed their defence cabinet out of their preferred members of the militaries (an advisory council was formed as to not let nepotism and corruption take precedence), and elections on March 3rd resulted in the dominant Social Democratic Party of Sweden and Norwegian Labour Party keeping power. The Union would vote 69-31 to join NATO on April 11th.


The flag of the Nordic Union of Sweden and Norway (big credits to u/JebbyFanclub on this post love the flag)

The optimism did not last for very long.

Looking at the 2000 Nordic elections, some disturbing trends were revealed. The centre-right had practically collapsed, alongside most of the moderate left, and in their place extremism rose. In Norway, the right-wing Progress Party made record gains and displaced the Conservatives, and the Red Electoral Alliance scored record results, taking many voters from the more moderate Socialist Left. In Sweden, the Swedish Democrats reached record highs, despite not displacing the Moderates yet, they were getting close, and the newly radicalised Left were surging. [5] The reasons why were not obvious at first, but soon became clear - many people were stridently and loudly opposed to the Nordic Union. The centre-right were “somewhat opposed” but ended up accepting it, angering many of its old voters and causing a giant shift to the far-right, and on the far-left, concerns were brewing about the newly moderate turn of the centre-left to gain new moderate voters, and additionally due to a dislike of the Nordic Union, the far-left gained heavily at moderate left’s expense.

A criticism of the Union among many was also that it didn’t go far enough. The two states were still mainly separate, with them controlling the vast majority of functions, and a defensive alliance would have been broadly the same. The structure of the Union seemed like a compromise, and while people were happy with it at first, it did not take long for people to point out the flaws and grow sour on it. The compromise structure truly pleased nobody - people in favour of the Union wanted it to go further, and people against it claimed there was no point in having it exist, and that all it did was weaken the countries’ sovereignty and provide more precedent to weaken it further.

For a few months, the Nordic dual governments worked as usual with minor incidence, until an ugly issue reared its head again - Europe.

The much more powerful European Federation had been constantly suffering under heatwave after heatwave throughout the 1990s. Crop failures were common and as the natural food market precipitously declined, the foodstuffs industry filled the gaps and became incredibly powerful. The biggest beneficiary was FulTec, which consisted of a majority and growing part of the foodstuffs industry, and was expanding past the Federation. Scandinavia wasn’t the perfect place for growing food - the Nordic Union had a minor food crisis themselves, but its cooler climate and relative safety from climate disasters (aside from wildfires) meant that it was one of the better places for agriculture in this new world. FulTec in the late 90s began to invest heavily in creating new farms and buying land in Sweden and Norway. This of course was not appreciated by the public and the governments, especially due to reports of human rights violations on these new superfarms, and so both countries passed new anti-monopoly laws to stop their overexpansion into the emerging Nordic foodstuffs markets. Europe protested this, and in 1998 sent ships to the Swedish coast to attempt to blockade the country. However, Europe had just been through the Channel Crisis with the United Kingdom, and with relations already frayed, decided not to overextend itself just yet and withdraw the blockade.

Europe’s food situation was marginally improved by 2000, helped by the new agreements with the UK, but the country wanted to prepare in case mass drought or a giant heatwave occurred. The country then looked to the newly formed Nordic Union, and decided action must be taken. On June 21st, 2000, while on a training exercise, a European warship spotted a Nordic merchant vessel close to crossing in the middle of it. Not knowing what the ship was, and fearing they would be attacked, in a moment of irrationality, the warship fired on the vessel and destroyed it, at least that’s how the story went. Every container ship of every country was valuable in these times, and so the Nordic Union demanded explanations from the European Federation - why they blew up their vessel without warning or any attempt at contacting the ship, and why they were holding a training exercise right next to Nordic waters without notice. Europe gave its arguments, but they were feeble and everyone knew that, and was soon threatening the Union to alter its trade routes in the North Sea, or face war. They refused, and the Nordic Union moved a fleet of ships into the North Sea near Denmark as a show of force. Europe followed suit, and a standoff developed. Panic built up in the Union, fearing they would go the way of Britain, but also not wanting to provoke a war, as they knew they would be quickly defeated. Just a few months in, the Nordic Union was already facing an existential crisis, and the dual governments were unprepared to deal with all of this.

Europe then decided to take things a step further - a week following the standoff, the Norwegian coast was surrounded by European warships bristling with guns. A blockade was threatened, unless the Nordic parliament could negotiate its way out and to a more favourable trade position with Europe. The Nordic government was forced to cave, and details of a trade deal would soon be released. The labour laws of the Norwegian and Swedish governments would be heavily weakened, for instance, work safety and overtime protocols would be butchered. The laws on the operation of foreign companies in the Union would also be weakened, giving FulTec much more room to expand, and the deal would force the Federation to make up a majority of the Union’s imports, despite already making up a large plurality. The people of the Union unanimously opposed the bill, launching massive protests in Oslo and Stockholm reaching close to two million people in total, some even escalating to riots. Every party in the parliaments was critical, the far-right and left especially so, and extremist support grew rapidly following. The social democratic governments of both the nations emphasised it was necessary to avoid war and an even worse situation, but that generally fell on deaf ears. A record wave of anti-Federation sentiment swept the country and fundamentally changed its culture, economy, and politics.

International response was limited. Britain released a harsh statement condemning the European acts, having been through this some years before, but was unable to do anything but watch. The United States was ambivalent and Canada sympathetic but generally uncaring. The Nordic Union had realised, just months after joining NATO, that its true enemies were not outside of it, but inside all along.

The years of 2001 and 2002 were dominated by unrest and rioting, a new thing for the Union mostly due to its better food and water situation. It was not reaching the same levels as the Federation down south but terrorism was still common, mainly against FulTec. As in many countries, factories were blown up and farms burnt down and private guards released gunfire, trying to defend the giant superfarms as much as possible. The Federation ideally would have been able to place its own soldiers in the nation to defend the farms but that was a red line for the Union and also would have led to civil war, so it never happened. Government buildings were also commonly attacked by extremists as well as the headquarters of large European businesses. Despite the unrest most of them stayed, as Scandinavia was a uniquely powerful economy to invest in with its better climate and stability compared to countries such as Greece, where most left. The Union would continue trudging on, slowly falling apart as violence and disagreement began to break it. That was until the summer of 2003, when Europe was burned alive and Scandinavia regained its freedom once more.

FulTec had already pulled out of Greece and the UK following the Red Summer but it was hesitant to do so in the Nordic Union. The comparatively low levels of violence compared to the former two and much better climate and amount of land for growing food made it a much larger food producer for the Federation, with most of its non-Federation based food being grown there, as well as being the only place it could get readily-available somewhat natural food, despite the low yields. However, as the Federation was weaker than ever, the Nordic Union sprang into action, revoking the universally hated trade deal on the 1st of July and barring FulTec from operating there on the same day, seizing control of its superfarms and factories. Europe was outraged but powerless and had far more pressing concerns at the time. The Nordic Union now had freedom, for the first time in years, and it would not waste it.

Dusk turns to Night: The United Kingdom in the 90s and early 00s

https://youtu.be/nE0azgwzRQc?si=07CIOD6t2Z-YyPZi 

The 1989 general election was an utter wipeout for the British Conservative Party, falling into third place behind the Liberal Democrats as Labour gained a colossal majority in the House of Commons. The Conservatives were crushed on all sides, having lost any support they originally had in the north over deindustrialisation and the privatisation of the NHS [6], and having lost the south to the Liberals over the economic collapse. Like others in Europe, despite development of North Sea oil and gas over the past few years, the UK’s economy was still heavily impacted by the jump in oil prices and the economy fell into ruin within months.

Labour spent its first year reversing much of the neoliberal policy of the previous 19 years of Conservative government, maintaining high approval ratings throughout, however, their honeymoon was disrupted by the 1990 Hot Summer. Most of the UK didn’t suffer from severe wildfires like much of the world due to its relatively low tree cover, however, record forty-degree heat hit the country and the most severe drought ever encroached, making reservoirs run dry and burning up massive amounts of crops. Crisis emerged as famine hit the country and the UK, being a food importer, struggled to meet demand for food, and to a lesser extent, water. The government struggled to keep order as the famine led to an immense crime wave and sprees of looting, stretching the police to its limits. However, it was doing much better than many other countries, such as Spain and Italy who suffered from much worse famines and were quickly falling into chaos. The situation in the UK and much of Europe was moderately alleviated by support from other nations, mainly the United States and Canada, who sent shipments of food to stop it from falling to revolution (as even to the isolationist President Graves, a collapsed Europe was not something America could afford). But that did not stop the Prime Minister’s announcement of the beginning of rationing, a policy that ended up never being reversed.

Britain had survived, and was arguably doing better than most of Europe, but faced ever more chaotic weather as the 90s marched forward, chiefly rain and flooding. The weather got increasingly difficult to predict, especially as the Met Office was strapped for funds - you could have torrential rain one day, the next crippling sun and heat, and storms were also getting more extreme. These events caused damage and destruction to many communities, but the main destroyer was flooding. Many towns and cities in the south and north suffered frequent, intense floods every year, ruining the local economy and causing many to leave to more elevated areas, but arguably the city that suffered the most was London. The city had already been struck by floods throughout its history, but this time they were reaching a new level, the Thames Barrier struggling to hold against the rushing water. The barrier, operational since 1983, was not built for the rapidly rising sea levels in the 90s, and so a new system was planned in - colloquially called the “Thames Wall”, which was designed to protect the city theoretically for sea levels at four degrees of warming, though many doubted it could. Construction began in 1993, but the project quickly became immensely costly, reaching into the billions of pounds, and with the extreme weather, progress was slow and work dangerous. Despite putting the project at high priority, the British economy had been facing a fiscal crisis and immense budget cuts since 1991, and struggled to find new revenue to fund the project. Seeking to cut costs, wages of the workers were kept low, and that became a grave issue when strikes broke out in 1995 over the terrible working conditions on the Wall, halting work for a crucial few months. Negotiations soon reached an agreement involving an above-inflation pay rise (which was key when looking at the incredibly high inflation since 1988) and safety measures to be put in place, but that drove up the cost immensely, and in 1996 the project was mostly shelved, with around half of it to be built in the end and small extensions to be implemented over time. These half-measures were simply not enough and London faced a catastrophic flood in 1999 which overwhelmed the new barrier completely. Many poor neighbourhoods in East London were devastated - thousands of homes and flats were destroyed and the reconstruction costs were immense, far too much for the government to pay. It was yet another symbol of the growing class divide in the nation, and those worst affected did not have the funds to move out to safer areas.


The aftermath of the Flood of 1999 in Barking, London. The area was relatively poor and working-class, and so its inhabitants disproportionately suffered compared to other areas.

It was not only East London that was affected - the financial centre was, too, and the impacts of that were perhaps more devastating for the country. Despite the precipitous decline of the world’s finance sectors, the centre of London still held great importance to the national economy, and the flooding of 1999 damaged that immensely as many major buildings and centres despite the protection were flooded. In light of all this, London’s national importance was declining, and other cities which were less flood-prone and had cooler climates were regaining their status once more, which had been stolen from them as British manufacturing collapsed in the 80s and London’s financial clout rose exponentially. Assets were being moved to Manchester, factories were rebuilt near Liverpool and Leeds, and coal mines were dug near Sunderland and Wakefield, to give a few examples. Population shifts were occurring at a great rate as people fled London and other low-lying cities in the south (and north) to stabler cities, where manufacturing was growing and employment prospects far more optimistic. London, with its decaying suburbs, constant flooding and dirty slums [7], had practically lost its place in the sun by the 90s, and the 1999 flood sealed its fate. The city continued on a steady decline throughout the years, though it still remained the nation’s capital due to the large costs of changing it. The sudden capital and demographic shifts did not come without their problems, though - the influx of people led to housing shortages, and while things were not as bad as in many American cities, the conflict arising from these shifts became brutal, and at this point, one major comes into play that helped define the UK’s chaotic political scene in the 90s and 00s - immigration.

The government position on immigration during the early 70s was generally strict, with the introduction of legislation such as the Immigration Act 1971 and the earlier Commonwealth Immigration Acts providing heavy restrictions on generally non-white immigrants. As the neoliberal faction took power in the landslide of 1977, however, things began to change quickly. Britain’s economy was booming following the signing of the Shanghai Accords, and construction of new suburbs and other city developments led to large amounts of job creation. Britain’s birth rate wasn’t as high as the United States but it was relatively so compared to the rest of Europe, and there were plenty of workers to fill the gaps, but additionally with the expansion of the university system [8], British workers preferred to go into more white-collar jobs. The government soon spied an opportunity to fill these places - immigrants. With the passage of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1981 among others, restrictions on immigration were relaxed and numbers increased rapidly. This came with caveats, including racism and the concentration of them in specific areas (as a result of the racism they basically group together), but they were able to integrate sort of successfully over the years. 1988 came and went, however, and many people suddenly found themselves out of jobs. On top of this, large numbers of refugees were flooding in from the Middle East, which soon began to increase tensions. The refugees were never able to find jobs mainly due to racism and generally being less skilled than many Brits or 80s immigrants but that did not stop them from being scapegoated and targeted for attacks. The refugees also failed to integrate and ended up being clustered either in camps or claustrophobic, moulding housing in city centres.

The new Labour government was suffering with the constantly recessing economy and approval ratings were dropping, and to save their popularity they targeted a group they knew was unpopular and everyone disliked - of course, the immigrants. In an infamous 1992 speech, the Prime Minister called the 80s immigrants “sickening offspring from the vile Conservatives” and blamed the new refugees and 80s immigrants for “stealing jobs from our proud British men” and announced they would pass laws to restrict entry and job applications for immigrants. The speech and policy (depending on who you speak to) utterly backfired, as sharp criticism was drawn from most parties and soon the outright hostile environment led to mass unemployment among immigrant communities. They quickly turned to desperation, and desperation turned to violence, as rioting overtook the inner cities of London, Birmingham, Leeds and many others. It wasn’t only the immigrants taking part, but young, socially liberal voters who had enough of the blaming and distractions of the Labour government, and this helped create yet another threat to Labour - the economically and socially far-left Greens, who in local elections next year made great gains in city centres. The violence also led to divisions among the immigrant communities themselves - many 80s immigrants resented the Middle Eastern refugees who they believed caused the violence against them, leading to infighting between them. Perhaps the worst consequence of all was the rise of a horrifying, new force on the fringes of the far-right - the British National Party.


The burning of a tower block in Brixton as a result of a BPF riot in the area. Photographed 1996.

The BNP were initially near insignificant, winning just 0.2% of the vote in the 1984 general election, but the people had now been pushed to desperation, and the rioting and chaos had provided new energy and ammunition for the party. They gained 116 seats in the 1993 local elections, mainly in city centres and the East of England, which was their base. Coastal erosion and immense flooding had devastated many communities there and despite the area having hardly any immigrants, the already-broke right-wing people were quick to blame them and so underwent mass radicalisation to the BNP. The same year, massive anti-immigrant protests and riots took place primarily in Essex and Lincolnshire, and backlash was underway. The government took action to suppress the growing Far-right, who took up arms [9] in response and formed the British Patriot Front paramilitary in late 1994, naming themselves after the recently formed National European Front. The BPF was of course banned by the police and was labelled as a terrorist group following several bombings in Leicester, but remained a significant underground force and caused havoc in many cities like their European cousins. Alongside the IRA (which will be discussed in the Britain interlude), the BPF regularly conducted bombings and stabbings and even lynchings on the city streets, mainly operating in the newly-built labyrinthine central slums. The cities of Britain suffered from terrorist attacks weekly, the phenomenon becoming a new normal to the weary people. A cat-and-mouse game was played between the government and the BPF for several years, the police receiving budget increases (revolutionary for the 90s!) while all other sectors continued to suffer under the boot of austerity. Despite the existence of the BPF, the BNP, buoyed by race riots but also by the increasingly heavy austerity, was gaining support, winning several seats in the 1994 and 1999 elections and coming into the mainstream of British politics. The government knew something would have to be done, but there were no pleasant options, and “drastic action” would have to wait until later.

Despite the consequences, however, it could be argued that the immigration backlash helped the Labour government, providing a distraction from economic woe and the chaotic climate, preventing them from falling further in the polls despite the split left-wing vote. Better for them for the press to be focused on deportations rather than benefit cuts, after all. [10]

Above even immigration, flooding and the collapsing economy, the biggest issue defining British politics during the 90s was definitely the European Federation and fishing rights.

What the UK needed most during the 90s and every following decade was food. The Hot Summer was devastating to British agriculture and during that time it was forced to rely on US and Canadian exports. These were not enough for the long-term and so the British government put in provisions and policy to expand the food supply. One of those was the expansion of fishing and the expansion of the area that the UK could fish, which caused great ire in the European Federation, who was also suffering from similar problems and didn’t want the UK to get ahead. Another point of conflict was related to foodstuffs. The Labour government had introduced strong anti-monopoly laws following their election and as a result British foodstuff companies which emerged in the mid-90s were numerous and constantly in competition with each other, unlike in the US and Federation where one company dominated over all. In the Federation, FulTec was growing and wished to expand, and saw the UK as fertile ground with it’s competitive environment, believing it could easily steamroll over the smaller companies with it’s money and power. Operations in Britain thus began in 1995 and continued for some years. FulTec regularly used underhanded tactics to gain an advantage - they often bribed other companies, used force to take over farms and breached labour laws by paying their workers far below the minimum wage (these workers were often refugees forced from the streets). Naturally, the British government despised this intrusion, and FulTec’s tactics were practically an open secret, but there was not yet enough evidence to prosecute the company, and Europe was likely to fight back hard against that. That all changed when an MI5 investigation combined with an “accidental” documents leak led to FulTec losing millions of euros in a court challenge and being forced to heavily scale back operations in the country. Europe challenged this but failed, and the Federation and the UK’s relations grew ever worse, and a conflict began to loom.

https://youtu.be/0Yt0ffGB2qg?si=qeKyzx8B5qd4ANVo 

Tensions came to a head on September 22, 1997 when a group of fisherman in the English Channel accidentally strayed slightly beyond the dividing line for where each country could fish, and came into contact with some European destroyers. They fired on the fisherman in response, threatening them to go away, but for a currently unknown reason (theories include strong currents or some miscommunication), the fisherman did not retreat and went towards the destroyers. Four fishermen were killed in the incident and four more taken hostage - the UK responded with outrage and demanded the fishermen be returned - the Federation had finally gotten a bargaining chip and planned to use them to gain concessions out of the UK, chiefly weaker labour laws and an expanded fishing zone. The idea the UK would agree to negotiations was a fatal assumption and the Royal Navy was deployed in the Channel the following day, surrounding a similar group of European destroyers and planning to do so until the fishermen were returned. It was an incredibly risky move, and the magnitude of it was displayed when, in a moment of panic, one of the European destroyers opened fire and damaged a British cruiser. At that moment it was clear to all that European-British relations would never be the same again.


One small misfire could lead to millions dead.

Miraculously, all ships held their fire, everyone unwilling to go to war over some fishermen. For a day the European ships remained surrounded and the Channel became swarmed with warships from both sides, all preparing for war. It was close, but at the last minute secret negotiations mediated by the United States led to the end of the crisis and the withdrawal of ships from the Channel. The official agreement was soon finalised and signed in neutral Dublin on January 4, 1998. It was a lot more comprehensive than was described, but the major headline-grabbing provisions were that the English Channel would be demilitarised and made a neutral zone, and that the UK would have more sea to fish in in exchange for the Federation having more sea to move their ships in. The agreement did temporarily defuse UK-EF tensions and set the stage for peace until 2003, meaning that in some eyes it was successful, at least as much as it could be for these times. However it was blatantly rushed out, with both sides appearing dissatisfied at many of the provisions, and many considered that to be part of the reason for the brutal subjugation of the country seven years later.

But for the five years between what became known as the Channel Crisis and the Red Summer, things were relatively peaceful between the UK and the Federation. Seeing the country as too powerful and worrying about the start of a great war, the Federation decided against taking further action against the UK - FulTec was at least operating in it. They preferred to go after the newborn, weaker and more arable Nordic Union instead. Despite some minor crises and incidents the Dublin Agreement held and the Channel remained neutral.

On the home front things were also growing calmer through these years. The government was fighting a protracted war against the BPF, and in response introduced lots of “anti-terror” legislation, significantly boosting the power of the police and security apparatus. Many criticised these laws as “dystopian” and lots of it came from the budget cuts made to pass it, however, whether by fault of the laws or not, in 1999 a major BPF cell was infiltrated and destroyed, capturing and killing lots of the group’s leadership. A domino effect began and soon the majority of the group’s cells and membership were destroyed and arrested, providing a killing blow to the organisation in what was called Britain’s most successful anti-terror operation ever. The operation also had the effect of associating the anti-terror laws with it, significantly increasing their popularity and setting the UK on the slow path to a surveillance state. The BNP suffered a drop in support as well as a result, and Labour’s position finally seemed somewhat stable. The UK also in 2001 finally started negotiations with Ireland over Northern Ireland, seeking to put an end to the IRA’s continuous violence that had been occurring since the 70s. Things were slowly beginning to look up.

Then 2003 arrived and brought the Red Summer with it as London experienced lethal 45 degree heat, the first instance ever recorded. Thousands were dropping dead as the nation was completely unequipped to deal with the heat and catastrophe emerged as in much of Europe. The nation was lucky to have lots of its agriculture moved up north, however, and so unlike Europe the UK did not have a major food crisis and was able to keep food prices from spiking too high. FulTec, heavily damaged by the summer, wanted to stay but found the hostile environment too much of an impediment for the increased production to be worth, and so withdrew completely in July, and with the Federation on the verge of collapse, the British Prime Minister gave a speech, announcing that the Dublin Agreement was “null and void” and that he would ensure the Federation would never pose a threat to the country again. The following day, British ships filled the Channel in a show of force, and the Federation could do nothing but watch and plot revenge.
