One Last Gasp of Freedom: Northern Europe following the Red Summer, and the formation of NAFTA

Both the UK and the Nordic Union were swept with anti-European fervour following 2003. Perhaps the biggest targets were businesses - the European-owned ones were often larger, richer and dominated over the few remaining smaller local ones. This didn’t hurt the local citizens but them being foreign and more powerful made them an easy target for the people, and most were shut down or outright destroyed following 2003. The Red Summer had sort of created a feeling of newfound freedom among the British and Scandinavians (moreso among the latter), and nationalistic sentiment took over. Incumbent parties were heavily boosted - in the UK, an early election in 2004 led to Labour winning over 430 seats due to a “rally around the flag” effect, and the incumbent socialist governments won again in Sweden and Norway in the same year, working with all other parties in “Government(s) of National Unity”. New problems awaited these countries, though, with the Federation, if it didn’t collapse, almost certain to come roaring back with a vengeance, among many others, and the two nations realised cooperation was necessary to survive in this brave new world.

A major issue resulting from the withdrawal of FulTec was food production. The problem was less in the UK, where FulTec had been restricted by strong anti-monopoly laws, but was more acute in the Nordic Union where FulTec had been allowed to control large amounts of the foodstuffs and agricultural industry. As FulTec withdrew, it abandoned the farms and factories it had been operating, and many were not reopened in time or were sabotaged, becoming useless. Later research showed this had increased (avg.) food prices by around 20% in the UK, and 45% in the Nordic Union and it took until late 2004 for them to fully recover. To fill up the gap, domestic-owned agriculture was expanding, but not fast enough, and to alleviate the shortage, trade was expanded. On the 26th September 2003, it was announced in Bergen that the North European Free Trade Area (NEFTA) would be formed between the UK, Nordic Union and later Ireland, and would cover most vital products, mainly food. The North Sea was now fully under control by British and Scandinavian ships as the Federation was still recovering from the Red Summer, so trade was easy and quick, with warships often helping transport things themselves and often escorting container ships. Another part of the deal was the agreement of the equal division of the North Sea between the two for the use of fishing, which was still seen as viable despite the immense decline in fish populations. Foodstuffs companies were also looking to the seas by this time as new ideas were coming to fruition. NEFTA worked well and despite some domestic criticism helped stabilise the situations in the two countries. Another trade opportunity, however, revealed itself the following year - the large and agriculturally fertile nation of Canada.


A cargo ship crossing the Northwest Passage, pictured January 2005. The rapid melting of the Arctic led it to become a viable trade route between Europe and Canada, as more crops were being grown in the country’s north.

Canada had been heavily impacted by 1988 but, like Scandinavia, had weathered the climate crisis fairly well. Its cooler climate allowed more crops to be grown and was opening vast amounts of land for agriculture, meaning it could afford only a small foodstuffs industry and could still feed almost all of it’s population with natural food, a rarity in most countries. The nation wished for a market to sell it to, and struggled to find opportunity - relations with the United States had been precipitously declining in the past few years, the European Federation was skeptical and preferred to keep to it’s own continent, and Northern Europe feared European retaliation. There was also the issue of the sea ice making trade routes risky and the United States sending ships to threaten blocking trade routes. However, the Arctic sea ice was melting at an unprecedented rate, the area experiencing it’s first ice-free summer in 2004, and the Federation was incredibly weakened. In summer 2004, as sea ice was at it’s lowest ever extent, Canada contacted the UK and Nordic Union, and in a matter of months a trade deal was finalised. NEFTA would be expanded into NAFTA - the North Atlantic Free Trade Area - due to Canada’s introduction. Food would remain the main transported product. Two major trade routes would be used - one from the St Lawrence River, and the other being the Northwest Passage, which was becoming a viable route due to the sea ice melting. More and more Canadian agriculture was being done in the rapidly warming, underpopulated north, and the opening of the passage allowed food to be directly transported from source to destination.

NAFTA received skepticism and mixed reception from abroad. The United States and Canada had been at odds for a few years, and trade between the two countries was limited. Upon the formation of the pact, however, worry and jealousy spread through it - worry that they would all team up to surpass or block the US completely from their trade, and jealousy that so much natural food was being transported to feed Northern Europe but not North America. They could do nothing but watch and wait for Europe to respond, however. Communication from the Federation in the years following the Crackdown was limited, but whatever came out appeared resentful of the treaty, and signs were showing a military buildup in the Federation. The majority of other countries were generally indifferent.

Domestically, NAFTA was immensely successful, helping bring down food prices to normal levels. Reception was mostly positive in all countries, and negotiations were soon being expanded to other areas of cooperation. Suggestions included defence and technology, which would both undoubtedly bring great benefit, but unfortunately alliance take time to create, and time was not on everyone’s side, as by late 2004, the Federation began knocking on Northern Europe’s doors once more.

The Iron Chains that Bind: The Rise of Neo-Colonialism in the Western World

By 2004, the European Federation was beginning to recover from the Red Summer. 2004 was cooler and marginally wetter than the last year, and food production and reservoirs were slowly recovering. FulTec was more powerful than ever before, many more foodstuffs were produced, and large dissent was dying down. The nation, though, had clearly been irrevocably changed by the events. Electricity prices remained unaffordable to most, and the government prioritised a giant project to build many nuclear plants across the Federation as a result, with disastrous results to come. The biggest change arguably came from the food - whatever natural food remaining had also become unaffordable to the populace, with most farms burned, and to fill that gap, FulTec stepped up to the task. Massive tracts of land were reserved for new superfarms and factories, as foodstuffs replaced all other foods in European markets. These were not the same as the old, 90s foodstuffs as well - the new ones as a result of the Red Summer had degraded in quality and lacked the nutrients and flavour the old ones had. FulTec, over the following years, experimented with many other methods to feed Europe’s population, some less successful than others.

Federal land was quickly being used up at a vast rate, and massive heatwaves still threatened to decimate the continental mainland, making the simple act of building there unviable in the short term. FulTec was then led to look north, to the countries of the United Kingdom and the Nordic Union, where they formerly held many of their farms and factories. The two nations by this point had fully separated from Europe, moving all their trade with them to Canada. Any advances by FulTec there would be fully rejected, as even in the incredibly unlikely scenario of the governments accepting them back in, the people of these nations would riot and protest violently, making operations there unsustainable. Despite these risks, the Federation and FulTec needed these nations land to survive in the future, and so in the middle of 2004, FulTec was given two objectives - In the United Kingdom and Nordic Union, ensure the governments allow access and development with few restrictions, and ensure the populace do not resist effectively. Achieving both those tasks were easier said than done, but FulTec had no choice but to achieve them.

They could either have done this the diplomatic way or the forceful way. FulTec could only choose the latter.

Thousands of hours of work led to the publishing of the plans for Operations Lion and Wolf late that year, for the UK and Nordic Union respectively. Both of those plans were similar in structure, the major difference being that Operation Lion would be performed first to catch the stronger UK off guard and destroy NAFTA, and Wolf would be performed afterwards, hoping the weaker Scandinavia would surrender quickly. The structure of the plans were generally similar, with Lion being written more in-depth due to being inherently riskier, as the Royal Navy was still a formidable force, especially when compared to the decaying FEN (Federal European Navy). Information about the plans was kept incredibly secret, even to the President, with him and his inner circle only knowing three key words referring to the three main phases - Precedence, Confrontation, De-escalation. The wording of them led him to feel disappointed - it felt too similar to the other incidents of the early 90s that led to FulTec dominating their food markets. Such a strategy likely wouldn’t work now, with the two nations alert and cautious. The operations were scheduled for the beginning of 2005, and the European President would see just how wrong he was in these thoughts.

Throughout late 2004, Europe became increasingly belligerent with the United Kingdom, especially following the creation of NAFTA. European warships constantly threatened British waters and it seemed that every day there was a new threat made towards Britain to direct more trade to the Federation. Britain was put on high military alert and fears rose that an invasion was imminent. An actual land invasion would naturally be impractical, with the Royal Navy being powerful enough to deter most invasions and weather in the Channel becoming increasingly volatile. The Royal Navy recognised this and planned instead for other naval confrontations, including a blockade. This, in the end, proved to be a mistake. The Federation was determined to outwit them and went for one of the least expected options - an incredibly risky but possibly rewarding one. The Federation demanded, among other things, that Britain reduce its EEZ and the area it fishes in, as it was expanded following 2003. Of course, the number of fish, and anything in the sea, was a small fraction of what it was even in the 80s. Britain just waved away the issue, essentially telling the Federation the issue no longer mattered and hoped they would simply forget. One of Britain’s biggest mistakes was not figuring out the Federation’s, more accurately FulTec’s, true motives.


A typical Royal Navy ship in the mid-2000s, built in the 1980s and being hurriedly refurbished occasionally since. Hardly any new ships were built following 1988 due to high costs and it was generally preferred by most nations to focus on maintenance.

The sparks of war were ignited when on January 2nd 2005, a European fleet raided and sunk a British container ship near the Isles transporting food heading from Canada. An ultimatum was sent by the Federation: abolish NAFTA immediately or they will destroy it themselves via blockade. The British treated it as an act of war and sent ships there to challenge the blockade - however that ended disastrously when European ships opened fire and a brief naval battle led to 8 sunk British ships and 3 sunk European ones. The United Kingdom declared war against the Federation, and the Nordic Union was put on alert for imminent invasion, not officially joining the war itself. More naval battles occurred in the following days near British waters, however many of the them were inconclusive as both sides, as in World War 1, both countries were reluctant to lose ships, and many of what they had were old and decaying anyways so they were a struggle to manage [11]. It was anticipated that the war would be fought primarily on the naval front, especially on the seas west of the British Isles, and so the majority of initial battles were fought there, with British ships desperately defending Canadian container ships. The war did have the effect, however, of slowing trade between Canada and Northern Europe dramatically, effectively cancelling NAFTA. The British government did consider using it’s nuclear arsenal to threaten the Federation, however as it was fearful of a nuclear war, and as it’s arsenal was ageing and untested, it decided against it for the duration of the conflict.

The war continued throughout early 2005 and led to minor shortages in Britain as Europe additionally blocked trade to and from the Nordic Union. However, the war was stagnant, only consisting of minor naval battles, and both sides knew something had to and would change. At the end of March, as the war appeared to die down, FulTec began the next phase of Operation Lion, with the Precedence (ultimatum) and Confrontation (the war) being completed, the last phase was the De-Escalation, and in it, FulTec would reveal their decisive trump card - their remaining agents in the UK.

Following 2003, the vast majority of FulTec members in the UK left the country, primarily due to the hostile environment there, but some of them were ordered to stay. Lots of these members had close ties with the British government, and were instructed to remain and build up ties there in case FulTec planned to return some day. As Operation Lion was being drafted, FulTec renewed contact with these members, and briefed them on the operation. It was by sheer luck and incompetence they weren’t caught, and the third phase of the operation was scheduled for early 2005. The members built up a supply of arms and spread themselves out in the major cities of the nation, biding their time until given the signal. On the 23rd of March that year, the De-Escalation began, and the signal would fire in the form of rising smoke on the Thames.

That day, radar spotted a fleet of European warships heading straight through the lower North Sea right towards the mouth of the Thames. The English Channel was regularly patrolled by the Royal Navy, and so a squadron of ships quickly encountered the European fleet, however, it was not enough, and so the RN fleet was damaged and retreated. An earlier major battle in the Celtic Sea had already occupied many British ships, and so few could be spared, and it came to the UK’s horror that it was a distraction all along. The European fleet entered the Thames Estuary, and with a combination of partly skill, mainly insane luck, and a once-in-a-generation flood that hit the Thames hard, it made it all the way through the Thames into London with little resistance and started bombing the flooded city. The chaos and smoke emerging from the north bank was the signal the undercover members needed, and in hours a band of disgruntled former BPF members was organised, having been gathered months earlier in preparation for the operation and sedated with bribes. The group marched on Parliament from all sides and forcefully broke into the building, invading the Commons chamber and holding it hostage. Similar events happened in Birmingham, Liverpool, Newcastle and other major cities as the BPF (which was promised a role in the new government) stormed and took over local government [12] headquarters. Protests sprung up, but the overall mood was confusion, and the UK was temporarily powerless to resist against the Federation.


European soldiers marching through a flooded and ruined London. Photographed March 28th, 2005 - the day of the surrender.

With the lull in communication, the English Channel was subsequently breached and European soldiers stormed the island, taking over the south in days. Most of the captive MPs did not live past the first day as many, including the Prime Minister and his Cabinet, were killed to “save food”. The BPF wrought havoc on the streets. The country, in total chaos, fell easily to the encroaching Europeans, who on the 28th of March, announced the “surrender of the United Kingdom” and the agreement of the formation of a new government. It would trade exclusively with the Federation and allied countries and allow FulTec almost free reign with British foodstuffs, essentially turning the United Kingdom into a puppet of the Federation. The UK also reduced it’s fishing zone heavily and acceded to practically all European economic demands. The new government formed was of the remaining members of the Labour Party and a group of FulTec executives providing intimidation. The BNP was snubbed, it and the BPF being promised a place in the new government, and after a few days of angry rioting they were both banned, hunted down and destroyed. The opposition parties also cried out against the invasion - they were not banned, but from then on, elections were practically rigged, with gerrymandering, voter intimidation and suppression being practiced to elect the Labour Party every time, though the opposition occasionally came close. Of course, there were mass protests against FulTec and Europe, but the passage of the Freedom of Expression Act of 2005 and liberal application of previous anti-terror laws soon brutally put a stop to that after a few months, and the island fell silent. Similar events occurred in Ireland, with the previously neutral nation falling under the pressure of intimidation and turning into a controlled democracy. The once great Empire had fallen and had finally, after centuries, been invaded by a foreign army, and the sun had permanently set and blanketed the Isles in night.

With the UK done, the Federation set their sights on the Nordic Union, which was a much weaker target. FulTec also had members there, and Operation Wolf was drafted quicker, consisting of only Confrontation and De-Escalation. A week following the fall of Britain, the FEN surrounded the Union and threatened surrender or invasion. The Union had been preparing for an invasion for months, but against the industrial might of Europe, despite food advantages, preparation was simply futile. The Union still refused, hoping to last out long enough to get a good deal with the Federation, but the following day Gothenburg was bombed relentlessly and European troops ransacked the city. Stockholm was also bombed, and with the nation at risk of full invasion, the government made the difficult decision to unconditionally surrender, hoping to at least keep some of their independence. The Federation was surprisingly lenient on the Union, fearing revolt there and liking it’s lack of resistance, they decided to have little influence on the government unlike the UK. All economic demands were accepted, including the destruction of anti-monopoly laws, and allowing FulTec to operate freely, but the only change in the political system was the suppression of anti-European and FulTec discourse, and government and all major parties would not challenge the changes made. Trade would also be redirected purely to the Federation and it would leave NAFTA (following the UK), officially abolishing the agreement. The Union was also given quotas of food to transport to the Federation due to it’s large production, unlike the UK. Despite getting off lightly, retaining it’s liberal democracy, massive protests took place, and the agreement would the haunt the Nordic government until it’s fall. It was still made a puppet, like the UK, it was shackled economically and politically to the Federation and would struggle to break out.

The invasion and occupation of Britain and Scandinavia is commonly termed as the beginning of “Neo-Colonialism” in the Western World by the remaining scholars and some politicians, with the Federation treating these nations purely as food sources. In this new world, food was something to fight for, and these developments showed how horrifyingly powerful the foodstuffs corporations had gotten, to the point where they were directing the conquests of other nations themselves. Western Europe had fallen to the Federation, yet only out of desperation was the Federation conducting these conquests, as more and more of it’s land was becoming uninhabitable. To ensure the nation survived it was forced to endlessly expand and travel north like a parasite until it finally ran out of blood to feast on.

---

https://youtu.be/2flpdqGfAsw?si=gvqKfQoVlnxZWdKm 

A Fracturing World: The Decaying Transatlantic relationship in the 90s and early 00s, and the fall of NATO

By all accounts, the Federation and the United States were very similar nations. They were both federal, had left-wing socialist-in-all-but-name governments, and shared common enemies in the forms of China (since the 90s) and the USSR. However, this new world was not one for cooperation, but it was dog-eat-dog, every man for himself, and this philosophy, alongside many other small causes that added up, would show the end of relations across the Atlantic and the fracturing of the West into numerous pieces.

Both Food, Inc and FulTec needed most of all land - mainly for farms but also for factories and anything else necessary to produce their foodstuffs. Both countries did have plenty of land, moreso the US, but what drove these corporations was the age-old ideal of “growth, growth, growth” and so they began looking abroad for it. FulTec was operating abroad earlier than Food, Inc in the late 90s as the Federation was experiencing a growing land shortage, opening plantations in Northern and Southern Europe. Spying the large, unused tracts of land in the USA, they began to open them there, which drew criticism from Food, Inc and the American government. The idea of foreign companies operating on their land was reprehensible to the protectionist Graves administration, and also to Food, Inc who needed more land. The administration was also fearful of them using their influence to spy on the US - at this point, this was not necessarily a legitimate concern, but the end of globalisation and isolationist tendencies of the new governments created suspicion in the populaces of the rest of the world. Due to all this, Food, Inc would retaliate and open their own facilities in the Federation in 1996.

The move elicited similar responses from the Federation, which was worried about their land crisis, and they took action, drafting laws to harm foreign companies and American products in retaliation. The United States was angered, and in a speech in May 1996, President Graves threatened 100% tariffs on European products unless the new laws were revoked. The Federation subsequently threatened 150% and after a rapid, terrifying climbup, a deal was agreed in Ottawa that removed the tariffs, placed minor restrictions on the corporations operations in the other continent, and promised further debate on the topic later, which never occurred. The deal reduced tensions in the short term and prevented the early destruction of NATO and the Transatlantic economies, but in the longer term, suspicions grew and tensions flamed up again. Unproven but not unlikely rumours of spying from both sides developed and protestors marched against Food, Inc and FulTec in both nations. The Transatlantic relationship had been permanently damaged by the tariff war and would never return to it’s full strength, despite attempts to improve relations by the Smith Administration. It is thought by many that even if there was no conflict between Food, Inc and FulTec and if the events of May 1996 didn’t occur, the isolationism of the United States and the authoritarianism of the Federation would have led to a split anyways. The death of globalisation had torn the Atlantic too far apart for them to meet again.

To help deflate tensions, negotiations started in 2000 for an agreement between the two nations relating to foodstuffs corporations to solve the issue once and for all. Repeated meetings failed to solve anything and in 2002 it was decided by both sides that Food, Inc and FulTec should simply not be allowed to operate respectively in Europe and in North America. Both corporations were heavily resistant, with FulTec attempting to stage a rebellion within the government to stop this, being the one likely to lose the most. Food, Inc Corp also protested heavily within the US government, but both were pacified with heavy subsidies to make up for the lost land. The corporations were upset not only at the loss of land, but also their prestige, being forced to do something by the government, but in the end the governments had the real power, and so on the 23rd of August 2002, the London Agreement of 2002 was signed, and the Federation and States would be one step further away from each other. The Agreement would reduce tensions, yes, but an unaccounted for side effect was that the United States would have less of a motive to intervene in the European continent if things got bloody, and both nations would slide further into isolationism, driving forward the collapse of NATO ever faster. 

The alliance was simply too fragile to hold through the 90s and 00s, with the foodstuff conflicts causing great tensions between the US and the Federation. The participants of NATO cared little for the alliance, not believing it would help them survive a Soviet attack, and preferring to focus more on their internal issues instead of some country nobody cared about. This was the same for the people too - in all countries, aside from the Nordic ones, support for NATO was declining throughout the 90s as it was thought money was being wasted on it, alongside the increase in internal conflict within the organisation making it look dead already.

The alliance was further damaged with the 1997 Channel Crisis, highlighting the tenuous state of UK-Federation relations. The UK was already becoming more NATO-skeptic as well, with the governing Labour Party claiming the alliance was “useless” following the Channel Crisis, and repeatedly threatening to leave the organisation between the crisis and Red Summer, though never following through. Turkey left in 2001 following a diplomatic conflict with Greece over warships in the Aegean, though the alliance did gain a new member in the form of the Nordic Union the previous year. Conflict with Europe, however, soured the relationship almost immediately. It seemed that even the Federation believed NATO was dead.

The Red Summer and invasion of West Berlin was the killing blow for the alliance, demonstrating clearly the Federation was unreliable and that Article 5 would not be followed through. The Nordic Union, worried about a European invasion and the surging far-left and right, held a referendum in 2004 on the issue, just four years after it joined. 66% of people voted to leave, and with this resounding mandate they did just that. Canada also left the same year - relations between it and the United States had plunged in the 90s, with President Graves placing tariffs and providing pressure on the nation to export it’s food, worrying them an invasion was imminent. The right-wing National Party would win resoundingly in 2004, and promised to leave NATO and build a border wall immediately following the election. And they did just that.

NATO now only contained three nations - the United States, European Federation, and the United Kingdom. The war between the UK and the Federation in early 2005 resulted in the UK leaving, as the USA did nothing except write yet another strongly worded statement in response to the conflict. The alliance was officially dead, as the Federation also left following, and the United States was the only member, making it completely useless and cease to exist. A New World Order was put in it’s place - one where nations would fight others for survival instead of cooperating, one where nations would apply tariffs and build walls instead of trading, one where international law was nonexistent and the mad kings of Chaos and Violence reigned through the dying world.

[1] Some notes on Athens for worldbuilding. Suburbanisation increased incredibly rapidly during the 70s and 80s, expanding further south beyond Glyfada and the north. Infrastructure was expanded but not fast enough and many houses were built shoddily and at a great fire risk, which became very dangerous in the 90s as Athens burned up. As the centre in the 80s and 90s due to the suburbanisation became cheaper, and as fires were common in them, people fled from the suburbs, with many of the outer ones becoming neglected, empty and as shelter for the many homeless or just burning to the ground.

[6] The system created following the 1987 British Healthcare Act was not a fully American-style privatised service (what the Conservatives aimed to achieve later), but relegated public healthcare to a secondary option for urgent care, with private care growing rapidly and beginning to dominate before the Sinai War. However, as a result, the quality of the NHS crumbled as investment was redirected to benefits to private companies or other areas.
Before the 1988 Crash people were generally able to afford private healthcare, however this was reversed following and massive protests emerged over the privatisation, becoming immensely unpopular. The Labour Party promised to revoke the Act in their manifesto and did that a few months following the election.
[7] As in other cities across the world, London during the 90s saw population flight from the outer suburbs to the central boroughs, perhaps accelerated by the presence of the Underground and buses. This led to mass overcrowding in the central boroughs, with many ugly flats and extensions being built to combat this, by this point London was increasingly resembling its Victorian era.
The Tube is still operational up until the 2000s but after 1988 becomes extortionately expensive and only usable by the upper middle class. Many of the extensions made in the 70s and 80s (such as the late 80s Jubilee and Bakerloo Chene extensions) are cut back and only major lines such as the Central and Northern are kept operational, and only in the city centre.

[10] A summary of the major British political parties during the 90s for reference and worldbuilding:
Labour Party: economically left-wing, socially centre-right. The dominant party in new British politics, holding just under 400 seats following the 1999 election despite unpopularity due to the divided opposition. Incredibly strong in the north, mainly in socially conservative industrial cities and the north-east. Also maintains an iron grip on Wales and central Scotland, and big city centres, although, especially in London, they are slowly going to the Greens.
Their 90s government is economically reminiscent of OTL early 80s Labour, however the party has abandoned much of its social liberalism to appeal to the socially conservative north to stop the BNP. They have gained many authoritarian tendencies throughout their tenure as a result of all the violence and that may be put to the test at some point. Most socially liberal members have left to the Greens.
Liberal Party: economically centre to centre-left, socially centre-left to left-wing. Was able to appeal to many southern, suburban Conservative voters in 1989 to wreck the party there and become the Official Opposition. Strong in much of the liberal south and parts of London primarily, as well as some areas in the north. Holds social liberalism (the ideology) as its official stance.
Much of it’s recent appeal has been in response to the authoritarianism and social conservatism of the Labour Party, promising a repeal of anti-immigration laws and “draconian” crime and policing laws. Additionally it maintains an environmentalist stance, promising massive subsidies to renewable energy and a slow rollback of coal, however, with the economic crisis and powerful trade unions everyone knows this is a pipe dream (which is why the party is anti-union).
Conservative Party: economically centre-right to right-wing, socially centre-left to right-wing. A shadow of their former self following the election of 1989. Kept their strength in a few rural areas and parts of the East of England, though their hold there is quickly going to the BNP. The old neoliberal faction is ITTL a mix of a more radical Thatcher and Blair, following the defeat the Thatcherist element is toned town heavily.
The party is split between liberal and nationalist factions who bitterly fight each other. The liberal faction is a slightly more left-wing version of the old neoliberals and wants a union with the Liberal Party, whereas the hard-right nationalist faction wants to use anti-immigration sentiment (despite being seen as the party causing it) to their advantage and win back BNP voters. The liberals win out after the heavy 1999 defeat for them and soon after the Liberal Conservative Party is formed.
British National Party: economically centre-left to centre-right, socially far-right. Was incredibly minor following the 1988 crash, but heavily rose due to anti-austerity and anti-immigration sentiment following. Strong primarily in the East of England and in left-behind rural areas, but also in city centres by white families scared of the race riots.
Runs mainly off anti-immigration sentiment, with half of it’s 1994 manifesto being dedicated to the issue. It promises mass deportations and holding refugees in giant camps away from civilisation. Also has a strong anti-austerity focus and a “law and order” focus like Labour has, wanting to make the BPF equal to the police and a new Gestapo-like force. They are constantly criticised for their unrealistic policy that would bankrupt the country and them literally being neo-Nazis, but this likely actually gains them votes as more vote for them as an anti-establishment choice.
Green Party: economically left-wing to far-left, socially left-wing. Gained new support following acceleration of climate crisis and gained strength in rural areas for campaigning against nuclear developments. Has strength in many rural areas (though not enough to gain many seats there) and more recently in big cities, including East London where they gained many seats in 1999, additionally in flooded parts of the East of England. Still minor but is only set to grow in the future.
The party is seen as a left-wing alternative to Labour who many grew disillusioned with especially following the “sickening offspring” speech, causing many to move to it. It lacks strength as many consider it to be in “fantasyland” with its anti-nuclear policies and pacifist ones such as nuclear disarmament (which many in Labour considered at one point), however many that still remember TMI remain anti-nuclear and the cost of wind and solar is actually declining. Often it is seen as a protest vote against Labour and in constituencies more affected by climate change.

“He who fights with monsters should look to it that he himself does not become a monster. And if you gaze long into an abyss, the abyss also gazes into you.”
-Friedrich Nietzsche, 1886 [3]

---

11/01/2018
MIDDAY
GOSLAR, GERMANY, EURO. FEDERATION

Old, frail, dying Klaus Riedel was lying down in a white, luxurious bed, covered in a blanket, alone in a small room with a desk, two sets of drawers and an empty closet. The bed was right by the window - he stared, gazing out of it to the town below, his eyes showing only emptiness inside. Occasionally, an aide would come check on him for a few minutes; to check his heart rate, blood pressure, and for other vital signs. Not that there was any point. If he wished, he could simply shoo the aide away and make her never come to check on him again. But Klaus didn’t mind the company - not even he would like spending days and weeks alone, with no human interaction. It was a nice break from the routine.

It was just a few months ago that Klaus, weakening and heavily coughing, had received his diagnosis in a private hospital in Frankfurt, near FulTec’s old headquarters. “Aggressive lung cancer,” the doctor said, or at least something along the lines of it, his memory was constantly failing him. “Untreatable. The best we can do is prolong it. And we’re not even sure we can do that.” The doctor spoke in a neutral tone, without any hint of a bias, but Riedel could have sworn there was some mocking undertone behind his voice. Paranoia, perhaps. Or something deeper. Not that it mattered, regardless. His days were numbered, anyway.

The people, the bloodless psychopaths at FulTec, they didn’t like him, he was well aware of that. He had been forced out (or “retired”, as the press called it) some years back, and was only made an observer in the corporation’s plans. He watched helplessly as they approved Project Unthinkable five years prior, despite his voracious moral and scientific objections. That was likely the final straw. And the Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 16, when the world burned up, seemed to validate their beliefs, as they shipped out FulTec Plenty, their latest product, en masse to the cities of Europe. Klaus, and the remaining scientists with a brain and a conscience, knew better, they knew that Project Unthinkable was unsustainable, and that it would fail very quickly, but that did not matter to the new execs. The goal was profit, it had always been, even when he himself was the CEO, with all the bloodshed and pain and suffering he had inflicted on the people of Greece, of Britain, of Scandinavia, of his home of Germany, and Europe itself. It was his karma, it had come back to bite him and kill him and leave him here alone and helpless, in his dying hometown.

Goslar had always been a treasured place for Klaus since his birth and childhood there, he had adored the greenery, the palace, the architecture there. Now all of that was gone, the forests burned and cut down to leave blank waste in their midst, the palace and architecture and monuments crumbling and being destroyed by the pollution from nearby superfactories. All he could see outside his window was smog, thick smoke impeding his view, he could hardly see his hometown below. Goslar was a rural town, hosting around 10,000 at this time. The evil, cruel, unspeakable minds of FulTec had drawn up plans, they needed bodies, people for Plenty, and the supply of criminals and people sent to death would not suffice, FulTec needed farm workers, after all. No, the vast majority had fled to the cities for work anyway, places like here were emptying, old, desolate these years. Who would notice if old, small towns like here went missing anyways?

Klaus had tried to fight his hardest against them, but he was too weak, cancer-ridden, and the elite laughed at him as he spoke weakly from a wheelchair, his frail voice carrying just a few metres, laughing maniacally, or were they crying? Were tears brewing behind these faces of steel, those empty expressions, had they gone insane or empty inside, convincing themselves these were the sacrifices they had to make for the security of the Federation. Klaus could not read anything anymore, everyone around them had confusing faces, expressions of dread, despair, hopelessness, insanity, everyone had gone insane in this deeply rotten world. He could never find it in himself to forgive them, never, but his mind had lost all capacity for anger, or hatred, or any emotion at all. He felt utterly empty as he stared at the smoke, ancient buildings barely visible behind it. One day, they may not be visible at all. Maybe FulTec had deliberately placed these factories there, to torment him in his last days of life.

The aide came into the room, handing him his tray of lunch, thankfully not any of FulTec’s products, at least they had the decency to do that. In his heart, he knew he deserved it, he deserved to be stuffed and forcefed with as much FulTec Plenty as possible, as he chewed on the stale food he could have sworn he felt the crunch of human flesh beneath his teeth. All of it, all of this was his fault, he knew, he had risen this company from the dead, he had destroyed all his competitors and planted the same factories which were destroying his home now, countless and innumerable lives were ruined and extinguished as a result of him and people like him, with the same mindsets, thoughts and ideas. He had destroyed his hometown, left all the good people there to be killed and cannibalised unknowingly by his fellow Germans. His final thoughts dissolved in the sickening heat as his last breaths echoed across the room.

Later that day, his passing was reported by his aide to her superiors. His death was unreported to the populace, only known to the higher-ups, and his body was taken to be processed and sold in a package of FulTec Plenty, a “fitting reward”, said the new CEO. And perhaps it was, for the Man who Destroyed Europe.

---

Europe was in a race against fate itself.

The continent was warming at an alarming rate, faster than any area on Earth aside the Arctic. The Sahara had extended into North Africa by the 2000s, and was quickly spreading across the Mediterranean, into Iberia and Sicily and beyond. Chronic megadroughts rocked Southern Europe and continued indefinitely, with food and water becoming a luxury to many, fuelling riots and chaos like the Federation had never seen. Normal life broke down as temperatures rose to the point of making summers unliveable, and in a matter of years, whole cities became abandoned as scores of people left for cooler pastures or just died in the streets, as often happened to the elderly. Southern Europe was left to the hands of terrorist groups and crime gangs, who ruled the dying cities with iron fists until even they could no longer survive.

However, even life up north wasn’t much better. Internal refugees flooded the cities and often were crammed into hastily-built, flammable housing which tended to catch fire during the summer. Speaking of summer, massive heatwaves had become a yearly occurrence, burning down swathes of forest until there was nothing left. Wildfire smoke blanketed cities and in many, face masks became mandatory and stay-at-home orders were common, not that they did much. Respiratory illnesses became the latest health concern and cases, which in the summer had become common on the level of the regular flu, were simply ignored by the few remaining hospitals which were already going bankrupt and stretching the nationalised health service to its limits. Fires were even taking place in big cities, where many newer buildings for refugees were constructed without adherence to safety codes, and many simply burned to the ground, killing many and forcing them onto the crowded streets and into the dark alleys. They were becoming homes for Europe’s countless number of homeless, which the government soon stopped bothering to record. Even for people lucky enough to live in a dwelling, they still weren’t built for the immense heatwaves that had become the new normal and often became incredibly hot in summer. Air conditioning had not reached Northern Europe from America, and even over there was a luxury, with electricity bills becoming unaffordable. Food was also being affected - whatever semi-natural food that still existed was only available in the “winter” months, and during the summer, only FulTec’s products were available.

Heatwaves were not the only climate event that the Federation had to deal with. Storms and flooding were becoming far more commonplace, with Germany in particular often being struck by major floods that killed hundreds. The Benelux and France also suffered from similar events. The Netherlands in particular was most at risk, with massive storms causing ever greater damage to towns, and more importantly, the barriers holding the nation together. The country was a ticking time bomb for the Federation, everyone knowing its flooding was inevitable, but the cost of moving everyone and everything, especially all the agriculture there, was far too much for the Federation to commit to, despite the even greater costs of waiting the issue out.

The Federation was also heavily changing socially as well, as the aftermath of the Crackdown had created a culture of fear among the people. The Local Protection Units were ruthless and bound to no law, and regularly raided the homes of so-called “dissidents”. Horrific rumours of torture prefiltered by the government were commonplace among newspapers and well-known by the people, and so the LPUs were heavily feared. People were pressured to report others they thought were “dissidents” for a reward (often a portion of natural food), who were usually innocent of any crime, and the LPUs quickly turned into a Gestapo-like system, creating an environment similar to that of Nazi Germany. Whether it was ever intentional or not is unknown. Whatever media remained was also broadcasting purely government propaganda. The newspapers (which were generally shared between the poor due to their obscene price) were still relatively reliable for the little foreign news they had, but domestic stories were screened by the government and incredibly distorted. Radio had resurged following a government effort to have one in most homes and their cheaper prices, but the few stations were also government-run, and so were considered unreliable. Television was hardly used due to requiring lots of electricity, but the few channels there were, like the radio channels, government-run. [4] Everyone living had seen a world without brutal authoritarianism and most had seen a world without the Federation, making propaganda ineffective to most. FulTec’s and the government’s hopes were that the younger generation and the one yet to be born would buy into it more for that reason.


Economically, things were practically in ruins. FulTec was the Federation’s biggest private employer (second to the federal government), boasting close to 20% and an ever-increasing amount of jobs. They all had horrendous working conditions, especially so after 2003. Lots of the time they hired from the unemployed as they would be more desperate and their jobs generally had no skill requirements. The trade unions had stopped pay and working conditions from getting too bad, being the main force fighting against FulTec, but their presence and power had collapsed following the Crackdown and passage of the Trade Union Act of 2003. Hardly any new workers bothered to join them, and they were collapsing like dominoes. The remaining jobs generally had abysmal pay, 30-40% being minimum wage, and almost non-existent safety measures and miserable conditions. The people hated seeing their pay being gutted for almost two decades, but with high unemployment, the employed were seen as lucky and so people would take any job they could get, giving employers the excuse to suppress wages. The waves of internal refugees also worsened the issue and increased job competition.


Politically, the Socialists were dominant, winning large majorities every election. The only parliamentary opposition were the Greens, the liberal ALDE and conservative EPP. The Greens were, to put it mildly, batshit insane, proposing incredibly radical and inhumane population control measures such as a zero birth policy and voluntary euthanasia (which would soon shift into the mainstream) and actions such as deindustrialisation to “save the climate”. The party in reality used to be much more moderate, however the dramatic worsening of the climate crisis radicalised them, and FulTec wished to keep a radical fringe opposition to the PES. ALDE and more reluctantly the EPP mainly campaigned against the authoritarian “crackdown laws”, their economic positions being similar to the PES by this point, if not slightly more right wing. With their positions getting ever more similar, in 2011 they decided to merge into the Democratic Alliance. FulTec wanted some form of an opposition to maintain the illusion of a legitimate democracy, and so the opposition struggled to make inroads. The media blasted PES propaganda come election time and immense voter suppression, intimidation, voter apathy and possibly some rigging called the elections for the Socialists every time. The opposition began to believe nothing would ever change, and so the drive in them faded, and FulTec remained utterly dominant.


The Federation was facing crisis, with climate disasters reaching biblical proportions and living conditions worsening each year. It was in these conditions that this shell of a nation trudged through rivers of blood, pain and despair to reach the end, as the nation and the world collapsed around it.

A World Altered: The aftereffects of the collapse of the AMOC in 2006


A map of the current, for reference.

Across the whole world, climate was breaking down. Many tipping points, such as the collapse of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, as well as the burning of the Amazon Rainforest [5], had already been reached, causing irreversible and catastrophic changes across the world. Despite scientists endlessly warning people and governments about the consequences, and the emissions reductions due to GDP loss, global inertia was too strong and the economy too fucked to create any meaningful change, and temperatures soared unstoppably higher. Perhaps the biggest one of all, the one that created the most change despite being invisible to the world was the collapse of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, or the AMOC.

The AMOC is the Atlantic’s main ocean current system, transporting

Paradise Lost: Desertification in the Iberian Peninsula and the passage of the Internal Migration and Security Act of 2006


An emergency heat warning broadcasted across all TVs in Spain, on an unknown day in July 2007. The alerts are also broadcasted by giant sirens and radios across cities, and by home radios too.

---

[1] The company Vosscorp (created by FulTec’s founder) worked throughout the 2000s and 2010s in basic electronics and computer systems for the European government. In the 2020s the government aimed to record and preserve as much data as they could in preparation for the inevitable global collapse, so Vosscorp built terminals across the Federation to store various data (e.g. papers, journals, figures) for future survivors (ideally FulTec and govt. elites).
[2] The often unreliable Disaster Risk Index was developed in Europe in 2008 following the previous years’ many climate disasters. It combines the local risk of flood, heavy wind, drought and other disasters to create a measure for how “safe” the area is. The index was adopted across the Federation to limited affect as critics say the index is too generalised and relies on unreliable measurements.
The Heat Risk Index is used in most countries (with varying methodologies) and measures the risk of lethal heat, which can come by simply incredibly high temperatures (e.g. what’s constantly measured in 2020s Iberia ITTL and the Sahara OTL) or “wet bulb temperatures”, where a combination of high heat and humidity prevents sweating from occurring and has lethal effects on people.
[3] I feel this quote fits much more into Section 1 as the Federal Government became the same as what it was opposing. As the Federation looks into the hellish future, all the nightmarish projections ahead of it, it does what it believe it must do to survive. And most of the time, they are not the right things to do (And yes, Friedrich Riedel having the same first name was coincidence and I only realised it later).
[4] Newspapers only consist of a few pages in the 2000s to save costs. Most of it is for domestic news, which is mainly FulTec related, political, or covering climate change and natural disasters (the European government does make an effort to educate the people as much about it as possible). There is a small section for foreign news. The economic situation has led to the entertainment, lifestyle and other related sections being defunct, so newspapers are quite limited in content.
On the radio, there is a weather station, a music station, and a few government-run news and informative channels. To replace the decline of traditional schooling, an educational one was set up in 2005, though that mainly teaches labour and more traditional skills. The news channel mainly covers domestic news as foreign news, with the death of globalisation, is very limited. There was formerly a separate channel for it but it was merged in 2004.
Television is even more limited with a channel for weather (+climate) and a channel for news only. They both, however, run almost 24/7.
Media in general has shrunk dramatically since 2003 as following the Red Summer and Crackdown the government had an opportunity to target it to cut costs.
[5] By 2000 the vast majority of the rainforest had already been cut down, but the remainder of it burned down in a colossal fire in July 2004, blanketing lots of the world in wildfire smoke.

Plans:
Section 3 - As The Abyss Gazes Back
-Europe in the late 2000s and 2010s - non-political, focuses on effects of climate change, development of European foodstuffs, struggle of Europe to survive
Climate change effects, evacuations
-AMOC collapses around the late-2000s, causes climate chaos across the world (do more research!) 
-Netherlands floods in 2007, barriers break in especially rainy year and Amsterdam, the Hague, Rotterdam flooded. Evacuation efforts take place and controversially, people are distributed around the country, threatening to damage the Dutch identity
-Desertification hitting Iberia - in 2006 Federation passes Internal Migration and Security Act, which gives government permission to declare areas “abandoned” and evacuate citizens out, preferably to the rest of their own state, but if that can’t happen (e.g. 2007 Netherlands), evacuate them across the Federation. Giant refugee camps built, which are very low quality. The act is first used in 2006 to evacuate most of the south of Spain. In 2008 Lisbon is controversially evacuated after heatwave and lots of political violence and in 2010 Madrid, then in 2012 Barcelona and all of Iberia are abandoned due to unrest and desertification. Some think evacuation is unnecessary.
-In 2008 Sicily is evacuated. In 2017 lots of the south of Italy also is. Mafia (which the Federation has been cooperating with for a while) takes over many functions in that area
-The south of France remains not evacuated though becomes more and more uninhabited until 2021, when Marseilles completely burns to the ground (yes, completely) and provisions are put in place. Some people still live there but they are few and most emigrate.
-Rome faces brutal riots in Second Great Heatwave following immense water scarcity, Catholic extremist groups there ally with factions in Vatican and launch armed revolt in city (2024). Rome descends into anarchy following which spreads across much of North Italy. Mafia and religious extremists take over lots of it
Political aftermath of 2003
-90% of trade unions collapsed by 2010, remaining ones merged into a few big unions similar to the USA, called the European Workers’ Collective.
-The economic crisis caused by climate change impacts, spiralling budget deficits caused by LPUs and economic decline caused by FulTec, forces immense budget cuts in 2009, destroying healthcare completely alongside education. The cuts get worse through the years
-Politically PES is dominant and wins large majorities every election, with Democrats and Greens as minor opposition. Greens grow following nuclear incidents (2014 election)
-LPUs become more and more powerful and drain federal budget over time. Federal government gets worried about it. They discover Project Unthinkable in 2015 and decide to keep it hidden and launch a revolt. They do that in the summer during the Great Heatwave, but an informer tells the gov and they wipe out the LPU head during the night, creating a new organisation more connected to the gov
-Following 2015 Great Heatwave, officials become worried voters will try to vote out gov in 2019, FulTec decides to take over gov incase of revolt, and does that in 2017, killing major officials and rigging elections, controlling Fed from shadows
Population control, foodstuffs
-post-2003, agriculture is failing in Europe - FulTec must take advantage of other things to make food. Copies Food, Inc and uses jellyfish blooms, but struggles with that and lacks funds. Food, Inc is much richer and more talented than FulTec is after 2003 - Europe is put on the brink
-January 2009 - FulTec Natural - an insect and roach-based foodstuff, is first sold. It is very popular and sells out quickly, and becomes the main foodstuff sold in Europe
-One-Child Policy introduced in 2010 to curb overpopulation. However, it’s hard to enforce, and families with second children often hid them at their homes or in secret, horrific “baby shelters” where they are hidden from the authorities (use China’s OCP as template)
-In 2013, as the food crisis gets closer and closer, the Federation begins “Project Unthinkable” (name unrelated to the Operation) - recycling human flesh as food. Firstly it is used on convicts, and is sold as FulTec Plenty, an alternative to Natural. It doesn’t reach the same heights as Natural, however, until 2015 and 16, where Natural is in very short supply and FulTec Plenty is mass produced
-Eventually deaths are in short supply as too many people need it - in early 2018, plan is agreed to wipe out rural areas and use their bodies. Additionally, squads are sent out to internal refugees and families are taken at random
Foreign affairs
-UK becomes increasingly close to the Federation to survive. In 2014, Southampton Agreement is signed, which ties the UK even closer to Europe, essentially making it a puppet
-Federation invades Iceland in 2013. Due to its relatively colder temperatures, it becomes a summer home for lots of the elite. With FulTec seeing record profits, it buys off Iceland from Europe in 2014 and turns it into a summer home for the elite, building mansions there, destroying the local economy and replacing it with itself. Almost everyone in Iceland gets employed by FulTec. Would turn out to be a mistake as the cost was immense and impacted FulTec heavily in the Great Heatwave, contributing to FulTec mass adopting Plenty afterwards
-Switzerland becomes a dominant party democracy then an autocracy during 2000s to protect itself. In 2010s Europe becomes belligerent to it for its water supplies. Switzerland is running out of stored food and so they try make an agreement with Federation, signed in 2015, to exchange food and water with each other. Europe also doesn’t have enough food tho and so they modify the agreement later to threaten Switzerland and benefit them more
Vatican City and religion

-Following Crackdown Vatican speaks out against it but is quickly silenced by the Federation. No one is killed to avoid creating martyrs but anti-government and FulTec speech is suppressed
-Dissent grows following and Popes turn more extremist
Other major events
-In 2011 a nuclear reactor in France just south of Luxembourg goes critical and explodes due to rushed designing and construction and massive corruption and incompetence, not going as bad as Three Mile Island but worse than Chernobyl and lots of the surrounding area suffers from radiation poisoning. It’s too much effort to evacuate people that are there so the government just lets it be. Following this the Federation decides to solely focus on coal as nuclear is too risky.
2024-2026 - The Federation’s downfall

-2024 - British Revolution - reaction to a fire and a massacre in Birmingham leads to revolution across the country, British Civil War begins following. Federation gets lots of its food from Britain and so suffers
-At the same time, the same thing happens in Ireland. The military coups the Nordic Union after unrest quickly builds and kicks out the European Union. Event is called the “European Spring”
-Federation is close to collapse - expands range of people used for Plenty. Takes all internal refugees and sweep less-populated areas, and take people at random in densely-populated, poor areas in cities
-It is a totalitarian state by this point despite the mass chaos, comparable even to the USSR and China. However, despite the harsh punishments, crime is basically unpoliced and most processed for Plenty are innocent. It has truly become “anarcho-totalitarian”

Part 2-3
A Fractured World: The Cost of Civilization
Section 1: The End of the Cold War (1969-1988)

Excerpt from “The Lord of Moscow: The Life of Sergei Savateev”, by Sindre Vølstad, Neu Stockholm Press, 956 ASJ

https://youtu.be/pO6q_mFjEUg?si=sppliPk6F6FwlKCi 

The death of Chairman Mao sent ripples through the world. 

In places like the United States, the Nixon administration breathed a sigh of relief. In the north, however, General Secretary Anton Agassi was wary of the new regime in the land of Chenism. The Soviet Union rallied the rest of the Second World, taking its place once again as the foremost authority of Communism. 


Brezhnev's motorcade on January 22nd, 1969. He would be assassinated this day. 

The second Sino-Soviet split can be traced back all the way back to January 22nd, 1969, when Leonid Brezhnev was assassinated by an unknown assailant. Early reports claimed it was a disgruntled Soviet soldier, however, a later investigation by the KGB discovered that it was actually an agent of the People’s Republic of China. This finding was released on February 29th, 1972, the day after the Shanghai Accords were signed. 

The assassination had several effects. One, the General Secretary dying during the midst of the Cultural Revolution to the south, and assassinated by an agent of the People’s Republic of China no less, caused the Soviet leadership a great amount of worry. Mao was quickly turning into a second Stalin and this did not bode well - many in the USSR had lived through the horrors of Stalinism, and had decided that a Soviet version of the Cultural Revolution must be avoided at all costs. 

The Politburo went through a few months of infighting, and in June 1969 they came up with their answer - the Supreme Triumvirate of the Soviet Union. The Triumvirate, made up by the Minister of Defense, the General Secretary of the Communist Party, and the Director of the KGB, would share executive power equally. Any major decision made must satisfy two of the three men, and most importantly, if anyone else in the Communist Party felt that they were misusing their power, they could be removed from office, impeached, and barred from holding any office in the future. This was a lingering issue that had been plaguing the Soviet Union ever since the days of Stalin, and one that Khrushchev and Brezhnev had failed to reform. And now, it was being used to prevent another Mao. The First Triumvirate was General Secretary Anton Agassi, Minister of Defense Andrei Grechko, and KGB Director Yuri Andropov. 

Another effect of the assassination was that in Brezhnev’s motorcade, three esteemed Soviet Cosmonauts were killed. These three cosmonauts were the first two Soviet men and first Soviet woman in space, and were treated as national heroes. They were on the way to the unveiling of the USSR’s new Soyuz-8, which was the USSR’s response to the Apollo missions. When it was found that the spacecraft had been sabotaged as well, Grechko proposed the first order of the Triumvirate: the authorization of militarization initiatives for the Soviet Space Program. The Americans had begun to militarize their low-orbit aircraft, after the Lockheed-Douglas merge in 1968. 

The Soviet Union spent the rest of 1969 and 1970 reorganizing their economy, industry, and even the reorganization of their government. With Mao executing his insanity to the south, the Politburo was more than eager to reform to prevent a similar thing from happening (and thus being held responsible). In 1970, the average age of the Politburo was decreased to 49 after Secretary Agassi forcibly retired some of the more elderly members of the Soviet government. They were given nice, comfortable, but humble apartments in Moscow and an early pension, along with vacation homes in the Baltic SSRs. 

Agassi, who had worked his way up through the CPSU from the humble home of an Armenian farmer and an Azerbaijani factory worker, understood how the quality of life was decreasing for the average Soviet citizen. He was celebrated as a “People’s Leader”: he frequently walked the streets and talked with Soviet citizens, asking them about how the Politburo could best represent them. He spoke candidly about the problems the USSR was facing, but he always tied it back to the lack of “Pan-Sovietism” and later on, the Sino-Soviet split. What he did not understand was that other Soviet citizens would discriminate against their fellow workers for being born into different republics of the Soviet Union - they were all sons and daughters of the Motherland, and all had been lifted from the Tsar’s oppressive regime by mighty Lenin. If an Armenian and Azerbaijani could find love, so could a Kazakh and a Turkmen, or a Ukrainian and a Russian. All had been lifted up to the supreme unifying culture of being a Soviet, and in that unifying culture, all tensions melted away. 

This caused some issues in the Central Asian SSRs, initially. A minor uprising in the Kyrgyz SSR was caused when the head of the Kyrgyz Communist Party was forcibly retired by Secretary Agassi, but the Red Army was called in and the unrest fizzled out by 1971. The Tajik SSR experienced a similar period of unrest. Tensions would require Moscow to keep a tight grip on the Turkmens. Efforts to wipe out corruption in the Georgian SSR were also far more than initially projected. 

But in order to enact this vision of a truly unified people, Secretary Agassi knew that he had to increase the standard of living. Racial tensions only existed when the people were unhappy, or so he thought, and so he dedicated 1971 to be the year that the Soviet Union would begin to modernize. No longer would the Soviet Union focus on spreading Communism - that would take care of itself, he would say - instead, at least for the 1970s, the Soviet Union would focus on increasing the standard of living for its Soviet citizens. Not just its Russian citizens, not just its farmers, not just the Kazakhs and the Turkmens, but for all under the Red Flag. This would lead to the Soviet Union supporting leftist movements in Africa and Latin America far less, though they still gave intel and training. 

In Vietnam, the Soviet Union stopped sending more advanced materiel to the VietCong, and instead only trained soldiers and sent small arms. Due to the increased number of American and South Korean troops, the Soviet Union strongly urged Ho Chi Minh to consider South Vietnam a lost cause. The USSR stopped offering intel and tactical advice as well. 

The detente continued peacefully. Many agreements relating to trade and arms limitations continued like in OTL. Secretary Agassi’s policies in combination with recognizing East Germany as an independent state would be the start of the Soviet Union opening up trade with the West and normalizing relations. “One People, Two Systems” was the doctrine of the Triumvirate at the time, as they believed that all were of the Soviet people, even if they didn’t know it yet. The Soviet Union was reshaping itself into being a truly egalitarian dictatorship of the proletariat, and prided itself into being the future of humanity - unlike the insanity that was taking place in China. Despite their best efforts though, the lure of Chenism would be too tantalizing and the idea of Eurocommunism would never catch on until a brief flare up in 2003. 

And then, on September 11th, 1971, Chairman Mao was assassinated. 

For a small period of time, the Soviets quietly celebrated. The Second Stalin was dead, and with it, China would return to a place of normalcy and rationality that befit a communist. Both Secretary Agassi and Minister Grechko were elated, but Director Andropov remained skeptical. Embedded agents, corroborated by satellite photos, showed vast amounts of political elite from Mao’s regime escaping from the People’s Republic of China. They were running everywhere they could - to North Vietnam, to North Korea, to the People’s Republic of Mongolia, and some into the Central Asian SSRs. Secretary Agassi and Minister Grechko remained hopeful until October 1971 when an escaped Chinese official, the leader of the Communist Party in his small town near Nanjing, told them in a top-secret meeting that the new leader of the PRC had betrayed communism. 

Chairman Chen Qiang had started to hijack the Cultural Revolution to suit his own goals, and those goals were relentless industrialization for the sole purpose of capitalist expansion. Already people were being rounded up and executed by the PLA for crimes of being “Maoist loyalists”, in addition to being intellectuals or those who didn’t agree with Chen’s new policies. 

All the effort from 1964-1972 to ease the tensions between China and the USSR vanished once it was discovered that an agent working for Chairman Chen had assassinated Brezhnev, and any desire to renew them evaporated when Chairman Chen Qiang and President Richard Nixon signed the Shanghai Accords. 

The USSR was now bordered by an insane, backwards capitalist country that had betrayed its workers. This cemented the USSR as the sole leader of the communist world, and Secretary Agassi repealed the Brezhnev Policy - only once China was back in the fold could the world revolution continue. The Soviet Union shifted towards a mindset of countering China rather than the West - China was quickly building the capacity to, in Secretary Agassi’s own words, “overrun the entire Earth”. Border skirmishes between the USSR and China led to almost 2000 casualties in 1971 alone. When the KGB arrested people, they began using the excuse of “pro-Chinese sympathies”, or “pro-Chinese mindsets”. 

It was then that Director Andropov proposed what would come to be known as “Monsoon Protocol”, in which the Soviet Union’s embedded agents helped grant the fleeing intelligentsia safe passage into the Soviet Union through North Korea and Mongolia. These members of China’s elite would then be given a safe haven in Moscow[1] and were even offered jobs in the Politburo, however, these Chinese refugees were for the most part never treated the same as the Soviet citizens who took them in. Although the last history books written in 2027 would never admit it, it was these intelligentsia that would save the USSR. 

The Politburo, despite Secretary Agassi’s reforms in the wake of Brezhenv’s assassination, was still set in their ways when it came to industrial and agricultural policy. It was the Chinese Exiles, as they came to be known, that provided a fresh pair of eyes and tales of the inefficiency of Mao’s policies that caused the Soviet Union to make a dramatic shift in its economic, industrial and agricultural policies. In 1972, the USSR began widespread industrialization programs to build massive factories (though not quite on the scale of China’s - at least not yet) throughout the north-west for the sole purpose of manufacturing parts to upgrade existing Stalin-era factories. Soviet and Chinese architects worked together to redesign the USSR’s infrastructure to be far more efficient, and while they retained their brutalist style, they did become notably more opulent. Elevated motorways stretched from Moscow to Leningrad, and 1km tall Worker’s Palaces were built in Kiev, Minsk and Riga. Intricate People’s Universities gave farmers the opportunity to learn how to be a factory worker, leading to a massive increase in education and the creation of a white-collar service industry. Irrigation efforts were reworked to dramatically increase agricultural yield, and were concentrated in the south-east. Lake Baikal was drained for irrigation efforts, beforehand there were many jokes about it constantly catching fire. But until 1975, the Soviet Union kept manufacturing large amounts of weapons. Minister Grechko and Director Andropov both believed that the USSR would soon be invaded, even though the Chinese Exiles universally saw it as unlikely. 


The Soviet Palace of Worker’s Rights and Culture, Moscow. Finished in 1985. 

In 1975, the Soviet Union would ratify their fourth constitution. This new constitution (known historically as the Agassi Constitution) enshrined the Soviet Union as the one true beacon of communism after the fall of China to Chenism. It also solidified the Triumvirate system into the law to prevent another cult of personality like how Stalin or Mao had. This new Constitution, however, still emphasized how the Soviet Law was supreme to the laws of the Republics. Like previous iterations, the citizens were in theory granted freedom of speech, freedom of the press, freedom of assembly and freedom of religion, however there were always many by-laws that prohibited these rights in relation to government opposition and organized religion. After the constitution was ratified, the Politburo also recognized the Chinese Exiles as the sole legal government of China, and not Chen (or Taiwan, for that matter). 

Near the end of President Nixon’s second term, the USA began to shift its focus on “fixing” the USSR much like how China had been “fixed”. It was Nixon who coined the “Two-Hand” policy, in which the USA juggled neutrality between the USSR and China. The USA’s representatives to the USSR always talked with a subtle hint of disdain for China that would always be followed by a claim of neutrality, and while the USSR was unsure if the USA actually disliked China, they operated on the policy of trying to bring the USA over to their side - they could not hope to fight off China alone. One of the more paranoid members of congress, a Democratic Senator from Louisiana, actually agreed with this - and the Washington-Moscow Treaty was secretly signed on March 31st, 1975. This treaty secured an alliance between the USA and USSR if China ever became more trouble than it was worth. To the USA, it was merely lip service. To the Soviet Union, it was one step closer to potentially bringing communism to the USA. 

As a result of the closer ties between the two nations, when the Helsinki Accords were signed in 1975, the Nixon administration kept a much closer eye on it being implemented in the USSR. The USSR would do its best to follow through on the treaty, however, many human rights abuses would still be recorded. The USSR never made any attempt to democratize, despite the urging of the Morgan and King administrations. But still, the two countries became closer than they had ever been before. Starting in 1976, the USSR allowed free passage of Jews to Israel as a sign of good faith. 

The detente continued unabated. In 1977, the Soviet Union finally built enough nukes to rival the United States, and it was here that both countries made an unspoken agreement to stop bloating their militaries to ridiculous levels. Afterall, the United States had stopped the spread of Communism in China through diplomacy and trade, so the USA decided to reduce their military spending, instead subsidizing the military-industrial complex for exports. The arms manufacturers lobbied for increased spending, however, they soon found their niche in the proxy wars in the 80s. Meanwhile in the USSR the reduced military spending meant there could be even more of a focus on modernization to improve the average quality of life of the Soviet citizen. 

The two countries began to truly focus on the path of peace (and profit) in late 1977, when Secretary Agassi met with President Winston Morgan in Bonn, West Germany. Together, they toured the Bundeskunsthalle and attended a concert of Beethoven’s Ode to Joy while eating a meal of grünkohl. Both leaders renewed their wishes for decreased tensions, and President Morgan continued Nixon’s “Two Hands” policy by subtly suggesting the cessation of trade agreements with Chenist China. Their talk would also inspire the USSR to consider opening trade up between itself and its satellite states, and authorizing small-scale “surplus” transactions that were not a part of the centrally planned economy. 

In 1979, during the Afghan Crisis, the Second Triumvirate debated back and forth if direct invention in the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan was necessary. Ultimately, Secretary Agassi and Minister Aleks Grigorev (the new Minister of Defense, who replaced Minister Grechko in 1977) decided against it as they believed that the Soviet Union’s military should be reserved in case China invaded through Mongolia. The Soviet Union would continue to supply and train Afghan communists, and allowed them to use Uzbek SSR military bases for mock combat exercises. The USA, while still openly neutral, did supply the Mujahideen with surplus weaponry from the Vietnam war and vehicles. Although neither country admitted it, Afghanistan had become another Vietnam and Korea, a proxy war for the forces of capitalism and communism to duke it out once again. Both of them took great care to keep the proxy war inside the borders of Afghanistan, but by 1981, the war fizzled out into a protracted conflict. 

The 1980s would prove to be an exciting time for the USSR. After hosting the United States at the 1980 Olympics in Moscow, Secretary Agassi signed a landmark trading deal with the European Community and began the mass production of cultural products for wide-scale export. Things such as posters, books, clothing and even nesting dolls, all with a Soviet flare, began to be circulated around the world. The West, who had already become culturally stagnant with the advent of Chenism and hyper-consumerism, greedily gobbled them up. The works of Lenin became casual reading, while clothes of the Soviet style occasionally became the hottest trend in the Northern Hemisphere. 

Then, the Second Triumvirate was faced with yet another quandary. Should they continue the process of normalizing trade with the West, or subsidize the rising prices in their satellite states? Both Secretary Agassi and Minister Grigorev decided on the process of slowly and carefully opening up trade[2]. Chen raised an eyebrow at this, and the USA began frothing at the mouth. The Triumvirate’s official ruling was that trade would be opened up very gradually, first in the outer Eastern Bloc and working its way inwards towards Moscow. Despite the efforts of reforming the economic, industrial and agricultural systems of the Soviet Union, there were still many products and machinery parts that the Soviets simply could not produce fast enough. They would need a great many items imported to fully retool their factories, and with it, the quality of life for the average Soviet citizen. To satisfy the hardliners, it was only the Warsaw Pact countries that had barrier free trade. However, there was nothing stopping the government from buying the splendors of the West through the Warsaw Pact. 

Overnight, the USSR began importing foreign food, agricultural products, fertilizers, advanced machinery and computer terminals in record numbers.
