Holden Terminals, Pan-Atlantic Business Machines, FulTec and 4M all scrambled for contracts with the Eastern European states. The Soviets began fully focusing on bringing up the quality of living of their citizens, while also secretly preparing for a war with China. Warm relations with the USA also prevented lots of ballistic missiles from being placed all over the world. 

In 1981, the Triumvirate quickly took notice of how efficient the updated factories were, and began subsidizing upgrade programs not only in the USSR itself but throughout the entire Second World. The Byelorussian SSR was turned into one giant factory complex, designed by Chinese Exiles. The Latvian SSR had its own complex of superfactories built, and that was where a majority of the USSR’s cultural products were built. These factories would become so large and complex that the USSR began importing workers from the Warsaw Pact in a special work program that granted the workers citizenship by 1986. In 1982, with the help of Chinese architects, the first Soviet Superfactory was built in the Turkmen SSR. 

The Soviet Union never stopped dreaming of the stars, however. In 1974, the Soviet Union had made their first manned mission to the moon when Soyuz-14 landed on the lunar surface. Secretly, Secretary Agassi and Minister Grechko both believed that the next world war would happen in space, be it from nukes dropped in space or countries using hypersonic spaceships to invade other countries. This was the Soviet Union’s main military priority since 1976, when the United States established Outpost One. The Industrial Goliath of China could easily create an army of spaceships and conquer the Moon and then the Earth. The USSR took great care to ensure that their plans for the upcoming “space war” were kept a great secret from both the USA and China. In 1978, the first prototypes for space-based weapons were tested in secret in the Arctic while the rest of the world was busy watching the 1978 Winter Olympics. In 1980, the Soviet Union began drafting up plans for their first space base, meant to also be a satellite relay station and later an automated numbers station. A small amount of the trillions of western products imported in 1981 were dedicated solely to this “Tunguska Protocol”. 


Soviet propaganda poster depicting the plans for Lenin’s Vigil, circa 1982

In 1982, the Politburo noticed large amounts of government funds being directed towards a “Cosmic Defense Protocol”. Western machinery parts that were requisitioned for upgrading factories mysteriously vanished. Initial reports from Secretary Agassi claimed that it was merely a clerical error, but when Minister Grigorev pushed back, an official investigation was called. 

In April of that year, the investigation was concluded. The investigation found that Secretary Agassi and Minister Grigorev were diverting huge portions of the defense budget on a Soviet Space Weapons Program that seemed not only impractical, as both the United States and China had not shown any effort to weaponize their space program, but paranoid as well. The hardliners accused Secretary Agassi of being mentally unfit to lead the Soviet Union.

In May 1982, General Secretary Agassi would resign from his post as he realized that if he went through on righting the Sino-Soviet split, he could never make good his plans to truly elevate the life of the Soviet citizen. This was followed by Minister Grigorev being impeached for such an overzealous response, and Director Andropov was found dead in his office. 

In an emergency session of the Politburo, the Third Triumvirate is formed. Demyan Petrov was picked as the Minister of Defense, while Yemelyan Fedoro was chosen to be the Director of the KGB. Both men were very liberal, coming from the Ukrainian and Latvian SSRs respectively, and so Gennady Yanayev, a hardliner communist, was chosen as the General Secretary to appease the conservatives. 

The USA, still playing neutral, expressed their condolences with Agassi’s resignation and hoped to continue foster good relations between the two of them. This resulted in President Morgan pledging to help the Soviets in their own endeavors in space. It was here that Chairman Chen proposed a project to build a joint USA-USSR-PRC space station together - the Station for International Cooperation and Friendship. It would be designed and built by scientists and engineers from all three nations in the hope of fostering better relations, and it was the first decision of the Third Triumvirate, passing with a 2-1 vote. Over time, more and more nations would join the project, such as the European Union, Brazil, India and even South Africa. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Po1rpnYwlY&pp=ygUeZHNjaGluZ2hpcyBraGFuIG1vc2thdSBlbmdsaXNo 

This new Triumvirate was even more economically liberal than the one that came before it. In 1983 the Soviet Union adopted a fourth constitution. This constitution, crafted during the dizzying heights of the Glorious Decades, allowed for the import of select products approved by the state. The Soviet Union also allowed for the export of cultural products to all countries, including China. Citizens could buy and sell traditionally “subversive” material but they had to pay a huge tax on it and would be put on a list. 

The 1983 constitution resulted in the USSR economy exploding overnight. The Lithuanian SSR would import several million Orthodox bibles, and suddenly half of Lithuania was on the KGB’s watchlist. This would lead to a very small uprising between the native Lithuanians and the Soviets, but it was quickly crushed by the KGB with religious materials being banned from imports. This was lifted a year later after a series of mass demonstrations by muslim Soviets in the Central Asian SSRs. 

One of the results of the close ties between the USA and USSR was the barrier-free travel introduced in 1983. A massive Soviet rock concert in Moscow featuring Dschinghis Khan attracted over 4 million people from both the East and the West. The Baltic SSRs became the site of a huge tourism industry. American and European businesses built factories all over the Kazakh SSR. Borscht was added to the menu of McDonald’s in 1984, and clothes manufactured in the Tajik SSR became the height of western fashion. The Azerbaijani SSR became extremely rich as its oil was sold to Turkey and Europe, and soon all of the USSR was being choked in the pollution of progress. Disco saw a resurgence across the world. And in 1984, Soviet citizens from every Republic came to Los Angeles to compete in the Olympics, and won quite a few medals. 


The first McDonald’s opened in the USSR, 1987

Finally, in 1985 after pressure from the USA, the USSR created the Concord of Moscow, which was essentially the USSR’s version of the Shanghai Accords. Being prototyped with barrier-free trade between the Estonian SSR and Finland, the Triumvirate finally lifted all trade restrictions. It solidified completely free trade between members of the Eastern Bloc and even allowed them to transition out of planned economies, but most importantly, it allowed any citizen of the Soviet Union to petition the government to import almost any product from the west. With the dawn of free trade, the Communist Party reimbursed each citizen with a small portion of the profits from their exports, creating the first Universal Basic Income. 

It was not all sunshine and rainbows, however. President King and Secretary Yanayev did not walk through meadows holding hands. The hesitation of the USA to honor the Washington-Moscow Treaty made the KGB increasingly suspicious of their supposed ally. Without a non-Russian like Agassi as the General Secretary, the policy of “Pan-Soviet” citizenship began to fall apart. In 1984, a massive terrorist attack disrupted the irrigation draining the Aral Sea, and an uprising in Estonia was put down in 1987. Anti-Azerbaijani race-riots would happen in Armenia throughout 1987, and 95% of the Kazakh SSR would become completely inhospitable to human life due to pollution. 

In 1988, the Soviet Union’s economy was valued at $4.02 Trillion, with some of the most valuable stocks in the world being state-owned Soviet companies. The economy is slowly transitioning out of being centralized and planned, and every citizen has at least one color TV and automobile. Not all the TVs were made in the USSR, nor the automobiles, but the citizens held a special pride for the products they made themselves.The Soviet Union and the United States were set to launch their first joint manned mission to the Moon to finish Lenin’s Vigil. 

But then, on one fateful day in June, Secretary Yanayev was called into a top secret but urgent meeting by Minister Petrov and Director Fedoro about the rapidly developing situation in the Middle East…


[1] The KGB wanted to keep a close eye on them, afterall.
[2] The idea for this ruling was so that the Soviet Union could again focus its resources on a potential war with China rather than propping up its satellite states. The idea of opening up was inspired by Gierek’s policies in Poland. 
[3] Unlike Outpost One, Lenin’s Vigil would never be completed. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=46PQWSoQUaM 

Section 2: The Green Miracle (1988-2000)

Moscow was immensely disappointed with Saddam Hussein’s decision regarding Iran. While the Politburo was saddened at the loss of Ruhollah Khomeini and the death of the Islamic Socialist movement, open war between Iran and Iraq could result in wide-scale total war throughout the Middle East. Minister Petrov, who had been working closely with the USSR’s ambassador to Iraq, was blindsided by Hussein’s suggestion of using nuclear weapons. To assure the rest of the Triumvirate, Minister Petrov promised he would resign if Iraq ever used their nuclear arsenal. 

On June 8th, 1988, Petrov submitted his resignation. 

With the accidental nuking of Tel Aviv, the Egyptian Coalition had run out of luck. Israel now had only one option to possibly save itself - the Samson option. And just like Samson toppling the pillars of the Philistine Temple, this action would topple the pillars of civilization and bring an end to the Glorious Decades. With the overwhelming force of the United Arab Army concentrated in and around Israel, many nukes slipped through their net. Soon Cairo was hit, then Beirut, followed by Damascus… the list went on. The Arab nations started launching warheads that were being tossed like water balloons as the process of mutually assured destruction was carried out. While the USA slept, the Middle East burned. 

Secretary Yanayev however was not as concerned as his peers. As far as he was concerned, this did not impact the Soviet Union. Petrov’s replacement, Ivan Voronin, viewed it differently. To Voronin, this was a wake up call. The USSR, and the rest of the leftist world for that matter, had stagnated and rotted ever since trade was opened up in the late 1970s. The average Soviet citizen lived better, yes, but at the cost of their heritage and their pride. Agassi was foolish to believe that the stars were the site of nuclear war when it was happening on their southern border. Minister Voronin was a stern believer in Brezhnev’s policies, and his first proposal to the Fourth Triumvirate was that the Soviet Union must once again be a defender of the burgeoning socialist movements that would inevitably spring as a result of the inevitable depression. Secretary Yanayev was also strongly urged by the Chairman of the State Planning Committee to gradually pull back on all “unplanned” economic activities. 

While the rest of the Politburo was initially skeptical of a depression, those fears quickly became reality when stock markets across the world collapsed and tourism took a permanent nose dive. Demand for Soviet cultural products dried up by July, and soon only the members of the Warsaw Pact could afford the USSR’s factory-made products. By August, the only shipments the USSR made to their western allies were essential machinery parts. The Minister of Agriculture and Food delivered an alarming report to the Politburo in September - harvests in the Ukrainian SSR were actually down for the 3rd year in a row. This was normally not a problem, as the USSR could simply import more food from the USA. However, with the entire transportation infrastructure of the world relying entirely on fossil fuels, importing would very quickly not be an option. The USSR instead began construction on a pipeline to divert the rest of the Aral Sea to supplement the Ukrainian SSR for the next harvest. 

For the entirety of its existence, the Soviet Union was never concerned about the environment. “Progress at any cost” had been the policy of Stalin and never stopped, even under Khrushchev, Brezhnev, Agassi and now Yanayev. Except, now almost a third of the once-arable land of the USSR was now tainted with industrial pollutants, toxic fertilizers, and acid rain. At the current rate of consumption, it was predicted that even simple staples such as bread would run out by January 1st, 1990. Immediately, a ration system was introduced. Citizens were encouraged to grow their own food in gardens, and in spring 1989, a selection of grain seeds were sent to every citizen who wished to grow a garden. 

Another aspect of life that was immediately changed was the production of “non-essential” goods was to cease by December 31st, 1988. The USSR had only barely begun to open up, so the transition was easy to stop. Citizens were allowed to keep certain products as long as they filled out the required paperwork and sent it to the State, or else risk a visit from the KGB. In 1989, this would be taken a step further, and the Ministry of Efficiency was created. Any excess luxury goods, such as surplus toasters, or old broken down automobiles, were to be collected and their metal repurposed and their wood burned. 

In October 1988, the USSR got a desperate plea for aid from Chairman Chen. He was begging for the Soviet Union to integrate buying Chinese products into their planned economy. Secretary Yanayev laughed to his face, and that was the last diplomatic meeting either country would have with each other. 

Then in November 1988, the Moldovan SSR attempted to secede from the USSR and join Romania, which the Communist Party of Moldova believed was weathering the crisis better. However, not a single citizen outside of Moldova would learn of the attempted uprising. Enter Sergei Savateev, an up-and-coming officer in the KGB. He was a truly ruthless man, and used not only traditional methods of coercion (at least for the KGB) but also some that could be considered almost American in nature. Soon, Moldovan politicians began dropping like flies, either from sudden heart attacks or simply disappearing, never to be seen again. Pro-Independence rallies turned into violent riots that left hundreds dead. Soldiers with pro-Romanian sympathies would die in horrific training accidents, or foolishly clean their guns while they were somehow loaded. Savateev was of the firm belief that Romania had betrayed the USSR over 30 years ago by exploiting the first Sino-Soviet split. The speed and brutality with which Savateev used to pacify the Moldovan SSR impressed, and horrified, many members of the Politburo. 


Sergei Savateev’s official state portrait, 1993. Expect to hear about him a lot.

The Soviet Union was adjusting very rapidly to the worsening depression, but it would soon be put to the test when on December 7, 1988 a massive earthquake would devastate the Armenian SSR. Over one million casualties would result from this disaster, along with trillions of rubles[1] of damage. The Red Army was sent in to regain order after Yerevan was lost to rioting and looting from bored Armenians. The reconstruction of the Armenian SSR would be a topic of fierce debate in the Politburo for the next couple of years, but it slowly became clear that no country in the world had the resources to fully reconstruct the republic. 

New Year’s Day 1989 was a bleak celebration. The government temporarily lifted the restrictions of many luxury goods, such as champagne, beef and toys. As Secretary Yanayev gave a speech after an unusually militant and grandiose Red Army parade, he candidly stated that while the worst was yet to come. It was because of the Soviet Union’s strict adherence to Marxism that allowed it to come out on top during the Great Depression and the Great Patriotic War. Already, every single stock market in the world had shut down with the exception of the New York, London and Brussels exchanges and even then they were only open once a week. The Eternal Depression, as it came to be known, would cause international trade to practically vanish. This caused a massive shift in internal politics in almost every single country - right-wing capitalist countries were morphed into glorious left-wing socialist states, all on their way to communism. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mwAGw92RHQc 

And it would be the Soviet Union who would guide them. 

Already, France had become a communist state with the election of Arlette Pascal. Mexico elected far left socialist Edmundo Gutiérrez who had campaigned on the death of corporate executives. The General, the leader of Myanmar, was already doing this: thirteen of the richest men hung from flagpoles in the Capitol, picked at by crows. As the KGB began recalling agents, some even predicted that the USA would soon become a fully socialist state under President Elliot Graves. There was a Red Wave sweeping the world.

Not all of the changes to nations were hopeful - Czechoslovakia, which had already been fracturing internally, finally split apart. It was remarkably peaceful - most of the world was still in the peaceful daze of the Glorious Decades. The KGB kept a close eye on this, along with the attempted uprising in the Latvian SSR that year. Finland was growing worryingly close with Sweden and Norway, who were in talks of forming a Union. 

The Soviet Union proposed their first attempt at leading the charge of Communism would take place in Iran. Minister Voronin claimed that, because Iran was on their border, they could not risk the Islamic Socialist movement stagnating once again. And this time, there was no pesky CIA to stop them. The Shah had recently been overthrown, and a new Revolutionary Socialist Party of Iran was taking over the government. While admirable, it soon became clear that they were not going towards the path of communism. The Iranians would be shown the ways of communism, and it would be Minister Voronin who would do it himself. Soviet tanks began rolling across the border, armed with water cannons and other riot-control weapons. This caused a huge uproar from the nearby Armenian SSR, which was still recovering from the earthquake and felt that they were being abandoned by Moscow. 

A week later, the Iranian Soviet Socialist Republic was established and joined the USSR. The purpose of the Soviet invasion of Iran was actually to see if they could put off some of the fires in Iran’s oil fields and salvage some of their fuel. After the earthquake in the Caucus heavily disrupted the flow of oil to Moscow, the Politburo realized that their fuel was running on borrowed time. This plan would see immense difficulty being implemented, as the Soviets had to invest heavily in the all-but destroyed Iranian infrastructure. The Soviet Union drained entire rivers in an attempt to stem the fires that Iraq lit, but brutally thick oil fires erased any crop yield in 1990 and 1991, on top of workers dropping like flies from cancer cases. By 1992, it was clear that this plan was useless. 

This would not be the only invasion that the USSR would orchestrate in 1989. Later that year, the Soviet Union would properly invade the Democratic People’s Republic of Afghanistan and reform it into the Afghan Soviet Socialist Republic. However, the Afghan SSR was an even bigger failure than the Iranian SSR. Drought, desertification and radiation made almost all the arable land unusable by 1991, requiring the Soviets to support them with surplus food and aid. And every day, waves of starving, radioactive refugees swarmed the border. Pakistan would shoot them on sight, which caused them to make a beeline for the Afghan SSR and the hope of getting into the Soviet Union. The Soviets attempted to integrate as many of them as they could - they were free labor, after all - but they were rapidly running out of space and resources. Minister Voronin kept trying to insist that the Soviet Union must be the nation that would guide these fledgling republics to communism, but as life got harder, the Politburo made the controversial decision to pull out of the Iranian and Afghan SSRs by 2000. 

The Minister of Foreign Affairs eagerly expected a response from the United States regarding Iran and Afghanistan, anticipating the USA to pull out of treaties and to treat it as an act of war. The USA was starting to have their hands full, and all they could muster was a shouting match between the White House and the Kremlin. Secretary Yanayev took all the treaties that the USA and USSR had signed throughout the Glorious Decades, brought them to the Politburo, and proudly burned them. In truth, it was a formality - the Secretary had secretly loathed the way the country was going before he took office, and even then, he was mainly outvoted by the other two members of the Third Triumvirate. Now though, with hardliner Minister Voronin on his side, he could finally steer his country in the way it was meant to go. Only Director Fedoro, and his Latvian sympathies, had to go. No one really knows what happened to Fedoro, only that he was there one day, and Sergei Savateev was there the next. 

All around Moscow, things were starting to fall apart. The Uzbek SSR, which began to see drought and desertification creep in from the Afghan SSR, required more and more aid from the Politburo to keep it afloat. Decades of industrialization had caused arable land to quickly dry up, and a study projected that the USSR would run out of aid by 2005. Things were getting even worse in the Turkmen SSR: after the Aral Sea was completely drained and the land overexploited to grow cotton, the planned economy collapsed overnight. Director Savateev thwarted several terrorist plots and suppressed a growing independence movement. The fields caught on fire however, and a massive fire tornado destroyed Poltoratski in 1990 along with the first Soviet megafactory. The casualties ranged in the millions, and with the Uzbek, Iranian and Afghan SSRs already draining Moscow’s coffers, the decision was made to evacuate Soviet citizens north. 


Drought, desertification and acid rain left much of the Central Asian SSR like this. Here, an abandoned Soviet food truck is left to dry in the sun. Photo taken circa 1999, during the last of the evacuation efforts in the Kazakh SSR. (OOC: screenshot of the Half-Life 2 Mod Swelter, which is set in Kazakhstan post Combine Invasion)

The Hot Summer of 1990 caused much of Siberia to melt, and with it, huge swathes of muddy taiga were exposed. The Minister of Agriculture and Food proposed that the evacuees of the Central Asian SSRs (which were quickly turning into radioactive dust bowls) help clear the exposed wilderness in the south to build more farmland. The Triumvirate approved this, with Director Savateev keeping a close eye on City-545, as the first refugee camp came to be known. 

Secretary Yanayev and Minister Voronin changed their focus to Europe, meanwhile. The leading economists of the USSR made a worrying report: most of Europe’s economies would collapse by 1995 if nothing was done. This could cause Europe to become one giant battlefield not seen since 1914, and with it, the Iron Curtain would fall. The KGB was worried that the burgeoning socialist movements in Belgium, West Germany and Italy might go down the path of “national socialism” like Hitler had before, and so the Triumvirate proposed the Yanayev Plan: Europe could survive, but it would need to carefully manage and plan its economy. And the Soviet Union would be the country to guide Europe. 

In 1990, Soviet envoys were sent to not just the Eastern Bloc nations, but the Western Bloc and Non-Aligned ones as well. The Western Bloc rebuffed them with various levels of politeness[2]. Brussels was actually inspired by the Yanayev Plan, and while they would never admit it, it was one of the reasons that caused the European Union to federalize.The Non-Aligned nations were far more hostile. The People’s Socialist Republic of Albania and the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia actually threatened to execute their Soviet envoys on the spot. This was not unexpected, however - Minister Voronin was almost counting on this. 

Yugoslavia had been one of the very few countries to not benefit from the Glorious Decades. Their extreme dedication to isolationism had brought their economy to its knees, and the federal government was struggling to maintain their grip on the populace. Veselin Đuranović’s ineffectual leadership had caused ethnic tensions and independence movements in Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Kosovo and Macedonia, and the country had been on the brink of civil war for almost a decade. Many of the various factions wanted to join the Western Bloc and others wanted to align themselves with the Soviets in the wake of the Crash of 1988. In one last desperate attempt to retain national unity and preserve the Yugoslav identity, Yugoslavia launched a not-so-surprise invasion of Albania, Greece and Bulgaria on February 25, 1990. Albania and Greece, both trying to court Brussels, were largely ignored by the Soviet leadership, but because Bulgaria was a member of the Warsaw Pact, the rest of the Eastern Bloc rose up in their defense. 

Bulgaria, which had descended into civil war when ethnic tensions broke out between the native Bulgarians and the Turks, was already fighting tooth and nail for their country’s survival. The ethnic Turks, who had been almost worked to extinction in Chinese-style megafactories in the 80s, had rebelled and declared the Bulgarian province of Kardzhali to be the “Turkish Republic of Bulgaria”. Nobody recognized this nation, however, as everyone had enough on their plate already. The Turkish breakaway state tried to join the military dictatorship of Türkiye, and was in the process of negotiations when Yugoslavia invaded. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LeUkUx9RMn0 

Minister Voronin wanted to show the world the might of the Soviet Army, which had not seen direct conflict since 1968. He ended up withdrawing Soviet troops from Mongolia[3], an event that the Chinese would later exploit. Fighting was initially very bloody and involved trench warfare with lots of infantry[4] and at the behest of Minister Voronin, Director Savateev was withdrawn from his post in City 649. All it would take is a few Soviet-made weapons delivered to a few Slovenian nationalists, some satellite photos of government formations sent to Bosnian rebels, and the poisoning of a Serbian general for Yugoslavia to fall apart. The Yugoslav War was mainly over by January 1991. Most nations of the Balkans would remain at war for the next two decades, as the ethnic groups fought over dwindling resources. 

The fighting did not stop there, however. Both Minister Voronin and Director Savateev wanted revenge against Albania for their siding with Chairman Chen all the way back in the early 1970s. As the various regions of Yugoslavia were fighting each other, the Soviet Union waltzed into Albania and set up a pro-Soviet regime. The partitions of Albania and Yugoslavia were completed in 1992, and the new regimes, loyal to the Soviets, were allowed to join the Warsaw Pact. East German Warsaw Pact troops were kept around for peacekeeping, and secretly helped funnel valuable mineral resources into the USSR and East Germany. 

The Soviet Union had re-asserted itself as the sole authority in Eastern Europe. 

Turning back to domestic affairs, the Triumvirate had noticed that ethnic tensions had been steadily increasing with the growing dust bowl spreading from Central Asia. In 1992, Azerbaijani nationalists sabotaged a natural gas pipeline and caused widespread ecological and economic damage. While the rest of the world was watching in horror as China committed war crimes in Taiwan, the USSR’s Red Army would come in second place in the Geneva Olympics. With the Armenian SSR already under martial law, a permanent Red Army division was established in Dagestan to keep watch on the Caucus SSRs and suppress Armenian insurgents. Azerbaijan SSR’s intact industry would result in the native Azerbaijani being worked to the bone in penal labor, with rebellious Armenians being sent there too. Conditions were kept deliberately weak to excuse harsher punishment and increased sentences. The farmland in the Caucuses were becoming more tainted by the day, so the convicts worked in industrial gulags making replacement machinery for the legions of factories in Western Russia. 

The KGB were watching with bated breath at the Olympic games in Beijing that year, and many were under the impression that it was a trap to hold valuable members of the athletic community hostage. The Triumvirate, now far more open in their hatred of China once again, protested against China’s imperialist conquests in Indochina, Mongolia and Taiwan. It was here that the true purpose of the Yanayev plan was revealed: with the United States no longer in the picture to defeat China, the KGB was secretly co-opting the remaining industry in Europe to mass-produce weapons of war. Bullets from Bulgaria, helmets from Hungary, and rifles from Romania. This actually helped stimulate the failing economy of the Eastern Bloc, briefly turning it into a hopeful recession. The Soviet Union also resumed research into using nuclear power as an energy source for transportation, prototyping it with their navy. 

The Iranian SSR was on its last legs, and in Spring 1993, the Soviets officially pulled out. The Iranians soon devolved into civil war between those who wanted to keep the Soviet-style of Socialism (mainly those already in power) and the proponents of a more Islamic-focused brand of socialism. 

As the crisis worsened, and each summer became hotter and hotter, the USSR’s southern neighbors began acting out more and more. By 1995, almost all the nations south of 40° N were in civil war conditions, and south of the Tropic of Cancer, total anarchy. Tehran only controlled a few hundred km of Iran, and most of Kabul was a wasteland. Türkiye had been an ultranationalist dictatorship for almost six years now, and was constantly threatening to invade Greece, Bulgaria and the Ukrainian SSR. Hungary’s mixed economy fully collapsed, with the nation entering civil war between communist hardliners and pro-Eurofed socialists. Romania was dealing with huge amounts of homeless teenagers, who roamed the cities committing petty crimes as a result of the strict rationing. These various criminal waves escalated into riots which escalated into a full-scale civil war between the once-wealthy industrialists and the government, with the starving citizens caught in the middle. 

In the summer of 1995, edged on by Turkish infiltrators, the Ukrainian SSR led an open revolt against the USSR. Sick of being worked to the bone for the past 5 years, the Ukrainian farmers started burning their crops as a form of protest to demand better working conditions, better hours and better pay. In response, the Red Army, directed by Minister Voronin, started to raze various Ukrainian cities to the ground. Families were broken up, with random members sent to gulags, held hostage, and some simply executed on the spot. Only a few fields were set on fire, as only a very small portion of the farmers actually participated in the rebellion. However, due to the hot, dry air, the fire quickly spread through central Ukraine. For almost the entire month of August, the air was filled from the smoke of the fires and smog that blew in from the Byelorussian and Moldovan SSRs. Whole cities, ones entirely disconnected from the short-lived revolt, were completely burnt to a crisp. In the final week of August, the Red Army gave up the hunt for rebels and focused solely on stopping the spread of the fires. As many as one thousand soldiers are thought to have died in the flames in a vain attempt to stop the fire. It finally stopped at the Dnieper River, and fizzled out. In the end, the rebels were placed on an island and forced to work to death on an empty stomach to show them not to mess with the country’s grain supply. The Politburo conducted an investigation and found that while the fire and the rebellion hadn’t completely crippled the food supply, the Ukrainian SSR would need at the minimum a decade of intense work to rebuild itself as the USSR’s breadbasket. 


Soviet relocation camp in Siberia, photo estimated to have been taken in 1999. Found smuggled in a suitcase in 2016 during a routine KGB raid in south Minsk.

The Politburo began full-scale evacuation efforts from the Caucasus and Central Asian SSRs starting in 1996. As part of the 14th Five-Year Plan, the Soviet Union started to build vast collective farms and living quarters in the Baltic SSRs at the sites of former tourist destinations. The recently resettled Soviet citizens were sent to clear trees and dead vegetation and help build these farms. Many were kept in tiny, cramped temporary houses and separated from their families, forced to live with total strangers. Naturally, this led to increased ethnic tension and eventually to race riots, and soon the Politburo was forced to segregate their settled citizens by ethnicity. After an especially severe race riot between ethnic Armenians and Azerbaijanis, with over 500 dead, the Politburo echoed Agassi’s own words of “From many nations, one People”. In other words, the Politburo demanded full loyalty to the USSR above any ethnic ties. For the stick, the Red Army would routinely patrol the worker’s camps, and for the carrot, the workers were told that they would be reunited with their families after the project was done. 

The Politburo was true to their word, and families were reunited, however due to the working conditions as many as a fifth of them died during the Great Western Resettlement Project of 1996-1999. Even with the vast public housing projects built, the Soviet Union was facing a severe housing crisis as millions of internal migrants were resettled every month. Cramped conditions, no matter how efficiently segregated, would still result in inevitable chaos. And so the USSR turned to the East: millions of acres of land in the once permanent taiga of Siberia were now remarkably green. The Politburo decided to fully exploit this “Siberian Miracle” and gave huge swathes of now empty land to the various ethnic subgroups. Azerbaijanis, Armenians, Georgians, Turkmens, Uzbeks, Tajiks, Kazakhs, and even European Turks, Iranians and Afghans were all given their own autonomous regions in Siberia. 

The Ministry of Efficiency had slowly drained the USSR of its excess wealth. Many automobiles had been broken down and turned into essential products like bed frames and hinges, while televisions were collected and put in public squares to be switched on once a week to spread news throughout the republics. But still, with all the rationing, the government began to notice that workers were reporting exhaustion and weakened immune systems. The Ministry of Health conducted an investigation throughout 1997 and discovered that it was due to mineral deficiencies resulting from a grossly uneven diet. Rationing and food shortages had caused many staples to be continuously out of stock for long periods of time, and while the governments of other countries fed their people tofu, soy and lentil bean steaks and grain-heavy energy bars, the USSR still could feed their citizens genuine bread. Due to a mistranslation in official state documents, an Estonian member of the Politburo signed off on creating the Shchedrost' fermera, or the “Farmer’s Bounty”. With many livestock animals dying of heatstroke, the Minister of Agriculture diverted many of the surplus oats and wheat grains to feed the displaced Soviets. Farmer’s Bounty was made in a very sloppy way - the barely-edible bits of grain were literally ripped up from the dirt, mixed with flour, yeast and water, and baked into a sort of crumbly bread. It was only a last resort, emergency food, however - many in the USSR still had access to genuine food, even if something was always in a shortage somewhere. 

Other notable events in 1997 included a Soviet probe being launched to survey the moon for any mineral and oil supplies. None were found. Secretary Yanayev suffered a stroke on March 10, 1997 and retired from public view. An up-and-coming clerical worker in the Politburo, Constantin Rutskoy, was chosen as his successor. Rutskoy was a rather meek and mild-mannered man, who while diligent and well-intentioned, was easily persuaded during debates with other members of the Politburo. No one thought that someone so suited to be a desk worker would become General Secretary, but that was precisely why he was chosen. Minister Voronin and Director Savateev had held a secret agreement between the two of them that if the Soviet Union was to survive this crisis intact, sacrifices must be made. Yanayev was too liberal and easy going to save the USSR, and while he was a commendable member of the CPSU, he was not General Secretary material. The General Secretary must be someone easily manipulated, someone with a gentle face that would ease the people into the coming chaos. Both Minister  Voronin and Director Savateev made sure that Rutskoy would be picked as General Secretary, and the Sixth Triumvirate was formed. The Sixth Triumvirate was also called the last Triumvirate, as it ruled until the Triumvirate system was abolished with the 2010 constitution. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H4V2jlhWJD4 

The first order of the Sixth Triumvirate was the invasion of Finland. As Secretary Rutskoy lifelessly claimed in a televised bulletin, Finland had been sabotaging Soviet industrial and agricultural efforts, along with personally attacking the leadership of many Warsaw Pact states. Some of the more ridiculous lambasts included being secretly run by Yugoslavian traitors, and collusion with the European Federation. In reality, the Soviet Union, which believed it was rapidly running out of living space and arable land, needed to do something and fast - or else risk total revolt like in Ukraine, just on a Union-wide scale. Finland was simply the easiest option to fix this, other than turning on their Warsaw Pact vassal states. Voronin expected the war to be over by New Year’s Day 1998. At first, Norway and Sweden secretly supplied their eastern neighbor but after a Swedish merchant vessel was almost sunk off the coast of Gotland, the two states made the harsh decision to remain neutral and leave Finland to their fate. Fighting was tense, with a naval blockade in the Baltic Sea, but swarms of soldiers from the Red Army, Poland and East Germany overwhelmed the Finnish troops. General Winter had taken a permanent summer vacation, and so both sides were reduced to fighting in mud, muck and blood. Entire forests were set on fire, and rivers ran red with gore. 


A beached Ukrainian SSR tank on the outskirts of Imatra, Finland. Photographed by Swedish journalists on December 9, 1998. 

The Finnish fought hard, however they were under-fed due to strict rationing. Many defected, entranced by the relative stability of the USSR. The Nordic War would continue for some time, before finally being ended by the Helsinki Treaty on June 19, 1999. The armies of the Warsaw Pact, re-armed by the Yanayev Plan, battered and bruised Finland until they surrendered. The Finnish SSR was established on November 21, 1999, and was ruled by hardliner communists sympathetic to the USSR. 

In September 1999, the resources of the USSR would be stretched to the breaking point. The Kazakh SSR was completely uninhabitable, and the Turkmen and Uzbek SSRs followed close behind. 20 million were dead from starvation due to the over-industrialization of Eastern Europe and Western Russia. The Ministry of Agriculture, overwhelmed by the influx of 50 million domestic refugees, said that not even the Anschluss of Finland could help. Secretary Rutskoy then suggested that the USSR utilize the rapidly thawing rivers in Siberia for irrigation. This was one of Rutskoy’s few thoughts that neither Minister Voronin or Director Savateev planted in his mind, and one of the few decisions he truly suggested of his own free will. As the Politburo began drafting up the plans for the 15th Five-Year Plan, the Minister of the Food Industry pointed out that in the Yakut ASSR, crop yields had actually been steadily increasing for the past 5 years. An investigation into the conditions in Siberia would lead to the Politburo to realize that their people would never know of a famine again. This was called the “Green Miracle”, and the Politburo began to rapidly deploy the displaced migrants in Siberia. Throughout 2000, as part of the 15th Five-Year Plan, the USSR began a massive effort to restructure and organize the rapidly greening Siberia. 

As the new millennium dawned, the USSR stood proud as one of the few nations left that still had its head on its shoulders. Europe was cooking in the heat and was on the verge of civil war. The USA was slowly turning into one giant dust bowl. China had resorted to invading their neighbors, and even then, their population was barely kept in check. Most of Africa and Latin America were in various states of civil war, and the Middle East was in total anarchy. 

But soon, the USSR would have to change if they wanted to survive, as the chaos was only just starting. 

[1] One of the many reasons why the USSR didn’t have a hard time after the Crash was because the immutability of the ruble was never revoked, meaning that it could not be exchanged for other currencies. This meant that foreign corporations in the 80s had to invest in rubles to grow their business, which in turn increased the value of the ruble. 
[2] The UK Labor government strongly considered joining the Yanayev Plan but after a month-long protest outside 10 Downing Street, the Prime Minister was forced to reject the plan. The Third Hellenic Republic also almost joined, but faced similar resistance. 
[3] The People’s Republic of Mongolia had actually been negotiating to join the Soviet Union. Secretary Yanayev and Director Savateev both agreed that it was untenable, however, as they did not have the resources to keep a place so far from Moscow fully defended.
[4] Fuel for mechanized divisions was kept in reserve for defensive purposes.

Section 3: The Fall of the Warsaw Pact (2000-2023)

The 21st Century would prove to be a defining chapter in the Soviet Union’s history. 

As part of the 15th Five-Year Plan, all of Siberia north of the Great Asian Dust Bowl - even previously autonomous regions - were to be dedicated solely to farming. Siberia’s main rivers would be diverted and used for irrigation, then filtered and recycled for human consumption. Like Farmer’s Bounty, water would eventually be used to reward loyalty to the State: criminals were given just barely enough to be continued to be used as labor, and those that were extremely loyal to the Politburo would have unlimited access to pure, fresh water. 

Yet, no matter how many internal migrants “volunteered” to farm, it seemed that most citizens of the Soviet Union were always barely scraping by. Coal was becoming harder and harder to ship in from Siberia, and thus many Soviet megafactories had to be shut down. Energy shipments were sent to the Byelorussian, Baltic and Ukrainian SSRs and used to fuel factories that kept the growing communist metropolises functioning. The first Soviet nuclear power plant was opened on July 7, 2000 in the northern RFSR, and was used to power a Soviet Navy base. The Minister of Energy hoped to have Moscow fully powered by nuclear energy by 2012. Already, the Ministry of Sustainability (helped by the KGB) was meeting their goals on reducing carbon emissions. 

The first republic to be hit hard by the reduction of industry was the Azerbaijani SSR. The republic’s vast reserves of petroleum and natural gas were finally exhausted after being all but spent during the costly Nordic War. And with it, the Politburo stopped subsidizing the republic’s industries. Overnight, almost 75% of the republic’s workforce was out of a job. Overexploitation and severe pollution from the Armenian SSR had made life in the Azerbaijani SSR unsustainable. 

The Ministry of Efficiency had reduced the quality of life of the average Soviet citizen, much to Agassi’s pleas. The average Soviet citizen had a guaranteed roof over their head, a scratchy mattress and three meals a day. For criminals and laborers in the new gulags, it was usually Farmer’s Bounty paired with boiled but dirty water. For the average citizen, it was stale bread and a soup (usually potato, cabbage and beet) with shredded cheese for protein. Members of the Politburo were given increasingly better meals for their loyalty but were never given something extremely extravagant unless it was a special holiday, like New Years, International Women’s Day[1], Labor Day, Victory Day, Constitution Day[2], and October Revolution Day. 

However, much of the splendor and luxury that the Soviet Union had briefly seen during the late 1980s was all but gone. Western style or traditional ethnic clothing were increasingly frowned upon, and in 2004, the Soviet Union implemented the “Standard People’s Uniform”, a large, one-size-fits-all (as very few people were overweight by this point) jumpsuit that was dyed red with dried beets. Cars were outlawed in 1995, with coal-dust powered, slow-moving buses serving as public transportation. Toys were banned in 1997 and instead children were encouraged to use their free time to play street sports, ballet or even take apprenticeships. Books were rounded up and collected in the late 90s to be preserved and placed in special communal libraries which also served as schools. Most western literature was destroyed and/or rewritten to have more eastern themes, like The Lord of the Rings being rewritten to have heavy subtext decrying the woes of hyper-consumerist models. Most importantly though, these libraries allowed the government to keep track of who was reading what, and the KGB always monitored those who continuously checked out subversive books. Officials with large luxury mansions were executed for parasitism, and their mansions repurposed into hospitals, orphanages and temporary housing for displaced migrants, which did earn the Sixth Triumvirate a more favorable view by the general populace. The biggest accomplishment of the Ministry of Efficiency came in 2001, when all the excess luxury western goods from 1985-1988’s Concord of Moscow were collected and disassembled in a failed attempt to recycle the petroleum based products. 


A photograph depicting a convict working in front of a grain silo outside of Leningrad, 2001

Many of the old-timers, who had witnessed the attempted reforms in the Glorious Decades, did not take the new policy of austerity well. The regular state police would routinely conduct raids against smugglers and hoarders of western technology. The biggest of these raids was in October 2001, when a warehouse outside of Moscow was found to contain over 2,000 televisions. 

A citizen’s loyalty to the state, and standing with the current political views of the Triumvirate, also had a large impact on their quality of life. Many members of Agassi’s cabinet or the liberal, non-Russian dominated ministers in the early 80s were deliberately treated badly, their western goods and property taken with extreme force and routinely stalked by Director Savateev’s goons. Loyal citizens were always given better quality food, cleaner water and more comfortable beds. 

But still, for most of the early 2000s, the average Soviet citizen lived a hard life, constantly starving or suffering a deficiency in some vitamin. In 2001, a large ration protest occurred in the Red Square of Moscow, where several grizzled elders demonstrated against the artificial squalor that the Politburo was enforcing upon them. The protest erupted into a riot when a nearby Politburo member was found driving in a private limousine, and the Red Army was called in to regain control. A KGB investigation afterwards calculated the death toll to be over 400, with the Politburo member (the Minister of Electricity actually, who was participating in the test run of an electric car) included. This was followed by a factory bombing in the Lithuanian SSR, but was quickly crushed by Director Savateev. Early in 2002, Secretary Rutskoy rubber-stamped a policy outlawing organized religion in most Soviet republics, however it was enforced only when it was convenient to the government. 

In 2002, the Soviet Union joined the fledgling Alliance of Nations, being the last of the old permanent Security Council members of the UN to join. The Alliance of Nations, unlike the United Nations, was far less centralized on the simple basis that it was nearly impossible to centralize an organization such as the United Nations on such a scale in this increasingly dangerous and chaotic world. Every year, a different city hosted the annual meeting, and every year, fewer and fewer delegates attended. Premier Deng Xiaoping was known for frequently blaming the West for China’s downfall, and the delegate from the United States, finally turned on their longstanding trading partner with the report that despite industry in the First and Second worlds drying up, carbon emissions were still increasing. In a signed report from the CIA along with circumstantial evidence from the British SAS and even one former KGB member, the Ambassador postulated that it was the PRC propping up the industry of South America and Africa. It is not known what was actually said by the delegates in the following ten minutes, but what is known is soon that the delegates for Pakistan and India were at each other’s throats. The remnants of NATO[3] (which was essentially just a piece of paper at this point), quietly speculated that it was a result of India cozying up to China in an attempt to industrialize, while Pakistan was playing up the USSR for similar aid. Less than a month later, India and Pakistan would destroy each other in mutually assured destruction. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h6g1PevHvUs 

Soon, the strength of the shield of NATO was put to the test when in 2003, the European Federation almost entered civil war. A later investigation by the PES in 2008 would claim that the leaders of the ECL were actually working with the KGB (which was partially true, but the USSR was exhausted from the Nordic War and was barely keeping its population in check). While Brussels was distracted, Secretary Weisser seized this moment to take West Berlin back from the imperialists. Keen observers in USSR politics at this time would note that General Secretary Rutskoy had no opinion on the matter, as both Minister Voronin and Director Savateev gave conflicting reports on the USSR’s stance on “the matter of Berlin”. Minister Voronin was of the opinion of helping East Germany, while Director Savateev felt it was a pointless, frivolous exercise. In the end, Minister Voronin and Secretary Weisser took over the West Berlin enclave in a matter of hours, as both of them had actually done training exercises for such a military operation all the way back in the 80s, when Voronin was a Major in the Soviet Army and Freida Weisser was a tank mechanic. Various citizens of West Berlin, known for being vocal against their compatriots to the East, were soon rounded up and sent to “ecological reeducation centers”, which was a polite term the East Germans used for prison farms. 


Soviet troops escorting injured East German troops after the annexation of West Berlin, 2003

The European Federation, of course, demanded that their allies help them take back West Berlin. The newly-formed Nordic Union of Sweden and Norway had recently declared their neutrality, out of fear of what had been done to Finland. The USA said that they literally could not spare any troops, as half the Midwest was under martial law and the Southwest was in a year-long drought and heatwave, with Phoenix, Arizona recently declared uninhabitable. The UK, meanwhile, attempted to scramble the RAF when a freak hurricane flooded South England - or at least that was the official story. The UK, still bitter after the Channel Crisis, decided to leave their mainland neighbors to their fate. Canada attempted to marshal their troops, but due to the long process of retrofitting their navy, the earliest they could get to Germany in their steam liners would be a month from then. 

The Politburo celebrated that day. The phoney alliance of NATO had been proven to be a sham, and was soon to collapse. 

Director Savateev, however, did not celebrate. Just like the USA, he was stretching his resources to the breaking point to keep the USSR together. The Tajik SSR, which had been already heavily depopulated, was now only inhabited by a small but extremely stubborn group of ethnic Tajiks. These Tajiks had rebelled against Agassi in the late 70s and now once again seized the means of production and held the farms hostage. Soviet troops were withdrawn from Berlin to help regain order, however, even with Director Savateev’s help, they soon became bogged down in a long, drawn out guerrilla warfare. Seeing the Tajiks revolt inspired the native Georgians, who rebelled and declared independence from Moscow. The Georgian SSR though had far more natural resources than the Tajik SSR, and was also much closer to Moscow compared to their Tajik compatriots, and thus an entire division of the Red Army was sent in to squash the rebellion. The Georgian Rebellion lasted only a year, as it was far less organized than the Tajik Revolt. The Uzbek SSR almost saw a similar uprising when water shortages started to hit the barely-living prospectors mining for uranium and nitrogen and phosphate to be used on fertilizers in the rapidly thawing Siberia. 

The Warsaw Pact laughed at the fracturing of NATO, but by 2004, they weren’t laughing anymore. The Democratic People’s Republic of Albania, which had been extracted of all valuable resources by the East Germans and Soviets the year before, descended into civil war as Moscow no longer believed the pro-Soviet puppet regime was worth propping up. Hungary had finished their civil war and was now strictly an agrarian communist society and was able to produce large amounts of food from 2004-2008, which the government began selling at exorbitant prices to other countries in Europe, at the expense of their own citizens. In Romania, their civil war had entered a new chapter as it was now between KGB-backed Communists and PES-backed socialists. 

Finally, in 2005, after the UK/EU blockade, NATO collapsed. Minister Voronin could not celebrate for long, as soon he was called in for yet another task in the increasingly arduous quest of spreading communism.

In late 2004, the Greek Civil War spilled over into the Eastern Bloc when the KKE requested aid from Moscow. Minister Voronin was still riding the high of fracturing NATO, and so gleefully sent troops into Greece. This disrupted FulTec’s carefully formulated balance of power in the Greek political system, and also prompted the European Federation to send in more of their own troops. The Warsaw Pact mainly kept to Macedonia and Epirus, while the Eurofed held much of the central areas. The far-right ESP held parts of the Peloponnese, Thrace and areas of the north. To almost no-one’s surprise, the increasingly unstable dictatorship of Turkiye invaded Cyprus and the Aegean Islands before collapsing into civil war in 2006.

The intervention in Greece was not a popular one in the Warsaw Pact. Places like Czechia and East Germany felt it was a waste of resources, that Bulgaria was in no risk of invasion from the dramatically unstable Greece and rapidly fracturing Turkiye. Several other countries, like Romania, Hungary and Poland silently agreed with them, but did not want to anger Moscow - at first. In 2006, after Czechia tried to join the (now increasingly centralized) European Federation, they were kicked out of the Warsaw Pact by an angry Minister Voronin. This set a precedent, and throughout 2006, the Warsaw Pact fractured. Many of the states no longer believed that it was necessary anymore after the collapse of NATO. Others believed that Moscow had only used the Warsaw Pact for their own gain, given that they drummed up all of Central Europe to fight in the Nordic War but never lifted a finger when Romania, Hungary and Bulgaria fell to civil war. All of them believed that Moscow was unfairly sharing resources with them. Czechia was followed by Romania, and then Bulgaria, until it was only East Germany, Poland and the USSR. 

In 2007, the final blow would come when East Germany proposed a forced reunification with their western neighbor. Minister Voronin reluctantly declined helping his longtime friends and allies retake the rest of their country. If Minister Voronin still had the might of the Soviet military in the 90s, he would have gladly fought with Secretary Weisser all the way to Bonn. But Voronin had finally faced reality. Half the USSR was now under martial law and was constantly bleeding resources keeping their own border in check. A full-on invasion of West Germany was not only impossible, it was effectively suicide. The German-Soviet split was the final nail in the coffin of the Warsaw Pact. Only two years after the fall of NATO, did the Warsaw Pact collapse as well. 

Normally, Director Savateev would have stepped in and put the fear of Lenin back in these vassal states, but he and Secretary Rutskoy were busy dealing with a devastating domestic crisis. 

Early 2005 was initially heralded as a year of hope when food shortages had decreased to such a level, that rations were actually increased for the first time in almost eight years. But the Green Miracle soon turned into the Green Curse - inexplicably, in the alarmingly warm north, trees began dying off en-masse. The USSR simply cut down the diseased tree corpses, burned them as fuel, and cleared the land for more farms. Yet when workers started dying of flu-like symptoms by the hundreds, then the thousands, the Ministry of Health sounded the alarm. On April 8, 2005, the first case of SARS-CoV-5 was confirmed. SARS-COV-5, or known simply as the “Red Flu”, was quickly spreading throughout Siberia. Director Savateev, Secretary Rutskoy and the rest of the Politburo scrambled to contain the spread of the virus. As more and more Siberian superfarms were quarantined, the Red Army was forced to be called in to enforce it as workers escaped. 

By summer 2005, the first cases were reported in Moscow, and led to a major riot when half the city was quarantined. A suburb in Voronezh was almost burned down after a factory almost caught on fire due to understaffing. The Minister of Health resigned in Fall 2005, feeling ashamed for the cramped conditions of the cities and the malnutrition causing the rampant spread of the virus. The Kyrgyz SSR was finally deemed too costly to keep by Moscow and was hastily mined by the Red Army in winter 2005, before slowly being absorbed into the Great Asian Dust Bowl. The Red Army forces trying to regain control of the Tajik SSR finally gave up in 2007 and fully retreated. As the Soviet forces retreated, they unknowingly spread the Red Flu throughout the decaying Central Asian Republics. 

In the end, all the Politburo could effectively do was let the pandemic run its course and burn itself out. By 2023, cases of the Red Flu still flare up in the fall, but it is no longer as grave of a threat as it was when it first spread. It is estimated that over 341 million would die from the disease between 2005-2025. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QC1aBVDsoWw 

Minister Voronin, aware of the growing pandemic via an encrypted telegram, stayed in occupied Greece as he tried to stop the Warsaw Pact from disintegrating from his mistake with Czechia as more and more Warsaw Pact troops withdrew to their native countries. The unwillingness to move Soviet troops due to the pandemic in addition to the European public growing weary of the war caused the Soviet Union and the European Federation to sign the Truce of Athens in 2007, effectively ending the involvement of both parties in Greece. As Minister Voronin and the rest of the Soviet troops returned to Moscow, Greece entered its final civil war. Along the way to Moscow, Minister Voronin made a stop in Istanbul and established a short-lived Turkish SSR, however by 2011, the USSR would only control Istanbul and the northern coast of Turkiye. This ensured that the USSR controlled the Black Sea all the way to 2027. 

The Warsaw Pact was effectively dead like NATO, and in its place was a loose confederation of chaotic communist states. The “People’s Coalition”, led by Poland, consisted of Romania, Bulgaria, Hungary, and a now fully communist Albania. Partitioned Yugoslavia was offered a place, but they were too busy fighting each other to pay attention to the shifting politics of the Eastern Bloc. East Germany had formed a union with Czechia, and both Berlin and Warsaw were playing Slovakia and Czechia off each other, resulting in border clashes throughout 2007 and 2008. Poland would send “peacekeeping” forces into Hungary when it was leaked that the government was selling food while their citizens were starving. With all the mineral resources extracted from Central Europe (or at least as much as the Soviets could get with their decaying equipment) and the Red Flu spreading to Europe, Moscow left their once vassal states to their fate.

When Minister Voronin finally returned to Moscow, Director Savateev informed him that the USSR was barely a nation, ravaged by disease, drought, wildfires and famine. Pollution and desertification had rendered entire republics uninhabitable. The Soviet Union was much less a union and more like a dying bear. Their resources were stretched thin. Minister Voronin and Director Savateev were happy to be working together again, using Secretary Rutskoy to rubber-stamp the harsh policies they needed to enact. Once he was back in the Motherland, the first order that Minister Voronin authorized was the creation of a vast border wall spanning the border of China, primarily around Mongolia and Manchuria. The cost in resources, labor and lives was enormous, but everyone in the Politburo was certain it was the right move, as the USSR must protect its food supply or risk total collapse. Millions of workers died, mainly from the Red Flu, but the Triumvirate deemed it necessary. It would prove the right move when suspiciously Chinese-looking refugees showed up in the farm gulags in Eastern Siberia, which prompted large numbers of the Soviet military to be stationed along the Great Wall of Siberia. Soviet energy development had gone a long way since 2000, and over 10% of their remaining Cold War equipment had been retrofitted to be nuclear powered. Tanks and aircraft were kept on standby in case their increasingly unstable neighbors to the south would try to invade the new breadbasket of the USSR. 


A section of the USSR/China border wall, being built by European Slavs. Estimated to be taken in June of 2007. 

In 2008, the Great Asian Dust Bowl spanned Istanbul to Shanghai, going as far south as Mandalay and as far north as Novosibirsk. Huge tornadoes regularly ripped topsoil off of the dwindling arable land, and the few livestock left (mainly scrawny, disease ridden chickens) were consumed by the harsh winds. An F-null storm[4] in April 2008 literally lifted a Soviet military outpost from the ground in the Uzbek SSR. Keeping the outer republics afloat, even if it was just to extract resources, was draining the USSR of almost a quarter of their yearly budget by 2009. 

The winter of 2009 was a particularly harsh one. Almost all of Siberia was melted for half the year, and with it, came a variety of particularly brutal plant diseases. Entire forests began dying off, not to mention all the recently released methane. Forest fires destroyed just as many trees. Shrubs started going extinct, and even crops became affected. Horseradish was thought to have been entirely wiped out until a sample was found in 2026. Desertification was causing minor famines every year, as food could not be transported from Siberia in time. 

Much to Voronin’s disappointment, he had learned that the “ancient Siberian fungi” was actually a failed attempt at a biological weapon targeting Chinese crops: Director Savateev had wanted to wipe out the Chinese without losing a single soldier by removing their food supply. Voronin found this cowardly - the Chinese were worthy of being destroyed in open combat. The team that had developed the project were all dead now, however, and had been removed from history by Savateev for their egregious failure. The biological weapon spread, and soon, plants started dying off en masse across the planet. It is estimated that the “Siberian Reckoning” destroyed over 20 million bushels of grains each year between 2009 and 2099. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9y9r0rMaJNU&pp=ygULa29yb3ZpcyBkYW3SBwkJrQkBhyohjO8%3D 

And all it took was one delayed shipment in 2010 for it to almost come crashing down. In the Komi ASSR, a group of displaced Georgian nationalists sabotaged a nuclear-powered train carrying a supply of Farmer’s Bounty to Leningrad, and Syktyvkar was destroyed. The town became uninhabitable from the lingering radiation. Immediately, martial law was declared throughout the entire Soviet Union. The Triumvirate was urgently moved to a secure undisclosed location in northern Siberia. When Secretary Rutskoy was not present, Minister Voronin quickly called him a traitor and that he had been behind the Syktyvkar Bombing. The Politburo called for a trial, where Rutskoy was tried in absentia. Those that defended him were taken away by KGB agents and never seen again. In the name of security, efficiency, and survival, the Politburo was forcibly reshaped and reformed so that only members loyal to Director Savateev and Minister Voronin remained. Throughout the summer of 2010, it is estimated that over 60% of the entire Politburo was purged, and for the rest of the year, the Red Army, KGB and state police regularly patrolled the cities to purge “pro-Rutskoy” agitators and Chinese spies. The KGB also purged old-time party members all the way back to the days of Agassi. Agassi himself was found hanging from a lamp post outside of his apartment in Vaasa, Finnish SSR. 

On September 4, 2010, Minister Voronin took Secretary Rutskoy’s place for the first National Address in almost four months. Minister Voronin proclaimed that Secretary Rutskoy had been working with the Chinese for almost four years and was responsible for almost every major disaster in the USSR since then, including the spread of the Red Flu and the Great Siberian Blight. Secretary Rutskoy had orchestrated the fall of the Warsaw Pact, and was the reason for the fracturing of Central Europe. Voronin then looked at the camera and passionately proclaimed that he would stop at nothing to save his Motherland, and that effective immediately, the office of Triumvirate would be replaced with him as the Supreme Minister. Lastly, he called upon his fellow countrymen to point out any would-be capitalist agitators, Chinese spies, American traitors, European socialists, and anyone else with Rutskoy-esque mindsets. 

In actuality, of course, Secretary Rutskoy was not a traitor mastermind. He had simply outlived his usefulness as the puppet of Voronin and Savateev. He was promised a secret luxurious life in Krasino, the only respite Director Savateev assured him was a quick death. Voronin and Savateev agreed in a secret meeting in early 2010 that drastic measures must be taken to save what they could of the USSR. Neither of them were actually directly responsible for the Bombing of Syktyvkar, but Savateev did take responsibility for deliberately starving a majority-Georgian populated work camp. 

Two weeks later, on September 18, 2010, the Soviet Union adopted its sixth and final constitution. This constitution was so oppressive that it would cause even Stalin to blush. Freedom of Speech, Press, Assembly and Worship are all finally repealed. A citizen evading work for more than 3 days would be executed for parasitism. Any Chinese-looking person outside of the Beijing District of Moscow would be executed immediately. The Triumvirate was abolished with the General Secretary, now referred to as the Supreme Minister, being the sole head of state. All non-Soviet refugees could work for 10 years in a Siberian Superfarm to earn their Soviet Citizenship. Internally displaced refugees needed to only work for 1 year to regain their citizenship, though the paperwork required made that almost impossible. Any westerner was to be shot on sight. The constitution also solidified that it is through the guiding hand of the Supreme Minister that the country had weathered the worst of the extended crisis, so anyone who goes against the infallible policy of the Politburo will be shot on sight.

With the restructuring of the Soviet constitution and the Soviet way of life came the complete top-to-down restructuring of the Soviet Administrative Divisions. The RFSR was divided in two - the land east of the Urals became the Siberian SSR, and was essentially one giant farm. In a practice later called “Bastion Doctrine”, the Georgian, Armenian, Azerbaijani, Kazakh, Uzbek, Tajik, Turkmen, Kyrgyz SSRs and even the short-lived Turkish SSR were to be evacuated as the Soviet government was pulling out and abandoning the republics by December 31, 2011. This had already been practically completed, however, as an average of 95% of the land in those republics had been abandoned, with the Kazakh SSR empty for almost a decade. This left only 9 republics of the USSR: Russia, Siberia, Ukraine, Moldova, Byelorussia, Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, and Finland. The Bastion Doctrine also officially let Central Europe fend for itself, as Moscow now believed that only the “core republics” could be controlled. A few of the now ex-republics[5] tried to declare independence, but with the widening dust bowl, plant diseases, unpredictable weather and creeping radiation, many of the nationalist movements died out by 2013. 

Turning to Europe, the short-lived People’s Coalition lasted only a few years when Warsaw decided that with Moscow turning on itself, they would take the security of Europe into their own hands and first annexed Slovakia in 2010 and then Hungary in 2011. Albania fell to civil war yet again in 2011, and refugees fleeing from the Balkan civil wars and climate change swarmed Bulgaria and Romania, causing a civil war due to the strain of resources and disagreements on how to deal with them. Poland set up a border wall along the southern edge of Hungary, and closed off access entirely by 2015. East Germany, extremely bitter from the betrayal of Moscow, became increasingly militaristic and almost fascistic in nature, adopting the philosophy of “National Communism with German Characteristics” after the death of Secretary Frieda Weisser in 2013. This was followed by the formal annexation of Czechia in 2014. The Polish Commonwealth and the Greater Democratic Republic of Germany then entered an alliance in 2015, called the Berlin-Warsaw Axis, but it was actually just both nations waiting for the other to slip up. 

The mass displacement and resettlement of almost a hundred million people caused intense unrest and in 2013, after an outbreak of the Red Flu in Moscow, the combination of ethnic tensions and squalid conditions caused civil disobedience to explode. As a result, Red Army patrols and KGB raids became commonplace all the way to 2023. 

With a growing number of citizens out of a job due to factories closing down, the USSR instead started to aggressively promote enlistment in the Soviet Army and State Police. Soon, cocky 17 year olds born during the Red Decades were armed and patrolling apartment blocks, always on the lookout for Voronin’s enemies. The Soviet Armed Forces swelled to almost 45 million active personnel, making almost an eighth of its entire population in the military. Moscow’s Police Force was almost 250,000 officers alone. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XR68p_k_I88 

The Soviet Army, after its purging of old-timers (in reality, anyone Savateev or Voronin didn’t like), in 2014 began to try another attempt to research using plant-based diseases to wipe enemy crop cycles. Leka Khalski, the new Minister of Defense, proposed that the Soviet Union launch this weapon against China to delay any potential invasion. Director Savateev used satellite photos to determine the best place to use the prototype weapon, only to make a shocking discovery - all of the vegetation in mainland China was gone. With the exception of some gargantuan farms in Mongolia and Indochina, China had absolutely no agricultural base. There was no way that China was feeding their 2.8 billion population. Director Savateev chuckled and deduced that China was recycling the dead for food. The KGB’s discovery was immediately used as propaganda, and made even the weakest of criminals in the Siberian Gulags thankful for Farmer’s Bounty. This actually increased compliance with the general populace, as the true nature of Siliao was parroted to any citizen who was acting out. “Be thankful you’re not in China and eating your mother!” the Red Army chuckled. 

2015 was a somber year, as Supreme Minister Voronin died of cancer on February 18, 2015 at the age of 74. On his deathbed, he pleaded that Director Savateev take up his mantle. According to his autobiography published in 2025, Savateev was hesitant but agreed with Voronin that it was in the best interest of the country. The rest of February was dedicated to mourning the protector of the Soviet Union, and on March 1, 2015, Sergei Savateev became the Supreme Minister. Savateev worked closely with Minister Khalski to keep an eye on the rapidly deteriorating situations in Europe, China and the USA. In 2016, the USSR confirmed that it was the only member of the Big Four not eating their dead. 

But even with the constant surveillance of the Red Army, KGB and State Police, the USSR was simmering with civil unrest. The Politburo then proposed the Worker’s Lottery in 2016, where once a month, lots would be drawn and the winners would get a week’s vacation in the newly opened “People’s Resorts” in northern Russia and Finland (which were pretty much just public campgrounds, but a week off was a vacation in and of itself). This seemed to be the missing link, and slowly, rebellion died down. Regrettably, a localized riot inside of the Beijing District of Moscow left all the aging Maoists dead. 

Supreme Minister Savateev, the Second Stalin, had pacified the USSR. 

Throughout 2017 and 2018, nuclear power grids were implemented across Russia and Eastern Europe. Due to strict rationing, intensive farming and armed guards patrolling gulags, the last major famine the USSR experienced was in 2019. The USSR hoped to transition their entire navy to nuclear power by 2025. The Red Army began routine military exercises in the Baltic SSRs to prepare for a Chinese invasion, which both Savateev and Minister Khalski believed was inevitable. In 2020, a border wall was constructed along Lithuania, Byelorussia, Ukraine and Moldova. It was named “Voronin’s Wall”, in honor of the man who had saved[6] the USSR from the Eternal Depression. From the wall, Moscow, Berlin and Warsaw all stared each other down like they were cowboys in a Mexican standoff. In 2021, the Soviet Union began to finally feel the effects of climate change yet again, and after much deliberation, the Politburo drafted and implemented a (rather lenient) two-child policy. Rat farms began to spring up across Siberia in 2022, which became the dominant protein source of the Soviet Union, replacing chickens. 

By 2023, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is clinging on to the vestiges of civilization. The USSR is still a nation, and is doing the best of the other former superpowers. Citizens don’t have to eat their own dead. You do your work, you are quiet and you keep your head down. Entertainment is mainly dancing and singing. Once a year, the citizens can go on vacation to the Arctic Sea. Ukraine is an over-industrialized wasteland, having long since lost its status as a breadbasket with the advent of Siberia. Moldova is treated much the same way, being effectively one giant military outpost. Latvia retains a large amount of arable land due to careful planning by the Politburo, and Riga remains a massive Navy base. Estonia enjoys a similar amount of prosperity, but Lithuania has seen a resurgence of Orthodox Christian rebels, which the Red Army routinely uses as target practice. Finland is now the site of massive luxury high-rises for loyal members of the Politburo. Outside of Voronin’s Wall, Central Europe is a corpse that is routinely picked over by Germany and Poland. Bulgaria and Romania had both lost their civil wars, and had fallen into anarchy much like the rest of South Eastern Europe. 


City square in a suburb of Minsk, Byelorussian SSR. An aged Supreme Minister Savateev, speaking to the nation through a televised broadcast, urges citizens to be wary of subversive behavior. Behind him is the Minsk Worker’s Palace. Taken January 7, 2023. (OOC: Screenshot taken from Raising the Bar: Retail)

But Supreme Minister Savateev eyed his western neighbors with suspicion. Berlin was becoming a lot like an old enemy from the Great Patriotic War. Very soon, he suspected, a Second Great Patriotic War would ignite…

[1] Despite a woman never holding the rank of a Triumvirate member, women were allowed to become members of the Politburo, including running a ministry, during Agassi’s reforms in the late 70s. 
[2] After Agassi resigned, Secretary Yanayev moved Constitution Day from October 14 (When the 1975 Constitution was signed) to August 10 (When the 1983 Constitution was signed). 
[3] In 2002, the membership of NATO would be just the United States, Canada, the European Federation, Iceland, the United Kingdom and the Nordic Union. Turkiye was expelled in 2001 as the military dictatorship was not recognized as legitimate.
[4] With the increasingly powerful storms, scientists had largely given up by 2003 to try to classify the storms. People were lucky if a tornado was still able to be measured by the dated Fujita scale from the 70s. 
[5] Despite the Bastion Doctrine abandoning large parts of the USSR, the 10 “shadow republics” were still drawn as USSR territories on official Soviet maps. Supreme Minister Voronin hoped to reclaim them one day. 
[6] Savateev was always careful to credit important accomplishments to Voronin, turning him into a folk hero that is celebrated much like Marx, Lenin, and after 2020, Stalin. 

Part 3
A Country in Name Only
Section 1: Dying Light (1988-2002)

Excerpt from “The Eagle’s Grave: America in the Red Decades” by Amaury Velasqué-Lafontaine, Columbia Press, 899 ASJ
