The political history of the United States of America had been shaky ever since 1988. The Election of 1988 was actually a rematch of the election of 1984, in which Texas senator and oil tycoon Franklin Howard King won against his opponent Elliot Fitzgerald Graves, the governor of Oregon. In the 1984 election, Graves won only Oregon and DC. He had platformed on a policy of “Energy Accountability”, which provided research into energy alternatives to oust Big Oil. Needless to say, this was very unpopular with the upper class, and when Franklin King got the endorsement of Permanent Advisor Richard Nixon, the election was practically over. Graves threw in the towel and quietly reduced his influence nationwide to only his beloved Oregon, where he did prototype a small-scale version on his policies that almost ended in a Supreme Court debate. 


Franklin King’s presidential portrait, 1985

In 1987, the Graves Campaign picked up speed again and looked at his shortcomings in the 1984 campaign (which were many). For his running mate[1], he picked Clifford W. Smith, the governor of Pennsylvania and a first hand witness of the Three-Mile Island disaster. The Graves Campaign tried focusing on the American economy, and the fact that it was stagnating compared to the USSR and Chinese economies. Part of his campaign included going to abandoned steel mills, factories and other production sites and having press conferences that featured ex-workers and former owners of the buildings in question. Most people scoffed when Graves pledged to revive American industry in the Rust Belt. America had transitioned to an economy dominated by the financial and service industry, with a growing information technology sector and a shrinking but still gargantuan agricultural sector. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eih67rlGNhU&list=PLw2qu_cqPb-mPzSdT5ml61LSO23OjlgEe&index=2&pp=gAQBiAQB8AUB 

In the United States, the unemployment rate was at 0.4% in May 1988. By the end of June 1988, it had jumped to 14.7% and would only climb. As international trade dried up, Graves’s proposals began to resonate with a vast majority of Americans. Despite not getting Richard Nixon’s endorsement, Graves became a popular choice for the everyday average American. King’s Campaign, meanwhile, was struggling to form a coherent platform in the wake of the Crash of ‘88 and the Sinai War.  

Everyone tuned in to the first Presidential Debate of 1988. Governor Graves wiped the floor with President King. King remained calm, collected, and charismatic, speaking in a soft southern drawl about how tariffs and trade negotiations could be used to stimulate the economy and make America the top dog again, but Graves was far more energetic in his performance. He was acting like he was the nation’s stern and disappointed father. “What President King fails to mention is that tariffs won’t incentivize our overseas industries to return to the mainland. We need jobs for Joe American. And we need them now!”

In October 1988, almost 95 million people tuned into the second debate. The unemployment rate was almost 18%. Hundreds of businesses across the nation had foreclosed and laid off millions of workers. As America switched on one of their five color TVs[2], they were greeted by President King and Governor Graves in the auditorium of the University of California, Los Angeles. King opened and thanked Wall Street and the rest of the American Financial Alliance for their continued support. He said that he had just spoken with Chairman Chen and was in the process of negotiating a trade deal with China. Graves, with his trademark zeal, rebuffed King. “That won’t put food on the table of the common man. We have enough “ifs” and “maybes”, we need “yeses”! Just on my way here, I saw elderly homeless veterans starving and on the streets. We need action, and we need it now!” For the rest of the debate, King fumbled at almost every question, and while he remained charismatic, his answers were vague. Graves remained resolute, almost enraged, and at the end of the debate, promised that if he was elected he would implement a vast industrialization program. 

“Vote Graves to stay out of the Grave!” was the slogan on everyone’s lips by November 1988. The voter turnout rate was 72.9%, and Elliot Fitzgerald Graves became president-elect in a landslide. 


The Election of 1988

King of course won his home state of Texas, but also managed to hold on to the "Moral Midwest" plus Mississippi and South Carolina, both places that had seen increases in their standard of living during his previous term. The Democrats also narrowly retook both the House and the Senate. During his concession speech, President King announced that he would be retiring from politics and returning to his ranch outside of Lubbock, Texas. As part of Graves’s transition to the presidency, he toured various areas hit hardest by the initial shocks of the Crash: California, New York, and Texas, respectively. 

January 20th, 1989 was a strangely warm day, but nobody had paid much attention to that yet. In his inauguration speech, President Graves made several huge promises: the government would help the unemployed find jobs, implement vast social services such as childcare and lunch for kids in schools, and even subsidized housing for those at risk of losing their houses. These new functions of the government would create millions of jobs, but soon the corporate donors of the Republicans took note of how increasingly socialistic Graves’s proposals were. Some pundits would lambast it as communist, much like how they lambasted the new communist President of France, Arlette Pascal. 

Immediately, President Graves, Vice President Smith and their cabinet began drafting up plans for the revival of the American industry. A new department, the Department of American Welfare, was created and began to help unemployed Americans find jobs and keep their houses. When asked about the chaotic state of the world, such as the coup in El Salvador, the civil war in Cambodia, and the rising amounts of socialist movements around the world, President Graves expressed his condolences but firmly stated that the welfare of the American people was his first priority. After the Soviet Union invaded Iran in May and Afghanistan in August, the warm relations between the two countries that had been building since the 70s evaporated. President Graves was a staunch isolationist, and as the economy buckled further, he authorized sweeping tariffs against many nations including former allies and trading partners such as South Korea, China, Japan, and even Mexico. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FFJ6Vv7Sn6o&list=PLw2qu_cqPb-mPzSdT5ml61LSO23OjlgEe&index=20&pp=gAQBiAQB8AUB0gcJCbIJAYcqIYzv 

In September, the Graves Administration announced a landmark bill: the American Union and Workers Act of 1989. This monumental bill made the right to unionize a federally protected right, established a federal minimum wage[3], granted huge subsidies to the rusting factories in cities like Chicago and Detroit, and handed out grants to create new businesses in those areas. 

A few weeks after the tariffs and the bill were implemented, relations deteriorated with a great many of the United States’s former trading partners. The most notable response came from South Korea, which had been extremely anti-communist since its founding in 1953. Graves’s protectionist policies and previous two decades of warm relations with China and the USSR caused anti-American sentiment to skyrocket, and soon the American troops stationed in the Republic of Korea were being driven out by angry Koreans. When the Americans evacuated the peninsula and the North Koreans rolled in, the Graves’s administration position was that of aloofness. Allegedly, multiple American soldiers had been injured and one even killed by South Korean protestors, so Graves’s Secretary of State claimed that the United States would not help a nation so hostile towards it. 

In January 1990, as part of the agricultural revival, the Graves Administration created the Feeding America By America Act. This act would award lucrative government contracts to start-up companies that aimed to grow food for American consumers. Just a few days later, on January 21, 1990, Food, Incorporated would be formed in New York, New York by Donald Keyser. The government took a special interest in Food, Inc, as while a majority of the start-ups in the early 90s would be staple foods like rice or bread, Food, Inc made a protein-rich tofu-like steak made out of soya and lentil beans. The farms that went under, usually farms that sold their products to other countries, were bought up by the government and sold to startups like Food, Inc. These large, corporate owned farms were the infant stages of the modern superfarm. Food, Inc got a notably large amount of land in the Deep South and upper midwest. 

When the Hot Summer of 1990 rolled around, Food, Inc and several other Agro-Businesses like Bayou Beans petitioned the Graves Administration to allow them to sell their products to the heat-wave ravaged Eurasia. The Secretary of Commerce and President Graves debated for a few days but came to the compromise of selling the surplus food only to members of NATO. 

The United States kept chugging away. In one of his few unpopular decisions, President Graves implemented gradual but wide-reaching rationing.The American Union and Workers and the Feeding America By America acts had created millions of jobs, but for every job that was created, it seemed like four more were destroyed. When Graves took office, the unemployment rate was 23.2%. In 1991, it was only down to 16.8%. The government was practically burning money trying to keep the nation functioning. Almost all government agencies had been cut back - the decision to abandon Helios Two was made in summer of 1989. The government was surviving on bonds, but even then, inflation was skyrocketing. Several major banks, such as Morgan-Hughes and American National, offered to donate money to the Graves Administration, inevitably in exchange for favors. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gs_9fXIBpEI&list=PLw2qu_cqPb-mPzSdT5ml61LSO23OjlgEe&index=42&pp=gAQBiAQB8AUB 

“If you truly wanted to help people, you’d donate to the poor!” President Graves shouted to the representatives. The representatives immediately backed down, but the President finally unleashed a bill he had been working on in secret for quite some time. Executive Order 12750, otherwise known as the “Of The People, For The People Act of 1991” was the most radical of Graves’s policies yet, and it significantly overhauled the taxation system so that the richest people had an effective tax rate of over 90%, and made it illegal for any government entity to receive a gift worth more than $250. But this was only secondary to its primary purpose: it made corporations liable to ludicrous (well over a billion dollars) fines if they were caught breaking the law. This Executive Order was at first deemed unconstitutional by the Supreme Court, but Graves later pushed it through Congress where it passed by the Democratic supermajority in the House and barely passed the Senate. 

This Act would single handedly save the government from bankruptcy when in Summer 1991, it was found out that Texas-based oil company King-Chevron was lying about the amount of oil in their reserves. President Graves himself ordered a full investigation, and found that King-Chevron was also guilty of price gouging, racketeering and intimidation of competitors. The CEO, Humphrey King, was forced to pay $472 Billion in damages and the company would later be nationalized in 1992. 

As the 1992 Election Cycle began, President Graves got the nomination unopposed. After fierce debate and several rounds of primaries, the Republican nominee would end up being Jack Dole, the senior senator for Kansas. He campaigned on a platform similar to Herbert Hoover in 1928, where he promised to cut taxes for the rich and re-open trading routes with China and the USSR. Dole was popular at first, as people were open to trading with China and the USSR again and were nostalgic for the Glorious Decades. 

Then, July 1992 came around and with it, the final Olympic Games in Beijing. The Graves Administration was extremely reluctant to participate, but in the end decided to do so at the suggestion of the First Lady, who said that it would be important for the nation’s spirit. The United States ended up taking home 35 Gold Medals, and almost 350 dead due to pollution-related causes. This was further compounded when China invaded Taiwan on August 1, 1992, at the tail end of the Olympics. The Taiwanese begged for help, for aid, for anything, but America literally could not spare anything. Their military had stagnated since the Nixon administration and all their reserve materiel had been requisitioned to help deal with commuter and gas riots. President Graves, however, also didn’t want to risk angering an increasingly unstable and aggressive China. Chairman Chen had become extremely bitter and hostile towards his former allies and trading partners, and Graves didn’t want to risk a few nukes coming for American cities. 

During the Presidential Debates of 1992, President Graves attacked the idea of reforming ties with China and the USSR. “I am not blind to the woes of the world, you would have us ally with those that invade Taiwan and those that invade Yugoslavia?” he pointed out. “Our cities are on fire, our children are starving and you want us to welcome war criminals with open arms?” The moderator, Hal Lehrer of C-SPBS[4], said that the President had spoken out of line and that the debates were for civil discussion, to which Graves retorted that he’s only happy because he has a job and that until the average American citizen is happy again, there’s nothing to be civil about. This outburst, despite the President later apologizing on live TV and saying that he’s been under an unimaginable amount of stress, actually resonated with a lot of Americans who were frustrated at the state of the world. 


The Election of 1992. Notice the demographic shift away from the South West and into the Midwest, South and Rust Belt. 

Graves’s policies had actually managed to win over a lot of hardcore Republican states. In 1992, Dole only won his home state of Kansas and kept North Dakota, Idaho and Texas. It was speculated that Texas voted for Dole in retaliation to the King-Chevron ruling, but regardless, Dole conceded defeat. In his victory speech on the night of November 3, 1992, President Graves reaffirmed his pledge to help the people of America the best he could. He promised that the worst was yet to come, but that he’d be with the American People every step of the way for as long as he was elected into office. 


Elliot Graves’s presidential portrait, 1993

https://youtu.be/1P3PnbRFd_c?si=eFG5iHhFjb4CIZlL 

In President Graves’s second term, he had practically the same cabinet (though the Secretary of Transportation retired in 1993 due to cancer). In 1993, America wasn’t much better. Unemployment was sitting at a stable 21.9%, and many in the densely packed cities were starting to have trouble affording fuel for their cars. Riots due to water shortages, power outages, gas prices and simple rage had caused several of the largest cities to deploy their state’s National Guard to supplement their increasingly militarized law enforcement. Graves’s demeanor (some would say passionate, others would say irrational) put off a lot of the US’s remaining allies, namely Canada and Europe. Europe, partly in response to America’s response to the Taiwanese invasion, decided that they would federalize. Graves’s reply to this was that he’d now have “less letters to ignore”. 

Graves’s approval rating with the ultra-rich, big business owners and hardcore Republicans was steadily nosediving, but his approval with the poor and middle class kept climbing. In the summer of 1993, after Social Security almost collapsed, the Graves Administration implemented the National Relief System - a universal basic income for every member of the nation, funded by taxes on the shrinking upper class. Then, in 1994, he introduced the American Industries Act, which gave grants to start-up manufacturing companies similar to the Feeding America By America Act. 

Later that year, when the United Nations would fall apart following China and the USSR’s withdrawal, President Graves remained unconcerned. All he had to say on the matter was “Maybe the third one won’t allow other countries to invade their neighbors.” 

On May 1, 1994, President Graves was invited to attend the signing of the Brussels Constitution. Graves declined, stating that he had more important matters to attend to, but his Vice President Clifford Smith would end up attending of his own accord. Clifford Smith was far more approachable (at least compared to the President) and was usually Graves's unofficial PR damage control in his second term, so he was welcomed as the United States’s representative during the ceremony. While in Brussels, Smith floated the idea of creating a third international diplomatic organization, an idea that would later become the Alliance of Nations. 

Despite Smith’s efforts, many countries (understandably) distanced themselves from the United States, as by 1994, almost half the world was in civil war conditions, anarchy or even warlordism. Japanese-American relations broke down after the Taiwanese invasion and in 1994, Japan finally repealed Article 9. 

In 1995, Graves was faced with some tough decisions. Oil prices were increasing exponentially and even with government subsidies, public transportation was floundering. The New York “Commuter Wars”, a series of riots in the New York metro system, forced the Graves Administration to take a long hard look at the current transportation system of the United States. This caused Congress to pass the Fuel Reservation Act in summer 1995, and with it, all reserves of petroleum were nationalized by the government and rationed out for vehicles like planes, ships, trains and buses, as they could transport more people. It became illegal to use oil for personal automobiles, with the only automobiles allowed on the road being emergency vehicles - not that it mattered, as very few Americans had the spare change to even drive their cars when food and other basic necessities were rationed and increasingly expensive. 

The Fuel Reservation Act was unpopular, but Graves bounced back in November 1995 with the American Hunger Relief Initiative, later known as the Universal Food Ration. This came at an opportune time, as the Great American Dust Bowl had just ravaged hundreds of farms across the nation, and hunger was starting to become a companion to many Americans. To help pay for this, even more “non-essential” government programs were scaled back or cut entirely, with the Lunar Space Program being permanently retired. In 1996, the last five astronauts would leave the Moon, never to return again. All leading food corporations were also nationalized, and Food, Inc was broken up into over a dozen different smaller companies.

https://youtu.be/Clj8htWcFho?si=PniFyAdl3XgHAwSP 

Even with all the welfare programs, government reach and an increasingly militarized police force, 1996 was the year that riots and civil unrest started to become the norm and not the exception. In the increasingly chaotic southwest, water riots in Los Angeles and throughout California would lead to the Governor of California to be assassinated on June 5, 1996. In the Rust Belt, the only area actually seeing any economic growth, one angry bus driver would kick off the Detroit Gas Riots which would leave almost 100 dead. 

By September 1996, President Graves was extremely unpopular with the political and economic elite of the country. He was impeached in 1995 for threatening to “beat senseless any chickenshit member of Congress who didn’t pass the goddamn hunger bill”. The few Republicans in the House put forth several motions to invoke the 25th Amendment and remove President Graves from office, but it never passed as President Graves was too popular with their constituents. 

During the election cycle of 1996, observers noticed that President Graves seemed to be more calm and collected - the stress of the presidency was breaking him, and he was only too relieved to not have to run again. President Graves got results, no one could deny that - but the DNC wanted someone a bit more level headed for the presidency. Several politicians participated in the primaries, including the Governor of Minnesota and the Senior Senator for New York, but Vice President Clifford Smith secured the nomination. After some debate, he picked Democrat Governor of Maine Roy Sanderson as his running mate. Smith campaigned on a platform of continuing President Graves’s work while also mending ties with America’s now distant allies. Being a witness of the horrors of nuclear power, Smith promised to fund research into alternative energies to get America’s cars going again. 

In 1996, Jack Dole won the RNC nomination unopposed. He campaigned on removing the ration system as the RNC felt that the worst of the crisis must have surely passed and that America was ready to resume her place as the financial capital of the world. However, they were sorely out of touch and performed even worse. 


The Election of 1996

Dole had actually managed to lose a state, resulting in yet another Democratic landslide. Fewer Republican representatives reached the House and the Senate, making the Democratic majority even wider - Jack Dole actually lost his seat and was ousted by a Democrat from Topeka, Kansas.

As Graves reached the end of his second term, he became notably more relaxed and calm. He would end up giving a farewell speech in early January 1997, with he and Clifford Smith both pledging to keep doing whatever they could to help the country. On January 20th, 1997, President Elliot Graves would leave the White House and never return. In 1998, he would set up the American Hope PAC, and retire from active politics to run a farm in Grants Pass, Oregon. Clifford Smith and Roy Sanderson frequently visited him to ask for advice to which he would kindly give. Elliot Fitzgerald Graves, 40th President of the United States, would die of cancer on October 2, 2007 in his farm outside of Grants Pass, Oregon. 


Clifford Wilfred Smith’s presidential portrait, 1997

During Smith’s inauguration speech, he reaffirmed his commitment to helping the average American weather the Second Great Depression and also of resuming diplomatic relations with the remaining nations of the world. 

https://youtu.be/tsgw0W1RE5A?si=agD3Z3UqqqLw3OXt 

President Smith was just as radical as President Graves, however he was far more subtle about it. Taking a page from FDR’s book, President Smith authorized the National Landmark Creation and Maintenance Act of 1997, which created over 600,000 jobs and tried to maintain the remaining national landmarks[5] as well as create new and existing landmarks. Throughout his two terms, President Smith would authorize the creation of 29 public monuments. Notable ones include:

The American Workers Monument in downtown Chicago, completed in 1998
The Nixon Monument in Yorba Chenda, California, completed in 1999
The National Monument for American Farmers outside of Lincoln, Nebraska, completed in 2000
The Monument to Public Service (featuring Presidents Theodore Rosevelt, Abraham Lincoln, Franklin Rosevelt, George Washington, Richard Nixon, and Elliot Graves) on the lawn of the White House, completed in 2001
The National Memorial for Vietnam Veterans at the gates of Arlington National Cemetery, completed in 2002
The National Monument of American Bankers, Entrepreneurs and Stockbrokers, outside Times Square in New York City, completed in 2003

Each of these monuments were meant to be tourist attractions: they were built around the nation, and also heavily advertised, with a televised opening ceremony that invited the heads of state of many nations once close to the United States. Many nations declined, however - the President of Canada only attended the ceremony in 1998, while the Prime Minister and King of the United Kingdom attended the 1998 and 1999 ceremony. Smith gave up sending invitations by 2002. 

Another initiative that Smith championed was the American Automobile Resurgence Initiative of 1997. This program allocated huge funds to research and implement a way to retrofit most cars to use alternative energy sources. Various sources were tested, with batteries charged using geothermal, hydroelectric, wind, and solar energy. While these were being worked on, Smith also approved a program to create a car that could run on coal or burned wood. There were quite a number of issues related to the alternative energies, but later that year on May 6, 1997, Ford-Chrysler would unveil their new coal-dust powered automobile, known simply as the “Steamer”. It was only available to the very rich however, at the low, low price tag of “only” $500,000, though emergency and federal services could get up to 80% off. Throughout the summer of 1997, as emergency services bought up coal-powered ambulances, reports of the cars overheating and exploding became more and more prevalent. In the fall of 1997 an investigation was conducted and found that Ford-Chrysler had rushed production to get the federal contract, and under the “Of the People, For the People” Act, Ford-Chrysler was forced to pay almost $257 Billion in fines. This bankrupted the company, and it was later nationalized and renamed to American Automobile Manufacturers in 1998. 

Research into alternative energies would continue for some time, until finally petering out in late 2001. Geothermal was only viable in the upper Midwest and Hawai’i, making refueling stations impractical. Solar was unreliable due to the amount of soot, smoke and smog in the air. Hydroelectric required water (obviously) and with what seemed like almost half the country in an almost permanent drought cycle, that was impractical. Wind was the only option left, but not only did wind power stations require lots of rare, precious metals that the USA didn’t have anymore, so did batteries. Rechargeable batteries were in their infancy[6] and required an enormous amount of resources to produce on a scale that could revitalize the American automobile industry. Lithium, Aluminium, Copper, even plastic were all used to create batteries - metals that the United States had sold to China in the 70s and 80s (for a great price!). 

A few prototype refueling and recharging stations were made. A geothermal station was built in Yellowstone, Montana, a hydroelectric station was built in Saint Paul, Minnesota, a solar station was built in Eureka, California and a wind station was built right outside Washington, DC. 98 cars with rechargeable batteries were built, and given to important government officials that frequently traveled the country. In August 2001, after the Secretary of Transportation’s car had a malfunction in the Mojave desert and he did not arrive at his destination, a search was called. The Nevada National Guard later found the car after a few days of searching, but it was too late. The Secretary was found dead of dehydration, and cooked like a pizza. Further examination found that the car’s battery had exploded, and while the head of the project assured President Smith that these were only temporary setbacks, the rest of the 97 cars were suffering from similar technical issues. A prototype limousine exploding in October 2001 was what convinced President Smith to pull the plug on the project. 

And so, the only option left was to use the expensive, prone to exploding Steamers. AAM was brought back from the dead and was used to manufacture cars for the government, military and corporations. Research was of course conducted to try to lessen the chance of an explosion, and by 2012 the risk of an internal explosion was only 0.9%. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M_Ld8JGv56E&list=PLw2qu_cqPb-mPzSdT5ml61LSO23OjlgEe&index=39&pp=gAQBiAQB8AUB 

During Smith’s presidency, the effects of climate change had become very undeniable and alarmingly fast. Almost half of the southwest had been shoved into Denver, and housing in cities was occupied as soon as they were built. This would lead the Smith Administration to create the Sustainable Urban Expansion Act of 1998, which would place hefty taxes on land that could be used for agriculture. In turn, state and municipal governments were given extra funds from the federal government to help develop housing for the increasing number of displaced citizens. To further incentivize internal migration to areas better suited for human life, the government subsidized many previously private services, such as shipping, water treatment and purification. 

When the Governor of Alabama authorized penal labor to make up for the cost of food production, the Smith Administration threatened to send in the Armed Forces to forcibly break up the prison-labor industry. The Army was slow to mobilize and so the State of Alabama sued the Smith Administration. It went all the way up to the Supreme Court, and in a 5-4 ruling, the Court declared that penal labor was legal under the 13th Amendment. In these exceptional circumstances, they argued, the forced labor of convicts by corporations was legal as long as it increased the production yield of essential goods such as clothing, metalworks and food. The corporations using these convicts would be required to pay for clothing, food and water to feed these workers, in addition to housing and also allowing federal agents to check their living conditions and ensure the convicts were treated fairly. 

President Smith was far more invested in geopolitics than his predecessor. He attempted to mend ties with the European Federation and the USSR, however, both of them rebuffed him. When the USSR and the rest of the Warsaw Pact invaded Finland, the Smith Administration cut all diplomatic ties with the member states of the Warsaw Pact. During the Berlin Blockade Crisis of 1998, Smith then helped spearhead the negotiations that would lead to the USSR lifting their blockade in exchange for a reduced nuclear presence on both sides. 

In 1999, President Smith requested Congress to vote on joining the Alliance of Nations. Even with a Democratic majority, the bill barely passed. Many in the country were skeptical about how helpful the Alliance of Nations could be to the US. The United States joined the Alliance of Nations on November 6, 1999, and became a permanent member of the new Security Council. 

Another bill President Smith pushed through Congress was the Reeducating America Act of 1999. Originally drafted by President Graves before he left office, the act would subsidize the collapsing education system of the country in an attempt to combat the falling literacy rate and create a new generation of scientists, engineers and other skilled workers to help tackle the problems that America would soon be facing. This initially caused college enrollment to skyrocket until it was quickly learned that many of the applicants had no intentions of actually using their education to better the country. Later in 2000, the Act was reworked into being a lottery-based scholarship system. It was too little, too late however - by September 2000, most colleges around the USA (and the world for that matter) would close for good. 

When the 2000 election cycle rolled around, President Smith secured the nomination unchallenged but was facing a steadily decreasing approval rating. The failure to revitalize the American automotive industry and the education system had significantly impacted Smith’s public image with the elite, and the strict rationing and environmental triage policies had made him unpopular with the poor. 

The RNC meanwhile had over a decade to rethink their strategy. The Republicans would have to go populist, rather than appealing to the elites and the economic prosperity of the poor. The RNC picked Alfred M. Keyes, a representative from Maryland. Keyes was both African American and also a Mormon, and the RNC hoped that he could appeal to both the racial minority demographic and the religious demographic. There were even rumors that he was a closeted homosexual, but the RNC hoped that such a diverse candidate could help them wrangle control of the country back. 

But in September of 2000, the internal stability of the United States was challenged when a group of penal farms declared independence under a reformed “Golden Circle of Dixieland”. These neo-confederates were nothing more than drunken racists who were taking out their frustration on racial lines. Still, Uncle Sam puffed up his chest and President Smith mobilized the Armed Forces. Supply lines were slow to move, and in early October 2000, the first reports of “Panther Mauls” came in. The predominantly black penal labor force had organized and risen up against the KKK. From monkeywrenching to fertilizer-based bombs, penal farms across the South were destroyed. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v582kPp43Mg&list=PLw2qu_cqPb-mPzSdT5ml61LSO23OjlgEe&index=41&pp=gAQBiAQB8AUB 

And with it, the United States was hit by its first major famine.

During the Presidential Debates of 2000, both Representative Keyes and President Smith condemned the racial violence in the South. Keyes, as an African American, demanded an immediate end to the hostilities. He said that this violence had erased all the progress of the Civil Rights Movement and the bloodshed was even an affront to God. Smith rebuffed him, saying that he didn’t go far enough. The Union was sacred, and it was only through the country’s combined efforts could America survive. By disrupting the flow of food to the rest of the US, this rebellion was affecting everyone’s lives. 


The Election of 2000

Keyes unsurprisingly lost, as while Smith was becoming disappointing, he was still seen as the better option of the two. Many corporations actually donated to the Smith campaign as he was seen as better for stability, and setting the precedent for stamping out rebellion in penal farms could end up being lucrative. Keyes won his home state of Maryland, took back Montana, and managed to win Utah, Georgia and South Carolina, which had not yet fallen to the racial violence. 

After Keyes conceded on the night of November 9, 2000, he pledged to travel the South in an attempt at calming the chaos. He successfully talked down a group of Panthers outside Rome, Georgia before disappearing. He would later be found by a squad of Kentucky National Guardsmen, hung from a noose and naked. 

January 20th, 2001 was a dreary day. America was tired of struggling. Crime was through the roof, and people were scraping by to pay their bills. Food was being rationed so tightly that soy-based steaks and bread were the only things consistently stocked on shelves. The nation was running out of hope. Graves’s policies had kept the country from shutting down completely, but Smith’s policies didn’t have the revitalizing effects he had hoped they would. The government was barely breaking even before the Second Civil War, and was now drowning in debt. America was sick of being told “just one more day like this, then everything will be better”. 

Smith watched with trepidation as the European Federation slowly became more and more authoritarian. He was worried that soon, the United States would have to take drastic measures to keep itself afloat. Already, cracks were beginning to form in the psyche of the nation. Alabama v. Clifford Smith had opened a nasty can of rotten, radioactive worms, and soon factories all over the country were petitioning to the Department of Justice to use penal labor. This was soon followed by the corporate-friendly governor of Illinois passing the Industrial Preservation Act, which significantly limited the power of unions. It was met by a nationwide strike, and the Governor eventually relented, however the damage was already done. 

President Smith’s last “successful” act as president was the American Mentorship Act, a bill that created a new department of the government, the Department of Mentorship. This new department would hire elderly professors and scholars, many who had been laid off as more colleges closed, to tutor and mentor newer government workers. With literacy rates only declining, these mentors would eventually be known colloquially as “Readers”. 

Smith’s downfall can be traced to August of 2002. Vice President Roy Sanderson was on a now rare overseas diplomatic trip to negotiate the London Agreement on the United State’s behalf. International relations had not improved, and with Turkey having been kicked out the year before, NATO was at each other’s throats. An up-and-coming representative from Virginia, Frederick Sweeney, made an impassioned plea to Congress that Uncle Sam needed help. They were bankrupt, and needed the help of every citizen, both public and private, to make it through this. And rather than welcome these helpful Americans with open arms, Uncle Sam had shackled them with fines and nationalized them. Representative Sweeney was of course referring to the massive financial power of the remaining megacorporations that dominated the food industry. He proposed an amendment to the “Of the People, For the People” Act of 1991 to massively reduce the fines and instead accept donations. Afterall, the government needed help. In the first week of September, the new bill narrowly passed the House of Representatives and was tied in the Senate. The Pro Tempore voted in favor of the act. President Smith could have vetoed the Act, but he ultimately chose not to. He felt that the benefits outweighed the negatives, and that ultimately, he could still help the country. 

He would regret that choice until his death.

Section 2: The American Nightmare (2002-2012)
Excerpt from “Corporatism in the 21st Century” by Ciarán Soltán, Man from Mullingar Press, 944 ASJ

The Midterms of 2002 resulted in a dramatic shift in policy. More and more Democratic representatives were being swayed by donations from large corporations. In some smaller cities in the Southwest, ones that had gone almost entirely bankrupt, politicians made deals with the remaining but powerful corporations to keep public services running. A new wing of the Democrats was emerging. Officially, they referred to themselves as the Pragmatists, but many in the New Deal focused Old Guard referred to them as the Corporatists. 

The deliberately vague definition of “donation” given by the “For the People, Of the People” Act of 2002 slowly opened the way for all types of corruption. There were a few cases of bribery and some forgery here and there, but for the most part, the Federal work force was holding the line. Law enforcement suddenly never had the time to investigate, as gang-related violence, rape, and murder were becoming ever-present. 

President Smith, meanwhile, was more concerned with the deteriorating state of the world. Vice President Sanderson had just returned from London and while he was successful at negotiating a peace between FulTec and Food, Inc, the changing political landscape made it a hollow victory. President Smith expressed his condolences to India and Pakistan and condemned the small nuclear war between them, with him comparing the senseless destruction to the Three Mile Island disaster. Smith’s sudden interest in foreign policy was a ploy for him to think of a way to undo the damage of the “For the People, Of the People” Act of 2002. He considered using an executive order but that plan risked impeachment, and the Supreme Court could simply strike him down. 

https://youtu.be/KjAQs39dWXA?si=crFN0fVsRUeMzcDQ 

His attention was caught when the town of Chicago launched a general strike in response to the working conditions in the rusting factories of the Midwest. The strike turned into demonstrations, which turned into protests, which turned into a march down LaSalle Street. Estimates range that 10,000 to 100,000 people marched, and included bus drivers, firemen, and even some of the more principled members of the Chicago Police Department. They were then joined with a group of African American marchers who were protesting the government’s weak response to the racial violence in the South. 

It is not known who started it, but the march turned into a riot as the mob swarmed Chicago City Hall. Rocks were thrown, then bricks, and finally a Molotov cocktail was thrown into the window of the Mayor’s office. The Governor of Illinois mobilized the National Guard - strangely, they were already on standby and quickly rolled into the city in a matter of hours. On October 3rd, 2002, martial law was declared by the Acting Mayor of Chicago. The Illinois National Guard worked with the rest of the Chicago Police Department to sweep the city. Almost 130,000 people were arrested in Chicago that month, some of them part of the riot and some of them for crimes committed while the police were distracted. The chaos died down, but it was like a dam had broken - from then on, Chicago was filled with tension and vapors of rage. 

The Smith Administration’s official position was to leave it up to the state government. In a televised address, President Smith expressed his sympathies for the frustrations of the rioters, but emphasized that only through law and order could these issues be resolved peacefully. He also stated that the federal government’s current priority was stamping out the racial violence in the South. 

As the unrest dissolved into just civil disobedience and the Armed Forces became bogged down fighting a guerilla war between Klan and Panther militias, Smith was hit with another problem - the Southwest was rapidly becoming harder and harder to live in. Already, millions had migrated to the northern, more cooler states, but those that could not move were on borrowed time. Arizona and New Mexico were locked in an almost endless drought cycle, with rationing placing stricter and stricter limits on water. Arizona’s National Guard had been permanently activated in 1997, with New Mexico following suit the next year. Both state’s governments had gone bankrupt in 1999 and were surviving on federal money, but that was quickly drying up. In a meeting with the Governor of Arizona, the Governor of New Mexico, President Smith and the Head of the Department of the Environment[1] in early 2003, the President learned just how bad things were in the Southwest. Crime was almost uncontrollable, unemployment was at a staggering 65%, emergency services were completely overwhelmed, and on top of that, Mexican cartels were exploiting the unemployed and using them to establish a vast black market. The federal government would run out of funds by 2015 trying to keep order in Arizona, and that was assuming the rest of the country didn’t dry up as well. President Smith considered his options, and ultimately, decided to enact the policy of National Triage and declared Phoenix, Arizona unsustainable - effectively abandoning it. All citizens were to evacuate by May 30th, 2003. Temporary housing was being set up in Colorado, but quickly the housing became permanent. 

The Red Summer of 2003 didn’t hit North America as bad as it did hit Europe. President Smith watched the civil unrest in the European Federation with much trepidation, and while he had hoped that Brussels would resolve the matter amicably, he was ultimately not surprised with the severity of the Crackdown. When the Soviet Union and East Germany took over West Berlin, all Smith could spare was a strongly worded letter of condemnation. The United States, barring the Deep South, was overall still being held together, even if it was being held together more out of fear than out of hope. 

As the 2004 Election Cycle began, President Smith endorsed Vice President Roy Sanderson to retake the White House and continue their work. The primaries would result in a different candidate, however - Representative Frederick Sweeney was the one who secured the nomination. He was chosen for his harsh stance on crime, and platformed on “stopping all crime by 2010”. Most of the country, barring the Midwest and the Deep South, was initially skeptical of this until the summer of 2004, when massive heat waves caused gargantuan brownouts due to coal shortages. This was followed by a crime wave that made the 90s look idyllic. As Sweeney campaigned, he blamed President Smith and called him weak and distracted, focusing on trying to make cars run again instead of protecting people. Sweeney even claimed that he had been working on a solution, and in early September 2004, he submitted it to Congress - The Labor and Work Reform Act. With it, he promised to return order to American cities. 

The RNC meanwhile, after trying to find Representative Keyes, ended up running a primary. Mayor for Green Bay, Wisconsin, Charles A. Wyatt, secured the nomination by campaigning on a platform of reducing rationing and trying to “jumpstart” the American Dream. He toured the entire country, stopping in every single state and giving large rallies. He promised that every unemployed American would get a job, and he sounded almost like President Graves.

During the Presidential Debate of 2004, the last televised debate[2], Representative Sweeney made law and order his top priority. He painted President Smith as a weak, ineffectual leader who couldn’t save Chicago, Phoenix or the South. He claimed that President Smith was a smear on the Democratic Party’s history and called him a charlatan. When asked about how the two of them would handle the escalating civil unrest, Mayor Wyatt suggested that he put a cop on every corner. Sweeney said that that wasn’t going far enough - that they needed to nip crime in the bud. He promised that every criminal would be going away for a “long, long time”. 


The Election of 2004

Frederick Sweeney won in a landslide, his talk about stopping crime, while initially vague, resonated with a lot of Americans. Mayor Wyatt conceded the night of the election, and wished President-Elect Sweeney well in his endeavors. The Republicans, despite having such political superstars as Abraham Lincoln and Richard Nixon, were becoming deeply unpopular with the American people. The three states that Wyatt won: Oklahoma, Arkansas and Alaska, he barely won by a slim majority. So many Democratic representatives were elected to Congress that they had a supermajority in both the House and the Senate. 

Later that November, Sweeney’s landmark bill would pass the Senate. President Smith was still too focused on the Southern Violence and the environmental situation in the Southwest to read the bill closely. A few days later though, he tried to reverse course and drafted an Executive Order nullifying the bill. The Supreme Court sided against him, and he spent the rest of his term trying to fight it. 

Just like the “Of the People, For the People” Act of 2002, the Labor and Work Reform Act of 2004 was another nail in the coffin for America. First, there was a total ban on firearms for most citizens. Only people authorized by the federal government could obtain a firearm, such as federal workers, police officers, store owners and landlords. All citizens had to turn in their guns to their nearest National Guard armory by December 31st, 2005. 

Second, following the model of the penal farms in the South, the bloated prison system was being replaced by factories using penal labor. The punishment for crimes were increased to act as a deterrent. Things like fraud, racketeering, embezzlement, burglary, and even something as petty as theft would land criminals in increasingly long sentences in a prison-factory. Murderers and rapists were sent to special high security factories, where they would await a sentencing while slaving away. Most of those incarcerated in actuality would never be seen by a judge, and would be worked to death in some corporate sweatshop making clothes or farming a field. 

Third, all cities with a population of more than 8500 were required to have a curfew from 8:00 pm to 6:00 am. This was to give the Police a chance to tackle the crime rate, and also remove homeless people from the streets. Momentarily, the streets of America became quiet as gangs, drug lords, cartels and mobs were rounded up and sent off to work as chain gangs. 

Just a month later, the first prison-factory was opened in Saint Paul, Minnesota by the Food, Inc. Many companies jumped at this lucrative opportunity, and soon factory workers were fired by the dozens. Factories that were close to bankruptcy started laying off workers left and right and filling up their assembly lines with gangbangers and smugglers. 

The Unions, of course, protested this and launched a general strike in the Rust Belt. However, part of the Labor and Work Reform Act classified striking as a punishable offense. Then, protesting was added to the list of punishable offenses. Soon, masses of unemployed, sweating strikers turned Chicago into a warzone once again. Factories still owned by Unions barricaded themselves inside, and some of them turned into standoffs with the Illinois National Guard. The struggling economy froze in place, as supply lines broke down due to nationwide strikes. 

President Smith’s last days in office were spent trying to repair the delicate supply lines that were keeping America on life support. Entire isolated communities starved to death, while federal water shipments to California were waylaid. The system was falling apart. On January 17th, 2005, with just three days left of office, President Smith suffered a stress-induced heart attack and collapsed in the Oval Office. He was rushed to the Winston Morgan Memorial Hospital and while he made a full recovery, he did not return to the White House. Vice President Sanderson was acting President for those three days, and all he did was coordinate Universal Food Ration shipments and try to keep more Southern cities from rebelling. 

On January 20th, 2005, President Frederick Ulysses Sweeney was sworn in. In his inauguration speech, he expressed his condolences to former President Smith, who was still in a coma. He dedicated his speech to him, and said that while he could handle the stress of wrangling the country back together, President Sweeney could. Sweeney then went on to explain that he was the owner of a telecommunications business in the Glorious Decades, and after the Crash of ‘88, that he fought tooth and nail to keep the company alive for as long as he could. He ended up filing for bankruptcy all the way in 1995. He promised the nation that he would fix the country better than Smith and Graves, but he’d need to fix the crime rate first. 


Frederick Ulysses Sweeney’s Presidential Portrait, 2005

President Sweeney’s first act was addressing the civil unrest in Chicago. He signed an executive order amending the American Unions and Workers Act of 1989, and replacing it with one that significantly curtailed the power of unions by making all American workers join a single, federally controlled union. Working with the Governor of Illinois, Federal troops retook Chicago by burning down factories occupied by Unionist holdouts. Later that week, on January 30th, 2005, President Sweeney said his infamous “strikebreaker” speech on live television and condemned any strikers, rioters and unionists as communist insurgents who were disrupting the very lifeblood of America. It had two meanings, however - the first was an obvious threat against any would-be rebels, but the second was to act as an assurance to the remaining financial titans of America that President Sweeney was on their side. After all, the biggest donations in American political history came from these corporations as a donation to the Sweeney campaign. 

https://youtu.be/BJH1Uolu7io?si=MAOXlEdRr5gPhbGR 

The next day, President Sweeney authorized the withdrawal of all federal troops from the South. Sweeney received widespread condemnation for this, but he rationalized it as a waste of resources. Most of the South was a dry, dusty desert or completely burned down by this point, so Sweeney deflected and claimed to focus on repairing the supply lines and attempting to revive the economy. 

Sweeney had been working with his corporate donors on his Labor and Work Reform Act for several years, and now that Sweeney was in office, there was nothing stopping it. The Smith Administration’s lawsuit was dropped, and Sweeney remained hopeful that the reduction in labor costs would help stimulate the economy out of a depression and into a recession. 

While the National Guard and the militarized police forces rounded up dissidents and sent them to factories, President Sweeney and his Vice President Barty “Hooper” Rogers attempted to curry favor with the government of the Nordic Union. The Nordic Union was considering a referendum for leaving NATO yet again, and while President Sweeney agreed that America was in no position to help her allies, he was still hopeful that that could change. By 2010, he had hoped, America would take her place as the dominant superpower again. 

Sweeney nor Rogers could sway the Nordic Union, and on March 24th, 2005, the Nordic Union of Sweden and Norway would leave NATO. Soon, this set a dangerous precedent and just a few weeks later Canada would leave as well. When the European Federation placed their blockade on the UK, President Sweeney started to plan a mediation between Brussels and London but his corporate donors advised against it, saying that Europe was no longer a worthwhile market after the signing of the London Agreement of 2002. The UK soon left NATO out of protest, and when Washington did not reply to a European request for aid against the UK, the EF left as well. 

By June of 2005, NATO had ceased to exist. 

Sweeney spent most the summer trying to negotiate a treaty of mutual defense with Canada, until at the end of August the American south was devastated with Hurricane Wilson. Several large cities were almost completely destroyed, including New Orleans, Louisiana and Palm Beach, Florida. Given the low-intensity but protracted violence in the South, federal aid could not be sent over land. President Sweeney did authorize a state of emergency in those areas though, and allowed the Coast Guard to assist in surveying the wreckage. 

Hurricane Wilson was estimated to have a death toll of over 40,000, and caused over $5 Trillion in damage. With the government barely scraping by, the decision was made to effectively abandon the southern coast along the Gulf of Mexico. The federal government did however work with Food, Inc to later organize a resettlement program from the devastated gulf region to the cooler (and more suitable for farming) states of Kentucky and Virginia. The displaced citizens were kindly given a job working at the local Food, Inc superfarms. 

Food, Inc, and many other companies, were soon running into a problem - even with the reduction of labor costs due to Sweeney’s bill, they still had to pay for all their other positions. Some of the smaller businesses had even stopped paying employees entirely and compensated them with necessities such as food, water, shelter and air conditioning. This culminated in the landmark case Richardson v. New York, in which the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 that so long as adequate compensation is given, employers could pay their employees in food and water in lieu of a wage. President Sweeney approved of this. In a press conference later that week, he said that it would bring the economy up, make sure employees got three square meals a day, and even teach them a trade. 

Later that year, in February of 2006, President Smith fully recovered from his condition. After seeing the blatant corruption of the Democratic party, he and a few other hardcore New Dealers would leave and form the New Green Party. The Old Green Party had languished in the early 80s after being co-opted by Big Oil to oppose nuclear energy after the Three Mile Island disaster. Smith, who had always cared about the environment and saw through the “greenwashing” of coal and oil, had decided that the Democratic Party had become just as pro-corporate as the dying Republican Party. The Sustainability and Welfare Party, or known to most as the Green Party, would begin campaigning in the Northeast in Smith’s home state of Pennsylvania. 

The first cause that the Green Party championed was the evacuation of Los Angeles, California. The Sweeney Administration had wanted to get an evacuation planned, but there was no room in the budget, and no corporation wanted to foot the bill. Los Angeles was declared “unsustainable” during a freak heatwave in late February, and fires started to ravage the Orange County countryside, uncontested by firefighters. The Green Party, led by Former Presidents Graves and Smith, organized an evacuation of Orange County. While a majority of the remaining corporations had sold out to their shareholders, there were a few in the pacific northwest who still believed in Graves’s cause. Pacifica Shipping, a transportation company that had worked with Graves before to coordinate the Universal Food Ration, offered their fleet of steamers to evacuate as many as 200,000 people from Los Angeles. 

Unfortunately, no good deed goes unpunished, and several of the steamers exploded as they were leaving the city. 23 people were killed and over three hundred were injured, including the CEO of Pacifica Shipping. When the trucks were dropped off at their corporate headquarters in Redding, California, several more exploded and ended up setting the company offices on fire. Howard Johnson, the CEO’s son, filed for bankruptcy in March of that year. 

The vast, corporate controlled media lambasted the evacuation efforts, using it to smear the fledgling Green Party, and then erased it from history. President Sweeney’s only comment was that the goal was noble but the results regrettable. 

Soon afterwards, the Sweeney Administration was beset with the aftermath of yet another devastating hurricane. Hurricane Whittney, an unusually large and long lasting storm, ravaged Hudson Bay and drenched New York City in apocalyptic floods. Food, Inc, Sweeney’s biggest donor, demanded that their headquarter city (and their biggest market) be protected from future cataclysm. Immediately, the Sweeney Administration began auctioning off the contract to build the Hudson Bay Sea Wall. American National, which was the only bank that had not foreclosed yet, bought the contract and the sea wall was to be named after them. The Green Party actually helped the clean up efforts, and this is what established their gradual rise in the Northeast. In February of 2007, the newly elected governor cut the ribbon on the finished American National Sea Bank. 

Other notable events in 2006 included the unraveling of the Warsaw Pact. This made President Sweeney a bit more relieved about the fracturing of NATO, but still he pursued an alliance with Canada, becoming gradually more aggressive. At first, he was worried about the USSR potentially invading Alaska but became more skeptical when the USSR and China became increasingly antagonistic towards each other. Then, on October 4th, 2006, the Emperor of Japan killed himself in ritual suicide. President Sweeney sent the Japanese a letter expressing his condolences, but no reply was even received from the increasingly isolated Japan. 

In 2007, rebellion and civil unrest had mainly died down around the country. The supply lines that were holding America together were strengthening again, and while over two thirds of the workers of America were not paid in wages but in food, it seemed that the country could recover. Summer of 2007 started early. In April, the average temperature in both the South and the Southwest was over 90 degrees. By May, much of Texas was uninhabitable, and on June 21st, 2007, the town of El Paso, Texas was declared unsustainable. The Sweeney Administration strongly urged all Texans to head north of El Paso and into Oklahoma and Arkansas. 

On July 4th, 2007, relations between the USA and Canada took a permanent nosedive when four Canadian border guards, for reasons yet unknown, moved four miles past the border wall [3] station of Blackpool, Quebec into American territory. Some have theorised it was an accident, like Former President Graves. Others, like the director of the CIA, viewed it as intentional, but this did not matter to the American border guards who shot at the soldiers upon sight. Two on each side were killed before the Canadian soldiers ran off towards the wall, alerting their superiors there. The American soldiers didn’t report it, hoping it was just a misunderstanding that would be brushed under the rug soon.

The Canadians didn’t see it that way.

Later that night, as the incident was passed up the chain of command, the Canadian army soon publicly accused the United States of trying to start a war, mobilising their forces near the site of the incident. President Sweeney vehemently denied this in an official statement, saying the soldiers shouldn’t have been breaching American territory and threatened “drastic action” should this continue. This was a bridge too far for the Canadian government - a day later, the Canadian Prime Minister broadcasted a speech on radio, claiming President Sweeney was planning to annex Canada and was jealous of its vast food supplies, and that all Canadians should “get armed and prepare for war”. Following this, forces built up on both sides, and in one of Sweeney’s greatest mistakes, he overreached and deployed a tank division near the town of Champlain, near Blackpool where the incident started.

The Canadian troops at the border, fearful the United States was about to invade, shot at a group of American troops near the wall, who fired back. The border clash led to fifty dead, plummeting relations, and nationwide fears war was imminent. As armies on both sides prepared for war, something unexpected happened - they both began to retreat. A last-minute phone call between President Sweeney and the Canadian Prime Minister led to an agreement to retreat all troops on the Quebecian border in exchange for negotiations for a trade deal later that year, which never panned out, and the grip of the nationalistic Canadian government tightened. The clash highlighted how far US-Canada relations had fallen, and they would never be back to normal again.

On October 2nd, 2007, the nation mourned when Elliot Graves, the 40th President of the United States, passed away from cancer at his farm in Grants Pass, Oregon. Flags around the country were at half mast, with the Oregon capital’s flag remaining at half mast for the rest of the year. President Sweeney, along with former Presidents Clifford Smith and Franklin King, would attend the state funeral in Washington, DC. 

2007 was considered the last “good” year, as in the USA, every year after that was filled with some horrible new disaster. In 2008, literally just a few days into January, did the United States confirm its first reported case of the Red Flu. President Sweeney actually used this as an excuse to outlaw gatherings of more than ten people, but it was never enforced because of how cramped cities had become. The Department of Health, which had been stagnating due to the chronic shortage of advanced medicine supplies, was reorganized into the Department of Sanitation, as that was about the only thing most state governments could manage now - make sure everything is clean, dispose of bodies in a timely manner, and hope for the best. 

2008 was also marked as the year that the agricultural centers of the US, mainly the South and the South West, would dry up completely, never usable again. Farms were slowly moved northwards but they were becoming more and more expensive. A heatwave in April of 2008 destroyed the last functioning superfarm in the South, outside of Charlottesville, North Carolina. The government was footing the bill (the Universal Food Ration was too popular to ever cut), but there wasn’t much else they could do. 

Food, Inc instead proposed using jellyfish blooms as their new filler for their ration. Ration Epsilon, as it was called, was rushed through the FDA to prevent another famine like in 2000. Sweeney’s Secretary of Commerce even allowed the Food, Inc to buy a record number of bankrupt fishing agencies, and soon the Food, Inc had the biggest commercial naval fleet in the world. 

https://youtu.be/whdzP0GHuc4?si=r4MLyFhfFBLvb4PQ 

As the 2008 Election approached, this became the main talking point for the two candidates. President Sweeney, due to his harsh stance on crime and his pro-corporate policies, was secured the nomination by the now majority Corporatist wing of the Democratic Party. The RNC, scrambling to appeal to voters, chose populist Representative James. J. “JJ” Thompson of West Virginia. Thompson attempted to appeal to the cautious miners in West Virginia[4] and the remaining independent farmers in the South, as well as the Rust Belt. He campaigned on a platform of undoing the American Unions and Workers Act of 2005 and amending the Labor and Work Reform Act of 2005 to remove the ban on guns, and as he toured the country, he was getting popular. Rather than risk all their work to be undone, the Corporates behind Sweeney used their vast media influence to spread the idea that both acts were already temporary. President Sweeney said on record multiple times that the acts would be lifted “when they were no longer necessary”. Sweeney had aimed for 2011, but as the days went on, he was becoming less and less sure if that would ever happen. The economy was stagnating despite the advent of free labor, and businesses were having a harder and harder time compensating employees[5]. 


The Election of 2008

On Election Day, the results were announced over the radio. Thompson managed to win only his home state of West Virginia, Tennessee (home to the largest independent farming community) and Mississippi due to the way that Sweeney handled Hurricane Wilson. The Green Party was doing even better though - Jennifer Walker became the Governor of Arizona and the first member of the Green Party to hold a governorship. 

Sweeney’s second term would cause his last hope for a better future to die. As the Red Flu spread across the country (which actually took some time due to how isolated different parts of the country were), more and more people became terminally ill. Yet the vast majority of those infected instead would receive devastating mental impairments and other damage to the nervous system - research was in its early stages before Sweeney pulled the plug, deeming it a waste of resources. In January of 2009, after a lengthy court case, the Supreme Court ruled 5-4 that assisted euthanasia for the terminally ill was legal and not considered murder. Chief Justice Jones actually referenced the Declaration of Independence: “If all other avenues have been exhausted and the only way to happiness and peace is leaving this mortal coil, it is up to the individual to exercise that right.”

In the aftermath of Jefferson v. Cincinnati, in 2009 alone, almost a million weary, broken Americans would end their lives - though the government never made that statistic public. America’s spirit had lost the battle with the Eternal Depression, and fewer people every year had the willpower to make it through the day. Following the Red Flu, a myriad of ancient Siberian plant diseases started to ravage the Midwest and the Rust Belt, forcing President Sweeney to reduce the calorie amount of the Universal Food Ration. 

In 2010, as the nation became more and more nihilistic, there was intense outrage that President Sweeney had made no attempts to undo his two landmark bills. As a result, the midterms in 2010 were marked by the Green Party performing even better, with the Governorships of Hawai’i and New Mexico both becoming Green. 

Sweeney’s Administration kept a close eye on the Second USSR Civil War, worrying that rival factions might try to take over Alaska. Sweeney ordered a pair of nuclear submarines to patrol the Bering Strait, but nothing ever came of it. In the midst of all of this, the city of Portland, Oregon seceded from the United States. Oregon, being the home state of Graves, was staunchly of the New Dealer faction and later followed suit, with parts of Washington and northern California seceding as well. A group of far-left Green Party radicals had gotten elected in various areas around the Northwest in 2008 and then in 2010 had decided that President Sweeney wasn’t serving the country anymore, so they declared independence and started talks about unifying into a new country. They called themselves Cascadia, and operated on a policy of eco-centered socialism. 

https://youtu.be/gApvH1WDr_g?si=M2bZlwtlzdSWHKs- 

The country of Cascadia did not even finish writing their constitution before their leaders were executed on live television and their army surrendered. Unlike the calcifying south, the Northwest was full of now prime real estate for farming. The Sweeney Administration was far more ruthless than the Smith Administration, and sent waves and waves of drafted conscripts into battle despite the high mortality rate. In the battlefields of Oregon, doctors euthanised more patients than they saved. Corporations such as Food, Inc and 4M were allowed to “sponsor” divisions of the Army and any territory they captured was allowed to be used for building a super farm or penal factory. The prisoners were sent off to Idaho where they were separated into different penal farms so that they couldn’t reorganize. 

The Green Party, including Smith, denied any allegations of being involved and condemned the rebels as “un-American malcontents who didn’t represent the ideals of the Sustainability and Welfare Party”. Still, the corporate media painted the Green Party and the rest of the New Dealers as vultures who wanted to remove the last bits of prosperity that America had regained after the Crash of ‘88. 

The Portland Rebellion sent shockwaves through America and was seen by some as a wake-up call. Big corporations like Food, Inc and 4M were taking over the government in real time, erasing the rights of the everyday citizen, and making them foot the bill. A week after the televised execution of Ted Kaczynski and Edward Abbey, the American Volunteer Army would form in Saint Paul, Minnesota. After faking a gas leak in the first Food, Inc prison plant to get the workers to evacuate, the AVA then used stockpiled charcoal to overload the machinery and cause the plant to blow up. 

The message was heard loud and clear and factories across the country began having spontaneous “equipment failures”. The overworked, overstretched and over-militarized police were tasked with catching any would-be AVA bombers. Universal Food Rations were withheld against communities that were suspected of harboring AVA members. Some relented, others starved. 

The deliberate sabotage of farms and factories around the country caused the food supply to dwindle further. Food riots became regular and brutal, with “death by food riot” becoming the most common fatality in the United States. The police and the national guard became indistinguishable, as both shot without warming, and with the production of armor or padding being kept slow so that the rebels couldn’t use it against the government. This was exacerbated further when in summer of 2011, the strongest heat wave recorded yet hit the world and caused entire forests to die off. Plant diseases, forest fires, drought and storms were shutting down farms by the hundreds. Entire towns were wiped off the map due to tornados or fires. This caused yet more people to crowd in the crumbling metropolises. 

The Purple Summer caused the Sweeney Administration and the American Foodstuffs Industry to rethink how they were producing their food. They were running out of jellyfish, and lentil beans had gone extinct due to a plant disease. Richard Holden, Governor of New York, proposed an ingenious idea: use cockroaches as filler. They were hardy, abundant, and rich in protein. In July of 2011, at the height of the Purple Summer, the Sweeney Administration abolished the FDA and let the foodstuffs industry run wild. Soon, everyone was eating bugs, and the riots started to die down in intensity. 

But now they were faced with yet another new problem: steamer trucks, in addition to exploding, were also rather slow, loud and quite easy to rob. Bandits, rebels, Klansmen and Panthers would all rob Food, Inc convoys, and despite the Sweeney Administration sending increasingly well-armed escorts that culminated in the entire 10th Infantry Division and a coal-powered tank, transporting food shipments became too risky. Food, Inc, which had earlier bought out AmRail, switched to solely using trains and boats to transport their shipments. 

And even then, they still ran into problems. After AVA bombed a Food, Inc train yard and nearby food processing factory outside Madison, Wisconsin, the decision was made to have factories that produced high-priority goods like food and clothing be staffed entirely by convicts. If they showed any violent behavior, they were executed on the spot. The few factories and farms that had a non-convict work force (there weren’t many by this point) had to fire their workers and create yet more unemployed, but President Sweeney was assured that it was necessary. 

President Sweeney would spend his final year in office hunting down the members of AVA like it was a game of whack-a-mole. In that final summer, he would commonly be found pacing around the West Wing in a distressed frenzy. Congress considered removing him under the 25th Amendment but instead his Vice President, Barty Rogers, took over his administrative duties. 

Sweeney had become callous and disillusioned with his own power, watching as the cityscape outside the windows of the Oval Office turned stagnant, festering, and sickly. He began cutting more and more programs, and in the summer of 2012, he would authorize the final manned space mission in human history. The last astronaut would look down at the Earth and see the same sickly green hellscape that President Sweeney saw. 

[1] President Smith established the Department of the Environment in his first term to better mitigate the effects of climate change and also document the deteriorating conditions. He pushed for President Graves to implement it during his second term, but Graves replied that he “didn’t know how cities turned to sand” and would leave it to the younger generations. 
[2] The decision was made in 2008 to discontinue televising Presidential debates because many were too poor to afford electricity for their TVs anymore, and viewership had dropped significantly since 1996.
[3] The newly elected anti-American Canadian government in 2004 built a border wall across much of the Canada-US border. It was mainly made of barbed wire and stone, and was built primarily for a show of force.
[4] Workers in West Virginia were paid better and had better hours because a majority of Washington, DC’s coal came from West Virginian mines. 
[5] After Richardson v. New York, many companies began paying their employees in food instead of a wage. Corporations kept reducing the pay to see how low they could go, but after a mass quitting in a Detroit law firm, the compensation stabilized to a barely-livable amount that kept only the most desperate people on. 
Section 3: The Rise of the Managerial State (2012-2026)
Internal report to the President of the United Xhosan Federation, based on research conducted by Amaury Velasqué-Lafontaine and Ciarán Soltán, during the 904 ASJ expedition into Yoosa

https://youtu.be/pOFZDP5anZc?si=Nwfr5e6KVm8Or-BY 

Despite his failure to wipe out crime and resurrect America out of the Eternal Depression, President Sweeney was immensely popular with the remaining political and economic elite - so much so that Food, Inc considered lobbying Congress to repeal the 22nd Amendment. Ultimately, it was decided against it, as the elites were worried that Clifford Smith could get elected for a third term. Frederick Sweeney was given a spot on the Board of Directors of Food, Inc, which would make him obscenely rich, and also given a huge, private ranch outside of Gladstone, Michigan. 

Sweeney could be described as corrupt, yet principled. The same could not be said of his successor. 

The Election of 2012 was notable for being the first election in US history where the Green Party won electoral votes. The GNC nominated Joseph Hill of Hawai’i. Hill was one of the original founding members of the party and was President Graves’s Secretary of the Interior. He campaigned on a platform of expanding environmental regulations, as current projections predicted that Hawai’i would have to be abandoned by 2017. He also campaigned on increasing the Universal Food Ration calorie amount and reforming the FDA. He only won his home state of Hawai’i, but the governors of Washington, Oregon, California and Nevada had all turned Green. 

The RNC was dying, with no new congressmen heading to Washington, DC. The primaries were only run in just three states: Montana, Wyoming and North Dakota. Bill Roemer won the nomination practically unopposed, and campaigned on an aggressive platform of wiping out the “fascism” in DC and calling the sitting members of the Senate “rabble-rousers, Benedict Arnolds and demagogues”. He used a lot of complex, flowery words in his rallies, and that was his downfall - the US educational system had been in freefall ever since 1988, and literacy was declining at such a rate that people born in the Red 
Decades only knew how to read and write a few basic words. Senator Roemer would only win his home state of Wyoming. 

Food, Inc and other mega-corporations pumped billions of dollars into the DNC’s campaign. There were primaries, but the results were rigged for their preferred candidate: Peter Stephen Jarret, Junior Senator of Alaska and son of President Morgan’s Vice President Andy Jarret. The corporate-controlled media viciously attacked Senators Hill and Roemer, making them look corrupt and incompetent. This was contrasted with their portrayal of Jarret, who they paraded as a return to “feel good” Americana and a vague message of wealth and prosperity. In cities across America, posters of Jarret appeared overnight, painting him as a perfect, Adonis-like man who was on the side of the common man. 


The Election of 2012

And it worked - Jarret won the largest landslide in US political history, winning a staggering 532 electoral votes. 


Peter Stephen Jarret’s Presidential Portrait, 2013

Despite his big talk of returning prosperity to America, President Jarret spent his first months in office signing executive orders that significantly curtailed the power of states in the name of “efficiency and unification”. He also disbanded the Select Committee on the Enforcement of Servile Rights, and removed many of the rights that were granted to immigrants and refugees, including the suspension of birthright citizenship. 

The repression began with the El Paso Massacre of May, 2013. Texan National Guardsmen brutally rounded up and murdered the entire population of immigrant refugees. The exact number of killed Mexicans is unknown, as the Jarret Administration denied any and all involvement.
