Note on diction: As Courtney is not very educated, her first few entries are written with simple sentences and have occasional spelling/grammatical errors. As she educated herself, her entries will become more coherent. 

June 17th, 2027

I was not able to take my old journal with me, not enough time. So much has happened in the past week and I cannot let them find out that I know how to write. I am writing now in the dead of night, after the communications black out. General Sitwell said that the bombs were flying and the Barn couldn’t be found. 

I haven’t slept in three days. It all feels like a dream, like it’s not real, and that tomorrow I’ll wake up in the Penthouse again. 

Richard’s wife couldn’t make it. Supposedly, she was killed by a vagrant when the Secret Service turned their back. Bullshit. He wants me, and only me. Darlene and Charles cried all the way to the plane. Despite it being the dead of night, the city was crawling with revolutionaries. Madison Square was filled with burning corpses. Cops and NGs[1] were shooting at each other. That church on broadway was filled with crying, and then silence. I saw some horrible writing on the ground, sprawled out and written with blood: “Ration Omega IS DELICIOUS”. I covered Darlene’s eyes, poor girl, though she was still tearing up and asking for her mommy. 

A group of men wearing grey bandanas and waving Canadian flags almost cornered us in an alley and tried to kill Richard. Agent Jaurez was killed. I hope his family made it to Alaska. Some bastard grabbed me and I thought I was going to die right then and there. I’d be fine with dying. Then he started oozing blood from his nose and fell over. Some agent, I never got his name, had shoved a combat knife through his neck and took him down before being pulled under. 

An armored steamer pulled up to us as we were nearing Times Square, and a squad of Green Berets jumped out. Said they were covering our retreat. We never saw them again. 

I don’t remember how we got to the air field. Richard looked like he was trying to find the right words, but was silent the entire time. The only thing he said that day was a simple “Thank you”, to the pilot. 

The plane sitting in the airfield wasn’t Air Force One, or some military bomber plane, but just a rusted cargo plane. Words in some European language was written on it. Richard, Darlene and Charles were shoved in, and then I was pushed in. A few agents buckled us in and then took defensive positions in the cargo bay. General Sitwell appeared from the cockpit and when he saw the President was in the plane, he rushed back and yelled at the pilot to take off, and that rebels were closing in. 

I’ve never flown before and I hope to never fly again. My ears still hurt. Darlene didn’t stop crying. Charlie had stopped his screaming and simply staring at the floor. The agents were wiping blood of their uniforms and drenching them in alcohol. 

It was the longest 19 hours of my life. Every single second, I thought that we’d be shot out of the sky. Or run out of fuel. Or just crash. 

When we landed, it was dark again. Off in the distance, I could see some muddy, white hills - ice, I think. A group of heavily armed men ran up to us, clad head to toe in patterened camo, gas masks and other military equipment. They saluted President Richard and after confirming who we were, rushed boxes off the plane and led us towards a dry, dirty path. At the end of the path, in a center of a field of weathered tree stumps, was a rusted barn. 

General Sitwell yelled something in his weird military slang and the rusted barn door swung open, revealing a darkness that seemed to go on forever. I felt a rush of warm air and looked behind us to see the rusted plane burning before something exploded and the metal frame fell inwards. The soldiers shoved us in and then shut the door when they were all inside. 

Richard swallowed hard and glanced at us. “Get them under. We’ll talk later.” 

One of the soldiers, his mask started glowing green and it was all I could see as he grabbed my hand and walked with me in the darkness. The barn didn’t smell bad, just like… dust. A squeak of metal later and we were in a cold metal place, an elevator. Darlene squeezed my hand so hard I thought it would fall off, and Charles was breathing so loudly. The elevator started descending, oddly silent, like it was brand new. 

After probably a minute, harsh, blinding lights began to sneak in through the doors before they finally opened, revealing a pristine concrete hallway. Dozens of doorways led to other rooms, one of them being a library, where I am writing this right now. 

The kids were led to a comfortably furnished room, with silk sheets, stuffed matresses, and sinks that despensed purified water. A plastic pink dollhouse, probably from the Good Times, was there for Darlene. Charles’s bed had a faded cowboy costume on it, complete with a pretend rifle. 

The soldiers offered to bring me a chair, but I just sat on Darlene’s bed with her. She kept asking me where her mommy was until she finally fell asleep. Charles tried to leave several times but a soldier stationed outside always stopped him. They were still wearing gasmasks, and later that day, Richard finally looked in on us. He said nothing, just a curt nod, and continued walking with General Sitwell. We weren’t allowed to leave except to use the restroom, and that was only if we had someone with us. 

At some point, food was brought to us. Hot, warm tomato soup with noodles was our dinner, or breakfast, or lunch. Darlene only ate the noodles. She was kind enough to let me drink her broth, but she’s still so skinny. Richard didn’t join us, though Sitwell told us that he wished us well. 

After our meal, Charles demanded something to entertain him. The soldier guarding us didn’t let him leave, but asked a nearby guard to get something for “the kid”. 

Richard finally showed up a little while after, and I saw him smile for the first time in months when he saw Darlene and Charles. “I got something just for you, sport,” he said to Charles, and took out a book. “Picked it just for you,” he handed it to him. It was yellowed and old, but in good condition. It was called Robinson Curuso: some adventure about a man surviving in the wilderness. Richard said that they were all Robinson Curusos now. 

He then pulled me aside, where he thanked me for watching over the children. How I’d become a proper member of their family, of his family, and soon it’d be made official. That shocked me. I didn’t even hear the reason why he gave me three gasmasks, it just went in one ear and out the other. 

He led me to his bedroom, a lavish, ornate room, and he made me relieve his stress. 

Suddenly, there was a loud humming noise and then the lights went off. I could hear Darlene scream out, until a soldier gently told her it was all okay. There was a knock at the door. Sitwell was talking through the doorway about the “Dead Man’s Hand” or something. I convinced Richard to let myself get dressed so that I could check on the kids. By the time I had gotten dressed, the lights slowly flickered back on, this time noticably dimmer. 

Darlene and Charles were fine, and Darlene had calmed down. I stayed with them for as long as I could, and finally, they fell back to sleep. 

And here we are, with me hiding out in the library. I found a clock in there, some old, wind up thing, and it might be almost 4 am. I write slow. The pencils here are for Richard and his advisors, I think, along with the bound notepad that I am writing this on. I will hide it in an airduct nearby. 

CB

June 20th, 2027

A lot happened today. I learned that the reason why the power went out was some kind of scary bomb attack by the Russians. Moscow’s last line of defense. The bombs blew up in the sky and messed with the power like the solar storm last year. Sitwell says that the communication lines to the Nest, the Coop, the Roost and the Yard[2] had been restored. Holden seems far less concerned about his wife’s disappearence than the kids are worried about their mother. Darlene asked if I could be her mother now. How could I refuse that? 

Holden later explained that the reason why he had given me those gasmasks were because of some kind of sickness the Chinese had made. Something very bad, and painful, and spread through the air. He called me stupid for not listening to him, and I lied by saying that I was so distrcted by the thought of being in his family. 

Not that I really have a choice. 

I’ve taken some time to explore more the bunker. Meals are regually hosted in the canteen at 7 AM and 7 PM. Being in the President’s family, we get an extra, smaller meal at noon, though Richard barely eats anything anymore. He spends all his time in the communications room, having whispered conversations on rickety, ancient telephones. 

Charles now walks around, holding his toy gun, with Corporal Weatherly, the guard that stayed with us that first day. Richard once jokingly saluted him, calling him a fine defender of America. Darlene is already bored of her dollhouse, and I found her instead reading some old girly magazine from 1979. The people look so happy in it. 

Suddenly, soldiers and plain-suited men were running through the hallway. One of them dropped a bundle of papers only to hurredly pick them up. 

“We under attack?” Corporal Weatherly asked the nearby soldiers. 

“Transmission out of China,” was all the man said before rushing along with the others. “Probably the last one. It’s just on repeat.” 

The communications room was packed with people, all rushing to open books, pouring over maps, or writing hurredly in books. Richard was in the room, intently listening to a headset as operators were tweaking knobs and dials. A thin looking man was hooking up a casette player and the spools were turning. Richard unplugged the headset and a calm, but defeated, voice was talking. According to one of the suited men, it was in Mandarin. I listened with them, watching them transcribe and translate it, debating over the meaning. It was only a few minutes long, and then followed by some recording of a vintage song. I’ll attach a copy of the transcript below. 

CIA REPORT 2027062043405-1-T-OMEGA
Broadcasted at 04:38, Beijing Time, 21 June 2027
Translated at 97% accuracy by Agent Sun on 20 June 2027, 21:13 Greenland Time

TRANSCRIPT BEGINS

Three notes sound.

Chairman Liang Guowei:

My comrades. Today sets the Red Sun over the glorious People’s Republic of China. It is through our steel will and noble sacrifices that our nation has endured and our people’s voice heard. We lifted our people from the madness of Mao Zedong and forged an economic alliance that changed the very world. We have brought stability to our neighbors and security to our people. 

But just as every day must end, so too must every nation. Today is our end. It is not the end that any of us did want. It is not the end we deserve. Against our best efforts by our bravest revolutionaries, glorious workers and selfless farmers, China has lost the battle for her national spirit. 

On 13 June, at 03:12 Beijing Time, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, made an unprovoked and aggressive attack against our people, our humanity, our dignity. Shanghai, Pyongyang, Seoul, Beijing and Hanoi have all been destroyed in an unprecedented and inhumane act of war and irrational aggression. The Glorious People’s Liberation Army, with righteous fury, did retaliate to defend China’s name. 

Chairman Liang Guowei takes a deep breath, and coughs. He is thinking of what to say. 

With this attack on our sovereignty, untold lives have been lost, and many more will follow. In the destruction of Beijing, our final mercy was released before its completion. It truly was meant to be a final mercy. Our world has seen incomprehensible suffering in the past forty years. Mercy and peace, without pain and indignity, was to be the People’s last gift. 

Chairman Liang Guowei begins to wheeze slightly. 

China’s long, eternal rest is approaching. It will be a peaceful rest. Quick, and painless. Soon our people will no longer have to bear the horror of living in this world. Women will no longer have to fear losing their child to a pointless war in a far-away land. Our eldest will no longer be working for the good of the People, but will rest at last. Our soldiers need never fire their weapons again and kill our fellow man. Hunger will no longer be met with sacrifice and silence. 

We will all know peace. It is not the peace we wanted. It is not the peace we hoped for. But it is still peace. Let us retain our dignity. Let us remember China as it was meant to be: a powerful, peaceful nation of plenty and equality, championed by strong-willed people who guide the world in a new age of prosperity for all. 

As you succumb to the last Mercy, spend it with those you love. Your comrades in arms. Your mentor in the fields. Your lovers and family. And let us hope that there will be ones to remember us. Let history tell the great tale of the People’s Republic of China! 

All hail the immaculate People’s Republic of China!

Chairman Liang Guowei takes a long sigh and a gunshot is heard. 

Immediately afterwards, a grainy, faint song begins playing. 

TRANSCRIPT ENDS

Agent Sun, the thin suited man, finished translating and read it aloud to Richard. Richard, sitting with his legs crossed, briefly pondered the meaning. 

“The plan continues. This changes nothing,” was all he said. He then noticed me, and rushed me out. 

CB

June 21st, 2027

Agent Sun was found dead today. He had killed himself. He was the only one who was fluent in Mandarin, and the only one to hear what the broadcast was actually saying. 

We are having a funeral for him tomorrow and cremating him. 

CB

June 22nd, 2027

The funeral was weird. Not many people showed up. Richard didn’t show up, he spends all his time in the communications room. 

It wasn’t like my grandma’s funeral. General Sitwell gave a speech about Sun’s service to America. A few other agents saluted, and then two of the soldiers carried his body and threw it into the furnace. General Sitwell played a few notes on a rusted bugle and then marched out of the room. 

CB

June 29th, 2027

Richard caught me in the library today. He was surprised, saying that he didn’t know I was so refined. I lied and told him I can barely read, and was only getting picture books to read to Darlene. 

He smiled, and told me he would show me his appreciation later that night. 

CB

July 4th, 2027

I woke up today to shouting and then a gunshot. There was a knock and then our door was busted down. 

“Clear!” a muffled voice said. It sounded like it was Corporal Weatherly. “The President is unharmed.” 

“What is the meaning of this?” Richard growled. 

“Some of the New Jersey boys got drunk and started to rant about seeing their families,” the corporal said, moving his flash light around the room. 

“And?” 

“A few of them tried to get out. Said they were going to go to Alaska or die trying. So the General made good on their word.” 

Richard buried his face in his hands. “How many did we lose?” 

“Just one. After Private Fox took some lead to the head the others fell in line.” 

I spent the rest of the day trying to find out more information about what happened. I overheard two guys talking about how Alaska is “off limits”, and that our base, the Barn, is a secret. The “others” weren’t told about it. Only three other people know about it. 

CB

July 5th, 2027

Apparently, the soldiers who tried to leave were all killed anyway. Richard called everyone into the main hallway and told us that he wouldn’t tolerate any “disruptions” to “the plan”. That he, and many others, had sacrified too much to throw this away. 

Turns out that’s not all what happened yesterday. Former President Jarret was confirmed dead by a team in Alaska - he had been found dead in his US Marine escort boat, and strung up something awful with his own body parts. 

Charles didn’t take it well, calling them “ungrateful traitors”. 

I am moving this journal to the room with the furnace in it. If I need to, I can burn it. 

CB

July 23rd, 2027

I’ve gotten very good at sneaking around the base. At night, after spending time with Richard, I always excuse myself to take a shower, then I go to the library to get a book to read. I don’t hide my ability to read from him anymore, but I always pick out smaller, easier books. He still doesn’t know I can write. 

But on the way back to his room, I always check the communications room for any new transcripts or information on the outside world. There’s an old, simple map on the wall, with labels for countries and tiny, yellow pins in certain places, like Moscow. I think it means they are destroyed by bombs. 

The map had been changed, slightly: a small island between that big island where we are and those two smaller islands near Europe had been crossed out. Iceland, it was labeled. Yellow pins were all over the island, and next to it was a half-translated document. The letters looked weird, like some were backwards, and it was about a Soviet commander announcing that he was wiping out the last of the “European cancer”. 

I looked at the map some more. Huge sections of the world, like the abandonded states, were completely blacked out. Europe was filled with red and black pins and China was completely crossed out. Some islands in the northern sea were circled and had various notes written next to them. I then saw something that broke my heart - New York City was crossed out. A black pin was neatly placed in it. 

“We won!” a voice came from behind me. I almost jumped out of my skin. 

I turned around to see Charles, wearing his silk night clothes. 

“What are you doing up?” I asked. 

“I heard you talking to yourself. I wanted to make sure you weren’t a traitor like those other soldiers!” he declared. 

“I’m not! I promise!” I assured him, kneeling down to give him a hug. I then looked him in the eye. He had sneaky eyes. “What did we win?” 

“Our company won, of course. Those slimy bastards from FulTec are all gone.”

“Watch your mouth! There is no need for an eleven year old to talk that way!” I scolded him. 

“That’s what Dad calls them. I didn’t know that was a bad word,” he apologized. 

“Well, don’t call them that around me!” I said, and gave him another hug. 

I led him back to his room, and when he was asleep, I secretly went down to the furnace room and wrote this. 

CB

August 3rd, 2027

The soldiers were on high alert today. The soldiers were actually holding their guns. They haven’t done that for almost a month. Some of them were even patrolling the hallway. Instead of encouraging it, Richard told Charles to “shut up” and told me and Corporal Weatherly to keep the kids in their room. 

Charles was in a sour mood for the rest of the day. Darlene was her usual happy self. She’s started writing poems, Richard shows me them every night. But today she gave me one just for me. I didn’t quite understand what she was writing about, but it sounded as pretty as a six year old could write. 

Dinner was brought to us today. Beef stew and wheat crackers again. Corporal Weatherly thinks that one of the cows died, and the cook is trying to make the most of it. Soon the bones will be ground up into our wheat flour, he joked. 

At about 10 at night, General Sitwell announced through the speakers that everything was all clear, and the soldiers relaxed. They didn’t let me leave the room with the kids - not even to go to the bathroom. I think that Charles told Richard that I was in the communications room. Richard himself came to get me, and apologized for the precautions. 

Something “had happened” in the Midwest and Sitwell was worried that the location of the base could be compromised. Richard was so tired that he simply retired to bed, and didn’t even use me. 

That was an hour ago. I snuck into the communications room for the first time in a week. Much of the USA was crossed out, with little blue pins in various locations - the bases. In between the west coast and the lakes were a ton of yellow pins and black pins. Scrawled notes in both Richard and Sitwell’s handwriting described how the “Portland Collective” and the “Lamb” had engaged in a battle for access to bombs in Montana and North Dakota. Big bombs - the ones that destroyed those cities earlier this summer. 

The Lamb’s army had launched a few of them, with Sitwell noting that Berlin and Moscow were hit, despite already being destroyed earlier this year (Sitwell had even wrote “MORON” in the sidelines). Some of them didn’t hit their targets though - a technician had wrote that he believed it was a compiuter malfunction, and now… there’s a huge radioactive wasteland there. 

Richard wrote saying that the Lamb was “out of the game” while Sitwell was worried he could make it here if he leaves his base in the Lakes. When Sitwell had confirmed that all the bombs were accounted for and had counted up the destroyed cities (there were a few extra ones in Canada and even one in Mexico), he had announced the all clear and to stand down. 

I could try to find more information about the “Lamb”, though I don’t want to risk my position. Besides, tomorrow is Darlene’s birthday and she want to have a tea party with me and Richard. I have to get ready for that. 

CB

August 4th, 2027

Richard didn’t show up for Darlene’s tea party today. Said he was too busy. Instead, he showed up to her room after dinner and gave her a wrapped package. She opened it up and her eyes widened. All was forgiven, it seemed. Inside was a tiny, smudged block of chocolate wrapped in foil. 

CB

September 1st, 2027

I worked up the courage to start reading Robinson Curoso. The words are pretty complex. It seems ancient, almost like another language. I had to check a dictionary for a lot of them. 

CB

September 20th, 2027

Been reading more RC. We are NOT like him, he’s not living in a secret bunker with all this food! He had to do everything, alone, in a forest! 

CB

October 15th, 2027

I’ve been getting restless. I’ve been begging Richard to show me more of the Barn. I’ve explored every nook and cranny, every corner and closet and I’m bored. I want to see the other levels. I know there’s a hangar, and a storage level, and also where they’re growing next year’s food. 

He finally relented today and took me in the elevator, then we went up a few floors. 

It smelled horrible. Like the streets of New York. I could instantly tell that this was where they kept the animals. I’d never seen anything before, except a cat once when I was a girl, and the hairless birds that would be in the streets back before the heat waves. 

This floor was a lot more open than the living quarters, and seemed like a large underground warehouse. It was filled with hundreds of tiny, metal boxes and tubes and pipes. Drains divided the floor. Workers wearing plastic suits and gas masks sprayed water using hoses, while others were organizing chemicals in syringes or writing things down on slates. 

“Mister President! Sir! We aren’t due for another inspection until next month!” a man said, wearing a gray jumpsuit and a hard hat. He came rushing up to me and Richard. “If I’d have some advance notice I’d have cleaned it up! Get rid of the smell!” He then looked at me, and his wrinkled face seemed confused. “Who is she?”

“The new first lady, actually. The next Mrs. Holden,” Richard said. 

I don’t remember how I responded. We had some awkward conversation and then I was led to one of the metal boxes. 

“This room contains half of the livestock left in North America,” the worker, Mr. Stevenson said. “Currently, we have 328 chickens, 11 turkeys, and 47 cows. Our sister site in Alaska has almost 1000 chickens, plus several hundred sheep, and at least a hundred cows. I’m not sure how many are still alive. They still think turkeys are extinct!” 

“What are turkeys?” I asked. 

Mr. Stevenson laughed, but Richard stared him down. 

“I’ll show you, I guess,” he muttered and led us down the hallway to a row of smaller boxes. He opened one of them and revealed a rusted cage made of rough steel. Inside, on a bed of dried grass, was a tiny, scrawny looking bird. Its eyes were red and bloodshot, and the feathers still on its body were gray and frayed. It had some weird, veiny sac on its throat, it looked quite indecent actually. 

“He’s not the most handsome fellow, but what if I told you that he’s actually our healthiest animal? We’ve been breeding them all summer but they’ve all been stillborn or blind,” he continued. 

That was all I could stand, so I excused myself. Richard quickly caught up to, and quietly escorted me back to the living quarters. 

“Does that satisfy your curiosity?” He asked. 

All I could do was nod. 

CB

October 23rd, 2027

Today, new people actually arrived. A couple dozen marines, all thin as bones and their equipment barely hanging on to their uniforms, and three other people. I’ve seen all of them in both Washington and New York. Governor Sanford, his wife, and President Sweeney. Sanford was covered in soot and his face had large scar on his bald, sunburnt head. Patricia Sanford was looking a bit tidier, though one of her arms was in a sling. President Sweeney was wearing a ragged, torn suit and had a blank stare of confusion. 

“Holy mackerel, Fred, what the hell happened?” General Sitwell smiled. 

“AVA attacked. Those damn rebels. They’re always there. They’re ALWAYS up to something,” Sweeney muttered, and then sighed. 

“The communists in the Midwest have taken everything between Lake Erie and the Western Exclusion Zone,” Sanford said. “Like we agreed, we preemptively evacuated once the rebels crossed into the Upper Peninsula. 

[1] Shorthand for National Guardsman
[2] The bases for Operation: Eagle’s Nest were all given code names with a farming theme, as their founders believed that they were symbolically farming and raising a New America like livestock
The Barn: A listening post on the north-western coast of Greenland, built in 1991 before the dissolution of NATO
The Nest: An entire underground city below Fairbanks, Alaska
The Coop: A series of compact but comfortable interconnected bunkers in Hawai’i
The Roost: Code name for the Cheyenne Mountain Complex in Colorado
The Yard: Originally built as a forward operating base for the invasion of Canada, refurbished into a seed vault. Located in Gwinn, Michigan. 

Document: The Shanghai Accords

The Shanghai Accords: A Treaty of Peace, Prosperity, and Mutual Respect between the United States of America, the People's Republic of China and the World
Authored jointly by President Richard M. Nixon and Chairman Chen Qiang
February 28, 1972 – Shanghai, China

Preamble
In recognition of the changing tides of history and the need for stability in an increasingly interconnected world, the United States of America and the People's Republic of China commit to a new era of peaceful coexistence, economic cooperation, and mutual prosperity.
This treaty is signed in the wake of historic transformation within the People's Republic of China, following the succession of Chairman Chen Qiang after the internal reorganization of the Chinese Communist Party in 1971. With the ideological turbulence of the past receding, both nations now look forward to a future built on trade, pragmatism, and respect.

Article I – Principles of Sovereignty and Non-Aggression
Both parties affirm the principle of mutual non-interference. The United States shall not pursue hegemony in the American Continents. The People’s Republic of China shall not pursue hegemony in the Pacific or Asia. 
Each nation recognizes the legitimacy and sovereignty of the other, and shall refrain from actions or rhetoric undermining internal stability.
Both governments agree to curtail hostile ideological campaigns against one another.

Article II – Diplomatic Normalization
The United States, and the rest of the United Nations, formally acknowledges the People's Republic of China as the sole legal government of China.
Liaison offices shall be established in Washington, D.C., and Beijing, with the goal of full diplomatic relations by 1973.
The status of Taiwan (Formosa) shall be resolved peacefully. The United States, and all future signatories, agree to reduce official engagements with the Taipei regime.
The People's Republic of China shall assume its seat at the United Nations Security Council, replacing the Taipei delegation.

Article III – Economic Cooperation and Trade of Essential Goods
Both nations commit to the free and affordable exchange of goods, with a focus on mass-produced consumer products, agricultural commodities, and industrial equipment.
The United Nations shall facilitate the import of Chinese goods, ensuring they remain accessible to the average consumer.
China shall import advanced agricultural, mechanical, and medical technologies from the United States to support its modernization efforts.
Both parties agree to remove tariffs entirely on either party's products. 
Joint trade councils will be established to regulate the flow of goods and ensure fair pricing.

Article IV – Cultural and Scientific Exchange
Programs will be launched to encourage exchange between scientists, engineers, students, artists, and cultural envoys.
Each nation shall open a cultural center in the capital city of the other to foster people-to-people understanding.
Academic and media professionals shall be granted access under mutual visa programs with minimal restrictions.

Article V – Military Restraint and Stability
Both parties shall avoid deploying military forces in provocative proximity to each other’s territories or spheres of influence.
China agrees to reduce its support of revolutionary movements abroad, in exchange for assurances of non-intervention by the United States in East Asian affairs.
Likewise, the United States agrees to reduce their intervention in the Americas.

Article VI – Long-Term Peace and Oversight
A permanent Sino-American Peace and Trade Commission shall be formed to oversee the implementation of this treaty.
The Commission shall convene biannually, alternating between locations in the U.S. and China.
This treaty shall remain in effect for a minimum of twenty years, with provisions for renewal or renegotiation thereafter.

Signatories
Signed this 28th day of February, 1972, in the city of Shanghai, symbolizing a new vision of global peace and mutual benefit.


Richard M. Nixon
President of the United States of America
 陈 强
Chen Qiang
Chairman of the People's Republic of China

Annex: Joint Statement
In forging this treaty, both nations have chosen the path of economic harmony over ideological confrontation. Let this be the beginning of a durable peace, grounded not in suspicion, but in shared opportunity — where American consumers and Chinese workers both find prosperity, and where nations with differences may still walk the road of peace, hand in hand.

BRUSSELS, BELGIUM, EURO. FEDERATION - The Federal Supreme Court decided in a ruling today that the provisions of the government of Italy’s Illegal Migration and Italian Security Act are a violation of federal law and must be revoked immediately lest the Italian premier be removed and new elections held. The ruling comes following a lengthy court battle between the Italian state government and the federal government of Europe, which claimed the new act (named above) were an overextension of state policy and breached the European Convention of Human Rights as well as federal Migration and Border Policy. The Italian government tried to argue that the provisions were technically within state power, but their argument was widely considered as weak and ineffectual, and was struck down today.

Italy’s Illegal Migration and Italian Security Act was signed on the 12th November 1998 by the premier of the Italian state government, who was narrowly elected in the 1998 local elections as part of a “black wave” for the far-right National European Front. The government has since taken a hardline approach on legal and illegal immigration to Italy, such as by deploying the local navy to turn around migrant boats and encouraging people to not shop at immigrant-owned stores. New provisions in the IMISA Act included launching a mass deportation program for refugees and encouraging the navy to sink migrant boats if they refused orders to turn around. The Italian government justified the act by claiming the immigrants are “stealing the jobs of ordinary, hardworking Italians” and said they will “spread radiation poisoning across the country”, a claim that has been criticised by experts. The act quickly proved controversial, as mass rioting from immigrants and leftist groups took over the cities of Italy for days before brutal suppression by the police, and far-right violence showed a rapid increase, leading to several deadly clashes between the different groups. The act received widespread condemnation by human rights groups and the federal government, who immediately challenged it and launched a court case against it.

The state government has yet to comment on the ruling, but officials have expressed their severe displeasure on it, as a spokesman commented, “the federal government is continuing to do all they can to stamp out local freedom and democracy”. MUNICH, GERMANY, EURO. FEDERATION - A brutal street fight in Munich last night between far-left and right groups led to a total of 37 dead, the final count shows. Severe drought in Andalusia continues for third year in a row

SEVILLE, SPAIN, EURO. FEDERATION - The city of Seville and the surrounding region of Andalusia has been suffering under a perpetual, record-breaking drought for the past three years ever since the “Black Summers” of 1997 and 98. The average precipitation amount has decreased by 40% since 1990’s “Hot Summer” and water supplies have ran dangerously low, causing agricultural yields to sharply drop and people to move out en masse. Cities such as Seville and Malága have been placed under strict water rationing, and these conditions show no sign of subsiding anytime soon.

The drought is unanimously believed to be caused by accelerating climate change, with the Federation’s Environmental Agency and UK’s Met Office announcing the world passed 2°C of warming since pre-industrial levels for the second time last year, and with the world only getting hotter. This has wreaked havoc on European and global agriculture, with large tracts of soil becoming unusable and workers dying out in the extreme heat. Areas such as Andalusia have adapted to these conditions by solely harvesting crops at night, which has reduced the mortality rate for farmers but has led to health problems among the workers. The lack of water has also made farming far more difficult, and many of the poorest have already left for cooler climates further north. Many scientists have voiced concerns of the issue of desertification, fearing that if temperatures continue their rapid rise, Andalusia and all of Southern Spain may turn to desert and become completely uninhabitable. It is rumoured that contingency measures are prepared for if a crisis point occurs, though not officially announced.

Next week, a member of the Federal Parliament and two members of Spain’s State Parliament will be heading to Seville to discuss these issues with members of the community and local government. Interlude
Utopia on the Vistula?
Poland 1975 - 2026
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rSktfVJc_IM or https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wChFEkCqt5s 

Excerpt from “The True History of Mad King Kowalski” by Marek Vytautas Orłowski, University of Warsaw, published in 972 ASJ

In the Early 1970s, Poland was experiencing rapid economic growth and large-scale revival of the previously stagnant RnD Sectors. Beforehand, the Bierut and Gomułka Governments had focused on rebuilding the country’s ruined public services and heavy industry - however, recognizing that the people work better when they’re not malnourished and pushed to the brink of revolt by poverty, General Secretary Edward Gierek (a name that would be passed down for Generations of Poles, for better or for worse) instead decided to invest large amount of taxpayer money into improving living standards (with utility items such as Televisions and Toasters being seen as status symbols to try and at least ape the prosperity of the West), while also not neglecting necessary social spending. Prices went down, wages went up, and even the State Controlled unions gave workers more leeway in terms of which strikes would be permitted (although the proletariat occasionally had to be reminded that the Party is never wrong - with the butt end of a Rifle). Where did Gierek and the rest of the PZPR (Polish United Workers’ Party) leadership get the funds for this Economic Bonanza? Why, with foreign loans, of course! And when people ask for you to pay them back? Just take more loans, maybe print some money if you’re feeling adventurous. While in another world, one with a worse economic situation, this could have gone wrong, the rampant spending in the West meant they remained hungry for more creditors and could turn a blind eye to any potential issues. After all, among the dwarves of the Eastern Bloc, Poland was, without a doubt, the tallest (with only Czechoslovakia, still trying to prevent another Prague Spring, hot on its tail) and could thus easily pay back any loans, right? 

Of course, to accompany the carrot there must always be a stick. The dreaded UB (Security Bureau, AKA Secret Police) ramped up their activity in the shadows, investigating any whisper of defiance both inside the Party and from illegal opposition outlets. And, with a bit of luck (and more than a few informers swayed by the promise of Western Goods) they managed to catch various ‘Anti-National Elements’, most notably Catholic Dissident Antoni Macierewicz alongside Independent Union Organizer and reformist Jacek Kuroń, nipping any sort of oppositionist activity in the bud and ensuring that the Party an the Party alone remained the monopolist of political power. 

Of course there were some hiccups. In 1978, John Paul II, the first Pole (and first Non-Italian in a few hundred years) became Pope. In light of this, to prevent his entire merry band from being dragged out of their mansions and onto the gallows, Gierek decided to allow some minor reforms, adopting a less hardline policy and giving the Church juuuust enough breathing room to make them think twice about any sort of opposition activity, while also underlining the fact it was to be LESS repressive, not Tolerant or anything near it. The Pope’s first pilgrimage did reinvigorate the Catholics of the country, but the Government’s tactical ceding of ground deprived the head of the church of an important part of his arsenal - sure, he could still call them out on their bullshit, but they did act relatively civilized (as much as one would expect from Communists). 

Another one happened in 1979, although the Party (in spite of their claims of being all seeing and all knowing thanks to a wide web of invigilation) remained unaware for years afterward. While the Poles’ desire for independence and sovereignty had been weakened by the common prosperity and token gestures of reconciliation, there were still some fire breathers who desired a Poland where the words ‘God, Honor, Fatherland’ were more than just words on paper, but law of the land. They congregated around former Communist turned radical nationalist Leszek Moczulski, and even at this early stage they contained a multitude of various internal factions, from Kraków Intellectual Socialists to Agrarian Populists from the Eastern Countryside to a handful of Nationalists who disagreed with Moczulski’s exact flavor of the ideology. For now, though, they remained a bunch of disgruntled and powerless politicians on the periphery, lacking means to influence the country’s direction. For now.

Poland’s age of opulence continued into the 1980s, with 1983 in particular being remembered as The Golden Year. Indeed, the ‘happiest barrack of the Eastern Bloc’ entered the Top 10 in the production of Coal, Steel and Sulfur, while falling just short in raw timber (much to the chagrin of the country’s small environmentalist communities). This was, of course, immediately the target of Propaganda, as the Government wished to paint themselves as the men who brought the once war torn and impoverished, rural central European Republic into now being among the great economic powers of the time.

With the pace of the economic reforms, Gierek decided to take a leap of faith and actually allowed for the expansion of private business (although under the oversight of the Communist Government). At the helm of one of Poland’s major companies was Samson, led by the then-young Marian of the Kowalski Family, although due to his family’s rather Anti-Communist leanings (his Grandfather having been a volunteer in the Polish-Soviet War of 1920, and his papa a major figure in the Anti-Communist Peasant Battalions of WW2) he was often sidelined by the Government in favor of other businesses. He remained undeterred, however, and remained the Polish People’s main producer of domestic ‘pleasure goods’ from steroids to bench presses to various types of ‘home-made’ candy. Having already helped operate a small private business before the Thaw, the Kowalski Family had the necessary experience and connections to make the most of the chance fate threw at their hands, quickly becoming a household name across the country.

In 1985, the ageing General Secretary decided it was best for him to retire and pave the way for younger figures to take his place. In spite of that wish, however, the Party overwhelmingly elected to give the reins of power to his barely-younger Second in Command Stanisław Kania - slightly more hardliner than his predecessor, but nevertheless dedicated to continuing the pace of Growth for the Polish Economy.

As history would prove, Old Edward got the hell out of Dodge right on time, as before long the Arab Israeli War would begin and the Earth’s long descent to hell would finally turn from a paved road to an express highway.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LBmUBMnuU2k

Naturally, Poland’s Industry was as energy intensive as ever, and thus near immediately began to struggle once the Red Decade started. At first, some in the Polish Politburo considered a ‘Special Operation’ to try and restore order to the Middle East (while also definitely placing themselves as the USSR’s loyal right hand men and thus potentially gaining valuable concessions) but were immediately discouraged following the publishing of the Jurasz Report. Witold Jurasz Senior was an expert Polish Diplomat, having been one of the last men to meet Alexander Kerensky alive (to try and coax him out of hiding) and acting as Poland’s Last Ambassador to Iraq when all hell broke loose. He would use his military experience to organize the Embassy Staff into a proper militia and fight their way out of the rapidly collapsing country, noting down everything he saw and, after reaching the Soviet Border, being escorted back to Warsaw where he presented his findings to Kania and his closest associates. The situation in the sandy republic was, to put it bluntly, apocalyptic - the sheer amount of ash blocked out sunlight for days at a time, and the burning oil fields gave what was once a bustling subcontinent a hellish, orange grow. Upon hearing of this, the Communist Leadership decided that, indeed, this wouldn’t be worth it.

As the Polish Economy began to decline and the long dreaded lines returned (alongside the rationing system, once abolished after the end of WW2), resistance once more began to spring up, although stunted by common propaganda promising a swift recovery if only the people shut up and kept their heads down. Some still refused to obey the Regime’s demands, and in late 1989 yet another secret meeting was held, this time in a freshly abandoned tire factory outside the city of Radom. Delegates from the Nationalist KPN (Still going strong), the Socialist ‘Revived Polish Socialist Democratic Party’ (Claiming to be the successors of the PPS that the Communists absorbed on their way to power back in the 1940s) and even the Anarchist Inter-city-niale gathered to try and iron out some sort of compromise. They succeeded, and on November 11th of that year (on the Independence Day that the Red Regime dreaded so much) proclaimed the Anti-System Opposition Congress (Kongres Opozycji Antyustrojowej) - a sort of Underground Government, where decisions were made by consensus in preparation for the inevitable collapse of the Communism across Europe. As time would prove, they’d have to wait quite a while.

Just a year later, though, they would get some hope - multiple figures in the Military decided that enough was enough. Kania’s plans to introduce more market elements in response to the crisis only made things worse, with massive  lines for basic products and even the expansive police state struggling to hold the line against tens of thousands of hungry protesters. In early February, Tanks would roll into Warsaw and other major cities, removing ‘unruly’ Government Officials and replacing them with loyal stooges. A Planned Economy would be reinstituted while, domestically, the state would pursue a more nationalistic approach, with some even postulating the rehabilitation of such notorious Anti-Communists as Marshal Józef Piłsudski and Foreign Minister Roman Dmowski as ‘well intentioned proletarian heroes’. While they didn’t go quite that far, the Polish Crisis necessitated reform to gain at least a semblance of domestic support in case Moscow (quite spooked by the potential setting of a precedent that yeah, the army can just waltz into the Capital and jail ruling communist elites if they feel like it) decided their ‘revolutionary brothers’ were acting up and needed a good spanking. In the end that didn’t happen, but the reforms stayed. For now.

Of course, the process didn’t go quite as smoothly as many aged commanders in the Polish People’s Army Envisioned. When Samson was re-nationalized Marian Kowalski, by now a bodybuilder, personally beat the Milicjant (Militia Officer) brought to arrest him to death before running for the hills. Eventually he would meet up with similarly unemployed former businessmen and their allies, forming their own small resistance movement - the name of which would be unfortunately lost to time. 

Unsurprisingly, the new Junta (mostly consisting of economically illiterate generalissimos) did not do any better at managing the state than their predecessors. The 1995 Ten Year Plan, meant to revive the domestic economy, end unemployment and decrease the crippling debt spiral the Government had found itself in, nearly immediately ran into problems - most notably corruption, with funds and construction materials going missing in the dead of night, never to be seen again. Apartment construction, the key to solving Poland’s overpopulation (which was already a problem beforehand, let alone now, with the ‘Golden Generation’ entering adulthood and seeking to have their own place to call home) was stifled by shoddy business practices and crippling incompetence. Nuclear Power expansion was approved (both to help fuel the struggling industries of yesteryear and to potentially, at some point in the future, allow for the Warsaw Regime to crack the secret of splitting the atom) but it too caused immeasurable problems to the rather inept class of ‘socialist people’s scientists’, with the project terminated before one of those dimwits had the chance to accidentally blow up the entire city. While that sort of accident never happened, another one did, putting yet another nail in the coffin of the ‘Eternal people’s salvation government’, 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5lPXrfNywHw

In 1997, Comrade Edward Gierek passed away, after over a decade in the shadows. While according to official records he died peacefully in his sleep, in reality his end was quite painful, all of the crap that had been placed in the air for the past quarter century making its way into his lungs and slowly turning the former Chairman into a living shell, incapable of any higher body functions. The State Funeral was as opulent as the Republic could afford for its ‘Greatest Revolutionary’ and ‘Man of the People’, with a short speech by the Generalissimo-Secretary himself planned to be at the start, alongside the singing of revolutionary classics and new songs (with the highlight being ‘An Ode to the Light Bringer’, a special tune written specifically in the memory of Gierek as part of a Government program to find use for the starving artists)... except things didn’t go as they should have.

Indeed, before the Generalissimo could even arrive, rouge reformist politician Marek Borowski, already marginalized inside the Party for his ‘Social-Fascist Degeneration’ took to the podium, flanked by his few remaining supporters, urging the people to rally and overthrow the brutal dictatorship that ‘disgraced our Leader’s legacy and sought to bring us back into the age of Bierut’. Before long the crowds got rowdy, and then riotous, with eyewitnesses reporting scenes not unlike those of the 1970 Workers’ Revolt - party committees were set alight, Milicja Officers ambushed and beaten within an inch of their lives, makeshift barricades erected. But alas, it was all for naught - before long the Junta realized what was going on and decided to begin their crackdown. Hundreds, perhaps even thousands of people died as Tanks began to shell through the packed streets, killing all souls unfortunate enough to be in their way, and Borowski’s body was never identified among the bloody sludge that had once been dozens of recognizable individuals. After a full week of radio silence from major media outlets (both the actual Radio as well as the collapsing TV Stations), the Government finally released a statement that ‘Anti-National Elements’ had been squashed, denouncing ‘foreign intervention in the affairs of the People’s Republic’. Behind closed doors, the Regime was forced to give more and more concessions to both the Milicja Obywatelska (Police) and its two offshoots (ORMO and ZOMO) regarding pay and holidays off, further stretching the already struggling budget thin. 

At least some of this money would be put to good use, as during a regular supply truck inspection multiple Policemen found the elderly Moczulski hiding in a box titled ‘Spare Parts’, being smuggled to a special session of the Anti-Opposition Congress. He was soon thrown in jail, and given a simple offer - rejoin the Party, and have KPN become a sort of ‘controlled opposition’ to PZPR, or die. He refused to dignify them with a response, and thus was publicly executed in Warsaw on an otherwise completely normal day. However, while this event was drummed up with much fanfare to try and discourage rebellion, it had the exact opposite effect - it killed whatever goodwill the Party had built up with Nationalists up to that point, making their efforts in vain and reinvigorating resistance. 

For the next half decade little of note happened. In 2004 Kowalski’ Resistance, suffering from a lack of supplies due to a handful unlucky fuck-ups related to weapon shipments, decided to join the Anti-Opposition Congress, with the man himself soon realizing just how big of an opportunity this was and using his expertise to expand the organization’s reach. Of course, some saw this generosity as a bit suspicious, but you don’t look a gift horse in the mouth, not when fighting the Communists.

In 2006 the Warsaw Pact, the dying beast that had kept the country chained to Moscow for decades, was finally put to rest, with the People’s Coalition formed in its stead. Of course, not everyone followed the charted course - Hungary, stuck as an agrarian society following a brutal civil war that devastated the country early in the decade, still insisted on shipping out every seed of grain even amid a brutal famine for the sake of international trade. There was a somewhat understandable reason for this - the devastated republic couldn’t afford to maintain its own industrial base, lacking expertise and resources, and thus had to rely on foreign imports to keep the basics of modern civilization functioning. To stop them would mean the possibility of another civil war, or outright societal collapse like in Bulgaria.

However, any excuse is good when you’re looking for one, and so, in mid 2008, the Polish Government authorized ‘Operation Brotherhood’, sending ‘peacekeeping forces’ to ‘protect our brother nation’ from ‘irresponsible governance’. A provisional Government was set up (with Slovakia conquered on the way), and while the vast majority of the populace was apathetic due to the decades of misery, a handful of communist hardliners (alongside the odd nationalist remnants which didn’t like the change from one foreign overlord to another) did decide to resist, with their insurgency causing hundreds of casualties and tons of unrest at home as veterans returned mutilated, in body bags, or worse - didn’t return at all.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3at2qjKuOpU

Eventually, the straw that broke the Camel’s back would prove to be, of all things, Alcohol. 
By 2009, much of the Government’s profits were through the sale of cheap booze back to their own populace. However, continued growth and the decline of the formerly fertile Lubelszczyzna region due to climate change and soil exhaustion, meant grain had to be reserved for only the staples of food such as bread. But even with cheap (and often, to put it bluntly, health hazardous) alternatives popping up, there simply wasn't enough alcohol to go around. As such, with a heavy heart, the elderly generalissimo addressed the people for what he did not yet know would be the last time, proclaiming, among some other nonsense lost to history, that beer rations would be cut. And then, all hell broke loose.

The people were fed up and flocked to the streets. Ironically, while the Police remained steadfastly loyal by the Government’s side, much of the UB decided to desert - not out of any idealistic desire for change, but because they too liked to get drunk, and also disliked being marginalized in favor of ‘stupid peasant cops’ (the inter service rivalry was very much alive, even after all those years). Before long the Anti Opposition Congress hijacked the whole thing, beginning the Beer Revolution, with Regime Loyalists hanged on lamppots and the elderly generals who drove the country into the ground finding themselves on the receiving end of the same torture they often dished out to dissidents and imagined traitors alike.

After the initial enthusiasm died down, the Congress sat down to try and iron out something resembling a proper constitution, with a set date for the first Presidential Elections since 1935 (technically 1947, if you were to give the Communists that much credit, or maybe even first free election since 1922 if you count voting infractions as invalidating). Whichever way you slide it and dice it, things soon went out of hand as everyone realized their interests no longer aligned, with KOA failing to mount a single nominee and de facto collapsing, with everyone going their own ways. The Anarchists, Socialists (with the Three PPS Successors finally unifying into one) and Christian Democrats (having reconciled the Oppositionist Christian Party with the former regime Satellite known as the Pax Association) all fielded their own nominees, while KPN held a congress to attempt and get back control over the situation. Before long things continued to deteriorate, with the Confederation’s line divided between the reformist camp under the relatively young Andrzej Mazurkiewicz and the old guard (staunchly dedicated to Moczulski’s principles, or at least their vision of what they are) under former partizan leader Adam Słomka (Nickname ‘Coal’). As both threatened to rip the movement asunder with their bickering, weeks went on with very little progress. Eventually, in a desperate bid to break the deadlock, Kowalski (by that point the richest man in Poland, not that money was worth much anymore, thanks to his ownership of re-privatized Samson, now mostly retooled toward wonder foods fueling the stomachs of average poles) stormed into the Congress Hall, proclaiming himself the nominee. Desperate to get some semblance of unity the delegates agreed to go along with this blant power grab, and Kowalski, with a platform of nationalism and somewhat vague populism (promising to ‘stop the thieves’ while also promoting privatization of certain non critical sectors of the economy) finished miles ahead of the other nominees, defeating them all in the first term. 

This victory meant he had quite the mandate to implement his desired changes. He had certain businesses ‘privatized’ (ie. taken from former Government Cronies and handed to his allies, who admittedly did at least know something about management), sent Maruzkiewicz off to Slovakia to manage the occupation (eventually admitting his former rival might be more than just an empty sounding brass, appointing him the Governor of all of Poland’s Southern Acquisitions) and subsequently pacified Słomka’s faction by stuffing the Government with friendly men he knew from his days as a Rebel Leader. Enraged, the KPN Dissidents demanded Parliamentary Elections (hoping to keep the President in check with the legislative - while it was far from the all-powerful beast it had been in the bygone Second Republic, it actually held influence as opposed to the rubber stamp of the communist era), to which the President agreed, also wishing to secure power over the Chamber.

The 2011 Polish Elections were overseen by a handful of observers (mostly from the Nordic Countries, alongside a single malnourished Englishman), and were deemed ‘free but not fair’, with the KPN (both factions) having an unfair advantage over the ‘official’ opposition thanks to their control of the Economy - any county that voted wrong was liable to be proclaimed ‘uninhabitable’, with locals sent to labor camps that were only different from concentration camps by the virtue of their name. That said, non-KPN Parties did make it into the Sejm (the only Chamber, as the Senate was never restored) - out of 401 MPs, 27 Represented the Polish Socialist Party, 17 the Christian Democratic Union and 5 the Free Peasant Movement (Representing Poland’s dying class of Yeoman farmers, already gutted by the Communist Era and now progressing desertification). There were also Two Anarchists (both found dead by suicide before their term was up) and a singular independent (who jumped ship to the Socialists in 2013).349 Seats should, logicaly, be a supermajority, but do not let that deceive you - Słomka pulled every string possible to get his men onto as many lists as he could, meaning he was the de facto puppetmater of the Sejm (even being elected as its Marshall, the de facto Presidential Right Hand Man barring the largely powerless Prime Minister) and thus made it his mission to constantly pester Kowalski about laws and then stonewall the legislative process if he wasn’t heard out. 

Such was life in Poland (now officially renamed the ‘Commonwealth’ by one of Kowalski’s first decrees, nullifying the old Communist Constitution of 1952), at least until 2013. Not that the common man would know, anyways. As Kowalski’s men were doing their best to try and (this time literally) clean up an old Communist Database to be used as an emergency food distribution center following a particularly bad drought in the Northern Regions of the country, they stumbled upon something disturbing. A plan, stretching back all the way to 1996, prepared by the old regime, detailing a three step program to turn human corpses (plentiful even back then) into food for the Poor. It was meant as a stopgap measure in times of War or Natural Disaster induced famine, but it horrified the crew nevertheless and they soon relayed the news higher up in the chain of command, all the way until it reached Kowalski himself. While disgusted, he did begrudgingly see a bit of potential use should (when) shit hit the fan, and quietly shelved it. The Four Man Clean-up crew would not live to see the Great Death - one was killed in a food riot in 2019 and the other three committed suicide (wheather they did the deed on their own accord or with some ‘encouragment’ from Policemen remains a mystery for all time).

For all this time, refugees had been flooding from the anarchic mess once known as the Southern Balkans into Polish Hungary. Initially the local government welcomed this extra workforce, but before long the Governor realized even the last fertile lands in central Europe simply didn’t have enough to feed them all, not even on near-starvation rations which made Death Camp food look like luxury delicacies. Under increasing pressure from both loyalists and oppositionists in KPN (alongside members of the Public) the President would order the creation of a massive border wall on what was once the hinterlands of Hungary, sealing it (and, as an extension, the rest of the ‘Empire of the Eagle’ as one Nordic satirist called it) from the endless waves of human beings. Before long it would be extended to also prevent Bulgarians and Greeks from thumping through the corpse of Romania and going around. As local civil wars degenerated into warlord eras and, later, total anarchy, this was increasingly seen as the right choice even among the few surviving members of the Polish Opposition. 

Thanks to the agenda of ‘helping keep the borders safe’, Kowalski would receive a popularity boost and triumph in the 2015 Presidential Election, winning an overwhelming majority of the vote (in no small part thanks to the allegations of vote rigging), defeating moderate LIberal-Conservative Witold Jurasz (Junior, who had little of his father’s political skills and mostly wished to help preserve whatever historic documents remained in the country with token foreign cooperation, running as a matter of principle) and a bunch of unrecognized anarchists without ballot access.

In the concurrently held Parliamentary Elections, KPN theoretically only lost 2 seats, but in reality saw a massive realignment as Słomka’s allies were expelled and replaced with either harmless economic wonks or staunch Kowalski Loyalists.

The Berlin Warsaw Axis was also formed.

In 2016, Kowalski took one final look at the Polish Internal Defense apparatus and was disappointed in what he saw - in spite of their large budgets and lack of any real red tape, Polish Law Enforcement had been failing in their fight against the tide of crime rapidly spilling into the country from the West and South. Corruption and communist influences were also cited. Seeing all of this he would reform the old Milicja, ZOMO, ORMO and UB into two groups - firstly the Pre-War Policja (Police) would be restored, with the usual hoodlum hunting duties, while all the nitty gritty assassinations and ‘fine’ investigations (costly ones, with DNA and shit) would be handed over to the newly formed ‘Centralne Biuro Bezpieczeństwa Publicznego’ (Central Bureau of Public Safety, CBBP), which was basically the same thing but staffed with Anti-Communists as opposed to communists (with the last surviving Reds often turned into Ration Omega and shipped abroad, usually to Africa or China in exchange for whatever ancient replacement parts they could offer to keep the moribound Polish Economy afloat) and all the major positions filled with men loyal to the President first and everything else second. 

In 2019 an useless Election was held where no seats were exchanged compared to 2015, with only a single Socialist MP who died of old age replaced by a colleague. 

In 2023 Kowalski decided to follow the scrap of paper he hand wrote called the Constitution, sticking to the two term limit while endorsing MP and former ‘Commissar’ (Appointed Official replacing a mayor) Andrzej Pruszkowski, a fellow ‘Lubelak’ and Partizan (although he was mostly on logistical duty for his ten years in the bush), who subsequently won in a landslide. In reality, of course, Kowalski remained the real power behind the throne - not as Prime Minister, nor as Marshall of the Sejm, but as Minister of the Interior. 

Two years later, the Polish intelligence service discovered that the Soviets were doing something… off. There was a significant realignment in troop numbers, large scale construction projects, human resettlement that seemed actually planned and not like spontaneous waves of refugees. It was clear the Bolsheviks were planning for… something, but just what eluded the Poles - they had no contacts left inside the ‘Home of the Global proletariat’ and there was only so much scouting from a distance could achieve. Against their better judgement, they handed this information to their ‘allies’ in the Greater German Democratic Republic, who promptly ignored it - some saw it as misinformation by the ‘fake aryans’, others saw it as just more posturing from the ‘idiot slavs’ in Moscow, all agreed it was probably nothing to worry about.

The Last Polish Parliamentary Elections (snap elections to be exact) were also held this year to elect members of the 5th Sejm. Nobody bothered to observe them anymore, but had anyone tried to, they would have found them neither free nor fair. The KPN won all but one seat in Sejm (with said brave independent being Słomka Himself, having left the party due to its ‘betrayal of the martyr Moczulski’s vision’ and fighting off three separate assasination attempts on the campaign trail), with this sharp turn towards authoritarianism mostly blamed on Kowalski’s increasing descent into madness. Obsessed over what the Reds could be plotting, heavily suspecting it was some variation of dragging Central European ‘traitors’ down to hell before the impending ecological collapse, he began construction of large scale bunker complexes (or at least as large as the country’s remaining industries allowed), storing people, supplies and priceless historical artifacts alike [1] to try and get them through whatever was going to come. They were placed at large distances from one another, to ensure that whatever that plan was (flooding, open war, drought or plague) at least one would survive… which also made contact between them hellishly hard should the ancient communication equipment give out. But that part must have been skipped in the planning process.

Just a year later the Polish-Nordic War would break out. While in theory over a fishing dispute, that was but a lousy excuse - there were very few fish left in the Baltic, certainly not enough to wage such a conflict over. No, in reality the Poles managed to capture an advanced Nordic Nuclear Submarine which beached on their shores, soon executing the crew and taking it for themselves, responding to Stockholm’s demands of giving it back by telling them to shove a finger up their arse. As such, the two states went to war, which was still ongoing at the time of the Great Death - while the Nordic Navies were far better than the meager rust buckets the Poles could field, the Pomeranian Coastline had been turned into a massive death trap, with any landing (or even plans at landing) little more than pipe dreams (or perhaps a very elaborate way of suicide). 

[1] After the Great Death, myths regarding the ‘Mad King Kowalski’s Treasure’ remained alive for generations, with adventurers from across the continent searching (often outside what was even considered Polish territory) for it in every building which as much as had a section of it located underground. This often resulted in them triggering ‘revenge weapons’ or causing the ancient structures to crumble under their own weight, most notably in the Warsaw Metro, where a clueless treasure hunter’s dynamiting of a wall to clear a path to what he was sure was the vault (in reality merely a disused service tunnel) caused multiple stations to collapse, killing seventy people and displacing a large amount of the survivor community, triggering a refugee crisis that later escalated into civil wars, overpopulation, plague and general chaos.

Interlude
The Argentine Sun, the Two Césars and la gran última Siesta
Section 1: Central America

The Monterrey “Quetzalcoatl” Superfactory, built during the height of Mexican industry. Photographed in 1987
Mexico

(Flag credit)
Official name: United States of Mexico/Estados Unidos Mexicanos (until 1995), Federation of Socialist Mexican States/Federación de Estados Socialistas Mexicanos (1995-2027) 
Capital: Mexico City
Government Type: Presidential Republic (until 2006), Far-Left Military Junta (2006-2027)
Population as of final census conducted: 241,528,255 (Circa 2000)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 192,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $2.816 Trillion USD
Primary Language: Mexican Spanish (Español Mexicano)
Member of the Alliance of Nations: YES (as of 13 March, 1996)
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (Until 1995), COMECON (1995-2008)
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

While Mexico didn’t reach the same dizzying heights of industry as China, or even the USSR, they were notable for being the most industrialized country in the Americas during the Glorious Decades. A lack of economic uncertainty kept the Mexican Economy booming and avoided any financial crisis in the 1970s and 1980s. 

Mexico was essential to Chen’s plans in the Americas, and as such, when the 1985 earthquake hit Mexico City, he led the charge in assembling an international team to aid the Mexican government and rebuild the city. It was estimated that 2,500-20,000 people were killed as a result of the damage, with almost 15,000 injured. Cuban doctors were flown in to care for the wounded, huge fundraisers were held in New York City, and China signed a very generous loan with Mexico to help rebuild the city and its industry. Even the USSR sent one million loaves of bread in solidarity. The United States helped pay for the rebuilding of entire apartment blocks, in exchange for assurances of a Mexican-American Oil Pipeline. Things were looking up for Mexico. 

Until they weren’t. 

Any hope at a full recovery was shattered when the last Sinai War turned into the first nuclear conflict in history. At first, the conservative PRI government saw this as a boon: Mexico was soon one of the top oil producers in the world. They assured their people that this was just a temporary blip in Mexico’s history, and that the oil boom would actually make Mexico even richer. 

The PRI’s Presidential Candidate, Marcos Juárez Huerta, narrowly won the Presidency in July 1988. Despite industry collapsing all over the world and tourism evaporating, the government continued business as usual. While Mexico’s economy was not hit hard initially, by November 1988 it was clear that President Franklin King was not winning re-election. President-Elect Graves platformed on a campaign of strict protectionism, as the United States had an 18.9% unemployment rate compared to Mexico’s 5.6%. 

Despite Mexico’s oil boom, demand for their other products were rapidly declining. By Christmas of 1988, factories were forced to lay off workers before closing down themselves. In 1989, this led to further economic troubles when President Graves implemented sweeping tariffs against many countries, including Mexico. Mexico was not alone in their frustration, however, as South Korea’s anti-American sentiment turned violent. This would lead to a group of far-left Mexican nationalists to bomb the Mexican-American Oil Pipeline on May 5th, 1989. The Cinco de Mayo Bombing[1] resulted in relations between Mexico and America breaking down, with the Democratic majority passing a bill that included tariffs against Mexico that expired in 2029. Huerta’s government remained optimistic that both sides could come to an agreement.

Both Mexico and the United States would cease to exist by 2029, however. 

Negotiations were met with shouting matches, and while the PRI never outright tariffed American goods back, there was a massive boycott of American-grown corn and soybeans. This led to a number of farms, which were relying on trade with Mexico to keep their businesses above the red line, finally going under. 

In the summer of 1989, while the anti-American sentiment hadn’t quite gotten to South Korean standards, a massive riot in Mexico City on June 8th, 1989 led to 14 deaths and over 100 casualties, not to mention almost a billion pesos of property damage. Mexico City was temporarily placed under martial law, and the government began to throw away money to the police forces, but the restrictions were never lifted. 

An unfortunate side effect of the Mexico City Riots of 1989 was that the Governor of Tabasco, Raul Juan Hernandez, was injured. He was simply at the wrong place at the wrong time, buying a pack of cigarettes before being strung up to a lamppost by the enraged mob of unemployed. His bodyguards managed to get him down in time before he died, but as he was rushed to the Chen Qiang Memorial Hospital he slipped into a coma due to oxygen deprivation and was pronounced dead on July 2nd, 1989. 

This forced the government of Tabasco to run an emergency snap election. Edmundo Ernesto Gutiérrez, the Deputy of Federal District 2, ended up winning the governorship in a landslide. Gutiérrez was elected in 1985, running on a campaign of social security and welfare after the chaos of the 1985 earthquake. He was the only member of the PRD that was elected in 1985, and won practically unopposed in 1988. With the governorship, he expanded his social programs tenfold. Using the leftover profits of the oil boom, Gutiérrez created a state-wide universal basic income and subsidized public transportation for the entire state. However, this caused citizens from all over the country to flock to Tabasco, quickly bloating it to be the second most populous state in Mexico, behind Mexico City itself. 

Gutiérrez began campaigning around the country to establish a safety net of social welfare for Mexican citizens. To deal with the deficit of American agricultural products, Gutiérrez championed an agricultural revival and nationalizing the entire oil industry, nationwide. 

His policies were put to the test when the Hot Summer of 1990 ravaged Mexico and the world. People from the northern states flocked to the metropolises in central Mexico. Soon, only 10% of Mexico’s population lived north of Mexico City. Tariffs and a sharp decline of oil demand caused the rest of the Mexican economy to enter freefall. Things weren’t as bad as in the USA, not yet, as Mexico still had much of its industrial base and slowly began to shift to a command economy. States across the country began adopting policies similar to Gutiérrez’s, and oil began to be prioritized for transporting essential goods. Unemployment started to skyrocket, reaching 22% by the end of 1990. The federal government, meanwhile, downplayed the economic crisis and claimed yet again that this was only temporary and that they were working closely with President Graves to reopen trade between the two countries. 

On January 8th, 1991, President Huerta and President Graves had their first bilateral conference since the Cinco de Mayo Bombing of 1989. The conference started with a calm, peaceful atmosphere of cooperation, but devolved into a one-sided shouting match when President Graves said that he was elected to help America, not Mexico, and that for the foreseeable future that was where his priorities lay. Either due to a mistranslation, or culture shock, the two Presidents almost engaged in an altercation until they were both separated from each other by their relevant security details. As Graves was escorted out of the building, he threatened war with Mexico, but backed down immediately upon returning to Washington, D.C. 

This dealt a massive blow to PRI’s public image, and Huerta’s approval rating dropped significantly. In an attempt to stimulate the economy and mitigate the damage of the Hot Summer, he passed several tax cuts. Ultimately, though, many of the largest companies in Mexico had to lay off waves of workers. 

In the 90s, throughout the energy shortages, unemployment and industrial decay, organized crime began to emerge on the fringes of society. Cartels, gangs, and smugglers started to appear quietly in many cities across the northern states, in small pockets of anarchy that had sprung up from the resulting migration (and reallocation of federal and state resources). The UN’s power was crumbling, and their Anti-Drug Task Force was more of a list of guidelines rather than the powerful force it had been during the 1970s and 1980s. Cocaine and marijuana dealers began popping up left and right, and other organized crimes like bank robbery and racketeering were becoming extremely common. In the north, small towns that had been abandoned by companies became arteries in the heart of the Mexican underbelly. Desperate people, willing to do anything to make money and keep themselves fed, started taking under the table jobs and knowingly began to help the cartels. Others, driven to a state of hopelessness, began using the drugs themselves. 

As legitimate jobs began drying up, gangs and cartels began controlling entire towns in the north. This was noticed by the government, of course, and the Huerta government began to use it as a talking point to distract from the growing poverty. The federal forces made exaggerated spectacles of capturing lowly crooks and bombastic drug busts, attempting to invoke the might of the UNADTF. While they were successful from a tactical standpoint, it only drove the cartels further underground. 

As the 1994 Election approached, the PRI desperately tried to appeal to the nostalgia of the wealth and prosperity Mexico had seen during the Glorious Decades. Their candidate was described as dull, boring, and by-the-books. It was no surprise that the PRD, who paraded Gutiérrez around like a saint, pushed him forward for the presidency. Famines in 1993 and 1994 only pushed public support further to the left, and in 1994, the PRD won in a landslide, gaining the governorship of 29 states, control of Congress, and Gutiérrez himself became president. 

In an era now referred to as the “Fourth Transformation”, President Gutiérrez, now commonly referred to as the “Titan of Tabasco”, dramatically reformed the country and implemented sweeping reforms that made Graves’s policies look moderate. Every single industry was nationalized, forming a country-wide universal basic income, and a ration system similar to America’s was created. Anti-corruption committees started redistributing land to poor farmers, and the largest business magnates had their assets frozen and seized. Housing programs began constructing large settlements for those displaced by the growing heatwaves. Those that resisted giving up their land were branded as enemies of the Mexican people, and mostly fled to the north where they attempted to seek passage into the United States. 

The fact that many cartels started to become unusually more organized, and started to use old government gear, is merely a coincidence. 

On February 1st, 1995, President Gutiérrez officially renamed Mexico to the Federation of Socialist Mexican States, and formally cut ties with the United States and their Alliance of Industrial Nations, instead joining the USSR’s COMECON. February 1st became a statutory holiday, and a new flag was unveiled in March.
