Mexico’s GDP actually began to very slowly increase from 1995-2000, though if this was a result of the black market or Gutiérrez’s policies is unknown. 

In 1996, Mexico joined the Alliance of Nations and also created the “empresa nacional de alimentos”, or the “National Food Company”. The NFC was created to help coordinate government resources to prevent major famines, and used an irrigation system similar to the USSR. The last of Mexico’s oil reserves were used to power farming equipment and trucks to transport the food. This prevented any major famines for the rest of the 90s, but just barely. For a while, Mexico’s main problem was not climate change or food, but a growing amount of disillusioned unemployed who became easy targets for the Cartels. 

In the depopulated north, backdoor deals between corrupt politicians and cartel members resulted in the cartel’s power rapidly expanding. Entire cities became controlled by cartels in all but name, and a lucrative black market sprung up. For those who knew what they were looking for, they could find just about anything the corrupt politicians wanted: rare delicacies from the Glorious Decades, clothing from any country, and even prostitutes that catered to every taste, not to mention the abundant designer drugs and military surplus. It was said that a broker in Todos Santos could even get nuclear weapons. 

Throughout 1996 and 1997, Vice President Smith and later President Smith tried to undo the divide between the United States and the now openly socialist Mexico. President Gutiérrez never acquiesced, instead slyly replying that he was elected to serve Mexico, not the United States. Smith gave up by 1998. 

In 1999, to deal with the rising number of youth joining gangs and cartels, President Gutiérrez began investigating the cartel activity in the north. This would lead to the creation of the “Mexican People’s Army”, a federal militia that served as the vanguard against rising crime. Recruits were promised a pension and stable pay, but most simply joined for the food and shelter. Throughout the end of Gutiérrez’s presidency, the MPA conducted several operations against the cartels. Some cartels were wiped out, but most of them resisted and held out against the MPA’s minimally trained army. 

As Mexico entered the 21st Century, a new problem arose: immigration. Much of Latin America was in chaos, with civil war and anarchy running rampant as far south as Bolivia. Millions of refugees fled north, seeking the relative stability that Mexico and the United States offered. Mexico began to actually see groups of African Americans flee into Mexico, escaping from brutally violent Klansmen. This immigration crisis led to further corruption, instability and resource shortages, and became a primary talking point in the 2000 Election. 

The far-left candidate for the PRD, Alejandro Ortega Ruiz, won in a landslide, though not quite to the same level as his predecessor. He campaigned on “making Mexico for the Mexicans” and regulating immigration, but also emphasized that Mexico’s next task would be to tackle the corruption and crime that the Cartels were causing. 

In 2001, Mexico would pass an anti-immigration law, and then throughout the early 2000s President Ruiz led the Mexican military in several operations against cartels in the north and the southeast. The budgets of municipal police forces were bloated to the extreme, and the Mexico City Police Department waged a brutal war to eradicate a number of gangs. After a gang-induced riot in 2001, police departments across the country began heavily militarizing, and in places with little federal control, groups of vigilantes began to organize and defend their communities from criminals. In many cases though, the leaders of these vigilante groups gradually grew an ego and started to enact their own versions of “mob justice”, becoming a gang in all but name. These were put down by squads of the MPA, and in the far north, the Vigilantes and Cartels openly fought a war without any pretext of supposed justice. 

The largest of these vigilante mobs resulted in the Tuxtla Gutiérrez Massacre of 2002. Over 50 immigrants were strung up and hung in makeshift gallows before the MPA intervened, using the same gallows to hang the four leaders of the vigilantes. 

People fleeing from the heat, drought, desertification, political violence and crime ended up settling in Mexico City, which had a population of 25 million as of the 2000 census. In the greater Mexico City metropolitan area, the population was estimated to be 46.7 million. The amount of people crammed into such a small area caused an enormous strain on resources, with plumbing constantly breaking down and water being rationed during the summer months. Outbreaks of disease resulted in entire districts being quarantined, and as resources became scarcer, the elderly and terminally ill began to be abandoned and left to their fates. 

In the mid 2000s, envoys from China arrived. These civic engineers and technicians worked with President Ruiz to momentarily help revitalize the Mexican economy, and they worked together to build vast apartment blocks for the growing number of displaced migrants. Many in Ruiz’s government would remain skeptical of China, however, and some states opted to not let the Chinese into their borders at all. 

In 2004, many in the country, including the highest members of the government and military, began to grow dissatisfied with the way President Ruiz was handling the country. The cartels were gaining more and more ground, and suddenly were seen equipped with surplus Chinese weaponry. This culminated in the Battle of Durango, in which an entire battalion of the MPA was forced to surrender to the Los Ganchos Cartel. With that, high-ranking members of the Mexican military began plotting a coup. 

President Ruiz was largely criticized for how his government handled Hurricane Wilson. Instead of diverting resources to help the devastated coast, Ruiz funneled yet more money into the armed forces and launched several concurrent campaigns all over the country against cartels and gangs alike. Desertions were common, and many soldiers left their posts to see if their families were part of the 50,000 casualties in the Gulf of Mexico. Ruiz then ordered an invasion of Belize by sending “peacekeeping” forces to help spread Mexican Socialism there. 

By March of 2006, civil unrest was at an all-time high as protesters and riots began sweeping the nation in response to Ruiz’s actions. There was no 2006 Election - in April that year, General Ricardo López Valdez of the Mexican Army launched a coup against President Ruiz and established a military Junta in Mexico City. Forces loyal to Ruiz fled to Honduras and Belize, and members of the MPA were diverted to chase them down. Valdez took control of the press and began to suppress the flow of information, notably the numerous losses that the MPA was suffering in the north against Cartels. By 2007, the states bordering the USA were controlled entirely by cartels, and entire neighborhoods in Mexico City were quarantined due to the Red Flu, only to be controlled by gangsters in the aftermath. 

Valdez’s government would end up being no better than Ruiz’s. Members of the government began defecting to cartels and corruption spread far and wide. In parts of the south, cities changed hands daily, becoming battle grounds between innumerable gangs and cartels, many of which died out within a year. Valdez became increasingly imperialistic, launching invasions of Nicuraga and Guatemala. 

By 2010, most of the territory north of Mexico City was under complete control of various cartels, gangs, and bandits, with vast stretches of land in anarchy. The temperature there had gotten so bad that many were nocturnal, and in areas where the cartels had complete control, they worked their slaves to the bone in plantations similar to Food, Inc’s superfarms. South of Mexico City, the MPA pillaged Central America and fought constant battles against rebels and cartels. Throughout Latin America, a growing sense of despair and dread dominated those who were caught in the crossfire. Many took to joining a side and embracing the violence, while others slipped into drug-induced wonderlands fueled by Bromista, the designer superdrug that was sweeping the world. 

The Purple Summer of 2011 forced the fanatical MPA to pull out of Honduras and Nicaragua. Famine swept the globe, and Mexico was no different. Unconfirmed reports of cannibalism in the countryside were suppressed by Valdez’s propaganda machine. In the aftermath, when the country stabilized in early 2012, Valdez was forced to declare martial law throughout the country after he was nearly assassinated by an IED. Civil unrest in Central Mexico exploded, with farmers and workers rising up before being beaten down by the MPA. People began to disappear, with the official explanation (if one was given at all) always being “suspected collaboration with cartels”. 

As a result of the attempted assassination, Valdez became deeply paranoid, pulling out of Belize and focusing on testing the loyalty of his men. Occupied Belize collapsed into a civil war between those who collaborated with the MPA, PRD and Valdez, and rebels who were suspected to be backed by cartels. The cartels that remained were extremely ruthless and barbaric, and as they spread chaos, millions fled the country. Some would even brave the ungodly heat and go into the USA, leading to the El Paso Massacre of 2013. 

The numerous gangs and cartels begin to fracture due to fanaticism and greed, turning the north into a lawless wasteland bereft of any semblance of order. Bandits robbed other bandits, slaves were worked to death in the scorching heat, and raving cannibals, driven mad with drug use, roamed the deserts and ate anyone they saw. In the south, the chaos was a bit more organized, with cartels taking over the blasted wasteland of Central America that had been nearly burnt to the ground by the MPA. 

After the Great Heatwave of 2015, the cartels became the dominant force in Latin America. Millions willingly lost themselves in “la Gran Siesta”, a euphemism for the intense hallucinations Bromista caused. By 2016, outside of a few places loyal to Valdez, south Mexico was entirely divided up between various cartels, using Bromista to forge an uneasy peace. Many towns were turned into cartel superfarms, their workers kept in a state of drug-induced bliss before dying of malnutrition, disease or overdose. To save on operating costs, many of the cartels began to feed their workers the remains of the fellows, and those that woke up from the nightmare usually ended their lives. 

Valdez and the MPA, who controlled only the Mexico City metro area and a number of collectivized farms in Central Mexico, were mainly left alone by the cartels, who believed that he was no longer worth the trouble. The leaders of the cartels lived like kings, their opulence granted by the drug-induced work force of a hundred million slaves. To recoup their losses after the Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2016, various cartels take over almost all of Central America. 

In 2018, the Jarret Administration authorized the destabilization of the cartels, shattering their loose confederacy. Soon, drug-fueled berserkers raged across plantations and Latin America became a bloodbath once again. Entire cartels were wiped out, while slaves launched uprisings that birthed new cartels and gangs to take their place. Valdez’s junta actually gained more power, as the infighting allowed them to “liberate” numerous states in southern Mexico. In the north, the heat had gotten so bad that even the cartels abandoned their night operations there, retreating to the tip of Baja California Sur and occupied Guatemala. Apocalyptic sandstorms shredded entire cities, and drought killed more people than violence. 

By 2020, everyone in Mexico was either a violent soldier or a bromista-addicted slave. Valdez was darkly paranoid, regularly going entire days without sleep for fear of being killed. As food supplies dwindled, he authorized the recycling of “agitators” into food. Drugs were so ubiquitous that even Mexico City was one step away from being cartel controlled. Pacificing chemicals were mixed into the rations, made of the people, for the people. Entire communities disappeared, never to be seen again, and soon no one in Mexico City starved. 

The chemicals led to many unexpected side effects. People began flying into fits of rage or bouts of uncontrollable mania. Violent crime exploded, with rapes, arson, and mutilation becoming everyday occurrences. The perpetrators were always caught, and then turned into more of the “wonder ration”, and the cycle continued. The crimes escalated to suicide bombings and the mass poisoning of water lines, and finally, an armoy was raided. In 2021, during the apex of the insanity, Valdez was killed by a frenzied MPA soldier when an incendiary explosive was detonated in his palace in Mexico City. 

Those in his inner circle, who while not drugged out of their mind were still violently sadistic. However, they were shaken to their core when they realized what was truly happening, and in that moment, it was like they woke up from the Bromista nightmare. An uprising spread through the city, and many chose to burn it all to the ground in one last party - la gran última fiesta. Millions died in that orgy of violence and fire, but it was not the end of the Mexican people, or even the MPA. There were still some who had the will to live, and there were some in the MPA who still had a conscience and believed in its cause. They led their people north, traveling by night and eating sparingly (the excessive violence had actually caused a slight increase in vegetable rations). 

Many did not survive the trek through the Chihuahuan wasteland, and those that did were captured by cartel members, killed by the American militias during the Night War of 2021, or simply lost the will to live and let the heat take them. 

In the end, all that went north died. 

Over the next five years, countless revolutionaries and dictators tried to take over the crumbling, burning remains of the Mexican Junta. Some were tyrants, and some were traitors who worked with the cartels, but none of them were able to establish the same level of control that Valdez had. The biggest, most ruthless cartels had conquered their rivals, with various groups controlling all of Central America south of the ruins of the Mexico City metro area. Out of fear, they left the other cartels alone, and were content to rule their own little drug-controlled fiefdoms. However, the Second Great Heatwave of 2023 fractured that tenuous peace. Even the most elite members of the cartels began to experience the effects of the rapidly deteriorating climate, and soon most of Central America was ravaged by storm after storm. 

Yet in spite of the hellish place the world had become, there were still those who held out hope and believed in a cause. On February 1st, 2027, outside the town of Chapata, a captain of the MPA would successfully use poison to wipe out the largest gang in Central Mexico, and began an operation to retake Mexico City. He would not be the first, but he would be the only one to do so with the goal of genuinely trying to improve the lives of its citizens. His charisma began to inspire those around him, and the spark to live again reignited in Mexico City. Captain Gonzales, as he was called, began to expand into the ruined husks of the northern cartels. 

On June 14th, 2027, Captain Gonzales would watch from the ruins of Naucalpan de Juárez as Mexico City was destroyed in a mushroom cloud. 

Guatemala

Official name: Republic of Guatemala/República de Guatemala, People’s Republic of Guatemala/República Popular de Guatemala (Disputed)
Capital: Guatemala City (de jure, until 1992), Flores (de facto, 1992-2010)
Government Type: Presidential Republic (de jure, 1978-1992), Far-Right Military Dictatorship (de facto, 1992-2010)
Population as of final census conducted: 28,954,243 (Circa 2000)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 25,900,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $7.426 Billion USD
Primary Language: Guatemalan Spanish (Español guatemalteco)
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: World Prosperity Organization (Until 1992)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

In 1973, the Guatemalan Civil War ground to a halt when Cuba suddenly withdrew their support for the rebels. Backdoor negotiations between Secretary Agassi and Fidel Castro redirected the Second World to a possible world war with China, and as such, the progress of socialism would have to be directed by the workers alone. 

The US-China Peace Commission, headed by Chairman Chen and President Nixon, began mediating a peace between the Guatemalan government and the Guerilla Army of the Poor. Throughout 1973 and 1974, negotiations were reached and the department of Quiche was to be turned into a fully autonomous zone, ruled by the indigenous Maya. 

The peace efforts were half-hearted, though, and in 1975 ethnic violence broke out once again. After the Massacre of Cobán in 1976, the United Nations authorized a peacekeeping mission into Guatemala. Operation: Azure Stars resulted in the US-backed regime being destroyed, and the United Nations established an interim government. Throughout 1977 and 1978, members of the old regime were put on trial, and while many of them blamed the USA and members of the CIA, ultimately all the evidence was circumstantial and the USA got away with little more than a slap on the wrist and a promise to subsidize the rebuilding of Guatemala. 

Enrique Serrano, the UN’s interim leader, won the presidency in 1978 and pledged closer ties with both the United States, Mexico, and China. In 1979, Guatemala would join the World Prosperity Organization and over the next couple of years China would help design and build several industrial megafactories, mainly concentrated around the northern autonomous zone of Quiche. 

In 1984, the new president, Luis Arana, started to force ethnic minorities to work in factories, much like how China was doing with their minorities. This caused ethnic tension to build up, but for most of the country, they are fine with it as it means dirt cheap goods and a skyrocketing economy. Guatemala sent convicts to help rebuild Mexico City after the earthquake of 1985, and resulted in a very close relationship between the two countries. 

Like many countries, it all came crashing down in the aftermath of the last Sinai War of 1988. Many companies in both the USA and Mexico were reluctant to do trade with Guatemala, and despite neither country officially tariffing Guatemala until the 90s, things got bad very fast. The USSR reimplemented the Brezhnev policy and Cuba began supplying the rebels once again. Guatemala entered another civil war, though there were some who said that it was just the second chapter of the original war from the 1960s. 

In 1989, President Arana was forced to declare martial law after mass civil unrest, as a result of food shortages, energy shortages and unemployment causing enormous demonstrations in major cities around the country, destabilizing the few businesses still functioning. 

In Guatemala, the Hot Summer of 1990 was called so as not just the environment went hot, but the civil war as well. Cuban-supplied rebels bombed factories across the nation, crippling the economy and sending so much smoke into the air that for two weeks in June, smoke covered the skies of much of Central America. Rationing was implemented, and all the chaos was blamed on Mayan rebels and their Belizean sympathizers. 

With the UK clearly dealing with their own problems, President Arana, who was now President-for-Life after an emergency law was passed, decided to invade Belize. Using wartime conditions, he was allowed to exert even more control over his citizens. Unsurprisingly though, this caused the rebel numbers to swell as many believed that he was nothing more than a dictator at this point. The wealth that their compliance had won them had dried up, and now everyone was poor and suffering together. 

As the civil war escalated, the government forces were kicked out of Guatemala City on February 7, 1992 by the rebel army, now called the Popular Front of Guatemala. Guatemala essentially was split in two: the north was a crumbling industrial society loyal to the government, and in the south, was an agrarian ethnostate that regularly executed European hispanics. After it became clear that the Popular Front of Guatemala was operating purely on ethnic lines and not trying to create socialism in their country, support from Cuba and the USSR dried up. 

Both sides of Guatemala fractured during the 90s, with the northern forces splintering into several industrial city states, and the southern forces turning into ethnically based anarchic communes. President Arana was killed by one of his generals in 1993, and after that the only thing that united the north was their hatred for the south. Conversely, the myriad of communes were only united in their hatred for those who had tried to work them to death in the 1980s. 

By the late 90s, things had stabilized into an uneasy peace as climate change, drought and famine were becoming more pressing concerns rather than unifying the country under one flag. The coasts were regularly flooded, and in the north, several industrial accidents caused wildfires to burn out entire forests and crop fields. 

When China arrived in the 21st Century, they propped up the struggling remnants of the central government in the north, and retooled their factories to dramatically increase their yield (and carbon emissions). The General of Flores used their new industrial might to conquer the rest of the squabbling north and united them against the “communists of the South”. 

China was the only thing keeping the north alive, and even then, it was on life support. Skirmishes into the south resulted in slaves, material, and food, and all China asked for in return was a portion of their precious metals. When China left in 2007, the north’s power vanished once again and the country collapsed into yet another stage of civil war. 

By 2010, fighting had gotten so brutal that many considered Guatemala a failed state. The General of Flores was deposed in 2008, and after that, many in the south waged war on who they viewed as “collaborators”. By 2015, the region that was once known as Guatemala was now ruled by several dozen feudal warlords, who waged war on each other and the cartels that were dominating Central America. 

As a result of the Great Heatwave of 2015, several Mexican cartels took over the ruined factories of the north and repurposed them to produce weapons for their own conflicts. Using Bromista, the various cartels subjugated and enslaved much of the population and used them to grow plants in greenhouses. In the 2020s, the largest cartel south of Mexico City, the Jinete de la Plaga Cartel, or Plague Rider Cartel, gradually took over Guatemala. 

By 2027, Guatemala is a storm-ravaged wasteland, its population blissfully addicted to the Siesta of Bromista. 

Belize

Official name: Belize
Capital: Belize City (Until 2005)
Government Type: Constitutional monarchy (1981-1991), Far-Left Military Junta (1992-2005)
Population as of final census conducted: 1,821,020 (Circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 690,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $418 Million USD
Primary Language: Belizean Creole (Belize Kriol)
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: None 
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Belize became fully independent of the UK in 1981. Unlike other areas of the world, Belize was not lifted up to a short but sweet utopian vision during the Glorious Decades. In fact, in 1988, Belize was considered one of the poorest nations in the world. The government of Belize tried to reinvigorate the economy by letting in foreign investment, but this only resulted in exploitation and further poverty. Many of Belize’s natural resources were exploited in such a way that the environmental damage was evident as early as 1982, when the Belize Barrier Reef reported record bleaching. 

After the Crash of 1988, not much changed in Belize, as poverty had already united the country. Cuba began to send aid to Belize in exchange for promises of their government becoming leftist, which many in power agreed to. Ties with the West were already dead before the 80s, and those in Washington and London would not help a small third world country in Latin America. 

Belize began to stabilize in the early Red Decades, as their incredibly small population made it easier for them to allocate land and food. With the help of Cuba, Belize barely weathered the Hot Summer and even began to set up collectivized farms. 

However, this attracted the attention of their neighbors in Guatemala. President Arana invaded Belize, citing the Cuban military bases there as a threat to their national security, and soon much of Belize was fighting for their own survival. To help with the war effort, and at the advice of Cuban fighters, Belize’s government was reformed into a far-left military junta. With the aid of Cuban guerillas and using their home turf advantage, Belize soon turned the war into a stalemate, much to Guatemala’s chagrin. 

In 1992, after the rebels in the Guatemalan Civil War took Guatemala City, the government forces retreated to the north and became even closer to Belize. Skirmishes intensified across the border, and Belize became more and more reliant on Cuba due to the wildfires and storms affecting their food supply. 

By 1993, the joint forces of Belize and Cuba had kicked Guatemala out of Belize, but much of the country was left in ruins. Belize City was devastated by constant bombings, and entire rural towns had been burned to the ground. It was here that Cuba gave their allies the unfortunate news that they would no longer be supplying Belize, or any country in Latin America, from now on. Not even a week after their victory against the Guatemalan invaders did Cuba fully evacuate Belize, taking all their equipment but leaving their military bases intact and unmanned. 

Belize’s miniscule government, overstretched and now scarcely able to man their own borders, struggled to keep law and order without the help of Cuban volunteers. Throughout the 90s, the Belize Junta lost more and more territory to anarchy until they controlled only Belize City and a few farms outside of it. In the weather-ravaged countryside, reports of gangs of bandits and cartels began to dominate the gossip of Belize City. 

Belize’s military government attempted to hold on to as many Cuban outposts as they could, but one by one, they were either willingly abandoned by the soldiers due to supply shortages, or taken over by groups of starving but organized bandits. By 2000, Belize had essentially regressed into a feudal society, with the junta in Belize City simply being the largest. Belize was already so far gone that China didn’t think it was worth it to attempt to industrialize them. 

Flooding became the largest problem in Belize. While their population was small enough that famine wasn’t a problem during the 90s, as floods constantly disrupted farms and destroyed crops, soon the supplies that remained had to be rationed. The floods also caused extensive damage to housing and buildings, leading to weakened foundations that were easily crippled by strong winds. In 2004, the government attempted to build a flood wall around Belize City, however constant rains slowed progress until it stopped entirely. 

In 2005, during a massive rainstorm that lasted weeks, the Belize Junta attempted to escape the city in a series of boats. They tried to sail to Cuba, but were caught in a storm and their ship capsized in the Caribbean. What little order was left was swept away with the water, and the one million inhabitants of Belize City struggled to survive as it fell to anarchy. 

Soon the people of Belize were facing another invasion: the Mexican People’s Army, who had invaded for “peacekeeping” purposes and pacified the rampant cartel rings in the countryside. At first, many actually joined the Mexicans, as they considered them to be the lesser evil compared to the Guatemalans or the numerous cartels. But the soldiers the MPA sent were untrained and incompetent, and for each victory they won against the cartels, they lost another five, not to mention all the innocent Belizeans caught in the crossfire. 

After eight long years and countless setbacks, the MPA finally pulled out of Belize, leaving it to the mercy of the cartels. They soon divided up the remaining communities and used them to grow food and drugs, keeping them blissfully unaware of the deteriorating world. In 2021, the Plague Rider Cartel from Guatemala invaded Belize, conquering it from the two remaining cartels. 

By 2027, Belize is completely abandoned as intense storms and biblical flooding prevent any long-term settlements or for greenhouses to last long enough for their crop to fully grow. The last cartel operation, located in Spanish Lookout, was abandoned in 2026 after a rival cartel poisoned their water supply. 

Honduras

Official name: Republic of Honduras
Capital: Tegucigalpa
Government Type: Presidential Republic (1979-1993), Far-Right Military Junta (1993-2000)
Population as of final census conducted: 18,903,743 (Circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 2,400,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $6.877 Billion USD
Primary Language: Honduran Spanish (Español hondureño)
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (Until 1992)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

In the 1970s, Honduras saw the record economic growth that many nations saw during the Glorious Decades. In 1979, the military peacefully transferred power to a civilian government, which worked closely with the United Nations Anti-Drug Task Force. 

The Anti-Drug Task Force was J. Edgar Hoover’s brainchild, being formed in 1973 to combat the rampant subversive drug use around the world. More importantly, it gave the powers that be an excuse to routinely raid and pillage those that they did not like: totally-not-planted evidence was always found on hippies, protesters and feminists. The Anti-Drug Task Force was also used for legitimate operations, mainly in South America, to combat the excess amounts of illegal chemicals in those areas. Marijuana, cocaine, heroin, and LSD were seized by the truckload, and governments that cooperated were rewarded. 

Honduras was the Anti-Drug Task Force’s main ally in Latin America, hosting a base in La Ceiba that contained holding cells, a forensics lab, and barracks for the militaries of the myriad of countries that were members of the Task Force. Honduras’s main goal for working so closely with the UN was not to tackle the drug problem, of course, but to deal with the Marxist insurgents that plagued the countryside. Throughout the 70s, the military government gave exaggerated stories about “drugged out hyper-Maoists getting their children addicted to weed and communism”, and the USA, trying to keep their military-industrial complex afloat, sent over military surplus from Vietnam. 

After Secretary Agassi resigned and the Soviet Union briefly became more liberal, as a token of good faith and that they were dedicated to working with the West, Minister Petrov sent several diplomats to negotiate with the Marxist insurgents. By 1984, the insurgency had surrendered and signed a peace treaty with the government, and negotiations were started to reintegrate the insurgents back into the capitalist, neoliberal Honduras. 

The Anti-Drug Task Force, and Honduras’s role in it, made them very dependent on trade with the USA and Mexico, and to a lesser extent, China and the USSR. Honduras joined the Alliance of Industrial Nations, the USA’s trading bloc, and was a large exporter of coffee and bananas. China was a major importer of their agricultural products, with their coffee supplying Chen’s megafactories. 

On March 1st, 1988, Operation: Silver Turkey was conducted by the United Nations Anti-Drug Task Force, led by United States Marines and Honduran commandos. The target of the operation was the Cinco Caballos Cartel, notorious for smuggling potent LSD throughout Latin America. The operation was for the most part mostly successful, with only three casualties (one Chinese operative and two Honduran commandos) throughout early 1988. The Task Force was closing in on the Cartel headquarters outside of Cruta when suddenly, the coalition was put on standby. The various participating countries covertly recalled their troops, citing national security concerns. 

Operation: Silver Turkey would never be completed, as on June 8th, 1988, the planned date of the raid on Cruta, Iran would launch their nuclear weapons, ending the last Sinai War and the Glorious Decades. Later that summer, as Cuba and the Soviet Union began to aid the fledgling leftist government around the world, the Marxist insurgency in Honduras saw a massive revival in the incomprehensible poverty that followed. 

The Marxists did not win the election of 1989, but the leftist government of the Liberal Party of Honduras barely won over the conservative National Party. Rather than acknowledging the Eternal Depression, the Liberal government instead blamed the state of the country on the rampant drug use and far-left communism that Cuba was spreading. In an attempt to rally the population, and make use of the large number of unemployed, the government implemented a sweeping draft and then launched a phoney war with El Salvador, blaming them for just about everything under the sun and performing huge military exercises along their border. 

During the Hot Summer of 1990, Honduras’s government was forced to implement widespread rationing due to resource shortages. Despite El Salvador, Cuba, and the USSR being blamed for somehow sabotaging the environment, the underground Marxist faction began to see a record amount of sympathy from Honduran citizens. This would lead to the government banning the Marxist faction in fall of 1990, and then martial law was declared in 1991. Freedom of assembly was suspended, along with freedom of the press. As Honduras slipped into being a police state, corruption and incompetence led to widespread famine by 1992. The last environmental laws were repealed and their national reserves were turned into gargantuan superfarms. 

Finally, on June 6th, 1993, Honduras invaded El Salvador. The invasion was spectacularly bloody and mismanaged, with a morbidly impressive amount of casualties being a result of friendly fire and supply line failures. In spite of Honduran propaganda portraying El Salvador as a backwards, communist country, the invasion was such a monumental military defeat that the government of Honduras collapsed into its own civil war in July that year. President Nasralla was executed by an angry general, and soon the military took control of the Honduran government. 

This led to widespread protests around the country, and various departments declaring independence from the capital. The Marxists, who Cuba had been secretly training, launched a full scale guerrilla war against the numerous right-wing governments and military dictators. The war raged on, with just about every city changing hands at least once, and in the chaos organized crime, gangs, and cartels flourished. Smuggling operations dominated the coast, and a black market emerged along the border with Guatemala. 

By 2000, the civil war had fizzled out into a protracted stalemate, with just a handful of city-states being controlled by various flavors of Marxist and Fascist dictators. Almost half of the cities had been destroyed in the fighting or from extreme storms. In the countryside, bandits roamed the no-man’s land in between the cities and routinely raided farms. Numerous attempts were led by both sides of the political spectrum to reunite Honduras, but they were routinely wiped out by the Cinco Caballos, who found their operations to be much easier with the communists and fascists fighting each other. 

That was, until in 2006, the Mexican People’s Army invaded Honduras. At first, they claimed to be on the side of the Marxists, and were spreading Mexican Socialism to the impoverished Hondurans. They also brought with them Valdez’s fanatical hatred for the Cartels, and with the help of the Confederacy of Western Honduran Communes, drove the cartel operations into the eastern side of the country. This resulted in the Cinco Caballos taking over the leadership of the fragmented far-right city states, and used leftover military equipment to wage war on the Mexicans and Marxists. 

In actuality, though, the Marxists had devolved into feudal warlords, and the Mexicans were merely their new lords. The Mexicans milked Honduras of all that it was worth, keeping their collaborators barely alive, and when it was clear that it was no longer worth the effort, they abandoned their holdings in Honduras. One particularly bad week-long rainstorm and a military defeat outside of Yoro caused the Mexicans to pull out of Honduras, and the few Marxist warlords left were easily defeated by the drug-fueled war machine of the Cinco Caballos. 

Soon, the Cinco Caballos controlled all of Honduras, and slowly worked at turning the entire country into one massive growing operation for the cartel. LSD was primarily produced, but the strain used caused numerous side effects such as severe psychosis and bouts of mania. Drug-fueled uprisings happened monthly, with the cartel guards using lethal force to routinely quell the disruption. 

In 2014, refugees fleeing from the Cuban Civil War attempted to stage a revolution against the Cinco Caballos, and for a few months, cartel slaves awoke and fought back. Eventually, they were beaten back down and forced back into their drug-induced stupor. 

The Great Heatwaves of 2015 upset the balance of power across the world, and in Honduras, this came in the form of the Guatemalan Plague Rider Cartel waging war on the Cinco Caballos. The Cinco Caballos were wiped out by 2017, with much of the cartel leadership defecting to the Plague Riders. Peace was short lived as in 2018 the Plague Riders began to experience incursions from the Mexican Black Rose Cartel, and by 2022 Honduras was essentially under Mexican control. 

Over the next five years, the country was thoroughly depopulated, and those that remained were worked to death in intensive farms growing luxury crops for cartel leadership, like coffee beans and scrawny, disease-ridden bananas. 

By 2027, Honduras is a heavily-fortified wasteland under control of the Black Rose Cartel. 
El Salvador

Official name: Republic of El Salvador
Capital: San Salvador
Government Type: Far-Right Military Dictatorship (1961-1995), Far-Left Military Junta (1995-2000)
Population as of final census conducted: 12,130,087 (Circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 100,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $2.771 Billion USD
Primary Language: Salvadoran Spanish (Español salvadoreño)
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (Until 1995)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

In the Glorious Decades, El Salvador narrowly avoided a civil war. The military dictatorship, using the economic splendor of the 70s and 80s, managed to keep a hold on their legitimacy. Crackdowns and raids, along with Anti-Drug Task Force operations, kept a tight hold on the population. For the average Salvadoran, they put up with the militarized government and the constant raids, as unless you were in the government’s crosshair, one could live an opulent life. 

That all changed, of course, after the Crash of 1988. No longer did the people stand by and watch as the government pushed everyone around. Mass protests erupted across the nation, and in 1989, a few members of the military launched a coup and did away with the sham of democracy that the PCN touted, instead deciding to rule directly. Things remained chaotic at best, however, and after the Hot Summer of 1990, civil war broke out between various left-leaning factions and far-right despots. 

Due to El Salvador’s small size, the fighting was brutal and intense. Entire departments were made uninhabitable due to industrial sabotage and scorched earth tactics, and Cuban supplies kept the leftist guerrillas operating. The fighting dragged on for three years, until in 1993, Honduras invaded El Salvador. Despite their differences, the two factions of the PCN and the FMLN made a truce and united to repel their northern invaders. 

The joint operations helped build trust between the two factions, and after Honduras was kicked out, a formal treaty between the two was signed and they began to start talks about jointly running the government. Neither side fully trusted the other, however, and on September 15th, 1995, the FMLN broke the armistice and took San Salvador by storm. The FMLN hoped that such a show of force would result in Cuba sending support once again, unaware that Cuba was facing their own problems. 

From 1995-2000, the FMLN Coalition ruled El Salvador, and while the average El Salvadoran was just grateful that the fighting had stopped and they could focus on rebuilding, they quickly lost faith in the FMLN as they proved to be exceptionally corrupt and prone to infighting. Storms and floods routinely devastated any attempts at rebuilding, and almost a million died in the famine in 1999. The FMLN began organizing witch hunts to find the remnants of the far-right junta, promising to “eat the rich”. In some cases, this was taken quite literally, as captured politicians from the Glorious Decades were roasted alive on a spit and then carved up to eat for the starving masses. Those that ate swore loyalty to the FMLN, first out of hunger, and then out of extreme guilt at what they had done. 

There were some, of course, who were absolutely appalled by the insanity happening around them, and talked about how communism had failed them. They didn’t need to eat politicians during the 70s and 80s, afterall, so a small but vocal minority advocated a return to an over industrialized system once again. 

The Civil War started up yet again in late 2000, when a dirty bomb exploded in San Salvador and caused radiation to leak across most of El Salvador, permanently tainting the soil for centuries. The remnants of the PCN fought tooth and nail against the FMLN, with organized crime and anarchy creeping in from the edges of the battlefield. 

For ten long years they fought, and there was no victor. By 2011, El Salvador had become a hellish wasteland, completely incapable of supporting any life, not just human. Industrial runoff and chemical rain had tainted the land not corrupted by the radiation, and in the few places possible of supporting life, apocalyptic storms and flooding destroyed any attempt of agriculture. Forest fires burned out the last husks of vegetation, leaving El Salvador a charred, desolate landscape filled with craters and shriveled, burned out foundations. 99% of the population fled, becoming members of the various leftist factions around Latin America or being sold into slavery by cartels. The few that remained kept to themselves, isolated in fortified bunkers and exploring the ruins by night. In the 2020s, parts of the habitable north were absorbed by Honduras, leaving the rest of what was once El Salvador to their own devices. 

By 2027, El Salvador has been forgotten by almost everyone, now lost to the annals of history. 
Nicaragua

Official name: Republic of Nicaragua/República de Nicaragua, People’s Republic of Nicaragua/República Popular de Nicaragua (disputed)
Capital: Managua
Government Type: Presidential Republic (1976-1989), Far-Left Military Junta (1989-1994)
Population as of final census conducted: 11,712,765 (Circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 4,600,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $1.499 Billion USD
Primary Language: Nicaraguan Spanish (Español nicaragüense)
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (Until 1989), COMECON (1989-1994)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Nicaragua's history picks up after the earthquake in 1972. After having signed the Shanghai Accords earlier that year, both the United States and China pledged help in rebuilding Nicaragua - after all, that could be a lucrative market. As part of the negotiations with Somoza, Nircugua was forced to open in exchange for international aid. 

This period of reform rapidly got out of the government’s control, and soon, Somoza was deposed in a peaceful revolution in late 1973. Working with the United States and China, Nicaragua was transformed into a neoliberal democracy with heavy investments from other industrial nations. The first free elections were held in 1976, and the right-leaning PCD established a foothold in the politics of the country. Throughout the rest of the 70s, Cuba attempted, against the Soviet Union’s change in policy, to inspire the downtrodden and rise up against their government. Unfortunately, they were too content with the current system and by 1978, Cuba had fully given up. This was the final straw for Castro, and throughout the 80s, he isolated Cuba from the rest of the world, only opening up communication when Ivan Voronin became Minister of Defense. 

Throughout the rest of the 1980s, Nicaragua became the largest exporter of coffee in the world, beating Honduras by a wide margin. The fact that Nicaragua used convict labor to grow the coffee in the rapidly increasing humidity is a fact many simply ignored, and so more and more coffee was made. Nashville House, the largest coffee company in the United States and Europe, had lucrative deals with the Nicaraguan government that resulted in corporate enclaves that were one step removed from being a company town. It was a well known fact that the new government would do anything to make a quick buck, especially at their citizen’s expense: factories were built in the middle of cities, industrial run off mixed in with irrigation water, and droughts were only met with snappy remarks and a policy that basically boiled down to “shut up and work anyway”. 

It was then no surprise that after the Crash of 1988, the government rapidly began to destabilize and collapse in on itself. Protests, prison breaks and cartels hiding out from the UN all contributed to the central government collapsing in early 1989 as Marxist rebels, supported by Cuba, raised the flag of the FSLN in Managua. That did not put a stop to the fighting, however, and the corruption only increased. A few countries tried to hold peace talks, though once it became clear that the country would be far too chaotic to grow coffee in, most of the world left Nicaragua to their fate. 

Spillover from the rampant civil war led to Nicaragua invading the comparatively wealthier Costa Rica in 1990, and with it, Cuba withdrew their support. The war dragged on for three years, and despite Costa Rica being a vastly smaller nation, they managed to win due to the constant infighting and mismanaged war effort. It was said that Nicaragua had a new head of state every season, and switched between right-wing and left-wing governments several times. 

After a particularly bad famine in 1993, with rumors of cannibalism in the fringes of the country, all central order collapsed and Nicaragua became a loose alliance of fragmented city-states. Soon the tides would turn, as in the mid 1990s Nicruagua was plagued with Costa Rican refugees fleeing the Colombian armies. What little order remained vanished and Nicaragua fell to anarchy. The rest of the 1990s in Nicaragua could be compared to feudal Europe. 

In 2001, Costa Rican cartels, namely the Agua Roja Cartel, expanded their operations into the no-man’s land that was once Nicaragua. The Agua Roja were unique in that they didn’t use drugs to control their serfs, but used excessive and brutal force instead. Throughout the early to mid 2000s, Nicaragua was pacified and put to heel under the Agua Roja, until the Great Storm of 2008, where a combination of flooding, storms, and rebellion forced the Agua Roja to completely flee Costa Rica and base themselves entirely out of Nicaragua. No longer did the Agua Roja engage in just drug growing operations, but intensive agriculture as well. 

From 2009-2011, Mexican Marxists, chasing the remnants of the various cartels in Central America, arrived in occupied Nicaragua and battled them for control. At this point, Valdez’s men were fighting just for the sake of fighting, viewing the cartels as subhuman degenerates who needed to be exterminated so that Mexican Socialism could finally be realized. The cartels were vastly better equipped, and more importantly, organized, and so by 2012 the Mexicans were kicked out. 

The various cartels worked together only because they shared a common enemy, and once Valdez left, they were at each other’s throats. The Agua Roja were wiped out in 2014, and in the Great Heatwave of 2015, many of the numerous smaller cartels died out. For the serfs, some of them briefly tried to make a stand and create their own city states, but their relief was short lived as in 2016 the Black Rose invaded them to set up gargantuan Bromista growing operations. 

As the environment got worse and worse, with cataclysmic storms, heatwaves and floods destroying Latin America, the Black Rose invested heavily in their growing operations in Nicaragua. Extreme UV radiation forced all their greenhouses to operate at night, and throughout the 2020s, various uprisings were launched against the cartels. Each one was put down with more force than the last, until in 2024, when the Black Rose began a policy of lobotomizing suspected agitators. 

As of 2027, Nicaragua is still under control of the Black Rose, but just barely. 
Costa Rica

Official name: Republic of Costa Rica/República de Costa Rica
Capital: San José
Government Type: Presidential Republic (1953-1989), Authoritarian Dictatorship (1989-1995)
Population as of final census conducted: 10,410,736 (Circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 1,200,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $4.636 Billion USD
Primary Language: Costa Rican Spanish (Español costarricense)
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (Until 1988)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

In the Glorious Decades, Costa Rica became the wealthiest country in Latin America. Carazo never became President, and thus Costa Rica maintained good relations with both the United States and the IMF. Yet despite the record economic growth and surging tourism, the President of Costa Rica, José Solís Arias, knew that it was only temporary, and something would bring it all crashing down. 

He proved to be right, although the circumstances were different to what he had expected: he believed a nuclear war between China and the USSR would bring about the end of civilization, yet it was a nuclear war all the same that caused everything to collapse. Immediately after the Crash of 1988, as early as June 8th, 1988, President Arias slowly severed ties with much of the world. He ordered the various industrial sites around the country to begin producing essential goods rather than consumer products. Costa Rica was supposedly one of the first countries to implement rationing, all the way back in July of 1988. This led to widespread protests, and after lethal force was used, disruption died down. In August of 1988, using a vague idea of nationalism and purity, President Arias used the military to sweep the country for foreign nationals, rounded them up, and deported them to their home countries. In situations where the national’s country did not exist, such as Iraq or Saudi Arabia, they were given a new identity and an offer to join the military of Costa Rica, or to leave and head to Europe[2]. Very few took the offer to stay in Costa Rica, as after the Media Blackout after June 8th, 1988, many believed that Europe was in a better state. 

In 1989, when it became clear that President Arias was one of the few heads of state in Latin America who was thinking for his people and not out of greed for a bygone era, he submitted a law to the Legislative Assembly making his presidential terms unlimited as long as poverty, homelessness and unemployment was above a certain percentage, in effect making him president for life. Whenever someone challenged him about his growing authoritarianism, and there were many, he would always show them the mighty asterisk in the clause and remind them that it was only temporary. 

In 1989 and 1990, Costa Rica barely hung on. Many social services were created, like government housing, community gardens, and strict water limits. Anyone who protested, either at the enormous overreach of the government or about their once glamorous life now reduced to one of rationing and heatwaves, were met with the full force of the Costa Rican military. The Hot Summer of 1990 almost crippled Costa Rica, but the early rationing of water helped the population cope with the changes. 

On September 1st, 1990, a group of Nicaraguan rebels crossed into La Cruz. They were chased by pro-government forces and took several Costa Rican workers as hostages. This enraged President Arias, who had severed diplomatic ties with countries solely to prevent a situation such as this. He sent in a platoon of Special Intervention Units with one goal: retake La Cruz by any means necessary. The SIU did not have to wait long, as by the time they got to La Cruz, the pro-government forces had already begun shooting the communist rebels, and the SIU simply mopped up the survivors. The pro-government forces had the decency to minimize casualties: only one Costa Rican was killed in the crossfire. 

For propaganda purposes, the one dead Costa Rican, Francisco Juan Calderon, was turned into a martyr, with an abstract minimalist monument erected in his name in La Cruz. Enlistment with the Costa Rican military skyrocketed, and Costa Rica managed to retake their occupied land with surprisingly low casualties. Nicaragua ended up being a rather easy opponent, as they were too busy fighting themselves than Costa Rica. Still, border skirmishes became such a common occurrence that Costa Rica built several fortified military bases along their northern border, and were in the process of building a border wall when the war ended and both Nicuraguas sued for peace 

In 1994, Costa Rica began the slow process of rebuilding their infrastructure. President Arias focused on building factories and production sites in between their northern border and San José, but this would prove to be a fatal mistake, as their entire eastern border was left undefended. President Arias was so focused on the Nicurgaans to the north that he was completely blindsided by Gran Colombia invading through Panama, trying to expand their territory. 

Over the next three years, Costa Rica desperately tried to defend their sovereignty. President Arias was presumed dead after San José was practically leveled, and organized resistance was slowly whittled down to just hit-and-run guerilla warfare. When the occupation forces stopped showing up in force, and were reduced to only a skeleton crew to oversee the country, the underground resistance hoped that this would be the end of their war and they could take back the country. La Sombra del Istmo, or the Isthmus Syndicate, was a powerful cartel that controlled much of Panama’s underground and once Colombia was distracted by Brazil’s war, they took over Panama and expanded into Costa Rica, battling the Agua Roja for control. 

Costa Rica was exhausted from fighting two wars of survival in just seven years, and many in the resistance deserted. A few of the most hardcore, dedicated men remained; they attempted to disrupt the cartel takeover of Costa Rica but many had given up, soon to be addicted to a myriad of drugs to keep them docile. 

Much of Costa Rica’s wealth was left intact outside of San José, and so throughout the 2000s the cartel leadership sold Costa Ricans as slaves to other cartels. As the country became less and less populated, lavish cities were built and the Agua Roja moved in. These walled enclaves were echoes of the luxury flats in New York City, with air-conditioning, running water, and other luxuries from the Glorious Decades. 

The Costa Rican resistance remained, if smaller than ever, and in 2008 they launched an organized rebellion against the Syndicate and Agua Roja. Millions of servants rose up and fought tooth and nail against those that have humiliated them for a decade, and in the process, many estates were burnt to the ground. Things weren’t going good for Panama either, and millions of refugees fled into Costa Rica, overwhelming the already distracted Syndicate. 

Order collapsed and for the next ten years, Costa Rica fell into total anarchy, with dozens of statelets forming only to fall a few months later. The Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2016 resulted in mass drought and millions of casualties, but the fighting continued. The Warlord of Nuevo Arenal waged war with the Captain of Limon, not to mention the 20 or so cartels that tried to take over land to recoup their losses after the heat waves. 

Every year, the heat got worse, and the storms got stronger, and by the 2020s storms became so big that they ripped entire towns out of the ground. Black Rose attempted to pacify Costa Rica and establish growing operations there, but the Second Great Heatwave of 2023 forced them to pull out. 

By 2027, Costa Rica is in anarchy, controlled by no warlord, cartel, army or government. 

[1] The Mexican-American Pipeline ended in Texas. King-Chevron, the owners of the American side, claimed to have fixed their end of the pipeline. King-Chevron would be investigated by the Graves Administration later that term and be found guilty of aiding the Mexican rebels in an attempt to provoke a war with Mexico, though those details were never released to the public. 
[2] At first, in the very early months after the Sinai War, Europe initially opened up their borders to stateless refugees. 

Section 2: South America
Panama

Official name: Mandate of Panama/Mandato de Panamá (1987-1989), People’s Republic of Panama/República Popular de Panamá (1989-1995)
Capital: Panama City
Government Type: United Nations Protectorate (1987-1989), Far Left Military Junta (1989-1995)
Population as of final census conducted: 8,175,891 (Circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 60,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $5.441 Billion USD
Primary Language: Panamanian Spanish/Español Panameño
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (Until 1987), COMECON (1989-1994)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

After the signing of the Shanghai Accords, both the United States and China looked to the increasingly unstable military government in Panama and declared them a threat to free trade. This resulted in an unprecedented United Nations mission, led by a joint coalition of the United States and China, that deposed Torrijos and made the Panama Canal a neutral zone run by the United Nations. This new Panama was a puppet state rife with corruption, as smugglers and pirates now flocked to the now open canal. As a result, the United Nations Peacekeeping Mission in Panama regularly engaged with small-time smugglers and pirates, and in the 1980s, cartels. The world turned a blind eye to the obscene levels of corruption and crime in Panama: as long as the nations of the world got their sweet, cheap goods, everyone was happy. 

Panama began to see a staggering level of income inequality during the 1980s, as the workers in the Panama Canal Neutral Zone became millionaires while just about everyone else struggled to make ends meet, with many turning to crime and forcing the State Police (what the military of Panama became after the joint invasion) to gradually escalate their brutality. 

In early 1987, things had gotten so bad that the State Police, using confiscated black market weapons, staged an uprising against the UN Panama Mission, and attempted to take back the canal. They were met with extreme and swift retribution, as countries could not afford even a momentary lapse in the flow of goods. By summer of 1987, all of Panama had been turned into a United Nations Protectorate, known as the Mandate of Panama. The State Police were thoroughly demilitarized and UN Peacekeepers took over just about every aspect of the government to keep trade flowing smoothly. 

That was the status quo until the last Sinai War caused fears of a third world war to break out. Many countries recalled their troops, and soon Panama was left to their own devices again. Anarchy followed, but on January 16th, 1989, Jovano Mendoza Vila, former State Commissioner of Panama City, reunited all of Panama’s former territory, including the canal. Traffic through the canal had fallen by over 1,594% by the time he had regained control of the country, and strangely, Commissioner Vila found it reassuring. He viewed it unlikely that any country would come by to control them again. 

Commissioner Vila, having long watched the poverty of his country force men into lives of crime, decided to create a series of social programs to help curb criminal activity. These were successful, though expensive. His government was forced to turn to heavily taxing the few ships passing through the canal, and then robbing them of a portion of their supplies. When that dried up, Commissioner Vila made a deal with the devil and allowed Colombian cartels to move their supplies through Panama, in exchange for food. The People’s Republic of Panama had no shortage of expensive and intricate weaponry, as the UN’s contraband vaults were never emptied when they left, but they lacked many other necessary things to help rebuild their country. Vila even joined COMECON and began to ally their nation with the USSR, which was the only major power who did not relentlessly bully Panama in the Glorious Decades. 

After Commissioner Vila was assassinated in 1990 by a greedy cartel member, the new military government of Panama gradually became just as corrupt as the US-China led puppet state. With the average Panamanian still not seeing a notable increase to their quality of life, unrest began to form, eventually spiraling into a civil war in 1994 between angry partisans and corrupt military officials. 

The war continued for some time, as while the military was significantly better equipped than the partisan rebels, the rebels were many and had nothing left to lose, having lived in poverty for so long. It was in the summer of 1994. The country was split roughly evenly, with the partisans on the western side and the cartel-backed military on the eastern side, and abruptly the Colombian Army swarmed Panama and took the canal. 

Colombia initially claimed to be on a mission to stamp-out cartel activity, which many in Panama agreed with, at first. Colombia proved to be just as cruel as a master as the military had been though, and the rebellion picked up again. Panamanian guerrillas made keeping the canal as hard as they could for Colombia, and in 1997, they got their wish. Colombia pulled out of Panama when the increasingly imperialistic Brazil began a campaign to take Bogota. 

This was where La Sombra del Istmo saw their chance and took over the Canal, becoming Panama’s final masters. The guerillas were exhausted and demoralized, and all holdouts were wiped out by 2000. Panama became just as corrupt as it was during the Glorious Decades, if significantly poorer. The Panama Syndicate used the canal to ferry drugs, slaves, and weapons to their clients in South America and Central America, as well as raiding abandoned islands in the Caribbean. The Panamanian Syndicate became known for trafficking “tango calves”, a euphemism for women sold into sex slavery, kept placid by Bromista. 

In August 2008, a massive tropical storm drenched Panama in a month of torrential floods and heavy rains. An uprising was launched, and the Cartel was driven out of Panama and west into Costa Rica. The storm destroyed much of the structures in Panama, including permanently damaging the canal beyond repair, and led to anarchy and warlordism in the areas that remained. 

Throughout the 2010s, the Isthmus Wasteland was occasionally picked over by various cartels, pirates, scavengers, and refugees fleeing from the chaos in Brazil. As the years dragged on and the environment crumbled, these new tourists stopped visiting, and in the 2020s the UV radiation got so bad that it was a death sentence to go outside during the day. The Solar Storm of 2026 caused the last palm trees to light on fire. 

By 2027, Panama is a wind-ravaged wasteland, ruled over by a scarce few warlords in tiny enclaves. 
Colombia

Official name: Republic of Colombia/República de Colombia (until 1989), Gran Colombia (1989-2000), Brazilian Governorship of Colombia and Panama/Governança brasileira da Colômbia e do Panamá (2000-2013)
Capital: Bogota
Government Type: Presidential Republic (until 1989), Far Right Authoritarian State (1989-2000), Military Occupation (2000-2013)
Population as of final census conducted: 104,706,063 (Circa 2010)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 71,900,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $43.372 Billion USD
Primary Language: Colombian Spanish/Española Colombiana
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (until 1989)
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

In Colombia during the Glorious Decades, the widespread reforms throughout China and the USSR caused many left-wing guerilla movements to lose hope and surrender to the government. Of the many groups that surrendered, only a few managed to actually be granted clemency. With the covert help of the United States, many of these groups were wiped out by the 1980s. 

Part of these clandestine operations included the assassination of prominent members of the April 19th Movement, a group that believed that the elections in 1970 were rigged and that Gustavo Rojas Pinilla rightfully won the presidency. The M-19 movement was the only leftist organization to continue to operate in Colombia during the Glorious Decades, and as such, special care was taken to ensure that it was to be wiped out. The United States, working with the right-wing government of Colombia, used the United Nations Anti-Drug Task Force as a cover to engage in their purges. 

Ironically, it turned out the Colombian underbelly was home to one of the largest drug running operations in history, and soon the United Nations created an international coalition to combat the rising criminal activity, the US and Colombia still worked on eradicating guerillas on the side. While many small-time gangs continued to risk capture to make extremely lucrative deals, the larger, more organized members tried to stay under the radar. This did not always work in their favor, as increasingly intricate drug busts were conducted throughout the 1980s, finally culminating in the death of Pablo Escobar during a joint USA-USSR-PRC raid on June 11th, 1986. This dealt a massive blow to the criminal underground, and for the next two years, crime dropped to levels unseen for decades. 

Colombia’s recovery stagnated after the Crash of 1988, and the right-wing government tried to continue business as normal, believing that the crisis was temporary - they’d both wiped out the drug lords, and they had wiped out their opposition. It was then to their complete surprise when a group of far-right paramilitaries started to vocally claim that the government wasn’t doing enough, and on February 6th, 1989, this resulted in the RNC, or the National Restoration of Colombia, to take over the government in a military coup. 

This new group was extremely fascist and nationalistic, and began to reorganize the country on “ideals of Colombian glory”. The Hot Summer of 1990 was not that devastating to Colombia (which now called itself Gran Colombia, despite still controlling the same territory as it did pre-1989) as protests were nipped in the bud with lethal force before they ever got out of hand. The government then blamed the protesters, claiming that if they had worked hard enough and lived with Colombian ideals, they wouldn’t have starved. 

Over the next few years, the RNC began tightening their leash around Colombia. The press was now completely state controlled, higher education was banned, and the homeless and jobless were forced to either join the Armed Forces or serve their sentences in “Patriotism Camps”, which mainly consisted of working as slaves in state-owned super farms. The more corrupt wardens of these camps sold their slaves to other cartels on the side, and a few even kept women as sex slaves. 

The RNC moved on to their next phase of restoring Colombian Glory - the reformation of Gran Colombia. Panama was invaded in 1994, and was swiftly taken over. This filled the RNC with bravado and confidence, and in 1995 Colombia invaded Venezuela. Venezuela was already in the midst of a brutal civil war that was rapidly deteriorating into warlordism and anarchy, and as such, was an easy target. Venezuela was subjugated in a brutal blitzkrieg that rivaled China in their invasion of Taiwan. Soon, Gran Colombia began siphoning large amounts of petroleum from Venezuela to fuel their war machines and aircraft, further securing their military superiority against Venezuela. 

But by 1996, Gran Colombia was not the only country that was battling for control over Venezuela’s oil reserves: the Second Empire of Brazil, having formed in 1991 in the aftermath of the Sao Paulo Massacre, rolled into Venezuela in a pincer move that shocked and overwhelmed the gargantuan Colombian invasion force. With every refinery captured, Brazil became more powerful, and just a year later Gran Colombia had fully retreated and was fighting to keep Brazil out of Bogota. 

On March 8th, 2000, Gran Colombia officially surrendered to Brazil, in exchange for a marginal degree of autonomy. This was granted in exchange for the complete demilitarization of Colombia, with Brazil in charge of both internal and external security for Colombia. Colombia was still allowed to rule Panama in Brazil’s name, though that was only done on paper as Panama was now under the complete control of the cartels. 

The lack of an armed police force, and the exhausted military of Brazil, led to an unprecedented amount of crime in occupied Colombia, making the Glorious Decades look like Sweden in comparison. Organized crime exploded, leading to the creation of a number of cartels and gangs. One of these, simply known as the Cartel, would rise to be the most powerful cartel before the Great Death, including crime syndicates from during the Glorious Decades. They were more powerful than the Mexican Black Rose, and the Brazilian Sons of the Amazon. By as early as 2002, The Cartel practically controlled all of Colombia from the shadows. Brazil was fine with it, as they received generous kick backs and rare goods obtained by the Panama Syndicate (which cooperated with The Cartel out of fear). “Seeing the Ballet” became a common euphemism for Brazilian soldiers on shore leave to visit the many Cartel-operated brothels. Some even tried the cocktail of powerful drugs that were offered throughout occupied Colombia. 

Throughout the 2000s, The Cartel began to expand their operations into remote parts of South America, battling other local cartels for dominance. Pirates began to avoid the coast of South America for fear of retaliation from the Cartel, which had an uncanny way of training their operatives. Not much was known about the recruitment process, but those that survived had unwavering loyalty to The Cartel. 

During The Cartel’s rise to power after the occupation, they kidnapped a famous Mexican chemist from the Glorious Decades named Miguel “Blanco” Trejo. Trejo had worked under Pablo Escobar during the 1980s and developed many strains of potent and addictive drugs. The Cartel placed him in a laboratory and told him he would die in one week unless he could do one thing: develop a way for them to enhance the combat abilities of their soldiers and operatives. Trejo did the best he could, using modified strains he had developed in 1981 as a base. In that time he was only able to make a potent paralytic drug that caused floods of pleasure and pleasant hallucinations. Trejo was spared, as The Cartel leadership (a man known only as The Vulture) believed that with some modifications, this chemical could become a very lucrative product. 

Trejo was given a luxurious private laboratory in a bunker beneath Bogota, and while he was told to devote at least a part of his time to developing a combat-enhancing drug, he was also able to develop and refine this lucrative wonder drug. Further strains ended up being so addictive, that many of Trejo’s guards got hooked on the stuff. At the request of The Vulture, the paralytic agent was toned down to just a mild sedative. One of the withdrawal symptoms of the drug was excessive fatigue, leading addicts to resort to desperate but usually non-violent methods to satisfy their cravings. 

By the mid 2000s, the drug was finished and had been tailored exactly to The Vulture’s specifications. Bromista, as it came to be known, was a game changer. The Cartel quickly gained control of local governments throughout South America, and other cartels waged war on them to find out the secret to their success. Druglords across Latin America tried to recreate the potency of Bromista but nothing came close. Rival cartels, such as Black Rose, engaged in chemical espionage and stole the formula for Bromista, though not that it mattered: the drug was so ubiquitous by that time that Black Rose was able to begin production of their own variant, Bromista could be found as far north as New York City, USA and as far south as Rio Grande, Argentina. 

The Cartel’s power grew rapidly, and The Vulture grew ever greedier. He began to plan an attack on the Brazilian occupiers and to expand his criminal empire. An uprising at a large plantation on October 10th, 2009 was the start of his rebellion, and the rest of Colombia saw it as a call to arms. Unknown to most however was the fact that it was a collaboration between The Cartel and Venezuelan Red Hand Guerillas. What The Cartel did not expect was the indiscriminate destruction the Venezuelans caused. The entire plantation was later razed to the ground, and farms across the country went up in flames. Improvised explosives turned Bogota into a labyrinth of death, and the major roads into Brazil were all mined to the point that they were uncrossable by The Cartel’s forces. 

The Cartel quickly betrayed their Venezuelan allies and the state soon descended into a civil war between anarchist partisans, Cartel mercenaries, and Brazilian troops. Forests burned in the conflict, blanketing Colombia in a thick layer of smog that hovered there for years. This was further compounded when on March 27th, 2011, a massive tropical storm devastated Colombia’s coast, destroying the remaining functioning farms in the north. Brazil gradually stopped sending reinforcements, and as of January 1st, 2013, Brazil completely pulled out of Colombia though they still claimed them as their territory. 

The Civil War continued, and after the Great Heatwave of 2015, The Cartel finally fractured. The Vulture was allegedly killed by one of his own men, and the heatwave destroyed the last functioning greenhouses for their operations. Both the production of Bromista and Sónico (the combat-enhancing drug, which saw only marginal success) were halted, and with it, the power of The Cartel came crashing down. The anarchists did not let up their fight, as they viewed both Brazil and The Cartel as their enemy, and in 2017, became the sole inheritors of what was once Colombia. 

As the Red Hand left to help “liberate” other countries from Brazil, they left behind a few scattered city states and farming communities that quickly turned on each other and collapsed into warlordism and then true anarchy. The Solar Flare of 2026 disrupted the careful balance of power in the region, and even the Black Rose began to struggle to control their workers. 

By 2027, Colombia is now two dozen independent city-states in a wasteland patrolled by cartels, bandits, and cannibals. Across the countryside, hundreds of farms are controlled by the Black Rose, who keep almost 50 million Colombians in a Bromista-induced state of euphoria as they work themselves to death. But even then, every day it becomes harder and harder to pacify their workers, and cartel leadership in Honduras fear that Colombia is a ticking time bomb. 
Venezuela


A pair of Venezuelan soldiers on guard in Caracas during the civil war, photographed sometime between January 16th and February 17th, 1992


The eighth star represents Trinidad, which “voluntarily” joined Venezuela in 1991
Official name: Republic of Venezuela/República de Venezuela (until 1995), Brazilian Governorship of Venezuela and Trinidad/Governança brasileira da Venezuela e Trinidad (1997-2014)
Capital: Caracas
Government Type: Presidential Republic (until 1995), Military Occupation (1995-2014)
Population as of final census conducted: 49,516,654 (Circa 2010)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 27,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $6.378 Billion USD
Primary Language: Venezuelan Spanish/Español Venezolano
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: COMECON (until 1994)
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

In the 1970s, Venezuela remained relatively poor and destitute. Despite having obscene amounts of oil, they could not compete with the dirt cheap Iranian oil that flowed like water out of the Middle East. Venezuela never had any financial crises in the 1980s, either, and the constant economic stagnation forced the marginally left-wing government to implement reforms in an attempt to diversify its economy to not just oil production and tourism. 

After the Crash of 1988, President Marcos Ortega Barrientos saw a dramatic increase to the demand for Venezuela’s oil. Countries across the globe were lining up to get their share of the oil to keep their economies running, and soon Venezuelan ports were struggling to accommodate the unprecedented influx of ships. From 1988 to 1990, Venezuela saw a monumental increase to their standard of living, being one of the few countries to actually see economic growth after the Crash of 1988. 

However, this made them a target: some countries, growing more desperate by the day, attempted to outright steal oil without paying the Venezuelan government. Others attempted to scuttle rival nation’s ships to get their supplies. It was chaos, and the Venezuelan government considered calling in the United Nations to help police their waters, but after seeing what the United Nations had done to other countries in South America, President Barrientos decided against it, instead dramatically increasing the budget of Venezuela’s military. 

The Hot Summer of 1990 caused tensions to flare up, and the social programs that were almost two decades old broke apart. Food shortages and drought led to protests, which led to riots, and as the government took more and more stringent measures to combat it, they were forced to enact martial law across much of the country.
