The Hot Summer crippled the rest of the world, and the countries that were once fighting each other for Venezuelan oil were now struggling just to keep their citizens fed. The demand for oil dried up, and soon Venezuela was one of those countries. Spillover of the civil unrest resulted in Venezuela being forced to invade Trinidad (though their dictator was allowed to remain in power) and later Guyana, which became a semi-autonomous region.

This sparked outrage, and on March 12th, 1991, the bombing of a historic government building in Coro signaled the start of the Venezuelan Civil War. Dissatisfaction with previous two decades of government policy caused many to violently resist, turning into its own brand of Venezuelan Anarchy, known as the Red Hand Confederacy. Organized crime syndicates engaged in racketeering and controlled roads, while smugglers sold Venezuelan oil to the highest bidder. Government forces were stretched thin, desperately trying to keep their own men fed well enough to defend their tiny, isolated enclaves. 

Skirmishes around refineries led to massive oil explosions and uncontrollable wildfires, causing what was left of emergency services to be overwhelmed and thousands to choke on the fumes. Many on the coast resorted to piracy and intensive fishing to feed their population, and on the border of the country, bandits routinely raided villages in neighboring nations. 

By 1995 the Civil War had become just a couple hundred isolated anarchic city-states resisting cartels that routinely fought over the same oil refineries. It was here that Gran Colombia invaded Venezuela, expecting little resistance like in Panama. They could not have been more wrong, however, as this gave every Venezuelan a common enemy and the Red Hand once again went to work destabilizing the oppressors. 

On July 3rd, 1996, the Red Hand had just kicked Colombia out of Caracas when just a few days later, refugees fleeing north spread the word that Brazil was preparing to invade. Minister Augusto Fernando César had seen the state of chaos that Venezuela was in and saw it as an opportunity to keep Brazil’s farm equipment running, not to mention their military. Plans had been drafted up in early 1996 and he waited for the Colombians to be defeated by the Venezuelans before he made his move. 

Colombia retreated to defend Bogota, leaving Venezuela wide open and Brazil moved in to squeeze it of all it was worth. It was made a priority to capture the refineries with minimal gunfire, and with each refinery Brazil captured, their military doubled in efficiency. Brazil had a lot of old police and military equipment left over from the days of the United Nations Anti-Drug Task Force in the 1980s, plus some old Vietnam-era surplus equipment. They carpet-bombed cities into submission, and blasted coastlines with their Navy.

Brazil overwhelmed Venezuela, and on January 28th, 1997, the last major city-state - Barquisimeto - officially surrendered. Captured soldiers were taken hostage and sent to prison farms in southern Brazil. The Partisan army was composed of both sexes, and some female soldiers chose suicide rather than becoming the property of some Brazilian commander. Red Hand holdouts remained, of course, but as the Brazilians tightened their hold on the country, they offered incentives to citizens who spied for them and reported information about suspected agitators. 

For the Red Hands that remained, they were only further emboldened by the relentless occupation by fascist Brazil. The supposed leader of the Guerillas, a mysterious man known only as “Six”, was killed in a raid outside of El Tigre on March 21st, 1997, and was immediately replaced by a man with a similar personality known as “Seven”. Every time the Brazilians dealt a blow to the Red Hand leadership, another rebel took the helm and carried on the fight. The Red Hands became vigilantes, fighting not just Brazil but bandits that preyed on the countryside. 

By 1999, the Red Hands were being led by “Thirteen” and Brazil had largely given up trying to track them down, instead focusing on holding on to oil production sites. The Red Hands had become noticeably well funded, suddenly sporting old Cold War era Soviet equipment, and cells were appearing across South America. In April 1999, the Ponce Mine in Ecuador was the site of a month-long siege between Brazilian collaborators and Ecuadoran rebels, suspected to be working with the Venezuelans. 

This was followed by the coordinated destruction and burning down of numerous Peruvian farms in 2002, leading Brazil to think that a rebellion was brewing in occupied Peru. However, this was merely a feint and the real operation took place in Venezuela itself, as the main pipeline into Brazil was destroyed in a spectacular and extravagant manner, including many improvised fireworks. This permanently crippled Brazil’s war machine and agricultural production as over 50% of the world’s remaining oil supply went up in flames. What it did not do is free Venezuela from Brazil’s grip, as Venezuela had a huge amount of arable land remaining. Venezuela’s military governor, General Otávio Mendes Rocha, enacted martial law and allowed all soldiers permissions to shoot with lethal intent. 

The Red Hand reduced their operations and stayed under the radar the best they could, planning their next offensive. The Red Hand had cells of operatives, called Fingers, in almost every occupied territory in Latin America, making alliances with both Socialist Mexico and the USSR. Later on, the Democratic People’s Republic of Argentina would send them military equipment and intel, using them as a proxy to keep fascist Brazil distracted and in the north. The Red Hand created a vast network of informants and spies, using the homeless and destitute to listen into Brazil’s plans. 

The next revolt began on December 16th, 2005 in Guyane. Laotian refugees, using their skills taught to them by their fathers and grandfathers during the Vietnam War, worked with the Red Hand to engage in an elaborate game of cat and mouse with the Brazilians. For the next decade, Brazil lost almost 100,000 men trying to keep the farms in Guyane functioning and flowing to Brazil. The governor of Guyane, General Aurélio Vargas Monteiro, was later executed on January 4th, 2006, for his failure to stop the rebellion. 

It was the operation in Guyane that got Argentina’s attention, and they began to plot to destabilize Brazil once and for all. Despite their numerous attempts to break free from Brazil, the Red Hand had not succeeded in liberating any country from their grip, not even their own. That changed in 2009, when Argentina brokered an alliance between The Cartel in Colombia and the Red Hand, and the October 10th Uprising happened that year. The Cartel had vastly more resources than the Red Hand, and soon were on the offensive against Brazil. A tropical storm in 2011 and relentless resistance forced Brazil to finally retreat in 2013, and that was where the next phase of the plan came into fruition. 

On May 20th, 2013, “Thirteen”, or as his true name was soon revealed, Anastase Herrero Perez, voluntarily turned himself in at the Governor’s Palace in Caracas. The Military Dictator of Brazil, Augusto Fernando César, came to personally execute Thirteen and cut off the Red Hand. This was exactly what they were hoping for, and a well-hidden bomb in the foundation of the Palace caused the entire structure to collapse inwards, killing both Thirteen and César. In retaliation, Brazil sent in a massive amount of forces, and left much of their military unorganized. Disagreements between the Imperial Forces and the Emperor of Brazil, César Henrique Morales, led to a breakdown in command and starting the Brazilian Civil War. 

The Red Hand finally got what they wanted, as Brazil fully retreated from Venezuela by 2014. This resulted in a new problem, as The Cartel, looking to get revenge on the destruction the Red Hand had wrought, moved into Venezuela and forced much of the population to work to death on plantations. Those that escaped The Cartel fought tooth and nail to resist, but in the areas the Cartel didn’t control, bandits and warlords enacting their own vengeance for the vigilantism the Red Hand conducted in the 2000s. 

The Red Hand of course had the last laugh, as The Cartel collapsed in the aftermath of the Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2016, ending in a full uprising throughout the summer of 2017. While The Cartel would never threaten Venezuela again, numerous warlords constantly prevented the Red Hand from fully liberating Venezuela. Throughout the 2020s, the Red Hand, aided by Argentina, slowly began to pacify Venezuela, though they faced setbacks in the aftermath of the 2026 Solar Flare. 

By 2027, Venezuela is under civil war between hardcore members of the Red Hand who don’t want to abandon their anarchist roots, and pro-Argentine members who want to establish a socialist republic with the goal of eventually joining Argentina as an autonomous republic. 
Guyana

Official name: Republic of Guyana (until 1991), Venezuelan Occupied Guyana (1991-1995), Brazilian Governorship of Guyana/Governança brasileira da Guiana (1995-2015)
Capital: Georgetown
Government Type: Presidential Republic (1979-1991), Military Occupation (1991-2015)
Population as of final census conducted: 1,883,086 (Circa 2010)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 600,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $8.28 Billion USD
Primary Language: English
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: World Prosperity Alliance (until 1989)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Guyana did not embrace the new free market initially, instead they tried to maintain their policy of “self reliance”. This only worked until the late 70s, though, and the young government struggled to maintain a hold on their power. Many began to protest the stagnating economy, leading to the Sugar Strikes of 1977-1978. Representatives from the World Prosperity Alliance offered to help negotiate with the workers, but in the end, the government made a deal with the United States and allowed US Strikebreakers in to make the sugar industry functioning again. 

Things remained tenuous at best, and when on November 18th, 1978 Jim Jones carried out the Jonestown Massacre and all claims of legitimacy by the current government of Guyana vanished. Due to the cultural stagnation, hedonism, and ennui, over 2,000 people ended up dying that day, including US Congressman Ronald Reagan, who had been investigating Jones. 

The people of Guyana had had enough, and on January 21st, 1979, a violent coup deposed the government of Guyana, replacing it with a populist right-wing conservative government modeled after much of the United States and Europe. Throughout the 1980s, this new Guyana would try to emulate the wealth of First-World Countries and worked closely with China to build many super-factories across their country. Entire forests were cut down, leading to almost 99% of Guyana’s wilderness to vanish by 1988. 

Guyana never had a chance to see the prosperity promised to them, as after the Crash of 1988, Guyana experienced shortages of just about everything: cooking oil, fuel, sugar and rice all became scarce and expensive. The economy completely crashed in 1989, and the right-wing government was replaced with a rag-tag coalition of left-wing politicians after a snap election on March 15th, 1989. The left-wing government devoted almost their entire budget to feeding their population and maintaining their living conditions for as long as possible, but by the Hot Summer of 1990 people began to bake in the savanna that had replaced the jungle. Riots and marital law ensued, and people started to raid military depots for rations to eat.

On April 25th, 1991, Venezuela, chasing anti-government rebels, invaded Guyana, claiming that it was always their territory anyway. Nobody recognized this claim, and as a result from the ensuing violence plus the droughts, famine, and economic conditions, throughout the 1990s much of Guyana would become depopulated with people fleeing to perceived stability of places like Brazil, Argentina, Colombia, and some even as far as Mexico. 

On August 26th, 1995, Brazil would invade Guyana as well, kicking out Venezuela and invading them for their oil. Members of the old government, who were effectively ruling city states that all simultaneously claimed to be the “new” capital, surrendered and collaborated with Brazil in exchange for keeping their power of the cities. Brazil agreed, though a general of the Imperial Forces was still selected to be the governor of the new State. 

Despite much of the wildlife being destroyed in the 1980s, Guyana still had a (comparably) large amount of arable land. Brazil began to set up intensive farming operations that maximized the efficiency and production yield of staple crops such as rice and wheat. Due to the small population that remained, Brazil didn’t need to keep as strong of a force there, and for a while, the citizens of occupied Guyana were content to be a part of Brazil. After all, it seemed like almost 25 years of corruption had finally ended, and now many people had a steady supply of food and water. 

That all changed in 2009, when various members of The Cartel began to expand their operations in Guyana. Guyana had gained the reputation of being a peaceful, backwater state of the new Brazilian Empire, and thus The Cartel viewed it as the perfect place to set up shop. The Cartel slowly and subtly bribed their way into controlling most of the local governments, and then diverted greenhouses to growing supplies for Bromista. People began to vanish off the streets, and Brazil always turned a blind eye. This was noticed by the Red Hand, who established a finger in 2010, and they engaged in counter-attacks involving monkeywrenching and other forms of sabotage. 

In the Great Heatwave of 2015, the Red Hand’s sabotages were revealed to have worked too well, and Guyana’s agricultural system could not be revived on a meaningful scale. Both Brazil and The Cartel abandoned their holdings, and those that remained fell into a vicious cycle of anarchy and warlordism. Between 2017 and 2027, various smaller cartels attempted to set up growing operations in Guyana, but they were always destroyed by severe storms, flooding, or sabotage. The Solar Storm of 2026 destroyed any hope of a unified Guyana. The Red Hand attempted to form communes in Guyana, but they were seen as no better than the Cartel and were always driven out. 

By 2027, Guyana is a barely-livable wasteland controlled by a dozen warlords. 
Suriname

Official name: Republic of Suriname/Republiek Suriname (until 1992), Brazilian Governorship of Suriname/Governança brasileira do Suriname (1992-2013)
Capital: Paramaribo
Government Type: Parliamentary Republic (until 1988), Far Left Junta (1988-1992), Military Occupation (1992-2013)
Population as of final census conducted: 1,727,611 (Circa 2010)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 450,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $186.4 Million USD
Primary Language: Dutch
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: World Prosperity Alliance (until 1992)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

In 1980, the newly formed government of Suriname managed to foil the planned military coup, but Suriname’s quality of life still declined. In the 1980s, Suriname was notoriously corrupt and considered one of the poorest countries in the world. Many corporations donated old and outdated equipment to Suriname for tax cuts, and lavish fundraisers were held in Suriname’s name, though if it actually helped Suriname is debatable. 

After the Crash of 1988, and with whatever foreign aid that actually made it to Suriname drying up completely, a far-left revolutionary group took over the government. This group, called the Unidad Rood-Zwart, or “Red-Black Unity”, did actually manage to keep the government functioning for a while, running through the Hot Summer of 1990 completely fine, which cannot be said for a majority of the world, as the Hot Summer of 1990 was the first true test of those that survived the Sinai War. While the Unidad Rood-Zwart was efficient, they were not by any means popular, and by early 1992 people were emigrating en masse to other countries much like what was happening in Guyana. 


On October 8th, 1992, Brazil would invade Suriname as they viewed the leftist government as a threat. Suriname, which had already been thoroughly depopulated, did not put up much of a resistance. By New Years of 1993, Suriname was already a fully integrated state of Brazil. The lack of any organized resistance allowed Brazil to keep a tight hold over the state for two decades, before finally being forced to relinquish control after a forest fire on August 8th, 2013. 

In the early 2000s, Brazil secretly worked with China, despite it being an openly leftist government. Part of this secret operation included building destructive mining sites across Suriname to access their huge reserves of precious metals. These Chinese refineries poisoned the soil and caused huge clouds of smog to choke the air in neighboring Guyana and Guiana. Suriname’s gold helped create an illusion of legitimacy to Brazil’s Real Novo. When China vanished from the continent in 2007, Brazil struggled to keep their refineries running, before finally being forced to close them in 2012. 

After Brazil abandoned Suriname in 2013, various cartels and pirates used parts of the coast as safehouses or attempted to start up growing operations. Refugees fleeing from the Brazilian Civil War and the famines of 2015 and 2016 passed through Suriname, but no large settlements remained. Paramaribo became a haven for smugglers and pirates, and drugs, women, and later human flesh were all sold en masse until it all burned down in the Solar Storm of 2026. 

By 2027, Suriname is in anarchy, ruled by pirates, gangs, cartels and cannibals. 
French Guiana/Guiana

Official name: Guyane (1989-1992), Brazilian Governorship of Guyane/Governança brasileira da Guiana (1992-2015), New Laos (2015-2019)
Capital: Cayenne 
Government Type: French Overseas Department (until 1989), Far-Right Populist Dictatorship (1989-1992), Military Occupation (1992-2015), Far-Left Confederacy (2015-2019)
Population as of final census conducted: 1,303,465 (Circa 2010)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 300,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $4.562 Billion USD
Primary Language: French
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Mediterranean Economic Alliance (until 1989)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

French Guiana remained one of the last colonial territories of the modern world. During the Vietnam War, many Laotian refugees were resettled to French Guiana, who all integrated themselves into the local culture. The Green Plan was a bit more successful, as help from China modernized their factories and production models. Movements for Guyane independence would actually fizzle out during the 1980s, as the economic splendor of Europe made many want to stay as a part of France. 

The Crash of 1988 forced France to spend billions of Euros to keep French Guiana afloat. On May 31st, 1989, the newly elected PCF President Arlette Pascal legally relinquished France’s claim on the nation, citing it as “imperialist”. Without France to help them, the government of Guyane struggled to maintain a hold on their population. The Hot Summer of 1990 is what finally crippled them, and the military staged a coup to take over the government and prevent total anarchy. 

Guyane, much like Suriname and Guyana, actually had a relatively large amount of arable land, which when coupled with a small population meant that their government could usually keep them fed past the Hot Summer. The main issues were power outages, heatwaves and drought. The far-right military government used extreme force to keep everyone in line, and Guyane survived two years like this until on January 26th, 1992, when Brazil invaded and annexed them. The military had been focusing so hard on maintaining order that they were blindsided when 10 million Brazilians marched across their border and had placed the flag of Imperial Brazil in Cayenne. 

Brazil had to keep their population fed or else risk a Sao Paulo Massacre 2.0, so Guyane was turned into one giant plantation. Occasional uprisings would occur, but would always be beaten down by the Governor of the State, Aurélio Vargas Monteiro. That was, until December 2005, when the Red Hand of Venezuela would ally themselves with the Laotian population of Guyane and they would launch a revolt against Brazil. This revolt escalated into a decade-long guerilla war, which finally ended with the Great Heatwave of 2015 and Brazil retreated. 

Soon the Laotians and their Red Hand allies were facing a new threat: the cartels looking to recoup their losses after the heatwaves. The Red Hand was a bit more successful in establishing communes in Guyane as opposed to Guyana and Suriname, and for a brief period of time Guyane was known as New Laos. 

In 2019, the Provisional Governor of Amapa, Coronel Álvaro Tavares de Moura, attempted to retake Guyana for the rapidly collapsing Brazilian Empire. New Laos requested aid from their allies in Venezuela, but none came, as the Red Hand was busy fighting the remnants of The Cartel. Brazil would fail in their conquest, as a group of pirates would end up destroying what little order remained in New Laos. The Los Hijos del Mar Bravo took over the coast, and after being wiped out by neighboring cartels just a year later, the area once known as Guyane and New Laos would be plagued by warlords trying to exploit the land. The 2026 Solar Storm did nothing to stop the fighting. 

By 2027, the land is still the battleground of feudal warlords, with the Red Hand unlikely to ever honor their promise to help reclaim it. 

Ecuador

Official name: Republic of Ecuador/República del Ecuador (until 1993), Brazilian Governorship of Ecuador/Governo brasileiro do Equador (1993-2023), Free Republic of Ecuador/República Libre del Ecuador (2015-2023, disputed)
Capital: Quito
Government Type: Presidential Republic (1976-1993), Military Occupation 1993-2023)
Population as of final census conducted: 37,049,097 (Circa 2010)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 20,400,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $179.8 Million USD
Primary Language: Ecuadorian Spanish/Español Ecuatoriano
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (1976-1992)
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

Ecuador was one of the few nations to already be in an economic crisis when the Crash of 1988 came around. Initially, they had seen the record growth and hedonistic splendor of the Glorious Decades, only for it to evaporate in 1987. 

Guillermo Rodríguez did not maintain as wide of a supporter base as he did just a few years earlier, and just a few months later, on July 17th, 1972, the military dictatorship collapsed, and was replaced by a far-left junta supported by the USSR and Cuba. This “New Revolutionary Council” initially promised social and economic reforms, such as nationalizing the oil industry in 1973. Yet as the years dragged on, the Council debated on if such a goal was worthwhile, as both China and the USSR had seen rapid changes. This lack of coordinated response doomed the junta, and on January 1st, 1975, the Council officially relinquished their power to a civilian government. Elections were held on November 15th, 1976, and the Social Christian Party’s own Dr. Álvaro Egas Cordero won the presidency. 

President Cordero used the oil revenue funds to bankroll various startups around the country, and by 1979 one of them had risen above all of the rest: El Oro Exportaciones, a banana plantation company that quickly began buying up large swaths of the countryside. EOE expanded their operations, and in 1980 opened their first cacao plantation. President Cordero ensured that their workers were paid very little, and had very few rights, and the price of their products were ludicrously cheap as a result. This won them very close ties with the United States and China, as their products began to be seen all across the world. It was reported in 1981 that Ecuador produced over 70% of the world’s bananas. 

This all fell apart on March 6th, 1987, when three massive earthquakes devastated Napo, Ecuador. The disruption in the economy had a cascading effect, resulting in Ecuador going into a depression. Over 2,000 would die from the earthquakes alone, with almost 20,000 missing or injured. In April 1987, the Ecuadorian government was forced to take out several massive loans from the IMF and China. These loans went to repairing their infrastructure and keeping their exports flowing, as the earthquake had damaged many roads in the northern provinces. President King himself sent several American engineers to help rebuild Ecuador, and more importantly, keep the bananas, cacao and oil flowing. 

So when the Crash of 1988 rolled around, Ecuador was already struggling to get out of their economic depression. They were not hit that hard, as much of their population was still unemployed and the government was in massive debt. Ecuador actually managed to bounce back in 1989 and 1990, selling oil to the desperate nations in the Americas. They weren’t as popular or easily accessible as Venezuela, but for a few months everything seemed like it could go back to the splendor of the 1980s. Rationing had already been introduced in the summer of 1987, so the Hot Summer of 1990 was not as impactful as it was for other nations. 

But because the conservative government had prioritized the economic recovery of the nation instead of the wellbeing of their citizens, and also dedicating plantations to grow large amounts of crops for export that then rotted on drydocks, by 1991 everyone in Ecuador was just barely hanging on. Famines and drought due to mismanagement of land are thought to have been responsible for almost 10,000 deaths throughout 1991-1992. The election of 1992 resulted in a new coalition government between the Ecuadorian Socialist Party and the Democratic Left Party, and their first priority was the restructuring of Ecuador’s agricultural industry and using their leftover oil to fuel their farming equipment. 

This government, despite claiming to have everyone’s best interests in mind, quickly capitulated to Brazil when they came knocking in May of 1993. Brazil then began to exploit Ecuador’s natural resources even more brutally than the conservative government in the Glorious Decades. This of course led to widespread civil unrest, with Ecuadorian collaborators being strung up by mobs and pipelines being sabotaged. They were not organized, however, and Brazil quickly suppressed each one. 

That was until the Red Hand established a Finger in Ecuador, and orchestrated the Ponce Mine Siege of 1999. Further sabotage operations and monkeywrenching made it impossible for Brazil to extract any Ecuadoran petroleum by 2001. And yet, Brazil never tightened their grip on the populace. The Red Hand had forced Brazil to abandon all mining operations by 2002, and as such Ecuador became one giant intensive farming operation. 

Due to its climate, or as some would say, sheer luck, the Brazilian Governorship of Ecuador managed to survive the Great Heatwave of 2015 with their farms barely intact. They were not spared during the Great Heatwave of 2016, though, and plants fried in the oppressive sun all across the country. Extreme weather events and tropical super-storms started to ravage the coast, and by 2017 the western half of the country was completely uninhabitable. 

The remnants of the Brazilian Empire managed to hold on to the eastern half of the state for quite some time, constantly battling incoming Venezuelan revolutionaries and Colombian cartels. On January 1st, 2023, Brazil’s forces finally retreated back into the Amazon Basin, and Ecuador was now its own country once again. This quickly devolved into a civil war between the numerous remaining factions in Ecuador.

As of 2027, Ecuador is still under civil war conditions between far-right fascist collaborators who want to desperately hold on to their power, far-left revolutionaries supported by Venezuela and Argentina, and ruthless cartels who seek to exploit both. 


Photo taken by a journalist of a river outside of Sao Paulo, Brazil, 1991
Brazil

Official name: Federative Republic of Brazil/República Federativa do Brasil (1980-1991), Second Empire of Brazil/Segundo Império do Brasil (1991-2013), Brazilian Emergency Government/Governo de Emergência Brasileiro (2013-2027)
Capital: Brasilia (until 1991), São Paulo (Civilian branch, 1991-2013) and Rio De Janeiro (Military branch, 1991-2027) 
Government Type: Federal Republic (1980-1991), Far Right Military Junta (1991-2027)
Population as of final census conducted: 423,694,861 (Circa 2010), 688,030,405 (total population of all occupied territories)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 300,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $1.89 Trillion USD
Primary Language: Brazilian Portuguese/Português Brasileiro
Member of the Alliance of Nations: YES
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (until 1991)
Great Death Survival Rating: Remnant

Brazil remained a military dictatorship at the signing of the Shanghai Accords, but the policies of “abertura” and “distensão” were much more successful, leading to the military’s authority to rapidly decline by 1975. Access to cheap, reliable oil kept the economy functioning smoothly, though the country remained relatively closed off during the 1970s. The military junta held on for dear life, as they were desperate to keep their power. With Asia seen as stable for the time being after the signing of the Hanoi Armistice on April 1st, 1975, Washington, DC turned their focus on the Americas and maintaining a peaceful region to conduct business in. Panama was already under control by the United Nations by that point, and one of President Morgan’s first goals in office was to keep South America in a state acceptable to the new world order. 

From June 1st-7th, 1977, the United States held a bilateral summit with Brazil’s President Ernesto Geisel. President Morgan, speaking as if he was some wise father giving his son advice, urged President Geisel to consider opening up Brazil more. The communists of China were no longer their enemies, but their greatest trading partners, and soon the USSR would follow suit. By 2000, he had said, communism would be completely extinct, with everyone living lives of splendor and wealth. 

The summit ended up going nowhere, and despite the growing viewpoint that the military was seen as unnecessary as the Korean Detente continued and the Vietnam War officially ended, the government reasserted themselves as the only thing keeping Brazil together. Widespread protests in 1978 and 1979 and a constantly nosediving approval rating forced the government to reluctantly authorize a referendum on returning Brazil to civilian rule. This was of course a ruse, and the military junta rigged the vote in their favor. This was heavily criticized, and only after the threat of an invasion by an international US-led coalition did the military relent and back down. 

On October 29th, 1980, Brazil held their first free election in decades. President Morgan attended the election to ensure it was free and fair, and after MDB candidate Dr. Renato Borges de Alencar won, President Morgan congratulated him on securing the presidency and hoped that Brazil and the United States could work together for the prosperity of both of their countries. Dr. de Alencar ran on a platform on opening up trade and signing the Shanghai Accords, and also tackling the rising crime rate that was plaguing much of Latin America. 

President de Alencar made good on his promise, and within his first 50 days in office he worked closely with President Morgan to integrate Brazil into the United Nations Anti-Drug Task Force. Throughout 1981, Brazil opened up several bases for the UNADTF, and conducted numerous drug raids in the slums of Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo. As Brazil opened up and became a part of the global community, their economy skyrocketed, quickly becoming the richest country in South America behind Uruguay. To compete with the other giants of the world, Brazil expanded their space program on March 1st, 1982. China would work closely with Brazil, signing an exclusive petroleum deal on the one-year anniversary of the expansion of their space program. Chinese technicians would train Brazilian scientists and test data was shared between the two nations, blossoming into Brazil joining the International Station for Cooperation and Friendship. 

Soon China became an even closer ally to Brazil than the United States, and factories and industrial parks sprung up across the southern regions of Brazil. China ended up building three SIZ in Brazil: one in Belo Horizonte, one in Vitoria, and one in Janaúba. Captured criminals were sent to serve their sentence working in the sweatshops, at China’s suggestion. Dr. Renato Borges de Alencar was reelected in the 1984 election, and his new administration was even harsher on crime and open to industrialization. Throughout 1985, almost half of the Amazon Rainforest was auctioned off to logging companies and pharmaceutical companies. President de Alencar’s administration was even more rabid against drug trafficking, and was one of the countries to participate in the June 11th, 1986 raid that killed Pablo Escobar. Brazil would have much to celebrate, as the detective who deduced where he was hiding was a Brazilian: Agent Augusto Fernando César. His unique mind led the investigation out of Mexico and into Colombia. Agent César quickly became the most requested agent in the UNADTF’s operations, and President de Alencar allowed him to help in investigations in exchange for political favors. These off the record deals led to Brazil’s police receiving the most advanced military equipment available at the time, and the US worked very closely with Brazil in carrying out drug busts throughout South America in the late 1980s. Brazil’s space program was also going very smoothly, as their space program made their first successful orbit on April 23rd, 1987. 

But then the Crash of 1988 happened, and Brazil desperately tried to stay as a rising power. Soon the UNADTF fell apart, with Agent César retiring to being just a policeman again. Countries around Brazil started to enter a decline, and with many countries suddenly now extremely protectionist, the booming economy crashed. PSP candidate Ulysses José Franco, after platforming on a campaign of social programs while also encouraging trade with other nations, narrowly won the 1988 presidency. In practice though, many of the programs fell through due to corruption and mismanagement, causing the black market to become almost a quarter of Brazil’s remaining economy. Like other countries, the Franco administration continued business as usual and expected the Crash to resolve itself in a few years. Some criticized him as being a communist like Gutierrez in Mexico, while others said he wasn’t going far enough. 

President Franco, trying to stop the spread of the “Argentine Mistake”, began sending huge amounts of foreign aid to Paraguay to keep their economy afloat. This caused many in the country to doubt his intentions. With each package of aid sent, be it medicine, food, water, or industrial equipment, Argentina would send a bigger shipment to one-up Brazil and curry more favor with Paraguay. It only finally stopped when President Franco was threatened with impeachment for sending over one billion reals worth of industrial supplies to Paraguay. 

The Hot Summer of 1990 put Brazil to the test, and they failed. Civil unrest rose to an all-time high, despite the rampant and extremely militarized police force. All the way to the end of 1990, President Franco held over a hundred trade summits with other countries, hoping to rekindle international trade, but all of them turned out fruitless. This was further exacerbated when on November 2nd, 1990, Brazil spent almost a billion reals on a failed orbital launch. President Franco then gave a long-winded speech on how Brazil needs to be hopeful, and that if they cannot manage to reach the stars, then what hope do they have of maintaining a good trading relationship with the other nations when the depression is over?

Morale was at an all time low, as hundreds deserted their posts in the military and police. Almost every major city was under martial law, and more factories shut down every day. Unemployment was reaching record numbers, and even a rent freeze did not put an end to the army of homeless that grew every day. Brazil was a powder keg, and soon something would cause the whole system to come crashing down, completely. The answer was, what would cause it to happen?

The answer came on January 20th, 1991, in a slum outside Sao Paulo. A government-controlled warehouse was found to be empty of their stock (a corrupt officer had probably sold the emergency food rations for a quick real) and a riot ensued. The heavily armed and over-militarized police opened fire on the crowd and ended up killing 230 people. President Franco didn’t have that much to say on it, calling it “regrettable” and hoped that in the future, horrible situations like this could be avoided. While he authorized the building of large farms in the remains of the Amazon Forest, opposition leader César Henrique Morales used it as a talking point. He said that the massacre was proof that the far-left model didn’t work, and that it was the President's fault that the crime rate had gotten so bad. Franco’s administration was painted as corrupt and incompetent, and if Brazil is going to get better, they must return to their roots: an anti-communist dictatorship. Morales further promised to completely rid Brazil of all crime, as criminals would be forced to work in the northern farms, and for more violent crimes, put to death. 

Morales quickly gained support across the entire nation, and calls to impeach President Franco grew and grew until on March 15, 1991 the opposition impeached President Franco. The next day, the Brazilian State Police executed Ulysses José Franco by hanging, as investigations by Agent Augusto Fernando César claimed to have found evidence of drug deals and corruption within the Franco administration. Over the next few weeks, Brazil was reformed into a military junta once again. 

However, this new military dictatorship operated in a unique way: there were essentially two dictators, one for civilian and internal affairs and one for military and external affairs. On April 9, 1991, César Henrique Morales proclaimed himself the civilian leader of Brazil, ruling in Sao Paulo, while Augusto Fernando César became the military leader of Brazil, ruling from Rio de Janeiro. To solidify his power, Morales removed the power of the states and Brazil was now an “empire” as opposed to a federation. 

Morales, now simply taking on the title of “leader”, passionately warned his people that the leftist chaos in Argentina and Uruguay would spread no further, and Brazil would become a beacon against communism where places like the United States had failed. Leader Morales created the “neighborhood watches”, and tasked them to always be on the lookout for drug runners and “Argentine spies”. Meanwhile, Minister César started recruiting large amounts of unemployed Brazilians into the military and police, with incentives such as access to clean water, air conditioning and reliable food. 

It was all a stop-gap measure though, as those in power knew that Brazil could not sustain its population without another Sao Paulo massacre happening. So, why not expand Brazil’s arable land? asked Leader Morales. He then proposed to Minister César to create a plan to prevent the spread of communism in Latin America, stop drugs from taking over the slums of Brazil, and at the same time ensure that Brazil would never have a ration riot again. 

This plan came into fruition on August 12th, 1991, when Brazil launched a surprise invasion of their neighbor, Peru. Peru had recently been taken over by the Shining Path Maoists and turned Peru into a hideous communist state, and so Leader Morales led the charge in putting their neighbors on the right path. Due to the brutality of the Shining Path and their myriad of sub-factions, the people of Peru were actually grateful that Brazil had come and saved them from the Maoists. Peru collaborated willingly, for the most part, and on January 5th, 1992, Peru officially became a new state of the Second Empire of Brazil. 

This resulted in severe backlash in the United Nations, as other states, notably the USSR and Australia called the act “monsterous” and an act of international war. Ambassador Álvaro Tavares Coutinho, speaking on behalf of Brazil, defended the action and blamed the United States’s capitulation to communist China as the reason why geopolitics in the Middle East were the way they were, and resulted in the Crash of 1988. In short, he blamed communism on the reason why Peru was now a part of Brazil. 

Then on October 29th, 1991, Brazil intervened in the Bolivian Civil War by backing up the fascist faction that controlled North Bolivia. Negotiations between Leader Morales and the general of the Bolivian State, Rodolfo Quiroga Salvatierra, started off on the signing of a formal alliance between the two nations. But on November 2nd, 1991, General Salvatierra was found dead. Brazil immediately claimed it was the result of the Argentine-supported socialists to the south, and annexed the Bolivian State to prevent the further spread of communism. The Bolivian State was just as eager to fight the communists in South Bolivia and thus enjoyed a relative degree of autonomy compared to the later territorial acquisitions of Brazil. The Brazilian Governorship of Bolivia and the Second Empire of Brazil both worked tirelessly for four years to wipe out the rebels in the South, but they were never able to destroy their stronghold in Eduardo Abaroa. 

Emboldened by their victories in Peru and North Bolivia, Leader Morales authorized the "reclamation" of Brazilian property that President Franco had illegally given to Paraguay as foreign aid. The operation took place concurrently with the South Bolivian Campaign, and while Brazil initially made rapid progress and was close to taking Asunción, Argentina came to their rescue and turned the invasion into a stalemate. Minister César was a bit smarter than his counterpart and knew that Brazil could never actually claim Paraguay, so the goal instead became to turn it into a neutral buffer state between Communist Argentina and Imperial Brazil. 

Even with the new resources coming in from North Bolivia and Peru, Brazil was still teetering on the brink of total starvation. They had used almost a quarter of their remaining petroleum in their military operations in 1991 alone, and soon they wouldn’t be able to defend Brazil, let alone run her farming equipment. Minister César had been eyeing the anarchy in Venezuela for some time, and was waiting for them to be at their most vulnerable. Meanwhile, on January 26th, 1992, Brazil invaded Guyane, annexing them by the end of the summer. It was from the draconian prison farms in Brazilian Guyane that Brazil managed to avoid a food shortage in 1992. Then on October 8th, 1992, Brazil would turn to Suriname and annex them. The new resources from their new states led to a gradual increase in living conditions around Brazil, and the approval for the military dictatorship was at an all-time high. 

Seeing the socialist coalition government that had formed in Ecuador, Brazil, aided by Peruvian anti-communists, invaded Ecuador on May 4th, 1993. The coalition government quickly surrendered and negotiated to keep as much of their power as they could. Leader Morales initially objected to this and planned to have them executed, however Minister César persuaded him not to, as this would direct the rage of the Ecuadorians to their collaborators who had sold them out, and not to the invading Brazilians. The oil from Ecuador helped supplement Brazil’s supplies, and intensive farming operations throughout the Amazon basin led to a surplus in food production for the first time in years. The oil was also used to fuel the Brazilian war machine in the South Bolivia and Paraguay campaigns but neither operation saw any notable progress on the Brazilian’s side. 

On May 15th, 1994, Brazil’s forces were routed during the Battle of Salto del Guairá and fully pulled out of Paraguay. Minister César personally executed the colonel in charge of the garrison, and began the construction of a fortified border wall along parts of the Paraguayan, Bolivian, Argentine and Uruguayan borders with Brazil. Of this colossal task, only the parts along the Paraguayan border were completed, and even then, the wall completely crumbled by 2013 due to continued erosion and rampant flooding. This defeat forced Brazil to also rethink their strategies regarding South Bolivia, and planned to fully withdraw by January 1st, 1996. 

On August 26th, 1995, in preparation for their operation to take Venezuela and their oil, Brazil invaded Guyana and kicked out the Venezuelan occupiers. Guyana was eager to collaborate, and as such, they were granted a relative amount of autonomy. Ruthless exploitation and intensive farming prevented any famines in Brazil during 1995, but drought started to become a common problem. The civilian government began digging community wells for ground water, and several old industrial facilities were retooled to become water purification plants. Water was, of course, used as a reward: loyalty to the New Party of Brazil guaranteed access to fresh food, meat products, and water. Housing was also based on one's loyalty to the party: many low-ranking officials had nice, clean apartments with air conditioning and proper insulation, while high-ranking officials had entire mansions to themselves, all furnished with resources plundered from the governorships. 

When Brazil fully pulled out of South Bolivia, the dictatorship began to draft up plans for the invasion of Venezuela and later Colombia. On July 7th, 1996, Brazil began the invasion of Venezuela. Brazil ended up invading with a force of almost 35 million soldiers. They took a gamble and reduced their presence in their occupied territories and along the border wall, but it paid off - with every refinery and oil well captured, Brazil’s military power grew exponentially. Soon they were engaging in carpet bombing campaigns and naval blockades, chasing the Colombians out of Venezuela by 1997 and officially annexing Venezuela on January 28th, 1998. 

On February 1st, 1997, speaking in front of the Imperial Mansion in Sao Paulo, Leader Morales announced that he had succeeded in his first promise: he had wiped out the spectre of communism in not just Brazil, but in all of her neighbors as well (both Paraguay and Uruguay were not full on communists yet). He had dared to go where the United States was too scared to go - actively attacking communism -  and had he had been in power in the 1980s, he would never have let the Egyptian Coalition and their communist allies destroy Israel. He now touted the new Brazilian Empire as stronger than the United States, stronger than the USSR, and stronger than China. But now he tackled a new stage in his plan: to wipe out drug traffickers, cartels and smugglers. 

Immediately after this speech, Brazil launched an invasion of Colombia. This invasion was not as intensive as Venezuela, as Brazil was far more cautious and kept a large part of their force in Venezuela as they protected their refineries that kept their war machine running and people fed. By 1998, Colombia was on the defensive and was desperately trying to keep Brazil out of Bogota. Losses were heavy on both sides, but due to Brazil’s genius propaganda and control of the state media, young men enlisted by the millions every month. For every Brazilian soldier the Colombians killed, two more would replace him. A popular recruiting poster depicted a massive graveyard, with Minister César shedding a single tear, captioned with “IT COULD END WITH YOU!”. 

On March 7th, 1998, Brazil joined the Alliance of Nations. As the Alliance of Nations had no hard power and was essentially a forum for ambassadors to shout at each other, Brazil’s ambassador Álvaro Tavares Coutinho defended the actions of Brazil as bringing stability and peace to the chaotic land of Latin America. Despite their position just a few years ago, the USSR and China now supported Brazil’s actions, using them to justify their own territorial expansions. 

In summer of 1998, Brazil embarked on an amphibious landing campaign, launching ships from Ecuador and landing on several sections of Colombia’s coast. This would end up having disastrous results, as chaotic and unpredictable waves made the transportation of troops extremely risky and Brazil was forced to fight their way into Bogota. Troops became bogged down and entrenched, with bombing runs no longer being viable due to the sheer number of possible friendly fire incidents. Quartermasters were reporting ammunition shortages despite supply lines remaining intact, and the Imperial Army of Brazil began a formal investigation into possible sabotage and theft. They concluded that the Red Hand, an anarchist group from Venezuela, were behind the sabotage. They were proven right, as the Ponce Mine Siege in Ecuador happened just a few months later in April 1999. This led to the El Tigre Siege that resulted in “Six” being killed. 

Leader Morales was furious when he learned of the siege, and ordered the State Police of Brazil to investigate this supposed rebel group. And rather than risk defeat like in South Bolivia and Paraguay, Minister César began a grueling scorched earth campaign to take Colombia. In October of 1999, Brazil had finally encircled Bogota and waited for the government to be strung up by its own starving citizens. 

On March 8th, 2000, Gran Colombia officially surrendered, and an armistice was negotiated. Brazil allowed the Colombians a small degree of autonomy, but in actuality, it was because they were exhausted and close to running out of resources. Sabotages and monkeywrenching operations from across the empire were adding up, and the efficiency of the Brazilian army was increasingly in question. 

On top of that, the climate was alternating between dizzying heatwaves and torrential rain, resulting in many buildings falling apart and infrastructure being damaged. Rolling brown outs had started in 1997, progressing to blackouts in 1998 and by 1999 the power was off more often than it was not. If this had happened before the Crash of 1988, the government could simply contract a company from overseas to come fix it, but that was not an option anymore. 

Leader Morales and his advisors struggled to find an easy fix for the problem, as they had no more countries to invade as a distraction. Their people were fed, yes, but that was only until the Venezuelan oil ran out and even then, many of the crops were destroyed by the humidity. Their answer came in the fall of 2000, as China offered to help “modernize” their equipment, for a fee. Leader Morales knew that if his people knew he was working with China, it would ruin him, so he went to great lengths to keep the identity of their “collaborators” a secret. With China’s help, Brazil’s energy sector was revitalized and intensive mining operations began in areas where agriculture was no longer possible. Factories were opened up again, and slowly Brazil’s infrastructure began to be rebuilt. 

Forest fires, drought and famine started to affect the productivity of the occupied territories, and in 2002, Peru would launch an uprising. Fires burned and farms crumbled to ashes, and Brazil mobilized a division in Acre to supplement their forces in occupied Peru. By the time Brazil’s reinforcements had rolled in to help regain order, they had learned it was merely a distraction and that the real target had been the refineries in Venezuela all along. The Red Hand had destroyed Brazil’s access to oil, and soon much of Venezuela burned with it. Brazil’s military was crippled, but Minister César had foreseen such a possibility: back in 1996, while drawing up the plan to invade Venezuela, the Minister ordered the military to start researching on how to build a nuclear bomb. Part of their secret deals in 2000 included negotiating for a nuclear bomb from China, to which they reluctantly agreed to. 

When the Venezuelan Uprising happened, the Brazilian Bomb became the worst-kept secret in the empire. Both dictators made sure to mention it at every possibility, and to make sure that any would-be rebels knew that they risked death by nuclear fire if they tried anything too drastic. What many did not know was that the nuclear bomb was actually not even functional (China knew it was stupid to give a foreign nation a functional nuclear warhead) and that the government of Brazil was going to great lengths to get it working. 

As the oil began to run out, Brazil enacted strict fuel rationing, with most fuel by 2005 being saved solely for military vehicles and for the transportation of supplies. Farming equipment was slowly retrofitted to use coal or steam power instead of oil, and pollution began to choke the skies of South America once again. But for the most part, everyone tolerated the increasing authoritarianism of the dictators. Leader Morales had started to get a massive ego, insisting he be referred to as “Emperor” and even reportedly executing a man for not bowing to him. To help cut back on food costs, as there was less food every year, the guards in prisons and labor camps began to mix the corpses of the dead into the slop they would feed their prisoners. Almost a decade of propaganda had made the people of Brazil view the Red Hand, Argentina and other communists as less than human, and some even took a sick joy in watching the prisoners eat, unaware that they were devouring their comrades. 

The first cracks began to show on December 11th, 2005, when the Red Hand launched another uprising, this time in Guyane. The deteriorating climate and the lack of reliable transportation meant that Brazil risked another Sao Paulo massacre, and so sent in a massive force to retake Guyane. Brazilians across the nation started to die mysterious deaths, and investigations found that it was due to food poisoned by the rebels in Guyane. On February 5th, 2006, Brazil was forced to reduce ration allowances for the first time since 1991. Meat was no longer readily available for everyone outside Morales’s inner circle, and most were reduced to eating vegetarian feijoada. After a food riot in summer of 2007, permanent curfews were enacted to help "ascertain communist collaborators”. Pollution from the Chinese machinery started to corrupt the ground water around Brazil, and many fell ill after drinking the tainted water. Brazil was quickly running out of resources, and to save the rapidly shrinking medical resources, Morales authorized the creation of “mercy doctors”, roaming government agents who would euthanize the sick and elderly under the guise of taking them to some nondescript hospital somewhere in the countryside. Anyone who suggested that the government was murdering them was actually an agent of the Red Hands, afterall! Then, when the Red Flu started to tour Brazil after being spread by Chinese visitors, the government denied any pandemic was happening and that the Red Hand were making up rumors to frighten the good citizens of Brazil. 

For most of 2008 and 2009, Brazil’s government was pulling their hair out trying to stop the spread of the Red Flu. The tainted ground water had made many people’s immune systems weakened, and the Red Flu thrived in the slums of Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. Minister César was playing wack-a-mole with the Red Hands, chasing them up and down the continent trying to track down their new leader. And all the while, Morales stayed holed up in his palace, high off his mind on Bromista and eating lavish feasts of beef and chicken as millions starved to death or died of the Red Flu.

On October 10th, 2009, with Brazil too tired and exhausted from chasing the Red Hand from Tacna to Cayenne, the Colombian uprising began. This was the beginning of the end for Brazil, as the demoralized and hopeless troops of Brazil fought only for their lives. Morales threw hundreds of thousands of lives away trying to regain Colombia (and his source of Bromista), and for almost a year and a half Minister César tried to take back Colombia. After the storm of March 27th, 2011, he realized that it was a lost cause and that Brazil was in its decline. He began to covertly send fewer and fewer reinforcements to Colombia, and secretly began to stockpile weapons and supplies in several bunkers throughout the Amazon Basin. Morales was becoming dangerously unstable, and César knew that he was no longer the charismatic strongman he once was in the 1990s. When Morales asked where he was going, he always claimed it was a lead on the Red Hand. 

Throughout 2012 and 2013, César silently prepared for a coup against Morales, completely pulling out of Colombia by January 1st of 2013. The occupied territories were worked to the bone as the threat of famine loomed. But on May 20th, 2013, César was truthful when he said he was leaving to pursue a lead about the Red Hand. “Thirteen” had voluntarily turned himself in at the Governor’s Palace in Venezuela, and he immediately left. César had long awaited this day, as he could finally put a bullet in the brain of the man who had been a thorn in his side for over a decade. Minister César was already in nearby Boa Vista, and so made the 24 hour journey to Caracas. 

It is unknown exactly what had happened during that day of reckoning, but Brazil leveled the city by June. Morales was expected to make a speech about the death of his friend and fellow dictator, unaware that he was plotting against him, but Morales was too inebriated to say the speech that was prepared for him, let alone show his face in public for risk of assassination. His advisors called him an imbecile, which turned into a shouting match and that was when César’s conspirators decided to execute their plan. Key members of the government, such as the Deputy of Food, the Deputy of Energy, and the Deputy of Justice seized control of various military bases. Others decided to side with Morales, as even though they had plotted against him, they knew that they were unlikely to win without César’s ruthless ingenuity. Morales was ferried to one of César’s bunkers in Redenção, and it was here that he stayed for the next four years, oscillating between being mournfully lucid and gleefully high, having endless orgies with his imperial concubines.

The Brazilian Civil War officially started on June 1st, 2013, when César’s forces attacked a government stronghold outside of Brasília. The Deputy of Propaganda kept up appearances, siding with Morales, and made César’s faction into an underground terrorist group much like the Red Hand. This was only feasible for so long, as on October 9th, 2013, a massive forest fire devastated Suriname and forced Brazil to cut their losses and retreat. Many of the returning soldiers joined César’s faction and started pillaging supply lines out of Guyana and Guyane. Martial law was declared throughout the entire country and sabotage caused the electrical infrastructure to permanently turn off across much of the region. Communications began to break down, and as the plundered resources from the occupied regions dried up, many in Brazil rose up with a Red Hand of vengeance. Far-left guerrilla groups sprung up in every city overnight, and members of the Red Hand from Venezuela began to train Brazilians in the art of guerilla warfare. 

Cities became prisons as the two factions of the government fought to keep their citizens in check. Hit-and-run tactics became suicide bombings, sabotage turned into full on destruction, and many cities along the coast were now controlled by neither faction but the citizens that inhabited them. The Brazilian People’s Army, aided by the Red Hand, made both the Loyalists and the Militarists run in fear. As more and more garrisons were recalled to help the fight in the heartland, the occupied territories began to rebel. The Governor of Peru, General Augusto Ferreira Lobo, was executed by a mob of starving Red Hand insurgents on January 21st, 2014, and it descended into a civil war. Only the northern half of it remained loyal to Brazil until February 7th, 2017, when Argentina came in to support the Peruvian communists. 

The first Great Heat Wave crippled Brazil, and almost 20 million died as a result of famine and dehydration. Soon, people joined the various factions of the civil war not over who they agreed with ideologically, but based on who was able to feed them at the time. Allegiances changed every season. Argentina, seeing how much Brazil had fractured in just a year, invaded the former states of Rio Grande do Sul and Santa Catarina. Brazil was forced to abandon both Guyana and Guyane in 2015, and the western half of Ecuador in 2016. The State of Bolivia was finally lost in 2017. 2017 was a turning point in the Civil War, as Morales was finally assassinated by one of his own men on July 7, 2017. No one was really leading either of the factions by this point, and they were fighting solely for the hatred they felt for the other side, which they viewed as subhuman traitors on the same level of Red Hand communists. 

By 2018, the military government only controlled the former states of Amazonas, Pará, Amapá, Tocantins, Goiás, Minas Gerais, and Rio de Janiero, along with parts of Ecuador, though they quickly became completely cut off by summer of 2018. Much of the eastern coast, between São Luis and Salvador, became a loose alliance of anarchistic city-states, and in between the two military governments and the anarchists, cartels took advantage of the chaos in the no man’s land. In the former state of Roraima, influenced by the Colombian and Central American Cartels, a group would form, calling themselves the Sons of the Amazon. They disrupted the fragile supply lines that supplied both factions of the military and the Red Hand aligned anarchists, and deals were struck with various powerful cartels. Brazilian military equipment and ammunition depots were sold off for Bromista and other drugs, and the members of Morales’s loyalist faction began selling their prisoners to the Sons of the Amazon in exchange for resupplies, unaware that they were buying back their own material. 

The Sons of the Amazon lived up to their name and eventually controlled the remains of the Amazon river, which had been broken up into thousands of tributaries for irrigation back in the early 1990s under Franco, and thus made an effective network to smuggle supplies across the entire country. Supplies covertly sent by Argentina to the Red Hand rebels were seized by the Sons of the Amazon and sold to the highest bidder, usually other cartels. When they had enough manpower, the Sons of the Amazon took over the last remaining functional ships in Brazil’s navy, and harassed every city near the water. The dramatic increase of floods resulted in this form of neo-piracy to be remarkably effective, at least in the sense that they disrupted the three warring factions vying for control of what was once the most powerful nation in Latin America during the 21st Century. 

In 2019, things had become increasingly desperate for the people in South America. Those that weren’t under the drug-induced grip of Bromista were facing chronic famines and flooding that routinely destroyed any hope for large-scale agricultural efforts. Rationing had gotten so strict in the coastal communes that underground “meat rings” had to be shut down by the People’s Army. The Military faction was doing slightly better, as the stockpiled rations meant that those in the command bunkers were barely scraping by, and shady deals with the cartels for food supplies became more and more common. The most common of these smuggled rations were crackers supposedly from the USA and dry, crumbly bars from Europe. 

After the failed attempt to retake Guyane in early 2019, supply lines finally broke down across the entire region controlled by the military remnants and facing severe famine, reports began to circulate of soldiers cannibalizing their dead comrades in arms. The coastal cities finally began to see a slight recovery in late 2019 when Argentina began escorting their shipments with entire navy fleets, and while everyone on the rebel coast was forced to become a vegan, very few starved to death now. 

In March of 2020, the ragged remnants of the two military factions signed a truce and joined forces, realizing that if they continued fighting each other, none of them could ever retake the coast. By now, their forces were just a few isolated bunkers in rural areas supported by several dozen barely functioning military bases. Much of the land north of the original Amazon river was no-man's land, now controlled by the Sons of the Amazon. Coronel Estêvão Nogueira Bastos, the self-appointed Commander of the Brazilian Emergency Government, stopped trying to retake their lost land and instead focused on defending what they still held on to. This led to a policy of “wait and see”, where the crippled military and their loyalist allies (numbering less than 10 million by this point) provoked conflict between the Sons of the Amazon, the Cartels, and the Red Hand rebels and scavenged what they could from the aftermath of the battles. 

The Emergency Government operated like this for the next two years, becoming the new guerillas as they evaded and stole from the cartels and communists. The new equipment from Argentina, plus the Emergency Government recovering their old material from Sons of the Amazon strongholds, resulted in the Sons being wiped out by the end of 2022. This was not the end of the chaos, though, as cartels from Colombia and Central America started to plunder the badlands between the two factions. In the Great Heatwave of 2023 and 2024, almost 50 million would die from dehydration and famine in what was once Brazil. All that Coronel Bastos had regained in the past five years was wiped out, and to further expand their influence, Argentina had begun sending members of their army to help train and reinforce the guerillas along the coast. Coronel Bastos later committed suicide on May 19th, 2026, and with that, the Emergency Government began to rapidly lose ground. Many soldiers in the shrinking Auxiliary Army of the Emergency Government defected to the People’s Coast or deserted entirely, starting bandit gangs of their own. Others joined the cartels. But enough remained to carry on the mission of re-uniting Brazil again, but not under a communist flag. In the aftermath of the Solar Storm of 2026, entire fields were lit on fire and computer systems failed. Radiation began to leak out of several military-controlled bunkers, and the last of the Emergency Government fled to Rio de Janeiro. 

As of 2027, the civil war is reaching its conclusion, with the siege of Rio de Janeiro entering its 2nd month. 
Peru

Official name: Republic of Peru/República del Perú (until 1988), Popular Republic of Peru/República Popular del Perú (1988-1991), Brazilian Governorship of Peru/Governo Brasileiro do Peru (1991-2014), Argentine Mandate of Peru/Mandato Argentino del Perú (2017-2025)
Capital: Lima (until 2011), Huancayo (2011-2027)
Government Type: Presidential Republic (1974-1988), Far Left Military Junta (1988-1991), Military Occupation (1991-2025)
Population as of final census conducted: 68,149,568 (Circa 2010)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 38,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $329.78 Million USD	
Primary Language: Peruvian Spanish/Español Peruano
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: World Prosperity Alliance (until 1991)
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

After the signing of the Shanghai Accords, both China and the United States worked together to negotiate with Alvarado to end his dictatorship, and lead them away from communism. Alvarado resisted this idea, and frequently lambasted both President Nixon and Chairman Chen. But as news of the wealth and prosperity from the outside world trickled in, he began to lose a grip on his power. On October 12th, 1974, Alvarado was deposed in a coup orchestrated by supporters of former president Fernando Belaúnde. Over the next five months, Peru was returned to civilian rule. 

Belaúnde won the 1975 Presidency in a landslide, and worked closely with both the United States and China to integrate Peru into this new prosperous world. This resulted in Peru and China signing a lucrative mineral deal in 1976, which helped revitalize the Peruvian economy. Using the United Nations Anti-Drug Task Force, Peru began to round up and arrest suspected leftists. 

This only further emboldened the remaining leftists, and in 1980, Fernando Ibáñez del Castillo won the presidency, campaigning on a harsh stance against the Shining Path and the growing crime rate. In 1981, after signing a treaty of mutual defense and joining the World Prosperity Alliance, China would send members of their Anti-Maoist Insurgency Corps to help Peru tackle the Shining Path. In 1985, Alberto Cisneros Valverde would win the Presidency, and while he was just as tough on drugs and Maoists as his two predecessors, he also wanted to turn Peru into a shining beacon of capitalism and international cooperation. He took out huge loans from the United States, the European Union, China, the IMF and even Brazil to begin gargantuan construction projects. Three massive skyscrapers were planned, and a massive expansion of Lima into the sea using man-made islands was also drafted up, though it never made it past the drawing board. The world's largest football stadium was also being built outside of Lima. 

Despite the promise of lucrative job opportunities and massive monuments that would surely place Peru as the Eighth Wonder of the World, poor planning and countless setbacks led to construction to begin in late 1987, rapidly increasing inflation and finally creating an economic depression in May of 1988. When the nukes dropped in the Middle East, only the football stadium had started construction. 

None of the mega projects would ever be completed, as Peru’s government would violently collapse on July 3rd, 1988, with the Shining Path guerillas taking over. This new government was far more radical than even Alvarado’s administration, and throughout 1988 and 1989 the Popular Republic of Peru engaged in a series of widespread land reforms. Corporations were nationalized, banks became owned by the state, and the richest people in the country were killed and lynched by mobs. Many in Peru were at first fine with this new government, as they blamed Valverde for their rapid decline in living standards. But when the Glorious Path of Peru, referred to by many as simply “the New Shining Path”, started picking off their more moderate opposition in addition to the rich, people began to second guess their faith in this new regime. The GPP began to cut rations as a result, letting only their most fanatical and loyal members receive the best food available. 

Even that would not last, as the Hot Summer of 1990 caused widespread famine and crop failure. In March of 1990, the GPP fractured into a dozen smaller groups, each with their own idea on how to bring communism to Peru. The country then descended into a brutal and chaotic civil war, with almost 23 groups at one point. August 12th, 1991 marked the end of this conflict, as the newly formed Second Empire of Brazil quickly invaded and pacified Peru. Those that had survived the cataclysmic civil war actually welcomed the Brazilians with open arms, and many of Valverde’s government who had escaped the purges voluntarily collaborated with Brazil, leading to their official annexation on January 5th, 1992. 

Through strict rationing and intensive agriculture, Peru managed to avoid any major famines throughout the rest of the 1990s. Brazil would invest heavily in mining operations throughout the 1990s, trying to get the last precious metals in the region. The Red Hand slowly infiltrated the various occupied territories of Brazil, and Peru was no exception, though they had to tone down their operations significantly due to how the public remembered the Glorious Path. 

Brazilian-occupied Peru remained relatively stable throughout the 1990s, with the first signs of trouble appearing in the 21st Century when forest fires destroyed hundreds of farms in 2001. Pollution and tainted ground water from Brazil’s mining operations also led to a major famine in 2002, and on July 9th, 2002, the Red Hand’s diversionary uprising would occur in Peru. This forced Brazil to crack down hard on Peru, removing what little autonomy they had left. Throughout the 2000s, less and less land was able to be used for farming, and as a result, cartels began to exploit the unemployed. Peru was the site of a massive Bromista smuggling operation by The Cartel, and the Panamanian Syndicate also had some dealings there. A group of former Glorious Path guerillas, forced to turn to banditry to survive, became known as the Red Column cartel and frequently fought the other two cartels for control of Peru’s coast. 

The Red Column’s influence only grew after March 1st, 2009, when the last Brazilian mining operation shut down. The three cartels had used abandoned mine shafts as safehouses to smuggle their goods into Brazil, and now they practically had free reign over the Peruvian part of the Andes. It would soon turn out to be not the blessing as they had hoped it would be, as throughout 2010 and 2011 severe storms would force Brazil to abandon the coast of Peru, relocating the capital to Huancayo. The ruins of the Belaúnde Football Stadium were swallowed up by the raging sea. The Panamanian Syndicate abandoned their operations when Lima flooded, and The Cartel followed suit in 2012, leaving the Red Column as the main criminal force in Peru. The Red Column and the Red Hand frequently fought each other, vying for control of the region. 

During the Brazilian Civil War, Peru remained loyal to Brazil, until on January 21st, 2014 their governor was assassinated by Red Hand insurgents. Civil war engulfed Peru yet again, this time between pro-Brazilian collaborators, Red Hand guerillas, and various cartels including the Red Column. This civil war was not as chaotic as the last one, thankfully, as the Great Heat Waves of 2015 and 2016 caused a temporary, unspoken truce between the factions. In 2017, Argentina began to help supply the Red Hand guerillas and their Peruvian cell. The Red Column was wiped out by the Sons of the Amazon in 2018, and by 2020, all of the pro-Brazilian forces had either been killed or retreated into Brazil itself, where they joined César’s forces. In the 2020s, the civil war had changed to the Argentine-backed Red Hand of Peru fighting a splinter faction of the Sons of the Amazon and numerous bandits. The Second Great Heatwaves of 2023 and 2024 finally forced Argentina to withdraw their support. The Solar Storm of 2026 caused major communication blackouts across Peru, leading to major gains by the cartels. 

By 2027, Peru has collapsed into warlordism and anarchy. 
Bolivia

(Flag credit)
Official name: Republic of Bolivia/República de Bolivia (1985-1990), Bolivian State/Estado Boliviano (North, 1990-1992), Bolivian Governorship/Governação Boliviana (North, 1992-2017), People’s Republic of Bolivia/República Popular de Bolivia (South, 1990-2001), Autonomous People’s Republic of Bolivia/República Popular Autónoma de Bolivia (North: 2017-2027, South: 2001-2027)
Capital: Sucre (1985-1990, South: 1990-2027), La Paz (North: 1990-2027)
Government Type: Presidential Republic (1985-1990), Far Right Authoritarian Dictatorship (North, 1990-1992), Military Occupation (North, 1992-2017), Far Left Military Junta (South, 1990-2001), Autonomous Republic of Argentina (North: 2017-2027, South: 2001-2027)
Population as of final census conducted: 22,423,731 (Circa 2020)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 23,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $45.98 Million USD
Primary Language: Bolivian Spanish/Español Boliviano
Member of the Alliance of Nations: YES (South)
Alignment: World Prosperity Alliance (until 1988), COMECON (south, 1994-2001) 
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Bolivia was quite possibly the least stable nation after the signing of the Shanghai Accords. 

The Banzer Coup proceeded, and oil and metal exports dramatically went up. Banzer was then pressured by President Morgan to hold elections, and after finally caving to pressure from the West, Bolivia held their first elections in 1978. The MNR maintained a slim majority, and throughout the 1980s, Bolivia slipped further into anarchy as a second military coup, this time by the Communist party who contested the election results. The Communist Party ruled for only a single month and three days before the MNR took back the country in a counter-coup, and all the high-ranking members of the Communist Party were executed. In early 1981, the FSB Party, a Bolivian far-right socialist party, believed that the rather moderate (in comparison) MNR wasn’t doing enough. 

With the help of President Morgan, Banzer then took back power and formed a big-tent alliance party called the Nationalist Democratic Action party. Once they had taken back power though, the alliance quickly dissolved and members of the Socialist Party maintained control of the government for exactly two weeks. They were kicked out by the Christian Democrat Party, which had gotten a large amount of support in Sucre and ruled all the way to March 25th, 1982, when Banzer himself took a hold of the MNR once again and forced his way back into power. 

Bolivia was clearly in a political mess, and so on April 4th, 1982, the United Nations was forced to intervene and created the Bolivian Mandate until a stable government could be created. The US, Canada, and Europe all worked together to design a more comprehensive system of government for Bolivia, one with many checks and balances but still streamlined enough to be a good market for this new age of free trade. The Provisional Government of the Bolivian Mandate gradually opened up their markets, and to help speed up the transition, they took out huge loans to stimulate the economy. 

The first truly free elections were held on July 6th, 1985, and Eduardo Arce Villarroel of the MNR became president, holding a large enough majority to where other parties couldn’t contest the results. Bolivia’s history of frequent coups did not project an image of stability, and as such, many companies did not do business with Bolivia. President Villarroel was forced to take out larger and larger loans just to keep the country functioning, and by 1988 Bolivia was considered one of the poorest nations in the world. 

After the Crash of 1988, the UN Peacekeepers were recalled to their respective countries and Bolivia immediately collapsed into civil war yet again. President Villaroel was assassinated on October 17th, 1988, and with no clear political successor, Bolivia descended into utter anarchy by the start of 1989.
