The Hot Summer of 1990 actually ended the civil war, as the factions could no longer fight each other and could only focus on maintaining the territory they already held. In the North, which was being supported by Brazil, they formed the far-right Bolivian State, and in the South, the far-left People’s Republic of Bolivia. The two Bolivias kept to themselves for the most part, as the aftereffects of the Hot Summer demanded all their attention, though there was never an official end to the fighting. Skirmishes along their border continued, and when Brazil reformed into the Second Empire of Brazil, they signed a treaty of mutual defense with the north, only to promptly invade it after their dictator died under mysterious circumstances. 

From 1992-1995, the Bolivian Governorship and Brazil attempted to wipe out the socialists in the South, but could never breach their strongholds in the Andean mountains. The socialists held out, but their stockpiles were running dangerously low and the agricultural potential of the Andeans were limited to say the least, so on June 22nd, 1996, Argentina and the People’s Republic of Bolivia signed a secret treaty, where the Bolivians would provide Argentina with precious metals and coal in exchange for food and weapons. Later in 1997, South Bolivia would join the Alliance of Nations. 

On May 20th, 2001, South Bolivia signed the Treaty of Patagonia, and joined the Democratic People’s Republic of Argentina as an Autonomous Republic. China, working together with Argentina, engaged in widespread mining operations in the Bolivian region of the Andes. By the time China left in 2007, the side effects of their operations became clear across the republic, wells reported contamination and pollution, leading to major droughts and an outbreak of cholera in 2008. The weakened population was then ravaged by the Red Flu, leaving almost 4 million to die between 2007 and 2009. 

Throughout the 2010s, Argentina had to invest heavily to keep Bolivia functioning. Bolivia’s farms suffered from chronic famine, and the Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2016 crippled their agriculture entirely. The Bolivian State, which had been fiercely loyal to Brazil, finally crumbled in the aftermath of the heat waves and was absorbed by the southern republic, with the help of Argentina. The northern regions had not had their ground water polluted on the same level as the southern mountain regions, and so as Argentina began to organize irrigation systems, the republic began to slowly recover. Things were still bad though, as drought and water contamination remained a massive problem in the 2020s, leading to Argentina gradually scaling back their support. The Solar Flare of 2026 caused widespread drought and extreme water shortages, leading to several water riots in December of 2026. 

By 2027, Bolivia remains the most unstable republic of Argentina, teetering on the brink of collapse and routinely being invaded by cartels and remnants of Brazil’s military. 
Paraguay

(Flag credit)
Official name: Republic of Paraguay/República del Paraguay (until 1999), Autonomous People’s Republic of Paraguay/República Popular Autónoma del Paraguay (2000-2027)
Capital: Asunción
Government Type: Authoritarian Far Right Military Dictatorship (until 1994), Federal Republic (1994-1999), Autonomous Republic of Argentina (2000-2027) 
Population as of final census conducted: 12,210,755 (Circa 2020) 
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 13,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $5.584 Billion USD
Primary Language: Paraguayan Spanish/Español Paraguayo
Member of the Alliance of Nations: YES (until 2000)
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (until 1994), COMECON (1998-2000)
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial 

Paraguay maintained a good relationship with Brazil and the United States during the Glorious Decades. Alfredo Stroessner remained open to the free trade that came with the Shanghai Accords, and thus became as industrialized as Mexico. Throughout the 1980s, Stroessner worked with the UNADTF to hunt down and capture suspected leftists, who were then forced to work in Paraguay’s many factories. Stroessner removed many safety laws and regulations, and Paraguay became the most dangerous country to work in, aside from China. Cancer rates in Paraguay were the highest in all of Latin America, and despite the rampant repealing of laws, Paraguay was still not the richest country in Latin America. 

In the mid 1980s, Paraguay was forced to rely on foreign aid to feed their unemployed (which numbered in below 1 million, a massive amount for the Glorious Decades) and to take out loans to subsidize many local industries. Throughout the 1980s, Paraguay had the highest income inequality in the world, even worse than China, as the top 1% were some of the richest people in the world while it was estimated at least three Paraguayans starved to death every day. 

After the Crash of 1988, all the overseas corporations vanished from Paraguay. Due to a treaty that President King signed with President Stroessner, the US was required to provide aid until King left office. Brazil’s President de Alencar had also signed a similar treaty, and the two countries did their best to keep Paraguay afloat. But the crime rate and unemployment skyrocketed, and when President Graves announced that he would withdraw all federal and industrial aid to Paraguay, the government almost collapsed and was forced to declare martial law across much of the country. Part of President Franco’s policies included reducing aid to other Latin American nations, as he said that Paraguay had a growing trade deficit with Brazil. 

In the end though, Paraguay would be the last nation to receive aid from Brazil, as President Franco didn’t want to have a repeat of the “Argentine mistake”. Medicine and canned food that could have been used to help the poor in the slums of Brazil’s cities instead went to Asunción where they were usually hoarded by those who had been tasked with distributing it. 

On August 10th, 1989, Alfredo Stroessner suffered a stroke and was pronounced dead a few days later. The military took over the country, and kept it on a tight leash. Argentina, which had been doing the best in Latin America by this point, offered to send supplies and slyly claimed that Brazil was stifling them. Paraguay resisted until the Hot Summer of 1990, when almost 100,000 died from starvation and malnutrition-related illnesses. The aid from Brazil was drying up, and soon some military governors demanded that Paraguay accept Argentine aid. In the places where the military refused, protests broke out and almost 350 people were killed in riots until Argentine shipments finally arrived. 

This caused relations with Brazil to sour, until finally, in late 1991 Brazil invaded Paraguay. This started the Paraguayan War, and Argentina would soon intervene after one of their diplomats was reportedly killed in the crossfire outside of the Battle of Caaguazú. Argentina was slow to mobilize, as at one point Brazil came close to fully taking over Paraguay. The military junta, which had gone through three leaders by this point, was gradually becoming more and more left wing as they began to work closely with Argentina. Paraguayan partisans overwhelmed Brazilian troops while Argentine artillery destroyed convoys and supply lines. Later on in 1993, Chile joined the fight on the side of Paraguay, though they only sent a small token force of less than 1000 troops. 

The war ended with the Battle of Salto del Guairá, as a joint Paraguayan-Argentine-Chilean victory. Much of Paraguay was left in ruins due to Brazil’s scorched earth tactics and routine bombing. Vast stretches of Cordillera were now no-man’s land, covered in ash and ghost towns. Almost 2/3rds of the factories built during the 1970s and 1980s were destroyed beyond repair, and over two million people were missing or presumed dead. 

Paraguay was reformed from a military dictatorship to a federal republic, though the military still retained a marginal degree of control - Coronel Esteban Duarte Caballero of the Paraguayan Restorative Party won the Presidency after being considered a war hero for his work in the Battle of Salto del Guairá. President Caballero worked closely with Argentina’s President Falcón to rebuild Paraguay, with an emphasis on fortifying their border with Brazil and preventing further conflict. Much of the Brazilian-Paraguayan border was mined in the late 1990s, and on April 3rd, 1997, the Federal Republic of Paraguay signed a treaty of mutual defense with the People’s Republic of Bolivia. Later that year, in July, Paraguay would join the Alliance of Nations. 

Due to Paraguay’s economy in the Glorious Decades being mainly focused on international manufacturing and later black market trade, their agricultural sector was quite minimal. When the country began to plan out reconstruction efforts, they made deals with Argentina to manufacture weapons and industrial equipment, using Bolivian metals, in exchange for food. 

In 1999, Capitán Alejandro Benítez Rojas of the Paraguayan Socialist Party won the presidency, and part of his campaign included creating even closer ties with Argentina, South Bolivia, and Chile. These talks would lead to the Treaty of Patagonia, and on November 12th, 2000, Chile, Paraguay, and Uruguay would join the Democratic People’s Republic of Argentina as their own autonomous republics, with South Bolivia signing the next year. 

Throughout the 2000s, Argentina would build lots of factories across Paraguay, as since they had the smallest amount of arable land, industry was concentrated there and shipped via sea or train to other parts of the Patagonian Alliance. Power rationing went into effect in 2012. Famine and unemployment began to slowly subside, though rationing became harsh during 2003 and 2011, and vegetarianism was enforced in 2013. Water rationing was also implemented in 2015. Due to the highly concentrated nature of Paraguay’s population, being all crammed in heavily fortified cities, it was particularly susceptible to the Red Flu, which wiped out an estimated 670,000 people from 2008-2011. 

In the areas of Paraguay that were impractical for industrial parks, training grounds and military bases were established instead. The Autonomous People’s Republic of Paraguay had the second-largest military in the Patagonian alliance, behind Argentina. Many that survived the Brazilian invasion in the 1990s would become high-ranking and respected members of the Paraguayan armed forces, commanding bases along the border. 

During the Brazilian Civil War, Paraguay would repel several incursions throughout the 2010s. By the 2020s, Paraguay’s largest problem would end up being the distribution of clean water, leading to several riots until desalination plants in Argentina and Uruguay began to increase the supply of water. Heatwaves also became more prominent, with an order in 2023 mandating all non-essential work be conducted during the night. In 2025, as Argentina began to colonize West Antarctica, many unemployed Paraguayans were resettled in the colony of Nueva Asunción where they would set up farms in the fresh, fertile lands. This exodus has led to a slight increase in criminal activity and reports of cartels trying to move in, though the Paraguayan military is constantly policing the region to combat this. The Solar Storm of 2026 would force the Paraguayan military to retreat from the border and set up defensive lines a kilometer back. 

By 2027, almost a quarter of Paraguay’s population has been relocated to Antarctica, and the Paraguayan Army is gearing up along with the rest of the Patagonian Alliance to wipe out the last remnants of Fascist Brazil and prevent them from using their nuclear weapons. 
Chile

Official name: Republic of Chile/República de Chile (1984-1990), Socialist Republic of Chile/República Socialista de Chile (1990-2000), Autonomous People’s Republic of Chile/República Popular Autónoma de Chile (2000-2027)
Capital: Santiago 
Government Type: Authoritarian Republic (1984-1990), Far Left Junta (1990-2000), Autonomous Republic of Argentina (2000-2027)
Population as of final census conducted: 41,197,488 (Circa 2020)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 42,000,000 
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $27.678 Billion USD
Primary Language: Chilean Spanish/Español Chileno
Member of the Alliance of Nations: YES (until 2000)
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (until 1990), COMECON (1990-2000)
Great Death Survival Rating: Remnant 

The signing of the Shanghai Accords not only limited how China could intervene in East Asia, but it also limited how the United States could intervene in the Americas. President Nixon was forced, begrudgingly, to tone down the US’s operations in Chile after March of 1972. While the US could not overly influence the politics of Chile or support any coup attempts (though given how the Guatemalan trials ended up not punishing the US, they could have gotten away with it) instead they pressured the international community to heavily restrict trade and lending to Chile. 

Living conditions in Chile began to sharply decline, with only Cuba and the USSR providing support for Salvador Allende’s government. The US wouldn’t have to wait long however, as Augusto Pinochet overthrew Allende on September 11th, 1973. The Nixon administration eventually began the process of gradually lifting the sanctions placed against Chile, hoping that once Pinochet’s regime had stabilized it could prove to be a lucrative market. The Morgan administration, meanwhile, reversed Nixon’s relaxed sanctions and pressured Chile to return to a democracy, as Morgan believed that only a democratic government would allow for a proper free market of ideas and products. 

Chile proved to be rather resistant to change, as Pinochet held on to power. Trade deals and international summits throughout the early 1980s finally led to Pinochet relinquishing power and holding free elections in 1984. By sheer coincidence, a coalition of conservative, right-wing politicians, many of whom were in Pinochet’s cabinet, were elected, and José Toribio Merino won the Presidency. Pinochet was given the title of “Executive Advisor” and pardoned of all his human rights violations from his rule. 

When Franklin King became President, he heavily promoted the idea that Chile was a stable market, and for the most part, it was true: While Chile was still technically a democracy, its citizens had very little actual political power and most of their civil liberties were in regards to taxations and buying things. President Merino repealed many labor laws and made unionizing illegal, and labor rights activists were routinely arrested for “drug running” and sent to UNADTF prisons or state-run penal factories. 

The authoritarian government heavily suppressed any news of the economic collapse during the Crash of 1988, and simply told citizens to continue on business as usual and that anyone caught claiming that there were economic problems was actually a cartel member and would be punished accordingly. They could not punish everyone though, and as companies began to shut down factories and lay off workers in record numbers, the news spread far faster than the government could suppress it. The federal elections in December, 1988 led to Camila Andrade Fuentes, a center-left socialist, gaining widespread support. Yet despite the overwhelming numbers of people voting for her, Merino mysteriously won again in a landslide. 

It was clear that the conservative majority had rigged the election, and this spiraled into full-blown civil war by January. Support from Castro and Voronin soon put Pinochet’s faction on the defensive, and the siege of Santiago finally ended on January 19th, 1990 during the Hot Summer. Cuban advisors then helped turn Chile into a fully socialist state, and held mass trials and executed Pinochet, Merino, and 37 others by hanging on April 14th, 1990. Due to Chile’s already cool climate and high altitude, famines and drought weren’t much of an issue during the 1990s. Chile would make an alliance with Argentina and join the Paraguayan War in 1993, though they could not spare many soldiers as they were still rebuilding and recovering from their civil war. Some Cubans, fearing the rising temperatures back home, stayed in Chile and eventually became citizens there. Chile joined the Alliance of Nations in 1996. 

Throughout the late 1990s, Chile’s navy would patrol their coasts to discourage any cartels from landing. Smuggling remained a problem into the 2000s, though eventually it became clear that Chile was not a good market for selling drugs due to their history under Pinochet. On November 12th, 2000, during Chairwoman Fuentes’s second term, Chile signed the Treaty of Patagonia and became an autonomous republic of Argentina. China would attempt to set up mining operations from 2001-2005, but gave up due to extreme weather. Many of the low-lying cities were abandoned in the late 2000s, with some citizens refusing to relocate and instead becoming nomadic “boat people” who traveled along the coast in huge convoys of barges. Overfishing and spillover from the Glorious Decades led to several large famines in the 2010s, with Argentina being forced to supplement Chile’s food supplies in order to prevent mass famines and possibly an uprising. 

Argentina took a special interest in Chile, as with a majority of the Andes in their two nations, they both had access to many precious minerals. As climate change got worse, the highland peaks remained quite cool, and snow fell on the highest points all the way until 2017. This caused a drought in both Chile and Argentina, but Chile felt it far stronger. Much of lowland Chile was declared inhospitable in 2020 due to excessive flooding, and Argentina began resettling many Chileans into the plains in Argentina and later, Antarctica. Vertical settlements began to be built in the Andes all the way back in the mid 1990s, and by the 2020s that was where the remaining population lives as they mine away for precious metals, and supposedly, uranium. 

After the Great Heatwaves of 2024 and 2025, President Roca, seeing the writing on the wall, began constructing many secret bunkers along the Andean mountains. These bunkers were stockpiled with enough rations to keep 100 people fed for over 25 years, advanced munitions and weapons to help rebuild civilization, and most importantly, books, technical manuals and knowledge. These locations were powered by nuclear reactors and could withstand three direct hits from a warhead twice the size of Brazil’s supposed nuclear weapons. 

By 2027, the Chilean Autonomous Region, despite being frequently beset with extreme weather, is actually a pretty chill place to live. Careful allocation of resources has kept the remaining soil mostly pollutant free and mining steady. 
Uruguay

(Flag credit)
Official name: Oriental Republic of Uruguay/República Oriental del Uruguay (until 1991), Democratic Republic of Uruguay/República Democrática del Uruguay (1991-2000), Autonomous People’s Republic of Uruguay/República Popular Autónoma del Uruguay (2000-2027)
Capital: Montevideo
Government Type: Minarchist Government (until 1991), Far-Left Authoritarian Republic (1991-2000), Autonomous Republic of Argentina (2000-2027)
Population as of final census conducted: 6,500,562 (Circa 2020)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 7,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $2.04 Trillion USD
Primary Language: Rioplatense Spanish/Rioplatense Español
Member of the Alliance of Nations: YES (until 2000)
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (until 1991), COMECON (1994-2000)
Great Death Survival Rating: Remnant 

During the Glorious Decades, Uruguay would end up being an experiment in prototyping the ideal post free trade country. Far-left guerrilla movements were suppressed and fizzled out by the early 1970s, and as a result the military did not feel the need to intervene. The authoritarian but civilian regime worked closely with the United States to catch any leftists and create a truly free market. 

On June 27th, 1973, Juan María Bordaberry launched a coup against the government to turn it into a military regime, claiming that the civilian government wasn’t doing enough to help the economy or deal with the rampant leftists. But as economies around the world began to skyrocket, by 1974 this military government was seen as obsolete and throughout the coming years, Bordaberry would step down and his replacement, Martín Ezequiel Ferraro, renewed ties with the United States. 

In 1977, the Uruguayan experiment truly began. Modeling themselves after many of Morgan’s decisions regarding budgeting and privatization, President Ferraro began to sell off many government functions and social services. Ferraro believed that Morgan wasn’t going far enough, though: it wasn’t just the fat that should be trimmed, but as much of the government as possible must be privatized in order for a true free market to emerge. 

Public education was privatized, with the intent being that corporations would provide education for their employee’s children as a part of their benefits, and thus make the industry more competitive. Many worker’s rights were also repealed, as if a worker didn’t like working at one particular company, they could simply leave and work for someone else who treated him better. Regulations in food and other safety measures were also no longer enforced, as if a company cut corners and caused food to be contaminated and kill several thousand people, it would spread through word of mouth and that company would become bankrupt. Taxes were made so small that they were practically non-existent. To make the country more attractive for foreign investors, the government began selling out key positions and policies to the highest bidder. For example, Aurora Capital e Participações, a Brazilian financial group, bought out the public transportation policy in Punta del Este and replaced the city’s fleet of buses with ones made by a Chinese manufacturing company that the group had invested in. 

By the 1980s, almost all of Uruguay was privatized, with the miniscule government only providing security, and even then, most of that was being given to contractors. Uruguay’s military had been turned into a PMC, and their police force had been turned into an army of rent-a-cops. Uruguay became a tax haven like no other, and many companies initially moved their headquarters to Montevideo just for that reason alone. But with the repealing of so many laws and the shaky enforcement of the few that remained, many things that were illegal in other countries became legal in Uruguay. Corporate espionage, money laundering, copyright infringement: pretty much all of it was legal unless it involved someone actually dying. Many of the drug lords in the 1980s would have lavish mansions in Uruguay where they would turn their dirty money into clean US cash, and suspected terrorists could walk around freely as long as they had enough bills on hand. Prostitution ran rampant, with tourists disappearing every day and vanishing into trafficking rings. 

This rapid change of economic policy did little to address the inflation and income inequality that the average Uruguayan faced. Due to the extremely flexible laws regarding crime, drug running, smuggling and other criminal activity, Uruguay became the country with the highest crime rates. The black market created almost 20% of Uruguay’s GDP, and the grey market even larger. Some criminal businesses actually got licenses and were “legitimized”: as long as they paid their minimal taxes, and weren’t causing any international incidents or wars, they were fine with whatever. 

In 1984, President Morgan was no longer impressed, but alarmed. He described Uruguay as not a free market, but total anarchy. A lack of minimum wage had led to many workers being paid in food, food that was stale or rotting, leading to workers to die and more importantly, not contribute back to the economy. Companies stealing other corporation’s secrets destroyed the very concept of a competitive market. Even Chairman Chen was disappointed with how the Uruguayan experiment was turning out. 

Throughout President King’s term, he pushed hard on using the UNADTF to help police and regulate Uruguay. The Uruguayan government (now essentially a coalition of corporate CEOs and mob bosses) actually only stepped in when over a hundred drug labs went on strike and demanded better pay and working conditions, with some of them even unionizing. The corporate security began to actively police against strikers, unionists and other labor advocates, which were becoming more prominent in the late 1980s. Meanwhile, the UNADTF began to provide legitimate security as peacekeepers and police officers, serving as Uruguay’s unofficial law enforcement. 

The Crash of 1988 hit Uruguay hard. Overnight, hundreds of companies relocated to their native countries, and as the UNADTF was recalled to their countries of origin, law enforcement began to seriously break down. Soon, just about everyone was poor, and in July of 1988 what was left of the government had been taken over by an organized crime syndicate based out of Montevideo, hoarding what little food was left for them and their guards. 

Many in Uruguay had had enough though, and began to organize to fight back and take back their country. Brazil desperately tried to prevent a left-wing uprising and thus sent aid to Uruguay’s “government”, propping them up even more. In response, Cuba started to covertly send supplies to Uruguay’s underground. Few of the supplies actually reached their intended destination, as bandits and other organized crime syndicates bartered the supplies for luxury goods. 

By 1989, much of Uruguay outside of Montevideo was total anarchy. Brazil and Argentina kept a close watch on their borders, as bandits and refugees frequently tried to cross over. President Franco was criticized for supporting such a barbarous regime, but he calmly stated the alternative was communism. Famines and food scarcity in 1989 led to an estimated 150,000 deaths, with the UN trying to pass an emergency resolution to intervene and provide aid, but no country was willing by this point. Cartels started to form and ironically provided the most stable employment in the country, and continued that way into 1990 until both Argentina and Brazil took a harsh stance against the criminal activity going into their borders, with President Franco finally withdrawing aid. 

The Hot Summer of 1990 caused things to finally collapse, as Montevideo exploded into a violent revolt that ended with the Legislative Palace of Uruguay being completely destroyed and burned to the ground, and almost a hundred hanged from nooses. This became known as the Uruguayan Revolution of 1990, with the USSR, Cuba and later Argentina offering congratulations. Camilo Pereyra, a former liaison to the UNADTF turned revolutionary, was declared the leader of this interim government in Montevideo. An alliance was made with Argentina, and their Gendarmería Nacional worked with the Oriental Revolutionaries to stabilize the rest of the country. Many factories and sites of industry were destroyed in retaliation, being seen as the survivors as methods of exploitation. 

Uruguay rapidly transformed into a left-wing republic, being headed by Chancellor Pereyra, and throughout 1990 and 1991 the government engaged in massive land reform programs and wealth redistribution. The vast hoard of stolen Cuban and Brazilian food was rationed out, and anything left over from the Uruguayan experiment was burned for catharsis. Some factories were kept, as they were retooled by Cuban engineers to produce essential goods that would increase the quality of life for their citizens, though the factories frequently ran into technical problems and were finally shut down by the mid 2000s. As a result, the Democratic Republic of Uruguay became very agrarian and began to experiment with irrigation to increase crop yield. 

This dramatic transition alarmed Brazil, and Morales cited it as one of the reasons why Brazil needed to become harshly anti-communist once again. Argentina began to trade surplus industrial equipment to Uruguay in exchange for some of their food, and ties between the two of them grew closer. Bandits and cartels still inhabited the fringes of Uruguay, and the overstretched and under-equipped partisans could not hope to stop them all. In 1995, after the end of the Paraguayan war, Argentina and Uruguay signed another treaty and Argentina began to provide additional security for Uruguay (especially along the Brazilian border) in exchange for a greater amount of harvested crops. Uruguay was also one of the initial nations to sign the new Alliance of Nations charter. 

In the late 1990s, Chancellor Diego Andrés Larrosa Bentancur, hoping to maintain their close ties with Argentina, participated in the talks that would lead to the signing of the Treaty of Patagonia. Uruguay became an autonomous republic within Argentina, and in the 2000s, Argentine troops swarmed the Brazilian border. Argentina began to invest in military bases in the north of Uruguay and also rebuilt many of Uruguay’s cities, as the ruins left were particularly susceptible to flooding and forest fires. Montevideo was restored in the mid 2000s (though in a distinctly brutalist style to use a minimal amount of resources) and shipyards began to be built along the coast. 

In the regions where agriculture was not practical, factories were constructed, though great care was taken to make them in isolated places so as to not invoke memories of the Glorious Decades. These factories only made replacement parts to keep Uruguay’s military and farm equipment up and running, and rarely produced anything else. 

On August 1st, 2014, the Patagonian Alliance launched an invasion into weakened Brazil through Uruguay, taking over the former states of Rio Grande Do Sul and Santa Catarina. Their campaign was put on hold when the Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2016 caused Uruguay and Argentina’s crop yield to dramatically decline, forcing extreme rationing across the alliance. Argentina decided to not pursue further conquest at the moment, though the two former states were added to Uruguay’s territory. 

In the 2020s, controlling the newly acquired Brazilian states would prove to be a challenging task for Uruguay’s government. Decades of anti-communist propaganda led to guerrilla warfare and rebellion, with farms being destroyed throughout the 2020s. The two occupied states, known as the Uruguayan frontier, became a hotbed for cartel activity and discontent. Rations were reduced every year in an attempt to control the population but the cartel’s numbers only grew in response. That was until the Second Great Heatwave of 2023 and 2024, when famine and drought finally made many of the former Brazilians give in and stop fighting back. Those with good behavior were given better living conditions, and as the citizens became more accepting of this new way of life, resistance finally died down by late 2026. 

By 2027, Uruguay is in a unique situation, as while they do not have much in the way of industry or military, they are one of the biggest producers of food in the Patagonian Alliance. Uruguayan farmers are in charge of the agricultural efforts taking place in the newly colonized Argentine Antarctic lands.  


Propaganda poster for the Argentine Communist Party, circa 2015
Argentina

(Flag credit)
Official name: Argentine Republic/República Argentina (until 2001), Democratic People’s Republic of Argentina/República Popular Democrática de Argentina (2001-2027), Emergency Provisional Regime of Argentina/Régimen Provisional de Emergencia de Argentina (2028-2036)
Capital: Buenos Aires (until 2027), Santa Roca (2028-2036)
Government Type: Presidential Republic (until 2027), Far Left Military Junta (2028-2036)
Population as of final census conducted: 94,178,752 (Circa 2020), 176,511,288 (including Autonomous Republics)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 93,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $142.386 Billion USD
Primary Language: Rioplatense Spanish/Rioplatense Español
Member of the Alliance of Nations: YES
Alignment: None (until 1993), COMECON (1993-2027)
Great Death Survival Rating: Remnant 

Argentina was one of the more isolated nations during the Glorious Decades, cut off from the major powers of the world and for the most part, unaligned. Argentina championed the Non-Aligned Movement, along with Yugoslavia and India, and later nations such as South Korea, Taiwan and Cuba. That was not to say they did not participate in the lucrative free trade that came with the Shanghai Accords, only that Argentina was not a member of any particular trading bloc. 

Juan Perón, aware of the changing political landscape around the world, voluntarily stayed in Spain for the rest of 1973 and moved to France in 1974, where he suffered a heart attack in Paris on March 7th, 1974. He was able to be treated immediately, and was prescribed a life-saving medical treatment for his other health conditions. When he had recovered, he contacted President Héctor José Cámpora and told him he was returning to Argentina. This was kept secret, as the Montoneros had recently attempted to assassinate José Ignacio Rucci and both Cámpora and Perón worried that violence could result from announcing his return. 

Perón finally returned in a surprise visit on June 20th, 1974. President Cámpora pardoned him and stepped down, calling a snap election. Perón was elected in a landslide, and resumed office for the third time on July 1st, 1974. Argentina’s economy rapidly rose, and without any oil shortages, it never came crashing down. Throughout the 1970s, Argentina was one of the few countries to target far-right groups instead of far-left ones. Perón, worried about rumors of him being aligned with fascists and escaped Nazis in the 1950s, began a special military operation to dismantle the Triple-A. While Perón did not succeed at wiping out and destroying the organization, he did make radical groups on either side of the political spectrum seem less attractive. The Montoneros actually disbanded on January 27th, 1978, and the Triple-A would dissolve in 1983. 

Juan Perón died on February 10th, 1979, at age 83. His wife and vice president, Isabel Perón, succeeded him as the 41st President of Argentina. Having worked with her husband for almost five years as his vice president, she went in knowing much more about politics than IOTL. on February 28th, 1979. She was not as loved as her husband, but still a respected president until she suffered a stroke on July 8th, 1982 and retired from public view. 

Her vice president, Raúl Alfonsín, was sworn in on August 19th, 1982 as her official replacement. He had a more conservative, right-leaning version of Perónism. It was under Alfonsín that Argentina officially joined the Non-Aligned Movement, and several trade deals were made with both Yugoslavia and India to help modernize and update Argentina’s industry. Throughout the rest of the 1980s, both the USA and USSR tried to woo Argentina to their side of the political spectrum, as some could describe Argentina’s economic system as being split straight down the middle between capitalism and communism, as Perón had implemented many social programs in the 1970s but still promoted free trade. 

Argentina wasn’t hit particularly hard by the Crash of 1988, as they were not completely dependent on foreign trade and also had a large amount of natural gas and oil. Argentina was still entering a crisis like the rest of the world though, for them, it was just slightly slower. Carlos Vicente Luis won the Presidency in 1988, campaigning on a platform of far-left Perónism and Latin American unity in this time of hardship. Petroleum began to be rationed in June of 1989, and after witnessing the chaos of the Hot Summer of 1990, President Luis enacted the initially controversial decision of passing even more left-wing policies such as nationalizing the remaining companies in the country and also creating a food ration for the unemployed. 

Argentina was so far south that the climate barely changed throughout the 1990s, and their main problem was rampant economic problems, a rising crime rate, and an almost endless flood of refugees from their northern neighbors. President Luis, trying to maintain some level of trade, began sending aid to Paraguay and Uruguay. Due to the exponentially decreasing stability of nations worldwide, especially in places like Colombia, Venezuela and Brazil, Argentina put their tiny military on standby. Throughout 1990 and 1991, President Luis ran a harsh and heavy-handed recruitment campaign for both the armed forces and law enforcement. Many joined simply for the pay, and while it took a few years for corruption to be weeded out, Argentina managed to keep their unemployment rate at a relatively small level compared to their neighbors. 

For the rest of 1990, Argentina worked with Uruguay to bring order to their countryside. Argentina was expecting an invasion from Brazil, who was struggling to maintain their government’s legitimacy. Argentina would be completely blindsided when Brazil instead invaded Paraguay on December 15th, 1991. President Luis, still hoping for Latin American unity and cooperation, sent a diplomat to mediate a peace between Paraguay and Brazil. Lucía Fernández del Valle managed to organize several talks throughout early 1992, but on March 25th, 1992 she was killed outside of Caaguazú. 

This was seen as a call to arms, and a record number of citizens enlisted during the spring of 1992. Industrial sites began to be retooled to produce weapons and equipment for the war effort, and the government started to parrot propaganda portraying Argentina as one of the few sane nations left, a beacon of rationality in this world going crazy. Nationalism and patriotism could only rise, and Argentina wholeheartedly joined the Paraguayan War on June 2nd, 1992, with almost 150,000 troops arriving to break the Siege of Asunción, overwhelming and defeating the Brazilians. 

President Luis called upon all of Latin America to rise up against Brazil and unite against their imperialism, but not many countries answered the call. Cuba sent several shipments of weapons, and Chile later sent a small force of only 1000 troops. Paraguay and Argentina resisted Brazil and were soon on the offensive, taking back more land every day. 

On May 15th, 1994, Brazil’s forces were finally defeated during the Battle of Salto del Guairá and the Argentine-Chilean-Paraguayan alliance declared victory. The victory of Argentina and Paraguay over a much larger and stronger country like Brazil was a huge morale boost. Any who held doubts about the way  Argentina was going were no longer questioning if this left-wing Perónism was good for the nation. Minister Voronin congratulated Argentina, and the USSR invited them to join COMECON, which they accepted. 

In the 1994 federal elections, Alfredo José Falcón of the United Peronist Party of Justice won the presidency, riding on the high of victory and promising closer ties with Argentina’s neighbors against Brazil’s aggression. Falcón was an even bigger supporter of socialism than Luis, and created policies like permanent rent freezes and protecting worker’s rights. 

Throughout the mid 1990s, President Falcón worked closely with Chile, Uruguay, Paraguay and South Bolivia to create a united front against Brazil. This resulted in the Treaty of Asunción on September 4th, 1994, the Punta Arenas Accords on February 22nd, 1995, the Treaty of Montevideo on June 25th, 1995 and the Treaty of Challapata on November 28th, 1996. Part of these treaties revitalized trade between these five nations, with Argentina usually supplying food, industrial equipment and security in exchange for labor, raw materials and energy. Industrialization projects helped rebuild South Bolivia and Paraguay while providing work for millions. Argentina, under President Falcón, was also one of the nations to sign the initial Alliance of Nations charter on June 11th, 1995. 

President Falcón also engaged in talks of federalizing the five nations into one, similar to what the European Union was doing. These talks, headed by Chancellor Bentancur of Uruguay and President Falcón led to the reforming of the various treaties into one unifying document: the Treaty of Patagonia. 

The wealth and prosperity that Argentina was experiencing (at least compared to the rest of the world) created monumental support for left-wing politics, throughout 1999 the openly-communist José Lorenzo Ramos of the Argentine Worker’s Party campaigned on turning Argentina and the rest of Patagonia into one nation, as only together could they survive the 21st Century. He said that both Falcón and Luis didn’t go far enough, and advocated for a communist democracy. Ramos won the Presidency on October 24th, 2000. Many in the nation were still cautious about becoming communist, but those against it never did anything more than whine. On November 12th, 2000, Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay signed the Treaty of Patagonia and Argentina officially became the Democratic People’s Republic of Argentina, with Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay as autonomous self-governed republics that were integrated into Argentina’s economy, rail lines, and military. Bolivia joined slightly later, on May 20th, 2001. When the nation was finally formed, their population was 144 million across the five republics. 

President Ramos cautiously worked with China from 2001-2007, mainly to extract coal from Chile and Bolivia as Argentina’s natural gas was running out and their petroleum had been exhausted by 1995. In May 2005, a massive tropical storm forced China to abandon their mining operations in Chile, and soon after, President Ramos ordered much of the Chilean lowlands to be abandoned. The Red Summer of 2003 caused minor famines throughout the republics, and the Minister of Economy created a program to maximize the calorie output in citizen’s food. This resulted in the sun tortilla, a large flat, tasteless tortilla made from wheat, maize and soybeans and fortified with several minerals, plus chemicals and preservatives to make them last longer. For most of the more impoverished workers in the autonomous republics, this became their main staple food. 

Strikes and power outages in 2004 led to civil unrest, and the Argentine government, struggling with maintaining a rusting prison system, instead created a prisoner work program where criminals could work off their sentence in various ways, such as farming, collecting trash, or if they were deemed especially gifted, they were educated in the remaining public universities by trained volunteers. More violent criminals were given a single chance to join the military in special penal battalions that patrolled the borders of Brazil and Peru, or be executed on the spot. South Bolivia was known for frequently using their penal battalions to launch raids into the Bolivian State, to various success. Unlike similar programs in the United States, Europe, China, the USSR, and even Brazil, some criminals actually managed to work off their sentences. Crime still gradually increased, and the law enforcement agencies of the five republics in turn became more militarized to keep up. 

President Ramos was re-elected in 2006, and emphasized on modernizing Argentina’s military. Ramos actually sent envoys to Central Europe to negotiate with the fracturing Warsaw Pact to buy their old military equipment. Argentina managed to get a few outdated submarines in exchange for Argentine soybeans and tortillas. Later on, after various bureaucrats reported water pollution, ties with China were officially severed and Argentina became even closer with the USSR. Researchers with the Chilean Ministry of Health also concluded that China had been unknowingly spreading the Red Flu through their supply lines and shipments from the mainland. This forced Argentina to implement quarantine measures in major population centers such as Sucre, Buenos Aires and Montevideo until 2010. 

Ramos also knew that Brazil would come back to finish what they started in Paraguay and Bolivia, and despite the Patagonian Alliance having a much better trained and supplied military than they did in the 90s, Brazil was still much bigger. In early 2006, Argentine intelligence began to hear rumors of an uprising in Guyane. Ramos, viewing this group as a potential ally against Brazil, finally had agents make contact with the Red Hand in mid 2007. Argentine supplies, ferried by submarine and dropped off in the dead of night, kept the Red Hand and the Laotian resistance fighting for years. Members of Argentina’s intelligence agency and the Red Hand eventually established the short-lived alliance with The Cartel in Colombia, carrying out the October 10th Uprising. President Ramos was not expecting The Cartel and the Red Hand to maintain close ties for anything longer than a year, so the betrayal was completely expected and actually factored into Argentina’s war plans. Brokering alliances with other cartels were also considered, but was decided to be a waste of resources. Using Polish and Soviet submarines, Argentina continued to supply the Red Hand in Colombia. 

In the Purple Summer of 2011, Ramos became less worried about Brazil invading Argentina as famines were starting to weaken Morales’s grip on his subjects. He began to plot with the Red Hand to bring about the complete destabilization of Brazil, and while Ramos was not able to finalize the details during his term, the Red Hand carried out their plan on May 20th, 2013. Soon after, Brazil was plunged into civil war. 

The Purple Summer began to put a strain on Argentina’s resources, with some sub-species of grapes and other fruits going extinct. Alcohol, while not outright prohibited, was tightly controlled and prioritized for sanitation as opposed to for recreational use. Meat began to be banned by several local governments to free up more land for growing food for humans.

Roberto Horacio Fernández, Ramos’s successor, worked on forming even closer ties with the USSR and also modernizing Argentina’s failing energy grid. Argentina spent thousands of hours and millions of pesos researching nuclear, solar, and wind energy, and relentlessly pressured the USSR to help collaborate with them. In January of 2013, Voronin finally relented and sent five Soviet physicists to help push Argentina in the right direction. The physicists would end up staying permanently, as the onset of the Brazilian Civil War and Voronin’s death in 2015 caused the Soviet government to abandon them. The scientists ended up not wanting to return to the USSR. They found that while Argentina had significantly less food and extreme weather was becoming a weekly problem, their government was significantly less oppressive than the Soviet Union’s. 

Fernández, at the request of Ramos, was strongly urged to remain at full alert along the Brazilian border as the civil war kicked off. President Fernández was far less cautious than Ramos, and was eager to strike Brazil first. The Secretaries of Uruguay, Bolivia and Paraguay all agreed with this, and Chile was neutral. On August 1st, 2014, Fernández finally launched an invasion into Brazil through Uruguay. By December, the Patagonian Alliance had taken two former states and parts of North Bolivia, when the Great Heatwave of 2015 caused a dramatic decrease in crop yield and even drought in some areas. President Fernández was forced to halt the operations in mid April of 2015, with the invasion force being reassigned to help maintain order. Rebel groups, usually supported by cartels, were blaming the communist government for the food shortages in 2015. This turned to protests, and later strikes, and parts of Bolivia and Paraguay were facing civil war and maybe even succession. 

The opposition was largely wiped out by 2016, though famines continued into 2017 with an estimated 25 million deaths due to starvation, drought, disease or civil unrest. Heatwaves caused even more to faint, and many regions switched to working at night. Vegetarianism was made mandatory across the nation, with buying and possessing meat deemed illegal except on certain holidays such as Christmas, Caraval, Easter, Patagonia Day (May 20th) and Independence Day. Citizens could register in waitlists with their local municipal slaughterhouse for their cut in advance, while supplies lasted. 

With this law put into effect, agricultural stockpiles saw a gradual increase as pastures for livestock were turned into intensive maize farms. There were some who still traded in meat, and some more ruthless people dug up corpses and sold the meat on the black market, marketing it as “Carne Criolla”. A special squadron of the Argentine law enforcement, based out of Buenos Aires, specialized in dismantling illegal meat rings with an emphasis on brutally executing any human meat traffickers as a warning to any who might sell their grandma for a quick peso. Argentina’s intelligence agency, learning the information from the Soviets in late 2014, knew what the majority of Brazil, Mexico, the USA, Europe, and China was actually eating, and the decision to make vegetarianism mandatory was to help make it easier to spot cannibals. Overfishing in Chile was also cited as one of the reasons to switch to vegetarianism. 

On December 1st, 2017, after having recovered from the Great Heatwaves, Argentina cautiously renewed their war against Brazil and launched an invasion on North Bolivia. North Bolivia was completely crippled, and became the territory of Bolivia, though they were not granted any autonomy and were kept under strict control. The two states that Argentina had taken from Brazil were also given to Uruguay. 

Also starting in February of 2017, and continuing until the second Great Heat Wave of 2023, Argentina began supplying Peruvian communists in their struggle against cartel-backed factions. Support was steady, but minimal. Grain and cereal based rations were sent along with weapons and ammunition, and carefully calculated so that only the regions bordering Bolivia could be reliably defended and held - if the Peruvians tried to extend too far, they’d inevitably run into supply line issues and be forced to retreat to their border with Bolivia. Other Peruvian factions of course continued the fight, but Argentina ensured that a small sub-group of the Peruvian Red Hand served as a proxy to keep cartels from invading Bolivia through Peru. In the 2020s, rations were gradually decreased until 2023 when only weapons were shipped into Peru. 

President Fernández established the “Counter-Fascism” Protocol, which was the government name for the program of supplying the Red Hand throughout South America and using them as a proxy to keep Brazil and the dozens of cartels distracted and disorganized. Special care was to give their main branch in Venezuela the lion’s share of the aid, including technical manuals, moth-balled artillery from the 20th century, and even some agents and tacticians to advise the guerrillas in New Caracas. After Brazil was kicked out of Venezuela and until the early 2020s, when Venezuela’s coast was still relatively safe from pirates and cartel raids, Argentina openly unloaded their supplies from rusted cargo ships onto ramshackle docks and piers. After 2022 though, the northern Brazilian coast and the places formerly known as Guyana, Guyane and Suriname were all crawling with cartels and bandits, who frequently launched raids to plunder Argentina’s life-saving cargo. In March 2022, the decision was made to supply the Red Hand only by night and via water-proof dead drops deployed by submarines. The Red Hand faction in Venezuela was the last guerilla group the Argentines supplied, with their last shipment arriving in January of 2027. 

President Fernández went down in history as a controversial figure. Some claimed his methods at restoring order were too harsh. Many cited his state-enforced vegetarianism policy. Many called him a warmonger. Marina Santiago Roca became the second female president of Argentina in 2018, the 47th president of Argentina, and also most notably, the last democratically elected president of Argentina. 

Roca at first campaigned on a hopeful recovery of the hardships in the mid 2010s, with promises of bringing Argentina’s nuclear power grid to fruition. She also campaigned on expanding women’s rights, such as making abortion protected by the constitution and birth control widely available. This did not have the effect she had hoped though, and was forced to make a controversial two-child policy in early 2020. 

President Roca would be the one to flip the switch on Argentina’s first functional nuclear power plant on July 11th, 2019, located in Chasico. For their help, the Soviet physicists were given luxury apartments in Rosario. This was followed by building a power plant outside of each of the capital cities, and several more along Argentina’s coast to eventually power desalination plants. 

President Roca, in one of her first days in office, would expand the Fernández Protocol to include the Brazilian branch of the Red Hand. This was met with threats of impeachment, though she managed to convince her cabinet that it was in Argentina’s best interest. Pacifying Brazil’s coastline by supplying the coastal communes would provide safe passage for supplies to Venezuela, and even Colombia if Argentina got that bold. More importantly, it provided a way to keep citizens employed and in factories, and not aimlessly wandering around, unemployed and easy targets for cartels and drug runners. Deteriorating climate conditions, famine and cartel activity forced Argentina to begin escorting their shipments in mid 2019, and by 2021, had switched entirely to dead drops much like how they would for Venezuela. Only the most dirty, low-grade left over bits of plants were used for rations for Brazil, but beggars couldn’t be choosers. Argentina then transitioned to sending more weapons than food, to help provoke fighting against hostile factions. 

Due to the worsening climate and the aftereffects of China’s industrial experiments, the northern republics of Paraguay and Bolivia were starting to become more and more costly to maintain, with the government of Argentina considering removing them from the Treaty. However, a group of surveyors in the Falkland Islands reported that in the past forty years, Antarctica had been melting at an unprecedented rate, with almost half of the west Antarctic ice sheet melting in the 21st century alone. By 2030 it was estimated that all of West Antarctica would be open to human settlement. At the moment, much of the Antarctic Peninsula south into parts of Ellsworth Land was already free of ice year round. 

This is when President Roca began the Antarctic Resettlement Program, and from 2021-2024 almost 10 million people from Paraguay and Bolivia were sent over to colonize this new fertile land in the name of the Argentine people. Later on, people from Chile and Uruguay voluntarily relocated to Argentine Antarctica to help coordinate the colonization efforts. The soil was initially harsh and rocky but the Argentines had all the space they could want. 

President Roca viewed Antarctica as Argentina’s saving grace. This fertile new land could save not just Bolivia and Paraguay, but also possibly their allies in Venezuela. President Roca had toyed with the idea of making Venezuela the sixth republic in the Patagonian Alliance, but it remained a pipe dream. As both her and her predecessor knew, the Red Hand were only useful for as long as they were drawing attention away from Argentina. 

In early 2024, President Roca reluctantly expanded the Fernández Protocol to include supplying guerillas in Ecuador to battle against the remnants of Brazil. This would prove remarkably tricky, as the weapons and materials rarely made it to the rebel bases located beyond the Ecuadoran Andes. Only three operations were ever successful, the rest of them being attacked and waylaid by pirates, cartels, bandits, or remnants of Brazil’s military. President Roca would withdraw support for Ecuador in November 2024, though intelligence was shared with the Red Hand in Peru regarding supply line issues. 

President Roca won reelection in 2024, using the Antarctic colony as a propaganda piece. The Great Heatwaves of 2024 and 2025 were what made President Roca realize that even Argentina and the rest of Patagonia might not survive the climate apocalypse. Chronic heatwaves had made nocturnal work shifts required by law since 2023, and even with the growing nuclear power grid, frequent brown outs caused many to die in the heat, and water was rationed starting in late 2024. 

But 2024 and 2025 proved to be an entirely different beast. 

Massive forest fires and drought in Uruguay crippled ration stockpiles, hurricanes destroyed two nuclear power plants, requiring several technicians to sacrifice themselves to prevent a meltdown, and incursions from Brazil into Bolivia forced a mass mobilization of reserve troops. Human meat rings were popping up at an alarming rate, and people falling into Bromista-induced comas became worryingly common. Buenos Aires was flooded with one meter of water for a month, with President Roca temporarily relocated to an undisclosed bunker in Puerto Santa Cruz. Cartels and pirates began to raid coastal towns that were cut off from communications, and the five secretaries were almost at each other's throats. Martial law was declared, and the Treaty of Patagonia was almost nullified. The penal programs that had been established earlier in the 21st century were replaced by simply shooting criminals. Argentina was unraveling. 

It was only the threat of Brazil that was keeping the nations together, and so to put a metaphorical bandaid on their problems, President Roca began the construction of a fortified border wall across Paraguay, Uruguay and Brazil’s border. In a controversial move, she also restarted the Fernández Protocol with a focus on sending not just supplies but also troops to the coastal communes in Brazil. Vanguard shock troops from Bolivia and Paraguay were sent to the coastal cities, with the express goal of goading the Brazilians into fighting as many of the fascists as possible. Operations to retake supply depots from cartels always turned out to be Pyrrhic victories. The vanguard troops were also told to seek out any information about the supposed nuclear bomb the Brazilian military remnants frequently boasted about.  

But this was all simply to buy time. 

President Roca knew that the world was changing for the worse, and soon Argentina could crumble. Plans were drafted to eventually evacuate everyone above the Tropic of Capricorn by 2030, and to dismantle Brazil’s nuclear weapons so that they wouldn’t have to constantly watch their backs. This was the best case scenario though, and so she also plotted a secret contingency plan. Bunkers began to be constructed in the Andean mountains and using the guise of censorship, the government began to collect technical manuals and surviving literature to store in these vaults of knowledge. These bunkers would house important scientists, politicians and engineers, along with their families and a squad of special forces to guard them. They could wait out the inevitable nuclear war and collapse of civilization and rule over the survivors as their architects, guardians, and jailors. 

The other members of the Patagonian Alliance were not told of these bunkers, though the Chileans suspected something was happening. Shipments of rations began vanishing across the Patagonian Alliance, and radioactive water began to mysteriously leak into the ocean off Chile’s coast. The last state-run newspaper was shut down and its printing press vanished. Training exercises, officially for the “Brazilian Pacification”, were carried out across Argentina. President Roca never returned to Buenos Aires, instead hopping in between the capital of the Antarctic Colony (Santa Roca, named after her) and Puerto Santa Cruz. 

In March of 2026, President Roca would host the final Alliance of Nations summit on the topic of potentially resettling humanity to Antarctica. This was President Roca’s last, desperate gesture to restore her own faith in humanity. As an olive branch, she invited the last remaining stable nations to discuss a partition of Antarctica. Many nations had already been making contingency plans for when the last remnants of civilization collapsed, and if they banded together and worked hard, they could remake the splendor of the Glorious Decades in this new Antarctic Eden. 

None would agree with her though. The United States and the European Federation both demanded exclusive rights to any oil found there, the USSR would only agree as long as Supreme Secretary Savateev was the sole head of state for this new multinational community, and East Germany refused to have any part of the plan if the USSR was included. The only country that seemed remotely interested in cooperating was Japan, but they claimed that they would need additional resources from Argentina in order to properly resettle. The Nordic Union, Switzerland, and the Union of Australia and New Zealand all remained neutral and refused to participate in this “polar folly”. 

The negotiations went nowhere, with President Roca leaving her humanity at the conference table. 

On November 1st, 2026, President Roca would launch an invasion of Brazil yet again, this time focused on encircling Rio de Janeiro (the last stronghold of Brazil’s fascist dictatorship) and wiping them out. Information regarding Brazil’s nuclear weapons was also a priority, but like many of Argentina’s military operations after the second Great Heat Wave of 2023 and 2024, it was in actuality a diversion. The 4-million strong invasion force, which amounted to nothing more than cannon fodder, was meant to draw attention away from Antarctica and the contingency bunkers in the Andes. 

Cities began to be slowly emptied out. Important scientists, engineers and mechanics were covertly escorted to various bunkers along the Andes. Curfews and martial law had become permanent across the nation, and succession groups were popping up in Chile and Uruguay, forcing more troops to be diverted. The five Soviet scientists were taken to a bunker underneath Cerro Norte, supposedly for their own protection but in actuality they were taken as hostages to prevent the Soviets from potentially attacking the Argentine mainland. 

Argentina was not devastated like other countries after the November 3, 2026 solar flare. Emergency technicians were sent to make sure nothing was damaged in the bunkers, and the decision to use only hard copies of files instead of computers ended up being a saving grace for not just Argentina, but humanity as a whole. Drought and wildfires burned almost half of Uruguay to a crisp, and desalination plants were being worked around the clock to minimize deaths from dehydration. The navigation and radar systems for all of Argentina’s navy became inoperable due to the EMP, and operations for the Brazilian Pacification had to be significantly scaled back. The Red Hand was essentially abandoned, as when Argentina’s communication grid was gradually restored, the regiments in Antarctica reported that they had been attacked by an unknown hostile force and that the garrison had been overrun. Satellites were completely fried, and after a week, an outpost in the Falkland Islands finally confirmed it was not cartel members, like many in the Argentine government had expected, but actually a country that had been largely neutral to Argentina: the Union of Australia and New Zealand. 

Argentina switched to a full war-time economy with all the remaining operational factories churning out guns, ammunition, and uniforms. The Patagonian military swelled to almost 35 million troops. Special Forces and elite battalions, ones that had been lying in reserve to protect the network of bunkers, were drafted up to fight against the Australian incursions. President Roca, worried about the holdings in Antarctica, diverted almost half of Argentina’s remaining functional military equipment and engaged in a break neck campaign to retake Antarctica. 

Information out of Antarctica was scarce, but battalions of tanks and reconnaissance blimps were spotted rolling across the Pensacola Mountains. Australian troops were estimated to be between 15,000 and 45,000, and were expected to reach Santa Roca by mid January, 2027. It was here that President Roca, now colder than lost winter, considered using Argentina’s emergency arsenal of nuclear weapons in a preemptive strike against Australia. The operational status of Argentina’s nukes were unknown. 

As of 2027, Argentina is teetering on the brink of total collapse, as the Treaty of Patagonia is slowly becoming just a piece of paper. Diversionary troops are being sacrificed by the millions in Peru and Brazil, with the rest of the Alliance becoming fractured police states. The Argentine-Australian War for Antarctica is rapidly turning into a war of survival. President Roca is no longer questioning if, but rather when the nukes finally fly, be it Argentina, Australia, or Brazil who launches them first.

Four Horsemen
Section 1: Neutral Arab States
Excerpt from "The World Obituary: Nations of the World during The Black Ages", by Dr. Alaric Themiston Heliodor, Prof. Marek Stęcrowicz Orionis, Dr. Aryasatya Pramodhyantara, and Dr. Eirikson Valehart. Great Lakes Press, Second Edition. Originally published in 967 ASJ, edited 973 ASJ


https://youtu.be/4j0O1CLtMsg?si=DU7N87-whaUk8H3K 
Algeria

Official name: Zakat Republic of Algeria (until 1989), Algerian State (1989-2009)
Capital: Algiers
Government Type: Presidential Republic (until 1989), Authoritarian Dictatorship (1989-2009)
Population as of final census conducted: 58,512,345 (circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 36,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $560.7 Billion USD
Primary Language: Algerian Arabic/Dziria
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Mediterranean Economic Alliance (until 1989)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Negotiations between France and the newly independent Algeria resulted in a young, but healthy democracy. The military of Algeria, riding high on the war of independence, decided to cancel a coup at the last minute, and as the Glorious Decades continued on, Algeria became a model of pre-Crash liberal democracy. Instead of opting for a full on civil war, Houari Boumédiène, leader of the FLN, chose subtler routes to gaining power. For the most part, Algeria continued down its socialist path, and the FLN manipulated things from behind the scenes. Coercion, bribery, and blackmail happened in just the right amount to tip things in the FLN’s favor while also keeping plausible deniability. While Algeria remained very democratic on paper, in practice it was incredibly corrupt, as corruption, infighting and smuggling led to many infrastructure and public works projects to fall through. 

This all changed in 1972, when Algeria signed the Shanghai Accords. China and the European Union began importing their oil in record numbers, and soon the corrupt politicians in Algeria realized they could make far more money selling oil, minerals and metal than by making shady business deals and smuggling construction equipment across Africa. China in particular made Algeria very rich, as they imported several million tons of gold, silver, zinc, and lead between 1972-1988. Pipelines were constructed to transport oil and natural gas from Algeria to Europe, with the Almeria-Beni Saf Pipeline opening in 1973, the Caligari-Annaba Pipeline in 1975, and the Trans-Mediterranean Pipeline opening in 1979, which transported oil directly to several cities in France and Italy. 

This made Algeria extremely, fabulously rich, and living standards skyrocketed. A single month’s salary for working at an oil refinery could pay for a new luxury car, and miners were compensated even more, with some of them becoming millionaires. The bickering between the two factions in the government simmered as everyone enjoyed the wealth and prosperity. Things were getting so good in fact, that in 1982, a socialist president was elected without so much of an eyebrow raised from the FLN. President Karim Belhadj, seeing what the rest of the Arab world was doing at the time, decided to expand living conditions and make an extensive welfare state. Funds were given to religious organizations, artists, bankers, grocers, pretty much anyone who asked for money, got it. Tourist traps sprung up all along the coast. Opulent and intricate sculptures were built in every city, and so much artwork was produced that a museum dedicated entirely to artwork produced during this era was opened in Algiers, called the Belhadj Memorial Museum. Mosques became extravagant temples that began to rival Mecca, and every imam had a limousine. 

President Belhadj was also remembered as the man who organized the “Oath of Brotherhood”, a conference held over several months in 1983. The conference, which invited many religious leaders from around the country, provided an open forum for religious sects to come together and discuss their differences with civility. While not every religious faction was able to make peace (such as the Twelver Shias, for example), a vast majority of them were. The Algerian Holy Parliament was created, which served as a way for religious leaders to discuss how to tackle political matters. One representative was elected to be the “Oathkeeper”, who would serve in the President’s Cabinet and advise him in religious matters. Many in the religious fringes tried to paint President Belhadj as an infidel, but this was disproven when he officially renamed Algeria to the Zakat Republic of Algeria - Zakat being the islamic concept of giving to charity, referring to the extensive welfare state. While the state remained openly secular, the religious in Algeria experienced a revival in islamic art, poetry, and even film. The Noor Cinema Festival, an annual film festival that featured Muslim-directed films, was held in Algiers two times: One in 1985 and another in 1987. 

While Algeria had joined the League for Arab Cooperation in the 1980s, they still remained closely aligned with Europe, China, and America during the Glorious Decades. As such, they did not provide any military aid for their brothers in Egypt and Iraq. As the Sinai Crisis spiraled out of control, President Belhadj urged everyone to keep a cool head, as he stated that “everyone on this Earth are brothers, and we should treat our family with love”. This fell on deaf ears to the delegates in Iraq, Egypt, and Israel. Algeria even offered to host negotiations in April of 1988. 

When the bombs dropped, because of their neutrality, Algeria was spared from any direct attacks. The Crash of 1988 heavily affected the welfare state of Algeria, as the price of oil rising meant fewer states could afford their products. Pro-Egypt Islamic Nationalists, who believed that President Belhadj was a hypocrite and should have intervened on the side of the Arab world, started bombing pipelines going into Europe. This was followed by a Chinese tanker being sabotaged and scuttled in the Mediterranean, spilling almost 100,000 tons of chemically-enhanced lead into the sea. After the EU stopped buying Algerian energy for “national security” reasons, and China stopped importing Algerian minerals, the carefully constructed zakat state began to rapidly unravel. Members of the nascent Qatifism movement targeted and destroyed mosques that were deemed “too opulent”, and then targeted the mansions of wealthy religious leaders. A bomb almost going off at the Holy Parliament Building in Algiers caused the Islamic Congress to be suspended indefinitely before being dismantled in 1990. 

By the end of August 1988, President Belhadj was the most hated man in Algeria. Many accusations were tossed around: lack of faith, corruption, and even treason. Belhadj was impeached on September 1, 1988, and while he avoided the death penalty, he was exiled from the country. Supposedly, he fled to Iran to help the Islamic Socialist movement there, but reports instead state that he died of lung complications in France in 2002. 

This led to the Algerian Crisis of 1988, where due to political infighting and civil unrest, the ruling coalition fragmented. After several months, the hundreds of candidates had boiled down to three: a famous footballer running on a platform of vague populism, the President of the Assembly, running on a platform of islamic nationalism, and the General of the Armed Forces, who ran on a platform of stability and self-reliance. Despite the low turnout, the votes took over 2 weeks to count, and the winner was the footballer. 

This caused General Mourad Ben Salah to stage an FLN-supported coup, and executed the footballer on live television on January 5, 1989. Martial law was declared, and the welfare state was heavily cut back to only the bare minimum. Rationing was enforced, and while it was claimed to be temporary, it was never lifted. Just like the rationing, General Ben Salah claimed that his dictatorship was temporary, and that it was only until the country was stable again. Radiation and smoke spreading from the ruins of the Middle East drifted across south Algeria, and checkpoints were set up along the border to catch refugees fleeing from the cataclysmic civil wars. Programs of self-reliance were established, with a large-scale reindustrialization program starting in 1990. 

General Ben Salah also destroyed much of the signs of opulence from the Glorious Decades, with the motto of “equalizing everything through poverty”. He was actually true to his word - the gold-plated mosques were broken down and their gold used for electronics, and the many luxury cars were broken down for parts. The General never hoarded these items for himself or his men, he drove the same austere vehicles as everyone else and executed those found hoarding. 

This mass shift away from consumer products and the smoke in the air actually caused Algeria to survive the Hot Summer of 1990 with minimal casualties, as more people died from smoke exposure than from drought or heat. Huge recycling factories were built on the edges of the Sahara. Intensive farms were set up in the fertile northern mountains, and while nobody was eating five-course meals, nobody starved either. 

Algeria seemed to actually be on the path to recovery. Housing projects, recycling drives, and intensive farms kept everyone more or less employed, and for a while, it appeared that things were getting better. Algeria even joined the Alliance of Nations in 1995, and signed several trade deals with European countries and later the Federation in the 1990s. Algeria also allied itself with Morocco, forming the Pact of Gribaltar. 

Behind the scenes, things were slipping. Increasingly devastating droughts in the southern provinces had required more and more water to be sent in. Reports of religious militants also dominated the news cycle in the mid 1990s, and caused further delays on water shipments. 

This culminated in a massive drought in June of 1996, forcing almost 90% of the population to flee to the northern cities along the coast. Overcrowding, resource shortages, religious extremism, and ethnic tension all grew until it spiraled out of control, escalating from violence and riots to a full on civil war. The Governor of Laghouat, the Imam of Qacentina, the acting General of the Armed Forces, and the “martyr of Sahara” all vied for control. The sands became stained with blood as increasingly horrific battles were fought across the quickly collapsing state, which by 2000 was no more. The civil war ended without a victor, just several dozen statelets that fell to famine and drought. 

The closest thing to a “victor” in this civil war was the city of Algiers, which renamed itself as the “People’s Government of Algeria”. The city-state, led by General Ben Salah’s former Minister of the Interior, started out with good intentions, but after the Red Summer was effectively little more than a puppet state for the Federation to siphon out the last remaining easily-accessable resources in Algeria. After the city flooded in 2009, it was never rebuilt, and the Mayor/General/President was hanged by a lamppost. 

Throughout the 2010s, the anarchy spread, with refugees fleeing from the Middle East to try to get into the Federation, unaware of their borders being closed for over a decade. These groups organized based on ethnicity, country of origin, and religion, and eventually organized into a very loose confederacy to prevent further incursions, as if saying “fuck you, I got mine”. Spanish and Italian refugees, fleeing from the purges in the Federation, settled in the north-western regions of Algeria, forming militaristic warlord states that constantly waged war with the Constantine Confederacy. 

The Great Heat Waves of 2015 and 2016 cripped what little civilization there was even further. Warlords waged war over wells and pumps, while a huge fleet tried to sail across the sea and land in France. They were massacred by the European Navy, and those that survived returned to a land devastated by drought and famine. Flooding and salinization ruined the coast. By 2017, reports of cannibalism were widespread, as survivors devoured those who had fallen from the heat. 

In 2018, a Spanish warlord managed to unite much of north-west Algeria, creating a feudal state organized along ethnic lines, before being killed by his lieutenant during the Second Great Heat Wave of 2023. Massive droughts caused many to die of dehydration and the warlords to fight amongst themselves. 

In the aftermath of the Second Great Heat Wave, those in the Constantine Confederacy had a low enough population that cannibalism was kept to a minimum. Tribes of raiders and scavengers fought over the ruins of Algeria and Tunisia, and farmers battled the encroaching Sahara to grow sickly, diseased potatoes. Some survivors had constructed crude, barely-functional desalination tanks that they guarded with ancient guns, quickly creating a water-based economy. 

This lasted until the Solar Flare of 2026, where the makeshift desalination plants broke down and were unable to be restored. The loose alliance that had united the survivors in the Constantine hills broke apart, and ironically, became more chaotic and violent than the feudal realms of the warlords. 

By 2027, the Constantine Water War slugs on, while millions of serfs are ground under the heel of a dozen warlords. Very few remember the country that existed here just 30 years ago. 
Tunisia

Official name: Zakat Republic of Tunisia (until 1989), State of Tunisia (1989-2002), Republic of Tunisia (1989-2002, disputed), Revolutionary Tunisia (1989-2011, disputed)
Capital: Tunis (de jure after 1989), Tripoli (de facto after 1989)
Government Type: Left-wing Dictatorship (until 1989), Government in Exile (1989-2002), Liberal Democracy (1989-2002, disputed), Authoritarian Dictatorship (1989-2011, disputed)
Population as of final census conducted: 23,083,270 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 6,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $11.1 Billion USD
Primary Language: Tunisian Arabic/Tūnsi 
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: COMECON (until 1989)
