Great Death Survival Rating: Partial


In the 1970s, the loosely socialist aligned dictatorship threw their lot in with the Soviet Union. Despite remaining extremely repressive, Habib Bourguiba decided that Chen’s China was a betrayal of the working party, and this earned them many brownie points with the USSR. Secretary Agassi frequently visited Tunisia, and throughout the 1970s, Tunisia was one of the more prosperous countries in the Second World. 

Following Poland’s example, Tunisia opened up and finally signed the Shanghai Accords in 1981. A large service and information technology opened up, with Tunis becoming the “call center capital for Europe”. Tunisia remained closely aligned with the Soviet Union, and prioritized them over their Arab brothers. In 1982, Bourguiba declined allowing the PLO to base their headquarters in Tunis. Instead, Egypt became their staunchest supporters (of humanitarian aid, at the time). 

Tunisia officially renamed itself to a Zakat Republic in 1983, despite already championing Arab Socialism. The third Triumvirate of the Soviet Union stopped trying to convince them down the path of full-on communism, and deemed the Zakat system to be “close enough”. Tunisia competed with Algeria in selling their energy to Europe, but never came close, with only a singular pipeline being constructed - the Marsala-Tunis Pipeline. Tunisia also developed a growing tourism industry, with mainly Soviet tourists visiting. After the Concord of Moscow, many Soviet citizens became fascinated with the Star Wars trilogy, with some visiting the filming locations in Tunisia and recreating scenes. 

In 1988, Bourguiba still refused to support the PLO and their allies in the Sinai War. After the Crash of 1988 and the rapid decline in Soviet aid (Voronin claimed that they were well on the way to communism, and Moscow would focus on other countries more “in need” of revolution), the CRD became more and more repressive. Pro-Egypt bombings never happened on the scale they did in Algeria: a major terrorist attack was thwarted by Special Agent Augusto Fernando César, his last international mission before retiring to domestic work in Brazil. This operation pacified the extremists, who instead moved on to Egypt where they followed the Grand Ayatollah in his Great Jihad. 

Tunisia became more and more of a police state, with immigration being suspended in August 1988, rationing implemented in October 1988, and a nationwide curfew being implemented in early 1989. Trade negotiations with Italy broke down, and the pipeline was shut down on the Tunisian side. Bourguiba still had many connections in Moscow, and managed to secure a deal with the Soviets. Tunisian oil was given to the Soviets for a lucrative price, in exchange for guns, ammo, and food. 

Inside the government, opposition only grew. Many compared Tunisia to the relative prosperity Algeria was experiencing, and some wanted to re-align themselves with the West and potentially receive more aid. This movement grew and grew, and on April 9, 1989, Bourguiba was deposed in a coup led by his Prime Minister, Mourad Kassar. Kassar quickly reorganized the policies of the government, such as suspending all sales of oil to the Soviets, and even lifting the rationing and curfew orders. Hundreds of services became privatized, all the government-owned companies were sold off, and generous tax incentives were made to lure in western investors. 

It seemed like a great plan, except, no one came. President Graves didn’t even send a reply to President Kassar’s half-dozen letters, promising lucrative income tax reductions for foreign investors and a willing workforce. Europe, who was quickly becoming more and more socialist, was incredibly suspicious of Kassar’s sudden change of policy. In response to this pandering, both the Soviet Union and China severed diplomatic ties with Tunisia. 

Kassar’s liberalization policies were a complete failure, and just a month later, on May 19, 1989, Kassar fled the country, taking with him anyone he deemed “worth a damn”. He ended up settling in Libya, where he claimed he was the legitimate head of state for Tunisia, governing in exile. He was killed by rebels during the 2002 Libyan Revolution, with much of his entourage killed or missing. 

This plunged the nation into a brutal civil war, with the northern half of the country becoming the “Tunesian Liberation Front”, composed of rebels who wished for a return to a Glorious Decades-era centrally planned economy. The rebels were headquartered in Bizerte, and used Soviet-supplied weapons to attack government forces. The remnants of Kassar’s government, those who didn’t flee with him, formed the “Tunesian Democratic Union”. The government forces, despite being based on liberal democracy, remained extremely oppressive and did not provide many opportunities for businesses or elections. They were located in Gabès, and constantly tried to beg the West for aid, claiming that once the rest of the country was under their control, they would hold elections. 

Both of these factions quickly turned into failed states, as the rebels fell to infighting and the government forces devolved into warlords and dictators. Many fled from Tunisia, taking boats across the sea to Italy. Tunis declared independence in 1995, and while they did not ally with the rebels, they did have a distinctly socialist government. Droughts in 1996 and heatwaves in 1997 resulted in almost half of the population dying, and a bomb going off at the last operational oil refinery caused the government forces to finally collapse. 

Tunis remained alone in a vast sea of anarchy, though the People’s President of Tunis was assassinated in 2002 around the same time as the Libyan Revolution, and throughout the 2000s, more than a dozen people held the office before being killed by conspirators or bandits. Tunis was burned to the ground in 2011 by a band of roving refugees, and increasingly hostile sandstorms devastated the countryside. Tiny, isolated communes remained, and after the Great Heat Wave of 2015, inherited the corpse of Tunisia. 

Between 2017 and 2022, many of these tiny city-states joined the Constantine Confederacy and started to share surplus food in exchange for technology. Islamic warlords and radiation-worshipping death cults from the former Middle East frequently invaded lower Tunisia, driving the survivors into the Atlas Mountain Highlands. 

After the Second Great Heat Wave, the survivors of Tunisia became even more closely intertwined with the Constantine Confederacy, and desalinated Algerian water was traded for tiny Tunisian potatoes. The Solar Flare of 2026 put an end to this, as disagreements over water allocation caused the Tunisian and Algerian sides of the Constantine Confederacy to fracture into a civil war. 

By 2027, the Constantine Water War wages on, though the Tunisian side is winning. 
Morocco

Official name: Zakat Kingdom of Morocco, Socialist Republic of Morocco (1999-2005, disputed), Moroccan Federation (2005-2009, disputed)
Capital: Rabat, Casablanca (2005-2009, disputed)
Government Type: Far-Left Constitutional Monarchy, Far Left Dictatorship (1999-2005, disputed), Federation Puppet State (2005-2009, disputed)
Population as of final census conducted: 48,504,294 (circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 38,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $281 Billion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic
Member of the Alliance of Nations: YES
Alignment: Mediterranean Economic Alliance, COMECON (1999-2005, disputed)
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

After the death of King Mohammed V, Prince Moulay Abdullah ascended to the throne in 1961. His elder brother, Hassan II, was killed during the 1958 Rif Riots when his plane was shot down. Hassan II was already groomed by their father to succeed him on the throne, so King Abdullah I was initially woefully unprepared for ruling. Out of fear and anticipating further riots, he relinquished some of his power and established a constitutional monarchy modeled after the UK. A bicameral parliament is formed, with the lower house being composed of a mix of mayors of large cities and religious leaders, being called the People’s Chamber. The upper house, called the Moulay Assembly, was composed of members of the aristocracy and other high-ranking members of his father’s government, along with governors and military leaders. 

This actually worked very well, and instead of people rioting in the streets and killing each other, they instead shouted from the top of their lungs in the capitol. The Moulay Assembly always had the final say and had to approve on what the People’s Chamber proposed, but when it came down to brass tacks, they agreed on a lot of stuff. King Abdullah I had succeeded in making his job a lot easier: the people governed for him and he simply signed off on orders. In the meantime, throughout the early 1960s, he continued seeing a tutor to help him complete his studies in law. 

Tax incentives and foreign investment led to a massive phosphate boom in the late 1960s, and in 1972, Morocco signed the Shanghai Accords. Phosphate became the country’s biggest export, going to places like Brazil, France, and China. A coalition of religious leaders and social democrats, called the Zakat Party (HA), proposed using the country’s vastly increasing wealth to create a safety net for those less fortunate. This notion barely passed, appealing to the more religious members of the Moulay Assembly. Besides the loose welfare safety net, most of the government’s policies in the 1970s boiled down to building a thriving tourism industry. Morocco was one of the more popular places to visit in Africa, and to try to emulate the tropical oceanic style of their competitors in the Pacific, beach resorts opened up all along their coast. Several Spanish resort companies collaborated with Moroccan conglomerates to create “resort cities”, completely planned cities where every single building was some kind of service. The largest of these, the Tangier International Resort, was finished in 1979 and provided almost 1% of Morocco’s GDP for that year. 

Unfortunately, King Abdullah I died on October 4, 1981, from cancer-related breathing complications. His eldest son, Prince Moulay Hicham, ascended to the throne. Unlike his father, he became very invested in politics, and earned the name “The Red King” for his many left-leaning policies. King Hicham I actively participated in every legislative meeting, and became a champion of the Zakat Party. Under his rule, he officially renamed Morocco into the Zakat Kingdom of Morocco, saying that a “true king serves his people”. The Zakat Party grew significantly over the course of 1982, but then it was split in a schism: King Hicham I began proposing radical reforms and expanding women’s rights. The Conservatives in the Zakat Party split and formed the Orthodox Zakat Party (HAL), and the liberals renamed the party to the People’s Zakat Party (HAA). 

There was a massive uproar at this, and as a compromise, King Hicham I officially passed a new constitution that made his position purely ceremonial, and the new head of state was a popularly elected President, whose Prime Minister was chosen by the Parliament of Morocco. The first Presidential Election was on December 1, 1982, and Tariq Benhassan of the HAA won in a landslide. His first major policy he passed through parliament was a massive increase to education spending, with a program to provide free tuition to families who had never been to college. President Benhassan ended up being an extremely controversial figure, as the country was split almost 50/50 in their opinion of him. He was known for being one of the first countries to host the newest secretary of the Soviet Union, Gennady Yanayev, who congratulated him on his socialist policies. 

Morocco quickly became a black sheep: the Arab world was distanced by their progressive rights for women, while the communist world confused by how Morocco never became secular: in fact, President Benhassen frequently paused debates and interviews to pray on live television. Many were baffled by this: he could never be accused of being an infidel as he was extremely pious, and he could not be described as conservative because of his radical views on women’s rights. As such, while Morocco remained an observer member of the League for Arab Prosperity, they did not aid either the Israelis or the Egyptians. 

After the Sinai War went nuclear, the stock market crashed, and the Shock rippled through the economies of the world, Morocco managed to barely survive the initial aftereffects. Morocco was a very energy-hungry nation, and with the massive drop of oil supplies, electricity was the first commodity to be rationed. President Benhassen started a campaign to encourage people to minimize electricity use, with citizens encouraged to use alternative light sources during the night. Phosphate mining kept the country’s economy afloat, if unstable, and energy shortages led to setbacks and supply chain disruptions. Every year, the welfare was cut back and chiseled away, bit by bit, as the government struggled to tackle the rapidly shrinking budget. Benhassen repealed his education program in 1990, and a massive famine during the Hot Summer required Morocco to use its own phosphate and import hundreds of thousands of kg of American food, putting the government in massive debt. 

The reduction of living standards were so gradual, and the President had earned so much good will, the public continued living on as normal, if less well fed and more unemployed. He won reelection in 1990, though not by as big of a margin as he did in 1982. In 1991, many of the coastal resort cities, which had been decaying for several years now, were turned into housing for the homeless. This plan, while it had good intentions, did not end up as the President had envisioned: years of little to no maintenance had made the buildings highly unstable, and over 3,000 people were killed due to structural collapse when a massive hotel gave out. Government-provided candles meant to replace electricity use during the night time led to several large fires, with the city of Fez almost burning down in 1992. 

With so many people looking for meaning in this crisis, President Benhassen turned to an unexpected solution: he began leading the nation in daily prayer on live television. This did help the morale of the nation, and saw a dramatic reduction of secularism. Based on interviews conducted in 1993, the number of people who described themselves as atheists, secular, or agnostic had dropped by 450%. In 1994, Morocco attempted to join the European Federation, but their application was denied. The countries that imported their phosphate also claimed that their trade contracts were now null and would need to be re-negotiated as the states were now part of a larger entity, and thus the contract reflected an obsolete nation. There was nothing in the European Constitution that stipulated this though, and in reality, it was just another attempt to exploit Morocco. In 1995, Morocco joined the Alliance of Nations, and continued to limp on towards the 21st century. 

This ended in June of 1996, when a massive drought devastated the Maghreb region. President Benhassen’s response to this was incredibly lackluster, and he was eventually impeached in July of 1996. His Prime Minister, Abdelkarim Tazi, took over as acting President, and tried to keep the country together. Western Sahara was officially given independence (it had already been completely autonomous by 1983) as it was seen as too expensive to maintain. Rationing was reduced to a point where people were barely given enough to live, and martial law was declared after food riots in Casablanca caused 203 deaths. 

President Tazi desperately tried to keep the country together, but it was running on fumes and held together with duct tape, spit, and hope. In 1997, Morocco had run out of oil and could no longer afford to transport their phosphate to the coasts for shipping, leading to it being prioritized for domestic use. Sandstorms in 1998 and 1999 caused further strife, and a border crisis near Tangier almost led to war with the Federation, which made a promising deal with FulTec fall through. 

Spillover from the Algerian Civil War forced Morocco to honor the Pact of Gribaltar and send troops to their eastern neighbor, however, this led to the interior of the country becoming only minimally defended. This was when former President Benhassen launched his “revolution”: bitter at his impeachment and feeling humiliated, he had been contacted by an agent of Director Savateev and was persuaded to go down the path of full communism. Using guns smuggled from Tunisia, Benhassen stormed the capitol, forced King Hicham I to reinstate him as President by “royal decree”, and killed President Tazi by hanging him. Some of his more radical supporters, believing that the Soviet model was the way of the future, began purging religious leaders in the community. Things got out of control and President Benhassen was hanged by his own men for not being an atheist, and things only got messier from there. The troops on their way to Algeria were recalled and a brutal civil war broke out. 

The Red King once again took up his mantle and tried to direct the military, suspending the democratic functions of government until the crisis was under control. The rebels, upon taking Casablanca, declared the “Socialist Republic of Morocco” and immediately allied themselves with the Soviets. In 2000, when shipments of Soviet weapons and supplies began arriving, the Civil War teetered on the brink of victory for the Socialists, while the Monarchist Forces were routed. King Hicham I was killed during the bombing of Rabat in 2001, and it seemed that the Monarchist Forces were about to surrender when an unexpected ally appeared: the Federation. While they were not AS involved as they were during the Greek Civil War, they did keep the Monarchists from losing for the majority of 2002. 

And then the Red Summer hit, and all the European and Soviet support dried up. More soldiers died from heat exhaustion than from combat, and temporary, spontaneous truces were formed on the battlefields as combatants stayed in the shade. The Socialists, believing their cause more just, broke the truces and got the last Monarchist holdouts to surrender. 

The Socialist Republic of Morocco lasted for less than two years, as in 2005, the Federation invaded Morocco to “liberate” them from the yoke of Moscow. The USSR, busy dealing with the Greek Civil War, the spreading Red Flu and various rebellions, could not spare anything and thus the Federation pacified Morocco in less than a week. 

A puppet state was formed, the Federation of Morocco, led by a Spanish general in the Federation’s Army. Not much changed, really - phosphate was extracted at great material cost, and hundreds died a month from heat exhaustion. Federation soldiers openly patrolled the streets, and criminals were executed rather than being sent to jail or to a labor camp. Collaborators were given extra water, extra food, reduced work hours and better housing. 

Of course, nationalists and rebels made it hard for them. Bombings by Moroccans led to retaliatory killings by the Federation. Displaying the Moroccan flag (of either the original kingdom or the socialist republic) became a crime in 2006. Works of art and national monuments were destroyed. Groups of more than 5 people were prohibited. Ironically, this common enemy made the Socialists and the Monarchists (though there weren’t many left) join forces, with King Hicham I’s personal guard taking several Federation soldiers hostage during a riot. 


Photograph of a crowd of rebels displaying the Moroccan flag during a protest in Casablanca. Taken in 2008. 

In response, the Federation simply bombed them, killing their troops and over 400 civilians as well. As word began to spread in the Federation of the massacre (despite their control of the media), public support began to dwindle. FulTec decided it was necessary, and so the operation continued, despite the Federation’s losses in Greece. 

The Federation’s control was finally lifted when a massive flood in 2009 destroyed the last functional ports on Morocco’s coasts, and it was deemed too expensive to repair them, so the troops were hastily pulled out. Many were left behind, with some of them joining the Monarchists and Socialists, which were at odds yet again. Federation collaborators were strung up by nooses, then suspected collaborators, and then anyone the mob didn’t agree with. 

The civil war resumed, and marched on into 2010 and 2011 before finally collapsing into anarchy in the Purple Summer of 2011. People were no longer fighting over phosphate, or for ideological reasons, but instead fighting over caches of FulTec rations or access to water. Warlords formed fiefdoms, forcing slaves to work to death in fields. Every month, hundreds died in suicide attacks to become martyrs. 

The Great Heat Wave of 2015 forced many of the survivors to flee north and into the Atlas mountains, divided by the remnants of the Socialists, Monarchists, and Federation Forces. All three factions had long given up their ideologies, essentially becoming identical warlords. In 2017, the Moroccans allied for the last time and forced the remnants of the Federation, led by a Spanish Warlord, into the ruins of north-west Algeria. 

After the Second Great Heat Wave of 2023, many were sick of the fighting and drifted west, eventually settling on the coast in the husks of the once-opulent resort cities. Settlements began to be formed as treasure hunters combed the ruins for anything that could be useful, and ate whatever they could, including their dead. A complex barter economy was established and these towns became loosely allied with each other against the Socialists and the Monarchists, who would come down from the mountains to raid them for supplies. 

In 2026, Morocco became flooded with refugees fleeing from the European Spring and the dwindling power of the Federation, who mainly joined the side of the Scavengers. This resulted in a brief increase in living standards as European mechanics and engineers created crude desalination systems and pumps. Morocco’s coast became a relatively nice place once again, as long as you didn’t go out during the day and were fine eating dead raiders. 

The Solar Flare of 2026 put an end to this, as whatever ramshackle technology the Scavengers and Mountain Raiders had built fell apart. The Scavengers were able to repair some of it, but for the Mountain Raiders, they did not have the skills, knowing only two decades of guerilla warfare. They looked down with jealousy at their neighbors and ramped up their raids significantly. 

By 2027, the Mountain Raiders were mounting offensives using looted Federation weapons. Now, the Scavengers were running from the ever-expanding ocean and the Raiders from above. 
Mauritania

Official name: Islamic Republic of Mauritania (until 1989), State of Mauritania (1989-2011)
Capital: Nouakchott (until 2002), Nouadhibou (2002-2011)
Government Type: Authoritarian Republic (until 1989), Feudal State (1989-2011)
Population as of final census conducted: 5,439,151 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: Less than 1000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $111.7 Million USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Organization of African States (until 1989)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Mauritania remained rather obscure and forgotten, even as far back as the 1960s. While they did sign the Shanghai Accords in the 1970s, the Islamic Republic of Mauritania was not very involved on the world stage, being a regional power at best. Mauritania, while they remained an observer state of the League for Arab Prosperity, were never granted full membership due to their resistance towards full on Arab Socialism and creating a Zakat state. Mauritania also never joined the Non-Aligned Movement, as they tried repeatedly to get into the trading blocs dominated by the USSR and China, flip-flopping between the two blocs in a futile attempt to curry favor with the two Eastern Giants. In the end, the country joined the smallest, least recognized and least influential trading bloc: the Organization of African States, which was composed of similarly ignored countries. 

The only resources of note within Mauritania were some reserves of iron, the rest of their vast resources were located in areas deep within the Sahara or in areas where it was extremely impractical and costly to extract them. While their economy never went into a recession, its GDP never rose as fast as their neighbors. Countries only bought their iron when they very urgently needed it for construction, and could not wait for cheaper, farther away sources to be shipped to them. Consequently, Mauritania became known as “Ould Daddah’s Playground”. Occasionally, some of the more socially liberal states like Morocco or Argentina would threaten an investigation by the UN, but they remained empty threats. 

In 1975, while trying to join the World Prosperity Alliance, Ould Daddah was thoroughly discouraged from invading Western Sahara. Instead, he tried to create a program of “National Excellence in Resources”, which basically boiled down to surveying the Sahara for mineral deposits. The results were quite bad (due to mismanagement, corruption, and sheer incompetency), and the findings are what cost them their potential partnership with China. 

Being their only lifeline, the iron mines were exploited more and more every year, with some of them reaching over 2 km deep into the earth. These remained extremely dangerous sites, yet millions still worked in them as it was the only reliable occupation in the country. The country teetered on the brink of famine several times, and the aging President Ould Daddah, at the insistence of the Soviet Ambassador (he was trying to join COMECON at this time) created a “self-reliance” food program, which boiled down to intensive fishing. In 1982, Mauritania almost got into a war with Senegal (another COMECON state) over fishing rights, which caused Mauritania to fail their application yet again. 

Droughts in the early 1980s forced many to move into the cities to look for work, further crowding the coast. Austerity programs and rationing initiatives created in the mid-80s also helped slow down the consumption of resources. Conversely, fishing only intensified, and several species were reported extinct as early as 1983. To further solidify his control, President Ould Daddah started covertly rounding up the nomadic ethnic minorities and forcing them to work in the mines, on the grounds of “protecting them from heat exhaustion”. In 1985, full-on resettlement programs forced the rest of the people in the interior of the country, those who had stayed behind, and placed them in newly built “economic invigoration camps”. Ould Daddah believed these initiatives would make the country look more modern, and thus more attractive to the rest of the world. 

By 1987, 90% of Mauritania’s population was located within 5 miles of the coastline, and the remaining 10% were military personnel who patrolled the desert territories for incursions. To Ould Daddah’s surprise, it turned out that no one wanted vast stretches of scorching sand, but still he kept the patrols up. Mauritania wasn’t as bad off as places like Bolivia, but very, very few prospects existed for its citizens. Many citizens tried to emigrate to other nations, and that was partly the reason behind the population resettlement programs and military patrols - if everyone could leave, he’d have no one to rule over. 

Because of how isolated Mauritania was from the world stage (though not by choice), they were barely affected by the Crash of ‘88 and the aftermath of the Sinai War. Food and fuel were already being rationed, and they were simply extended. President Ould Daddah reportedly laughed up hearing how Egypt and the rest of the Middle East had gone up in nuclear flames - he viewed it as justice for having excluded him for so long. 

Problems only really started making themselves apparent in 1989, as various countries in Europe, the Americas and Africa placed tariffs on their iron. This was Mauritania’s last lifeline, and with it, the economy was washed away with the tide. 

On February 7, 1989, President Ould Daddah would appear on live television to attempt to reassure the handful of wealthy citizens that things were totally fine, and Mauritania would find another source of income. This went so badly, that he was assassinated with a hand grenade halfway through his speech, with the cameras still rolling. 

There was no civil war - there wasn’t really anything to fight over. A bloodless coup (minus Ould Daddah’s corpse) of a cabal of wealthy land owners, industrialists, farmers, and mine owners banded together and decided to cut back on what little worker’s rights were left. They all decided that it was a mistake to ban slavery, and thus reinstated it. It was claimed that it gave every man a purpose, and the radical leaders in the new government even claimed it was their right. 

But that was where the new rulers’ common interests stopped. Infighting and disagreements quickly fractured the coalition, turning the patchwork of slave-based city states. People starved to death every day, or were forced to eat barely-organic foods that people in the 2020s would salivate at. The strict caste system and the sheer callousness of the Beidane had caused many, many people to die. Sometimes, landlords would force their slaves to swarm another Beidane’s land. In the Hot Summer of 1990, some slave owners even started feeding their slaves the remains of their fallen brothers, as they were seen as unworthy of receiving actual food. Other slave owners believed this was barbaric, leading to a small war, but the anarchy remained. 

Each of the city-states claimed to be the true successor to Mauritania, and some of them waged war on the others to grow their influence. By 1995, Mauritania had been divided into several major factions. The Iron Tagant controlled the remnants of the iron mines, though they were quickly running out of ore. The Salt Lords sold their fish to the other factions, but they too were running out of stock. Sublime Gorgol was the largest of these factions and sold crops to the others. 

And what did they use as a currency? Well, the only resource in abundance left - other humans. Very large transactions were paid for in iron, fish, or bread, or sometimes gold, but for tiny transactions, slaves were exchanged. How many slaves a lord owned was viewed as how influential they were, with the more slaves they owned, the more powerful their standing was. Mercenaries engaged in expeditions into the Sahara to capture fleeing refugees, and sold them in the coastal cities for fish and bread. 

Word of the “Black State of Mauritania” spread, and those caught out in the deserts usually started to travel in large groups, as well as armed as they could, to fight off the raiders. Many women chose suicide if they feared their capture was imminent and there was no way out. Eventually, a small coalition of escaped slaves and militant socialists banded together in the Sahara, and began hunting these raiders back. This faction, the Sands of Time, were supposedly supported by Libya and Senegal. 

But for the Despots in the Black State, this only further emboldened them. The three factions united in 1998, forming the Confederation of Sublime Mauritania, and coordinated only in the defense of their territory. The back-and-forth nature of the raids only intensified, and in 2002, Nouakchott was destroyed in a series of brutal bombings. Senegal did not claim responsibility. 

The Red Summer of 2003 caused much of the population in the Sahara to die from dehydration, and raids no longer went east, instead focussing on Western Sahara and Morocco. Slave revolutions picked up in frequency in the 2000s. Iron Tagant was overthrown in 2004, followed by Sublime Gorgol in 2006. The Salt Lords held on through sheer force of will, and were the de facto inheritors of Mauritania’s legacy. 

However, in the Purple Summer of 2011, the increasing heat and acidification of the ocean caused the last local fish to be hunted to extinction. And with it, the remains of civilization also went extinct. 

Evidence is somewhat scarce, but according to Senegalese documents from around the time, a huge number of refugees from the north attempted to cross into Senegal. Some of them were shot down, and others escaped into the fragmenting states to the east. A final civil war, followed by a slave uprising, and followed by anarchy led to Mauritania to complete a complete wasteland by 2015. A few scavengers from Morocco ventured down the coast, though there was very little worth taking and by 2023, scavengers had stopped going that far south. 

By 2027, Mauritania was an empty, desolate wasteland. 
Somalia

Official name: Somali Zakat Republic (until 1990), Somali Caliphate (2000-2009)
Capital: Mogadishu
Government Type: Left-Wing Authoritarian Dictatorship (until 1990), Far-Right Theocracy (2000-2009)
Population as of final census conducted: 20,391,961 (circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 2,400,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $152 Billion USD
Primary Language: Somali/Af Soomaali
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: World Prosperity Alliance
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial


Somalia was a major battle ground for the proxy war between the USSR and China. In the 1970s, both countries dumped absurd amounts of money into Somalia’s economy and government. General Barre used this aid very well actually, significantly reducing rural poverty, having Soviet-style government purges against corruption, and dramatically increasing the literacy rate across the country. Goaded by China, and as a compromise for Ethiopia gaining Eritrea, Djibouti was granted to Somalia in an attempt to curry favor with them. 

As the Arab world was very intertwined with the Soviet Union, Barre made several alliances with other Arab Nations. This led to both Somalia and Ethiopia making peace over the Ogaden region, with the area being granted autonomy but still technically being administered by Ethiopia. Part of the treaty, known as the Dubai Pact (as it was mediated in the United Arab Emirates), stipulated that Ethiopian and Somali citizens could cross their border without visas, and also were given economic incentives to buy from each other. Ethiopian factory workers would cross the border every morning to go to work in Somalia, and Somali grocers stocked the markets of Ethiopia. The highlight of the treaty was that a new, joint Somali football team was formed (comprising of Ethiopia, Somalia, and the lands formerly known as Eritrea and Djibouti, respectively). In private, both Barre and his counterpart Selassie were unhappy with the situation, but it was a requirement for the ludicrous amounts of foreign aid both nations were receiving. The welfare state only increased, and after much pestering from his Arab allies, Somalia was renamed to the Somali Zakat Republic in 1979. 

In 1980, seeing the rapid growth in China, Barre fully allied with them and joined their trading bloc, the World Prosperity Alliance. The USSR did not take this well, and completely severed diplomatic relations. This opened the flood gates for China to come in and invest even more into the infrastructure of the country, with factories and processing plants springing up along the coast. China even rented out several docks from the government, and used them for unloading products for the African nations. China ended up using Somalia as a massive testing ground for all of their industrialization “experiments” for their adventures in the 2000s. Several mega-factories were built, mainly along the north coast along the Gulf of Aden to help facilitate shipping. Yet despite all of this industrial investment, their economy is still almost entirely based on agriculture. 

When the Sinai War, the Crash of ‘88 and the Shock rolled around, Somalia remained relatively stable. Their huge surplus of food kept everyone well fed, and rationing was not implemented until 1990. Much of the welfare related to education and healthcare had to be gradually scaled back, and Barre’s advisors were ripping their hair out trying to convince foreign businesses not to leave. The only country that still regularly traded with them was China, however, warehouses began to be raided by roving bands of refugees fleeing from the apocalyptic chaos in the north. On top of that, the industrial effects of China’s “economically viable” machinery led to a mass-die off of fish and ground water pollution, culminating in a week-long torrent of acid rain followed by a months-long sandstorm. Within just a few weeks, the people were rioting in the streets and raiding government depots. Barre, not believing it was China who was responsible for this sharp decline of living conditions, suspected it was sabotage carried out by Ethiopian saboteurs, so he rallied the country and blamed everything on Ethiopia, promptly invading them on June 27 1990. 

The Ethiopian-Somali “War”, if one could call it that, ended in a massacre as the comparatively professional Ethiopian Army gunned down the armies of peasants. By July 1, just a few days later, over 100,000 Somali soldiers had died and the Ethiopians had only lost three men. Barre tried to bug out and escape, but was caught in the streets of the capital and strung up by Soviet-influenced revolutionaries. 

This quickly spiraled out of control into a 25-way civil war, with just about every one of Barre’s advisors and commanders claiming to be the new head of state. Djibouti claimed independence but was immediately annexed by Ethiopia in 1991. Somalia collapsed into feudalism at best, and absolute anarchy at worst. City states rose and fell, declaring war on each other and raiding depots. Chinese factories were retooled to pump out weapons, and gangs, bandits and raiders carved up the countryside into tiny fiefdoms. Scavengers and pirates exploited refugees from the Middle Eastern nations, mainly from Yemen, and sold scrap to rump states in the Arabian peninsula. 

In many ways, Somalia was even more unstable than the ruined rump states in the Middle East, and several nations proposed a United Nations mission to help stabilize the region - but that brought into question if the nations in the Middle East needed to be stabilized as well, and then there debates about if the Soviet invasion of Iran and Afghanistan needed to be fought off too, and the conversations just devolved into further “but what if…” and nothing was done. Even China stopped trading with Somalia, just ignoring it for the most part and waiting for the anarchy to settle down. 

The brutal chaos continued until around 2000, when the civil war finally died down and a very unlikely successor arose: an Islamic warlord by the name of Warsame Nur al-Haqq. He was a devout follower of Qatafism, the mutation from Twelver Shia that was used to justify the Sinai War. As such, he turned the ruins of Mogadishu into an agrarian confederacy of neo-luddites. He immediately set out to reunite the rest of Somalia, succeeding in late 2004. When he attempted to take back Djibouti, Ethiopia beat them back and Ayatollah Nur al-Haqq was killed in battle on September 22, 2005. 

Somalia once again fractured into civil war, as the Ayatollah’s many lieutenants fell to infighting much like Barre had before them. The northern coast declared independence and sandstorms devastated the area around Mogadishu until the Caliphate finally collapsed in 2009. While the agrarian neo-luddite lifestyle remained the country would never be reunited. 

The northern coast, being the most stable region of the area despite the frequent droughts and famines, were visited by China in 2006. China was barely able to restore the power plants and build a desalination plant before they pulled out in 2007 and never returned. This tiny area, known as the People’s Democratic Republic of Somaliland, was frequently beset by all sides from refugees, raiders, pirates, bandits and religious militants from the south. However, with how sparse technology was in Somalia, along with the strict distrust of technology, it was very easy to fight off the invaders. Somaliland’s main problem was the amount of people who wanted to emigrate to the relative stability of Ethiopia. 

Between 2009 and 2011, almost 80% of the surviving population in Somaliland fled west, and it wasn’t until 2012 that word finally reached the desolate streets of Hargeisa that Ethiopia had fallen to civil war as well. And so, with nowhere else to go, the people in Somaliland eked out an existence the best they could. Technology frequently broke down due to the constant sandstorms, or melted in the heat, or just simply stopped working. This forced them to go out on scavenging runs, and less than a fifth came back alive, and most of the time they didn’t even find what they were looking for. 

Cannibalism had been practiced openly for some time, but nobody reveled in it. When famine struck (and there was always a famine somewhere) the dead were prepared in a communal soup. Other than that, people ate sorghum and cassava bread or roasted maize. In the aftermath of the First Great Heatwave of 2015, Somaliland set up a series of low-tech desalination plants that used the sun’s heat to sterilize dirty water through condensation, though it was a very slow process. Water gradually became the most valuable commodity in the stagnating republic and was used to reward workers and farmers loyal to the Somaliland regime. By the 2020s, Somaliland was very similar to the agrarian anarchy to the south, not because they distrusted technology but because everything had more or less broken down. Desertification had gotten so bad that Somaliland was effectively cut off from the feudal confederacy of the Water Lords, and millions died. 

Many took the Second Great Heatwave as a divine punishment, and the waning Somaliland Regime stopped trying to enforce the ban on religion. The Victorious Queen expanded into south-west Somalia to get access to the coast, but flooding and desertification kept them from expanding further. After the Solar Flare of 2026, there was no longer a difference between the agrarian luddites to the south and the pretend communists in Somaliland, and many are losing hope. Apocalyptic suicide cults have sprung up along the shrinking coast, but the government can’t really dissuade people from it - what are they gonna do, shoot them? This dealt a massive blow to the public image of the Communist Party of Somaliland, as it was found the General Secretary had participated in a suicide ritual with 200 others on December 5, 2026.

As of 2027, Somaliland is a desolate place. No raids or civil wars are fought there - there is nothing to fight over. The mass deaths from famines, drought, and flooding have led to the population actually stabilizing, so cannibalism is kept to a minimum, but the people left in Somaliland are trapped there. There are no materials to make boats to cross the sea to Mecca, and there are no desalination systems left, just pumps and rickety old wells. All anyone can do is simply wait for the end to come. 

Section 2: Dreams of a United Arabia
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ft_dXvtLceE 
United Arab Emirates

Official name: United Zakat Emirates
Capital: Haya
Government Type: Federal Constitutional Monarchy
Population as of final census conducted: 23,138,230 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 10,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $2.461 Trillion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: League for Arab Cooperation
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

The United Arab Emirates emerged from the shell of the Trucial States in 1966 and by 1972 had become one of the richest and most prosperous nations in the history of the world. Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan was not successful in securing military aid from the British, instead they chose to support the economic and financial development of the new nation. Roads and highways were built with British money and massive oil wells covered the landscape. This infrastructure ensured that the resources in the UAE would be easily accessible by the energy-hungry nations visiting the Persian Gulf for oil. The British got a massive discount of course, and the UAE’s GDP grew by almost 1,567,540% between 1967 and 1988. In 1979, they joined the “Trillion Dollar Club”, a prestigious title that indicated that they were among the wealthiest nations in the world. 

The UAE chose the path of Zakatism only in 1981 at the insistence of the other Arab states. The average person in the UAE did not experience as much of a living standard increase as in places like Syria, Saudi Arabia or Libya, but it remained a prosperous place. The UAE was also the site of some of the largest and most obscene vanity projects in history, such as a palace made entirely out of gold, a city with perfume mixed into the building materials, an underwater football stadium, performing Khaleeji folk dances in zero-G environments, spectacular car races (the match in 1985 included jumping the Strait of Hormuz) and making intricate glass sculptures out of desert sand that could catch light in unique ways and recreate scenes from the Quran. 

The Al Noor Al-Kamil Museum, frequently referred to as just “the Kamil”, became the largest and most prestigious art collection in the pre-Great Death world. It was located in Umm Al Quwain and according to many, it put the Louvre to shame. Many of the Sheikhs would also import foreign art work to display in their spacious private mansions. The Sheikh of Dubai was known for being particularly interested in collecting Japanese poetry, to which he would read aloud to his guests at his weekly balls. Other Sheikhs were more interested in the sciences or religion, as the Sheikh of Sharjah was an internationally renowned expert in the history of mathematics during the Golden Age of Islam. Conversely, the Sheikh of Fujairah had graduated from several prestigious British universities during the 1960s, and ordered a report on the way oil extraction could affect nature. 

This report, called the 1978 Report, completely changed how the Sheikh of Fujairah saw the world. He ordered all copies of it destroyed. 

Meanwhile, as a way of fostering unity and understanding between the Emirates, a joint project was proposed to create a shining “city of the future” to be the new capital of this nation. This project took many years and cost almost $400 Trillion USD, but it employed a great many people. It started in 1967 and was finished in 1985 in a grand ceremony attended by many of the most famous people in the world, including President Franklin King, Secretary Gennady Yanayev, Chairman Chen Qiang, Commissioner Friedrich von Schwerin, along with the leaders of many other countries. The opening ceremony lasted an entire 5 hours, while the opening festival lasted an entire week. Fireworks and neon tubes kept the city immersed in a constant stream of colors and sounds. The ten largest buildings in the world were all located in the city, and there was even a private jet plane service to transport executives between skyscrapers. 

When the city was nearing its completion, a referendum was held on what to name the city. Many names were submitted, the popular ones including Dignity, Karma, and Tawāḍu. In the end, Haya won. The city quickly became the subject of many legends throughout the Post-Great Death Era, including the fabled “Crystal City”. 

As Qatifism rose in the late 1980s, the President of the United Zakat Emirates, President Saeed Al-Mazrouei, chose to support his Arab kin, though only minimally. Sanctions were placed in Israel (thus violating the Tehran Accords) but that was the extent of his support - no money was sent to Egypt or guns to the United Arab Army, and they did not allow any of the members of the Egyptian Coalition to use their ports or military bases. Because of this, when the bombs dropped, the UZE was spared any nuclear blasts. 

This did not help them survive any better. Their problems were just beginning. 

On June 17, 1988, a large group of Qatifist militants crossed the border from Saudi Arabia and started sabotaging pipelines heading into the Arabian desert. The President authorized the miniscule armed forces of the UZE to stabilize the region, but this was a feint - the real target was Dubai. Several mysterious packages arrived in the ports of Dubai and over 4000 people were injured before the authorities locked down the city. Mosques and businesses were bombed and over $600 Billion USD of damage occurred on June 17 alone. On June 18, the Sheikh of Abu Dhabi was assassinated, causing a minor succession crisis due to his only son taking credit for the bombings. By June 19, this had spiraled into a civil war as the President did not recognize his claim but four of the other Sheikhs did. On June 20, waves of refugees started pouring in, and this split the government of the UZE further. On June 21 President Al-Mazrouei was killed by being pushed out a window (official sources claim he had given up and decided to end it all) and any semblance of a unified government went with him. 

Waves of Qatifist militants and displaced refugees flowed across the formerly United Zakat Emirates, with many foreign businesses leaving Dubai and Haya. The site of the Chinese embassy was particularly gruesome, as the Ambassador was reportedly drowned in oil. It was estimated that one in 20 diplomatic personnel were killed during the fall of Haya and Dubai. 

By July, the country was divided into a brutal civil war with large swathes of it in anarchy. Fumes from burning oil wells coated the sky with smog for decades. Mansions were destroyed by hordes of Qatifists, believing they were purging hedonism from the world. 

By August, things were getting downright apocalyptic. Multiple Emirates were overthrown, replaced by a Qatifist government that immediately fractured to infighting. The harsh winds merged with the oil fires to create giant flaming sandstorms that shredded entire towns and burned the remains. 

People fled east to the Hajar mountains into Oman, or stole boats to sail across the gulf into Iran (which still had a government at this point). Pakistan conducted several evacuations in early August before they were attacked by Qatifists and forced to stop. 

Warlords began to emerge near the end of 1988, conducting raids on the many strongholds in the mountains and other Qatifist fiefdoms. Floods and fires destroyed the remaining buildings along the coast. Artifacts and treasures, some predating Islam, were thrown into the sea. Transformers and power stations were destroyed for being “altars to Iblis". 

Once all the “temptations” were destroyed (or at least attempted to), the surviving warlords began to create “awqāf”, or communal towns ruled by a Qatif warlord. These towns remained very stagnant and barebones, with only minimal technology, and many died from famine, corruption, drought, and environmental hazards. All of these Qatifist settlements died out by 2000, falling from warfare or radiation. 

Some of the more saner warlords in the northern reaches of the Middle East (mainly around the ruins of Israel or Syria), once the dust had settled and everyone was eking out an existence before dying of radiation poisoning, began spreading campfire tales of the wondrous glories of Haya and Dubai, and the many treasures they held. Expeditions into the scorched ruins of the Emirates became a popular pastime for scavengers and raiders alike. In 2001, a joint expedition between pilgrims of the United Arab Republic of the Nile and the State of Hejaz ventured into the ruins of the UZE and came back with many Islamic works of art produced during the Glorious Decades. Further expeditions were met with limited success. 

However, in the northern reaches of the Hajar mountains, outside the ruins of Fujairah, a tiny enclave of hardened survivors gradually coalesced. Some of the survivors were from as far as Bahrain, others from Yemen. These survivors, while they had no official name, have been referred to by historians as the “Fujairah Group”.  Records show that they were extremely territorial and hostile to any groups that intruded on their territory due to frequent raids from warlords, Qatifists, and bandits. During an expedition to the region around 2678 AD, ruins were uncovered showing a massive wall made from scrap metal and rusted vehicles. Skeletons were found impaled on spikes, serving as a warning. It is speculated that the group operated on a strict survivalist doctrine, where members cooperated only when it ensured the community’s survival. It was also remarkably egalitarian, especially for a community in that part of the world: both women and men worked alongside each other to defend the fortifications or grow food. The population peaked at around 50,000 people, and the group was attacked multiple times and had lost territory, as evidenced by multiple fortifications that have been partially destroyed. It is speculated that sometime around 2070, the group died out or left the area, becoming nomads. 

As of 2027, the United Zakat Emirates are a wasteland, with the exception of the Fujairah enclave. 
Bahrain

Official name: Zakat State of Bahrain
Capital: Manama
Government Type: Syndicalist Arab Republic (until 1988), Authoritarian Dictatorship (1988-1992, disputed)
Population as of final census conducted: 2,574,376 (circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: Uninhabitable
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $467.2 Billion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: COMECON
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Bahrain was born in 1965 when workers toppled the British occupation of the kingdom. This created a period of instability, where the National Liberation Front, the Arab Nationalist Movement and the National Union Committee all vied for control. The National Liberation Front was funded by the USSR. The Arab Nationalists were funded by Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Lastly, the National Union Committee was funded by a loose coalition of nations who simply wanted peace in the region: namely, the USA, Britain, Iran, and at one point even China. Then, in 1967, the NLF split and Maoist Militia was formed, called the Popular Front. This faction was funded by China. 

In many ways, the instability in Bahrain was considered the “Great Arab Front of the Cold War”, being compared to the Korean War or the Vietnam War. It was estimated that 24,000 people lost their lives during the fighting in 1965-1969. In 1969, President Nixon would authorize the sale of over $5 million USD worth of guns and arms to the NUC forces, with Britain donating many old weapons from WW1 to them. This proved to be a turning point, and with Soviet and Chinese forces being bogged down in the Sino-Soviet Border War, in addition to Secretary Brezhnev being assassinated earlier that year, the NLF and PF floundered. The Arab Nationalists, not wanting to spill more blood of their brothers, surrendered. A truce was signed on June 1, 1969, and the Nationalists joined forces with the NUC to secure the rest of the country. The last rebel outpost, being a Popular Front outpost in the caves in the center of the Island, surrendered on June 29. 

A formal armistice was signed on July 20, 1969, and a provisional government led by the NUC was formed, with elections being slated for August of 1970. That said, the representatives of the Western Countries realized that maybe they had backed the wrong faction, as while this new Bahrain wasn’t communist, it was its own breed of socialism: syndicalism. The National Union Committee was in fact an alliance of unions from the numerous oil rigs around Bahrain, and even a union of oil tankers. The government was not made up of representatives or members of the ruling party, but instead directly ran by the members of the unions that worked the country. 

On August 24th, 1970, the first general election concluded and Hassan al-Mutairi became Chairman of the People’s Syndicalist Confederation of Bahrain. This new Bahrain was remarkably decentralized, with the capital simply being where the Chairman lived. Meetings of the People’s Congress of Bahrain met every year at a random industrial site, and was essentially just a union meeting on a national scale. If one was a member of a union, they were considered to be an extension of the government, and thus Bahrain technically held the record for the highest percent of the population working in government, being 96.7%. 

The most popular unions decided to merge together into a political bloc, called the People’s Party of Bahrain, and won re-election in 1975, 1980, and 1985. Chairman al-Mutairi was reelected in each subsequent election as well, though his cabinet changed very frequently to provide adequate representation. Despite being the first officially secular Arab nation, Bahrain was officially renamed to the Zakat State of Bahrain in 1982. 

Most of Bahrain’s budget went to safety inspections, infrastructure maintenance, housing development and agricultural imports. Healthcare and vacations were provided by the government and voted on by unions, housing was made by people, for the people. Corruption was remarkably scarce, as the Bahraini took immense pride and joy in their work and publicly shamed anyone caught embezzling or skimping on the safety of their workers. Bahraini oil rigs eventually turned into tiny ocean-bound enclaves that could hold almost 2000 people each, equating to a small city, with entertainment and schooling for the families of the workers. 

In 1972, Bahrain was recognized as independent by Iran as part of the Tehran Accords, in exchange for Iran having a stake in their oil industry. The Tehran-Bahrain Oil Company remained marginal in the politics of Bahrain. 

Bahrain was not a popular place. It had an extremely small population, and emigration was a notable issue throughout the 1980s. In 1975, after a national referendum, diplomatic ties with China were severed, with Chairman al-Mutairi citing Chen’s betrayal of the workers as the main cause. In 1983, after the USSR began to reform and open itself up more, Chairman al-Mutairi believed the next step they would take was to become syndicalist like Bahrain. As a way of the two countries growing closer, Bahrain joined COMECON in 1984. 

In the mid-1980s, a new ideology began to emerge in the politics of the nation: pan-Arab Syndicalism. Many of the workers of Bahrain began to believe that a unified Arab nation, operating on syndicalism, was the next natural step to the Zakat state. As such, while Bahrain did not participate in the Sinai War, they did support their Arab brothers in the hope of creating a unified Arabian state. Bahrain did place sanctions on Israel, and at one point even thought of nationalizing the Tehran-Bahrain Oil Company due to Iran’s reluctant support of Israel. 

When the Israelis decided to engage in Operation: Samson and retaliate, Bahrain was considered, but the Prime Minister of Israel decided against it - Israel’s goal was to never completely wipe out an entire nation. So even though Bahrain was spared from nuclear devastation, they were not spared from the chaos that engulfed the Middle East. 

Bahrain was a major target for the rogue Qatifist-dominant United Arab Army. After the Capture of Jerusalem, several Iraqi divisions headed towards the southern peninsula in an attempt to capture Mecca from the Sunnis. Along the way, some of them diverged and headed east to take out the monuments to hedonism in the United Zakat Emirates. Bahrain was on this path, and parts of the Saudi Navy attempted to defend Bahrain from the UAA. 

Bahrain of course had a very small military, as most of the security budget was devoted to law enforcement. The Saudi ships defended the island nation as best they could, but they were easy targets for what was left of the Iraqi air force, as they indiscriminately bombed everything on the sea around Bahrain. Throughout June 1988, every single Bahraini oil rig was disabled if not outright destroyed. Burning oil and smoke choked the skies so thickly that the entire Gulf of Persia was obscured for several months, preventing access to ports. 

Chairman al-Mutairi, seeing how Qatifist militants would invade their island any day now, took several sweeping authoritarian measures and centralized the government. This was done without the approval of any of the unions, and several of them walked out and declared their own governments. This caused a second civil war, except this time they were also fighting Qatifists and Soviet-backed communists. Chairman al-Mutairi was assassinated by pro-Soviet communists on September 7, 1988. Manama was destroyed by Qatifists in November of 1988, and radioactive rain began to soak the island. 

By 1992, the civil war had fizzled out into pure anarchy and chaos. Once much of the technology had been destroyed, and all the accessible oil burned, the Qatifists left the island, never to return. The survivors, numbering less than 1% of the pre-1988 population, tried to band together and scrape out some kind of life. This proved significantly harder than they thought, and just a few months later held a referendum to create a series of boats to sail to somewhere better. The results were to try to move to Iran, unaware of the equally chaotic situation there. 

When the ramshackle fleet of boats arrived on the shores of the Iranian Soviet Republic, they were attacked and besieged by Iranian Zakat Socialists who persecuted the Bahrainis for being too secular. The refugees fled further east, with some of them taking refuge in the Afghan mountains, and some of them going either further, only to be shot on sight by the Pakistani military. A very small number of the survivors reached India and were resettled in the Kashmir mountains. These Bahrainis (estimated to be less than 100) would end up becoming a part of the Kashmir Covenant after the Indo-Pakistani Nuclear War of 2002. 

Ironically, around 2003, a group of refugees fleeing the Indo-Pakistani War would end up settling in the ruins of a Bahraini oil rig in the Persian Gulf. This settlement lasted only a few years before falling into the ocean in 2007. 

Throughout the 2010s, the island once known as Bahrain was occasionally picked over by survivors and scavengers. Around 2013, a group of Italian neo-crusaders tried to extract some of the oil in Bahrain, but they all died of heat stroke. The ruins of Bahrain were referred to as a "monument of sin” by Qatifists before the movement died out in 2035. 

As of 2027, the island sits there still, baking in the sun. 
Lebanon

Official name: Zakat Republic of Lebanon (until 1989), Emergency Auxiliary Regime of Lebanon (1989-2003)
Capital: Beirut (until 1989), Tripoli (1989-2003)
Government Type: Federal Republic (until 1989), Authoritarian Confederacy (until 2003)
Population as of final census conducted: 6,475,693 (Circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 10,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $326.9 Billion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (until 1988)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

The United States, seeking to counter the growing influence the Soviet Union was gaining in the Middle East, opted to send additional troops to Lebanon in 1969 and 1970. With this additional support, the vast number of PLO members in Lebanon were pacified, with some even speculating that a civil war could have happened if the US had not provided additional support. 

Lebanon remained the deregulated financial hub of the Middle East, sometimes called the “Arab Switzerland”. In the 1970s, it was even claimed that there was snow on the peaks of the mountains, and many wealthy Arabs frequently vacationed there during Laylat al-Raghaib. Lebanese banks were where many oil barons and artists stored their wealth, and Lebanon also had many coastal resorts and yacht clubs. And just like European Switzerland, Lebanon remained quite neutral during the Glorious Decades. In 1972, as part of the Tehran Accords, the members of the PLO in Lebanon were forced to relocate. Many chose to move to Iraq. 

In 1976, President Élias Sarkis began to lift many of the emergency decrees passed in the early 1970s and full democracy was restored to Lebanon. His successor ended up being Rami Haddad of the Chehabist Union Party. While President Haddad was a Chehabist, he was noticeably more aligned with Islam than Christianity. In 1979, Lebanon was officially renamed to the Zakat Republic of Lebanon though in Christian circles it was referred to as the Caritian Republic of Lebanon[1]. 

President Haddad was succeeded by Salim Arslan, also a Chehabist, who delicately balanced the relations between the Christian and Muslim populations. Despite being a Zakat Republic, Lebanon refused to join the League for Arab Cooperation, instead joining the USA’s Alliance of Industrial Nations. Beirut became known as the “New York of the Arab World”, as many regional headquarters for multinational companies were located there before the city of Haya was finished in the UZE. The Beirut Stock Exchange also remained the primary financial hub for the Middle East, and while Haya tried for a while to usurp it, it never came close. 

When the Sinai War began, Lebanon remained neutral. They even made it a point to have their borders guarded by a coalition of both Muslim and Christian soldiers. But this did not save them. A fog of radioactive dust coated Lebanon, and refugees flooded the border to get away from the devastation in Jordan, Iraq, Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia. 

An emergency election was held right after the bombs dropped, and Karim Barakat was elected. He ran as an independent, though eventually gave birth to a political party known simply as “National Stability”. Barakat was remarkably humanitarian: assets of now defunct nations were nationalized and used to fund refugee camps and prop up welfare. The tiny Lebanese Army participated in several operations to protect other national governments from Qatifist rebels (such as the operation to protect the Saudi Crown Prince during the evacuation of Kharj) and the Lebanese Guard stayed in Mecca, including many Christian soldiers. 

Unfortunately, the social services of Lebanon were very quickly overwhelmed. Overcrowding and poor sanitation caused an outbreak of cholera, and radiation caused many to become infertile. Mass panic-buying led to government-enforced rationing. Pro-Egypt and Pro-Israeli protests dominated the politics of Lebanon for the rest of the summer, leading to nationwide martial law. One riot at a ration distribution center led to 56 dead refugees. Overworked soldiers began deserting their posts to protect their families. In Beirut, a housing project for Palestinian refugees was burned down by far-right Christian rebels. This provoked violence between the Christian and Muslim communities in the city. Shots were exchanged between local law enforcement and suspected Qatifists in late November, turning the city into a warzone. And finally, on January 7, 1989, President Barakat was assassinated by a Qatifist terrorist. 

Most of Lebanon fell during the wave of looting, rioting, and Qatifist terror. Some cities held on, usually protected by nearby military bases, while others were burnt to a crisp in the madness. Beirut was leveled by routine bombings in the summer of 1989, and what was left of the government relocated to Tripoli, where even there they struggled to keep looting to a minimum. And then, the cities became silent. Radioactive particles were everywhere: in the water, in the soil, in the dust and cobwebs, and very few places were spared. Refugees, citizens and soldiers alike began dying of acute radiation poisoning or from eating toxic rations. 

Things had fizzled out by late 1990, and surviving cities had become strongholds for the gaunt, skeletal figures that had yet to die from radiation poisoning. General Marwan Tabet, operating out of a military base near the ruins of Beirut, established the Emergency Auxiliary Regime of Lebanon. This organization could very loosely be called a government and its main day-to-day operations included such dreary tasks as attempting to humanely euthanize people exposed to radiation, surveying water tables for pockets of minimally contaminated water (everyone was infertile and dying of radiation anyway, just at different rates), distributing the stockpiles of rations that were still marginally safe for human consumption, and coordinate against Qatifists raids (which became less and less common as the years dragged on). This last task was what united many of the survivors. As they became less frequent, some cities left the alliance, though many retained friendly relations with Tripoli. 

A donation of 1 million kg of packaged food was airdropped to Lebanon by various Nordic countries in 1991, but most of the world ignored their plight. Agriculture was completely abandoned in 1994, as soil contamination and radioactive rain had permanently stunted the growth of all plants in Lebanon. Overall, this did not impact the survivors much. Less than 500,000 citizens remained, and every day people left in the hope of spending their last days somewhere better. 

In 2003, a group of far-right Christian warlords (commonly referred to as “Crusaders” by other survivor groups) ransacked the fragile confederacy of Lebanese city-states. General Tabet was hanged by an Italian raider, and Tripoli was burned to the ground. Mosques and synagogues were demolished across the wasteland. These raiders destroyed the last remaining strongholds of Lebanese civilization, before being destroyed themselves by the radiation saturating the water. 

Between 2003-2026, outside of a few isolated bunkers and outposts, Lebanon remained a desolate wasteland picked over by roving bands of Qatifists, Crusaders and Israeli Exiles. In 2007, a Qatifist militant attempted to destroy Mount Lebanon, though he failed. In 2015, wildfires burnt down much of the withered vegetation that still survived. In 2024, the radioactive salt particles from the Dead Sea rained down and permanently tainted the water tables in Lebanon.

As of 2027, the ruins of Lebanon are inhabited by a group of Syrian exiles and a few Crusader outposts, who routinely fight over the same pool of radioactive water. 
Syria

Official name: Zakat Republic of Syria
Capital: Damascus
Government Type: Presidential Republic
Population as of final census conducted: 36,013,784 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 600,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $4.08 Trillion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic 
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Alliance of Industrial Nations (until March 1988), League for Arab Cooperation (after March 1988)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Syria’s 1963 Ba’athist coup caused a major split in the Arab world, and was a significant step back from a united Arabia. For almost 10 years, diplomatic ties between Egypt and Syria remained on edge. This was exploited by the USA, with the Nixon administration viewing it very similarly to the Sino-Soviet Split. With the opulence and wealth resulting from the Shanghai Accords and practically pacifying East Asia and the Americas, the USA began to focus on creating a similar political and economic climate in the Middle East. The US’s heavy involvement in the Middle East in places like Bahrain, Lebanon, Iran and Syria were a testament to this. 

The US was Syria’s only option at this point, as China was too unstable, the USSR was still very pro-Egypt, and Egypt itself had felt extremely betrayed. So the Assad regime went full steam ahead with currying the USA for support. In 1969, Syria began to transition back into a somewhat faulty democracy. The Ba’athist party retained a majority of seats of course, and international observers cited the elections as free but not fair, but what could the USA do? The Middle East was very quickly becoming a tool for Moscow, and Washington couldn’t be that picky. 

That changed in 1972, when the USA and China signed the Shanghai Accords. This led to a total inversion of Cold War politics. With China’s assurances, the USA began to win in Vietnam, eventually turning into a stalemate. This was a massive morale boost for the West, and the USA was no longer scrambling to secure allies. Wars began to be fought with tariffs and trade negotiations, rather than soldiers and guns. With this, the Nixon Administration began to pressure President Hafez al-Assad to make elections more free and fair, and more importantly, make the country more stable and attractive to businesses. 

Seeing how lucrative things had gotten for the other nations in the Arab world, Assad turned down the authoritarianism of the Ba’athist party, instead allocating funds to infrastructure, education, and economic investments. This made Assad extremely popular, and he was subsequently reelected every single election, not by using intimidation or voter fraud, but because people began to genuinely believe in him. Syria saw almost $1 trillion USD in foreign investment between 1972 and 1988. Syrian oil often rivaled Iranian oil for how cheap and accessible it was. 

As the Arab world got gradually wealthier, they stopped being so hostile towards each other. Diplomatic ties were restored with Egypt on September 30, 1973, with President Karim al-Haddad and President Hafez al-Assad pledging renewed friendship between the two nations. Syria was invited to participate in the secret invasion of Israel before it was cancelled at the insistence of Moscow. 

Syria was the biggest importer of concrete and building materials in the Middle East. Massive, intricate elevated highways connected every major city, while opulent palaces, mansions and houses covered the countryside. Golf became a very popular sport in Syria. While Syria was not a financial beacon like the UZE or a banking paradise like Lebanon, it was still a very sizable market and as such, many companies around the world catered to the Syrian people. Some historians even claim that Syria saw the largest growth of the Middle Class during the Glorious Decades. 

Syria’s military remained well funded, as Assad was constantly worried that Iraq would invade them at the behest of Moscow. As part of a treaty signed with the Morgan Administration, the USA provided the Syrian army with modernized equipment. This forced the USSR to make a similar treaty regarding the defense of Iraq, and as such, caused some temporary hostility between the two superpowers. 

As the 1980s rolled around, Syria stood above their neighbors as by far the most wealthy and influential Arab nation. Syrian oil companies frequently engaged in trade wars with the Iranian counterparts, though they were very careful to not violate the Tehran Accords. The USA and China were Syria’s largest customers, and it was Syria’s refusal to sell their energy at equal rates that denied them a spot in the League for Arab Cooperation. 

While Syria’s elections remained flawed at best, with the Ba’athist party remaining by far the most popular and powerful party, numerous smaller fringe parties were created. These parties included the Arab Friendship Party, the Kurdish Party, the Communist Party, and the Financial Party. These parties rarely managed to win anything more than a local election, and when they did, it was only because the Ba’athists endorsed them. At the insistence of the rest of the Arab World, Syria was only renamed to a Zakat Republic in 1987. 

Of course, when the Egyptian Coalition revealed itself and threatened to invade Israel, the King Administration was baffled when Syria announced that they had joined the coalition. This resulted in the USA placing sanctions on Syria and pulling all of their foreign aid. When Syria refused to back down, they were kicked out of the Alliance of Industrial Nations. A few of the more wealthy members of Syrian society protested, but for the most part everyone was behind Assad and proud to stand with their Egyptian brothers again. 

Members of the Syrian Army joined Iraqi forces in both the Iranian Front and the Israeli Front. Syrian soldiers fought extra viciously, as Assad had promised them luxurious rewards if they performed well. Syrian forces mainly comprised armored divisions, foot soldiers, and artillery. The Syrian Navy also worked with the Egyptian Navy to form a blockade around Israel. 

For their ruthlessness, both Israel and Iran launched nukes at Syria. Damascus was destroyed, along with Aleppo and several other large cities. President al-Assad was killed in the blast, and the Ba’athist party collapsed into infighting. Qatifist revolutionaries then roamed the countryside, destroying the roadways and concrete monuments to Assad. Military bases were besieged by Qatifist militants, who then used the equipment to terrorize cities. 

In the West, a group of military police and special forces groups fought house by house, street by street and city by city to push back the Qatifist horde. These commanders, initially united in their struggle against the Qatifist rebels, quickly fractured into dozens of sub-factions based on almost every political ideology imaginable. These territories eventually became divided into city-states, centered around important industrial sites, farms, or military bases. 

Many fled on boat or by foot into Turkey or Greece, where they became refugees. However, by 1990, things were getting tough in Europe, and so Turkey started providing aid to some of the Syrian City-States. This caused another wave of infighting between the city-states and the Qatifist warlords, particularly over access to Lake Assad. Tabqa Dam was subsequently destroyed in 1992, causing a massive flood of radioactive water to destroy several settlements. 

As Turkey became increasingly militaristic, the coastal city-states began to fear a possible invasion from the north. By the late 90s, the Qatifists had started fighting each other more than the coastal states, as they disagreed on how certain technologies would have been viewed by The Founder. Some city states, like Latakia and Tartus, had set up scavenger-based economies where they prowled the Mediterranean for valuable scrap and sold it to places like Libya, the Federation, or Greece in exchange for food, fuel, and weapons. This led to the creation of several jury-rigged desalination machines along the coast. These coastal cities then used the distribution of water to gain influence on the other, more inland city-states. 

By the time of the Red Summer, Latakia and Tartus became so influential that they practically controlled the ruins of Syria. Around this time, a group of radical Christian Warlords attacked the coast of Lebanon, Syria, and Israel. While they were successful in wiping out the remnants of the Lebanese government, they were not so successful in Syria. The people in Syria fought back, but some of the outer cities fell to the Crusaders before they succumbed to poisoned, irradiated water or were killed by Islamic warlords.
