Latakia and Tartus made an alliance and rallied the rest of the city states to build a series of fortifications along the Jabal al-Ansariya mountain range. These efforts ended up leaving them wide open to an attack from the north, as the situation in the 90s inverted and millions of Turkic refugees began flooding the city states. This forced the biggest of the remaining cities (Latakia, Tartus, Idlib and Hama) to finally unite into a defense-based confederacy, known as the Wadi League. Latakia and Tartus remained the undisputed leaders, and frequently tried to undermine the other. Idlib and Hama on the other hand were entirely dependent on the water and trade from the coastal states, and served as the closest thing to a breadbasket in the ruins of Syria. 

Trade along the Mediterranean dried up as Greece and Turkey fell to civil war, the Federation became increasingly totalitarian, and the last states in North Africa collapsed. By 2011, the Wadi Fleet stopped acting as a merchant fleet and instead became a heavily militarized group of nautical scavengers, whose primary goal was to keep the desalination machines running. As the heat got worse, farms were moved into underground greenhouses made in the ruins of sewer tunnels (which ironically became quite rich in nutrients for the plants and acted as a great fertilizer) and lit by tiny, grated holes barred with rebar. 

Soil was another thing the Wadi Fleet gathered. While Syria was not nuked as badly as Jordan, Israel, or other nations, radioactive dust storms had corrupted much of the land in Syria. Underground soil was rotated and disposed of when it was determined it was unsuitable to grow crops on, though during the Purple Summer of 2011 the supply of new soil had gotten so low that many in the Hama state starved. There are hints of cannibalism during major famines, but no evidence has been found. 

By the 2020s, the Euphrates had completely dried up, turning into empty riverbeds filled with skeletons and salt. The last of the Islamic warlords had either fled north or died out. The Wadi League became completely centered on the cultivation and purification of water, with some of the younger Syrians born after the War starting a cult born out of reverence for the almost ritual way water from the sea was purified and transported to the outer cities. 

The seas only became rougher as time marched on. Tartus was destroyed in a massive flood in late 2022, with Latakia leading the organized effort to rebuild it. This new Tartus was notably less influential in the League, and Latakia became the undisputed leader. Fires and dust storms in 2023 and 2024 caused a shift away from making crummy, easily fixable hovels and shanty towns and instead repurposing existing concrete and stone ruins. This took place during the Second Great Heatwave, and many died during the restoration of the stone houses. Many of those that died were those displaced from Tartus, which further solidified Latakia’s grip on the League. 

In the mid 2020s, excursions from the southern Crusader states and Israeli raiders plagued the League. This led to the Battle of Hama in 2025, where the League Militia fought off a band of almost 10,000 Israeli raiders and lost only 3,000 men. The Solar Flare of 2026 devastated the Wadi League, causing a severe drop in water desalination. This escalated into a civil war pitting Latakia against the others. 

As of 2027, the Wadi League Civil War is raging on, with Latakia desperately trying to fix their desalination plants to regain their influence over the region. They lose more ground everyday, and it seems that the Idlib Militia is poised to become the new power in the area. 
Libya

Official name: Great Zakat Republic of Arab Libya (until 2002), Libyan State (2002-2010, disputed), Libyan Emergency Government (2002-2011, disputed)
Capital: Tripoli (until 2002), Tripoli (until 2010, disputed), Benghazi (2002-2011, disputed)
Government Type: Far-Left Dictatorship (until 2002), Center-left Confederation (2002-2010, disputed), Authoritarian Military Dictatorship (2002-2011, disputed)
Population as of final census conducted: 8,472,374 (circa 2000)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 4,800,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $2.5 Trillion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic 
Member of the Alliance of Nations: YES
Alignment: COMECON
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Libya was the only country that participated in the Sinai War that lasted long enough to not only join the Alliance of Nations, but survive into the new millennium. Libya made a lot of money selling oil to the Warsaw Pact and other communist nations, but when China was taken over by Chen, Muammar Gaddafi refused to sign the Shanghai Accords. Libya only signed the Tehran Accords in 1980, at the insistence of the other Arab nations. Finally, after much debate with the new leaders in Moscow, the Shanghai Accords were signed in 1985. Libya still prioritized their communist brethren but became very rich selling oil to the ever-hungry China. 

While Libya was technically a Zakat state, having it added to their name in 1986, the country did not experience the extensive liberalization that many other Arab nations did during the Glorious Decades. Libya was firmly in Moscow’s sphere of influence and neither Beijing nor Washington tried to change that. Gaddafi remained the sole head of state, kept in power by the military. The welfare state was heavily scaled towards those loyal to Gaddafi - those most loyal to him (mainly in the military) got mansions and a stipend to spend on whatever they wanted, while the average citizen had a decent quality of life and suspected traitors were outright denied welfare, instead laboring on farms or in factories. 

What Gaddafi said was law, and any who questioned this either wound up lying dead in a ditch somewhere or breaking their back on a labor farm. Some of his supporters in the military even created vast, seemingly pointless public work projects for the sole purpose of working laborers to death. One of these projects included expanding the Great Manmade River to encompass every major city in the Sahara. Desalination plants provided clean drinking water for the citizens on the coast, which was then piped off to the interior of the country. 

In part to Soviet aid (mainly given as a way to keep Libya allied with Moscow and not changing sides), Gaddafi was allowed to enact a great many socialist reforms. Minimum wage tripled between 1972-1988, and rent was reduced by as much as 60% in some places. The coastal cities hired Soviet architects that turned them into towering testaments to the glories of socialism, and were very similar to the Soviet Worker’s Palaces. Tripoli became notable as the home to the largest statue of Gamal Abdel Nasser in the world. Like Tunisia, Libya was also a very popular vacation spot for Soviets and other members of the Eastern Bloc. As relations with the West warmed, the coast of Libya also became a popular destination for Italians and West Germans. Benghazi in particular became a popular meeting spot for West and East Germans. “I’ll meet you in Medina” became a common euphemism for this. 

Libya participated in the Sinai War not so much out of the desire to liberate the Sinai from Israel, but simply because Gaddafi wanted to show solidarity with Moscow-aligned Iraq and Egypt. Gaddafi remained paranoid however, and only sent a token force to participate in the operations in Sinai. For the most part, Libya helped enforce the blockade around Israel and Iran. Libya’s Armed Forces were kept on high alert and this is what allowed them to intercept and shoot down the Israeli missiles before they destroyed any Libyan cities. 

Gaddafi considered the Sinai War to be a complete failure, and seeing the Qatifist-led revolutions sparking across the Middle East, he closed the eastern borders of Libya. The navy was recalled and instead patrolled the coast, ensuring the desalination plants remained active. Gaddafi had rightfully predicted that water would soon become a resource to be fought over, and further closed down the borders of the nation. Claiming it was to protect against ideological and physiological corruption, mobile “Territory Defense Units” were organized and began to actively shoot any incoming refugees. 

Libya’s economy very quickly collapsed and Gaddafi was forced to undo many of his welfare policies, resulting in a sharp decline of living standards. Those in the military or working essential jobs were prioritized, but everyone else was pretty much on their own. Evacuations throughout the 90s moved people further and further inward until 99.9% of the population lived in Tripolitania. Libya became extremely authoritarian and repressive. Those suspected of harboring refugees or hoarding supplies were executed. Extra water rations were offered for providing the authorities any information about subversives. 

In May 1989, Prime Minister Mourad Kassar of Tunisia fled the country and landed in Libya. Gaddafi kept him around as an insurance policy, and also as a way to control Tunisia once the dust had settled. Kassar managed to convince Gaddafi (who was overworked and stressed at the time) that he had just been privatizing Tunisia’s government as a demonstration of how bad capitalism was, and that socialism was always going to be the future. Still, Gaddafi did not trust him, and had him watched at all times. He was always treated better than many citizens and Gaddafi frequently talked with him, trying to groom him into being a puppet for the eventual annexation of Tunisia. 

When the United Nations collapsed, Gaddafi followed Moscow’s example and did not join the Alliance of Nations until all the way in 2002. Gaddafi remained active in COMECON, being one of the last remaining nations to do so, and frequently attended economic conferences in Moscow, Buenos Aires, and Mexico City. Libya was given extra funding by the Soviets as they served as an example of a country that had not given in to Western temptations, and had remained a socialist country even after the introduction of the Shanghai and Tehran Accords. In 2001, Gaddafi even hosted a COMECON meeting in Benghazi. 

While out in Moscow in December of 2002, Gaddafi’s government was overthrown in a popular revolution that spiraled into a civil war. Kassar was killed in the fighting, along with several prominent Gaddafi loyalists. At the insistence of Minister Voronin Gaddafi remained in Moscow, where he had become a political tool very similar to his own plans for Kassar. 

The Red Summer of 2003 turned the Civil War into a stalemate. Libya became divided into two camps: the Libyan State, claiming to be a decentralized, egalitarian socialist confederacy of various large cities, industrial sites and farms. The other side was a group of Gaddafi loyalists that held out in the Jebel Akhdar around Benghazi led by Colonel Faris al-Marwani. The Tripoli Confederacy had a much larger population than the Benghazi Remnant, but because the Benghazi Remnant had most of the leftover military equipment, they were roughly matched. 

Skirmishes and raids were conducted between the two proto-states in the ever-widening no man’s land. The Great Manmade River was destroyed by the Loyalist forces in 2004, and after some loyalists defected, the Loyalists and Rebels had several naval battles in the Gulf of Sidra. In 2008, Benghazi was almost seized by the rebels but were saved at the last moment by a nearby Soviet fleet. Voronin promised that once the rebels had been dealt with, Gaddafi would be restored to power. This caused the fighting to renew, however the Soviets had unknowingly spread the Red Flu to the Loyalists, who then spread it to the Rebels on the battlefield. 

The Rebels finally sued for peace in late 2009, and the two sides were in the process of reuniting when a large army of desperate refugees from the United Arab Republic of the Nile attempted to overwhelm Libya’s coast to get access to their rusting desalination plants. The Loyalists did their best to fight off the invaders, but Tripoli was sacked and burned to the ground in early 2010. The refugee army then took over the remaining naval craft and tried to sail across to Italy, where they were promptly blown to bits by the Federation Navy. Benghazi fared slightly better, fighting to the death to defend their desalination plant, but a storm in 2011 caused the city to finally fall and was destroyed in the chaos. Records also indicate that Gaddafi was unceremoniously killed during one of Savateev’s purges in 2012. 

By the time of the Great Heatwave of 2015, the refugees had become little more than raiders and pirates. A settlement called “New Cairo” was built around the last working desalination plant. The native libyans were worked to the bone by their new masters, though the refugees (made up of Egyptians, Sudanese, Syrians, Palestinians, and Iraqi, among others) constantly bickered with each other over the division of resources. Starvation, drought and famine killed many during this time. 

Between 2017-2027, two major uprisings were launched against the invaders, and both times, the Libyans were beaten back into submission. Suicides and deaths from pollution hollowed the population further. Cannibalism became openly practiced, with some warlords taking great delight in eating a Libyan family, one by one, and making their relatives watch. 

The Second Great Heatwave of 2023 finally caused the fragile alliance to fracture, and the warlords, raiders and pirates split along national lines. An Egyptian pirate ended up dominating the ruins around Tripoli, while Sudanese and Iraqi pirates both fought for control around the ruins of Benghazi. The ruins of Greece and Turkey were frequently plundered by these pirates. In 2025, the Egyptian pirate tried to launch a raid into the Constantine Confederacy but was beaten back by the Tunisians. 

After the Solar Flare of 2026 and the desalination plant stopped working, the three pirate factions significantly ramped up their operations. The Wadi League engaged in several naval battles with them, while the Crusader states in Lebanon were sacked. 

As of 2027, the Libyans are planning another uprising and will succeed or die trying. The Sudanese and Iraqi pirates have made a temporary alliance and plan on invading Egyptian Tripoli, believing that they have some secret stash of water hidden away. 
Kuwait

Official name: Zakat State of Kuwait
Capital: Kuwait City
Government Type: Constitutional Monarchy
Population as of final census conducted: 5,096,827 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 900,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $2.06 Trillion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic 
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: League for Arab Cooperation
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Part of Saddam Hussein’s deal with Moscow stipulated that he could endanger the USSR’s foreign relations with the Middle East. The formation of Bahrain into the first syndicalist government in the world was promising but not what the Soviet Union desired. Moscow needed to present the image of a gentle, guiding hand leading the world towards communism, and the dictatorships in Libya and Iraq did not help this. Saddam refrained from antagonizing Kuwait, but Iran kept the country at arm’s length. Iran viewed the country as beneath them, and not worth the trouble to take any serious military action against, and thus Kuwait was more or less left alone by its more antagonistic neighbors. 

Kuwait became a cultural center for the Middle East, especially in regards to poetry and cinema. Kuwait City held a royal Poetry Symposium every year, where the best writers from around the Arab world would gather and read their works to the Emir. Those that won were printed by the Royal Press of Kuwait and distributed across the world. 

At the insistence of the West, and strangely Iraq, Kuwait opened up even more politically and the Emir became a ceremonial position. Part of Saddam’s demands were that the fringe communist party be recognized as legal. This confused the West, but they let it slide - it was the 1980s, and communism was seen as on its way out. This tiny communist party fractured further, and by 1988, it only held 4 members, all of whom were just edgy students at the University of Kuwait. 

In 1983, Kuwait joined the League for Arab Cooperation, and the socialist president, Sami al-Mutairi, officially renamed it to the Zakat State of Kuwait. While Kuwait wasn’t as lucrative of a market as other nations in the region, it was viewed as the most stable, and thus they still had a decent amount of foreign investors. Kuwait also became known as the “Hollywood of Arabia”, or less kindly as “Los Arabia”. The biggest Arabic movie of the Glorious Decades, “The Nile Runs Red”, premiered in Kuwait City on April 6, 1987. It was a biopic about the life of T.E. Lawrence and how he inspired the Arab Revolt against the Ottomans, however it was dripping with subtext that not only implied that T. E. Lawrence was no better than the Ottomans, it also drew many parallels to the current political climate. Some critics even claimed that it portrayed the Arab Revolt as unsuccessful and that another would be necessary. What few can deny is that in the Arab world, military enlistment skyrocketed. 

When the Sinai War broke out, Kuwait’s government debated back and forth against joining the war on the side of the Iranians or on the side of the rest of the Arab world. Kuwait attempted to remain neutral, but finally placed sanctions on Israel in June 1988. The sanctions didn’t really do much, as they were more symbolic than anything, and Kuwait avoided being destroyed in a nuclear hellfire. 

But this did nothing to save them. Radioactive dust storms blew in from the ruins of Jordan and Iraq. A state of emergency was declared and the tiny Kuwaiti military mobilized to defend their borders, only to be quickly overwhelmed with waves of refugees from Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Jordan and Syria. The Emir and the President were both assassinated by Qatifist rebels when they attempted to flee to Pakistan. All the leaders of the rapidly fraying Kuwaiti military met similar fates. 

By August of 1988, Kuwait had ceased to exist as a nation. The relatively undamaged infrastructure in Kuwait City, along with its access to the sea, provided a tantalizing prize that warlords around the region fought over. Some of them were former members of the Jordanian Army, others were Iraqi border security, and one was even reported to be a Sudanese truck driver. 

Throughout the 90s, Kuwait became the stronghold of many despots and warlords. A revolution would depose the current warlord, then this new regime would expand into the wasteland to scavenge for supplies, only to inevitably overextend and collapse from another coup. Many died from violence, starvation, radiation and drought, but because of the massive oil fires cutting Iraq and northern Saudi Arabia in half, Kuwait was the only place people could go to. The Soviet occupation of Iran had turned the Zagros Mountains into an impassable barrier, while Pakistan’s navy had become increasingly violent with a “shoot first, ask questions later” policy.  

And yet, millions poured into Kuwait every single year, in an attempt to get a boat and to sail to somewhere, anywhere that was better than the hell on earth they were experiencing. Sewage-based farms, similar to the ones in Syria, attempted to keep the survivors in Kuwait fed but chronic famines led to cannibalism to be normalized. 

In 2002, after Pakistan and India destroyed each other, a large amount of rusted boats and hand-made rafts arrived in Kuwait, carrying almost 100,000 Pakistani refugees. This caused a major upset in the balance of power in Kuwait, which at this point had been divided into several “wards” roughly organized along national lines and run by groups of former soldiers who amounted to petty gangsters. The Bahraini Defense Force, a poorly named group of militants that controlled the docks, allowed the refugees to stay as long as they built their homes on the outskirts of the city. 

The city continued to expand outwards, creating millions of ramshackle hovels that would fall apart every sandstorm and burn down in fires. Eventually, the city was a loose confederation of refugee states. Iraqi, Syrian, Iranian, Kuwaiti, Saudi, Bahraini, Qatari, Pakistani, Indian, Turkish… the list went on. Kuwait became the place for people with nowhere else to go. Kuwait eventually became so powerful that even the raiders and warlords stopped attacking the place, and were allowed to conduct business and use the brothels as long as they didn’t cause a scene. The Scrap Bazaar of Sabah Al Salem Stadium was the best place to barter for metals on that side of the Great Iraqi Fire, and the Dust Island (formerly Green Island) grew the best food in the area, when they could. 

In 2005, an Iranian chemist and former employee of the Imperial Persian Oil Company (IPOC) by the name of Dr. Layth al-Harqan began an ambitious project to create a series of desalination stations around the coastline. There was still some minor radioactivity in the water, but at least it wasn’t full of salt and other pollutants. These desalination plants initially caused some tension between the wards until one was completed for all of them. They were very delicate however and required weekly cleaning or else the water produced was just a thin trickle of brownish sludge. Entire teams of scavengers made their living off providing repair materials for the life-giving water systems. 

In the 2010s, as relations between the wards all became warmer and people stopped fighting over water and food as much, some of the community leaders even proposed the idea of a “survivor’s council” which functioned very similarly to the United Nations (by this point, each of the wards were their own microstate, with a distinct language, culture, ethnicity and shack-building style). 

The idea took a while to catch on, finally being created in 2016 as a way to better coordinate scavenger teams to keep the desalination plants running. In 2017, a united militia was also created to help repel an invasion of raiders. This confederacy never had a formal name and was frequently referred to as just “the council”. These two unified efforts remained the only ways the microstates cooperated, as distribution of food, water, and building materials could never be agreed upon. Any attempt of a formal leader never worked either, and so Council City had, at one point, 27 mayors. 

In the 2020s, the environment itself became the greatest threat to the fragile stability of Council City. At times, lethal heat made it deadly to go outside even during the night. Sandstorms in 2021 caused the desalination plants of almost every ward to malfunction, leading to a massive water riot where 6,000 were killed. Flooding caused landslides and sinkholes. A massive storm in 2023 caused Kuwait Towers to collapse into the sea, killing over 70,000. In 2025 the heat had gotten so bad that it became lethal to attempt to leave the city by land, and all scavenging operations were forced to use boats and comb the coast of Iran. The Solar Flare of 2026 did not affect the city much, as the desalination plants were already primitive and the fixes had been done many times already. Many were confused on why they broke down without a sandstorm, though. 

As of 2027, Council City is limping day by day, if a little more hungry, a little more thirsty, a little more violent, and a little more hopeless than the last. Political conflict is all but extinct, and more people everyday choose to take the easy way out rather than waiting for a slow, painful death from starvation, dehydration or radiation. 
Qatar

Official name: Kingdom of Qatar
Capital: Doha
Government Type: Islamic Absolute Monarchy
Population as of final census conducted: 4,284,135 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: Uninhabitable
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $426 Billion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic 
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Unaligned
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Qatar would have been poised to join the ranks of the wealthy Zakat republics. Emir Ahmad bin Ali Al Thani was quite unpopular with his people, and various factions within his government were working with foreign powers (namely the British) to potentially rectify this. Unfortunately, this attempt at deposing the Emir was unsuccessful. 

Qatar became the black sheep of the Arab world - sure, it was relatively prosperous, but there was no welfare net and government spending was kept to a minimum. Law enforcement and security forces prevented any uprisings, but even then, peace was enforced by gunpoint. Because of how the wealth was distributed, the average citizen saw very little economic prosperity. Outside of the nobility and their cronies, the people of Qatar were very poor. Many left the nation to go work for other Arab states and sent their money back home to their families. 

Much of the most bizarre artwork created during the Glorious Decades originated in Qatar. The Qatari nobles had very peculiar tastes, and prided themselves on spending obscene amounts of money to commission nonsensical projects from controversial artists, for the sake of holding world records. Tourism did take off in Qatar, though it was not as popular of a place to visit simply because tourists didn’t like seeing 15 starving kids on their way to see the World’s Largest Chair. 

Some of the projects bordered on torture, like an intensive banana farm in the middle of the desert, staffed entirely by government officials who participated in the failed uprising in 1972. The bananas reportedly tasted quite sour, and almost 600 barrels of water were used everyday to keep the plantation from drying out. In 1977 the Qatari government announced that they had finished creating a replica 1:4 scale Mount Rushmore, floating on a manmade island in the middle of the Persian Gulf. But instead of US Presidents, the heads on the replica were all members of the royal family. The artist who designed it skimped on a lot of the building costs, as by the early 1980s the island had begun to fall apart, but the artist was safely in Liechtenstein by then. 

The Emir didn’t really participate much in world politics, instead just sitting around and creating the world’s largest sandcastle. By February of 1988, much of the government of Qatar had grown dissatisfied with the way Qatar was progressing in comparison to the other nations of the Arab world. As the Egyptian Coalition ramped up their aggression towards Israel and Iran, Qatifist missionaries appeared in Qatar. Civil unrest gradually ramped up as people demanded better living conditions and to help their brothers in their struggle with Israel. Demonstrations turned to protests, which turned into riots, and finally on June 6, 1988, right before the bombs dropped, Qatar collapsed into civil war. 

The Qatari Civil War was extremely bloody and brutal. Government corruption and fears of an uprising similar to this one had caused the Emir to massively defund the police and military, with only his most loyal soldiers given working guns. As such, the rebels fought with sticks, knives and their bare fists. But eventually the Emir’s forces ran out of ammo and some of them surrendered. The Emir was found and hung from a lamppost on June 28, 1988. 

And yet that was not the end of the anarchy - waves upon waves of refugees fleeing the nuclear devastation swarmed the ruins of Qatar, and stifled any attempt at an organized government. Qatifist militants destroyed the many absurd projects and bands of looters stole whatever they could. The Qatari that survived fled however they could, be it by boat or foot. Some ended up in Kuwait or Hejaz but many died in the desert. 

By the 2000s, the last survivors in Qatar had died of starvation or radiation poisoning. Some of the larger projects and works of art still stood as they were not able to be destroyed by the increasingly primitive Qatifists. In the 2010s, the ruins of Qatar became avoided by survivors for being “cursed”, eventually turning into a macabre time capsule of what architecture was popular during the Glorious Decades. 

As of 2027, Qatar is an uninhabitable wasteland, slowly being absorbed by the radioactive desert. 
Oman

Official name: Zakat Sultanate of Oman
Capital: Muscat
Government Type: Islamic Absolute Monarchy
Population as of final census conducted: 6,502,702 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 260,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $961.3 Billion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic 
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: League for Arab Cooperation
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

Inspired by the liberal reforms happening all across the Arab world, Qaboos bin Said deposed his father and became the Sultan of Oman. Combined with China’s ever-lasting greed for fossil fuels and a rapid increase to the GDP, Sultan Bin Said created a generous welfare net and significantly increased spending in education, social services and healthcare. Oman became so prosperous that many of the rebels in Dhofar surrendered and rejoined Omani society. The Sultan set a deadline for the rebels: lay down your arms by December 31, 1973 and receive full amnesty. 

Many of the rebels, seeing the dramatic increase to standard of living, took this offer. A few holdouts remained (mainly along the border with South Yemen) but an international coalition of Lebanese, Iranian and Syrian soldiers wiped them out by April of 1974. 

In 1980, Oman was renamed to the Zakat Sultanate of Oman, but other than that not much happened in the state. Oman was regarded as a quiet place for elderly Arabs to retire to. There were no large resorts, no extravagant art projects. Omani cinema and literature was not regarded as visionary, but neither was it regarded as drab or dull. Many young people chose to emigrate to the more lively Arab nations like Syria, Lebanon and Kuwait, leaving behind a politely aging population. Other than migrant workers and international students (Omani universities were considered to be the best in the Arab peninsula) only the elderly remained in Oman, and they were content with that. 

As the Sinai War ramped up, the Sultan expressed his support for the Egyptian Coalition but did not send any aid or even sanction Israel. “Oman stands with Egypt”, was all he would say when asked to comment. 

Oman was spared from being directly hit from any nukes, but they still felt the after effects. Most of the smog and dust from the war ended up concentrated in the skies above Oman. It was reported that in Muscat, the sun was not seen until sometime in mid-April of 1990. Everything was coated with a thick layer of vaguely glowing orange dust. Water rationing was enacted in July of 1988, and the government continually advised the population to stay indoors. Gasmasks or face coverings were required when going outside. 

Oman was also spared the wrath of the Qatifists, as their aging population prevented the movement from taking off in their borders. Their comparatively simple cities with minimal monuments also prevented any outside incursions by Qatifists. Instead, Oman was swarmed with refugees from the UZE, Saudi Arabia, and Yemen. A few Iranian boats even crossed the Gulf of Oman and fled to Muscat. 

The Sultan attempted to be generous and allow as many of the refugees in as he could, but rapidly deteriorating living conditions and spillover from the Yemeni War caused the social services to quickly become overwhelmed and the government folded under the pressure. Sultan Qaboos bin Said was pronounced dead on October 19, 1988 having died from a mixture of radiation poisoning and pollution related causes. This resulted in a succession crisis as the government was torn between helping the increasing number of refugees or intervening in the Yemeni War. 

Oman spiraled into chaos as the remnants of the government had a “cold” civil war. No one actively fought each other, but every high-ranking minister, general or mayor claimed that they were the interim leader of Oman and that everyone else wasn’t taking the role seriously. The country became more and more divided as some of the local government refused to allow in refugees, with some even resorting to shooting them, and others attempted to send aid to North Yemen. The country only devolved further and entire local governments collapsed into anarchy due to riots, uprisings, or simply running out of social services. Those that could leave fled into South Yemen or attempted to sail to Pakistan. 

By the Hot Summer of 1990, any resemblance of a government was gone. Anarchy reigned across Oman. Gangs of refugees banded together into bandits and terrorized the aging population before many succumbed to dehydration, radiation or the sands. Sometime between 2001 and 2003, the last able-bodied survivors left in Oman retreated to the northern mountains and eventually joined the Fujairah Group. Throughout the first quarter of the 21st Century, Oman was frequently picked over by scavengers and other survivors before being completely abandoned sometime after the Second Great Heatwave of 2023. 

As of 2027, Oman is a radioactive cemetery. Only a small outpost in Fujairah remains. 
North Yemen

Official name: Yemen Arab Republic
Capital: Sanaa
Government Type: Far-Right Dictatorship
Population as of final census conducted: 25,379,600 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 40,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $2.41 Million USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic 
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: World Prosperity Alliance
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

The two Yemens remained rather isolated and poor nations - North Yemen more so than their southern neighbor. Initially, the recently deposed monarch received aid from Saudi Arabia and Jordan but that dried up by the end of the 1960s. The new Yemen Arab Republic was formed. 

This new nation was plagued with instability, corruption, and further political infighting. Even Saudi Arabia stopped providing aid for them as Saudi money had an uncanny habit of disappearing into the pockets of high-ranking military officers. The inability of the central government to effectively govern the region led to another coup and a group of far-right militants deposed the democratically elected President, promising to reform the country properly. This was followed by the dictator being assassinated just a few years later, and finally, a group of three rather authoritarian statesmen banded together and realized that North Yemen would forever remain the laughing stock of the world if they didn’t get the country functioning. 

In 1981, North Yemen turned towards the only nation that took them seriously anymore: China. China had wanted to gain more influence in the Arab world and so set out to revitalize the infrastructure of North Yemen. Oil refineries and factories were built with Chinese money, in exchange for China building a few military bases in the region. The USSR, seeing what China was doing, then sent boatloads of aid to South Yemen and heavily militarized the border. 

Unfortunately, due to the heavy pollution that North Yemeni factories produced, the country remained on the sidelines of the Arab world. In 1985, the Executive Chairman of the North Yemen Transitional Government was assassinated due to public dissatisfaction from how the domestic situation had been handled, and he was quickly replaced by a pro-Chinese businessman. He proved to be a very weak and ineffectual leader, and when the Sinai War rolled around, he struggled to keep the country together. 

China initially provided support and security to keep North Yemen in line, but by August of 1988 they had completely pulled out and had left them to their fate. Hordes of refugees escaping the nuclear devastation crossed the border while native Yemeni tried to escape, knowing how bad things were there already. Some tried to reach their families in South Yemen by crossing over into Oman while others escaped into Saudi Arabia. 

Sometime in December of 1988, things got so bad that yet another coup took over the remnants of the nation, this time by an ambitious general who rallied what was left of the armed forces for an invasion of South Yemen. It failed horribly, with the last remnants of the North Yemeni government crumbling apart by April of 1989. North Yemen quickly fractured into a mosaic of microstates reminiscent of the Holy Roman Empire, and remained that way for several years. Some of the microstates eked out a living selling crude oil to nearby states, while others survived on raiding and pillaging. 

In 1994, the remnants of the Saudi military invaded the mountains in Yemen in an attempt to create a new Saudi kingdom. The Qatifists, warlords, and bandits were easy pickings for the battle-hardened Saudi soldiers and they pacified the area quickly. This new Saudi kingdom was ruled by the last member of the Saudi royal family, King Saud V, and it soon became clear that many of the Saudi soldiers had missed being in power. Many of the survivors in Yemen had accepted being serfs to roving bands of violent men but a few banded together and resisted. When it was discovered that the Saudis were unfairly distributing rations from old Chinese military bases and hoarding wells, an uprising toppled the occupying force. King Saud V was killed in a bombing that created a landslide and resulted in an estimated 500 extra deaths. The Saudis retreated and once again North Yemen fell to anarchy. 

The Red Summer of 2003 and the Purple Summer of 2011 both took their toll on North Yemen’s fractured, feudal society. Fiefdoms and khanates rose and fell, many lasting less than a year. Radiation, smoke, and pollution forced the survivors further and further up the mountains. Chinese factories and military bases became routinely picked over by both North and South Yemeni survivors. 

By the time of the Great Heatwave of 2015, only the hardiest, most resourceful survivors remained, concentrated in tiny enclaves at the peaks of mountains or in isolated strongholds. Trading had kept them alive for now but everyone was quickly running out of water. Nearby survivors in Hejaz offered them some of their water and a deal was worked out, where North Yemeni survivors would help the Hejazi scavenge for materials to trade to the Ethiopians. 

As the two communities grew closer, they eventually signed a formal treaty of cooperation and North Yemen joined Hejaz after the Second Great Heatwave of 2023. To help coordinate scavenging missions, the many survivor communities were organized into several communes based on where they were in relation to the mountains. Almost 5 decades of constant civil war, corruption and anarchy had made the North Yemeni extremely durable and adaptable survivors, and as such became some of Hejaz’s best scouts and scavengers. 

As of 2027, North Yemen is working very closely with their Hejazi allies to ensure the Quran is not forgotten. 
South Yemen

Official name: People’s Democratic Republic of Yemen (until 1993), Yemeni Emergency Regime (1993-2003)
Capital: Aden
Government Type: Far-Left Communist State (until 1993), Far-Left Military Junta (1993-2003)
Population as of final census conducted: 29,760,901 (circa 1990)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 300,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $14.97 Billion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic 
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: COMECON (until 1993), unaligned (1993-2003)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

South Yemen remained a minor state in Moscow’s sphere of influence until the 1980s, when China and the USSR began trying to outdo the other. China’s spending in the Northern state forced the USSR to spend ludicrous amounts of money building up the southern state’s infrastructure, military, education, healthcare and welfare systems. After the USSR began to liberalize this cascaded further into a relatively rich and open communist state. Free speech and freedom of expression remained restricted but the government became marginally more democratic and immigration laws were significantly relaxed. 

Abdul Fattah Ismail remained in power and kept the nation stable in the immediate aftermath of the Sinai War. He had voiced his support for the Egyptian Coalition but did not place any sanctions or offer aid in any way. At the request of Voronin, South Yemen had actually been building up their military to eventually invade and annex North Yemen to turn it into a land purified from China’s influence and to unite all Yemeni people under the banner of communism. They did not have to wait long, as the remnants in North Yemen attempted to invade the south. The communist forces beat them back with ease, and also began to patrol their borders to keep out refugees. Due to the rampant spread of the Qatifist movement, Ismail’s government deemed refugees to be a security risk and thus heavily regulated the flow of immigrants. On May 19, 1989, a border checkpoint near Dhula was destroyed in a bombing. The perpetrators were never found. 

Over the summer of 1989, South Yemen gradually repealed many of their reforms they had conducted throughout the 1980s. In the name of national security, elections were suspended and a curfew was enacted. Rationing was introduced in large metropolitan cities. As Ismail’s government became more and more authoritarian, this caused civil unrest to gradually ramp up. Paranoia due to Qatifist violence resulted in some large cities outlawing mosques and organized religion (in the past, the communist government had turned a blind eye to it as long as it wasn’t too obnoxious). 

The Hot Summer of 1990 put South Yemen to the test. Radiation, smog, sandstorms and rebel activity all cascaded into the worst famine seen in centuries. Still, the government massaged the statistics so that things didn’t seem that bad. Hundreds of farms turned to dust as the once-arable land became tainted with salt and radioactive sand, bankrupting many farmers and further taking up resources in the rapidly shrinking budget. Ismail stepped down in October of 1990 due to stress and health-related issues and was replaced by his Minister for the Interior, Nadir al-Ashmari. 

Secretary al-Ashmari proved to be even less popular than Ismail had become but he remained resolute, rigid and dedicated to the goal of keeping Yemen together. All private property was seized by the government and all remaining businesses were nationalized. The unemployed were required to take exams determining their health and fitness, with many of them being reassigned to either be soldiers or to work in the new collectivized farms springing up in the grasslands in Lower Yemen. Those that were seen as unfit were given extremely mundane desk jobs with minimal rations as a way to discourage citizens from purposely failing their exams. 

While the USSR attempted to provide them with aid whenever they could, South Yemen’s location made it very difficult. Soviet fleets were busy participating in the Yugoslavian War and air drops could only be made sparingly. Between 1990 and 1993, the Soviet Union only managed to send 5 shipments of aid to the hardworking communists in South Yemen. 

In short, they were on their own. 

Almost 5 million died of pollution, radiation, dehydration and famine between 1990-1993. The country was being held together by overwhelming force alone. The soldiers in the Yemeni Army enjoyed extra privileges to keep them from rebelling and many of them took to bullying citizens for fun. Corruption and bribes flourished, and a small underground black market was established. Supplies and resources were mismanaged or just disappeared into the pockets of corrupt officials. 

This caused Secretary al-Ashmari to become extremely unpopular, with strikes and protests rocking the political landscape in 1993. It all stopped when their northern neighbor was invaded by the Saudi Remnants, and several high ranking members of the military used this as an excuse to take control of the government. Secretary al-Ashmari was killed by firing squad and the entire country was placed under permanent martial law. 

This “Yemeni Emergency Regime” frequently clashed with groups of workers who had had enough and wanted better living conditions. Those that survived were sent to work to death in a labor camp. Citizens suspected of harboring “pro-Western thoughts about the myth of good working conditions” had their rations reduced and those loyal to the military were given the best rations. Officers traded female laborers like a currency, and discrete pleasure houses for off-duty soldiers sprung up across the wilderness. 

To their credit, the military junta did protect the borders from groups of roving bandits, Qatifists, and raiders. Aden was almost destroyed in 1995 when a group of Somali refugees and pirates attempted to burn it down. The Junta ordered an evacuation and they were largely successful in it, which boosted their public image for a time. 

Due to the amount of resources required to keep them livable, the outer regions of the state were gradually abandoned throughout the late 90s, until by 2000 the Hadhramaut was completely abandoned. Some groups of rebels would stay and attempt to eke out a life in the abandoned regions but they never survived long. Sandstorms caused farms to gradually be moved to greenhouses or to underground areas, significantly lowering the amount of available food. The various members of the military junta began to bicker and quarrel about the allocation of important resources and the alliance almost fell apart twice. 

The Red Summer of 2003 finally caused it to come crashing down as the officer in charge of each city waged war on each other over the rapidly dwindling water reserves. At the same time, partisan uprisings toppled the military governments only to fall to further conflict once they no longer had a common goal. 

By the 2010s, many had died and all that remained were a few isolated enclaves and outposts. Unlike their counterparts in North Yemen, these strongholds rarely traded with each other and became isolated fortresses ruled by bandits, warlords and cults. The Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2023 further reduced the population, until by 2024 the remains of South Yemen were divided between two extremely territorial proto-states. 

The first one, ruling out of the ruins of Ibb, was controlled by a remnant of the Yemeni Armed Forces. He called himself simply “The General”, and frequently got into fights with the other proto-state over water sources. To his south was the land of the Dust-Walkers, led by a cult leader who preaches a mix of Sunni Islam and Buddhism, with a healthy dose of cannibalism and self-sacrifice to boot. It is their fear for the fanatics to the south that keeps the General’s people in line. 

As of 2027, the Dust-Walkers are launching attack after attack at the fortifications surrounding Al Qa'idah and are wearing down the General’s forces. Everyday, more soldiers die and resources are stretched thinner and thinner. The General’s days are numbered. 

[1] To date, this is the only recorded reference to a “Caritian Republic”, which is very similar to a 20th Century Arabian Zakat Republic, though with a distinctly Catholic flair. Some scholars claim that the Holy See during the Great Death (2027-2035) resembled a Caritian Republic. 

Section 3: The Arab Century
https://youtu.be/HuJDNXmogdM?si=Nq8CK7FjxtGoAHyb 
Jordan

Official name: Zakat Kingdom of Jordan
Capital: Amman
Government Type: Constitutional Monarchy
Population as of final census conducted: 23,595,916 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: Uninhabitable
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $636.4 Billion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: League for Arab Cooperation
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Jordan remained displeased with the amount of territory Israel had taken during the various Arab-Israeli wars, and as such remained the Palestinian Liberation Organization’s main backer. Jordan was particularly angry about the loss of the West Bank to Israel. Jordan, Iraq, Egypt and Syria had planned on launching a surprise counter-attack on Israel around the end of October 1973, but Secretary Agassi advised against it, citing the sheer overwhelming support the USA was providing the young nation. 

The countries reluctantly agreed and stood down, calling off the attack. They decided that they would need overwhelming, absolute force if they were to have any hope of liberating their brothers. They would need an army, the biggest army in the history of the Arab world, and the greatest technology available. This army, referred to as the United Arab Army, would need to vastly outnumber the Israelis and the Iranians. Its soldiers must be the best men available, with the greatest weapons available, and every single one of them must go to war knowing that they may have to lay down their lives in the hope of a United Arabia. The fastest jet fighters and the sturdiest tanks would be needed if they were to stand a chance. 

President Karim al-Haddad, the man who replaced Nasser after he stepped down to deal with his health, worked with his peers in the Arab world to coordinate this long but subtle campaign of rearmament. The League for Arab Cooperation did a remarkable job of remaining inconspicuous - none of the intelligence communities of the world realized that the Arabs were preparing to attack Israel and not each other. For 15 years, the world viewed the Middle East as a place well on its way to becoming as peaceful and prosperous as Europe or North America. 

On the surface, the League for Arab Cooperation appeared as a simple trading bloc and multinational confederation to help advance Arab politics, and that was one aspect of it - however, the true purpose was to facilitate the enormous funds needed for recruiting, training, and supplying the military force that would become the United Arab Army. Shipments of artwork, building materials and humanitarian aid always contained something that furthered the goal of this massive army. A shipment of Saudi cloth would contain one or two ballistic vests, while raw phosphate from Jordan contained a separate jar of gunpowder. As long as the powers of the world got their cheap, cheap oil, no one bothered to look too closely. 

Jordan had an important role in this operation. Jordan was located in roughly the center of the Middle East, and as such became an important logistics center for the secret alliance. Materials and supplies were routed through Jordanian companies and sent to other nations. Jordan also didn’t have as much oil as other nations in the Middle East, and as such the people of Jordan emigrated abroad in the 1970s in search of better opportunities. Many in Jordan ended up as migrant workers in Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain and Iraq, and Jordan began to be referred to as the “displaced kingdom”. To the women and children that stayed behind, their husbands sent them some of their hard-earned money, and this flow of cash was used by the government to further improve the infrastructure of the nation - officially to make it more attractive to workers, though a secondary purpose was to facilitate the secret rearmament of the Arab nations. 

Jordan also remained rather authoritarian throughout the 1970s, as King Hussein I retained a tight hold on the government. A series of peaceful protests were carried out in 1983, inspired by the liberalization occurring in other Arab countries around the same time. Some in the intelligence community believed that the rampant militarization would be followed by a civil war, giving a tiny peek behind the curtain at the looming Arab war machine, but King Hussein I relented, finally signing a constitution on May 10, 1983. 

This constitution not only turned the nation into a constitutional monarchy similar to Morocco or other Arab states, but also renamed the nation to the Zakat Kingdom of Jordan. Many of the oppressive decrees made in the 1960s and 1970s were lifted, and elections were held - in 1984, Tariq Nabil al-Khatib became the Prime Minister of Jordan. Prime Minister al-Khatib was a good friend of King Hussein I and worked with him to help implement his policies. The Zakat state of Jordan wasn’t as extensive as their other Arab neighbors, but Saudi Arabia donated about $50 million USD every year to help pay for the healthcare and education programs. 

King Hussein I became extremely popular with his people, and was frequently seen in public with Prime Minister al-Khatib. King Hussein I was also quite interested in various sports, particularly motorcycle racing, where he participated in the first Arab Motorcycle Race, held in Amman in 1985. These liberal reforms helped attract many back into the country, and the population rapidly increased. Mining remained the most profitable sector in Jordan, and with Prime Minister al-Khatib’s reforms, workers were finally allowed to unionize and working conditions dramatically improved. Phosphate from Jordan provided the base for fertilizers around the Arab world. 

When 1988 rolled around and the plan was nearing fruition, Jordan stood with Egypt and Iraq. Jordan became a staging ground for Operation: Ăzarʾēl, the Arab military invasion into Israel to recapture the West Bank. Initial battles were successful and showed promise, but the Jordan army got bogged down outside of Hamra due to supply chain issues. Reinforcements from Iraq and Syria were waylaid by the Israeli airforce, and for most of May 1988 Jordan struggled to make any ground. 

On June 7, 1988 the United Arab Army completed Operation: Mīkāʾīl and reached Israel through Palestine. They met up with the Iraqi, Syrian and Jordan forces to begin Operation: Jibrīl, which was the siege of Jerusalem. Things seemed to be looking up, with the Israelis on the retreat and the dream of a United Arabia seeming closer than ever. 

The next day, in an attempt to get the Israelis to surrender and end any more bloodshed, the Egyptian Coalition authorized Iraq to detonate a nuclear bomb 2 km off the coast of Tel Aviv as a show of force. 

But an Iraqi soldier misheard his orders and dropped the nuke directly on Tel Aviv instead. 

The Qatifist militants (which made up a large majority of the United Arab Army) believed this to be the start of Judgement Day, and that soon the world would be remade to be one without sin and temptation. This caused the Qatifists to throw themselves at Jerusalem's defenses, and when Israel’s threats of nuclear war were ignored, as the defenses were breached the Prime Minister of Israel authorized the Samson Option. 

Many capitols in the neighboring countries were destroyed. Amman was one such city. Because they were so close to Israel, they had no warning time. King Hussein I was killed in Raghadan Palace. Prime Minister al-Khatib was killed when Irbid was destroyed. Many other cities were outright destroyed, and the government of Jordan collapsed. 

Jordan became hell on earth: a land of burning fires, scorching sands and enough dust to block out the sun for decades. The survivors quickly took to fleeing the nation, going in some vague direction east. Many ended up in Kuwait or Saudi Arabia, and some of them even made it to Afghanistan and Pakistan. The members of the Jordan army who were still in Israel tried to take down as many Israelis as they could, believing they had no home to return to now. Those that survived joined the PLO in their Long March south to the ruins of Egypt, and others joined the Qatifists and became Islamic Warlords. 

The corpse of Jordan was picked over by scavengers and warlords so many times, that by the early 2000s it had been picked completely clean of anything useful. As the environment worsened, Jordan eventually became an impassable barrier, plagued by sandstorms and soaked by radiation. The Dead Sea evaporated in the 2020s, and radioactive salt particles blanketed the surrounding region. 

As of 2027, Jordan is a desolate, hellish wasteland incapable of supporting any life beyond the microscopic level. 

Saudi Arabia

Official name: Zakat Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
Capital: Riyadh
Government Type: Islamic Absolute Monarchy
Population as of final census conducted: 43,286,345 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 1,000,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $3.348 Trillion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: League for Arab Cooperation
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

According to many scholars, Saudi Arabia was the birthplace of the Zakat system. Saudi foreign policy dictated that a portion of the government’s budget be given to less developed Arab nations as an act of charity, brotherhood, and solidarity. Negotiations during the early 70s led to an absolutely ludicrous and rapid increase to their GDP, though not as fast as other Arab nations. The industrial goliath of China imported barrels by the billions, consuming close to 30 million barrels per day during the Glorious Decades. 

Saudi Arabia never liberalized during the Glorious Decades, either - they were so obscenely rich that they were able to create a rather robust welfare state and still have left over money to dump into security, law enforcement, defense, and foreign aid. It was Saudi money that erected the vast, intricate network of oil pipelines that connected Asia, Europe and Africa. It was Saudi money that funded public schools for every single child in the Middle East, and Saudi money that paid for lavish banquets where the elite of the world would gather and raise a glass of champagne at another year of easy living. 

Saudi Arabia was the harshest and most repressive government in the Middle East, though Gaddafi’s Libya came close. Saudi Arabia was built on islamic law, and while that made them extremely generous and pious, it also made them quite conservative and resistant to change. Protesters in various towns actually claimed the government wasn’t being conservative enough, especially in relation to women’s rights, capitalism and defense. These ideas would significantly alienate the world from Saudi Arabia though, and so the King at the time (Khalid I) delicately balanced the demands of these conservative hardliners while also keeping Saudi Arabia open and attractive to investors. 

It was also Saudi money that funded the secret coalition of Arab nations intent on battling Israel. Tensions with Iraq and Saudi Arabia had been growing steadily throughout the 80s, and increased military spending between the two of them caused many to suspect a possible war between them. Iraq seemed to be getting on everyone’s toes those days: Iran, Syria and Saudi Arabia all seemed poised to squash the Iraqi fly. Many suspected it was going to be another proxy war between the USA and USSR, like Vietnam, Korea, and Bahrain. 

But the idea of the Zakat system was not the only thing that was born in Saudi Arabia. Qatifism, a fringe reactionary movement born out of Twelver Shia, emerged from the eastern cities of Saudi Arabia. It was described by many to be a twisted form of anarcho-primitivism mixed with conservative Shia islam. Works of art, along with oil wells, pipelines, and other industrial machines were destroyed. This caused economic instability to say the least, so King Khalid I banished the founder of this movement. He drifted around the Middle East, gaining many followers in Iraq, Iran, and Syria, before settling in Egypt. 

In 1987 the new President of Egypt, Mahmud al-Saeed, met with the drifter and convinced him and his people to join the Egyptian army. Qatifism had gained around 15 million followers by then, and almost all of them joined the United Arab Army. Others went to neighboring nations and convinced more citizens to join the cause, particularly in Iraq and Syria. 

The Egyptian Coalition had found its army to overwhelm Israel. 

President al-Saeed managed to convince the founder that not only was he the return of Jesus Christ (Isa as rendered in Arabic), but managed to convince the founder that he himself was the Mahdi, and his destiny was to conquer the enemies of Islam, starting with Israel. 

King Khalid I wanted absolutely nothing to do with this nascent movement, increasing the security budget of Saudi Arabia to keep an eye on these increasingly violent followers of Qatifism. 

In May 1988, when the Sinai War rolled around, Saudi Arabia remained militarily neutral in the conflict, though they provided humanitarian and logistical aid to the members of the Egyptian Coalition. Many of the bullets fired in Arab guns came from Saudi money. Israel did not target Saudi shipments as they did not want to upset the flow of humanitarian aid, but instead placed extremely harsh sanctions on them. Saudi Arabia even provided a legion of first aid responders to comb the battlefields of Iran so that the blood spilt would be minimal. 

Despite the King’s efforts to suppress Qatifism, this only caused it to grow, and in early June protests broke out demanding the nation join the battle. Fearing a revolution or civil war, King Khalid I relented and formally declared war upon Israel (but not Iran) on June 2, 1988. 

Less than 100 Saudi soldiers reached the frontlines at Jerusalem before the nukes dropped. For their trouble, Riyadh was blown to pieces in a mushroom cloud. Many mourned for the death of King Khalid I. Luckily, the Crown Prince was visiting a military depot in Kharj and was spared from the destruction. 

As the armies of the Egyptian Coalition retreated from the ruins of Israel to deal with the uprisings in their respective countries, some of them joined together to help defend the less-prepared nations such as the United Zakat Emirates or Bahrain. The Royal Saudi Navy, which was positioned in the Gulf of Persia to serve as a blockade against Iran, attempted to protect Bahrain from rogue vessels commandeered by the Qatifists. The Royal Saudi Air Force engaged in a bombing campaign to deny the Qatifist militias access to Iraq’s air force. The fog of war made it extremely difficult however, as every nation was essentially fighting a civil war. Friendly fire led to an estimated 10,000 deaths in Saudi Arabia alone. Near the end of June, the remaining ministers gave up and attempted to evacuate to North Africa. Working with Lebanese soldiers, they evacuated many of the high-ranking members of the Saudi nobility, including Crown Prince Fahd, and relocated them to Alexandria. However, the Crown Prince’s escort was shot down by rogue members of the Syrian Air Force, who then also bombed the city, killing President al-Saeed as well. 

Qatifism soon became a fire that none could control, and it burned through the Middle East, toppling governments and destroying industries. Saudi Arabia was no different. The bombing of Riyadh was viewed as the signal to begin the Qatifist uprising, and many in the Council of Ministers were assassinated by Qatifists. By July 1, 1988, the government of Saudi Arabia had ceased to exist, being replaced by a loose coalition of military generals and low-ranking officials. 

This led to an all out civil war between the remaining members of the nobility and their commanders, resulting in Mecca becoming only minimally defended and taken over by Qatifists. Some of the more secular members of the Saudi Armed Forces believed that defending Mecca was a lost cause and more resources should be spent on trying to secure oil fields, which were burning at an alarming rate due to Qatifist sabotage and Israeli nukes. Many of these soldiers vanished into the desert, never seen again, either killed by Qatifists or simply deserted. 

With great effort, a group of Lebanese Guards and Saudi Special Emergency Forces retook Mecca in mid-July 1988, but it remained a pyrrhic victory. Hundreds of thousands were killed, including civilians and priests. Operations expelling Qatifist forces were successful in Jeddah, Medinah, and Ahba. 

When the dust had settled at the end of August, almost the entire Saudi Royal Family was dead. Only a few minor princes remained. The Saudi Armed Forces weren’t in a better state, as defections, desertions and warlordism had claimed many commanders. General Fahd ibn Talal al-Mutayri, the last remaining general in the Saudi Armed Forces, decided that defending the holy cities along the Red Sea was the best option the Saudis had, and so dedicated his remaining soldiers to securing the western coast and reinstituting law and order. 

This new State of Hejaz allied itself with the newly formed United Arab Republic of the Nile, and collaborated on securing the area against warlords, bandits, and Qatifists. For the rest of the 90s, Mecca was defended against the Qatifist horde. This caused a minor schism in Islam, as some believed that it was not right to deny the Qatifists access to the holy sites of Islam. Many survivors went out into the wastes to attempt to sway the minds of the Qatifists, but none returned. On June 13, 1993, the founder of Qatifism was reported dead from radiation poisoning. His name has been lost to time. 

While many were content to live in peace, trying to live a good life before radiation or the sun took them, there were some members of the former Saudi army that missed the glory of their nation. They came up with a plan to “pacify” the chaotic anarchy to the south, in the land that used to be known as North Yemen. These soldiers convinced the last member of the royal family, the Crown Prince Saud V, to join them in their venture. The Chief Imam of Mecca, Abdulrahman al-Harithi, had become more politically influential than the remnants of the Saudi government, and so the hardliners decided that they would need to make a new kingdom where they were in control. 

North Yemen was in anarchy, ruled by warlords, bandits and Qatifists. It remained relatively divided, and as such the Saudi remnants were able to quickly pacify the settlements in the lower Sarawat Mountains. This new “Saudi Kingdom” lasted less than a year, as a popular uprising broke out when it was revealed that the Saudi occupiers were unfairly distributing food between the natives and the Saudis. The Saudi Remnants were humiliated, and King Saud V was killed by the mob. 

When the survivors returned to Hejaz, they were not allowed back in, and eventually wandered the wastes until settling in the ruins of Egypt and joining the United Arab Republic of the Nile. They defended the Suez with much zeal, but few of them were allowed back into the Arabian Peninsula. 

Hejaz and the United Arab Republic were kept alive by the sheer number of pilgrims that visited the region, bringing with them materials to repair guns, or tiny rations, or jugs of dirty water. Some could not offer anything other than their life, and so stayed in Mecca or Medinah to give their life defending the cities. Qatifist incursions still happened, but became less and less organized. General banditry and warlords soon replaced them. 

But by the Red Summer, things were getting grim. Fewer and fewer pilgrims were making the journey to Mecca, and relations between the United Arab Republic of the Nile and Hejaz were souring. Famine, drought and radiation were severely limiting the resources of both nations. Water riots in Tanta led to hundreds dead, and rising sea levels were coating the fertile lands with salt and made them unable to sustain life. On top of that, the Nile had become completely unpredictable. Disagreements between the mostly secular United Arab Republic and the religious Hejaz state over trade led to the two proto-states severing ties with one another. The United Arab Republic would fracture into civil war over allocation of the Nile, but Hejaz remained united, starving and dying of thirst. 

Chief Imam Abdulrahman al-Harithi attempted to distribute the left over rations equitably, yet many still died. To deal with the sharp decrease in agriculture, after much debate, he also authorized cannibalism. Only Qatifists were eaten, then dead Christian and Jewish warlords, then fallen Muslim warlords, and finally, the dead within Hejaz. It was here that many chose to starve to death rather than succumb to the depravity. It is estimated that 2-4 million died of starvation between the Red Summer of 2003 and the Purple Summer of 2011. 

In the 2010s, Hejaz would find itself fighting off several incursions from the more desperate remnants of the United Arab Republic, mainly Syrians and Sudanese. They believed that Hejaz had some secret reservoir of water, and attempted many times to break into the strongholds in the upper Sarawat mountains. 

During the First Great Heatwave, when the very buildings around Mecca seemed to sag and melt in the heat, it seemed that very soon Hejaz would once again return to the pages of a history book. That was until a group of African traders arrived in the salt-soaked ruins of Jeddah, claiming that they represented an organization that dealt in water and food. All they demanded in return were riches and jewels. The ailing Chief Imam, Musa ibn Rashid al-Zahrani, accepted the offer. As a token of good faith, he gave the traders a golden sculpture made during the Glorious Decades. It was a gamble, as none in Hejaz knew if these men would be true to their word, but they had nothing left to lose - it was either this or death by dehydration. 

Despite the traders leaving at night (it had become lethal to go out during the day ever since 1997), the sculpture warped and melted in the heat until it resembled a lion about to pounce. To the Water Lords of Ethiopia, this was considered a great gift and as such, they dispatched over a million barrels of water to be sent across the sea. The Ethiopian soldiers that escorted it were mainly Shia or former Qatifists, but they were welcomed into the holy cities with open arms. Women, children, and the sick were prioritized first, followed by religious leaders starting with the youngest, then soldiers in a similar order, and finally everyone else. 

Hejaz and Ethiopia developed a healthy trading relationship, where the many decadent wonders of the Glorious Decades were exchanged for shipments of water and food. Islamic art, silk robes, and golden sculptures were offered up in exchange for the waters of life. Young muslims from the horn of Africa began to migrate to Hejaz to take their pilgrimage, while Hejazi volunteered to be workers in Ethiopia. Many did not become slaves, as Hejaz was too precious a source of rare metals. Weapons were prioritized, and used in the feudal wars until Tewodros Bekele Hailemariam won the Ethiopian water wars and declared himself the “Emperor of Lake Tana”. 

Hejaz was kept alive through the trading, slowly becoming more austere and humble with every year. Silk robes and gold trims were replaced with simple clothes made from wool. Heirlooms were exchanged for bread and water. Eventually, as they began to run out of things to trade, groups of scavengers would try to pick through ruins to bring the Ethiopians valuables. Islamic artwork and other artifacts were kept and traded only when necessary, such as during the Second Great Heatwave. 

In the mid 2020s, a new problem began to emerge: with the rapidly decaying infrastructure, worsening climate, and extreme chemical pollution, many of the buildings and holy sites were falling into disrepair. The Kaaba had not been properly cleaned since 1994. Its kiswah had not been changed since 2023, due to the scarcity of materials. Many islamic traditions had been gradually scaled back and were at risk of being forgotten forever. Most importantly, literacy rates had plummeted dramatically, to the point that very few people outside of imams could read anymore. 

In 2025, Hejaz embarked on an ambitious project to not only preserve as much Islamic scripture as possible, but to actively write the Quran on as many surfaces as possible. Irrigation and fortifications were restructured to be verses written in giant arabic text, or carved into the walls of buildings. Imams worked at great length to manually copy, by hand, text to new quarans. Working with the many muslims in the Water Lord Confederacy, materials were gathered to erect a protective cover above the Kaaba to prevent acid rain from damaging the building further. Rare silks and other cloth were donated by muslims throughout Free Africa and sent to Hejaz to be turned into new kiswahs. On June 16, 2026, the Kaaba was cleaned for the first time in over 20 years. 

The Solar Flare did not impact Hejaz as much as other countries. Electrical systems had all broken down, and the few electronics that did work had been given in tribute to Ethiopia. The only notable event that marked the Solar Flare was a sharp increase in Qatifist raids, who believed that the lights in the sky signaled the start of the world being remade. 

As of 2027, Hejaz toils night and day to restore the holy sites of Islam. 

Iraq

Official name: Zakat Republic of Iraq
Capital: Bagdad
Government Type: Left-Wing Authoritarian Dictatorship
Population as of final census conducted: 57,239,804 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: Uninhabitable
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $626.85 Billion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic, Kurdish
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: COMECON
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Saddam Hussein was extremely bitter at how the rest of the Arab World had folded to the west. Syria and Egypt were no longer united. The Saudis, Omanis, and Emiratis had all bent over backwards to Europe, America, China and the rest. Iran was becoming less Islamic by the day. Only a few remained proud, steadfast Arab states. 

In 1973, Iraq turned to an unlikely ally - the Soviet Union. The remaining “true” Arabic nations - Libya, Tunisia, and Egypt - were all allied with the USSR. As Egypt and Iraq became closer and closer, Saddam learned of the secret plan to liberate Palestine. He believed that this common goal would be the first step to reunite the Arab world in a single Ba’athist state. 

To the outside world, Iraq remained a wildcard of a state. None of the major powers, not even the Soviet Union, was sure what exactly Saddam was thinking. Iraq frequently performed military exercises along their border with Iran and it seemed that they constantly flip-flopped between favoring the West and the East. It was all a feint of course (mostly). Saddam played the role of a sabre-rattler rather well. Diplomatic crises with minor Arab states such as the UAE, Qatar and North Yemen kept much of the world on their toes, but Saddam always backed down before things got too bad. 

Iraq also supported communist movements abroad, such as in Bahrain, Kuwait, and Syria. Many members of the PLO left Lebanon and Jordan to move to Iraq, where they were given extra privileges for their belief in the cause. Iraq was where the United Arab Army was trained, with Iraq providing the largest amount of troops other than Egypt. Saddam also roped the Soviets in to help him develop nuclear weapons and power plants. Iraq was one of the few countries to not completely outlaw nuclear power. 

In the 1980s, after the failed Iranian revolution, many of the Shia socialists fled to Iraq, which had become a melting pot for radicalized Arabs. Using Saudi money to buy massive amounts of arms shipments, Egypt then covertly sent the equipment to Iraq through proxy companies in Jordan and Lebanon. Iraq also bought tons of old Soviet equipment throughout the 1980s. The other nations in the Arab world, while they knew that Iraq was involved in some way in the coming war for Palestine, worried that Saddam would double cross them and set himself up as the undisputed leader of the United Arab Republic. Libya’s Gaddafi, another close ally of Moscow, had similar ambitions. 

Secret meetings between Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Jordan about Saddam’s true motives concluded with President al-Haddad admitting that Saddam would receive a high-ranking but ultimately ceremonial position in the theoretical Arab republic. As it stood, they needed Iraq’s large army and their equipment if they would have a chance to succeed in liberating Palestine. And so, things went on as they had for the past decade. In 1986, the Wanderer and his followers came to Iraq. The movement of Qatifism spread heavily in Iraq, inspiring many Iraqi to join the armed forces. Iraq’s military swelled to 7 million active members between 1986 and 1988. 

In 1988, many believed that Iraq was preparing to invade Iran. The Iraqi-Irani border became one of the most militarized zones on the planet, and constant military exercises had the Iranians on high alert. The rapidly liberalizing Soviet Union didn’t want Iraq to compromise their gains with the West and frequently told Saddam to tone it down. 

Much of the world was shocked when Iraq threw their lot in with the now rabidly-nationalistic Egypt, none more so than the Soviet Union. Diplomatic ties between Iraq and the USSR almost collapsed until Saddam explained exactly what he was doing to Moscow. They cautiously relented, but stipulated that Iraq could not use nuclear weapons. 

Iraq was equally split between the Iranian and Israeli front. Iraqi soldiers made the land routes out of Iran impassible, while a blockade prevented them from using the ocean. They never invaded Iran, but every time the Iranians tried to mobilize and push outwards the Iraqi pushed them back. The soldiers on this front were mainly career soldiers, ones who had spent several years in the Iraqi army constantly watching the border with Iran. This meant many of the soldiers heading into Israel were the fresh Qatifist-aligned troops. 

These Iraqi Qatifists marched with the Syrians and Jordanians to retake the West Bank. The reinforcements from Iraq helped the Jordanians break past Hamra and into Palestine. The Qatifists were noted for practically throwing their lives away, frequently doing suicidal actions and fighting without self-preservation. 

When the United Arab Army had surrounded Jerusalem, Saddam finally had his moment. As a show of force, he authorized an Iraqi soldier to detonate a low-yield nuclear bomb 2 km off the coast of Tel Aviv, far away to not cause any damage but close enough to send a message. 

The soldier who was flying the jet misheard the order, and dropped the bomb on Tel Aviv. This action would end up setting off the chain of events that would doom the world. 

The nuclear taboo had been broken, and nuclear-capable countries around the world readied their arsenals. The Soviet Ambassador to Iraq got into a shouting match with Saddam and fled the country. President al-Saeed remained speechless. Out of stubborn determination or ignorance, he still believed that the situation was salvageable and that a United Arab Republic was still possible. 

The Qatifists did not see it that way. The Founder claimed that the sound of the nuclear blast was the trumpet of Israfil, and it signaled the start of Judgement Day. They threw themselves at Jerusalem, ignoring the Israelis warnings of retaliatory strikes, and broke in as the first clumps of radioactive ash began to fall. 

It is unknown how Saddam responded to the event, as Baghdad was the first city nuked. Israel, Iran and Iraq began lobbing their payloads at each other, with the capitals of Syria, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Iraq all being destroyed. Dozens of oil fields went up in flames.
