A massive oil fire practically sliced Iraq down the middle, eventually burning into Saudi Arabia. 

The Ba’athist Party and the rest of Saddam’s regime very quickly fell to infighting. Millions were dead, and millions more were displaced. Rebel Qatifists forces took over various military bases and used the munitions to destroy yet more cities. One group even took control of Iraq’s remaining arsenal and bombed the Dead Sea and Persian Gulf with two low-yield nukes before a brave Iraqi pilot sacrificed himself to prevent more targets from being destroyed. 

The Iraqi civil war raged on for some time, as millions fled the country and millions more were killed. Over the course of 1988, every single high ranking member of the Ba’athist Party was either killed by Iranian vigilantes, angry Kurds, Qatifists, or other members of the crumbling government. Operations to put out oil fires failed or were only temporarily successful. Iraq’s provisional capital was moved every month due to the gargantuan firestorms that engulfed the region, setting entire cities on fire. Several evacuation attempts were made in 1989, and numerous members of the local government and military engaged in multiple campaigns to reunite the country. 

By 1990, it was clear that there were no victors and that Iraq had become a desolate, anarchic wasteland. Only Qatifsts stayed to destroy the remnants of industry, everyone else fled to Turkey, Iran or Kuwait. When the 21st century came around, Iraq had become a burnt-out desert, completely abandoned by all and avoided by scavengers and warlords alike. 

As of 2027, the Great Fires of Iraq still burn. The desert is so hot that it is incapable of supporting not just human life, but any life at all above the microbial level.

Egypt

Official name: Zakat Republic of Egypt (until 1987), Great Arab State of Egypt (1987-1988)
Capital: Cairo
Government Type: Authoritarian Republic
Population as of final census conducted: 210,561,234 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 8,700,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $2.53 Trillion USD
Primary Language: 20th Century Arabic
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: COMECON (until 1975), League for Arab Cooperation (1975-1988)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

When Gamal Abdel Nasser stepped down as President of Egypt in September of 1970, he was regarded as the most famous man in the Arab world. In his place was a man named Karim al-Haddad, who grew up in Suez and saw firsthand the violence of the Arab-Israeli Wars. As long as the USA kept sending aid to Israel, none of them stood a chance of creating a peaceful Arab world. So President al-Haddad turned to the only power that seemed sympathetic to their cause - the USSR.  

The Soviets managed to convince President al-Haddad that as it currently stood, it would be foolish to attack Israel right now. Practically the whole world - from the United States, to Europe, to China and many places in the Americas and Africa - would be united against them. To stand against Israel now would mean the complete annihilation of the Arab people. President al-Haddad reluctantly agreed. In 1975, he founded the League for Arab Cooperation as a way to help foster unity between the Arab states and also prepare for this future war with Israel. 

President al-Haddad juggled Moscow and Riyadh, oscillating between Arab socialism, nationalism and religion, keeping just neutral enough to continue receiving aid from both the less secular Arab nations and the Communist world. One of President al-Haddad’s biggest accomplishments was the creation of the Great Arab Roadway, a series of highways, elevated motorways, and tunnels that connected many major Arab cities, spanning from Casablanca all the way to Kuwait City. The Great Arab Roadway even had several bridges spanning major gulfs, like a motorway crossing the Red Sea to connect Khartoum, Sudan to Mecca, Saudi Arabia. 

Some of the numerous communist policies that Egypt dabbled in included massive land redistribution programs. He also emulated Agassi’s idea of a “Pan-Soviet” national identity and created a system where Egypt recognized only two identities: Arab and Non-Arab. By default, non-Arabs couldn’t own land, get married, own a house or vote, but they also didn’t need to pay taxes, so Egypt became quite wealthy from all the large businesses hiding out in Cairo. After taking an extensive and convoluted exam, a Non-Arab could be registered as “Honorary Arab” and be able to marry other Egyptians and vote but they could never own a house or land. Egypt became a beacon of Arab socialism and its population exploded, reaching 200,000,000 people in 1978. The Nile Delta became one enormous sprawling megapolis. 

President al-Haddad remained staunchly secular like his predecessor. This caused some friction among the other Arab nations and various religious groups. In the 1980s Egypt fought a protracted conflict with several Islamic guerilla groups. The most notable event from this period was when the Aswan Dam was occupied by a group of terrorists, leading to a 25-day standoff between Egyptian security forces and the terrorists. 

In 1985, President al-Haddad finally relented and significantly relaxed the restrictions of organized religion. Shia Islam in particular saw a huge resurgence, and Supreme Imam Maulana Javed Rahmani of Pakistan congratulated him for this. Ultimately, this only caused further conflict between the more secular members of his cabinet (who felt he had given in) and the more pragmatic ones, leading to protests and threats of violence. President al-Haddad weighed his options and decided to resign, and was later assassinated in 1986. It is unknown for sure who the assassin was: many rumors floated around, including the CIA, KGB, China, the Israelis, and some even suggested the PLO. 

In his place was elected Mahmud al-Saeed, a small, sly man who spoke in short, deliberate sentences. When he learned of the secret plan to liberate Palestine, he scoffed at it. Why stop there? Why stop at Palestine? Make the new Arab Nation the fifth superpower! While his public persona was that of a radical, peace-making Nasserist, in private his ambitions dwarfed that of Saddam and Gaddafi. 

President al-Saeed made peace with the radical Shias and managed to convince them to join the Egyptian Army - if Egypt’s enemies were destroyed then surely it would be grounds for making the nation less secular, as it meant that Allah had favored their cause. He attempted to pit Gaddafi and Saddam against each other, promising that whoever liberated the most territory would serve as the supreme commander of the United Arab Nation. He also created a vast series of bunkers beneath Cairo under the guise of Metro stations and storage warehouses. He even reportedly made several deals with Moscow to get more military aid, in exchange for officially becoming Communist in 1990 and rejoining COMECON. 

But by far the most important contribution he made to the war effort was when he met the Founder of Qatifism in Alexandria on June 6, 1987. Later that day he pledged himself and the rest of the Qatifist movement to Egypt’s cause. Many historians speculate that al-Saeed claimed that ultimately, both Egypt and Qatifism worked towards the same goal. He also played into the Founder’s delusions of martyrdom and persuaded him to believe that he was the Mahdi - prophesied 12 Imam in Shia belief. 

On New Year’s Day, 1988, al-Saeed believed that Egypt was finally ready to fight Israel and take her place as the fifth Superpower. Egypt’s military had swelled to 35 million soldiers, with almost 17 million additional soldiers from Iraq, Syria, Jordan, and Libya. On May 15, 1988, at a rally outside of Suez, President al-Saeed famously said the 21st century would be the Arab Century, and declared war on Israel. The rest of the Egyptian Coalition declared war as well or sanctioned Israel. 

Using the huge army of Qatifists, Egypt waged a costly war of attrition across the Sinai. Within days, vast stretches of the peninsula were under Egyptian control again. It was at the original Israeli border that Egypt started to face serious resistance. The trenches outside Gaza became cramped tombs that made WW1 look like paradise. Every day, Israeli bombers would carpet bomb Egyptian cities and every day, the air raid siren would beckon millions to hide in the Cairo Metropolitan Metro. 

It was June when Egypt broke through the trenches. Syria and Iraq had reached the West Bank and the Israelis did a massive tactical retreat, falling back to Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. The Egyptians, led by the Qatifists, chased them every step of the way. However, the Israelis had prepared for this, and had turned every major Israeli city into a fortress of concrete, barbed wire, machinegun nests and cameras. The Soviets, still sharing intelligence with the Egyptians, reported that each Israeli city was mostly self-sufficient and could hold out for years. All the Egyptians would need to do is wait outside their walls. By 1989, the people would have revolted and this new Israeli government would be more than willing to negotiate. 

However, that was not fast enough for al-Saeed. He authorized Saddam to do his show of force above Tel Aviv. It was to show the Israelis that the Arab World meant business. If the other major powers objected to nukes being used in this way, he was content to throw Saddam under the bus. 

But things did not end up that way. 

In retaliation, Cairo was carpet bombed with the Israeli Air Force’s remaining munitions payload. Many of President al-Saeed’s cabinet was killed in the blast, along with 40 million people. 

But things got even worse. 

Reports were pouring in of Qatifist squads rebelling and destroying much of the infrastructure in Israeli Sinai and the Arabic towns in Israel. Then demonstrations in Egypt itself rocked what was left of the government as hundreds of towns were toppled by violent revolutionaries advocating a return to “the old ways”. Skyscrapers, statues and oil wells were destroyed. And this fire was spreading all across the Arab world - soon the remaining leaders were all struggling to regain control of their countries and armies. President al-Saeed remained relatively safe throughout most of June, operating out of a bunker deep beneath the Suez Canal, but he was killed along with the Saudi Crown Prince when rogue Syrian Qatifists shot down the Prince’s plane and leveled the city. President al-Saeed was drowned when his bunker flooded with the waters from the Red Sea.

Egypt practically tore itself apart throughout 1988, with hundreds of tiny statelets forming along the Nile. Loyalists desperately attempted to regain control and re-establish a united Egyptian republic. The Founder himself rode around the Nile Delta like an angel of death. Many in the PLO, enraged that their homeland was now a pile of radioactive slag, rallied the remaining sane members of the Egyptian Coalition and forced the Qatifists out of the Delta, where the Founder then moved on to attack Mecca once again. 

The survivors, wartorn, scarred and too tired to fight anymore, settled in the Nile Delta. This group, composed of Palestinians, Jordanians, Iraqis, Syrians and Egyptians, eventually formed a government they called the United Arab Republic of the Nile. Much of the Levant had become a barren land salted with radiation and now many Arab nations were without a home. 

Almost the entire surface of Egypt was destroyed, blasted millions of years into the past. Even the pyramids were nothing more than dust and sand. Very, very, very little technology remained, all hidden in the many bunkers and tunnels beneath Cairo. 

This new regime was plagued with corruption, frequent deaths and instability. The All Arabian Congress was frequently deadlocked and the remaining technology was hoarded by the few government officials that had escaped the nuclear destruction. Expeditions into the Levant and Arabia were conducted for scavenging but they were frequently beset by warlords, bandits and Qatifists. This was until they made contact with the remnants of Lebanon and Saudi Arabia in Hejaz, and the two new states allied together. The Nile provided sickly, withered crops and Hejaz provided technology to help maintain the two of them. 

Many chose to leave the fledgling Republic in search of a better life. Ethiopia, Morocco, Turkey and Europe were common choices. For those that stayed, every year became harder. The Nile fluctuated between a salty trickle and a roaring typhoon that decimated the humble shacks and hovels along its banks. Finally, in 2003, it shrunk to the point that even the ruins of Cairo barely got any water. The All Arabian Congress, already unable to agree on even the most simple of tasks, fell apart as each of the survivor groups fell back into national lines. The Egyptians demanded the lion’s share of the tiny Nile, while the Sudanese demanded that they should get an equal amount as the Egyptians. The Palestinians demanded that they should have it since they had been out of their homeland the longest and the Iraqi demanded it because they fought the hardest in the War. The ruins of Cairo became an intricate maze of complex border disputes between a half-dozen stateless nations. Alliances were made and broken every month, and men were driven mad with thirst. 

When the Red Summer finally ended and the water returned to a relatively normal level, the damage had already been done, and the Nile Republics were never united again. All six of the major survivor groups constantly stole from one another or became bandits and warlords themselves, leading raids into Arabia and the Levant or west into the ruins of Libya and Algeria. 

Then the Purple Summer of 2011 came, and for the first time the Nile completely dried up[1]. Many left after that. Some attempted to attack the “probably Qatifist” Mecca, thinking that they had some secret supply of water. Others went to the coast to raid the states along the Mediterranean. Many of them became no better than the Qatifists that had destroyed their cities. A small number of them even allied with Israeli raider groups, partaking in eating whoever they could find. 

Those that remained, a few stubborn Egyptians who grew up hearing stories of Nasser and the early Revolutions, stayed behind in the decaying metro system. Over time, secret passages were found, some of them empty but some of them containing shipments of rations, building materials and one of them even contained an underground spring. More and more people were forced to spend months underground as the radiation, sandstorms, drought and fires caused untold destruction. 

By 2020, they were permanently underground. The population slowly grew, eventually spreading out across the entire Greater Cairo Metro Underground. But the Second Great Heatwave fractured even this tiny population and the various underground city-states became fierce rivals in the control of the few underground springs. 

As of 2027, the survivors below Cairo are rapidly running out of living space, food and building materials. The only thing that keeps them going is the idea of outlasting the Israelis. 
Israel

Official name: State of Israel (until 1988), Israeli Provisional Government (1988-2015), Israeli Confederacy (2015-2027)
Capital: Jerusalem (until 1992), Petah Tikva (1992-2027)
Government Type: Parliamentary Republic (until 1988), Authoritarian Dictatorship (1988-2015), Military Confederacy (2015-2027)
Population as of final census conducted: 8,683,789 (circa 1980)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 3,100,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $526.77 Billion USD
Primary Language: Hebrew
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: Nonaligned
Great Death Survival Rating: Remnant

Israel was a state that was constantly on edge. It was believed to be necessary - the Israeli government had to be ever vigilant and protect the Israeli people. That was why, when the various Arab nations surrounding Israel stopped being so aggressive to them, the Israeli government remained suspicious. 

Outwardly, Israel was cautiously optimistic, but the inner workings of the government were pulling out their hair trying to find out why Egypt was content to just let Israel keep the Sinai Peninsula. Yitzhak Navon, the man who replaced Golda Mier as the Prime Minister following his narrow victory in the 1969 election, described himself as a pragmatic optimist. Internal and foreign policy switched to neutrality and non-interventionism, as long as Israel’s neighbors acted equally neutral. 

Prime Minister Navon engaged in several bi-lateral summits with various countries throughout 1970 and 1971. Some of these meetings ended up including the Soviet Union, Iran, Turkey, and South Africa. Israel also held regular conferences with the United States and various Western European nations. The leaders of many Middle Eastern nations declined to meet with Navon but that was certainly better than completely ignoring him. 

In late 1971, Mossad became increasingly worried about the rumors circulating out of China. The assassination of Leonid Brezhnev had already made the Prime Minister’s cabinet worried about the greater geopolitical situation around the world, and when it was confirmed via CIA satellite that Mao Zedong had been killed as well, this quietly set the government of Israel into panic mode. The rapidly escalating hostilities between the USSR and China, and with the rise of previously low-ranking party members to the leadership of both countries, made inter-communist relations extremely unpredictable. 

In 1972, Mossad was even more confused as Chairman Chen re-organized China from the ground up to be a hyperindustrialized mixed economy, one now firmly aligned with the USA. With every report Prime Minister Navon received, he became more perplexed and in mid-1972 ordered the Mossad to make the observation of the Eastern Situation Israel’s highest priority. 

And then in September 1972, Israel was invited to an “urgently important” diplomatic meeting being held in Switzerland. Inside that conference room were representatives from the United States, Egypt, Iran, China, and several other Arab nations such as Saudi Arabia, Syria and Lebanon. As Navon’s aide and translator told him, the United States and China had organized this meeting to mediate a more permanent and lasting peace in the Middle East. Chairman Chen’s translators all stressed that this was of the utmost importance and that the new world order rested upon peace in the Levant and Arabia. 

The negotiations progressed over several weeks and finally on October 8, 1972, the Tehran Accords were signed. This binding treaty ensured that for the next 50 years, the nations of the Middle East would have an undisputed monopoly on the sale of petroleum. Other nations were forbidden from selling their oil below a certain price limit, and in return, the Western World and China would provide generous foreign aid packages to ensure the safety of Arab workers and a steady flow of cheap energy from the Middle East. 

Some of the conditions that Israel stipulated was control of the Sinai Peninsula and the State of Israel being recognized diplomatically by their neighbors. While the Sinai was conceded, the Arab states did not recognize Israel. Ultimately, they compromised on not placing sanctions on Israel, but no guarantee could be made that they would not attack Israel again. So the United States stepped in and penned a clause that made it so that not only would the USA give generous military, intelligence and logistical aid to Israel, but if any nation attacked Israel the West and China would boycott the purchase of Arab oil. On top of that, a formal treaty of military and economical cooperation was signed between Israel and Iran, ensuring that Israel would have an ally that wasn’t an ocean away or on the other side of the continent. President al-Haddad of Egypt, after much deliberation with the Saudi diplomats, finally signed the accords and provided the last signature needed. 

And thus, it seemed, peace was brought to the Middle East. 

Israel remained isolated throughout most of the 1970s, and only signed the Shanghai Accords in 1978 when it was clear that Chairman Chen had secured his place as China’s ruler and wasn’t going to be deposed any time soon. Israel began to extensively settle the Sinai peninsula, building numerous intricate and luxurious cities, resorts and parks. Many of these lavish resorts ended up opening in the 1980s, to massive success. Israel also let many Palestinians leave peacefully, who usually emigrated to Iraq or Egypt. As relations between the East and West improved, many Jews were allowed to immigrate to Israel, which massively swelled their population. This huge influx of new ideas, perspectives and cultures caused a rift in Israeli society, culminating in a constitutional crisis in 1984. European Jews frequently got into fights with Soviet Jews and mass protests forced the IDF to begin construction of new detention camps. 

Prime Minister Navon was finally outed in the 1984 election, and a much more moderate Jewish man from Canada named Gideon Morani took his place. Prime Minister Morani heavily focused on stabilizing the country. Generous welfare plans (funded by Iranian oil profits) helped lift many Israelis out of poverty and several new government positions were created, such as the Minister for Integration, which focused on ensuring that the many new Jewish immigrants felt safe and that their voices were heard. While Navon’s administration was quite secular, Morani’s doubled down even further on secularism. Morani was known for famously saying “All Jews, from the steppes of Asia to the jungles of South America, are welcome here. All of them have a home in Israel.” 

But both the Navon Administration and the Morani Administration remained cautiously wary of the political situation in the East. In 1982, during Agassi’s corruption scandal, Mossad began to consider a war between China and the USSR as a serious possibility. Israel had already refused to outlaw nuclear power in the aftermath of the Three Mile Island incident, and had developed nuclear weapons as far back as 1973, but Israel’s government began to conduct extensive research into underground arcology, hydroponics, desalination, and the potential biological and ecological effects of a nuclear war. Israel also never completely let their guard down, extensively fortifying their cities and conducting monthly drills. By 1985, many considered Israel to be the most militarized nation on Earth. 

Israel did not believe that the Arab world had completely forgiven them and had moved on. Their suspicions were proven right as the Arab world began to become notably more aggressive in the mid 1980s. Qatifism and extremism surged in the opening months of 1988. And finally, when the Egyptian Coalition revealed itself and demanded the Sinai back, the Israelis were not surprised. 

Israel shifted to a total war economy, and martial law, rationing, and strict curfews came into effect the second the invasion started. Trenches, artillery, and machinegun nests ensured that the invading army would pay in gallons of blood for every inch of territory they took. Bombing runs crippled supply lines and prevented large amounts of armor and mechanized infantry from reaching Central Israel until June. 

Many towns became dead silent as only the IDF was allowed to roam the streets. A total media blackout ensured that only government-approved information was transmitted over radio and television. Israeli ambassadors tried to leverage more support from other nations but much of the world was distracted by many other things, such as the hostage crisis in Sri Lanka, the efforts to rebuild Tuvalu, the ongoing negotiations between Maoists and Jihadists in Malaysia, Cape Verde’s attempts at developing a cure for Malaria, protests in Gabon, the Qatari civil war, democratic backsliding in Ghana, Sudan’s new pro-Egyptian government, martial law in the Congo, the cholera outbreak in Zimbabwe, the famine in Zambia, and investigations into war crimes in Cambodia. 

Once Prime Minister Morani heard of the nuking of Tel Aviv, he sighed and tried to give the invading army one last chance to avoid apocalyptic bloodshed. The Qatifist Army refused to halt their siege of Jerusalem, and when the city was breached on June 8, 1988, a tired, sleepless Morani authorized the IDF to launch retaliatory nuclear strikes. 

Many in Israel did not heed the warning sirens, and thus did not seek underground shelter as the bombs arrived. The Haifa metropolitan area was obliterated in a mushroom cloud and over 2 million Israelis lost their lives in an instant. Prime Minister Morani, upon learning of the untold destruction being carried out across the Levant and Arabia, simply told his cabinet to do “whatever they wanted now”, and excused himself to his office. 

He was later found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. 

This caused a civil war within Israel’s government as many deserted their posts to be with their families. Those that remained were split about what to do, as some felt that they had nothing left to lose and might as well take down as many Arabs as they could, while others wanted the bloodshed to end. A few said why stop at Sinai and take over the rest of the Levant. 

By July of 1988, the Israeli civil war had concluded, with General Barak Ze’ev Shamir declaring the Israeli Provisional Government on July 2, 1988. He pacified the more rabid members of the IDF, allowing a grace period for all Arabs to leave the nation by the end of 1988 - afterwards, all non-Israelis would be shot on sight. 

The Israeli Provisional Government, essentially a military dictatorship led by the IDF, focused on securing the cities devastated by nuclear weapons and carpet bombing. Unofficial censuses were conducted and it was concluded that over one third of Israel’s pre-war population had died in the bombings or had gone missing. Surveys were then conducted to determine the amount of arable land left and the results were grim. As it stood right now, Israel would barely be able to agriculturally sustain a population of 1 million, let alone its pre-war population of 9 million. 

Israel’s surface remained relatively quiet throughout the rest of 1988. Most of the invading Arabs had retreated to deal with the escalating civil wars in their homelands. As the new year came, this changed, as the violence and chaos began to spread to Israel. General Shamir activated the Ark Protocol, which was the mass-scale evacuation of civilians to a huge series of underground bunkers built throughout the 1970s and 1980s. Originally constructed as a contingency plan for if the USSR and China nuked each other, it would serve as the new home of the Israeli people. Many of these bunkers were located beneath the many tourist destinations established along the coast, including some parts of the Sinai. Other bunkers were located beneath major cities though some of them were damaged to the point of being unusable. This series of shelters, known as the “Kibbutz Network”, were connected by tunnels that spanned the length of much of Israel. Many of these Kibbutz complexes were relatively self-sufficient, with primitive hydroponics and extensive desalination systems powered by nuclear reactors. 

The Ark Protocol would take quite some time to fully activate, as bunkers would need to be assessed on their habitability, the water purification systems would need to be tested, and most importantly people would need to be collected and evacuated to the bunkers. Finally, once a bunker had reached its occupational capacity, its entrance would need to be destroyed on the surface and its external defenses activated by the IDF. 

Many had believed that Israel’s government was destroyed when the war reached its nuclear conclusion and had emigrated to Europe or further east, sneaking back into the USSR. A few Jews ended up in Kashmir of all places, where they would go on to found the Brotherhood of Peace along with Muslims, Hindus and Christians in the aftermath of the Indo-Pakistani Nuclear War of 2002. 

Those that remained had to go through a complex process to confirm their identity, their political standing (mainly just to make sure they wouldn’t be a threat to General Shamir’s regime) and most importantly, have their fertility and health assessed. Terminally ill survivors, or women deemed infertile due to the radiation exposure, were carted off to a remote section of the desert and euthanized with cyanide-laced rations. The IDF saw the most desertions during this period as they combed through the wreckage of the cities and were forced to execute survivors not following the fertility doctrine. 

Numerous incursions, mainly from Qatifists or Jordanian survivors, kept the rest of the IDF busy when they weren’t assessing civilian health or demolishing bunker entrances. Arad was the site of a massive battle between the remnants of the Israeli 12th Infantry Brigade and what remained of the Egyptian 4th Infantry Brigade. 

Another part of the Ark Protocol involved completely closing off immigration (this was quite easy to do, as nobody really tried to get into Israel around this time) and also to sever diplomatic ties with every single nation on Earth. Ambassadors and diplomats were covertly extracted and transported to the ruins of Ashdod, where they went through the same process other civilians had to go through. 

By 1991, the IDF had finished canvassing the ruins for survivors and were setting up the last few bunkers. Extensive border security operations were then conducted. Automated missile defense systems, minefields spanning entire cities, and extensive chemical weapon use turned the surface of Israel into an uncrossable no-man’s land for the rest of the 90s. The last major operation conducted by the IDF included scuttling all of their remaining operational military vehicles into the Sea of Galilee and then retreating into Ginosaur. 

On Sunday, September 27, 1992, the last IDF soldier entered a tunnel in Be'er Sheva and sealed it behind her. The first part of the Ark Protocol had been completed. 

Not much is known about the exact details on the political, social and economic situation of Israel during this time. Only scattered documents in diaries, along with oral tradition, give glimpses of what life was like in the bunkers. Records indicate that 236 bunkers existed in the Kibbutz system, though only 197 have been discovered. Each bunker held a capacity of 10,000 individuals for at least 50 years, kept functioning by a nuclear reactor. Every single individual had a dedicated job - it was believed that giving citizens time to freely think would lead to rebellion. Resources were stretched to the limit. Diets consisted of a mix of fungi, lab-grown potatoes, and dehydrated nutrient packets. Religion and culture became very important, with some bunkers going out of their way to preserve Jewish traditions. The rabbi became important advisors to Provisional Commanders and offered guidance during times of famine and hardship. 

Living space and resources were considered extremely precious and distributed with mathematical precision. That was why, when survivors were assigned living quarters and a job, all males were ordered to submit to mandatory sterilization procedures. Healthy sperm was stored in various unmarked tunnels beneath the IDF’s command bunker and a list of all fertile women was kept. If a woman was found pregnant after 1993, she was to be transported to a high security military hospital where the baby’s health was constantly monitored. If the baby survived and was born healthy, the mother had a choice: either she or the father must die, as the population had to be kept stable. Many women chose to give up the father (usually a rapist rather than a lover), but some women chose to sacrifice themselves. In most cases, the choice was never even presented, as the mother died during childbirth. 

Once a year, in bunkers with a population below replacement level, the Provisional Commander (usually a veteran of the IDF or a member of the Pre-War government) authorized a fertility lottery, where a few women were chosen to be artificially inseminated. In order to be in this pool, the woman had to maintain a good standing with the Provisional Government, be a devout follower of Judaism, be married, and most importantly consent to a sterilization procedure after the child was born. If the child was stillborn, this procedure was still carried out. 

Another important aspect to life in the bunkers was the longstanding order of permanent martial law. The law was not as complex as pre-war law, and the few rules left were very strict. IDF soldiers served as the judge, jury and executioner, and citizens were given a single chance to correct their mistake or line of thinking before being deemed a criminal. For more violent crimes, they were sentenced immediately. It was seen as a waste of resources to imprison rule breakers, or even execute them, so what the IDF usually did was dump the criminals in the tunnels between the bunkers and let them fend for themselves. Many died, either from starvation, dehydration or radiation, but a few managed to be tough enough to survive. Rape, thievery and hoarding were the most common reasons Israelis were exiled from their bunkers. 

This kept the population on a very tight leash, but as the years dragged on, it became harder and harder to enforce it. Disagreements between the local leadership and central command over what exactly constituted an “unforgivable crime” led to a gradual breakdown of structure, and by 2015, each of the bunkers were essentially independent city states, loosely allied only in the pursuit of survival and the preservation of the Jewish people. 

On the surface, Israel had once again become a brutal battleground. Some of the exiles had managed to escape the tunnels and reach the surface, and banded together into groups for common survival. These gangs, known as the Israeli Exiles, frequently fought with Arabian raiders or European Neo-Crusaders. When they weren’t fighting other groups or themselves, they were frequently seen trying to break back into the Kibbutz system. 

In 2004, the largest group of Israeli Exiles, known as the Followers of Cain, kicked out the last of the Qatifists from Jerusalem and reclaimed it for the Israeli people. This caused a large stir in the survivor community and warlords from as far as Pakistan traveled to the Levant to take back the holy city. While the Israelis were vastly outnumbered, in order for an exile to survive on the surface they had to be particularly brutal so they did not go down easily. 

By 2011, the last of the IDF’s automated defenses had been exhausted, with every SAM turret destroyed or out of missiles, and most of the mines already detonated. Groups of Israeli Exiles had deciphered where entrances to the Kibbutz system likely where and significantly ramped up their attempts at breaking back in. This caused the IDF to create their “Purity” Policy, which consisted of Central Command pre-emptively severing contact with the “compromised” bunkers to prevent any ideological or biological contamination. A few of these bunkers would be broken into, and became havens for gangs of Israeli Exiles, Arab terror groups, and one under Qiryat Shemona even became the headquarters for the neo-Crusader group known as the Order of Paul. 

As this policy became used more and more, it caused further friction between the local commanders and the IDF leadership, and was one of the major factors for the Second Israeli Civil War. In 2014, the bunker under Rahat refused to seal off their entrance to the tunnels, and instead tried to evacuate as many civilians as they could and told them to flee to Shoval. Central command, fearing that the surface raiders would exploit this, authorized an emergency battalion to stop the fleeing Israelis and seal the breach. 

Almost 6,000 people were massacred that day. 

The soldiers were told that they had been contaminated with a plague and that to prevent the sickness spreading to the rest of the system, all of the carriers had to be put down. The tunnel was then collapsed in a controlled demolition. 

When the other local commanders realized what the IDF had done, it kicked off the Second Israeli Civil War. The main bunker located under Petah Tikva was attacked by a coalition of 36 neighboring bunkers and led to the aging General Shamir having his hands and feet cut off and sent to hobble around on the surface until he bled out. 

With each year, the bunkers became more and more isolated. Some of them allied together and traded supplies, while others went silent. A few tried to reform the Provisional Government, but those were wiped out by a much larger coalition. This Israeli Confederation soon became distracted with a new problem - the Israeli Exiles were getting more and more successful in breaking into the bunker system. Refugees were evacuated when they could, but it led to overcrowding and disease. 

Electrical systems began breaking down in late 2017, and by the end of 2018 less than 100 bunkers remained. Radiation contaminated several bunkers when a reactor was damaged in a battle with invaders. The IDF almost always beat back the raiders but each battle was more costly than the last. Resource shortages, famine, and raids had caused some bunkers to nearly run out of food. A few of them decided to take drastic measures and completely cut off the flow of refugees. Others randomly executed those who were deemed too old, too sick, or had broken a mysterious arbitrary law. And then, a very small number of them decided on another option: the recycling of Arab invaders as an emergency ration for refugees. 

The raiders were only growing more desperate as the bleak situation on the surface worsened, and the IDF was gradually running out of bullets, despite creating underground gunsmithing factories. The bunkers switched to communicating using automated coded messages, and one by one they went dark. 

By 2025, only thirteen bunkers remained, regularly transmitting coded messages to each other. They were the most distant, isolated bunkers, separated by dozens of kilometers of tunnels from the nearest bunkers. These ones were never the site of a massive refugee crisis and had remained obscured enough to not be broken into by raiders, or had lasted long enough to re-seal the entrances. In 2026, the bunker beneath Taba in the Sinai was flooded after a landslide caused a wall to collapse, reducing the number to 12. 

The last message sent out by one of these bunkers consisted of the phrase “The 20th umbrella is leaving Algiers”, transmitted out of the bunker beneath Neviot. Many researchers believe that this message indicated a catastrophic system failure. The Solar Flare significantly damaged the Kibbutz system, causing many tunnels to flood, nuclear reactors to stop functioning correctly, and hydraulic doors to seal themselves. 

As of 2027, the status of Israel is unknown. While evidence does exist that the inhabitants of the modern-day state of Amursky trace their lineage to Israel, it is not known precisely when they left the Levant. The most common accepted theory places the date between 2035 and 2070. 

[1] The Nile returned in 2012, but became so unpredictable that it was unreliable to use for agriculture until the 2100s. 
Except from a weathered pamphlet found on a boat sunken in the Gulf of Tonkin

In the Eastern Provinces of Saudi Arabia there lived a devout follower of Shia. He resided in the town of Al-Qatif, on the shores of the Persian Gulf. He was an outcast imam who had been removed from his Mosque for preaching such a conservative lifestyle that even the King’s opposition was confused. To him, the Zakat system was not Arab socialism, but a great temptation, made by wicked men in high places who had long forgotten that hard work was its own reward. To him, women were to be protected, not bought like slaves at a market. He became disillusioned with how soulless and stagnant life had become, and left the streets of Al-Qatif to wander. 

Everywhere he went, he saw the same thing: men falling into temptation and hedonistic desires. Was this how mankind was meant to live? In such spiritual rot? With every city he visited, he only became more firm in his belief that the answer was no. Arab oil had tainted not just the Arabian world, but the whole world as well. And everywhere he went, he saw the same, tired people, with the same dull look in their eyes, as if they wanted to escape this madness. 

The Pact of Iran must be destroyed. The oil had to stop flowing! He chanted as he walked the streets of Al Jubail. He walked the streets naked, for he did not have the skill to make clothes by hand. He did not wash himself, for he did not have water to bathe in. He was handed a robe made of silk by a man who pitied him. This man became his first convert, and they both walked side by side, naked, as they preached of the temptation and corruption that had tainted all of mankind. 

In 1982, the soldiers of the corrupt false King of the Saudis did surround the man and his followers, and banished them from the holy land. As he wandered the Arab world, his flock grew, and many joined him. Fletchers, carpenters, machinists, weavers, bakers and butchers all joined him, for they too had become weary of the world. They clothed themselves in raiment uncorrupted by greed and materialism, and ate food prepared without excess and sin. And everywhere they went, they were cast out and told to leave. Men and women, secular and devout, Sunni and Shia, shunned the Wanderer and his people. 

That was until he came to the glorious land of Egypt, of Cairo-Upon-The-Nile. Egypt was like the other nations of the world, except they had tricked the Tempter and were merely pretending. They still lived the Old Ways and labored in secret to reunite the Ummah. The righteous President of the Arab Republic, Mahmud al-Saeed, saw in The Wanderer that he was a kindred spirit, as they both labored for the good of all mankind. 

The Righteous President saw the valiant jihad The Wanderer was leading, and swore to uphold his cause. With holy weapons blessed in the waters of the Nile, The Wanderer and his people joined the fight to unite Arabia and eventually all of mankind, freeing them from the tyrants of temptation. Many saw his cause was just and joined his movement, pledging their lives so that mankind might one day be free of hedonism and laziness. 

The righteousness of their struggle was only confirmed when Israfil sounded the trumpet and began the Day of Judgement. It was in Mecca that The Wanderer revealed himself to be the Mahdi, and the Righteous President revealed himself to be Īsā ibn Maryam, and the two of them set to work in ridding the world of temptation and evil. 

But Īsā ibn Maryam was murdered by non-believers, and in holy retribution the Mahdi passed judgement of many of the wicked kings and lords throughout the land. The ummah rallied around the Mahdi and they marched across the world, tearing down the monuments to vanity, temptation and hedonism. With each tower that fell, mankind became more pure and righteous. 

When the ummah was cleansed, when humanity was shown to live again without excess greed and temptation, without destroying the beautiful world, the Mahdi declared His work was done. He ascended to the heavens to await the death of His enemies, leaving behind his teachings to his many disciples. 

Soon, once all the excess and greed, the hedonism and debauchery are wiped away, He shall remake the world to be the place of purity and beauty it was always meant to be. 


Addendum
The Sinai War
From “The Four Great Sins: A History of the Atomic Wars” by Elder Mateo Álvarez Sombra-Kolob, fifth edition. Originally published in 943 ASJ, current edition published 971 ASJ

https://youtu.be/AhCWZiJgh2c?si=ykgVNpUrpO1JPVGC 

The Sinai War was the result of 15 years of preparation by a coalition of several nations. The ambitions of several national leaders clashed and resulted in the slow descent and death spiral that ended the old world. And yet, most of the factions involved believed they were truly doing the world a service. 

The Sinai War involved the Egyptian Coalition and the Israel-Iran Axis. Some nations provided support to the Coalition, but did not involve themselves in the war directly. Others simply expressed their public approval of the Coalition, or simply sanctioned Israel. 

Arabic nations that remained truly neutral included Algeria, Tunisia, Morocco, Mauritania, Lebanon, North Yemen and Somalia. Algeria even offered to mediate a peace between Egypt and Israel, though both parties ignored the offer. Other Arab and predominantly Muslim countries only sanctioned Israel, like the United Zakat Emirates, Bahrain, Kuwait, Pakistan and Malaysia. Oman and South Yemen expressed public support for Egypt but declined to place any sanctions on Israel. 

Of the four main powers, only the USSR paid any attention to events going on in the Levant. The USA and Europe were both trying to deal with a number of hostage situations abroad, and the Chinese didn’t expect the violence to escalate significantly. 


The leaders of the Egyptian Coalition. From left to right: Prime Minister Tariq Nabil al-Khatib of Jordan, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Foreign Minister Saud bin Faisal Al Saud of Saudi Arabia, Brotherly Leader Muammar Gaddafi of Libya, President Mahmud Al-Saeed of Egypt, President Omar al-Bashir of Sudan, Foreign Minister Rahim Altaf Qureshi of Pakistan and President Hafez Al-Assad of Syria. Photo taken sometime in 1986. 

The Egyptian Coalition comprised the nations of Egypt, Sudan, Libya, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Syria and Iraq. Saudi Arabia and Pakistan provided mainly logistical and economical support, rather than military support. 

The Sinai War was essentially split into three fronts. The first was the Sinai Front, where the armies of Egypt and Sudan fought to take back the Sinai Peninsula from Israel and eventually move north-east towards Jerusalem. Libya provided logistical support for Egypt in this front, and also provided a part of their navy to help create a blockade in the Mediterranean. The other front was the West Bank Front, where the armies of Jordan, Syria and Iraq advanced from the north and into the West Bank of Israel. Saudi Arabia and Iraq also pooled their navies to create a blockade against Iran. The third front was the Iran-Iraq border, where Iraq tried to prevent Iran from providing as much support to Israel as they could. The Egyptian Coalition tried to minimize the bloodshed on this front. 


Mahmud Al-Saeed, President of Egypt from 1986-1988

The war opened on May 15, 1988, when Egyptian President Mahmud Al-Saeed made a famous speech at the Suez Canal. He announced that not only Palestine shall be liberated, but that the Arab World be united again and become a superpower to rival the USA, Europe, USSR and China. He claimed that the 21st century would be the Arab Century. Syria, which had previously been firmly in the sphere of the USA, unveiled its allegiance to Egypt and the rest of the Arab world. This caused diplomatic ties to be severed between the two nations, and Syria was kicked out of the Alliance of Industrial Nations. Similarly, the USSR severed diplomatic ties to Iraq for their aggression and violating the Tehran Accords. 

The Egyptian Coalition all declared war within 24 hours of Al-Saeed’s address. The other neutral Arab nations did not place sanctions on Israel with the same level of synchronicity, however. Kuwait, for example, debated back and forth between supporting Iran or throwing in their support with the rest of the Arab world. Ultimately they decided on placing sanctions on Israel, though it was near the end of the war in June. 

President Al-Saeed had previously made peace with the more radical elements of the officially secular society of Egypt, and had also managed to convince the leader of a new movement - known as Qatifism - to join his cause as footsoldiers. This swelled the Egyptian Army, increasing its membership by 15 million over the course of 1987. Part of Iraq and Syria’s army was also composed of Qatifists. 

Israel had long prepared for this potential war as well, and shifted to a full wartime economy. The entire country was placed under martial law, strict rationing and an extremely harsh curfew. Drills were conducted every day at random times. The Israeli Air Force engaged in bombing runs around the clock, slowing supply lines down as much as they could. 

Within 6 days, the combined Egyptian and Sudanese armies rolled over the Sinai, retaking it with much bloodshed. It was believed that over 1 million soldiers, mainly Qatifists, died within the first week. A small contingent of Libyan forces, numbering less than 100, were sent to serve as rear guards. Gaddafi claimed the majority of his forces remained on alert and were stationed at the border to form a redoubt for Egypt to retreat if things got messy. Evidence found in the ruins of Moscow instead shows that he had planned on taking over Egypt (along with Tunisia) if things hadn’t gotten quite so messy. 

Egyptian and Sudanese commanders frequently used the Qatifist recruits as cannon fodder, serving as a vanguard so that the more capable and battle-hardened mechanized infantry could focus on taking out Israeli positions. Israel had established few bases in the Sinai, all of which fell by the end of May. 

The Mediterranean Blockade saw far fewer casualties. The Libyan and Egyptian Navy, both composed of old Soviet equipment, was roughly evenly matched with Israel’s navy, composed of old American equipment. Syria’s navy was composed of old American equipment as well, which allowed the three navies to more efficiently exploit weaknesses in the Israeli navy. However, the Israelis used the same advantage to destabilize the Syrian Navy, and forced them to retreat near the end of May. Overall, less than 2,000 casualties were reported in naval battles between Israel and the Egyptian Coalition, the majority of which were sailors in the Syrian navy. Israel attempted to break through the blockade several times, but failed. Ultimately, Israel resorted to escorting super-sonic carrier planes across the sea as their main method of resupplying. Libyan ships also accidently sunk a Lebanese fishing vessel on June 7, 1988. 

Iraq, Syria and Jordan primarily fought on the West Bank front. Jordan was bogged down at first, unable to make much progress into Israel before the reinforcements and supplies from Syria and Iraq arrived. Syria diverted some of its military to help reinforce Iraq’s forces on the Iranian front, but a majority of their army marched south to help Jordan break through the Israeli defenses. Syria, using old American equipment, provided most of the mechanized infantry, armored divisions and artillery on the West Bank front. Iraq provided mainly air support and tanks. Lastly, Jordan provided combat engineers and ensured the supply line remained intact. Of the professional armies, Syria’s soldiers fought the hardest, as President Al-Assad promised luxurious rewards for the soldiers who killed the most Israelis. 

The Iranian front was rather small, consisting of a heavily militarized border between Iraq and Iran, and a Saudi-led blockade in the Persian Gulf. The Saudis and the Iranians played a very intense game of political chess with their forces, always keeping the other on edge but never going far enough for actual battles to take place. The Iraqi-Iranian theatre, meanwhile, saw a small but steady stream of casualties over the course of the war. About 1000 a day died from artillery strikes, bombings and mechanized assaults as the border shifted constantly. The Iraqi soldiers were very well trained though, having prepared and trained for this for almost a decade, and managed to ultimately keep the Iranians at bay and unable to make any major strikes against Iraq or the rest of the Coalition. 

The majority of the fighting happened in June of 1988, when the Egyptian Coalition broke through both the Sinai and West Bank fronts. This caused the Israeli army to perform a massive tactical retreat and regroup around Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. Egypt had already been informed via Soviet intelligence that Israel had concentrated most of their defenses in the Central Levant, and that this was where the fighting got the heaviest. Saudi Arabia finally sent troops around this time. On June 7, 1988, the two sides of the United Arab Army met and encircled Jerusalem. 

Soviet intelligence suggested that the Arab forces simply wait out the Israelis, but this was not fast enough for President Al-Saeed. He authorized Saddam to detonate a nuke 2km off the coast of Tel Aviv, as a show of force. This was the whole reason why President Al-Saeed had put up with Saddam’s erratic nature - he was the only Arab state with nuclear weapons, and had been promised a high-ranking ceremonial position in Egypt’s planned superstate. However, the pilot misheard the order and dropped the nuclear payload on Tel Aviv itself, ending any chance of a peaceful resolution. The Qatifists in the United Arab Army viewed this as the start of the Judgement Day, and began attacking Jerasulem with all of their might. Israel threatened to retaliate with nuclear strikes if the army broke into Jerusalem, but this did not stop the invaders. 

On June 8, 1988, Jerusalem’s defenses were breached and the nukes started flying. 


Photo taken by an American diplomat outside of Haya, UZE. 

After the fall of Jerusalem, several cities and oil fields were targeted by Israel. The capitals of Libya and Sudan were both targeted by Israel, but the nukes were shot down before hitting their targets. The nuke destined for Tripoli landed somewhere in the Mediterranean Sea, while the nuke destined for Khartoum sank into the Red Sea. Gaddafi and al-Bashir then both activated the rest of their armed forces to defend their borders against the inevitable flood of refugees. Gaddafi also ordered his navy to attack the ships in Egypt’s navy, though only with the intention of scuttling them. The Libyan navy told the Egyptian sailors that the ships had been compromised by Iranian spies, to which the sailors believed. 

As for the Qatifists, after the capture of Jerusalem the Founder of Qatifism declared himself the Mahdi and set off to take over Mecca. In the chaos, he and his army were able to easily take over the city. With this, Israel decided they had nothing left to lose and launched their nukes to destroy Iraq. 

Bagdad was targeted first, obliterating much of the high command in the Iraqi military, including Saddam Hussein. This was followed by Mosul, Basrah, Erbil, Kirkuk and many, many nearby oil fields, such as the West Qurna, Artawi, Az Zubair, East Baghdad, Hamrin, Majnoon and Nahr Umr fields. 

Saddam, in his last moments, decided to take Israel down with him. The Haifa metropolitan complex was destroyed. Many in Israel, sick of the air raid drills, did not heed the warning and millions died. For Iran, Tehran was targeted, but the missile didn’t reach its destination. Isfahan and Ahvaz were direct hits, and the numerous oil fields nearby were set aflame. The Abteymour, Ahvas, Bibi Hakimeh, Gachsaran, Karanj, Kupal, Mansouri, Marun, Masjed Soleyman, Rag Sefid, and Shadegan fields were all turned into burning geysers and hellish pillars of smoke. 

Nukes destroyed several notable cities, such as Damascus and Aleppo in Syria, killing President As-Assad. Al-Omar oil field in Syria was set alight. Cairo was targeted, but the bomb was shot down, instead landing in Suez. Because of this, the Israeli Air Force used their remaining supply of conventional bombs to turn the Cairo metropolitan area into dusty wasteland. In Jordan, the destruction of Amman and Irbid resulted in both the Prime Minister and King dying. This was followed by Riyadh and the death of King Khalid I. Finally, major Saudi oil fields were targeted, such as the Abqaiq, Ghawar and Shaybah fields were destroyed by Iranian nukes. 

In total, over 25 million people died within the span of three hours, and almost 900 billion barrels of oil started to burn. 

Other nations were destroyed not by nuclear fire, but by Qatifist rebel movements. Kuwait’s government was wiped out within two months of the nukes dropping. Qatar’s government had already fallen a few days before the nukes dropped, and also to Qatifist insurgents. 

Qatifist-induced violence reached as far as Algeria, where several mosques were bombed. Tunisia, due to being a much smaller country, had an easier time wiping out their Qatifist violence. Lebanon was also plagued by pro-Qatifist violence but it was quickly stamped out. Qatifist violence was strongest in Iraq. Many Qatifists gained access to Iraqi munitions and equipment, and a few of them even managed to gain control of Iraq’s remaining nuclear weapons. A suicide mission led by a squad of brave Iraqi soldiers stopped them, but not before the Qatifists detonated low-yield, high radiation bombs on the Dead Sea and the Gulf of Persia. In other places, like Egypt, Syria, and Jordan, Qatifist revolutionaries destroyed what little bits of government had survived. President Al-Saeed was ultimately killed at the end of June, 1988, when his bunker under Suez was destroyed and he drowned in the Red Sea. 

And then there were nations like Oman, which were spared both the wrath of the Israelis and the Qatifists. Oman collapsed not from war or revolution, but the massive influx of refugees and the effects pollution had on the environment and populace. North Yemen’s collapse was much more violent, as a weak leader was unable to prevent the country from falling into civil war yet again. Lebanon lasted the longest, but refugees and environmental degradation made life there very hard. Israel’s Prime Minister, showing immense guilt for the lives taken, committed suicide, plunging Israel into a brutal civil war. Finally, in Sudan, the disastrous results of the war ended in the government collapsing. 

The UZE was hit particularly hard by the Qatifists, due to the country’s reputation for excessive wealth. Pipelines were sabotaged and Dubai was the site of a massive terrorist attack. The Royal Saudi Navy and Armed Forces attempted to evacuate citizens and slow down the Qatifists, but their efforts did little to help the situation. The massacre in Haya and the death of many diplomatic officials also caused a reduction in diplomacy worldwide. Bahrain was a similar story, though it was not targeted because of its perceived wealth, but simply because of how small it was. Being the smallest Arab state in that era, it was very easy for the Qatifists to overwhelm it. Again, the Royal Saudi Navy attempted to help evacuate as many people as possible and also to shoot down any unauthorized fighter jets (usually Syrian or Iraqi ones, piloted by Qatifist militants). Almost half of the Royal Saudi Navy was destroyed by rogue Iraqi fighter jets who carpet bombed the fleet, the sea and the island. Bahrain’s fear of the Qatifists would ultimately lead to a civil war that made them an easy target. Lebanon’s army was the other main force to combat the Qatifists. They worked with the Royal Saudi Armed Forces to help escort the Saudi Crown Prince and also participated in the mission to retake Mecca from Qatifist forces. While the mission to evacuate the Crown Prince ended  up proving a failure, the campaign to retake Mecca was not, though many, many died. 

In total, almost 75 million died in time between May 1988 and July 1988. Some historians consider the liberation of Mecca from Qatifist forces to be the end of the war, while others classify the nuclear cascade to be the true end. 

Regardless, the effects are still felt today. 
Document: The Tehran Accords
The Tehran Accords: A Plan of Peace and Stability for the Middle East
Preamble

Recognizing the need for peace, stability, and cooperation in the Middle East, the United States of America (represented by President Richard M. Nixon) and the People’s Republic of China (represented by Chairman Chen Qiang) have negotiated with the many diverse nations within the Middle East region to create a plan for lasting prosperity not just for the nations involved but the entire world. The signatories of this document commit to the goal of eliminating conflict with the State of Israel, providing safe, affordable access to Arabian energy and creating a stable energy market for the industries of the world to thrive. The parties have agreed to the following: 

Article I: Cessation of Hostile Acts towards the State of Israel 
The participants of the Six-Day War of 1967, along with any nations that have previously expressed hostility towards the State of Israel, are to cease attacks against the State of Israel. After the signing of this document, direct or indirect attacks against the State of Israel shall be met with the immediate termination of this agreement. 
This provision does not require any signatory states to recognize the State of Israel or open diplomatic relations with them. Only the cessation of hostile acts is required. 

Article II: Sanctions and Economic Warfare
All signatories agree that no nation shall place sanctions, trade embargos and other forms of economic warfare against the State of Israel. The violation of this clause shall be met with the immediate termination of this agreement. 
Policies already in place at the signing of this document must be ended by 31 December, 1973. 

Article III: Energy Market Stabilization 
All non-Arab signatories (with the exception of the Imperial State of Iran) are to refrain from setting their energy export prices below the agreed market level, inflation withstanding. 
The agreed market level shall be determined by a joint council of economists from the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, the Imperial State of Iran, the Syrian Arab Republic, the Iraqi Republic, the United Arab Emirates, and the Arab Republic of Egypt. 
The market price will be re-evaluated every year on 10 June. 
The United States, Canada, Western European Union, People’s Republic of China and Japan all commit to immediate and sustained financial contribution to ensure the continued creation, maintenance and regulation of Arabian energy infrastructure and industries. In addition, the signatories of this document all pledge to prioritize the purchase of energy from the countries making up the Joint Energy Council. 

Article IV: On Israel’s Continued Security 
The United States again commits to the security of the State of Israel and will provide additional funding, military aid, and technical support to dissuade any Arab state from attacking Israel and violating this agreement. 
The Imperial State of Iran and the State of Israel, recognizing the critical need for regional stability, agree to establish an organization for the mutual defense of both states should conflict arise. 
The members of the Palestinian Liberation Organization shall relocate from states neighboring Israel. 

Article V: Duration
This treaty shall remain in effect for 50 years, after which it may be re-evaluated. 
Any countries breaking this agreement shall be subject to a total embargo of all goods from the remaining participant countries. 

Article VI: Other Clauses For Regional Stability 
The Imperial State of Iran shall recognize the sovereignty of the People’s Syndicalist Confederation of Bahrain. In exchange the Imperial State of Iran shall receive 50% of the profits from the Tehran-Bahrain Oil Company. 
The Arab Republic of Egypt, the Syrian Arab Republic and the Heshamite Kingdom of Jordan shall recognize the territories gained by Israel in the Six-Day War of 1967 as sovereign territory of Israel. This treaty defines these areas as the Sinai Peninsula, the Gaza Strip, Golan Heights and the West Bank. 

Signatories
President Richard M. Nixon, representing the United States of America
Chairman Chen Qiang, representing the People’s Republic of China
Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, representing the Imperial State of Iran
King Khalid I bin Abdulaziz Al Saud, representing the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
President Hafez al-Assad, representing the Syrian Arab Republic
King Hussein I bin Talal al-Hashimi, representing the Heshimite Kingdom of Jordan
Sultan Qaboos bin Said, representing the Sultanate of Oman
Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan, representing the United Arab Emirates
Chairman Hassan al-Mutairi, representing the People’s Syndicalist Confederation of Bahrain
President Élias Sarkis, representing the Republic of Lebanon
Emir Sabah Al-Salim Al-Sabah, representing the State of Kuwait
Emir Ahmad bin Ali Al Thani, representing the Kingdom of Qatar
President Abdul Rahman al-Eryani, representing the Yemen Arab Republic
President Saddam Hussein, representing the Iraqi Republic
President Salim Rubaya Ali, representing the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen
President Karim al-Haddad, representing the Arab Republic of Egypt
Prime Minister Yitzhak Navon, representing the State of Israel
Interlude
The Final Emergency
Bangladesh

Official name: People’s Republic of Bangladesh (until 1989), Islamic Republic of Bangladesh (1989-1999), Indian Occupation of Bangladesh (1999-2002) 
Capital: Dhaka (until 1999), Bogra (1999-2002) 
Government Type: Parliamentary Republic (until 1989), One-Party Islamic State (1989-1999), Military Occupation (1999-2002)
Population as of final census conducted: 282,577,001 (circa 2000)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: Uninhabitable
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $349.14 Billion USD
Primary Language: Bengali 
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: COMECON (until 1982), World Prosperity Alliance (1982-1989) 
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

Bangladesh split off from Pakistan on December 16, 1971, succeeding in their War of Independence. With a new pawn on the chessboard, the various regional powers attempted to curry favor with this nascent nation. China initially supported the efforts of Bangladesh before Chairman Mao was assassinated, and foreign aid was suspended as Chen reorganized the Chinese government. The USSR, sensing an opening, made overtures to Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and firmly secured an influence over the fledgling government. China seemed to be out of the picture, so Bangladesh became an experiment for the USSR to demonstrate to India how socialism was the way of the future. 

After President Rahman was almost assassinated on August 15, 1975, he placed the country under martial law and further tightened a hold on his power. He suspended elections and became a dictator in all but name. Using his attempted assassination as proof of “pro-Chinese sentiments”, he was able to obtain additional security services from the USSR. In fact, he completely defunded the military and police except for those loyal to him, and relied on Moscow for everything else. 

Throughout the late 1970s and early 1980s, the Morgan Administration and Chen’s China attempted to persuade President Rahman to open up Bangladesh and democratize it. Moscow had been less and less willing to prop up Rahman’s regime, and Rahman realized that his power was waning. In 1981, after an attempted coup, Rahman relented and agreed to democratize as long as he was given assurances that he would not be persecuted by any future administrations. This was followed by Bangladesh signing the Shanghai Accords and Tehran Accords. Moscow was initially feisty about this, but they soon had their hands full with Agassi’s scandal. 

The 1980s were a brief golden age for Bangladesh, as tensions with their neighbors died down. China proved to be a far more willing trading partner than the USSR and ended up investing heavily in Bangladesh’s infrastructure and industrial capacity. Rahman’s replacement, Mahmud Chowdhury, was a lot more open to free trade - as long as it benefitted him and his government, of course. He also loosened up emigration and censorship laws, though labor laws suffered. With every year, the country was less socialist and more consumerist. Bangladesh’s fishing industry exploded, with advanced, cutting edge chemicals being added to the water to supposedly enhance the fertility of the fish. Bangladesh’s ports also became major trading hubs for shipping companies throughout southeast Asia and internationally. In 1983, President Chowdhury created a worker’s exchange program with China, with millions of Bengals moving to China to work in the numerous factories. This was actually to cover up the disastrous result of the December 27 Incident, in which a Chinese-built factory’s foundation sunk into the ground and ended up killing almost 50 people though many, many more were injured. The rivers of Bangladesh became so polluted that river fires were a common enough hazard to be included in weather reports. The government (along with several private companies trying to protect their investments) attempted multiple operations to clean the waterways but none were successful - instead, the state invested in complicated, expensive mitigation efforts rather than cutting back or enforcing pollution laws. 

Bangladesh remained neutral in the Sinai War, though they did express their support for the Egyptian Coalition. And like the rest of the world, their economy practically collapsed in the aftermath of the Crash of ‘88 and The Shock. Many migrant workers returned home, and Bangladesh rapidly became a crowded mess of swamps and decaying cities. President Chowdhury attempted to negotiate with China for aid, but then he received a mysterious missive from Moscow: Director Savateev, the KGB’s rising star, sent them evidence of China’s extermination of muslims and other ethnic minorities who had refused to renounce their faith. While President Chowdhury was initially skeptical about this, other, more vocal members of his government expressed their concern with this information. This year, China might demand their labor, but next year? Next year they could demand they give up their faith. 

Negotiations between Bangladesh and China quickly soured, with China giving up more and more concessions to keep trade alive. Ironically, this made the Bengals only more suspicious, and confirmed the paranoia of the more radical members of the Bengali government. Things came to a head in early 1989, when a group of far-right militants, inspired by the movements happening around the world, overthrew the Bengali government and established the “Islamic Republic of Bangladesh”. 

This period of Bengali history is not well documented, as the Islamic revolution spiraled out of control into a series of civil wars, coups, and infighting. By the end of 1989, the “Bengali Qatifist Party” emerged the winner by sheer brute force. Electrical infrastructure not already destroyed by the fighting or the weather was then dismantled as “altars of temptation”. When the Bengali Qatifists ran out of internal enemies, they started lashing out at their neighbors. Myanmar threatened an invasion several times, while Qatifist raiders frequently harassed Indian border guards. Incursions became so frequent that at one point, India had almost 100,000 personnel stationed across their various border fortifications. Bengali raiders, some of them Qatifists and others forgoing any religious pretext, preyed on ships in the Indian ocean. Much of Bangladesh’s mainland was dying and farms were withering from pollution or saltwater flooding, so fishing and raiding were the 170 million Bengal’s main source of sustenance and trade. 

Indonesia, China and India avoided the waters around Bangladesh but this caused the raiders to only strike farther and farther out. India participated in several bombing campaigns throughout the late 1990s, until finally, China, India and Indonesia, sick of being harassed by the seemingly endless flow of Bengali raiders, made an unlikely alliance and engaged in a brutal, bloody campaign to pacify Bangladesh. If Qatifist Bangladesh was a wasteland, Bangladesh in the aftermath could be described as about as desolate as the surface of the moon. It was then no surprise that Indonesia and China did not want to partition the conquered land, instead they did not even protest when India absorbed the land formerly known as Bangladesh. 

Bangladesh was a pyrrhic victory, as almost all of its land was usable, its infrastructure nonexistent, and constant flooding caused almost weekly resettlement. Still, India welcomed the extra land - they were rapidly running out of space. Bangladesh was annexed by India in 1999, officially as a “special military zone”, which equated to nothing more than intensive labor camps, penal farms and mobs of scavengers trying to sift through the ruins to get any bits of metal that hadn’t been washed away in the chronic floods. The Indian Army patrolled the waterways in loud, coal-powered boats and policed the survivors. Many slept on the ground, while the Army slept in their boats. 

Any semblance of law and order vanished after the Indo-Pakistani Nuclear War of 2002. General Vikram Rathore, who was in charge of the Indian forces in the Bengali Detention Zone, decided that Emergency Minister Singh no longer had any authority over him, as India didn’t exist any more. He then declared himself Emperor of Bengal, and seeking to expand his territory, he fell in battle in Calcutta. 

With this, Bangladesh became an anarchic free-for-all. Pro-Chinese Neo-Maoists fought the remnants of the Indian Army, Pakistani-style Islamic Socialists waged war on anyone expressing even remotely Qatifist-aligned views, and that was on top of the innumerable gangs of bandits, gangsters, smugglers, pirates, cultists and rebels. The waters of Bangladesh smelled of iron and salt for decades. 

By the Purple Summer of 2011, the last farms finally died out and Bangladesh became incapable of supporting any agriculture. Smuggling, raiding and cannibalism increased exponentially. More people died every year from dehydration than violence. At night, swarms of rabid cannibals chased down anyone they saw, eventually fighting each other in “hunger crusades”. In the largest of these groups, a cult began to form, one worshipping some long-forgotten god of death. These cannibals clashed with the death cults in India and Bhutan before dying out in the mid 2020s. 

As of 2027, Bangladesh is a wasteland filled with rotting, bleached bones and rivers stained red with blood. 
Sri Lanka

Official name: Republic of Sri Lanka (until 1990), Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka (1990-1999), Indian Occupation of Sri Lanka (1999-2009) 
Capital: Colombo (until 1999), Kandy (1999-2009) 
Government Type: One Party Unitary State (until 1990), Totalitarian Dictatorship (1990-1999), Military Occupation (1999-2009) 
Population as of final census conducted: 32,874,281 (circa 2000)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: Uninhabitable
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $851.8 Billion USD
Primary Language: Sinhala
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: World Prosperity Alliance (until 1990)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

The JVP Insurrection of 1971 failed spectacularly, with the young, inexperienced Marxists failing to capture any provinces at all. The crippled USSR, still rebuilding itself after the death of Brezhnev, was unable to capitalize on this and could only watch as socialism was banned in all forms in Sri Lanka. Even stranger, as the dust settled a joint US-China stabilization mission arrived on the island not long after in 1972 and helped rebuild the lightly damaged infrastructure. 

Under immense pressure from the US, the socialist experiment of the Dominion of Ceylon ended and on May 22, 1972, the Republic of Sri Lanka was founded. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, the leader of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party and wife of the first Prime Minister of Sri Lanka, worked closely with the Nixon Administration to dismantle the “failed socialist experiment” that Ceylon had become. In its place was an American-style federal republic with a lucrative free market. In Sri Lanka’s first election, Dulan Wijesinghe of the United Nationalist Party became the country’s first president and was subsequently re-elected every election. 

In actuality though, the Republic of Sri Lanka was an oppressive one-party state with very little social services. Due to obscure amendments and by-laws, all in the name of preventing another Marxist uprising, the UNP’s opposition never made it big past the local elections. It wasn’t entirely draconian, though, as they still allowed barrier-free immigration and generous tax reductions for foreign investors. The new government focused on creating luxurious tourist traps and catering to visitors rather than improving the lives of their citizens. Many Sri Lankans emigrated abroad, mainly to work in India, the infant Zakat states, or China. 

India, wanting to usurp China as the industrial powerhouse of the world, heavily invested in Sri Lankan industry under the administration of Prime Minister Raghunath Prasad Malhotra. Prime Minister Malhotra and Chairman Chen begin playing a game of political checkers using Sri Lanka - for every resort or mineral refinery India invested in, China would invest in two more. Many ports became exclusively Indian or Chinese ports, with their products being shipped to either Chennai or Shanghai. The rivalry between the Chinese and Indian companies and shell companies was rather fierce, and by 1983, every single Sri Lankan company had been bought out by either an Indian or Chinese conglomerate. 

For the most part, the average Sri Lankan was fine with this. Working in tourist resorts or the service industry was basically identical regardless of which nationality the parent company belonged to, however for the more dangerous industrial jobs like mining or mineral refinement the experiences were vastly different. Indian-sponsored jobs tended to be much safer and more reliable work, but Chinese-sponsored jobs were less reliable, less safer, but paid much better. Many young Sri Lankans would fall for the lucrative siren song of working in a Chinese sapphire mine, and lose their life in the tunnels beneath Sri Lanka. Some of these sites would later become tourist attractions, with one company attempting to turn a mine outside of Bandarawela into an underground resort and theme park. 

As Sri Lanka continued to be exploited more and more by the giants in New Delhi and Beijing, a small but extremely vocal minority continued to rally against the regime allowing this to happen. Eventually, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam started to ally with these dissidents and ramped up their operations against the government. Protests and riots turned into deliberate sabotage operations, terrorist attacks, and finally, in 1988, the largest hostage crisis in the history of the world. 

On May 14, 1988, the Weerawila International Resort, Casino and Business Center was captured by a group of well-armed, well-trained and shockingly efficient army of Tamil Tigers. They were sporting what appeared to be a mixture of European, Chinese, Soviet, American and Indian weapons, along with extremely advanced electronic communications and cutting-edge ballistic armor. The terrorists apparently had insider knowledge of the layout of the resort as well as detailed schedules of security personnel, and were able to secure the campus within 13 minutes.
