By the time Sri Lankan authorities arrived at the scene, the resort had been turned into a fortress, with every entrance watched by snipers, mined with claymores, and patrolled by bomb-vest wearing guards. 

The first attempt to breach the resort happened just an hour after the building was taken over, when three Sri Lankan police officers attempted to sneak into the building to see just how many terrorists they were dealing with. As a warning of what would happen if further attempts were made, the leader of the terrorists, Sarathan Muralidevan, executed three hostages in the center of the resort. He then demanded, over loudspeaker, that every attempt to breach the compound would result in an entire floor of hostages being killed. 

The Weerawila International Resort, Casino and Business Center was a massive building, Sri Lanka’s crown jewel of tourist traps. It had been built by both Chinese and Indian companies, who had realized there was much more profit to be made if they worked together. The resort was almost 7,000 meters long and contained 37 hotels, 214 water parks, 156 theme parks, 1,476 restaurants, four zoos, three American-style shopping malls, and even an underground train system for the workers. The hotels had a total capacity of 100,000 people, but the actual grounds could hold well over 2 million. When the Tamil Tigers came in, only 78,904 people were there - most of them tourists from Europe, Israel, Canada and America. 

Part of Muralidevan’s demands also included at least one television crew to be active at the scene at all times, and that everyday, at noon Indian Standard Time, he would be granted one hour to express his views. If these demands were not met, he would demolish one floor of a hotel at a time, and after he had collapsed all of the hotels, he would blow up the park along with everyone in it. 

The Sri Lankan Hostage Crisis, sometimes referred to as just “the Crisis” because of how many people’s lives were on the line, instantly made national news. Multiple countries created entire committees of law enforcement officers with extensive training in hostage crisis negotiation, and caused an almost immediate shift in foreign policy. Many news channels offered around-the-clock coverage on the situation, featuring interviews with hostages who had let go, officers on the scene, foreign dignitaries, and later on, tourists and fans of Muralidevan. Almost every single television channel had a small box in the corner of the screen that cycled through updates on the Hostage Crisis. 

Behind the scenes, the United States and Western Europe both had the manpower and equipment to kick down the door and kill most of the terrorists before they could blow up the resort, but the governments of India and China both pressured them to hold back their troops. The resort represented a colossal investment of several nations, being valued at almost $20 trillion USD. 

Everyday, Muralidevan went on air and ranted for at least an hour about how hedonistic society had gotten, how godless everyone had become, how billions around the world were being exploited for the good of a few, and how both China and the USSR had failed at creating a “people’s state”. Every day he had something new to criticize, and everyday, he gained more fans. Ironically, he became a marketing icon. His face was plastered on anything from coffee mugs to T-shirts to even a brand of beer being named after him. Hundreds of people from all over the world, mainly women, started hanging posters of him on their wall - despite not understanding what he was saying, or even comprehending the reasons behind the hostage crisis. By the end of May, people began visiting Sri Lanka exclusively to see the site of the world’s largest hostage crisis. Security forces in Sri Lanka actually switched to preventing rabid fans from getting into the site rather than keeping the terrorists out. 

After each “Terror-Cast”, members of Interpol would negotiate with Muralidevan. Everyday, more hostages were released, and eventually supplies were airdropped in, but any attempt at getting the terrorists to stand down were met with executions and threats of further violence. That was until on June 8th, 1988, when President King and the President of the European Commission, Baron Friedrich von Schwerin of West Germany, announced that they had finally secured the release of all hostages and that the terrorists would stand down. Apparently, what had broken Muralidevan was when he found out that he had essentially been turned into a product. 

https://youtu.be/XHVymL9ar08?si=O6dBrW9CUg3kgAQn 

And just when the first hostages were being sent home, all eyes were glued to their screens as they watched the apocalyptic chaos breaking out in the Middle East. 

Sri Lanka became the site of one of the largest humanitarian crises in history, as airports, ports, buses and freeways became overwhelmed. Some were praying, others were taking advantage of the crisis and began looting businesses. Things got so bad that the United States sent a naval supercarrier to the island to help assist in evacuation efforts. Many nations were so focused on making sure the former hostages made it home safely that they did not pay attention to the immediate aftermath. 

The Tamil Tigers, enraged at the humiliation they had faced when the greatest terrorist attack in history was foiled by just a few t-shirts and fan letters, launched an all-out uprising against the Sri Lankan government. The Indian-Sri Lankan highway was bombed, and Indian forces assisted the Sri Lankan army. The early days of the civil war wasn’t so much a civil war as it was just anarchy. Many believed the world was ending. Fires burned and places of worship were packed, while others simply tried to get on with their day. Both Indian and Sri Lankan forces deserted to be with their families. 

When it was clear that the world was in fact, not ending (at least in Sri Lanka) the government engaged in a massive counter-attack and took back much of the coast from the socialist rebels. By the end of 1988, the Sri Lankan government, assisted by both Indian and Chinese troops, the rebels had been forced underground and the Chinese left. Refugees from the Qatifist chaos in the Middle East were resettled in south Asia, including Sri Lanka - and this is where the rebels found their new advantage. Convinced that they would create a buddhist Zakat state, several refugees joined the socialists and served as spies, allies and soldiers. On top of that, evidence suggests that the Soviet Union began smuggling weapons to Sri Lanka to arm the rebels. 

In 1989, it was clear that the world was changing and for the worse. Countries were far more hesitant to work together, and the only thing that kept India supporting Sri Lanka was the fear that the chaos would spill onto the mainland. The Crash of ‘88 and the Shock were only making things harder. As living standards plummeted, the idea of a socialist state sounded much more appealing to the average Sri Lankan, who were usually unemployed as tourism and the service industry had taken a permanent nosedive. Everyday, more people joined the Tamil Tigers, and everyday, government forces were pushed further and further. 

By the start of 1990, the Tamil Tigers controlled almost 75% of the island, with government forces being concentrated in Colombo. Over the past two years, Colombo had been turned into an absolute fortress, a maze of checkpoints, barbed wire, and concrete. Unless the rebels suddenly received a fleet of bomber planes (which was unlikely given the current fuel crisis), they did not have the manpower to successfully breach the militarized city. And so they simply waited. 

The Siege of Colombo lasted from September 9, 1989 to July 14, 1990. By October 1989, all routes into the city were controlled by Tamil forces, cutting off the government from their supply depots. India initially provided supplies to the Sri Lankans, but after a famine was projected to rock the country in 1990, the government decided to suspend all aid to Sri Lanka. Disease ravaged the city in February 1990, followed by food riots in March of 1990 and martial law being declared in April of 1990. In June, rumors of an uprising circulated, before finally being put into motion in July. The government forces were hung from lampposts, with Dulan Wijesinghe being hung in gallows constructed in Independence Square. The last of the government forces surrendered on July 14, 1990. 

The Tamil Tigers proclaimed victory and immediately set about to create a socialist state. All shortcomings and resource shortages were blamed on the previous government, who had sold out the Sri Lankan people to the Indians and Chinese. As this new government formed, a man by the name of Ravindra Senaratne seized control. In the name of unity and preventing tyranny, he assumed complete executive control of the fledgling Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka. Members of the old government were purged, followed by those with Pro-Indian, Pro-Chinese or Pro-Soviet sympathies. And then, people were just killed for being at the wrong place at the wrong time. Massive soviet-style gulags and labor camps were built in the countryside and industry stagnated. The many resorts were turned into sterile apartments and prisons. 

Agriculture became the primary focus of this new regime, but severe ground pollution from mining and chemical spills caused much of the land to be unfarmable. This didn’t stop the government, though - they simply claimed the farmers weren’t truly believing in the “cause of Sri Lankan Socialism”. Rolling black-outs and power shortages coated the island in darkness. Senaratne claimed that all of this was temporary, that once Sri Lanka was back on her feet he would relinquish power and create the perfect democratic socialist society, one that never knew hunger and one that was truly egalitarian. 

For the most part, the extreme draconian measures kept starvation at a minimum - so many people were killed in purges, heatwaves or natural disasters that very few people died from lack of food. The intensive farming provided just enough food that rebellion wasn’t on many people’s minds, and some actually believed that all of this austerity was necessary to create a perfect socialist state. 

The fragile peace was kept until 1994, when a massive famine caused extreme levels of rationing and thousands dead from food riots. Senaratne, knowing his power was at risk, threatened to invade India… unless India gave them 1 million kg of food. India initially ignored them, but when Sri Lankan ships began harassing Indian fishing vessels, Emergency Minister Singh relented and sent them the food. It was all a ploy, of course - Singh had his back up against the wall and was facing calls for his removal from power, and to pacify the more humanitarian members of the Indian government, he relented and sent the shipment to spin it as a humanitarian gesture. 

The food shipment did help, for a time, but Sri Lanka found it was much more efficient to turn to “priviteering” - much like how the ancient British government sanctioned piracy against their enemies, the Sri Lankan government authorized both civilian and military vessels to harass, raid and plunder coastal settlements and sea-faring ships. Bangladesh and Sri Lanka had several naval battles in the Indian ocean, but Sri Lanka was far more cautious about targeting larger, more powerful navies such as Malaysia, Indonesia, Pakistan, and China. The ruins of the Maldives were a frequent destination for the Sri Lankan privateers, usually to scavenge for food and ammunition. 

India was not taking this lying down, and built several large naval bases along their coast to help police against the Sri Lankan privateers. Naval battles between Indian-operated fishing vessels and fleets of Sri Lankan raiding boats caused a significant disruption in the supply chain in India, so much so that by 1998 India had complete control of the Bay of Bengal. 

Senaratne had been preparing for this outcome for a while and on May 6, 1999, he launched a proper invasion of India. He had significantly overestimated the military capabilities of India, and on May 17, 1999 he surrendered only to be killed when Colombo was leveled by Indian naval forces. The Indian army swept across the island and completely demilitarized it, turning it into an advanced industrial center - since the ground was already so polluted, India decided to utilize it to its fullest extent and within months, smog blanketed the entire island. Sri Lankan prisoners of war were forced to comb through the ruins on the island and scavenge for bits of metal, wood, anything that could be used to keep India’s economy running. 

After the collapse of Singh’s government in the Indo-Pakistani Nuclear War of 2002, the remnants of the Sri Lankan Occupational Authority remained loosely allied with the government remnants in Kerala and the western coast of India. A record number of soldiers deserted in the aftermath of the war, going back to the mainland to see if their families had survived. Those that stayed behind were either sadistic, power-addicted maniacs and a few who still genuinely believed in India’s mission of maintaining stability at any cost. 

A loose alliance between Kerala and Sri Lanka kept the two areas functioning - Kerala provided rations while Sri Lanka manufactured supplies and ammunition. Every year, more Sri Lankans were killed, either by bored Indian soldiers or by heatwaves. In 2007, after China came through and razed what was left of India, the remaining Sri Lankans staged an uprising and launched a rebellion against the Indian occupiers. Many atrocities were committed - India burnt down several towns and forced millions of Sri Lankans to work to the death. However, the Indians were few, and the Sri Lankans were many, and on December 27 2009 the last Indians were killed or driven off the island. 

The survivors inherited a broken, polluted rock in the middle of a churning, violent ocean. Every single day, storms and typhoons would batter the island, getting stronger and stronger. Torrential rain washed away the ruins of hundreds of settlements. The extensive mining conducted in the 20th century along with the biblical rainstorms caused landslides and sinkholes to open up all over the island. 

But still, a few scavengers refused to abandon their home and set up tiny self-sufficient enclaves in the central mountains. Eventually all of their stockpiles of food would run low and contact was established with the Keralan Junta. The old trading alliance was restored, but this time Kerala gave them mysterious green crackers and other heavily processed rations. Scrap metal from Sri Lanka was untouched by radiation and was thus very valuable, with the Keralan survivors paying handsomely for the detritus. The Sri Lankans battled the encroaching ocean to get the rusted sheets before the waters swept them away, going further and further into dangerous, unstable areas to keep themselves fed. 

By the 2020s, these storms had gotten so destructive that many finally fled the island and took their luck on the mainland. Every day, a group of holdouts would be swept into the sea or be swallowed up in a sink hole. Evidence suggests that the last group of survivors left the island before the end of 2023. 

As of 2027, Sri Lanka is a desolate, storm-ravaged wasteland picked over by only the most desperate of scavengers. 
Nepal

Official name: Kingdom of Nepal (until 1991), Indian Emergency Regime of Nepal (1991-2011)
Capital: Kathmandu
Government Type: Semi-Constitional Monarchy (until 1991), Military Occupation (1991-2011) 
Population as of final census conducted: 42,233,498 (circa 2000)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 700,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $42.7 Billion USD
Primary Language: Nepali
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: World Prosperity Alliance (until 1988)
Great Death Survival Rating: Forgotten

King Mahendra held on to the Panchayat system as long as he could. As the world opened up and became more and more democratized, Mahendra was pressured by various world leaders - among them President Nixon and Chairman Chen - to follow suit and join this new, highly interconnected world. Despite the advances in medical technology, King Mahendra suffered several debilitating heart attacks throughout the early 1970s until he finally went into a coma after his 5th heart attack on September 30, 1974. His son, Birendra, succeeded him and was crowned on February 24, 1975. 

King Birendra was far more open to the modernization of Nepal. Throughout the late 1970s, he held several meetings and summits with various representatives from China, the United States, Europe, the Arab world, and finally India. As the Emergency ended and President Malhotra started his grand reforms of the Indian state, he made many overtures to King Birendra. India believed that maintaining good relations with their neighbors was essential to their continued stability in the face of a rapidly industrializing China - one that could easily sweep over the Asian continent if they so chose. 

Like Sri Lanka, Nepal was the next game of political chess between India and China. This only intensified when King Birendra held a referendum in 1980 and the Panchayat system was dissolved - in its place was a semi-constitutional monarchy, and the first elections were held in August of 1981. 

Two major parties emerged: the monarchy-endorsed Royal Party, which was supported by India and several other Non-Aligned Nations, and the other party was the People’s Party, which was supported by China, and to a lesser extent the USA and Europe. The People’s Party was a strictly modernist party, one that promoted atheism, agnosticism, secularism, and economic policies aligned with Chen’s “capitalism with Chinese characteristics”. The People’s Party also advocated for barrier-free immigration so that the people of Nepal could work abroad in Indian or Chinese factories. Meanwhile, the Royal Party was far more conservative both economically and politically. They strived for “democracy with Hindu principles” and deep respect for King Birendra. Part of the new system ceded much of the monarchy’s power to the elected representatives, and the Royal Party wished to provide minimal resistance against King Birendra’s goals. 

The results of the first election were heavily contested, but verified as both free and fair by several outside observers such as representatives from Switzerland, South Korea, and Argentina. The new government of Nepal was split right down the middle between Royal Party loyalists and People’s Party progressivists. The first action the government voted on was signing the Shanghai Accords - which passed on November 14, 1981 with a 74% majority. 

Nepal slowly morphed into a rather unique country - it was still deeply religious and remained closely tied, culturally and religiously, to India. However, despite their resistance to secularism, Nepal became extremely close to China. Almost 15 million Nepalese emigrated to China to work in factories, while 9 million traveled to India, mainly to work on the foreign-owned cattle farms. 

On June 25, 1984, Nepal formally left the Non-Aligned Movement and joined the World Prosperity Alliance, firmly placing them in China’s economic sphere of influence. In 1987, Nepal saw a brief surge in tourism as warmer winters made the mountain climate much more pleasant. 

After the Crash of ‘88 and the Shock, the rapid economic downturn forced many Nepali migrant workers to return home. A majority of politicians in the People’s Party, becoming disillusioned with China’s consumerist policies, jumped ship to the Royal Party to save face. Others simply became independent, advocating for policies suspiciously absent of mentions of China. 

King Birendra called a snap election and the Royal Party overwhelmingly dominated the new government. Numerous trade deals were signed with India, along with a few military alliances. Trade with India helped the Nepalese stave off major resource shortages, but electricity and fuel became rationed. Most of the country stood firmly behind King Birendra and approved of the measures he was taking - mainly by pretending that China didn’t exist. 

This angered most of the hardcore People’s Party supporters, who loudly shouted (to anyone that would listen) that the country was regressing and only firmly aligned with China and the West could Nepal get out of this mess. However, even they were silenced when China began to perform military exercises along their border. 

With each week, the quality of life declined. Businesses closed each day. Dozens of half-built resorts were shut down and later turned into housing for the homeless. Fuel prices surged, and as the winters became noticeably warmer, melting snow and glaciers caused landslides in several small towns. 

About a year after the Crash, in June of 1989, civil unrest gradually increased. A growing number of citizens were angered by the lack of welfare policies and the lack of employment opportunities. Protests and marches dominated the streets of Kathmandu. Some of these turned into riots, with agitators advocating for a “strictly Maoist” government and a centrally planned economy. King Birendra, worried that this would affect his relations with India, clamped down hard on these protestors. This only further emboldened them, and led to the Kodari Uprising on August 26, 1989, where a group of pro-Maoist rebels took over several local government buildings. 

These “uprisings” spread and King Birendra made several more treaties with India, asking for additional military support in exchange for even more favorable trading rates. Indian peacekeeping forces arrived in late November 1989, and participated in several campaigns to retake captured cities. Nepal slipped further and further into India’s sphere of influence, giving up parts of their sovereignty in exchange for supplies and security assistance. 

Things remained tenuous at best, with the government of Nepal barely retaining control of the country. That was until the Hot Summer of 1990, when due to famines in India, supply shipments dried up and several soldiers were recalled to help deal with the fallout. The rebels, now encompassing a huge coalition of factions united only in their desire to see King Birendra deposed, launched a massive civil war. India did what they could to help support the crumbling regime, but with the support of China, the rebels made massive gains. On December 26, 1990, King Birendra was killed during the Battle of Kathmandu. Many pro-government forces surrendered after that and on January 13, 1991, spillover from the violence reached India. 

The “pacification” of the “Nepal problem” was one of the first goals of Emergency Minister Singh, who finally annexed Nepal on December 2, 1991. Due to the extreme unrest in the area, it remained an extremely militarized part of India. Hundreds of military bases were built along with the border with China and checkpoints guarded water pipelines. Suspected rebels were sent to work in labor camps or were straight up executed. Many of the survivors of the old government collaborated with India, and were allowed to keep their positions in return. As the climate became warmer every year, many high-ranking members of the Indian government and military moved to occupied Nepal. While food was hard to grow in the mountainous environment, the constantly melting snow and glaciers meant that water was never in short supply. 

After the Indo-Pakistani Nuclear War of 2002, General Arjun Pratap, the commander of Occupied Nepal, openly criticized Singh’s “monumentally stupid” use of nuclear weapons and declared that he was no longer fit to govern India. General Pratap’s faction, the Indian Emergency Regime of Nepal, remained one of the more stable factions to emerge from the nuclear conflict. Their high concentration of military equipment along with controlling several hundred water pipelines made them very influential in the ruins of India. 

General Pratap sought to counter the growing madness of Singh and engaged in several campaigns to retake parts of North India. At one point, the Indian Emergency Regime stretched as far south as Nagpur and controlled much of the remaining arable land in India. These campaigns were initially successful until groups of raiders and Samsarists started targeting Pratap’s forces. With each battle, more land was lost, and famines and droughts spurred uprisings. The Purple Summer of 2011 put an end to this, as while Pratap was focused on retaking parts of Bihar, a group of Nepalese soldiers staged a coup and took control of Nepal’s remaining pipelines and reservoirs. They believed that the Indians were hoarding all of the water and letting the Nepalese die of dehydration, and took matters into their own hands, completely unaware of the heatwave crippling the world’s water supply. 

Later, Pratap was killed by a Singh loyalist outside of Kanpur and any sense of order broke down, as the Indian Emergency Regime splintered into several hundred warlords and bandits seeking to control the rapidly dwindling supply of water. 

For several years, Nepal was a warzone. Massacres and executions forced millions to flee only to be eaten by starving peasants, bandits, and even Samsarists. By the time of the First Great Heatwaves in 2015, Nepal had a population of less than 2 million. Only the toughest, most resourceful bandits and raiders remained, but the promise of nearly unlimited water was very tempting indeed. These groups continued to war against each other for years, eventually creating their own isolated fiefdoms where tiny, sickly crops grew in walled-off farms. 

As of 2027, less than one million remain in the peaks of what used to be Nepal, many who consider Civilization to have ended in 2002. 
Bhutan

Official name: Kingdom of Bhutan (until 1989), Socialist Republic of Bhutan (1989-1991), State of Bhutan (1991-1997), Indian Occupation of Bhutan (1997-2002)
Capital: Thimphu (until 1989), Wangdue Phodrang (1989-2002)
Government Type: Absolute Monarchy (until 1989), Far-Left Authoritarian Dictatorship (1989-1991), Anarchist Theocracy (1991-1997), Military Occupation (1997-2002) 
Population as of final census conducted: 896,597 (circa 2000)
Estimated Population as of June 14, 2027: 15,000
GDP as of June 7, 1988: $2.73 Billion USD
Primary Language: Dzongkha
Member of the Alliance of Nations: NO
Alignment: World Prosperity Alliance (until 1991)
Great Death Survival Rating: Partial

Bhutan remained a rather destitute and isolated place, even with the Shanghai and Tehran Accords. Bhutan’s economy was incredibly tiny, even for a Glorious Decades era nation, being based entirely around subsistence farming and animal husbandry. While it had more natural resources than other poor nations like Bolivia or Mauritania, many simply forgot that Bhutan even existed. 

Bhutan, eager to gain more influence and thus more wealth, was among the first nations to recognize Bangladesh as an independent state. This caused some ire with India but ultimately Prime Minister Gandhi had enough on her mind and said several statements that amounted to nothing more than “a final pre-emptive warning of starting the process of severing diplomatic ties” between the two states. 

One of the reasons why Bhutan remained so isolated and unpopular was how oppressive and authoritarian King Dasho Sonam Dorji was. After assassinating Jigme Singye Wangchuck during his coronation in June of 1974, Dasho Sonam Dorji proclaimed himself the rightful monarch of Bhutan and clamped down hard on his opposition. He had all the members of the Wangchuck family publicly executed as a show of power. Further displays of authoritarianism and autocracy isolated Bhutan from the world stage, and the state became treated in a manner similar to Yugoslavia, North Korea, Myanmar and Taiwan - a tiny, insignificant state with no cultural, political, economic or military power. 

King Dasho Sonam’s foreign policy started out as peaceful and welcoming, but over time morphed into a paranoid game of chess that manipulated neighboring states into giving foreign aid to his people. Pakistan, Bangladesh, India and China all fell into his little game, which resulted in Bhutan joining the World Prosperity Alliance in 1980 despite not having any major industrial centers. The King even “loaned” workers to China in exchange for additional supplies and cheaper trade deals. 

In the 1980s though, the King had seen just how rich and luxurious other states had gotten, and so he tried to loosen up Bhutan to let in some of that wealth. He started an ambitious economic project to increase tourism to Bhutan, starting with numerous “state parks” and later on planned resorts. What surprised him though was the demographic of tourists: mainly Indian and Malaysian Buddhists, coming to see the various temples around the nation. This seemed to be the missing link, and once Bhutan was promoted as the “Buddhist Capital of the World”, tourism skyrocketed. King Dasho Sonam even attempted to create Buddhist “gift shops”, though these were not successful at all. What was successful were “meditation classes” and guided retreats. When the Great Way Temple of Thimphu was completed in 1986, foreign tourism increased by 950%. Indian and Malaysian Buddhists were no longer the primary demographic - instead, it was mainly business executives from North America, Europe and Japan, participating in corporate retreats and team building exercises. 

The Crash of ‘88 didn’t affect Bhutan all that much, as their economy was still heavily agriculturally based and their attempt in tourism had only barely started to expand. Tourism was still present - however it was mainly just Indian Buddhists now, who were secretly content that the “fake Buddhists” had all vanished over the span of a month. 

And yet, despite their relatively stable condition, many were upset at King Dasho Sonam for the continued poverty and poor living conditions. As the quality of life started to get worse and not better, unrest gradually grew until a full on revolution on August 7, 1989 broke out. An uprising in the Royal Palace, led by a socialist guerilla named Tenzin Namgyal Thondup, resulted in King Dasho Sonam Dorji being executed on August 11, 1989. The civil war escalated significantly after that with the Royal Bhutanese Army desperately trying to regain control of cities across the state. During the Battle of Gelephu, several Indian Buddhists were held hostage by the secular socialists. 

Despite Malhotra talking a big talk and claiming to use force when necessary, the Indian Army negotiated with the Socialists and secured their freedom. MP Singh, Leader of the Opposition in the Rajya Sabha, used this one of his main talking points to criticize the Malhotra administration, saying that choosing to negotiate with the Socialists legitimized their coup. Support for an invasion of Bhutan grew, but with the Sri Lankan Civil War happening (relatively) closer to home, Singh was unable to get enough votes to authorize an invasion. 

The Socialist Republic of Bhutan was a very short-lived state, lasting less than two years. The interim socialist government of Thondup was initially supported by the USSR until he refused to enact full communism, instead creating a system he described as “agriculture with socialist characteristics". With this, Yanayev pulled the plug on their aid and left the new government to their fate as heatwaves and famines ravaged the country in 1990. Quality of life decreased further. Many Bhutanese, having been disillusioned with King Dasho Sonam’s empty promises and Leader Thondup’s reforms, turned to Buddhism as a way of coping with the horrible state of the world. Pure Land Buddhism became very popular, as people from all over the world wished to be reborn in a land purified from disease, corruption and hunger. 

This led to a small group of Buddhists advocating for a government focused on spiritual fulfilment, as both the monarchy and the socialists had not improved the quality of life. If the quality of life could not be improved, the only thing the government could do was help prepare its citizens for the next life. A new school of thought emerged - described roughly as “reaching heaven through violence”. In a world so corrupted with violence, using violence in a manner to attempt to achieve nirvana would be preferable, as those that fall would be reincarnated to a better world. 

This movement, eventually known as “Samsarism”, grew in members until it vastly outnumbered the Socialists. On January 26, 1991, Leader Thondup was captured by Samsarists and underwent “forced reincarnation”. The leader of this movement, known only as The Last Guru, turned the ruins of Bhutan into a totalitarian theocracy that made Pakistan look as secular as China. 

Under The Last Guru, it is estimated at least 50,000 people were forcibly reincarnated every year. Those that remained became more radical and extreme in their mission to escape this life, and so rogue Samsarists spread to places in war-town Indochina, starving India and even China to spread their “way out”. This Buddhist-promoted violence helped legitimize Singh’s rule, and India engaged in numerous pacification campaigns against the Samsarists. China even used a similar excuse, stating that their expansion into Indochina was to end the Samsaran violence. 

Finally, on May 27, 1997, India invaded and annexed Bhutan, turning it into a massive military detention camp. An enormous amount of troops were required to maintain control of the region, as the Samsarists frequently launched uprisings against the Indian invaders. In 1998, despite the huge amount of arable land, Indian forces engaged in a massive scorched earth campaign to make it harder for the Samsarists to fight back. Indian authorities attempted to relocate the suspected Samsarists, but that only resulted in their ideology spreading to other prisoners. 

When India and Pakistan destroyed each other in nuclear war, the Samsarists used this as further evidence that the world was dying and that mankind’s only hope was to escape to a more pure land through reincarnation. The remaining Samsarists overthrew the confused, disorganized Indian occupation force and significantly ramped up their reincarnation plans. 

After the war, the Samsarists spread throughout the Indian wasteland, waging war against other cults and bandits. Samsarists were one of the more unique cults during the late Black Ages in that they refused to partake in cannibalism, as this was seen as prolonging suffering. Instead, when it became clear that supplies were running out, the members of a group of Samsarists would partake in one night of excessive pleasure and consumption before engaging in ritual suicide. 

Because of this rather morbid outlook on the world, the movement died out over time, with the original cult in Bhutan all committing ritual suicide in 2015 during the Great Heat Wave. After that, Bhutan became a barren wasteland, occasionally picked over by bandits and scavengers. A few outposts of survivors remained in the more isolated valleys and mountains, occasionally fighting off Chinese deserters, islamic warlords, and Yama cultists. 

In the 2020s, many of these survivor groups allied together to create a tiny, informal confederacy focused on protecting the enclaves. This alliance was only partially successful as raiding parties became more common and larger in number, causing as much as half of the valley to become violent anarchy. 

The Holocene Hyperwave actually put an end to this, as the extreme humidity in the surrounding area below the mountains caused much of the raiders to die off. The alliance broke apart and while the city-states remained more or less friendly with each other, they did not work together to mitigate the water shortages. Other areas were instead ravaged by famine and desertification as a result of the Indian army’s actions in 1998. 

As of 2027, the tiny survivor group in Bhutan is still eking out a miserable existence, either being devastated by floods caused by melting glaciers, or starving as a result of the rapidly dwindling arable land.
