Interlude
The Shock
Excerpt from “The Blood of the Earth: The Economic Downfall of the Pre-Great Death Societies” by Alaric O’Braunfels, Munich Press, 972 ASJ


Photograph of an abandoned oil well located in North Dakota, 1997

https://youtu.be/KjWd5WetF8c?si=wE6KnsMPQC88XgLX 

After the Sinai War of 1988, over 90% of the world’s crude oil supplies went up in flames. Fires burned indiscriminately for almost a century, and now, much of the former Middle East and parts of North Africa are vast fields of grey-green glass, mountains of ash and scorching sands. Very few live in that part of the world now, but in the areas that remain, huge treasure troves of information from this era have been uncovered. 

Many countries in the world were not so concerned about the massive loss of life as they were for the monumental loss of oil. The dirt-cheap oil from Iran, plus the Three Mile Island incident and the subsequent lobbying by Big Oil, had made almost every single country entirely dependent on oil not only for their infrastructure, but their economy as well. Oil-based products were ubiquitous - just about everything was made from oil in some way, be it the rubber and synthetic fibers made for clothing, electronic insulation materials, disposable plastic bags for food, and even medicines and fertilizers were made in processes utilizing petroleum. 

And so, it was a massive shock to the rest of the world when suddenly the price of everything jumped. Medical equipment inflated by almost 2,500%, and kept climbing. Many pharmacies went out of business by 1995. Rubber used for manufacturing cars nosedived, and the last tires were made by 1991, with everything afterwards made using recycled rubber. Rubber was later collected and hoarded by the remaining industries after 2000, as it was needed for making hoses and gaskets for valuable machinery such as filtration systems and pumps. Electronics miniaturization was permanently reversed, as with the exponential increase to electricity bills, industries no longer prioritized making objects such as computers and monitors smaller and smaller. Instead of using plastics to insulate their products, they now had to use heavy, bulky ceramics and metals. These materials also would hold on to heat for longer periods of time, requiring computers and other essential electronics to become larger and larger. It also, unfortunately, made them more dangerous, as chipped ceramics and heated metal caused industrial accidents to slowly but gradually increase. Hundreds of thousands of companies went bankrupt between 1988-1992, and entire industries went completely extinct, never to be revived again. Telecommunications are only just now making a comeback, in the 30th century. 


Train yard outside of Minneapolis, Minnesota, 1990. Many of these trains would never run again. 

The first area to be affected by this massive drop in fuel was of course the transportation network that had connected the world during the Glorious Decades. When an American bought a pack of cigarettes from a store, they were buying tobacco from Brazil, paper made from trees in Zaire, placed in an embossed plastic box manufactured in China, and shipped using Iranian oil across the United States to be bought at a gas station in Olympia, Washington. 

By the end of the summer of 1988, not even a year after the Sinai War, the Crash and the Shock, global trade had practically vanished. Many countries were busy trying to keep their essential industries and commuter networks running, and had no resources for international shipping and exporting. Shipping all but dried up by 2000, and until then they carried only the most essential supplies such as crude oil, food imports, fertilizers and raw metals. By 2010, many cargo ships had been disassembled for parts, or were turned into housing for the poor, like in New York City. 

Personal automobiles had fallen out of favor within a few years of the Crash, and instead, many governments opted for mass public transportation programs. Oil and later coal powered buses dominated the streets of American metropolises until the late 2000s, while in places like the European Federation, Nordic Union, UK and Japan saw electric powered trains and rail lines. The UKs were shut down in late 2009, while the Federation shut down theirs in 2014, citing “increased terrorist activity”. Japan’s public transportation system held on the longest, as it was only shut down in 2024 during the Second Great Heat Wave. In other countries, like the USSR, China, and Patagonia, many people lived close enough to where they worked that commuting wasn’t an issue, and in the rare cases it was, horse-drawn carriages and rickshaws became the dominant method of transporting workers to and from their homes. 

Planes remained in use, though only for the very, very rich. Cargo planes, mainly running on a mixture of dirty liquid coal and natural gas, frequently transported important plutocrats across the USA and European Federation, respectively. In other places, such as Australia and the USSR, blimps had actually begun to see a comeback and replaced the conventional aircraft of their militaries - by 2027, only the USSR, Australia and New Zealand, Japan and the Patagonian Alliance had functional air forces. 


Two women in the Great American Dust Bowl in 2024, wearing clothing made in the early 1990s

Clothing was the most visible casualty of this massive drop of oil supplies. Much of fashion, from not just the west but around the world, relied on synthetic dyes and oil-based looms. A lack of reliable fertilizers, and worldwide famines, led to most textile plants such as cotton, linen, and hemp (which was still illegal, but this hadn’t been seriously enforced since 1989) to see reduced yields as arable land was prioritized for growing food for the now stagnant and decaying metropolises. Of course, for the very rich, they could still buy new synthetic clothing and silks, but the most expensive thing was dyes. In the 1990s, having obnoxiously colored clothing was a sign of wealth, as opposed to the Glorious Decades, when it was considered tacky to wear such obnoxious clothing. Instead, many in the 1970s and 1980s in the west wore suits and dresses made from silk and leather, while only the very poor were forced to wear these synthetic clothes made with bright, neon colors. 

This led to a massive shift in how clothing was viewed and worn. Previously, anyone could buy a new set of tuxedos for about the same price as a cheeseburger, and when a hole showed up, they’d simply buy a new one. However, after the Crash, new clothing became frighteningly expensive. Materials, both synthetic and natural, dwindled in supply and soon, everyone was thrifting. This led to a period from 1988-1991 when everyone was wearing second-hand clothing from a variety of different fashion periods. Some men even chose to wear dresses. In the 1990s, many people only bought one or two new clothes a year, usually for special occasions like weddings, graduations, or other big celebrations. But by the 2000s, many were too poor to afford new clothes at all. The Smith Administration introduced a minor program in 2003 that focused on this, as the civil unrest in the South had significantly reduced the supply of cotton and other textiles. With this program, called the American Clothing Act of 2003, granted all Americans one free set of clothing a year, and gave them up to five coupons for repairs that could be exchanged at any clothing store. This program showed some promise, but after the Kentucky-based Bowling Green Textiles Company bought up all the working textile mills, Government-Issue clothing became far more drab. This led to a brief period between 2007-2014 where clothing was made from a patchwork of different styles, textiles, and colors, referred to as “rainbow style”. Severe wear-and-tear from the elements, pollution and from being handed down to so many people led to many of these patchwork clothes to break down by the mid 2010s. On top of that, the supplies used to repair textiles were in very short supply by this point, and BGTC had monopolized the remaining supply shops. In 2015, they changed their policy so that only BGTC-manufactured clothes would be repaired at their shops, and only then if they hadn’t been modified by the owners. With the loss of dyes, this led to a dramatic decrease in variety and color for clothing, with many people now wearing simple, undyed cotton clothing that eventually became eternally stained a dull brown through years of exposure to sweat, acid rain, and pollution. 

Other countries had seen similar changes in fashion, though some of them weren’t all a result of supply shortages. In the Soviet Union, for example, all citizens were required to wear denim jackets and pants, dyed red with beets, while soldiers and police were required to wear dress uniforms when not on active duty. In Europe, people wore light shirts and shorts made from linen, to help keep their bodies cool. In much of Latin America and Africa, the death rate was high enough that there was a steady supply of second-hand clothing, but when new clothing was made, it was usually made from hemp, as many cartels grew it on the side. One exception is in the Patagonian Alliance, where many citizens wore austere but comfortable wool clothing made from Argentine goats, alpacas and llamas. In Australia and New Zealand, their main textile was actually a mix of leather and synthetic fibers from recycled materials from the Glorious Decades - as their populations were extremely small, they could afford to make and reuse the old materials from that time. In China, however, they used whatever they could find - cotton, hemp, linen, and as some reports implied, human hair. Clothing was always in short supply in China - it was not uncommon to see children as young as 10 running around naked, never having worn clothing in their life. Japan went through a similar fashion cycle as the USA, though they settled on robes and kimonos evocative of feudal Japan. 


Food, Inc Corn Farm #5634-6745N, located outside of North Platte, Nebraska. Photographed 2023

Another industry that was completely crippled by the death spiral of oil supplies was the agricultural industry. In many poorer countries in Africa, Latin America and South Asia, farming systems broke down by 1991 as the heat and humidity caused many tractors, mills, and other farming equipment to stop working. Because so many of these machines were entirely dependent on oil, they also stopped working throughout the 1990s. This forced much of the world to tend to their crops by hand - a time-consuming process that suffered the risk of heat stroke. Other, richer countries, like the Big Four, were able to keep their agricultural equipment running into the late 2000s, with research conducted into making steam and coal powered farming equipment. These jury-rigged tractors and combine harvesters carried the risk of exploding and setting the whole field on fire, and also decreased the yield of the harvest by contaminating the ground. 

But another major problem arose by the turning of the second millennium - the dramatic decrease in fertilizer production. In order to meet demand in the ever-growing cities, without fertilizers to reinvigorate the ground, many farms had to make bigger and bigger fields crammed with crops. In the 1990s, vermin such as moles, gophers, and rats were drawn to the plants, and insecticides were too expensive to produce. Some farms began building walls around their fields, and by 1995, many employed armed guards to routinely hunt for rodents. After the Great American Famine of 2000, these guards now also protected the crops from thieves and starving homeless. Without the fertilizers, the farmers had to work the ground harder and harder every year, until in the late 90s, a massive dust bowl started to form in Oklahoma, climbing all the way up to Montana by 2027. 

Industrial fertilizers were still able to be produced, of course, just in an incredibly small amount. The farms that initially bought all these fertilizers were the ones owned by Food, Inc, and because they were able to produce more food (and thus sell more), they put the other farms out of business. By 2004, Food, Inc had an effective monopoly on the synthetic fertilizer supply in the United States, but even then, other farms got by using older, more tried and true methods such as using manure. Septic waste was pumped in from cities, and while initially it showed promise, the numerous chemicals and contamination in the waste proved too toxic to the plants, causing entire fields to die out. Eventually, a method was developed to separate the human waste from the chemicals, but even then, it was extremely costly. By 2010, fertilizers were considered too costly to produce, with every country (except for Canada, the USSR, and New Zealand) switching to manure-based crop fertilization. 


Hospital in Leeds, UK. Photographed 2013

Medical technology and the production of pharmaceuticals also dramatically declined after the Shock. Disposable medicines went extinct by 1993, and many medicines such as painkillers, anesthesia and antibiotics became very costly to produce, leading to alcohol to be the most popular way of dulling pain. The decline in antibiotics also contributed to the spread of many diseases around the world. By 2005, many pharmaceutical companies had shut down, with the functional ones falling under the umbrella of Bethesda PharmTech Inc. The Sweeney Administration was noted for shifting resources away from medical and pharmaceutical production into agricultural and industrial production. Medical supplies also heavily relied on plastics, so things such as IV tubes, syringes and other tools became harder and harder to produce, which forced the medical industry to recycle them. This led to sterilizing agents to be used up faster and faster, with alcohol replacing it. It was speculated that at least three outbreaks of Hepatitis C in 1997 alone resulted from the use of improperly sanitized IV drips.  

As a combination of reduced energy supplies, the difficulty of replacing parts, and electrical malfunctions, freezers across the world became more and more costly to keep running. Organ transplant and blood transfusions became almost impossible to perform, unless the donors were local, ready and willing. The lack of reliable refrigeration also heavily affected the food supply, as places like supermarkets and warehouses rotted during brownouts. People eating improperly refrigerated food caused gastrointestinal diseases to skyrocket and yet more medical resources to be used. Across the world, refrigerators became centralized and standardized, with working refrigerators seized by the government in Europe, North America and Asia. Many countries, by 2000, had opted to use mainly non-perishible rations made out of their staple food, like Ration Beta in the USA, Ful-Tec Natural in the EF, and the ubiquitous tortillas made all across Latin America. 

Like medical supplies, food became harder and harder to package, as disposable plastic-based containers and wrappers quickly became impractical. Paper bags instead became the most common way of transporting food and medicine, with glass bottles for liquids and some food occasionally being stored in metal cans, though metal was usually prioritized for industrial repairs and military equipment. 

Most furniture also saw a massive decrease in production, with wood being prioritized for burning, and textiles being prioritized for clothing rather than cushions. Some plastic furniture was melted down in the mid 1990s in an attempt to recycle them, but nothing came of it other than extremely toxic fumes. Many apartments became austere and barren, with most people across the world simply having a bed frame, a table, one or two dressers, and two to three dirty, rickety chairs. A large industry sprung up in the USA revolving around repairing and maintaining furniture made before the Glorious Decades, and unlike the clothing industry, this one was never monopolized and thus never died out. For the extremely wealthy, it became common for people to use furniture exclusively made out of glass that was dyed in random colors - glass was much easier to produce than wood and metal. However, things such as chairs quickly fell out of favor as they tended to shatter rather violently. In China, furniture was usually made with metal, or with wicker if you were a high-ranking member of the CCP. The USSR adopted several Kazakh customs, such as sitting on the ground instead of a chair when eating, to reduce the amount of furniture produced so that wood and metal could be focused on things like buildings and weapons. 

The electronics industry was almost wiped out by the Shock. Disposable electronics became almost impossible to manufacture, as almost no country had enough oil to spare for the plastics or enough metal to make the circuitry. Most computer technology regressed, landing at a roughly 1940s-era level by 2027. Computers were big and bulky, filled with exposed wires, circuitry, and prone to overheating and exploding. CRT screens became prohibitively expensive, with a general switch to colored buttons. In the 2020s, many countries began sifting through landfills and junkyards for valuable bits of electronics from the Glorious Decades, mainly containing traces of silver, copper, gold and aluminium. By the Solar Flare, many countries had considered advanced electronic devices to be wastes of energy and resources, and as such, many electronic devices were kept as primitive (and practical) as possible, consisting of glorified on/off switches as opposed to computers. Most of the elites in the Big Four, Patagonia, Australia and New Zealand, and Japan had access to Glorious-Decades level technology, complete with LCD screens, neon tubes and hard disk drives. 

The lack of synthetic rubber also strangled the life out of many industries. Hoses, gaskets, tubes and insulators all became impractical to produce, let alone tires. A vast majority of industrial accidents between 1988-2027 are believed to have been caused by improperly maintained rubber components. In places like China and the USA, there was a drive to switch to pure metal-based tubes but that had various degrees of success and failure. The rubber components in machines made them particularly vulnerable to sabotage, a trait that the AVA and Pilgrims exploited heavily. 

So, how did the world deal with this massive drop in fossil fuels? Well, for the most part, they had to use more fossil fuels. Energy grids shifted from being oil-based to coal and natural gas based. Most supplies of oil ran out around 2005, though a few places in Australia and Canada had left over reserves all the way into 2027. Some countries used more natural gas than coal, but around 2015, most accessible deposits of natural gas had been exhausted. It was known that this would happen for some time now, and all the way back in the early 1990s, countries had began experimenting with various ways to bridge the gap and replace their pollution-spewing coal-based infrastructure. 


The Banfora Solar Farm, Greater Senegal. Taken on June 29th, 965 ASJ

A lot of the alternative energies used today, in the 30th century, were developed in Australia and New Zealand and Japan. The “Green Quartet” (nuclear, solar, wind and hydroelectric power) had their origins in those two countries, but were not able to be produced on a large scale until the Xhosan Solar Renaissance of 435 ASJ (2462 AD). 

Japan, long reliant on imports of coal and oil, saw their infrastructure rapidly decay over the course of the 1990s. An initiative to switch from personal automobiles to public transportation helped things, and energy was rationed so strictly that entire apartment blocks became bathed in darkness for days at a time. Before the Emperor’s suicide in 2006, and the “Great Departing”, the keenest minds in Japan had come together to make the most of their extremely limited resources and develop alternate ways of fueling Japan’s vehicles, infrastructure and supply lines. Of these, hydroelectricity and nuclear were for the most part, already in use - Japan had a few nuclear power plants that had been safely shut down in 1980, and all of them were up and running again by the year 2000. Japan had only 12 nuclear power plants before the TMI incident, and while they did not shut them down, they were deliberately kept on levels to safely minimize their output. The Japanese Nuclear Safety Commission heavily regulated the gradual ramping up of the reactors, but demand seemed to only increase despite the austerity measures in place by the government. In 2003, rolling blackouts caused a few of the overwhelmed and understaffed plants to be evacuated out of fears that they could explode similar to TMI. The first major nuclear plant after 1988 was built in 2004, outside of Tokyo. 

As a result of the aftermath of the 2003 heat waves, Japan’s Minister of Energy commissioned research into geothermal energy sources. Japan had actually dabbled with geothermal power stations all the way back in the 1920s, and so several prototype stations were designed. They were built in isolated rural zones (as rural as one could get in Japan), and away from population centers, and used active volcanos to heat water and used the steam to turn turbines, thus generating electricity. Ocean water was used, and the first major prototype geothermal power plant, located in Yanaizu-Nishiyama, was opened in 2005 and was capable of outputting 75 MWe. 

Geothermal was costly to create for how little energy they produced, and Japan was very careful to expand their nuclear power, as their supplies of uranium were extremely limited, though Japan was in the process of filtering radioactive particles from sea water, mixing it with filler, and creating “dirty rods” for reactors. Solar power was also considered, however the skies of Japan were far too cloudy for it to be practical. 

Hydroelectricity remained a large producer of electricity, with the Minister of Energy working with the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries to implement hydroelectric dams into the irrigation systems of Japan. In 2004, plans were drafted up to create a major hydroelectric dam outside of Tokyo to power a series of desalination plants, but construction did not start before the suicides. 

Almost all of Japan’s research was lost in the “Great Departing”, as numerous scientists, disillusioned with life, leaped off of buildings. Many nuclear power plants almost went critical, as depressed workers simply didn't show up to work. Japan’s Minister of Energy, Takumi Aoyama, struggled to form a cohesive work force with the will to live to keep the country functioning. He would end up founding the Steward Society. 

It would take a full 11 years later for Japan to rebuild itself enough to once again focus on expanding its power sources. By this time, in 2017, Japan’s energy infrastructure had been entirely dedicated to desalination and food processing, with the last of Japan’s coal, oil and natural gas used up. It was here that Japan made contact with the Union of Australia and New Zealand, and began to import not just uranium, concrete, and other materials for nuclear power plants, but experimental thin-film solar cells as well. Solar batteries were first prototyped by New Zealand in 1990, while they were advanced and upgraded by Australia in the late 2000s. It wasn’t until ANZ exchanged technology with Japan that the solar cell was finally perfected. 

Dr. Martin Kea Rutherford is credited as developing the thin-film photovoltaic solar cell, for the New Zealand Minister for Energy. The cells were initially time-consuming to produce, with the first factory producing them once every 34 hours. It was after exchanging technology with Australia that the process was significantly sped up, with efficiency peaking at just 86 minutes per cell in 2007. Australia later developed bifacial cells, allowing both sides of the panel to receive power, though this increased production time to 2 hours 42 minutes. Australia, with its vast, open deserts, proved to be the more efficient country to build solar farms in, and factories across Australia’s east coast churned out panel after panel until they ran out of silicon in 2025. 

When the Steward Society got ahold of the first shipment of ANZ solar cells, the Prefect for Technological Development created a program at the First National Academy for Technological Education devoted entirely to increasing the efficiency of the solar cells. While a lot of the smog had cleared from the skies of Japan, it was still overcast more often than not, and the production output of the solar cells was severely limited (as they had been designed to be used in crystal-clear skies above the Australian Outback). It was in 2020 that Japan was finally successful in their endeavor, as scientists at the FNATE developed the first multi-junction solar cell, allowing it to receive power from different wavelengths of light, significantly increasing the overall effectiveness of the cell, and allowing (albeit minimal) electrical collection during cloudy, overcast days and during dawn and dusk. 

These solar cells then spread all throughout Japan and the Union of Australia and New Zealand. Japan’s decaying public transportation system (just a series of trains in the largest 4 cities in the country) became entirely solar powered, though the trains were finally shut down in 2024 as the solar panels literally melted in the heat. 


Offshore Wind Farm located off the coast of Auckland, Old Zealand. Photo taken around 341 ASJ.

Another technology perfected by ANZ and Japan was wind power. Wind turbines were built along New Zealand's coast in the 1990s, but technology remained primitive and inefficient until the early 2020s. By the 2020s, New Zealand was powered by armies of solar panels, wind farms and even a few geothermal substations, in addition to a hydroelectric integrated irrigation system. The scientists in the Steward Society, upon seeing the schematic, proposed a number of changes that dramatically increased the stability of the structures, allowing for larger offshore turbines to be built. 

Australia and New Zealand and Japan were exceptions though - much of the world continued to limp along on oil, then natural gas, then coal, becoming dirtier every year. In places like Africa, Latin America, and the former middle east, many simply burned whatever was on hand to create steam to power ancient, Victorian-era machinery like boilers and steam engines. A few countries in these regions, such as Brazil and Mexico, experimented in hydroelectricity and solar power, respectively, but these projects never left the prototyping stage due to the political instability plaguing their nations. 

Nuclear power plants were built across many countries, however these “dirty reactors” were, for the most part, a rushed construction more focused on supplying power than the safety of the workers inside them or those living nearby. The only countries that managed to perfect nuclear energy were the USSR and Australia, with the USSR (after many, many attempts) developing nuclear powered train engines by 2010, though they were incredibly crude and bulky. These advanced nuclear power plants eventually migrated to the Nordic Union, Poland, and East Germany, though they remained large and bulky, incapable of outputting a fraction of the MWe that a Soviet, Australian or Patagonian reactor. Recently uncovered evidence found during the Sinai Expedition of 817 ASJ has pointed to the ancient nation of Israel as extensively utilizing nuclear power for their Kibbutz bunkers. Israel’s nuclear power plants were in the middle - they weren’t as advanced as those in Europe or Patagonia, but they weren’t as crude as the experimental ones built in North America and Australia. Of the 100+ Israeli bunkers discovered, more than half of them have become saturated with radiation, now pristine portals into the past much like the ancient ruins of Pompeii once were. 

In many cases, once a country had run out of oil, they switched to coal. Ironically, in the countries most vulnerable to this (mainly in Africa) their transportation and infrastructure weren't entirely reliant on petroleum and oil, so their supply lines remained relatively intact, but severe famines and resource shortages devastated entire economies. A few ancient African electrical infrastructures remain intact, if non-functional, giving archaeologists a look into the engineering of the past. 


The Hoof-Er Dam, completed sometime before the Black Ages (many historians agree around 1936). Destroyed in 254 ASJ in a battle between the New Cascadian Republic and the Legion of Canaan. 

Hydropower was a double edged sword in many cases - dams could provide ludicrous amounts of energy, with the ancient Guri Dam (completed in 1978) in what was once Venezuela producing over 10,000 MWe. However, chronic drought cycles and irrigation demands usually forced hydroelectric dams to be decommissioned. Other times, governments believed that the energy supplied from them outweighed the fact that a few thousand people would starve to death. Ancient China is known for building a vast majority of such dams, including the Three Gorges and Ertan Dams, during the early 2000s. This caused already strained water supplies to be diverted from their normal water cycle, and is thought to be one of the contributors to the mass die-off of vegetation in mainland China in the Black Ages. 

The European Federation was also known for over-utilizing hydroelectric dams in the 1990s, leading to mass famines and drought cycles to persist well into the 22nd century. A majority of their dams were also built in the now flooded region known as the “Low Countries”, leading to 90% of their hydroelectric power stations to be underwater by the 2020s. The European Federation was initially a leader in alternate energies in the immediate aftermath of the Shock, as numerous prototype solar farms, wind farms, hydroelectric dams and nuclear power plants were built along the former regions of Iberia, France, and Italy. The European people were quite rowdy though, used to the instant gratification of the Glorious Decades, and did not take the policy of austerity well. Far-left and Far-right terrorism hampered the development of many solar farms, and a nuclear accident outside of Brussels in 2011 led to all of their nuclear power plants to be decommissioned. Like the UK, the coal miners and their unions forced many governments to stay on the path of fossil fuels, with coal becoming the dominant source of power in the EF and UK by 2015. 

The only exception to this was the state of Denmark (now part of the Kingdom of Norway), as their wind and hydroelectric farms were not only efficient, but were able to be used on ocean water instead of freshwater rivers usually reserved for irrigation. Because of this, wind and hydroelectric power were allowed to thrive and evolve over time, with the UK, Ireland, and Nordic Union all receiving prototype plants during their occupations by Brussels. In the 2010s, these technologies were replicated around Europe, and now the Irish Isles are powered by vast, off-shore wind farms. The Nordic Union leaned a bit more towards nuclear power though, however it was merely a shield to develop nuclear weapons that they could use to deter the Lion of Brussels and the Bear of Moscow from invading them again. 

East Germany (now the Holy Empire of Europa) managed to integrate tiny hydroelectric dams into their irrigation canals and vertical step farms, much like how Japan and ANZ integrated into their farms and cities, though East Germany’s were far less efficient and generated only a fraction of their Pacific counterparts. Still, East Germany is notable as the only country in Europe to notably integrate hydroelectric power into their energy grid and not result in major droughts due to the mismanagement of rivers and lakes. 

Poland on the other hand, much like its history in the Black Ages, was a mixed bag. They used a little bit of everything. Mining unions kept coal in circulation, while small-scale hydroelectric dams caused drought, but not enough to be a concern to Kowalski. Stolen nuclear research from the Soviets allowed for some limited production, and a few wind farms were built in fields too polluted to grow crops in. 

The United States ended up being hit the hardest when it came to trying to dig their way out of reliance on fossil fuels. Hydroelectric dams in the Southwest contributed to the rapidly expanding desert, while geothermal power proved to be too inefficient to supply America’s gargantuan energy needs. The skies above America remained eternally smoggy, so solar was out of the question. Corn-based ethanol was prototyped in the early 2000s, but the Smith Administration deemed it more important to use that corn to feed the growing number of starving unemployed. Some nuclear power plants were recommissioned in the northwest (now the Cascadian Confederacy in the present day), and a few dams were built along the Great Lakes, but America greedily gobbled up coal like their livelihood depended upon it - which, for the most part, it did. 


Nuclear power plant located in New Tokyo (formerly Yelizovo), Japan

In the present day, fossil fuels are very, very rarely used, mainly only a novelty or by researchers studying pre-Great Death technology. Boiling polluted water for environmental purification is a large source of energy in the reconstruction and geoengineering programs in Africa and Latin America. Research into heat-resistant solar farms are being conducted, with a Xhosan company hoping to turn the entire Middle East into a massive solar farm by the end of the 30th Century. 

Appendix: The Last Comforts, Part 1

From “The Restaurant at the End of the World”, by Tali Iqaluppik-Larocque, Tu Nedhé University Press. 3rd edition, printed 970 ASJ 

https://youtu.be/I5banQi2LuM?si=dzKNLYqM4M6bLQoi 
Introduction 

For many of us, food and cuisine is a glue that keeps our lives, our families, our cultures and sometimes even our nations together. What we eat, how we eat it, and whom with, speaks volumes about a society’s values and rituals. This has been the way since time immemorial. The mythic Romans had Saturnalia, which emphasized over-indulgence through a feast of nuts, cheese and pork. A thousand years ago, as late as the mid Black Ages, the ancient Americans had Thanksgiving, in which a huge turkey was to be roasted up and eaten, savagely. And yet, this savagery united those in the ancient American states, with the President even pardoning his meal. As of today, many societies around the world hold meals to be a sacred part of life. Food not only nourishes us and allows us to live another day, but it also is a time for us to come together with those close to us and share the highlights of the day, their joys, their sorrows. To eat alone is to be selfish, to not share these life-giving gifts with loved ones. From the oppressive Reformed Empire of American Alaska to the egalitarian United Antarctican States, from the poorest vagrant to the richest solar lord, eating is one of the many things that unites us as humans, just like drinking, breathing, and dying. 

During the Black Ages, after the Crash of ‘88 and The Shock, those around the dying world clung desperately to the last comforts in their lives, now empty of purpose and entertainment. But over time, governments tried harder and harder to feed their people or risked dying themselves in a violent revolution. Nourishing meals dwindled and dwindled, until it was said that “there was nothing to drink but the salt of the sea and nothing to eat but the lead of the bullets fired at you”. The darkest years in human history can be traced to these years, where after decades of reckless overindulgence, it finally came crashing down, and humanity began to eat itself to ward off starvation. 

Was it worth it? I’ll let you decide. 
Food, Inc’s E-Z Steak Dinner
Produced: 1990-2004, -2065 (alleged) 
Weight: 124g 
Calories: 298 (3g protein) 

Before Food, Inc, dominated the food industry (and later the government) of the United States, in their early days they tried to invoke nostalgia for the Glorious Decades with this staple meal of the 1990s. Made in the style of TV Dinners popular in the 1960s-1980s, the product consisted of four components. 

First was a tiny 25 gram vegan steak, made with soy beans, corn, mushrooms, and wheat. The steak supposedly was meant to imitate the texture and taste of beef steaks, though most of the public disagreed with this. The steak, while being considered tasty and relatively nutritious, was described as rubbery and stringy. Served alongside the steak was a serving of roughly 98 grams of mashed potatoes and green beans. The mashed potatoes were usually creamy, but rather bland, and reminded many of the texture and feel of ice cream (a popular sweet food during the late Golden Age and early Black Ages). The green beans were described as losing their color as the years dragged on, with them being “barely green” by 1997. Lastly, the final part of the product was a tiny dollop of a dark brown, syrupy sauce. Flavored with thin flakes of peppers and spices, the sauce was usually sauteed with the steak or drizzled over the mashed potatoes. 

The product remained extensively popular throughout the Red Decades, with the poor and unemployed being given government-subsidized shipments of the product from the Universal Food Ration. Many chose to eat the steak with a side of government cheese and other dairy products in the early half of the Red Decades, before the Great American Dustbowl began to form. Initially, in the immediate aftermath of the Shock, some families ran into issues trying to keep the product properly refrigerated until consumption. During the National Refrigeration Consolidation Plan of 1996, when the American government started to centralize working refrigerators to maximize food preservation, many families started the practice of immediately cooking the product upon receiving it. After finishing the meal, it was common practice in the 1990s to dip the tray into a pot of boiling water and mix it with flour and other grains to make a gruel that sometimes, vaguely, tasted like the E-Z steak. 

After the start of the Second Civil War and the Great American Famine of 2000-2005, Food, Inc, had decided that the E-Z Steak was no longer worth making. A vast majority of their ingredients were grown in the now war-torn Deep South, and keeping the product refrigerated long enough to make it to distributors was becoming increasingly difficult. This caused a shift towards making food products non-perishable, long lasting, and as efficient as possible.
Food, Inc’s Ration Alpha
Produced: 2003-2026, -2098 (alleged)
Weight: 450g (earliest record) - 100g (latest record)
Calories: 800 calories - 250 calories, 3 g - <1 g protein

At first, Ration Alpha was a veritable feast of nutrition. Designed with efficiency, nutrition, and shelf-life in mind, the first versions of Ration Alpha boasted an even greater calorie count than the E-Z steak. This of course came at the cost of taste and texture. The earliest ones, made during the Smith Administration, were a chunky loaf of 11 vegetables and grains, some of which are now extinct. Wheat flour was used as the base, and bits of corn, rice, beets, potatoes, and salt and garlic for taste. 

As time went on though, various plants were deliberately not grown due the poor ratio of calories to growing space (and thus lower profits). Ingredient after ingredient was cut, until it was a small, thin bun of wheat, corn and potatoes, with a sprinkle of sea salt for flavor. In 2013, it was decided that this was still not efficient enough, and the gruel was baked into a cracker rather than a loaf. This allowed for more of it to be stored at once, and was also easier for measuring rations. Before water rationing was widespread, many housewives would grind up these rations and use them to bake a sort of mushy pseudo-bread, by mixing it with water and leaving it out to dry on a reflective metal surface during a heat wave. 

Ration Alpha remained the most nutritious government-issued ration in the United States for quite some time, although, for a brief stint in 2015-2016, this was not the case. Ration Alpha was eventually made only for government officials and collaborators in the 2020s, as important vegetable samples were shipped off to Alaska and Hawai’i. 
Food, Inc’s Ration Beta
Produced: 2004-2022, -2065 (Alleged)
Weight: 300g (earliest record) - 50g (latest record)
Calories: 740 calories - 110 calories, 5 g - <1 g protein 

Ration Beta was born out of the trend of recycling E-Z steak trays to make a sort of soup. The product, being a block of dried vegetables held together by wheat, could be eaten raw, but it was intended to be dropped in a pot of boiling water and stirred into a (sometimes) flavorful soup. In the early days, many types of vegetables were used to add flavor, like carrots, beans, peas, onions, tomatoes, and garlic. By the 2010s, though, it had been reduced to just faded, withered tomatoes and beets. 

In the 2020s, due to the widespread water rationing, Ration Beta was completely discontinued as it was viewed as too inefficient for the chronic droughts facing the world. Flavor was no longer a concern, as the very rich could get their own properly seasoned and flavorful foods, and to many in the streets, they had long forgotten the taste of anything other than salt, smoke, and sadness. 
Food, Inc’s Ration Gamma
Produced: 2008-2014, -2100 (Alleged)
Weight: 150g
Calories: 890 calories, 13-19g protein (true number unknown)

Gamma was created out of brutal efficiency and widespread loss of arable land. Reports of protein deficiency had become widespread, and government rations of peanut butter were running dry. Peanuts went extinct in the USA in 2015, actually - one of the first casualties of the Great Heat Wave. Labor was the one resource the USA wasn’t running out of any time soon, but still, workers needed to eat, and they needed to eat protein to remain efficient workers. Employers couldn’t just fire them: if everyone was living off government handouts by this point, then it wouldn’t matter what city the workers came from - Seattle to New York, everyone was running out of protein. Meat and dairy could not feasibly feed the entire population, let alone a single state, so the scientists in the recently emancipated Food, Inc (which was made state owned from 1995-2007) began to wonder how to fill the protein deficit. 

CEO and future President of the United States, Richard Shelby Holden, proposed an ingenious, if desperate measure to feed the protein requirements of the nation. Vegetable protein was a bit too slow to grow, and many crops did not do well in the increasing aridity. Instead, he proposed, using more exotic sources of nutrition - such as jellyfish blooms, junk fish, crickets, and cockroaches. This allowed more nutritious fish to be saved for the elites, for those who could actually buy them, and the poor could eat whatever sources of protein they could get. It’s not like they could tell the difference between what an insect tasted like and a prime rib steak. (well, maybe they could, but everyone was too hungry to complain). 

Food, Inc bankrolled the “Great Pest Exterminations” of 2008-2011, and insects eating crops were considered a boon instead of a curse. They were free protein, after all. Worms, slugs, ants, flies and crickets were all collected from the baking farms. In the north, outside of major industrial districts like Chicago, the Twin Cities, and Detroit, old warehouses were converted into fly farms, using trash and human waste as a culture. Residents were told it was a recycling center, which it technically was, but for those who worked there, their silence was bought with Ration Alpha. For those who tried to speak, they vanished into the night, and all of their testimonies were conveniently discredited. 

Jellyfish blooms were a bit more tricky to get back to the states intact, but made for a great filler. Products with blooms ended up having a sort of spongey, rubbery feel to them, and helped mask the chitinous, crunchy texture of ground up bugs. 

Of course, using human waste to grow swarms of flies and grinding up radioactive cockroaches caused some health issues. Reports of infertility began to rise, and some people even lost hair. This was all swept underneath the rug though, and with suicide being legalized nationwide, that problem eventually took care of itself. 
Food, Inc’s Ration Delta
Produced: 2014-2016
Weight: 100g
Calories: 460 calories, 2g - <1g protein 

Using insects for protein was running into problems, as this new livestock was quickly causing diseases to spread. It was also using way too much arable (ish) land for how little it produced. Jellyfish were going extinct, with the last batch of them being brought in before the end of 2013. Something had to be done, and quick. 

The cities had been picked clean of insects, rats, and other animals. The only plants that could grow in places outside Michigan and Alaska were extremely scrawny stalks of corn, withered tomatoes, shriveled lettuce, tiny potatoes, and diseased wheat. The country was running out of options. No matter how efficiently the land was farmed, no matter how thinly the ration was cut down, there still wasn’t enough food to feed the country. 

The government once again turned to unorthodox sources of nutrition. Mold was scraped from pipes, cacti were ripped from the ground and shredded into a stringy, spiny paste, and boats began to sift algae and krill from the gray oceans. Seaweed was also collected and used as a filler. 

Every single one of these sources ended up being not only unprofitable, but grossly inefficient for the amount of protein they produced. Mold could not be grown fast enough to be farmed, cacti only grew in the lethally hot southwest, and the algae, while relatively nutritious, was extremely expensive to collect, requiring advanced nets that were nearly impossible to make in the energy-strapped economy. 

Ration Delta was made in an extremely limited number. Estimates range between 1-4 million units of the ration were produced. The product, consisting of a thin, bubbly cracker pocked with green and gray spots, was notoriously hated for the bland, crunchy taste and the weird smell the product gave off. 
Food, Inc’s Ration Omega
Produced: 2014-2027
Weight: 400-100g (reports are inconsistent) 
Calories: [REDACTED]

Omega, given the jump in letters in the Greek Alphabet, was meant to be an absolute last resort, for the poorest of the poor without any hope for something better. Originally stemming from the idea of using human corpses as fertilizer, the heartless elites in the highest echelons of corporate and government society decided to skip the fertilizer bit, and just use human bodies. Not only was it practical, it was extremely cost effective. 

Only the highest ranked members of the US Government and the Food, Inc Board were told of the true nature of the frequently advertised, yet mysteriously absent, “Plutus Fertiziler”. The public was told that wondrous breakthroughs in fertilizers, crop rotation and farming practices had created a massive surplus of crops, and that protein deficiencies were a thing of the past. 

Very few made the connection between the rise of Ration Omega in parallel to the numerous disappearances that began to plague the cities of America. Criminals were never seen again, vanishing into the vast penal farms, never to be seen again. And no one made the realization that those in power never, ever got Ration Omega - it was always the poorest of the poor who were given the ration. It’s also a good thing that farms and ration factories became entirely staffed by convicts, as well - after they had “served their sentence” they were usually released… into a meat grinder. 

It was, in the end, a stop gap measure. Human civilization was on the brink of collapse. The War on Cold had been won, and the heat was rising. Everyone - from the most dignified ambassadors to the lowliest of hobos - was living on borrowed time. It was not a question of if, but when, everything came crashing down. And Ration Omega bought the government time. In those hopeful years of 2014 and 2015, they still believed they could turn things around and a magical miracle food was just around the corner. But it was quickly realized that if America was to survive, many must be left behind. 

So, the main source of protein was human flesh: the most expedient, cost-effective ingredient in the ration. What else was in it? Basically anything that was even vaguely edible. Weeds, moss, fungus, cacti, and even tree bark. If it was organic, it was thrown in with the greenish slop. Kudzu vine was the most prominent of these, being the only plant that reliably grew in the ever-expanding dust bowl. And after the lands were stripped clean of all vegetation, the lands turned to dust. By 2017, cities had been scraped clean of moss, rats were considered extinct, and bugs were a now mythical pest. 

As it turns out, recycling the dead for food over and over again is not sustainable at all. By the mid 2020s, severe protein deficiencies and even reports of prion diseases began to show the government just how bad things had gotten. People weren’t dying fast enough, and those that would become Ration Omega had been eating a diet of nothing but recycled humans for years. It was estimated that by 2028, the process would become so inefficient that it would take more calories digesting the ration than it would give the person who consumed it. 

It is unknown what the government had planned if the United States had lasted that long. 
FulTec Unity Bar
Produced: 2004-2026
Weight: 150g - 120g
Calories: 600 calories - 350 calories, 22g - 19g protein

It was the aftermath of the Red Summer and the Crackdown. Agriculture, devastated by the insane summer heat, riots and the general strike, had taken a severe blow and was only slowly recovering. The staple meals that Europeans had lived off of throughout the 90s and early 00s were no longer sustainable to create; there was simply not enough agriculture for it. The Federation delegated FulTec the task of feeding the majority of the European people, their first product was devised with cooperation from the European Federation, a “wonder ration” specially made to unite the divided states and hostile people of the Federation together and hopefully keep them from rioting in the streets.

With the repeal of anti-monopoly and anti-corporate laws in the late 90s by the federal government, FulTec had grown immensely in power and dominated over the other, more localised foodstuffs companies established across the Federation. Following the Red Summer, FulTec had become the Federation’s sole private food supplier, and they were intimately linked with the European government, helped by them contributing their resources to stop the general strike of 2003. “Natural” food was still available in the winter but in the summer FulTec was dominant, and as the summers became longer and winters warmer they became even more dominant, leading to them becoming the Federation’s single food supplier by 2010.

The Unity Bar was a granola bar, meant to be synthesis of every country in the Federation and condensed into a tiny block that would ideally outlast any heatwave. Early iterations of the bar actually lived up to its name, and the extra workers required to harvest the ingredients did actually create a few million jobs. 

What the government did not disclose was the extremely high mortality rate on those farms. 

The very first iteration of the Unity Bar, like Siliao, was actually quite healthy and nutritious for its size. It was considered wasteful to (attempt to) create the vast variety of products produced in the Glorious Decades, so instead, Europe’s agricultural resources were consolidated into a clean, tightly packed ration. It also used ingredients from each of the ten constituent countries (despite the centralisation), further fostering an idea of European Unity. Each of the ten nations contributed one major ingredient in the first version of Unity, which was then shipped to various FulTec plants across the country. Here is what was sourced from each country. 

Italy: Durum wheat
Spain: Dates (dried and pulped)
Portugal: Figs (dried and pulped) 
France: Apples (dried and pulped) 
West Germany: Plums (dried and pulped) 
Belgium: Pears (dried and pulped) 
Netherlands: Barley wheat
Denmark: Rapeseed oil
Austria: Soybean butter
Luxembourg: Grape raisins

The ingredients were mashed together to create a sort of trail mix, and then held together with wheat flour. According to advertisements, the bars were soaked in the juices of the drained fruits, but evidence of this has never been found. 

What the technicians did not take into account was the ever-expanding dustbowl and desertification in Italy and Iberia. Many fruits became unable to be grown in large enough amounts, and durum wheat had the strange habit of catching on fire. The flooding of the Netherlands and saltwater inundation in Denmark caused vast fields of barley and rapeseed to become barren and no longer capable of producing crops due to the soil pollution.

The recipe was changed, and while it remained relatively nutritious, it was far less flavorful. The farms of France, Belgium, Austria and Germany became overworked and crowded, growing the majority of the oats, wheat, barley, and soybeans in the Federation. Grape production focused solely on creating wines, as the alcohol was needed “for medical purposes”. Plums and apples were still used and produced for the ration, though in increasingly small numbers. By 2021, it was estimated that every Unity bar produced only contained less than 1 gram of combined fruits. 

While it started as a cheap, low-cost ration for the poorest, it eventually became the premium ration for government officials, soldiers, and high-level collaborators in federation satellite states, like Ireland, the UK, and the Nordic Union. And yet, even this shallow, calorie-dense granola bar was still far better than FulTec’s later products.
FulTec Marine
Produced: 2007-2012
Weight: 110g - 80g
Calories: 400 calories - 270 calories, 28g - 6g protein

Despite the success of the Unity Bar and decent performance of their other products, FulTec still struggled throughout the remainder of the 2000s, driven by the colossal natural disasters that occurred such as the flooding of the Netherlands and abandonment of Iberia and Sicily. They were only kept afloat by government support, and the Board of Executives looked around the world for inspiration. In the late 2000s, giant American boats swept across the Northern Atlantic, drawing massive hauls of ‘something’. But that ‘something’ could not be fish, as hardly any remained in the oceans. After some research and consultation with scientists, FulTec came to the conclusion that they could only be jellyfish, and found an idea for a new product, FulTec Marine.

The product would mix mainly crushed jellyfish bloom alongside some nuts, fruit and insects to create a bar smaller than Unity but one easier to mass-produce and feed the poor with. It would have a very rubbery and gelatinous texture, which testers described as “off-putting”, but it was put on the market in late 2007 anyway.

Surprisingly to the company, the product was initially a large success, with people preferring its new texture to the tough, stale one of their other products. It quickly grew in the market and fed a plurality of the populace from 2007-09. However, FulTec had made a large miscalculation, believing the jellyfish blooms were larger than they were and that they would be the main ingredient of FulTec’s Ration Gamma, despite their intelligence in Food, Inc. suggesting the opposite. Jellyfish blooms near European waters soon began collapsing at calamitous rates, and the answer became obvious to all of FulTec.

By 2009 the ration became far too costly to make, and it’s presence on the market dropped in proportion. It could not afford to be reduced in size; it was already small enough, and so it was simply withdrawn from the market over time, creating a large dent in FulTec’s ailing finances. It was taken off the market fully in 2012, as the last jellyfish blooms were collected by Europe, America following a year later.
FulTec Natural
Produced: 2009-2021
Weight: 120g - 90g
Calories: 450 calories - 290 calories, 39g - 11g protein

Soybeans, the main protein of the Unity Bar, became increasingly harder to grow in large enough numbers. Heatwaves and drought had caused the remaining crops to become smaller and more sickly every year. In 2009, just five years after the Unity Bar’s debut, it was deemed no longer a priority to grow soybeans - instead, an alternative source of protein was to be found. 

Corporate espionage and spies embedded in the United States had uncovered the American government’s plans for using ground up insects as the new protein source for their rations. FulTec, dissatisfied with the increasing production costs of soy, decided to explore other, more similar avenues. Locusts and mealworms, common pests of the dying French farms, became sought-after sources of protein. Workers were told they were disposing of them, but a few workers caught on. They were never seen again. 

The seas around Europe had long since stopped producing fish in any meaningful number, and instead, boats were sent to canvas the coasts of the Federation for plants such as duckweed, seaweed, and other materials. Lastly, the few swamps and wetlands of Germany, France, and Denmark were combed for collections of muck and algae. Again, workers were simply told that they were clearing the way for more farmland or harvesting water for irrigation, not that they were actually collecting the ingredients for Europe's next meal. 

FulTec Natural was produced to look exactly like the grain-heavy Unity bar on the outside. In reality, it only used a minimal amount of oats, grains and barley. Inside of it was the main course: a thick, nougat-like filling made of powdered bugs, dehydrated duckweed, and a thin, runny paste derived from algae. Small amounts of salt were added to mask the taste of the algae.

The product, according to reports, felt “distinctively un-natural” in the mouth, and did not taste particularly pleasant, the salt mixing poorly with the other products creating a nasty flavour, however it was good enough that Europeans did not actively avoid the ration (unlike some others). Natural was cheaper to produce than most of FulTec’s other products and had significantly enhanced nutritional benefits, making it an instant hit among the people and FulTec’s executives, many believing it was the “wonder ration” they had for so long been trying to achieve. By 2010 it was being mass-produced and became by far FulTec’s dominant product. 74% of FulTec’s sales in May 2013 were Natural. Other products such as Marine and the Unity Bar were pushed out of the market. For a time, some thought FulTec had solved the hunger crisis.

However, with the endlessly rising temperatures, Natural was never going to be sustainable. Production remained shaky at best, even at its peak, and duckweed, seaweed, and insects were all gathered in amounts that were never consistent. Signs of decline in its production were being observed before, but the Great Heatwave of 2015 dealt a killing blow to the product, with repeated mass deaths of insects and disappearances of duckweed and seaweed being common. The product quickly became incredibly costly to create, and drastic measures were being made to cut their costs and avoid fully transitioning to their last resort. In 2015, crickets were replaced with fly larvae, and in 2017, ocean materials stopped being collected. Algae remained the only option that was (marginally) viable, but that required water, a resource in increasingly short supply. In 2021, it was decided that even that was no longer worth the production cost, and FulTec Natural was permanently shelved, to be replaced with something vastly worse and inhumane in its stead.
FulTec Plenty
Produced: 2013-2027
Weight: 200g - 180g
Calories: [REDACTED] 

By the early 2010s, FulTec’s executives knew that the nation and the world was doomed; after all, it was what their climate data showed. Natural would not last, none of their products would, what little existed to create “food” was rapidly disappearing. They were running out of options, and turned to increasingly desperate ideas to feed the population of Europe in the long-term and buy themselves some time to escape before the starving populace turned on them and killed them all.

The idea of using people as food was first proposed sometime in the late 2000s as a joke, a last, last, unthinkable resort for if shit really hit the fan. The idea was aptly titled “Project Unthinkable” and shelved until in 2012 FulTec revisited it and began to take the plan slightly more seriously. Before long, it was taken completely seriously and plans for “FulTec Plenty” began to be devised. FulTec had finally done the unthinkable, perhaps some years earlier than expected.

FulTec Plenty, much like Ration Omega, was created as a way of minimizing production costs while also reducing the population of “deviant” Europeans, considered basically anyone terminally ill, politically ambitious, violent or simply at the wrong place at the wrong time. Where FulTec diverged from Food, Inc was their inhumane ruthlessness when it came to eliminating their opponents. Before the Great Heatwave, the fact that FulTec Plenty was edible (which is a stretch) was secondary to its primary purpose, which was helping to eliminate opposition to the state. It was prototyped in the UK, where in the summer of 2012 rioters in Brixton were carted off to an industrial waste disposal facility and “disposed of”. Reports of stolen soybeans in the area made one particularly cruel Jerry (many Brits called the occupiers and collaborators Jerry despite many of them being from Belgium) petition to use this "perfectly good protein” to reduce costs. Throughout 2012, protesters and vigilantes unknowingly volunteered to help FulTec test just how far they could recycle a human body. 

Another aspect of the project was “total agricultural denial” in occupied states. Outside of designated, FulTec operated farms, in high-resistance areas (mainly the south of France and lots of Italy) the countryside was combed of all organic natural resources. Larger bushes and trees that weren’t burned by wildfires were sent back to Belgium to be processed into lumber, but much of the remaining vegetation was collected and dumped into a vat, where it was mixed with ground up fungi. In theory, it would make all hostile areas incapable of supporting a populace strong enough to fight back. 

The identity of FulTec Plenty was a closely guarded secret, known only by FulTec’s executives, the workers operating on the process, and the heads of the federal government. FulTec in 2012 presented it to the government as a way of disposing of resistance and opposition, calculating correctly it would be the most likely way to convince them to adopt the product. In 2013 it was introduced to the markets, advertised as a variant of Natural but cheaper and containing more protein. The product sold well, with occasional complaints regarding the taste, but they were less than the many complaints about Natural from testers. After reaching above 1 in 5 of sold foodstuffs, however, the price suddenly spiked; they were running out of people to use. There were only so many criminals and protestors on the streets, after all. Plenty stayed around the 20% mark for a while, being sold as a more expensive but nutritious variant of Natural, until 2015 arrived and the status quo crumbled into dust.

The mass dieoff of almost all of Natural’s ingredients, especially insects, meant that it’s production costs, and therefore its price, spiked suddenly and never returned. Natural had become unsustainable to create, at least in its current form, and the primary nourishment of the vast majority of Europeans had vanished from them over a few weeks. If a replacement was not found, there would almost certainly be an uprising and the end of the Federation.

The price of FulTec Plenty, however, had conveniently stayed the same throughout the Heatwave despite supposedly using the same ingredients as Natural. Being too malnourished and exhausted to critically think about it, people quickly moved onto the product and sales exploded uncontrollably. The government had to expand production quickly, and thus introduced reforms designed to do just that. All prisoners and people convicted of crimes would be killed and sent to processing, and all recorded deaths in general would be processed for Plenty. The price spiked, but Plenty remained affordable for lots of the European populace, and with the help of a few subsidies, it quickly and utterly dominated the foodstuffs market following the Heatwave. People had become the staple food of Europe.

Of course, not everyone was malnourished, and some people had many sources of intelligence from within the Federation’s government. The LPUs ——

Eventually, the supply of corpses from the Heatwave ran out, and Plenty’s price spiked yet again. It had become the only way the government (which by this point had [REDACTED]) was able to reliably feed its people and stop them from rebelling, and so more measures had to be taken. The definition of subversive expanded, but that was still not enough, and the new, sadistic leadership of FulTec, completely disconnected from the person’s daily life, came up with measures designed to keep Plenty existing until “global civilisation collapses”. The measures were devised in 2017 and put into action the following year and would change the society and fabric of Western Europe for centuries to come.

Lots of rural Europe was dead, with everyone aside from the elderly having moved from there to the cities. Most remaining rural towns were near FulTec’s farms and exclusively for workers there. The remaining rural towns were considered a burden on the state by FulTec, and so were promptly wiped off the map beginning 2018. Squads were sent to them to round up and kill all people there, who were processed for Plenty. The towns would be destroyed and materials repurposed for the cities. This form of “rural genocide” was quiet, hardly anyone had connection with these places anymore and whoever knew was silenced. The other major measure involved the movement of internal refugees within the Federation, which had already caused serious instability before. Squads would patrol common routes for the refugees, round groups of them up, and again, shoot them. With their sheer number it would not make a massive dent in their number, but it was still statistically, and far more morally, significant. The measures worked in that they massively increased the number of bodies available for Plenty and brought down its price, and they also worked in transforming the European Federation into a nakedly genocidal terror-state, an organ of totalitarianism that was contrarily also in anarchy in many of its cities, a “state” where law was long-dead and the innocent were prosecuted instead of the guilty. In fact, it could no longer truly be called a state past 2018, or even arguably past 2013, or 2003.

These measures, of course, were not fully successful. People escaped, and told these stories to others in the cities if they could even get there, however these gained little traction. Distrust of the government was already universal despite unanimous consumption of their products, and these “rumours” gave the Federation another excuse to further ramp up things, sending “anti-terrorism” squads into the major cities and placing stricter and stricter rules on them, including strict curfews and martial law. The Federation became increasingly concentrated around its major megacities, ideally making it easier to be controlled and surveilled, although [REDACTED]
