October 23, 2033 - Richard Holden dies in a bunker in Antarctica 
April 2035 - The last Qatifists die out

The Great Silence (2035-2127)
Spring 2040 - The survivors start surveying the land in Antarctica
Mid 2051: Resettlement projects in the mainland begin
2060-2080: Expeditions into the ruined mainland. 
January 1, 2070 - The Fujairah enclave is wiped out
2086: Resettlement of New York.
2087: The USSR’s remnants make contact with the Antarctic expedition. Small survivor enclaves in the Arctic Circle and parts of the southern tip of South America + Australia are found. Wars break out between the Survivors, who have not forgotten the sins of the past and seek to enact a bloody war of revenge, and the Expeditioners, who ironically are quite peaceful and share their bounty with the survivors. Decades of living in cramped bunkers and never knowing if resettlement is even possible has created a sense of intense community and selflessness.
2088 - The last oil fires in the Middle East finally stop burning
2092: The Survivors and Expeditioners make peace, and the various remnants of the governments start to rebuild their nations.
January 1, 2105: The Great Fire. Somehow, (haven’t decided yet), the vast repository of knowledge that the scientists prepared in the 2020s gets destroyed. Humanity never recovers.
2100: The new societies start to forget their past sins and become more hedonistic, however they can never get too lazy as the amount of minerals left and the small amount of arable land keeps humanity very small (probably 1 million at most)
January 1, 2122 - Rodger Richard Holden’s fast forward happens

The Second Dark Age (2127-2462)

The Second Renaissance (2462-3000)

I’m pretty much done with the chapter, but if you’re curious about the BtS lore I’ve kept all my notes here

USSR General
Power behind the Throne: Chief Director Sergei Savateev of the KGB, and Ivan Voronin, the “New Generalissimo” and Supreme Marshal of the Soviet Union. General Secretary is Gennady Yanayev from 1982-1997. He is followed by Constantin Rutskoy from 1997-2010. During the Shadow Civil War, Savateev pits Voronin and Rutskoy against each other and convinces Voronin to become dictator. 
Gulags Re-Opened for political dissidents (Vorkuta Coal basin makes sense when you don’t spend 90% of time throwing snow off roads)
Siberia is actually somewhat hospitable, and nobody cares about the disease deaths - just send in more convicts to replace the ones who die
KGB Returns in full force, real power behind the throne
Satellites are getting rowdy, the old junta geezers who took power in Satellite States in the 90s (Think OTL Polish Martial Law) are getting old and senile and there’s nobody to replace them
Lake Baikal drained to do irrigation, beforehand there were jokes about how it constantly caught fire.
In the 80s, the warsaw pact countries start trading amongst themselves
The USSR claims that their prosperity comes from their strict adherence to Marxism-Leninism, with even a resurgence of Stalinism. China turned to capitalism and doomed the world. 
The USSR doesn’t eat their dead but they do use them for fertilizer in Siberia. 
State of the outer republics/countries they annex in the 90s
KGB focuses on keeping European Russia in check. 
Eastern Europe is pretty much left to fend for itself in the 2000s. 
In the 2020s, Green Siberia is worked to the bone to provide for European Russia. 
Due to extensive industrialisation the demographic boom at the beginning of Food, Inc era stopped mostly because every sudden industrialisation of any agrarian country can lead to sudden demographic changes
In the 1990s, the USSR forcibly makes the rest of Europe not in the EU join the Warsaw Pact
Finland tries to resist, gets overwhelmed by massive Soviet hordes. EU and D.C. rattle sabers but do nothing due to deteriorating situation at home. Scandinavia and other neutral states pay lip service to Warsaw Pact but in reality remain basically independent. After the Reds Withdraw the Warsaw Pact States (Now a mix of Communist Dictatorships, Military Juntas that shed off all pretense of Communism while keeping the old elite, and Nationalist Regimes that took charge after killing and eating their nomenklaturas) decide it’s better to hand together than hang separately and remain in a very clenched-teeth alliance, trying to toe the line between Brussels and Moscow. 
Multiple failed uprisings occur in the 80s - notable ones are in 1982, 1984 and 1987. These insurrections give the KGB ammunition to impose far more draconian laws. 
USSR Shadow Civil War - internal restructuring of administrative regions. The “Core Republics” are resettled while the rest of the USSR starts dying off in 2010

USSR - As a Whole 
1969 - Brezhnev is killed by a disgruntled soviet soldier. Later narratives would claim that it was an agent of Chen. As a result of this, and the Soviet cosmonauts being injured, Soviet spaceships would be designed for war as well. This is partly in response to the Lockheed and Douglass aircraft merge the year earlier and the advance of American planes
1964-1969 - Any attempt of Sino-Soviet peace evaporates once Leonid Brezhnev is killed. As the Triumvirate is formed, the Soviet Union takes a hardliner stance of China, believing Chen to be combining the genocidal excess of the Cultural Revolution with the betrayal of communism for capitalism. 
1969 - Triumvirate Established: the General Secretary, Director of the KGB and the Minister of Defence after the failure of Khrushchev to successfully reform the Soviet Union. Any major decision made must satisfy two of the three men, and if anyone in the Soviet Government feels they are misusing their power, they can be removed and barred from holding any office in the future. This is also to prevent another Stalin, and also in response to Mao’s cult of personality (and later Chen’s). 
1969-1972 - Border skirmishes between the USSR and China are far deadlier in this timeline and leave over 2000 dead, along with the China-USSR border starting to become patrolled more often. 
1969-1982 - Anton Agassi is very personable much like Gorbachev. He walks in the streets and talks to the citizens in person. He spoke candidly about the problems the USSR was facing but always tied it back to the Sino-Soviet split 
1970 - The average age for the member of the Politburo is 49: Agassi forcibly retired several politburo members. 
1970 - The Soviet Union begins the process of “pan-Sovietism”, which eliminates cultural representation to create a sense that all the various ethnic minorities are one super majority - Soviet. This would lead to the ethnic tensions starting in 2009.
1970 - Agassi’s policies in combination with the Chancellor of West Germany recognizing East Germany as an independent state contributes to the normalizing of foreign and trade relations between the two. However, this makes East Germany feel betrayed. 
1970-1974 - The Soviet Union doesn’t so much create a detente with the USA, so much that it reorganizes and starts to believe that the new China under Chen is the greatest threat it faces. Many agreements from OTL relating to trade and arms limitations are still signed. 
1970-1975 - The Soviet Union still supports North Vietnam. Supplies, guns and training are funneled into the north. After the War ends, the Soviet Union does not recognize South Vietnam as a legitimate country. 
1970s - The concept of Eurocommunism never catches on. 
1970s - The USSR is more conservative in supporting Africa and South America. (This is so that China can do it in the 2000s) 
1970s - Anyone with pro-China viewpoints was considered clinically insane and sent to asylums 
1970s - Soviet society sees a huge increase in education and white-collar service industry 
1970s-80s - As a result of the reduced tension between the USA and USSR, Jews are allowed to emigrate at much higher numbers 
1970s-80s - The USSR never, ever democratizes during this period 
1971 - Soviet economy is centralized around industry in the north-west and agriculture in the south-east. This is more successful due to the Chinese intellectuals working with Soviet ones. 
1971 - Agassi removed the concept of the Brezhnev policy. After Chen took over the PRC, the USSR undoubtedly became the sole leader of the Communist world 
1971-74 - Some of the escaped Chinese nationals get jobs in the Politburo. They declare a government-in-exile and are given a small commie block in Moscow to operate out of. 
1972 - In response to China’s second industrial revolution, the USSR launches wide scale industrial production efforts. These help stimulate the failing USSR economy. 
1972 - Iraq is far more pro-Moscow 
1975 - Escaped Chinese intellectuals and engineers would help redesign the USSR’s infrastructure to be more efficient. Brutalist architecture is replaced with opulent but intimidating towers.
1975 - Using the advice of the escaped Chinese intellectuals, and also in opposition to Brezhnev's moderate stance, the agricultural system of the Soviet Union was overhauled. 
1975 - The Soviet government is more open to reform after seeing what happened to China and the Prague Spring
1975 - A new constitution of the Soviet Union is drafted. The new constitution enshrines the Soviet Union as the one true beacon of communism after the fall of China to Chenism. It also enshrines the Triumvirate System to prevent another cult of personality like how Mao or Stalin had. The new constitution, however, still emphasizes how the Soviet law has higher priority than local laws in the Republics. Like previous iterations, the citizens were in theory granted freedom of speech, freedom of the press and freedom of assembly religion, however there were always by-laws that prohibited these rights in relation to government opposition and organized religion. 
1975 - The United States, believing that China has been “saved”, shifts focus entirely to the Soviet Union. The Nixon administration would take the Helsinki Accords more seriously. 
1975 - After this year, “pro-Chinese sympathies” is the most common excuse used by the government 
1976 - With full on war with the west seeming less and less likely, the Soviet Union, after building enough nukes to rival the United States, starts divesting from their military to make public work programs.
1976 - Agassi meets with Morgan in West Germany and they have a good time
1976 - Inspired by the Shanghai Accords, the Soviet Union begins opening up free trade with its satellite states. These “independent” trades are not planned. 
1976-1988 - The USA does not resume defense spending, instead the US/USSR militaries stagnate during the late 70s/80s with the exception of exports. Because of this, the Soviet Union doesn’t have a submarine run aground near Sweden, and relations with the Nordic Countries are peaceful
1976-1988 - Both the Morgan and King administrations dance the fine line of being pro-China while working on easing tensions with the USSR
1979 - Because the Soviet Union does not directly intervene in Afghanistan, the policy of detente does not end. This does not lead to the boycotting of the 1980 and 1984 Olympics
1980 - Agassi is far more diplomatic when it comes to Afghanistan. Instead of invading it, they only send supplies and train troops. 
1980 - The Warsaw Pact countries began to slowly normalize trade with the West. This was prompted in part by the Polish Crisis
1980s - The Soviet Union begins importing terminals, food and other goods from the west
1980s - The Soviet Union does not go for a guns-over-butter policy 
1980s - The Soviet Union and the USA don’t place lots of missiles everywhere 
1980s - In the core USSR and throughout the eastern bloc, factories are updated and retooled to be more modern 
1981 - The Soviet Union does not stop working on space-based weapons
1982 - The First and Only Space War in the Food, Incverse. Tensions between China and the USSR briefly flare up when China tries to land a spaceship on the moon. The USSR, due to no formal warning by the Chinese on what they were doing, assumes that China is attempting to annex the moon. The place where China lands is very close to the work-in-progress space base the Soviets were building. And so begins a very brief low-orbit war. China and the USSR start knocking satellites down and when a low-yield nuke is detonated several thousand KM above Beijing, the USA starts mediating an end to the battle. President Morgan reminds both countries of the potential economic ramifications of their actions on their citizens, and this calms them down. The USA starts growing closer to the USSR as they were just as surprised as them, and this is what leads down the path of working together on a joint mission to the moon. Agassi steps down and Gennady Yanayev becomes the General Secretary who shows his hatred for China far subtler. The Station for International Cooperation and Friendship project is then drafted up by China and submitted to the United Nations as a way of normalizing relations between all three countries. It is then viewed as the end of the Cold War, as the Soviet Union starts opening up.
1983 - The Soviet Union adopts a fourth constitution. This constitution, crafted during the dizzying heights of the Glorious Decades, allows for the import of products approved by the state. The Soviet Union also allows for the export of cultural products to all countries. Citizens can buy and sell traditionally “subversive” material but must pay a huge tax on it and will be put on a list. Lastly, in a tiny amendment, the Soviet Union recognizes the Maoist government-in-exile to be the sole legal government of China. They are the only country to recognize this claim. 
1983 - A massive soviet rock concert is held in Moscow. Over a million people attend from all over the Eastern Bloc
1985 - The Concord of Moscow: Basically the USSR’s version of the Shanghai Accords. For a fee, a citizen of the Second World could petition the government to import a select item from the West, but only if it was mass produced in a Superfactory. Also facilitated free trade between members of the Eastern Bloc. 
1986 - 95% of Kazakhstan is uninhabitable due to pollution 
1986 - Chernobyl obviously doesn’t happen 
1988 - By this time, the USSR economy doesn’t collapse. The economy is worth 4.08 Trillion USD in Q1 1988. The restructuring of the USSR Economy and the trade relations established with the west (while still under a planned economy), not invading Afghanistan, the lack of military buildup in the 80s, and helping the economies of its satellite states become self-reliant, the USSR is thriving, though not as opulent as the west is. The standard of living is probably comparable to 1970s USA
1989 - Soviet invasion of Iran, as the brainchild of conservative communist Ivan Voronin. The hope was that the Soviet Union could stop the fires and salvage some oil from the Middle East however this plan falls through by 1992 when it becomes clear that there is no salvaging it
1989 - After the crash, the Soviet Union tries to woo Western Europe into joining the Eastern Bloc. This resistance is partly what prompts the creation of the Eurofed
1989 - Soviet invasion of Afghanistan: Due to foreign relations disappearing overnight, Voronin proposes an invasion of Afghanistan as the USSR no longer has to worry about keeping the USA on its good side
1990 - The Balkan Uprising: When Yugoslavia invades the Warsaw Pact the Soviet Union has to draw troops away from Mongolia. 
1991-1995 - As China starts invading their neighbors, the USSR sounds the alarm and starts a massive build up of their military. This would cause the Soviet Economy to become one of the only growing economies during this time. 
1991 - Partition of Yugoslavia
1992 - The USSR does not participate in the Olympics 
1992 - Partition of Albania
1994 - The USSR military begins transitioning to using nuclear fuel
1995-2000 - The Soviets leverage access to Ukrainian grain to cause Turkey to become increasingly dependent on Soviet policy. 
1996 - A major ethnic conflict is sparked between ethnic Armenians and Azerbaijani. This prompts the USSR to demand all internally replaced refugees swear loyalty to the USSR and USSR only. 
1997 - Creation of Farmer’s Bounty, the USSR’s version of Food, Inc, FulTec and Siliao. It is made from the same type of oats usually fed to horses. 
February 24, 1997 - A Soviet Probe surveys the moon for oil. None is found.
1997 - The USSR attempts to annex Finland, however the Nordic Union comes to their aid. 
October 1998 - The Soviet Union starts blocking all land routes into East Germany
1999 - After a major famine (20 million dead) the USSR forcibly starts irrigating the rivers of Siberia to support massive superfarms. Central Asian refugees are sent to work in farm gulags. 
1999 - After the costly Nordic War, Finland becomes the 18th Soviet Republic. The Helsinki Treaty is signed and the Nordic Union must give the USSR 1 billion bushels of grain a year for “peace”. 
2000 - The 15th five year plan restructures the entire economy yet again - All of Siberia is dedicated solely to farming, with access to water prioritized for irrigation. Citizens are given access to bigger water rations based on how loyal they are to the State (And Savateev specifically). 
August 3, 2002 - At a Alliance of Nations meeting, China is accused of industrializing Africa, offsetting all the hard work that the US, EU and USSR have done to curb emissions
2004 - To cut back on manufacturing costs, the USSR creates the “Standard People's Uniform”, an easy to make denim jumpsuit that is typically dyed red. 
Berlin Crisis - in 1998 USSR cuts all land routes to and from West Berlin, so it’s supplied by plane. In 2003 they invade while Federation is suffering
Second Greek Civil War - Greek is basically a puppet of EU as they rely on it and FulTec for food and water, FulTec rigs Greek elections to ensure PASOK stays in power. In 2004 KKE rebels and far-right militias also. USSR invades but EU sends forces over, almost causing a war. In 2007 agreement is signed for both parties to withdraw, Greece is left to itself and collapses over the coming years
April 8, 2005 - First reported case of Red Flu
Late 2000s - The Fall of the Warsaw Pact. The civil unrest in Eastern Europe leads to the USSR pulling out their support. 
January 2007 - The USSR begins constructing a massive border wall with China
2008 - Turkey is annexed by the Soviet Union, becoming the 19th Republic
Winter 2009 - Forests dying off en masse throughout Eurasia due to the combined effects of ancient plant diseases, wildfires, acid rain and drought
2010 - The Soviet Union adopts its fifth and final Constitution. This constitution is so repressive that it would cause even Stalin to blush. Freedom of Speech, Press, Assembly and Worship are all repealed. A citizen evading work for more than 3 days is to be executed for parasitism. Any Chinese-looking person outside of the Beijing District of Moscow is to be executed immediately. The Triumvirate is abolished with the General Secretary being the sole head of state (though in actuality the KGB operate everything from behind the scenes). All non-Soviet refugees can work for 10 years in a Siberian Superfarm to earn their Soviet Citizenship. Internally displaced refugees (such as from Central Asia, Central Europe, or the Caucasus) need only work for 1 year to regain their citizenship. Any westerner is to be shot on sight. The constitution also solidifies that it is through the guiding hand of the Supreme Minister that the country has weathered the worst of the extended crisis, so anyone who goes against the infallible policy of the Politburo will be shot on sight. 
2010 - The Shadow Civil War: Due to the compounding effects of climate change, civil unrest in Eastern Europe and the internal resettlement of large amounts of refugees, the USSR enters a civil war. The director of the KGB pits the General Secretary and the Supreme Marshall against each other and dissolves the Triumvirate. 
2011 - Massive famine causes the USSR to restructure itself into 8 “core republics”, with the remaining republics essentially being abandoned. 
Mid 2011 - Massive race riots from resettled peoples cause martial law to be enacted in Siberia, then the rest of the USSR. It is never lifted. 
2012 - Bastion Doctrine is established, officially leaving Eastern Europe to fend for themselves. 
2013 - A Red Flu outbreak in Moscow kills 3 million throughout the year. Also, as a result of the new “Core Republics” regime, ethnic tensions skyrocket further
2014 - The USSR military is estimated to be 33 million active personnel. The Soviet Military begins looking into using the newly unearthed plant diseases in biological warfare: the Politburo thinks of using it against China but they realize that China has no agricultural value left. This leads the KGB to conclude that China is recycling the dead for food, which is immediately lambasted and used for propaganda purposes. 
2015 - The USSR starts opening up “resorts” (more like public camping grounds) in the far north. Good workers can get treated to “vacation” lotteries
2016 - Renewed tensions between Kazakhs and Turkmens cause the Red Army to routinely comb gulags for signs of revolt
2020 - By this year, random KGB crackdowns happen almost constantly to keep the populace in fear 
2022 - A race riot in Moscow causes the Beijing Enclave to be destroyed
2023 - The USSR is still a nation, and is doing the best of the big four. Citizens don’t have to eat their own dead. You do your work, you are quiet and you keep your head down. Entertainment is mainly dancing and singing. Once a year, the citizens can go on vacation to the Arctic Sea. 
USSR - Specific Countries
Ukraine 
2006 - Ukraine, realizing that it is the breadbasket of the USSR, attempts a worker’s strike for better conditions. The Second Ukrainian-Soviet war ends with 35% of the arable land of Ukraine burned down and Ukraine being turned into a highly militarized police state, essentially one giant gulag. 
Ukraine is treated very similarly to Mongolia is treated by China
By 2023, Ukraine is an overindustralized wasteland, having long since lost its status as “breadbasket” with the advent of Green Siberia. 
Belarus
A majority of the rapid industrialization that took place in the 70s and 80s happened here
By 2023, the BSSR is the site of a massive border wall with Eastern Europe.

After the crash of 88, the MSSR has a resurgence of independence movements. This is crushed by the up-and-coming junior officer Savateev
By 2023, Moldova is treated much the same way as the Ukrainian SSR
Lithuania
In the 1980s, Lithuania imported several million Eastern Orthodox bibles. 
An uprising in 1982 is quickly crushed. 
In 2001, Lithuania attempts its own uprising. This is crushed by Savateev. 
By 2023, the Lithuanian SSR is home to an insurgent radical orthodox movement that aims to bring Lithuanian independence back to the forefront. The Red Army uses Lithuania as target practice for the inevitable Chinese invasion. 
Latvia 
Large factories were built here in the 80s. A majority of exported Soviet products were built in Latvia. The Soviet Union begins a deal with the Eastern Bloc to import workers and grant them citizenship. 
Latvia retains a large soviet military presence all the way up to the 2020s
Latvia’s land remains arable all the way to 2023, due to careful planning (read: luck) in the organization and ratio of farms to industrial/military sectors
Latvia would see a small tourist industry in the 1980s
In the immediate aftermath of the crash of 88, a small independence movement forms and is quickly crushed by the Red Army
Latvia is overall a pretty chill place by 2023 standards
Estonia
Finland and Estonia begin a trading relationship in the 1970s
Estonia becomes the main tourist hub of the Soviet Union in the 80s
A small uprising against Russification happens in 1987
Tourist destinations become collective farms in the late 90s
By 2023, Estonia is not quite as bad as Lithuania but not as good as Latvia
Uzbekistan 
During the Afghan Civil War, pro-Soviet troops are trained in Uzbek SSR
After the crash, the USSR had to put in more and more investment into keeping the Uzbek SSR afloat. 
In 2005, a water riot causes 243 deaths 
In 2009 the SSR’s supply of Nitrogen and Phosphate run out and with it the support of Moscow
From 1994-2010 the USSR begins a resettlement program for the Uzbeks that sends them to work in farms in the Krasnoyarsk Krai
In 2011, as part of the Bastion Doctrine, Uzbek SSR is officially abandoned by the Soviet Government.

In the 70s Kazakh SSR is intensively settled and industrialized 
Kazakh SSR is the first SSR abandoned, in 1999
Kyrgyzstan
In 1970, Agassi removes the Kyrgiz first secretary and replaces him with a Russian. This causes widespread unrest. The Red Army is called in and they deal with a small insurrection, but overall, it fizzles out by 1971. 
Most of its natural resources run out by 2005, and it becomes a dustbowl by 2008
The Soviet Union begins a resettlement program around the same time as the Uzbek one, and it goes very bad. 
Tajikistan 
In the 70s, Tajik SSR has civil unrest due to the Russification policies
In the 80s, Tajik SSR exports a lot of clothes for the USSR, and becomes rich as a result. 
In 2003, Tajik SSR tries to go independent. The USSR steps in to try to put it down, but get bogged down and eventually retreat in 2007. Think OTL Afghanistan 
Turkmenistan 
The USSR keep an iron grip on the turkmens

This combined with the Aral sea being destroyed leads to widespread ecological collapse in 1989.

Georgia
In the 70s and 80s, the fight against corruption is more successful.
Because of Brezhnev’s death, the Georgian language being repealed is not impactful.

In 2009, the Georgians rebel again, and the Red Army is forced to fight the insurgents all the way until 2011 when the Bastion Doctrine is enacted
Azerbaijan
Due to the nature of the Glorious Decades, Azerbaijan SSR gets really rich in the 80s
Of the three Caucus Republics, Azerbaijan sees the worst of it. Azerbaijanis are suppressed by the Soviets and worked to the bone. 
In 1992, a terrorist attack destroys a pipeline and causes a massive response from Moscow, who commit war crimes while the rest of the world is focused on the invasion of Taiwan. 
In 2001, Azerbaijan SSR’s resources dry up and the USSR stops subsidizing the industry. The pollution from Armenia has drifted over and significantly hampers quality of life. 
In 2003, the USSR starts subsidizing a resettlement program
Armenia 
In the 80s, Armenia gets super polluted along with Belarus. 
Anti-Azerbaijan race riots happen in 1987

in 1995 the USSR offers resettlement to Siberia.

Standard of living is good, comparable to USSR, because of cheap oil

Mexico and Central America:

Mexico (Population of last census, 2000: 241,528,255)
Economic problems don’t happen in 1976 and 1982
The earthquake in Mexico City in 1985 is met with an international effort to rebuild 
The United States leads this effort, part of the reconstruction deal includes building a Mexican-American pipeline
After the crash of 1988, Mexico actually sees a very brief boom in economy due to its large oil supplies and the PRI manage to narrowly win in the July 1988 general election
The government operates business as usual which causes a huge uproar. The conservative government thinks that the depression is temporary
The massive demand for oil leads to Mexico extracting large amounts of oil and selling it at high prices. However, later that year and in 1990, oil demand crashes and Mexico’s oil company goes bust, leading to severe economic crisis
In 1989 President Graves tariffs most Mexican goods, leading to economic collapse. Mexico institutes reciprocal tariffs and a trade war begins. The policies are never reversed and anti-American sentiment sweeps Mexico. The PRI loses in part due to not being in touch with this, hoping Graves would reverse these policies after negotiation
In 1989, unemployment causes mass unrest, leading to riots in Mexico City 
This results in Edmundo Gutiérrez, a socialist in the PRD, receiving governorship of the state of Tabasco in a snap election. He campaigns on nationalizing the oil industry and creating jobs in the agricultural industry 
A terrorist attack destroys the Mexican-American Pipeline in 1989. 
In 1990, during the Hot Summer, Mexico is hit hard, with a massive migration from the northern states to the southern coastal ones, concentrated around Mexico City 
After tariffs destroy the rest of the economy, many states begin implementing similar reforms despite the government claiming that it is only temporary and that they are working closely with President Graves to resume trading
President Graves almost causes a war in 1991 when he says that he was elected to help America, not Mexico, and also (maybe) says some racist things
Throughout the 90s, cartels expand to make up for the collapse of the formal economy, and sell lots of drugs due to people being unemployed and depressed
In 1993, Governor Gutiérrez begins running for president. The PRI desperately tries to appeal to the average Mexican using nostalgia for the Glorious Decades, however they can’t compete with Gutiérrez’s policies, which have made the state of Tabasco the state with the best living conditions which have proved very popular with the public
Famines in 1993 and 1994 cause a dramatic shift to PRD as almost a million die of starvation over the course of a year. 
The Mexican Revolution of 1994: In 1994’s election, Gutiérrez wins in the biggest landslide in Mexican history, and with a majority of the politicians on his side, he enables sweeping reforms such as nationalizing every single industry, and implementing an American-style Universal Food Ration. Wealth redistribution programs give huge amounts of land to farmers, and those that refuse to give up their land are tried as enemies of the Mexican People. Government work programs are created to build housing for those displaced by climate change. 
In 1995, Gutiérrez officially renames the United States of Mexico to the Federation of Socialist Mexican States (Federación de Estados Socialistas Mexicanos). 1995-2000 are considered the “Golden Years” of Socialist Mexico, as the unemployment rate reached as low as 15% nationwide, and for those five years, homelessness was down to 0.1% and poverty was briefly eliminated. Mexico’s economy actually started rising, very slowly bro im sorry but this is Food, Incverse poverty will not be eliminated in this rip mexican plot armor If USA isnt doing it Mexico isnt doing it
In 1996, to deal with the growing food crisis, the Mexican Government creates the “empresa nacional de alimentos”, or the National Food Company
In 1996 and 1997, Vice President Smith and later President Smith would try to negotiate with President Gutiérrez for a lowering of tariffs and a renewed trade deal but was frequently rejected
In 1996, Mexico joins the Alliance of Nations
In the late 90s, in the depopulated northern states, corruption started to emerge. Backdoor deals and secret meetings between politicians looking to make ends meet and opportunistic black market dealers lead to the rise of organized crime in the emerging wasteland
In the late 90s, in the depopulated northern states, corruption grows rapidly as cartels take over the local governments. Collusion between desperate politicians and the cartels leads to their expansion in power and the rise of the black market there
In 1999 and early 2000, President Gutiérrez begins to investigate the reports of cartel activity in the north, leading to the creation of the Mexican People’s Army.
Throughout 2000 and 2001, large amounts of immigrants fleeing from the chaos in central and south America begin appearing on the border of Mexico. There are even some reports of African Americans fleeing from the Klan members in the Deep South
This immigration crisis ends up being one of the main talking points in the 2000 Election, leading to far-left Alejandro Ortega Ruiz to become President, campaigning on making Mexico for the Mexicans and to also stop the growing black market and drug cartels in the north. 
Mexico passes a strict immigration law in 2001, and then throughout 2002 President Ruiz engages in several operations leading the Mexican People’s Army against the cartels in the north
A massive riot in Mexico City in 2001 leads to the police being nationalized by the government, and vigilante groups begin appearing to deal with organized crime
In 2002 vigilante groups in the south begin to enact mob justice with the immigrants fleeing north into Mexico, resulting in the Tuxtla Gutiérrez Massacre of 2002. Over 50 people were found to be killed before the Mexican government intervened 
Due to climate change, immigration, drought and famine, more and more people are populated into Mexico City and the surrounding cities. This starts to cause a massive strain on resources despite the communist nature of the country. 
From 2003-2006, China works with President Ruiz to create jobs and revitalize the industry in Mexico. Unknown to the President, China is also working with the cartels, giving them a huge edge in the civil unrest. 
In 2004, unrest begins to grow in the Mexican People’s Army, dissatisfied with President Ruiz’s way of handling the country. The cartels begin to win more and more battles, and after the Battle of Durango results in a massive rout against the MPA, high ranking members of the army begin to plot a coup
In 2005, Hurricane Wilson devastates the coasts of Mexico leading to over 50k casualties
In 2005, Ricardo López Valdez, General of the MPA, involves Mexico in the politics of Belize by invading them for “peacekeeping”. The Mexican Armed Forces begin to be stretched thin between their southern border, the northern cartels and Belize
President Ruiz is narrowly re-elected in 2005 due to voter suppression and a divided oppositionMexico’s president can only serve one term and it’s in 6 year increments, so 1989-1995-2001-2007
In 2006, Valdez gets more and more support and launches a coup against the government and establishes a Junta in central Mexico, centered in Mexico City. In a twisted attempt to end the chaos and famines, he launches an invasion of Honduras 
In 2007, Valdez launches skirmishes against China in Guatemala. Meanwhile, the cartels control most of the north of Mexico. Valdez begins to control the press and flow of information to prevent the citizens from learning these devastating losses
Throughout 2008, members of Valdez’s government begin to defect to the cartels, some out of fear and some out of treachery and greed. Inspired by the changes to labor in the USA, the cartels begin to create farms using slaves to fund their operations
Valdez occupies the collapsed Guatemala in 2008 as it falls into civil war
In 2009, Valdez launches yet another invasion, this time of Nicaragua 
By 2010, the northernmost states in Mexico are in complete control by various Mexican cartels, with the last remnants of the MPA either defecting, surrendering, or retreating
The Purple Summer of 2011 leads to Mexico pulling out of Honduras and Nicruagua. This leads to a major famine with unconfirmed reports of cannibalism throughout the countryside
In 2012, Valdez is forced to focus on the cartel activity. Civil unrest against his junta begins to pick up, resulting in martial law being declared throughout the country. Valdez becomes deeply paranoid, and members parts of the MPA loyal to him begin arresting agitators for being “cartel members” 
In 2013, Mexico pulls out of Belize as the civil unrest spirals into a low-intensity civil war between forces still loyal to PRD, the MPA and Valdez, and the cartels, which are becoming far more chaotic and brutal. This leads to a record number of people fleeing the country, even going north into the USA, resulting in the El Paso Massacre that year
In 2014, cartels begin to splinter and fracture due to factionalism. Some of them take over southern Mexico, moving into places like Belize and starting to cause issues with leadership between cartels. 
In 2015, during the Great Heatwave, the cartels gain far more control as people take their drugs to escape the harsh reality. By 2016, outside of a few places loyal to Valdez, most of Mexico is divided up between various cartels. These cartel states are essentially labor-intensive superfarms that operate at night, with the population kept under control by malnutrition, drugs and force. Drugged workers are fed the corpses of their fallen with a slurry of vegetable paste
In 2016 and 2017, the cartels actually leave Valdez alone (they think he’s no longer worth it) to take over bits of central america for their growing operations, including Guatemala, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica
In 2018, meddling from the Jarret Administration causes the Mexican cartels to fight each other, shattering their fragile alliance. Valdez’s Junta actually gains more power, liberating some communities in the south
In 2019, the entire northern parts of Mexico are so dry and hot that even the cartels abandon their night operations there, retreating to Baja California Sur and parts of Guatemala
In 2020, a heatwave and famine leads to the insane Valdez to repurpose the corpses of “agitators” into food
Much of Mexico’s population is either insane from drug abuse or weary from despair, leading to a huge increase in suicide bombings and brutally violent crimes. Entire towns become so drugged out that they fall into a coma and never wake up again
In summer 2021 it is leaked to the population of Mexico City that Valdez has been feeding the poor to the poor and a revolt occurs, killing Valdez in the process and leading to a mass exodus of people north. Many are captured by the Cartels and drugged and used as slave labor, while others make it north, leading to the Night War of 2021
Throughout 2021-2026, various revolutionaries and dictators take over the crumbling Mexican Junta, some of them tyrants and others traitors who work with the fracturing cartels before being deposed 
In 2022-2024, the biggest Mexican cartel invade and annex Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, and parts of Costa Rica
In 2025-2026 the cartels fracture further leading to several of them being absorbed by the others
In early 2027, a minor captain in the MPA controlled town of Chapata, engages in a mass poisoning operation against the biggest cartel and becomes the new dictator of Mexico City. 
In 2027 right before the Great Death, the captain in the MPA, now called the Generale, is gaining more and more ground from the North Cartel
Guatemala (Population of last census, 2000: 28,954,243)
Civil war goes on OTL until in 1973 Cuba stops supporting the insurgents and the US-China Peace Commission starts negotiating an end to the violence
This results in the department of Quiche being turned into an autonomous zone ruled by the indigenous Maya
However, poor negotiations result in more ethnic violence, leading to renewed conflict in 1975
This results in a UN mission into Guatemala in 1976 that leads to the US-backed regime being destroyed 
In 1977 and 1978, the UN mission holds a trial for the government but the US is left off the hook
In 1978, the new president pledges close ties to both Mexico and the United States
In 1979 and 1980, Guatemala begins building Chinese-style megafactories
In 1984, the new president begins forcing indigenous people to work in their factories. The rest of the population is fine with this due to the economy skyrocketing
In 1988 when both Mexico and the United states cut off trade, ethnic tensions resume
In 1989 the President declares martial law, and Cuba begins supplying the rebels once again
Throughout 1990 the rebels destroy factories, causing smoke to blow over into Mexico
In 1991, Guatemala invades Belize
In 1992 the rebels take Guatemala city 
In 1993-1999, in the south, rebels regularly execute European hispanics and have a very agrarian society. In the north, the remnants of the government constantly infight
In 2000-2007, China props up the north by giving it industrial support, which they use to wage war on the south and also each other
By 2008, the entire country collapses in Civil War yet again
By 2015, the country is in a feudal warlord era
In 2016, Mexican cartels move in to repurpose the Chinese machinery to mass produce weapons and later Bromista (Bromista is the drug that gives the Cartels so much power. In such a shitty world, escapism is very popular. Bromista is a combination of crack, LSD, and magic mushrooms, giving the user intense but usually pleasurable hallucinations)
In the 2020s, the populace is kept drugged and used as slave labor for the cartels
In 2027, Guatemala is basically a puppet of Mexico
Belize (Population of last census, 2000: 1,821,020)
In 1981, Belize becomes independent 
In 1982, the Belize Barrier Reef reports record bleaching
In 1988, Belize reports record poverty 
In 1991, after its clear that the UK is too busy, Guatemala invades Belize
Throughout the 90s, Guatemalan rebels aid Belize but because it’s so chaotic, cartels move in and start setting up drug rings
In 2005, due to flooding, the remnants of the government are driven out and the Mexican army invades for “peacekeeping” 
Throughout the 2010s, Mexican far-left forces and cartels battle for control
In 2013, Mexican forces pull out and Belize essentially becomes a cartel state
In the 2020s the populace is kept drugged and used as slave labor for the cartels
In 2021, the cartel puppet state of Guatemala officially annexes Belize, which is in turn a puppet of the Mexican cartels
In 2027, Belize is uninhabitable due to frequent hurricanes and intense rains preventing any agriculture
Honduras (Population as of last census, 1990: 18,903,743)
In the 70s, the economy grows far faster
In the 80s, after returning to civilian rule, Honduras works closely with the United Nations Anti-Drug Task Force
In 1984, the Soviet Union helps negotiate an end to the Marxist insurgency 
In the 80s Honduras is very dependant on trade with the US
In March 1988, this timeline’s version of Operation: Golden Pheasant happens, called Operation: Silver Turkey, and the focus is against cartel operations and not Contra
In 1988 after the Crash, Honduras experiences a revival of the Marxist insurgency, aided by Cuba
In 1989, this new leftist government is seen as ineffective, and to distract the population, Honduras starts a phoney war with El Salvador, blaming them for their economy and filling their country with drugs
In 1990, the Hot summer causes widespread rationing and the Marxists become more popular
In 1991, martial law is declared
In 1992, due to famine, Honduras removes the environmental protection in its national reserves and replaces them with intensive farming
In 1993, Honduras invades El Salvador. This fails and actually unites El Salvador against them, leading to a far-right military coup 
In 1994-2000, Honduras is in civil war conditions between far-right military groups, far-left revolutionaries, and drug cartels
In 2000, the cartels win out and the country devolves into a warlord state
In 2006-2007 the Mexican junta invades Honduras for intensive farming, claiming to be on the side of the Marxists
Because of the agricultural potential, Mexico (aided by Honduran collaborators) and the cartels fight over Honduras between 2008-2011
In 2011, a massive storm causes a huge military defeat for Mexico and they retreat
In the 2010s, Honduras is turned into one giant drug-growing operation
In 2014, fleeing refugees from Cuba attempt to stage a revolution in Honduras but they are quickly put down by the Cartels
In 2022, Mexican cartels officially annex Honduras as part of Mexico
In 2027, Honduras is thoroughly depopulated and the land is used to grow luxury crops (like coffee beans and bananas) for Cartel leadership
El Salvador (Population as of last census, 2000: 12,130,087) 
In the 70s, due to greater economic conditions, the Civil War is delayed
Crackdowns in the 80s lead to the military government barely holding on to legitimacy 
The depression in 1988 leads to protests and a coup in 1989
This leads to a civil war after the Hot Summer
In 1990-1993, the far-right junta fights against leftist guerillas aided by Cuba
But in 1993, Honduras invades. This manages to unite the warring factions and they quickly push them out
In 1994, the two factions try to peacefully rule El Salvador but the rebels break the treaty in 1995 and take San Salvador
The new leftist coalition government rules from 1995-2000, and is incredibly unstable and corrupt. Thousands die from famines and extreme weather. 
From 2000-2010, the civil war starts up again between the remnants of the Junta and the leftists. 
By 2011, the civil war has been so destructive that almost the entire country is incapable of supporting life, with the soil heavily damaged from the civil war, industrial run off, and rampant forest fires
In the 2010s-2020s, El Salvador is turned into a wasteland, with 99% of the population fleeing 
In 2020, the northern parts of the country are absorbed by Honduras 
By 2027, El Salvador has ceased to exist, with most of its citizens having forgotten about the country due to excessive drug use
Nicaragua (Population as of last census, 1990: 11,712,765)
The 1972 earthquake is just as destructive, however China and the USA help 
Part of the deal that USA and China made included reforms to open up the country more
In 1973, Somoza is deposed in a peaceful revolution
In 1974-1978, Cuba attempts to inspire guerilla uprisings but nothing comes of it, the citizens like the new system too much
In 1974-1980, Nicuarugua is transformed into a neo-liberal state with heavy investments from China and the US
In the 1980s, Nicaragua becomes the biggest exporter of coffee
After the crash of 1988, the country collapses rapidly 
In 1989, Marxist rebels, supported by Cuba overthrow the weakened government
In 1990, due to infighting and severe corruption, Nicaragua invades Costa Rica
In 1990-1993, the Costa Rica-Nicaragua War occurs. Due to the extreme poverty and infighting in Nicaragua, Costa Rica manages to win despite having a much smaller army
In 1994, Nicaragua collapses into warlordism 
In 1995, Costa Rican refugees fleeing from Colombia overwhelm the country
From 1995-2000, Nicaragua collapses into anarchy
In 2001, Nicaragua is annexed by Costa Rica
From 2002-2008, Nicaragua is turned into a giant cartel growing operation
After the storm of 2008, the central Cartel is packed into Nicaragua which is retooled to grow crops as well
In 2009-2011, Mexican marxists battle the Cartels but are unsuccessful 
In 2012-2015, infighting between cartel factions cause a civil war that ends in the Great Heatwave of 2015
In 2016, the Mexican cartels invade 
In the 2020s, despite frequent storms and high UV radiation, plus deadly humidity, Nicuraga is a major growing location for the Cartels
In 2027, Nicaragua is under control by the Cartels but just barely
Costa Rica (Population as of last census, 1990: 10,410,736)
In the 1970s, Costa Rica becomes extremely wealthy 
Carazo never becomes president and Costa Rica maintains its good relations with the US and the IMF
After the crash of 1988, the new president severs ties with much of the world
In 1989 and 1990, Costa Rica hangs on, implementing rationing and several social services
In 1990-1993, the Costa Rica-Nicaragua War occurs. Due to the extreme poverty and infighting in Nicaragua, Costa Rica manages to win despite having a much smaller army
In 1994, Costa Rica attempts to rebuild 
In 1995, Colombia, invading through Panama, takes over Costa Rica
In 1997, while Colombia is distracted, Cartels take over Costa Rica along with Panama
From 1997-2000, Costa Rica is reformed into a cartel state
In 2001, the Costa Rican cartel state takes over Nicaragua 
From 2002-2008, Costa Rica is the South American Cartel’s base of operations, thoroughly depopulated and turned into a series of walled, luxury cities
In 2008, however, a rebellion launched by indentured servants destroys many of the estates, and refugees fleeing from Panama cause a breakdown of Cartel order
From 2009-2017, Costa Rica is anarchy 
In 2017, trying to recoup their losses from the Great Heatwaves, Mexican cartels try to establish growing operations in Costa Rica
In the 2020s, Costa Rica is plagued by storms, with entire towns being destroyed 
In 2027 it is in anarchy 

South America: 

Panama (Population as of last census, 1990: 8,175,891) 
Panama is a military dictatorship following the coup in 1968
As part of the Shanghai Accords, China and the USA take joint control of the Panama Canal to facilitate free trade
Throughout the 70s, Panama becomes rife with corruption
Because of the decreased tensions in the cold war, during the 80s, the world pretty much just lets Panama be
In 1987, the Panama military attempts to stage an uprising due to the vast income inequalities
In early 1988, Panama becomes a UN protectorate 
After the Sinai War UN funds dry up and countries start recalling large amounts of troops
In 1989, the military launches a successful coup 
In the early 90s, the military engages in drug smuggling to fund their social security programs
By 1994, the Military is just as corrupt as the US-China occupation and causes a civil war
In 1995, during the civil war, Colombia invades and takes over the Canal
In 1997, Cartel members take over the Canal while Colombia is distracted by Brazil
A huge storm in August 2008 forces the cartels to abandon Panama and it falls into anarchy 
Throughout the 2010s, it is occasionally picked over by pirates, cartel members, and refugees 
In the 2020s it is uninhabitable during the day time due to high uv radiation 
By 2027, there are some warlords
Colombia (Population as of last census, 2010: 104,706,063) 
In the 1970s, because of the reforms in the Soviet Union and China, the far-left military groups are wiped out by the 1980s
As a result, the M-19 movement gets more prominence 
Throughout the 80s, the government and m-19 duke it out. This would result in a United Nations peacekeeping mission being established and Colombia’s drug lords not getting as much influence
Pablo Escobar is killed in a joint USA-USSR-PRC operation in 1986
After the crash, the far-right paramilities gain more power and take over the government in 1989, establishing a fascist state
In 1994, Colombia invades Venezuela and then Panama in 1995
In 1997, Brazil invades for living space
Between 1998-2000 Colombia fights back against Brazil but is conquered 
In 2002, the Cartels begin to gain more power against the overstretched Brazilian forces
The cartels begin further forays into Central America throughout the 2000s
In 2009, an uprising in a plantation causes a civil war that rips through Colombia
In 2011, massive storms along Colombia’s coast cause farms to fail 
By 2013, the civil war has devolved into anarchy and warlordism
By 2027, the country is in total anarchy
Venezuela (Population as of last census, 2010: 49,516,654)
In 1973, because of no oil crisis, Venezuela doesn’t have a rapid standard of living increasing 
But in 1983, it also doesn’t have a debt crisis. 
The OTL reforms in the 80s happen in the 70s, it diversified its economy and created lots of additional sectors 
After the crash of 88, Venezuela actually isn’t hit as hard as their large amounts of oil made them relatively independent to the doom spiral of resources. 
In 1990 though with the hot summer food shortages cause severe riots and social unrest
This leads to the government taking more and more drastic measures until in 1991 a riot blows up into full civil war 
In 1993, the civil war gets out of hand and turns into anarchy 
In 1995, Colombia takes over Venezuela for their oil 
In 1996, Brazil invades Venezuela from the other side to also get their oil, kicking out Colombia
This ironically gives the Venezuelans a cause to rally around and they launch a guerilla war against Brazil, funded by the USSR and later Argentina
The Venezuelan rebels launch several major operations in the areas occupied by Brazil. Major uprising include in 1999, 2002, 2005, 2009 and 2013. 
The uprising in 2002 destroyed the Venezuelan oil fields, causing heavy smog to blanket northern South America
Brazil still maintained their occupation as Venezuela had a large amount of arable land surprisingly
In the 2013 uprising, Brazil sent in a huge amount of their forces, this caused the rival military faction to take over and caused the Brazilian Civil War
In 2014 however the Cartels took over the arable parts of Venezuela and the rest of it devolved into warlordism 
In 2017 multiple uprising at cartel plantations caused the Cartels to abandon their holdings
In the 2020s it is under civil war conditions between Marxist revolutionaries and cartel-backed warlords 
By 2027, it is still under Civil War
Guyana (Population from last census, 2010: 1,883,086)
In 1978, due to the cultural stagnation in the West leading to further ennui, the Jonestown Massacre leads to over 2,000 deaths
The program of self-reliance works only until the 1978 when they give in and start free trade
The Sugar Strike in 1977-78 is met with US strikebreakers coming in and massacring the workers
As a result of the Sugar Strike and Jonestown Massacre, a violent coup in 1979 replaces the government of Guyana with a populist right-wing government
In the 80s, this conservative right-wing government tries to emulate the wealth of first-world countries by working with China to build mega-factories
Entire forests are logged, with almost the entire wilderness being cut down and exploited
In 1988, after the crash, public life nosedived and things like cooking oil, fuel, sugar and rice all became scarce and expensive 
This caused the economy to completely crash and the government to be upended in a violent revolt in late 1988
But in 1991, Venezuela would annex parts of Guyana 
Throughout the early 1990s, Guyana would become thoroughly depopulated from people fleeing the situation, famines, drought, extreme weather, and cartel violence. 
In 1995, Brazil invades Guyana and pacifies them for the most part. Members of the old corrupt government collaborate with the Brazillians in exchange for keeping their power
Guyana manages to keep a large amount of arable land, so the Brazillians use it as a breadbasket 
In 2009, a Venezuelan fighter group establishes cells in Guyana 
In 2014, monkeywrenching operations destroy the last remaining working farms in Guyana 
As a result of the Great Heatwave of 2015, Guyana’s agriculture cannot be revived and Brazil abandons them
After 2017, the Cartels establish a few bases but for the most part, Guyana is an arid wasteland 
By 2027, it is in a warlord state
Suriname (Population as of last census, 2010: 1,727,611)
Not really much happens. 
In 1980, the military coup is unsuccessful 
In 1981, the corruption and quality of life becomes so low that it’s considered a third world country, with many corporations donating to Suriname for tax cuts
After the Crash of 88, with foreign aid drying up, a far-left revolutionary group takes over in November 1988
This far-left government led to widespread anarchy and famine, forcing many to flee the country 
In 1992, Brazil invades them 
Throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, Suriname is one the territories that Brazil keeps a tight hold over, not because of the resources there but because the resistance is disorganized and impoverished 
In 2001, China begins building advanced mining facilities in Suriname 
Throughout the 2000s, the Chinese refineries poison the soil and begins to spill over into neighboring regions like Guyana and French Guiana
When the Chinese funds dry up in 2008, Brazil tries to keep the refineries running but run out of coal by 2012
A massive forest fire in 2013 causes Brazil to abandon Suriname
Throughout the rest of the 2010s, the Cartels occasionally use Suriname as a base
By 2027, Suriname is anarchy 
French Guiana (Population as of last census, 2000: 1,303,465) 
In 1970, refugees from Vietnam are settled here
In 1976, the Green Plan is far more successful 
The economic success of France in the Glorious Decades causes many independence groups to die down
After the Crash of 1988 though France struggles to keep French Guiana afloat before the Communist President of France relinquishes claims to it, calling it “imperialistic” 
A far-right military coup happens in 1990, after which Guiana devolves into feudal warlord state
Brazil invades in 1992 and makes them a breadbasket 
Brazil would hold onto them until 2005 when Venezuelan and Laotian refugees would organize a guerilla war against the Brazillians 
After the Great Heatwave of 2015, Brazil abandons them to anarchy and warlordism
After 2016, Cartels start to use Guiana for bases and plantations 
In 2019, Brazil attempts to reconquer them but the Cartels hold them off
By 2027, Guiana is still in a sort of feudal warlord state controlled by various cartels
Ecuador (Population as of last census, 2010: 37,049,097) 
The military Dictatorship collapses in 1972, being replaced by a far-left military junta
This junta nationalizes all the oil in Ecuador in 1973, however because of the lack of an oil crisis, this is far more successful than in OTL
In 1975, Ecuador peacefully transitions to a Civilian government, with elections held in 1976
In the late 70s/early 80s, Ecuador uses their oil revenue to create huge banana and cacao plantations, producing a vast majority of the world’s bananas during the Glorious Decades
As the oil booms shows no sign of stopping, and the US likes their bananas, their leader is not killed in 1981 
An earthquake of March 1987 results in widespread destabilization of the economy, forcing Ecuador to rely on domestic products more
In 1987, the Ecuadorian government takes out loans to help repair their infrastructure, with President King sending American engineers as a sign of good will (and keeping the oil flowing and bananas growing) 
After the crash of ‘88, due to the already declining economic situation, Ecuador wasn’t hit that hard. In 1989 and 1990, they make a lot of money selling oil and rationing isn’t introduced until the Hot Summer of 1990. 
In 1991, famines and drought cause widespread poverty, leading to a far-left government taking over in 1992. 
This government, despite claiming to have the people’s interests in mind, ends up capitulating to Brazil in 1993
Brazil exploits Ecuador's natural resources to create huge farms and mining operations 
Uprising in 1999
Ecuador's oil runs out by 2001
Brazil keeps a tight leash on Ecuador throughout the occupation
Ecuador manages to barely survive the 2015 Heatwave but crumbles during the 2016 one
Due to extreme weather events like storms and flooding, the coast and western half of the country in uninhabitable 
From 2017-2022, a faction of Brazil’s Junta holds on to the eastern half of the country and fights incoming revolutionaries from Colombia and Venezuela 
In 2023, Brazil retreats, and Ecuador devolves into civil war
As of 2027, it is still under civil war conditions 
Brazil (Population of non-occupied territories as of last census, 2010: 423,694,861)
The Dictatorship progresses as it does OTL until 1974, when the policies of “abertura” and “distensão” are much more successful 
Because there is no 1973 oil crisis, Brazil’s economy is pretty much fine for the most part
In 1977, President Morgan begins negotiations with Brazil to enact policies of democratization 
In 1978, due to the success of turning China capitalist and ending the Vietnam war and the detente in Korea, a military junta protecting the nation against communism is seen as unnecessary 
In 1979, the military government tries to assert themselves as the only thing keeping the country together and providing security, but with the growing drug trafficking operations, this is seen as obsolete 
In late 1979, the military attempts to engineer a coup during preliminary elections but is stopped by US observers
In 1980, overseen by President Morgan, the first free president elections are held
The president in 1980 runs on a platform of being harsh on crime
In 1981, working together with the United States, the UN and other countries, Brazil leads the charge in anti-drug trafficking operations 
In 1982, Brazil begins expanding their space program 
In 1983, after signing an exclusive petroleum deal with China, Brazil joins the International Station for Cooperation and Friendship
In 1984, China opens many industrial factories in Brazil’s southern region
In 1985, Brazil begins auctioning off huge swathes of the Amazon rainforest to logging companies
In 1986, Brazil participates in the operation to apprehend Pablo Escobar. The detective responsible for finding him is Brazilian. His name: Augusto Fernando César
In 1987, Brazil’s space program makes their first successful orbit
In 1988, Brazil begins working with the US to engage in drug busting operations throughout all of South America. This results in a massive militarization of Brazil’s police, and even their army is drafted to be extra forces 
In 1988, after the crash, Brazil desperately tries to maintain their power. The international drug busting alliance is broken up and various countries around Brazil fracture
In november of 1988, a populist centre-left politician, Ulysses José Franco, runs on a campaign of social services while also emphasizing trade with neighboring countries
In 1989, rampant corruption fueled by cartel operations cause the Franco administration to fracture and their social services to crumble
In 1990, during the summer, civil unrest grows as the population feels that the Franco administration is prioritizing the remnants of international trade. An orbital launch in November 1990 causes widespread protest from starving unemployed in Rio de Janeiro 
On January 20, 1991, the Sao Paulo massacre occurs. 
Capitalizing on this, opposition leader César Henrique Morales claims that the far-left model doesn’t work and that left-wing corruption is what allowed the drug problem to get so bad. He begins campaigning on a platform of ridding all crime, returning Brazil to its roots as an anti-communist dictatorship (hoping to get more aid from the west) and impeaching Franco
On March 15, 1991, the opposition impeaches Franco and the next day, the Brazilian Police, led by César, execute him on phoney drug charges. Throughout the next few weeks, Brazil’s government is restructured into a military junta.
On April 9, 1991, César Henrique Morales proclaims himself the civilian leader of Brazil, ruling in Sao Paulo, while Augusto Fernando César is proclaimed the military leader of Brazil, ruling from Rio de Janeiro 
CHM begins organizing “neighborhood watches” to be on the lookout for “argentine spies” or “drug runners”. AFC begins recruiting large amounts of Brazilians into the military with incentives of bringing safety to Brazil and stopping the spread of the Argentine insanity with the recent revolution in Uruguay 
From 1991-1992, Brazil invades Peru and North Bolivia
From 1991-1994, Brazil attempts to invade Paraguay
From 1992-1993, Brazil invades Suriname and French Guiana
From 1993-1994, Brazil invades Ecuador
From 1993-1995, Brazil attempts to invade South Bolivia but is stopped by Argentina
From 1995-1996, Brazil invades Guyana
From 1996-1997, Brazil invades Venezuela
From 1997-2000, Brazil invades Colombia
With South America effectively divided between far-right Brazil and far-left Argentina, Brazil calls themselves the Empire of Brazil
From 2000-2007, Brazil takes a break from conquering countries to focus on their domestic issues such as rampant power outages. Working with the Chinese (in secret), Brazil invests heavily in mining and energy production
In 2005, in a sort of twisted form of dehumanization, Brazil begins feeding leftists their own dead
In 1999, Ecuador would launch an uprising
In 2002, Peru would launch an uprising
In 2005, Guiana would launch an uprising
In 2009, Brazil loses control of Colombia due to civil war, desertification, and Venezuelan guerillas  
In 2010, during their last census, the total population of the Brazilian Empire is 688,030,405
In early 2013, Venezuelan rebels would assassinate a visiting Augusto Fernando César and cause the Brazilian Civil War due to the military/police and César Henrique Morales not being able to agree on a successor 
As a result of pollution from Chinese machines and the creeping effects of climate change, more and more civilians end up joining far-left guerilla groups
In late 2013, a forest fire causes Brazil to abandon Suriname
In 2014, Peru’s Pro-Brazil governor is overthrown and Brazil is only able to keep the northern half
In 2015, Brazil abandons Guyana and French Guiana due to the first Great Heatwave
In 2016, Brazil abandons the western half of Ecuador
In 2017, Brazil begins losing core provinces to far-left rebellions and cartel operations and on July 7, 2017 César Henrique Morales is killed by his own men
In the more rural areas of Brazil and occupied Peru and Ecuador, the far-right military government remains strong while the rural areas in the east are gradually taken over by far-left militias
In 2019 Brazilian soldiers resort to cannibalism due to being cut off from supply lines
In 2018 Argentina begins supplying the rebels with guns and materials 
In 2022 the situation in Brazil gets even worse when Cartels invade from the ruins of Colombia and Venezuela
In 2027 Brazil is still under civil war
Peru (Population as of last census, 2010: 68,149,568)
The military dictatorship happens as OTL
In 1973, China and the USA work together to negotiate with Peru’s military dictatorship and lead them away from communism 
This results in the military dictatorship being overthrown in 1974, and leadership being returned to civilian rule
In 1975, the government, with the help of the CIA, begins rounding up and executing suspected leftists 
In 1976, China signs a lucrative minerals deal with Peru and begins revitalizing their economy
In the 80s, far-left revolutionary groups and cartel operations begin to cause internal conflict in Peru
In 1981, China begins aiding the government of Peru in eradicating the Maoist insurgency 
The Paquisha War never happens
Peru lasts a bit longer, but in 1988, hyperinflation catches up to them 
In late 1988, the Shining Path takes over the government 
Throughout 1988 and 1989, the Shining Path government creates widespread land reform and lynches powerful members of corporations and the government. The civilians are kept in check through fear and rationing
In 1990, the Hot Summer destroys the agriculture of Peru and causes widespread famine
In March 1990, the Shining Path breaks apart into several factions and launch civil wars on each other
In mid 1991, the newly formed dictatorship of Brazil launches an invasion of Peru 
The remaining people who escaped the purges welcome the far-right Brazilian government, and collaborate in ruling Peru 
In 1992 Peru is formally annexed by Brazil and becomes several states
Through strict rationing and intensive agriculture, Peru avoids famines throughout the 90s and Brazil invests heavily in mining operations
In 2001, a massive forest fire cause many farms to be burnt down 
In 2002 an uprising led by Venezuelan rebels causes Brazil to crackdown hard
In the mid 2000s, as the land gets more and more exploited by pollution, drug smuggling starts to become prevalent 
In 2009, the mining operations end because Brazil no longer has working equipment to extract resources 
In the 2010s, extreme weather and famines cause people to abandon the coast 
In 2013, with the start of the Brazilian Civil War, Peru is left to their own devices
In 2014 the pro-Brazil governor is overthrown and Peru devolves into civil war between far-left hyper maoists, far-right pro-Brazil fascists and exploitive cartels wanting to make a quick buck
In 2017, Argentina intervenes on behalf of the leftist faction 
In the 2020s, the war become Argentine-backed leftists fighting cartel members
In 2025, Argentina withdraws their support and Peru collapses into warlordism
By 2027, it is still in warlordism 
Bolivia (Population as of last census, 2020: 22,423,731)
In the 1970s goes the same as OTL with the Banzer coup in 1971
In the 1970s, oil and metal exports go up
Banzer is pressured by Morgan to hold elections
The first elections are held in 1978 and the right-wing military faction maintains a tenuous grip 
Throughout the 80s, multiple factions of the military orchestrate coups: two in 1979, one in 1980, two more in 1981, and another in 1982, then one last one in 1983. These alternate between far-left and far-right regimes
Things get so bad that the UN is forced to intervene in 1983 and create the Bolivian Mandate
The US, Europe and Canada work together to design a new system of government for Bolivia. 
This new government includes free-market capitalism introduced in a gradual way, and involved the provisional government taking out huge loans 
The first truly free elections are held in 1985 and the right-wing civilian conservative faction wins
Bolivia is considered one of the poorest countries in the world pre-1988
After the Crash of 88, Bolivia immediately collapses into civil war with far-left and far-right factions attacking UN peacekeepers who eventually leave during a diplomatic crisis in late 1988
Bolivia devolves into anarchy in 1989
In 1990, the anarchy resolves itself into a far-right fascist state in the north and a socialist far-left state in the south
In 1992, Brazil takes over the northern half of Bolivia
In 1993-1995 Brazil attempts to take over the southern half of Bolivia but is unable to attack their strongholds in the mountains 
In 1996, South Bolivia makes a pact with Argentina exchanging minerals (mainly lithium) for food
From 1992-2017 Brazil holds on to North Bolivia until Argentina takes it from the crumbling Brazilian Empire
In 2001, South Bolivia formally petitions to join Argentina
From 2001-2007 China helps set up mining equipment. These machines are extremely inefficient and damage the water table
In 2008 water pollution causes droughts in South Bolivia 
In the 2010s, Argentina invests heavily to keep Bolivia functioning 
In 2021, with the drought and water situation only getting worse, Argentina significantly scales back their operations in Bolivia though still occupies them 
As of 2027, Bolivia is the most unstable part of Argentina, with cartels and far-right Brazilian paramilitaries attacking every once and a while 
Paraguay (Population as of last census, 2020: 12,210,755)
Paraguay retains good relationships with Brazil and the US
President Morgan continues to send military aid to Paraguay to help them catch rebels and communists
In the 80s though this causes widespread corruption and drug trafficking to skyrocket
In the 80s, Paraguay has the highest income inequality in the world
In 1989, Graves cuts off all aid to countries, including Paraguay, and this causes the government to almost completely collapse
In 1989, Brazil attempts to keep Paraguay afloat with aid as they don’t want the “Argentine Mistake” to spread
Argentina however sends more aid to Paraguay, and this causes the two of them to maintain closer ties
In 1991, the new far-right Brazilian government attempts to annex Paraguay and set up a neutral buffer state between them and communist Argentina, but Argentina comes to their aid and helps defend them against Brazil
The Paraguayan War lasts from 1991-1994, and ends with Brazil retreating to invade their northern neighbors. 
From 1994-1999, Argentina heavily fortifies the border with Brazil, building a huge wall and mining the border
Throughout the late 90s, Argentina helps establish leftist governments which eventually join Argentina as an autonomous region in 2000
Due to Paraguay’s pre-1988 economy being mainly focused on black market trade and smuggling, their agricultural sector was minimal
Argentina builds lots of factories in the 2000s
In the 21st century, Paraguay is mainly used as training grounds and for industrial plants
Chile (Population as of last census, 2020: 41,197,488)
In the 1970s, Chile’s left-wing government succeeds as OTL
However, as part of the Shanghai Accords, the US isn’t allowed to overtly overthrow the Marxist president 
Instead, Chile was the subject of immediate and harsh sanctions, only receiving aid from places like Cuba and the USSR
The US wouldn’t have to wait long as Pinochet gained power just like OTL
The sanctions would still continue into the 1980s, when negotiations were entered and trade deals were reached in exchange for a return to a democracy 
In 1984, elections were held and a coalition of right-wing conservative politicians took over, coincidentally many of them were in Pinochet’s cabinet 
Throughout the 1980s this new government would carry out human rights violations in the guise of “anti-terrorism operations” and combating drug smuggling
In 1988, during the federal elections, it was revealed that they were tampered with when the conservative majority mysteriously won in a landslide despite the overwhelming popular support for the center-left candidate 
This turns into a military coup yet again, and while the far-right military government attempted to consolidate power, a far-left communist insurgency, aided by the USSR, starts to fight back
In 1990 during the Hot Summer, the far-right government gets defeated by the communist rebels 
In 1992, Chile makes an alliance with Argentina
In 2000, the Marxist government negotiates with Argentina to become an autonomous province 
In 2001-2005, China works with Chile to access resources but gives up due to extreme weather
By 2027, the Chilean Autonomous Region, despite being frequently beset with extreme weather, is actually a pretty chill place to live. Careful allocation of resources has kept soil mostly pollutant free and mining steady. 
Uruguay (Population as last census, 2020: 6,500,562)
In the 1970s, the far-left militias are less violent
This results in no military dictatorship, but the authoritarian civilian regime is supported by the United States to take out leftists
With no far-left terrorism, the attempted military dictatorship has a lot less legitimacy and public support
Because of no 1973 oil crisis, the economy gets better and in 1974 the authoritarian regime transitions to a democracy 
Modelling themselves on the USA, they begin privatizing large amounts of the government functions and social services in 1977
To help make their country seem more attractive to foreign businesses, Uruguay’s government began to sell out key positions to foreign investors. Companies could buy out the public transportation policy of a city, for example
In the 1980s, Uruguay becomes an experiment on minimalist government, with the state pretty much only providing security 
As such, tons of businesses move their headquarters to Montevideo
But with such an increase of wealth inequality comes crime: throughout the 1980s, drug trafficking (blamed on leftists) is common, with the UN engaging in an official Drug-Bust operation in 1984
In 1988, after the crash, the government is taken over by a bunch of organized crime syndicates, which hoard all the remaining food for themselves and their guards
In 1988-1989 Brazil supports this regime
In 1990, during the Hot Summer, things get so out of hand that the population explodes in a violent uprising. 
In 1991, aided by Argentina, a left-wing government takes over and begins massive wealth redistribution programs 
Uruguay's transition to a left-wing government alarms Brazil, and this spurs them to become a far-right dictatorship 
In 1991 Argentina sends the left-wing government military supplies, and joins Argentina to help defend Paraguay 
In 2000, around the same time as Paraguay, Uruguay joins Argentina as an autonomous region
The Brazilian-Uruguayan Border is heavily patrolled by both Argentine and Uruguay troops, with a large navy presence 
In 2014, Argentina would launch an invasion of weakened Brazil through Uruguay, taking over the states of Rio Grande Do Sul and Santa Catarina, which were added to Uruguay's territories in 2017
In the 2020s, Uruguay is hit by several famines and Argentina is forced to reduce their rations 
In 2027, Uruguay is able to still produce a lot of crops
Argentina (Population of core territories, after last census, 2020: 94,178,752)
Peron resumes power in 1974
In this timeline, due to the lack of an oil crisis, Argentina’s economy isn’t so bad in the 1970s
Peron doesn’t die in 1974, his heart attack and signs of pneumonia are caught early 
Peron dies in 1979 a national hero, and his third wife, Isabel, learned from his governing style and is more competent as a leader
One of the tenets of Peronism is neutrality and non-alignment, and as such Argentina abstains from allying themselves with the USSR or the USA/China
Isabel Peron rules from 1979-1982, after suffering from a heart attack and retiring from public view
In 1982, there is no Falklands war (maybe) and Alfonsín becomes president, campaigning on a more conservative, center right version of Peronism
Throughout the 1980s, the USSR and USA both try to woo over Argentina to their side of the economic spectrum. 
Argentina joins the non-aligned movement and creates several treaties and trade deals with Yugoslavia and India, this results in modernization of their factories 
Argentina resists the entire time all the way up to the crash of 1988
In 1988, the new president, Carlos Vicente Luis, campaigns on a platform of far-left Peronism with an emphasis on Latin-American unity
With Argentina not partaking in the free trade of the Glorious Decades and also being energy independent (Argentina has a huge amount of natural gas) they aren’t hit that bad by the Crash of 1988, instead getting only a recession 
In 1989, inspired by both the USA and the USSR, Argentina begins the rationing of petroleum and other energy sources
In 1990, after witnessing the Hot Summer and the chaos that was happening around the world, the President of Argentina makes the initially controversial decision to enact more left-wing policies including the nationalization of all companies and implementing a food ration
In 1991, after seeing the chaos in Uruguay, the government sends aid to them. Seeing the growing fascist nature of Brazil, Argentina puts their military on standby, expecting to see an invasion through their border with Brazil. Instead, Brazil invades through Paraguay 
In 1992, Chile and Argentina sign a pact of mutual defense and economic cooperation
From 1991-1994, Argentina, Uruguay and Chile fight Brazil in the Paraguayan War. Argentina sees a record number of citizens enlist in the war effort, and the government frequently parrots propaganda that Argentina is one of the few sane countries left. This sees a record rise in nationalism and patriotism
In 1994, the President, Alfredo José Falcón, elected platforms on a campaign of Peron-style socialism and South American unity
In 1994, when Argentina drives off Brazil from Paraguay, this is a huge morale boost and shows that even such a big country can be defeated by a much smaller one. It also makes many think that it proves left-wing economic models are better than right-wing ones. The USSR congratulates them in their victory against Brazil
In 1996, South Bolivia makes an alliance with Argentina
In 1994-1999, Argentina helps rebuild Paraguay and set up fortifications along their border with Brazil and also begins to establish more left-wing style governments in Paraguay
