In 2000, the new openly communist president, José Lorenzo Ramos, works with Paraguay, Uruguay and Chile to make them autonomous regions so that they can better survive the climate crisis. This new president says that the previous administrations didn’t go far enough and that only together can they hope to survive in the new millennium 
In 2001, South Bolivia becomes the next autonomous region of Argentina and the country officially reforms itself as the Democratic People’s Republic of Argentina. In 2001, when the country is formed, the population is 144 million
In 2003, Argentina joins the Alliance of Nations
Throughout 2001-2007, DPR Argentina cautiously works with China to retool their mining operations in South Bolivia and parts of Chile, mainly to mine coal as Argentina’s natural gas is running out
In 2005, a massive tropical storm forces China to abandon their operations in Chile
In 2006, Ramos wins a second term, and platforms to modernize the military. With the Warsaw Pact recently dissolved, they negotiate with Central Europe to buy several old warships
In 2007, Argentina officially severs ties with China and makes an alliance with the USSR
In 2008, after China has left, Bolivia’s water table becomes noticeably polluted which turns into a decades-long drought 
In 2012, the new president, Roberto Horacio Fernández, campaigns on a platform of collaborating with the USSR to modernize their energy. The USSR is reluctant, and only offers minimal support due to the long distances. In 2013, Voronin sends a few scientists to help push the Argentines in the right direction
In 2014, Argentina launches an invasion into weakened Brazil through Uruguay. The territory gained is eventually granted to Uruguay
In 2015, 2016 and 2019 famines due to heatwaves kill an estimated 25 million people total
In 2017, North Bolivia is taken over by Argentina
In 2018, Marina Santiago Roca, the second female president of Argentina, comes into power. She develops a nuclear program
In 2020, the total population of Argentina and her autonomous territories is 176,511,288
In 2021, Argentina begins pulling out of Bolivia
In 2022, Argentina begins colonizing the newly melted west Antarctican ice sheet
In 2023, Argentina organizes evacuations of parts of Chile and Bolivia
In 2024, Roca gets a second term and platforms on a campaign of expanding women’s rights, legalizing abortion for all women in the DPRA
In 2025, spillover from the Brazilian Civil War reaches Argentina and thus President Roca drafts more soldiers
In 2026, Argentina begins constructing a border wall
In 2027, Argentina is gearing up to wipe out Brazil once and for all

Island Nations: 

Cuba (Population as of last census, 2010: 22,190,622)
In the 70s, Cuba is skeptical of free trade and follows the USSR
However in 1983, with Agassi no longer in power, they are pressured to open up free trade. 
A trade deal in 1984 lifts the trade embargo and visa-free trade leads to a major exchange of ideas and culture from the USA and Cuba, and a huge tourism boom
Cuba withdraws from Angola in 1985
The Rectification Process of 1986 results in a huge service industry popping up in Cuba
In 1988, it all comes crashing down with Graves ending the trade deal. The Soviet Union attempts to keep Cuba afloat from 1989-1990 but soon it becomes too expensive and by 1991 Cuba is essentially on their own
In 1989, Castro gets very dictatorial and involves Cuba in wars again, including supplying Guatemalan rebels, Honduran Marxists, El Salvadoran Rebels, and Nicaraguan Guerillas 
In 1990, Castro takes over Guantanamo Bay and seizes all the US’s military equipment there. The soldiers are evacuated in secret by the Graves Administration but any involvement with Guantanamo Bay is covered up
In 1993 however, due to resource shortages, Cuba suspends all their operations in Latin America and becomes a hermit kingdom much like North Korea
In 1994-1997 strict reforms in rationing and population control leads to Castro barely holding on to power. A two-child policy is introduced in 1994. Martial law is declared in 1995, and penal labor is implemented in 1996. The country completely runs out of energy by 1997, leading to most lights being wood-burning fires
In 1998 and 1999 large storms in the Caribbean cause large amounts of refugees to flee to nearby Cuba where they are turned away by the Cuban navy
In 1998, due to resource shortages and allocation of farm land, livestock are made illegal and after 2000 eating meat is declared illegal. Then in 1999 the two-child policy is reduced to a one-child policy. Forcing everyone to be vegan, combined with the strict population controls, actually prevents any major famines
In 2000 the census estimates the population is sitting at a “stable” 20 million, mainly concentrated between Havana and Camagüey
In 2000, when China comes around, Castro almost declares war on them but instead only fires a warning shot
In the 2000s, constant tropical storms wear down the Cuban coast, leading to a policy of “declaring war on the winds” and building underground 
In 2001 storms and flooding cause much of the northern archipelago to be abandoned 
In 2002 a massive hurricane devastates Havana, leading to the capital of Cuba being moving to Camagüey
In 2003 a massive uprising from penal workers leads to the entire island of Isla de la Juventud to be abandoned by the government, devolving into anarchy
In 2004, the cramped conditions in the Santa Clara-Camagüey Corridor lead to an outbreak of cholera. The Cubans manage to keep the losses at only under 1000 but at huge material cost: alcohol is temporarily made illegal so it can be used to sanitize the cramped cities
In 2005, Cuba is almost destroyed by Hurricane Wilson. Fidel Castro is incapacitated and his brother takes over running the country. Most of the coastal cities on either end of the main island are abandoned due to flooding, and fall to anarchy and warlordism. Leaving a city requires a license. 
In 2006, Cuba begins a “national water reclamation” project, using chemicals to make rainwater safe for human consumption. Unfortunately, as a side effect, the chemicals make the water unsuitable for irrigation and leads to a minor famine later that year
In 2007, the country almost collapses into civil war but Fidel Castro manages to use his charisma to keep it together
In 2008, in a last ditch effort, the Cuban navy begins secretly raiding the ruins of islands in the Caribbean, using penal labor to scavenge for supplies, namely building materials, food, and electronics
In 2009 the situation gets slightly better, with the increase in material from the navy expeditions allowing for a marginal reduction in rationing and for reinforcing the remaining infrastructure 
In 2010 anarchists from the coasts and cartel members begin to encroach on the government territory, leading to a draft. The new recruits are notorious for deserting, easily swayed by the mind-altering drugs of the cartels
In 2011, the Red Flu makes its way to Cuba from cartel members. This results in the entire city of Santa Clara being quarantined, Fidel Castro dying from Red Flu, and the remnants of Cuba falling into civil war
From 2011-2014, the civil war rages on, deteriorating into warlordism and then finally anarchy. Cartels attempt to establish bases on Cuba but are driven out by the extreme weather. Civilians attempt to escape and usually end up being slaves in Central America, being killed by Klan members, or die at sea
In 2015 and 2016, during the Great Heatwaves, the last of the vegetation above ground dries up, forcing the remaining survivors further underground
From 2017-2027, Cuba is an abandoned wasteland. Scavengers and pirates occasionally pick over the ruins but are always driven out by the storms. An isolated network of PCC bunkers maintain contact but due to flooding and soil erosion, by 2027 only one of these bunkers remains
Antigua (Population as of last census, 1990: 214,714)
In 1976, the economic reforms are more successful and Antigua becomes a major vacation destination. 
They become independent in 1981 and join Bermuda. 
In 1988 after the depression and the end of tourism Antigua tries to become a tax haven but that doesn't work. 
In 1990 the president declares himself dictator. This causes a civil war that fizzles out into anarchy by 1992. 
By 2000, due to constant and powerful storms, the island is abandoned. 
Dominican Republic (Population as of last census, 1990: 20,882,615)     
In the 70s, tourism and international trade skyrocket
In 1979, Hurricane David results in only minor damage. It is quickly fixed by taking out loans from the IMF
In the 1980s economic issues don't happen and Guzmán doesn’t off himself
In 1988, after the crash, civil unrest from Haiti result in the Dominican Republic declaring war on their neighbor
In 1989, this fizzles out into a civil war
The Hot Summer of 1990 causes severe resource shortages and plunges the country into anarchy 
By 2000 the country is abandoned 
By the 2020s, much of the country is flooded
Bahamas (Population as of last census, 1990: 609,276)
Becomes independent in 1973 as in OTL. 
However, due to the inherent corruption of the PLP, in 1976 the country falls to a peaceful revolution backed by the USA.  
Immigration causes a boom in their economy, leading to a massive service industry and being the largest tourist destination in the 80s
The crash of 1988 leads to a military coup in 1989, and a reverse of the immigration situation: many tried to flee to America and Haiti due to the flooding
In 1990, part of the Hot Summer causes a massive tropical storm that destroys Nassau and creates a civil war
Throughout the 1990s, the Bahamas are depopulated 
By 2000 the islands are abandoned 
By 2027 the entire country is 2 meters below sea level (but just barely, the ruins of buildings still poke out into the sea) 
Barbados (Population as of last census, 1990: 478,911)
Tourism industry and economy skyrockets in the 1970s
The agricultural industry is destroyed in the 80s
After the crash of 1988, the economy dries up and the government goes bankrupt
In 1989 and 1990 law and order break down across Barbados, with the wealthy leaving for places like the USA
The Hot Summer of 1990 causes a humanitarian disaster as the poor bake in the heat 
In the 1990s the island is thoroughly depopulated and falls to warlordism between various pirate factions 
By 2000 the island is mostly abandoned due to international shipping disappearing 
By 2027 the island is 0.5 meters underwater
Dominica (Population as of last census, 1980: 128,519)
Gains independence in 1978 as in OTL
Hurricane David is much less destructive in 1979
Because of this, the economy skyrockets in 1980 with tourism exploding
No coup happens in the 80s
In 1988 after the crash the military takes over 
However in 1989 a massive hurricane destroys 90% of the island’s infrastructure and leads to over 90k deaths due to the lack of a coordinated disaster response 
In the 1990s the island is completely depopulated 
By 2027 the island is 1 meter under water with heavy winds destroying the buildings
Grenada (Population as of last census, 1990: 223,680)
Gains independence in 1974 as in OTL
In 1979 the communist coup happens just like OTL
However Bishop remains in power, and there is no military coup in 1983
Instead, in 1983, the USSR and Grenada begin talks about opening the country up to free trade
In 1983-1988 the economy slowly opens up to foreign investment but Bishop remains cautious 
In 1988, after the Crash, Grenada immediately begins a system of rationing and cuts off all exports. This is followed by making an alliance with Cuba
From 1988-1993 the Cuban-Grenadan pact keeps Grenada functioning but just barely 
In 1989 a ration protest leads to over 25 dead
In 1990, the Hot Summer causes a famine, and Grenada relies heavily on Cuban supplies to keep themselves functioning. An estimated 3500 people die from starvation 
In 1991 Bishop dies leading to a power struggle between his military commanders, but they sort it out quickly to continue receiving aid from Cuba
In 1992, due to deteriorating conditions springing from extreme weather, the military government of Grenada begins negotiations with Cuba about evacuating their citizens to Cuba. Elite members of the government are slowly evacuated 
In 1993 Cuba abruptly cuts off the aid and evacuation efforts, leading to the facade of order in Grenada crumbling into anarchy and warlordism
Grenada lasts a little bit longer than their neighbors, and a small amount of their population manages to escape to Martinique 
By 2004 the island is mostly abandoned and Hurricane Wilson destroys the last vestiges of civilization in Grenada 
By 2027 Grenada is 1 meter under water 
Haiti (Population as of last census, 1980: 22,978,143)
In the 70s and 80s, despite the rampant corruption, the country remains a popular tourist destination
Jean-Claude Duvalier’s wedding to a mixed race woman in 1980 isn’t as controversial and is actually celebrated
After the crash of 1988, Jean-Claude Duvalier runs away to the USA and leaves the country behind which falls into civil war
This leads to a border dispute in 1989 that results in the Dominican Republic invading Haiti, however they are just as unorganized as Haiti’s military and collapse into civil war
The Hot Summer of 1990 plunges the country into anarchy and warlordism
Storms throughout the 1990s cause many to flee 
By the 2000s most of the country is abandoned 
However by 2027, much of the Haitian side of the island is still above water, and occasionally cartel members pick through the ruins
Jamaica (Population as of last census, 1980: 4,936,655)
In 1972 Shearer isn’t defeated
The USA works with Jamaican authorities to eradicate the reggae movement. People like Bob Marley are arrested on grounds of “cultural crimes” and “adjacent communism” 
In the 1980s Jamaica is a big tourist destination with a huge service industry
After the crash of 1988, Jamaica rapidly transforms into a totalitarian marxist society in a violent revolution, with American tourists being held hostage in August 1988. President King’s VP personally went to Jamaica to negotiate with them, however he is delayed due to weather. 
In September 1988, a colossal storm devastates Jamaica, killing almost the entire population as a result of landslides, building collapses, drowning and chemical exposure
In the immediate aftermath, the United States evacuates the survivors (being only 4,963 people) 
Jamaica is completely abandoned by 1989, though throughout the 90s rebels, pirates and cartel members would occasionally stop on the island
By 2000 the island is so devastated by constant storms that it’s uninhabitable 
By 2027 most of the island is still above water, with only minimal land loss due to sea level rise
Saint Christopher-Nevis-Anguilla (Population as of last census, 1990: 76,362)
Independence succeeds as in OTL
However after the crash of 1988, due to the rapid economic decline, the countries petition to join the UK again but are rejected. Instead they form a federation between the three of them
The federation lasts for less than a year as civil unrest, resource shortages and a breakdown of law cause a civil war in 1989
However, in a rare case of humanitarianism in the Food, Incverse, the ruling Junta in 1990 orders the mandatory evacuation of all three islands and they land in Venezuela who are actually pretty chill with them, initially 
By 2027 most of the islands are under water
Saint Lucia (Population as of last census, 1990: 295,211)
Independence succeeds as in OTL
Hurricane Allen isn’t as strong in 1980 and Saint Lucia remains relatively prosperous with lots of tourists
Banana exports also increased during the 1980s
After the crash of 1988, rationing is introduced and exports are ceased
In 1989 and 1990, the government gets slowly more authoritarian and suspends elections
The Hot Summer of 1990 causes civil war to break out, and the fighting destroys crops and causes a famine
Throughout the 1990s the civil war deteriorates into warlordism and finally anarchy 
A hurricane in the late 90s forces the survivors to leave
By 2010, the island is completely abandoned 
By 2027, the island is 0.75 meters underwater 
Saint Vincent and the Grenadines (Population as of last census, 1990: 221,983) 
Independence succeeds as in OTL
Uniquely, tourism isn’t prevalent here: instead, intensive farming is set up for Bananas
The Economy still goes up though
Likewise, in 1988, the crash doesn’t completely wipe out the economy, instead causing a depression
The 1989 election results in a far-left politician winning, however the government doesn’t recognize the win as legitimate and it results in a civil war 
The civil war fizzles out by 1990 with the left-wing politician winning and establishing a planned economy 
Strict resource allocation and brutal repression keeps the country together through the Hot Summer
However, throughout the 90s, intensive agriculture combined with soil erosion due to strong winds cause increasingly devastating famines 
In 1997 the famines in addition to constant refugees leads to a civil war yet again with the government swinging to the far-right this time
In 1998 a genocide leads to almost 100,000 people dead
A Hurricane in 1999 ends up destroying the command center for the far-right junta and anarchy ensues
Throughout the 2000s, due to the rising sea level and extreme weather, people begin evacuating the country 
At first the warlords and remnants of the junta make it illegal and classify it as desertion, punishable by death, but Hurricane Wilson in 2004 makes them reconsider 
By 2010 the islands are evacuated 
By 2027 the islands are mostly underwater 
Trinidad (Population as of last census, 2000: 2,479,445)
Becomes a republic in 1976 like OTL
The black power movement is less violent in this timeline but more successful
In the late 70s the economy increases due to oil production
After the crash of 1988, a far-left group takes over the country and begins radical reforms
These reforms are initially viewed as popular by most of the lower class 
In the Hot Summer of 1990, spill over from the Venezuelan civil unrest causes Trinidad to close their borders
Due to their energy supplies, Trinidad is able to barely survive the Hot Summer but uses up a majority of their oil running farming equipment 
In 1991, Venezuela invades Trinidad. The dictator of Trinidad drafts up almost half the population and they put up a large fight but ultimately he surrenders in an attempt to keep his position. Instead he is executed
In 1992 Venezuela enters civil war and initially leaves Trinidad alone political infighting dominates Trinidad from 1992-1996
Tropical storms and flooding in the mid 90s cause much of the remaining population to be crammed into the north of the island
In 1997 a large flood causes famine that further ruins the political situation, collapsing into warlordism 
In 1998 Venezuelan guerillas begin using parts of Trinidad as bases in exchange for food
In 2001, Brazilian forces burn Trinidad to the ground in a scorched earth campaign 
From 2001-2004 Trinidad is in anarchy 
By 2010 Trinidad is abandoned due to rising sea levels and storms
By 2027 90% of Trinidad is under water

Egypt Coalition
United Arab Emirates (Still formed as in OTL. Growth is far faster than OTL, and economic aid from Britain helps overcome infrastructure bottlenecks. The Sheikhs do a lot of vanity projects, mostly fancy palaces and importing foreign works of art to fill their private mansions, but some of this does trickle down to the average person. A few even order studies on the effects of Oil Extraction on Nature (seeing how the healthy refineries and oil rigs made their private gardens far less fancy), but subsequently cover up and suppress the findings to save the economy. An entire new Capital City is erected between 1972 and 1985, called Dignity after a Referendum (Karma got 40% of the vote, but lost due to the Buddhist connotations of the word turning away some of the more conservative minded members of the populace), becoming a place of legendary opulence, with many post Great Death myths seen as originating from Glorious Decades Era Dignity. After the Arab Israeli War the country falls into chaos, with much of Dignity consumed by firestorms and subsequently reclaimed by the desert, but some expeditions by richer warlords (and a handful of foreign cultural initiatives) still head there as recently as 2023 to try and recover lost artifacts (with mixed success). Not shown on maps by 2000, uninhabited by 2004.
Bahrain (the 1965 March Intifada succeeds, but the country subsequently falls into chaos between the communist National Liberal Front, the Arab Nationalist Movement and the loosely leftist National Union Committee. The Soviets back the NLF, Egypt backs the Arab Nationalists while the NUC is given money by a very loose ,,I don’t want you to win, I want the others to lose” coalition including but not limited to their former enemies in Britain, the USA, and Iran. In 1967 the Popular Front, a Maoist Militia, broke off with the NLF and started their own side. Eventually, though, after years of constant war, the Union Committee won around 1969 and established a somewhat decentralized state, one that would hold elections in 1970. Said elections were won by the NUC-Aligned People’s Party, which would subsequently be re-elected in ‘75, ‘80 and ‘85. After Iran agreed to recognize the state’s independence in exchange for a stake in its Oil Industry, it soon began growing, trading with both sides of the Cold War (although charging the Soviets and Chinese higher prices for, you know, backing the losing side). With no Islamic Revolution in Iran to speak of, it remained quite prosperous, although the age old issues of corruption and wealth inequality (not as extreme as many other arab states, but Union Bosses often proved little better than their aristocratic predecessors - or were straight up one and the same in a few occasions) remained. In 1988, Brahin remained on the sidelines of the Arab Israeli War, although it was soon flooded with refugees. The Chairman of the National Union Assembly (the highest authority in the land) tried to take authoritarian powers to stop the crisis, but all this achieved was to cause a bunch of Unions to walk out and de facto begin a Second Civil War. This one did not see a conclusion, as by 1992, the country had collapsed into chaos, its remaining oil supplies too deep to be worth going after, especially given the risk of radiation poisoning. By 2000, not shown on most maps. A few Hindu Nationalists tried to eke out an existence here in the late 2010s, even taking over an offshore oil rig, but that too came to an end when the rickety, long rusting structure was swept away by a storm. 
Jordan (Jordan remains the PLO’s Main Backer throughout the 70s and 80s, experiencing rapid growth thanks to Jordanians working abroad sending their hard currency back to the country, allowing the Government to invest in infrastructure and improve the living standards of vast swathes of the populace. After a series of peaceful protests in 1983, the oppressive decrees of the late 60s were lifted and elections held - in 1984 and early 1988, respectively. The King would be beloved by much of the populace. The Mining Sector was especially profitable, although in spite of all of this the Military remained rather underfunded. This showed during the Arab Israeli War, as the Jordanian Army saw nothing but defeats until the Nuclear Conclusion arrived. Amman had a warhead lobbed straight at it, causing the collapse of Government, and following the subsequent near apocalyptic conditions most of the survivors ditched the land and fled elsewhere - some followed the PLO to their new promised land in Egypt, a handful went North to work alongside Islamic Warlords, and some even headed South in a vain hope to reach Somalia. The few who remained died out by the late 90s. Not shown on maps by the mid 2000s. 
Lebanon (With direct aid from the USA, Lebanon gets their Civil War somewhat under control, kicking out the PLO in the mid 70s and returning to their old position as a deregulated Financial Hub. One of the better places to be in the Middle East, and by the early 80s the Government rescinds most of their Emergency Powers and restores full Democracy, even if it’s a bit chaotic and plagued by ethnic conflict. When the War begins, Lebanon remains neutral, but that doesn't stop them from getting a healthy little dose of Radiation once everyone else nukes one another. The Government tries to keep a lid on things but the looting, mass panic buying and rioting stretch public services to their limit, with most local Governments (and the Central One) having collapsed by the Nuclear Winter of 1988-1989. The few that remain are plagued by the usual ills of post apocalyptic statecraft, namely abysmal cancer rates and horrific poverty. That said, it’s still not too bad, not until a band of Crusaders go down here in the mid 2000s and fuck everything up before dying of radiation poisoning. Lebanon’s remains never recover from that, and by 2015 it’s pretty much devoid of human life aside from a handful of real tough sonsovbitches hiding in basements or cellars and a handful of Crusader Outposts looking out for God knows what. 
Saudi Arabia (Invested a lot in other Arabic States to boost their economies. Their own economy was booming during the Glorious Decades, even more so than OTL, allowing for the Government to develop a generous welfare net while remaining a dictatorial and theocratic regime. Infrastructure is quickly developed. Riyadh faces civil unrest over the Government’s decision to mostly stay out of the Arab Israeli War, eventually forcing the King to declare War but only weeks after it actually begins. He gets a nuke lobbed at his capital for his trouble. After this, as expected, Saudi Arabia mostly collapses, although Mecca and Medina become independent ,,Islamic Republics” kept afloat by the still thriving pilgrimages, while in the mid 90s a group of Generals in the South get together and try to carve out a new homeland for Saudis in Yemen, and initially successfully manage to crush the feuding local authorities but fall to native revolt after it’s revealed they were stealing food to feed their own. Not shown on maps by 2000, although both Republics are doing somewhat fine (even if struggling with maintaining their utilities and their ageing population of clerics) given the circumstances. 
Syria (Assad decides not to antagonize Israel, since he has no backing from the Soviets or Egypt, and as such focuses on internal improvements. Under US Advisory, Syria begins to reform into a faulty Democracy - there are Elections, sure, but the Ba’ath Party still holds a majority of seats and is never ejected from power, with the opposition failing to ever consolidate and mostly consisting of a constantly shifting circus of small, seasonal parties formed along tribal lines. With Israel’s position stronger than ever, Syria doesn't intervene in Lebanon, instead focusing on economics - with oil prices booming, and china ever hungry for more produce to feed its labour pool, Syria soon becomes by far the most prosperous state in the Middle East, actually giving its citizenry a taste of their economic gains. Rural Areas are uplifted thanks to large scale infrastructure projects, with Assad consistently re-elected - many claim the elections are only for show, and while that is true, he does remain consistently popular with the people. He does keep the Military on his good side, though, and while the Syrian Army is not as strong as Egypt’s, it is still miles ahead of Jordan. When the Standoff begins, Syria surprisingly stands with other Arab States, which results in the USA pulling the plug on many of their investments. That doesn't last long enough to really bite into the prosperity, though, as the War goes Nuclear and the Syrian Government collapses. Multiple Nuclear Warheads are detonated in its territory, with Damascus turned into an irradiated wasteland and several other major cities merely pits of death and misery. In the following decades, the country becomes split among two rough lines, with the West ruled by ,,Neo Crusader” City States (huddling around the coastline) and the interior led by various Islamic Warlords, who could have rather easily driven the crusaders back into the sea if not for their constant infighting. That said, by 2020, the desert is so hellishly hot most of the Islamic States cease to exist, with only a handful of the most extreme ones holding on by pure fanaticism alone. The Coastal Warlords, meanwhile, grow closer together and form something of a mini EU for the sake of surviving together, actually rebuilding the city of Tartus after much of it is destroyed by a devastating storm (and the subsequent fires) in 2022. Not shown on maps by 1995, let alone 2000. 
Libya (Much like OTL, Libya’s Oil Profits give it one of the highest degrees of prosperity in all of Africa, while also keeping it relatively debt free. That said, Gaddafi’s many eccentric projects are also given extra funding thanks to this, and no opposition is tolerated. The Great Manmade River (a series of pipes made to give Libyans further inland access to drinking water) is further expanded. Minimum Wage Triples, rent reductions for the poorest citizens reach upwards of 60%, and thanks to even more Soviet Aid the cities of the coastline, most notably Tripoli, become hubs of opulence that made eyes water even among some Western Countries. Of course things go to shut during the Arab Israeli War, as after a short boom in prices the demand for oil plummets, and Gaddafi is pretty much forced to undo many of his reforms or risk total economic collapse. Hordes of refugees fleeing the Sahel also begin to cause trouble in the borderlands, and even the adoption of mobile,Territory Defense Units” that pretty much kill anything that even approaches the border doesn't help. By the late 90s, quality of life plummets as essential goods and services are rationed toward people who work in essential jobs and surveillance . In 2002, while he’s out in Moscow trying to convince them to send him some more cash, a popular uprising erupts that, you guessed it, soon escalates into a messy revolution and subsequently - civil war. It eventually turns into a brutal stalemate, with the rebels holding Tripoli and the Loyalists holed up in Benghazi. By 2006 it’s more like two city states that occasionally fight primitive naval battles and clash for whatever scrap remains in the no man’s land between them. By 2010 Tripoli fell to a rowing band led by a formerly Mauritanian Warlord, who sacks it and subsequently tries to use the stolen ships to sail to Italy before being blown to bits by the Federation Navy.  Benghazi holds on a bit better, but a storm in 2011 causes a collapse in law and order, with most subsequently leaving the ruins and leaving them to rot. By 2020, not shown on most maps. 
Kuwait (The Oil Fueled ,,Golden Era” never ends - with Saddam Hussein too busy being a Stooge of Moscow, he is not allowed to do anything that could endanger the Kremlin’s foreign relations. Kuwait develops an even more liberal culture than in OTL, with actual anti corruption programs and the Royals even giving up some of their powers in the early 80s for the sake of better PR in the West. Kuwait City is even considered for the host of TTL’s Arab League HQ, although that idea is eventually abandoned. For the first time ever, Kuwaiti - Iraqi relations become half decent, with Saddam agreeing to stop constantly molesting the borderlands in exchange for the small state agreeing to legalize its fringe Communist Party (the first meeting had a whopping 17 members attend, two of whom left by the end, accusing the newly elected Chairman of ‘Revisionism’). The Government throws a lot of money at cultural programs like Theatres ‘n shit. When the Nuclear War comes, there is actually a bit of a tug of war inside the Parliament on if they should back their traditional Iranian Allies or maybe show Solidarity with the Arab World and declare war on the Israelis. Both options are shit in their own right, so the Emir decides to sit things out. As the Nuclear Apocalypse begins, the country is immediately hit with the environmental aftermath and de facto collapses due to waves of Iraqis fleeing to perceived safety within its walls. It fell from one warlord to another for a few years before mostly settling down as an overcrowded refugee port by 2000, although its population dwindled from that point onward as disease and horrible living conditions took their toll. In 2027, Kuwait City still (suprisingly) stands, but for the most part it's just the surviving refugees forming a proto state of several colonies inside the Al Salam Palace and Grand Mosque (the Kuwait Towers also held a group of survivors until they collapsed in 2019), surrounded by slowly rotting architecture and slightly fresher dusty, lifeless slums, signs of two ages long gone - an age of optimism, and an age of thinking tomorrow was worth living to see. The rest of the country is abandoned. 
Qatar (the 1972 Palace Coup fails, and so Qatar becomes the Black Sheep of the Middle East - sure, it grows very prosperous, with its GDP breaking records by growing 1,800% from 1971 to 1988, but very little of that actually trickles down to the average person, with the vast majority of this cash wasted on vanity projects by the Nobility - one of which literally consists of burning money as a status symbol. They don’t bother to buy tons of foreign works of art like the Liechtenstein Government, or to make their own like the Kuwaitis, instead they hire “controversial” artists to create the most kitschy works imaginable. Honorable mentions include the world’s largest chair, a Banana Plantation in the middle of the desert tended to exclusively by former Government Officials, and a small (only about 25% of the size of the original) replica of Mount Rushmore, except with the faces of the largest donors instead of US Presidents (the donations covered over 150% of the project’s total cost, leaving a hefty profit for the designer, even when one of the quartet demanded that their teeth be made with Ivory instead of stone). Qatar didn’t give much of a shit about World Politics, and to not piss off their American trade Partners they stayed out of the Arab Israeli War, which provoked mass civil unrest. Right as the Nukes fell the country itself collapsed into Civil War, mostly fought with sharp tools and melee weapons due to a lack of firearms (the Government defunded the Military and Police to fuel their debauchery), and in the ensuing chaos it was rapidly overwhelmed by waves of refugees. By 2000, very few remained, not having succumbed to starvation and radiation, with even the hardened survivors dying out by 2010, their bleached bones slowly drying in the shadows of Osymandian Statues, perfect time capsules of the Glorious Decades. Unlike Kuwait, nobody bothered to risk men to save those “works of art”, and so many of them still stood in half decent condition by 2027 (aside from the World’s Largest Chair, some of which was chopped up into firewood in the 90s and the rest burning down due to a lack of maintenance somewhere around 2004-2006). Not shown on maps by 2000.
Oman (Things go even better than OTL, with the Consultative Assembly slightly more powerful and social services further boosted by the discovery and subsequent exploitation of Oil. Things are calm after the rebels are crushed in the mid 70s. Oman stands alongside the other Arab States against Israel, and while no nukes are lobbed at it, spillover from Yemen’s Civil War, mass pollution, oil fires blackening the skies and the death of much of the Government cause it to spiral into chaos and not recover. Not shown on most maps by 1995, not on any by 2005.
Yemen, North (Remains poorer than south due to Saudi hostility and less connections)
Yemen, South  (No 1979 War means no Civil War, opens up due to big COMECON Connections. Both states begin to fight after Soviet Assistance dries up in the early 90s, the Civil War escalates after both are cooped by ambitious Generals, eventually the Saudi Remnant Intervenes, tries to set things up as a sort of Redoubt, fail due to native revolt. By 2000 mostly abandoned outside a few enclaves, even they wither away by 2010. On Maps, if shown, still shown as North and South Yemen.)
Iraq (Population: 57,239,804, circa 1980)
In the aftermath of the Tehran Accords, Iraq turned to an unlikely ally: the USSR
PLO members from Jordan and Lebanon move here in big numbers, eventually become qatifists 
After the failed Iranian Revolution, Iraq signs several treaties with the USSR and even starts to develop their own nuclear energy program, though in secret 
Iraq offers to allow the Islamic Socialists from Iran to live in Iraq
In the 1980s, Iraq starts building up their military, with many believing that they are planning to invade Iran 
However, in 1988, when Iraq joins the Egyptian Coalition, they unveil the true reason for their build up: the invasion of Israel 
Bagdad is one of the places nuked, with many other locations in Iraq nuked 
Between 1988-1990, Iraq falls to chaotic civil war
Qatifists try to gain access to their nuclear arsenal
By 1991 though, there are no victors, and massive oil fires have burnt down much of the country 
By 2000, it is completely abandoned 
Great Iraqi Oil fire
By 2027, it is so hot that Iraq is incapable of supporting any life - in some areas, like in India and Pakistan, where the nukes actually created tiny wildlife sanctuaries, Iraq is completely and utterly uninhabitable 
Egypt (Nasser’s successor is not Sadat but someone more openly Pro Soviet. This means the Israelis never give up the Sinai. The Soviets, worried about potentially tying China further the the USA (Still deluding themselves into thinking that Chenism was just a phase that they’d grow out of) convince the Arabs to not launch the Yom Kippur War, else their foes be united in support of Israel. The Egyptians begrudgingly agree, instead focusing on cobbling together an alliance for a future War - which would later grow to be the Arab Coalition of ‘88. For now though, they do this under the guise of closer economic integration, in the vein of other major such unions like COMECON. Instead he focuses on internal reforms, like giving land to poor families, which helps agriculture get back on its feet. The Profits of the Glorious Decades allow for Cairo to invest a lot into their Military, which slowly grew stronger during the 80s. By 1988 they feel confident enough to challenge Israel, and we all know how that ends up. After the Nuclear War, the Government collapses into infighting, with various Military Warlords and Islamic Statelets emerging. Eventually the PLO, which underwent its own "Long March” from the irradiated hellhole of Palestine, manages to take over the remaining fertile lands in the Nile Delta and pretty much forms the nexus of a new civilization. By 2000, though, they were struggling as the Nile became far less predictable, with its levels nearly drying up or causing horrible floods seemingly at random due to climate change. The other states, due to the radiation, sandstorms and desertification, mostly die out by that point too. That said, using a network of basements and the never completed Cairo Metro (a sort of vanity project by the country’s final President, chosen after the death of Nasser’s Successor in 1986) they form a literal ,,underground state” in a sort of ironic echo of what the Israelis were doing. By 2020 not shown on any maps. 
Neutral Arab States 
Algeria (The 1965 Coup doesn't happen as the Military decides to bide their time, instead manipulating the Administration behind the scenes like a bunch of Creons instead of moving against the Popular President. While, as can be expected, the state remained corrupt and often influenced by special interest groups, it did develop a somewhat healthy Democratic System, with two parties peacefully exchanging power on several occasions and multiple cabinets actually surviving their term without the need for snap elections. The Oil Boom means the country becomes very prosperous, and while a large cut of the profits goes toward the Military and Elites, much is still left to the average citizen, raising living standards. The country’s third president, elected in 1982 and then re-elected five years later, establishes a robust welfare system and actually reconciles many of the feuding religious groups in a widely publicized conference. Of course, he faces accusations of infidelity, but they’re disproven rather quickly. As can be expected, the Economy collapses alongside the prices of Oil in late 1988, and the President is impeached by the People’s National Assembly for incompetence, but the various parties and factions subsequently bicker for very long about who to elect in his place, with a variety of candidates - including the President of the Assembly, a popular footballer, and a General in the Armed Forces - discussed and falling through. Said General, very salty, stages a coup and subsequently turns the country into a Militarized Dictatorship, trying his best to keep the Southern Border intact and turn the country toward self reliance. However, a horrifying drought in 1996 forces hundreds of thousands to flee north, causing ethnic tension as locals usually don’t want to share with the newcomers, escalating into outright violence and riots. By 1998 the situation was out of control, with a four sided civil war (all of the sides are Dictatorships, but two are led by Civilians and two by Military Men, all of whom are from different groups) that mostly fizzled out by 2000 (not helped by the refugees forming their own statelets). Algiers proclaimed independence from one of the sides ( the ,,People’s Government of Algeria”, a somewhat Socialistic affair led by a former Minister of the Interior) and became an independent city state, one that was nevertheless flooded in 2009 and not rebuilt. Not shown on most maps by 2000, and not on any by 2010. 
Tunisia (The Democratic Constitutional Rally, a loose alliance of Socialists and Arab Nationalists, still established a repressive dictatorship, but the modernization process was far quicker than in OTL thanks to Tunis openly aligning itself with the Soviets to mooch off foreign aid. The rise in prosperity was not as sharp as in other states, due to Tunisia already being quite well off (especially for African Standards), but it was noticeable nonetheless. They still aided the PLO but refused to participate in the Arab Israeli War. In the subsequent chaos, combined with a rapid end to all Soviet Funding, the country began to teeter on the brink, with the CRD becoming increasingly authoritarian as time went on.  The President was cooped by his prime Minister, who subsequently tried to realign with the West and do a mass Privatization Program, but the Graves Administration was not interested, and Europe remained sceptical of such a formerly Socialist man suddenly having a ,,change of heart”. As such, his liberalization gave him no benefits at all, and the people started to get angry. To try and salvage the situation the President pretty much admitted defeat and evacuated everyone he considered worthy to a newly erected “Tripolis Fortress City”. The rest of the country fell into two separate camps - the Northern ,,Tunesian Liberation Front”, which called for a return to Glorious Decades era Centrally Planned Economics, and the ,,Democratic Union” which wished to instead try and beg the West for Assistance. Both fell by 2000, although Tunis managed to hold on. The President was assassinated in 2002, and since that point the office had around a dozen holders by 2010, none of whom held it for longer than half a year. As Libya collapses too, so does Tripoli, finally overwhelmed by the hostile weather and bands of remaining refugees. Not shown on most maps by 2020. 
Morocco (Prince Moulay becomes King instead of Hassan, ushering in an age of Liberalization and moderate Democratic Reform. A Bicameral Parliament is born and subsequently forms several successful governments, all while Morocco profits from the phosphate boom and invests in becoming what amounts to a tax haven, using the profits to develop a healthy tourism industry. After Moulay dies of cancer in 1981 (earlier because of the shit in the air), he’s replaced by his son (also Moulay), the ,,Red Prince”, who ushers in more progressive (mostly feminist) reforms and strengthens his father’s welfare net. The mid 1980s see increasing investments in education and the passage of a new constitution, one that reduces the monarch to a purely ceremonial figure. For a while, after the crisis, things go on as normal, until the decline in trade makes their economy highly unstable. The Government cuts back on welfare, much to the public’s chagrin, but has enough public credit to keep things going for the time being. The illusion of normalcy (with Elections and decent living standards) continues until 1996, when a drought fucks up much of the interior and forces the Prime Minister to decleare Martial Law. Living conditions continue to decline, and when the Algerian Civil War spills over in 1999, a Revolution (somewhat backed by Moscow, as they want the phosphate) happens and a Republic is proclaimed, one that immediately collapses into infighting between a ,,locally grown” so to speak Socialist Wing and Pro Moscow Communists. This escalates into a Civil War that degenerates into anarchy by 2003. Not shown on maps by 2010, although it remains a popular destination for various scrap hunters, who even set up temporary (building anything permanent with the storms is a fool’s errand) towns on its coastline, under the shadow of long dormant high rises and towns buried by the sands of time. After the anarchy, the federation comes in and sets up a puppet state
Mauritania (The Mauritian People’s Party remains as Authoritarian as OTL, but the development process is even faster than OTL. Iron Mines are exploited to their fullest extent, and a reckless program of fishing means that there are signs of those pleasant animals going the way of the dodo as early as 1985. However, most ignore this, and the nomadic populace is herded into those newly built Industrial Sites as little more than slaves to fuel the President’s Economic Agenda. Droughts caused by even harsher climate change mean that more and more are forced to move to the cities for work, and even by 1988 certain areas of the country are de facto unpopulated aside from Law Enforcement and Military Units sent to keep any potential dissidents in line and stop enemy incursions. Without any stupid incursion into the Sahara, the country remains decently prosperous, even if plagued by endemic corruption and on shaky ground, with wages and whatever welfare exists adjusted to the international prices of iron. As the Crash Happens, the President tries to calm people down but is killed by a hand grenade on Live Television, being succeeded by a cabal of Slaveowners. Some are Industrialists and some are Agricultural Barons, but they’re united in their support of the practice. The Ban on Slavery is reversed and before long the country goes full on Autarkic, and after they work the ,,lesser” castes to death they begin raiding neighboring countries for their citizens. This proves a terrible mistake, as someone (it was never proven who) bombs the Capital in 2002, causing a collapse of the ,,Government” with the exception of a couple coastal port towns. The interior is completely consumed by the Sahara. By 2010 not shown on maps.
Somalia (Under Barre’s rule, thanks to a tug of War between the USSR and China, it receives a lot of aid. He mostly focuses on internal improvements, like fixing the literacy rate, curbing corruption and fighting rural poverty. Annexes Djibouti in 1974. Thanks to his newfound links to the Arab World, the Ogaden War never happens because international mediation sees Somalis in Ethiopia be given Autonomy and both states sign various treaties to facilitate trade. Neither side is happy but they also don’t want to lose out on lucrative international loans and benefits. As the 80s begin, Barre definitely turns away from the USSR and endorses limited scale Private Growth, causing them to pull out but further enriching the country as China pretty much uses Somalia as a testing ground for their later haphazard adventures in Africa during the 2000s. As the Glorious Decades come to a close, with their economy pretty much fully based around food, they remain semi comfortable until around 1990, when water acidification kills off their fisheries, foreign business pulls out,and several sandstorms fuck up whatever agriculture remains. Barre tries to salvage the situation by invading Ethiopia, and as expected his peasant levy gets their asses handed to ‘em by the semi professional Ethiopian Army. In the aftermath of this, the country collapses into anarchy, with pirates hunting whatever little commerce remains in nearby waters and the rest trying to barter off Barre’s achievements as scrap in exchange for food. There aren’t too many takers, though, and a flow of Yemeni (or further northward, fleeing through Yemen) refugees doesn't help. Around 2000 mogadischu is taken over by a semi competent theocrat who begins a campaign to reunite the country, and actually manages to carve out a sizable fief in the center of it, but is killed when the Ethiopians bomb him as a ,,border security operation” and his lieutenants collapse into infighting shortly afterward. By 2010, as piracy dries up and the environment becomes borderline hellish, Somalia becomes heavily depopulated, with many people even trekking into the interior to become ,,associates” (slaves) of the Water Lords. Many don’t make it. Not shown on most maps by 2020, although some Communist States (mostly ones formerly aligned with China, or China itself) insist their comrades in Somalia are still just fine.
Djibouti (Uprising in the early 70s after another rigged Independence referendum, succeeds in expelling the French with Soviet aid, merges with Somalia. As the country begins to collapse in the 90s, Djibouti proclaims Independence, only to immediately be invaded by Ethiopia. Addis Ababa sucks everything of worth out of the province - not that there’s much, with their main source of income, the Port, useless due to a lack of trade. They too leave around the year 2000 and leave the area in anarchy, with most inhabitants fleeing or dying of radiation poisoning brought from the North with winds. Depending on your nation’s political affiliation, shown as part of either Ethiopia or Somalia by 2010. )
Israel 
Israel (Population: 8,683,789, circa 1980)
Israel keeps Sinai, and Egypt’s new Pro-soviet government makes Israel cautiously peaceful 
Israel signs the Shanghai Accords in 1978
Without the Yom Kippur war, Israel is able to focus more on their internal matters
Israel is suspicious of it though, and starts researching bunker ecology, desalination, nuclear power and many other things on how live underground, fearing an invasion or nuclear war between China and the USSR
Instead of settling the West Bank and Gaza, Israel settles the shores of Sinai, letting the PLO simmer
Israel turns much of the Sinai into lavish resorts in the 1980s 
The influx of Jews from around the world (such as the USSR) create further rifts within the Israeli government, which almost falls to civil war in 1983 after a constitutional crisis 
Throughout the Glorious Decades, Israel mainly keeps to themselves, instead focusing on using financial leverage against their enemies (namely Iraq and other Arab countries) 
The only thing keeping Israel as a country is support from the USA, as Israel becomes the most militarized country on the planet 
Israel also develops their nuclear weapons all the way back in 1973, though after TMI, they scale it back and allegedly dispose of them
In april 1988, the new leader of Egypt starts aggressively claiming that Sinai should be returned to Egypt. The PLO also starts ramping up their operations 
On May 15, 1988, Egypt and their coalition invade Israel, leading to the Sinai War
On June 8th, 1988, Israel launches their nukes, causing the collapse of civilization 
In summer of 1988, Israel falls to civil war and a radical fundamentalist authorizes the expulsion of all Arabs from Israel and parts of Lebanon, Jordan, Syria, Saudi Arabia and Egypt, after December 31st, 1988, all Arabs will be killed on sight
In 1989, Israel activates their “Ark Protocol”, and retreats to many underground bunkers beneath their tourist destinations. It turns out that these bunkers, made to be relatively self-sufficient, are all connected and span the length of Israel and into parts of the Sinai
Between 1989-1990, as people are evacuated into the bunkers, various fundamentalists try to attack Israel, with the IDF shooting on sight 
By 1991, Israel has severed diplomatic relations with the rest of the world, and begins setting up tons of traps/mines on the surface to dissuade refugees from entering the Kibbutz complex 
On January 1st, 1992, the last IDF soldier retreats underground and for the most part, Israel’s status is left as a mystery 
In the late 1990s, Israeli “exiles” begin showing up in Jerusalem, which has been settled by Arab refugees. Turns out that in the bunkers, it was a waste of resources to feed or even execute prisoners, so they send them to the surface. These groups eventually form gangs for survival, and start to pillage the ruins on the surface. They also claim that every male had to deposit some of their sperm to be frozen, and then was forcibly sterilized 
In 2001, the largest of these gangs, the largest of which is the “Followers of Cain”, kicks out the last arabs from Jerusalem, which then causes it to turn into a warzone 
In the 2000s, the Israeli exiles and the Arabs duke it out, with neo-crusaders from Europe joining in as well 
By 2011, much of Israel’s automated defenses have been exhausted, with their SAMs depleted and many of their mines detonated. Some entrances to the Kibbutz system have been attacked by outsiders, and the IDF enacts a policy of preemptively severing contact with the bunkers to prevent them from “contaminating” the survivors of Israel. A few of these cut-off bunkers become havens for Israeli Exiles, Arab terror groups, and one in Qiryat Shemona even becomes the headquarters for the Order of Paul
In 2014, radiation begins leaking out into the Mediterranean
In 2015 and 2016, several Israeli exile groups band together to try to dig their way back into the bunker complex, and in 2017 they finally break into a bunker under Arad. This leads to a series of battles between the IDF and the invaders 
In 2018, several Israeli bunkers authorize the “koch drach oyvim” program, basically recycling arab flesh for food
Between 2017-2024, various areas of Israel stop sending automated messages. The bunker complexes used coded messages to communicate, and gradually, bunkers go dark. In 1992, it was projected that 236 bunkers existed in the Kibbutz system, but by 2025, only thirteen bunkers still produce signals 
After the solar flare, all 12 remaining bunkers stopped transmitting 
As of 2027, the status of Israel is unknown 


Australia (Population: 36,845,591, Circa 2020) 
Politics: 
1969-1972: John Gorton, LNP
1972-1983: Gough Whitlam, ALP 
1983-1990: Bob Hawke, ALP
1990-1997: Bob Hawke, AALLP
1998-2016: Callum Fraser Dorrington, AALLP
2016-2025: Malcolm Clark Rhyder, GSP 
2025-2029: Damien Harkness Reid, GSP
LNP: OTL Liberal-National Party, Centre-Right
ALP: OTL Australian Labor Party, Centre-Left
AALLP: Australian Alliance of Liberals and Labor Party, a coalition formed after the Crash of 1988, Left-Wing with a touch of social conservatism and heavily focused on environmentalism. Anti-immigration, extremely protectionist, anti-military, oversees the union with New Zealand
GSP: Green Socialist Party, an originally fringe party formed in 1991 by people who believed that the AALLP wasn’t doing enough. Centre-right, eco-fascist, syndicalist government that is very nationalistic and pro-military, wants to formally take over Antarctica and New Zealand. After the Chinese attack on the navy, nationalism skyrocketed and under Reid, Australia began to prepare to take Antarctica “by force” from those “Godless commies” in Patagonia
In 1972, Australia does not sign the Shanghai accords
In 1972, a whole slew of welfare policies are enacted, like increased welfare payments, legalizing divorce, healthcare was nationalized, education was made completely free. Australia unofficially recognizes the Maoist enclave in Moscow as the true government of China, and not Chen. Australian troops are withdrawn from Vietnam, and relations with the US become strained over refusal to sign the Shanghai Accords and also ending their involvement in Vietnam. Grants for the arts are also made. The work week is limited to 36 hours, and 18 months maternity leave is given to both parents (though they cannot take it at the same time). A pension is made to support single parents, and civil rights laws are passed on the same level as the US (in this time line, the civil rights movement is far less polarizing and discrimination purely based on race is pretty much nonexistent) - Pretty much it’s a welfare utopia
Australia does not establish diplomatic ties with China or Taiwan
In 1973, relations with the aboriginals become very close, with a specialized welfare system and a sort of “affirmative action” program 
Despite not signing the Shanghai Accords, Australia’s economy still grows, just not nearly as fast as other countries 
In 1975, the negotiation for getting loans to extract minerals is more successful. India, South Korea and Argentina would help fund the extraction 
March 23, 1975 - Australia legalizes birth control after doing research into thalidomide and the pill 
In 1976, Australia helps resettle indochinese refugees, mainly to their outlying islands. Australia also sees a lot of emigration of Australian citizens out to other countries like Japan, Western Europe, and North America. 
In 1977, the ANZUS treaty collapses due to Australia and New Zealand’s refusal to help fight in Vietnam War and their stance against nuclear weapons
Summer 1980 - Evidence of coral bleaching is found off the coast of Australia, prompting research into climate change and the effects of industrialization on the environment 
In the 1980s, Australia actually BANS research extraction on areas that could damage the environment, mainly Tasmania
In the 1983 election, Bob Hawke wins as in OTL but he is much more popular
Hawke’s foreign minister though is a bit more involved with the non-aligned movement, and Australia officially joins it, eventually becoming the leader of it in 1988
Under Bob Hawke, trade unions are protected and Australia is one of the few countries to actually have worker’s rights enforced 
In 1984, Australia actually makes birth control non-taxable. Hawke also gradually lifts tariffs and opens Australia up to outside trade, though they still do not sign the Shanghai Accords or join a trading bloc
Hawke doesn’t reduce the government this much ITTL, nor are parts of it privatized 
February 26, 1986 - Australia outlaws Chlorofluorocarbons 
In 1987, Australia officially federalizes and removes all legal influence from the UK
In 1988, representation of Aboriginals is increased on the federal level
After the crash of 1988, PM Hawke is advised to ban immigration, to which he agrees. He also authorizes a program to pay for the safe passage of Australian expats around the world, with a deadline of returning by December 31st, 1988. The Christmas, Cocos-Keeling, and Norfolk Islands are also to be evacuated by this date 
In 1989, Australia makes several deals with neighboring islands and countries (like New Zealand, Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines. Japan is considered but not contacted) and sets up many trade deals 
Later in 1989, Hawke sets up a rationing system for oil to phase it out and to build more nuclear power plants (at this point, Australia’s sole nuclear power plant is located in the middle of the outback three KM from Kalgoorie). Oil is completely phased out by 2000
In 1990, the LNP disbands with many of the moderate liberals jumping ship to join the labors and they create the AALLP party, with Hawke as its leader. He gets reelected in the aftermath of the Hot Summer of 1990, after which Australia creates the Department of National Stability - a governmental organization that focuses on mitigating brushfires, famines, drought, and also researching alternative energy sources
Throughout the 1990s, 10 nuclear power plants are built, with 35 more being planned. In the meantime, solar and wind power is slowly developing. Rationing is enforced in 1997, a one-child policy is enforced in 1996, and in 1995, the justice system is overhauled by having criminals work as laborers in the outback. This is very successful at deterring law-breakers. Advances in arcology are made, with massive apartment blocks being built to house rural migrants as they move towards the cities as the government engages in massive rebuilding projects. These projects provide jobs and help the economy, while also implementing nature better into cities. 
In 1995, Australia joins the Alliance of Nations, but never hosts a meeting. 
How does Australia develop all this stuff? Well, they actually use the various islands in the pacific as test beds for the technology. Some islands are the site of humanitarian disasters after prototype nuclear batteries catch fire and burn down entire towns. Australia’s security service sweeps these under the rug, but Hawke’s opposition, Dorrington (a liberal moderate who jumped ship in 1990) exposes it and uses it to force Hawke to resign. 
Under Dorrington’s government, further advances in arcology are made, with community gardens being heavily encouraged in every community. Dorrington also initially rescinds the ration policy
In 2003, the Red Summer causes Australian emergency services to be overwhelmed as cases of heat stroke and dehydration skyrocket, while also leading to a famine. Dorrington is forced to reimplement rationing. He gives the executive order for mandatory evacuation into one of 15 “mega cities” along the coast, with the deadline for everyone to move out by 2015. He begins working with several prominent members of the aboriginal community to create “reservation cities” for them, if they want, though many choose to remain in the coastal mega cities
In 2004, Australia begins researching more cost-effective ways to desalinate water. It starts out slow, but continues to be more and more necessary 
In 2005, a massive brushfire burns down Darwin and much of the northern coast line. Contact and trade with outlying nations like Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines gradually become less frequent  
In 2006, Australia begins retrofitting their navy to use nuclear power
In 2007, pirates and illegal refugees are becoming more frequent, leading Australia and New Zealand to form a military alliance and having their navies work closely to patrol their coasts
By 2008, all remaining companies in Australia are controlled by unions
Also in 2008, the Red Flu reaches Australia through a boat of people fleeing Indonesia, leading to a strict quarantine in Cairns
In 2009, a scandal involving miners falsifying where they dump their refuse leads to stricter laws about land management, though the union bosses and the government remain relatively hostile towards each other
In 2010, while most secondary and tertiary education is still free, only primary education is readily offered by the government. Citizens must take an exam, and if they show enough aptitude they are allowed to go to secondary school, and must take a similar exam to go into tertiary school. If they fail either exam, they instead go to a trade school and get a union-provided job 
Most popular professions in Australia from 2000-2016 is being a farmer, post 2016 it is being in the armed forces/militia/police
In 2011, due to the Purple Summer, certain livestock such as sheep, pig, and cattle are banned, with most animal protein coming from vertical chicken farms and later on, Emu farms
In 2012, advances in desalination technology have led to practically limitless clean water. Coupled with advances in solar technology, Australia is completely self-sufficient with energy 
In 2013, overtures from the UK, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and USA all try to pressure Australia into exchanging technology, but Australia remains extremely isolationist. 
In 2014, China tries to invade Australia. This is a huge turning point in Australia’s identity. Enlistment skyrockets, and Australia begins talks with unifying with New Zealand
In 2015, large seawalls are built in South Australia 
The Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2016 cause Australia to ban working during the day, and switching to closed off greenhouses
In 2016, capitalizing on the invasion, Rhyder is elected on a platform of militarizing Australia to prevent further invasions. Australia gradually becomes more and more fascist, with labor unions and state governments declining in power with the federal government becoming more and more powerful. He also begins secretly developing a nuclear program
In 2017, Australia and New Zealand finalize their union, with New Zealand merging their armed forces with Australia but remaining autonomous in internal affairs 
In 2018, a massive tropical storm forces the evacuation of the remaining islands in Australia’s sphere of influence. Despite being technologically supported by Australia, and even having a work program where they could earn citizenship, Australia refuses to evacuate them. Instead, New Zealand offers to resettle them in the northern island. 
In 2019, the old penal system is abolished and now criminals are simply sent “to the outback” 
Also in 2019, ANZ begins researching and developing blimps and other dirigibles for air transport
In 2020, the ANZ navy begins shooting unidentified boats on sight 
In 2021, the New Zealand armed forces are retrofitted to use nuclear or solar power. Reconnance blimps, used by the state security forces and the army, are a common sight in ANZ
In 2022, the new zealand economy becomes entirely intertwined with Australia’s after the Rhyder government begins building sea walls in New Zealand
In the Second Great Heatwave of 2023 and 2024, NZ is plagued with drought, leading to Australia to exercise more control over their allocation of land, resources, and city infrastructure. Desalination plants are built, along with solar and wind farms, though NZ refuses to build any nuclear power plants on their shores
In 2025, Reid is elected PM, and he is even more nationalistic than Rhyder was
Even with all the advanced arcology and brutally efficient resource allocation, ANZ still faced a major famine in 2024 and as such, in 2025, Australia begins looking into using the rapidly melting Antarctica to expand their farms
In 2026, Australia begins researching more efficient ways of building vertical farms, along with what it would take to colonize Antarctica. They also start preparing for war with Argentina
After the solar storm of 2026, much of Australia’s infrastructure is permanently damaged. Several nuclear power plants go critical, blowing up 4 cities and leading to almost 10 million deaths. As radiation begins to spread across western Australia, the government realizes that they need to bug out and fast. A campaign to colonize Antarctica is drawn up, while emergency bunkers are built in the Tasmanian reserve. 
As of 2027, ANZ is fighting tooth and nail for control of Antarctica. Citizens are being evacuated from Australia to NZ, and plan to be resettled in Antarctica. 
Why are they invading? Australia’s meteorological society predicts that due to the increased climate change, it’s predicted with near 100% certainty that a devastating “hypercane” would form in the Pacific
New Zealand (Population: 6,478,121, circa 2020, New Zealanders, 1,543,925 refugees) 
Politics: 
1972-1975: Norman Kirk, Labor
1975-1978: Robert Muldoon, National
1978-1984: Bill Rowling, Labor
1984-1987: David Lange, Labor
1987-1990: Jim Bolger, National 
1990-1999: Jim Anderton, New Labor
1999-2011: Te Ariki Mātene Raukawa, Islanders Party
2011-2020: Elliot Tamati Fraser, New Labor
2020-2023: Moana Iosefa Ngata, Islanders Party 
2023-2026: Reuben Te One Kaipara, New Labor
2026-2034: Anahera Waimaru Tohu, Islanders Party
Labor Party: OTL NZ Labor Party
National Party: OTL NZ National Party
New Labor: Started at first as OTL NZ New Labor Party, who left Labor because they felt they weren’t left-wing enough. Focuses on the welfare state, government stability, and close ties with Australia. After 2011 it essentially becomes Australia’s puppet party to influence New Zealand. By the 2020s it is a center-right nationalist party, though they still protect the welfare state
Islanders Party: A Maori-dominated egalitarian party, with focuses on the environment, clean energy, anti-military, and protecting democracy. 
In 1972 the values party is formed, the equal pay act is passed, labor is elected, NZ withdraws from the vietnam war. New Zealand DOES sign the Shanghai Accords, however, they are so isolated that many countries (bar papua new guinea) consider them impractical to trade with
In 1973, New Zealand does not send a frigate to protest French nuclear testing
In 1974, Norman Kirk doesn’t die due to advances in medical technology in the 1960s
In 1975, Kirk loses to Muldoon, who tries to integrate New Zealand into the world economy, though he is more or less unsuccessful. The Waitangi Tribunal is established. 
In 1976, New Zealand day is not changed to Waitangi day. Instead, it is given to October 10th, the day the Waitangi Tribunal Act is passed. 
In 1977, New Zealand signs the Gleneagles Agreement, condemning Apartheid. In January, the occupation of Bastion Point results in further negotiations between the government and the Maori. New Zealand also distances itself legally from the UK, though not as much as Australia or South Africa
In 1978, unemployment reaches 1% due to the stagnation of economic conditions. Many begin to leave for places like Indonesia, the Phillipines, Japan and South Korea
In 1979, Air New Zealand Flight 901 successfully lands. Careless days are created to reduce fuel consumption. The Three Mile Island disaster solidifies New Zealand’s anti-nuclear policy
In 1980, the equivalent of the CER agreement is signed. Rent and price freezes go into effect until the next election. 
In 1981, Rowling wins reelection due to the economic stagnation. He implements more welfare policies and also tries to make New Zealand more attractive to tourists and investors 
In 1982, limits on livestock and crops are implemented to try to prevent a dust bowl/economic crash 
In 1983, the first major tourist resorts are opened, they see some success but overall New Zealand is not as popular of a destination due to how remote it is
In 1984, David Lange of the Labor Party is elected
In 1985, the Greenpeace vessel is not sunk and is able to safely leave NZ, though the French immediately seize it 
In 1986, New Zealand decriminalizes homosexuality but still does not allow civil unions to be formed. New Zealand officially distances itself legally from the UK, and becomes a federation much like Australia
In 1987, Maori is made an official language. Wind and solar energy begins to be researched, though it is in the very early prototype stages. The Edgecumbe Earthquake miraculously results in almost no damage, as only a single car is damaged, which is then paid for by the government. Jim Bolger wins election with a coalition government
In 1988, the right to unionize is protected under law. Cyclone Bola strikes the North Island, leading to a government program to build a sea wall. Unemployment is at 5% by the time the Crash of 1988 happens
After the crash of 1988, Bolger desperately tries to make New Zealand attractive for investors, offering tariff-free imports, tax benefits, and streamlined immigration. This does basically nothing, and only further fuels discontent. 
In 1989, the welfare state is slowly dismantled to cut government spending and to try to make New Zealand seem attractive to capitalists who like tiny governments. The only trade deal that is successful is one between Australia and New Zealand. Many in the labor party leave due to their dissatisfaction of how the labor party handled the economy in 1987-1990
In 1990, Jim Anderton of New Labor wins in a landslide. He begins to rebuild much of the welfare state, makes a closer alliance with Bob Hawke of the AALLP, and begins constructing sea walls as a way to reduce unemployment 
In 1991, Australia and New Zealand begin exchanging solar and wind technology. New Zealand also evacuates Tokelau 
In 1992, a huge storm devastates a wind farm off the coast of Great Barrier Island. 
In 1993, Australia tries to convince New Zealand to use nuclear energy but they are very very resistant. Constant overcast weather significantly slows the development of solar technology. Outside of a few prototype wind farms, much of New Zealand is still using fossil fuels 
In 1994, cars are banned, and fuel is prioritized for transportation 
In 1995, an economic recession causes the NZ government to nationalize several large companies to prevent the complete collapse of the economy. New Zealand joins the Alliance of Nations
In 1996, more offshore wind farms are made but they are costly and extremely dangerous to build. To compensate, coal mines are opened 
In 1997, a Maori politician of the fringe “Islanders Party” begins campaigning on regulating the environment in an almost draconic way. Te Ariki Mātene Raukawa also tries to shut down the coal mines. 
In 1998, strikes, protests, and occupations later force the government to negotiate with the growing “Islanders Party” group
In 1999, Te Ariki Mātene Raukawa wins in a narrow victory of the New Labor party, and begins expanding the welfare state and removing any legal discriminations against the Maori. He also draws ire with the Australians about their treatment of the Aborigines, but maintains cool relations. 
In the early 2000s, New Zealand begins an arcology project similar to Australia’s
In 2002, the first combination hydroelectric dam and desalination plant is made in Port Waikato. 
In 2003, New Zealand begins a deal with Australia to export their clean water to help the droughts in Australia. A pirate off the coast of Wellington takes an Australian merchant hostage, and the Australian navy starts a policy of “shoot first, ask questions later”. New Zealand reluctantly agrees, and signs a pact of mutual defense with Australia. 
In 2004, a bill to increase military spending barely passes. PM Raukawa is against it, but signs it to prevent a constitutional crisis. 
In 2005, New Zealand sends humanitarian aid over to Australia after the Darwin brushfire. NZ scientists begin helping Australia construct several desalination plants
In 2006, Australia and New Zealand make a deal to have New Zealand’s military use Australia’s oil and gas, and Australia will retrofit their navy to be entirely nuclear powered by 2026
In 2007, NZ and Australia’s navies become even closely intertwined.
In 2008, the Red Flu spreads through New Zealand, causing almost 70,000 deaths in 2008 alone. 
In 2009, more wind farms are made. Advances in solar power lead to panels covering the roofs of cities
In 2010, NZ has switched to a command economy that relies heavily on trade with Australia
In 2011, limits for livestock are made but are not outright banned like in Australia. The New Labor party returns. While Fraser doesn’t dismantle anything his predecessor made, he becomes more open to nuclear energy and also starts to militarize New Zealand more.
In 2012, a deal is made with Australia to exchange all of their oil to power NZ’s military. 
In 2013, New Zealand considers trading with Japan, and starts to negotiate with them. 
In 2014, New Zealand is shocked by the attempted invasion by China. Enlistment increases but not on the same level as Australia. Fraser begins talks with Dorrington to formally unify, though Fraser wants to ensure NZ’s autonomy. 
In 2015, the great heatwaves finally create enough sunlight for solar farms to become more viable. A massive solar farm begins construction outside of Hamilton. 
In 2016, Australia starts running out of oil, and so NZ switches to coal for their ships. Fraser starts reopening coal mines, but is extremely careful about it. 
In 2017, Australia and New Zealand officially merge into the Union of Australia and New Zealand. 
In 2018, a massive tropical storm leads to New Zealand to evacuating a large amount of refugees in the outlying islands nearby. They are resettled in north island. This wins Fraser a lot of respect with the Islander Party. 
In 2019, a scandal occurs between Fraser and Rhyder getting into a row over criminals. It’s revealed that Fraser has been sending convicts to work for the Australians. 
In 2020, Fraser resigns and a snap election causes Moana Iosefa Ngata to become PM. Ngata is known for causing friction with Rhyder over the ANZ navy policy. 
In 2021, the New Zealand armed forces are gradually retrofitted to use nuclear power. This causes protests with the armed forces, and NZ pauses their retrofits. 
In 2022, more seawalls are built. Australia doesn’t like how resistant the Islander Party is, and thus tries to influence the New Labor party. 
In 2023, Reuben Te One Kaipara, a maori sympathetic to the Australian cause, becomes PM. He engages in a PR campaign calling for nationalism, militarism, and nuclear power
In 2024, NZ has its first ever drought, and Australia intervenes. Kaipara works with Rhyder to make NZ’s infrastructure extremely interdependent on Australia’s. More desalination plants are built, and an underwater pipeline begins transporting clean water to Australia. 
In 2025, Australia faces a massive famine and New Zealand is forced to finally enact rationing to stabilize the food security. Kaipara works with Australia to look into colonizing Antarctica
In 2026, NZ is against war with Argentina. This causes a schism between the two countries, and Anahera Waimaru Tohu becomes PM, pledging greater autonomy of NZ’s military. After the solar storm, NZ offers to help rebuild Australia’s infrastructure and sends them massive amounts of aid, but is shocked when Australia becomes hell-bent on colonizing Antarctica. 
In 2027, Australia begins exercising much more control over NZ, and starts evacuating citizens to New Zealand, overcrowding the islands. People loyal to the Australian government and military are sent first, then regular citizens, and lastly refugees/aboriginals. NZ finds this repulsive, but a faction within them collaborate with the Australians in their war against Argentina. 
Misc Island Nations
Nauru (Population: 22,020, circa 2010)
Australia doesn’t mine that much phosphorus in Nauru during the Glorious Decades. 
In the 1990s, after the Crash, Australia begins a mining project there. 
Phosphate from Nauru is used to fertilizer in Australia. In exchange, Australia sends shipments of food to Nauru
In 2001, a military base is established on Nauru, along with a navy detachment to help protect it against pirates and refugees
