A massive flood in 2007 leads to over 1000 deaths
A desalination plant is made in 2009
In 2012, vertical farms and cities are developed due to the rising ocean 
In 2018, Nauru is evacuated to New Zealand
Cook Islands (Population: 26,151, circa 2000)
Cook Islands is less corrupt during the Glorious Decades, with Thomas Davis winning fair and square in 1978
The US Military set up a few bases on the Cook Islands, but abandoned them by 1990
New Zealand sets up sea walls in the 1990s
Vertical farms and acrology keep them relatively well fed, but constantly raids and floods lead to New Zealand to evacuate them in 2001
New Caledonia (Population: 402,765, circa 1990)
A burst of violence erupted during later 1970s between the French and the indigenous Kanak independence movements.
France negotiated a deal for infrastructure building, tourism promotions, and gradual independence process in 50 years under the backing of Australia, New Zealand, and US
Tourism became a good income source for New Caledonians, but heavy nickel mining operations by the French, Americans, and Chinese began to damage the islands
The Crash happened, tourism revenue dried out, killing off at least 60% of the economy. The government had to heavily rely on nickel mining, which further devastated the islands
Due to the nickel mining operations, France reneged on the independence deal by 1990.
Violent civil war began in New Caledonia in late 1990.
France decided to abandon the islands completely by January, New Zealand evacuated pro-French New Caledonians and others by March, about 260 thousands, abandoning the rest of New Caledonians.
The drastic reduction of the population actually helped the new radical Kanak government with them needing to feed way less people. Still the damaged land meant they had to import food somewhere. Australia exported a bit to them (in exchange for nickel supplies), but not much else
The government had to ration food by 1992 and implementing authoritarian measures, causing further violence.
A major storm hit New Caledonia in 1995, destroying the Kanak radical government, the islands briefly fell into anarchy.
Order was finally reestablished after everyone (about 120 thousands) agreed on a truce
With such devastation, many abandoned the islands, the rest asked for a merger with Vanuatu in 1997, formally joining in 1998.
Australia forced Vanuatu to open New Caledonia for further mining due to nickel being very important. As a relieve, Australia will accept a percentage of displaced people with New Zealand but Vanuatu took the brunt of it
The storm and the mining devastation kept displacing more and more New Caledonians to Vanuatu, Australia, or New Zealand
Some remnants of the radical Kanak government tried to rebel against Australia when the Chinese tried to invade them. China basically went, “Cool then, you can join” but not really helping them.
Australia came back and restored order into the islands, continuing their mining operations.
Australia was forced to pull out of New Caledonia after a particularly destructive storm in the later 2010s, only evacuating their staffs and some collaborators, abandoning everyone there.
By 2027, New Caledonia were mostly abandoned and flooded with only estimated 1000-2000 people lived in Mont Panie.
Fiji (Population: 1,037,387, circa 2010)
Becomes independent as in OTL
Land ownership is a hot topic throughout the Glorious Decades, though Fiji still remains a tourist destination 
In 1987, the coups don’t happen, as everyone benefits from the increased tourism
After the crash of 1988, Australia and Fiji begin closely trading
In 1989, Australia begins prototyping more efficient farming methods on Fiji
A military base is established on Fiji in 1990
Reliance on Australia remains a tenuous topic throughout the 1990s, but as food shortages, rationing, heatwaves, droughts and natural disasters become more prominent, it dies down
Sea walls are built in the late 1990s
In 2004, Australia builds a nuclear power plant on Beqa Island
Refugee boats lead to military patrols in the late 2000s
In the 2010s, Fiji is entirely dependent on Australia, with the main island essentially completely devoted to farming. 
Between 2009-2014, Australian sailors would frequently take shore leave in Fiji 
After the invasion though, the nationalist government began investing less in Fiji. “self reliance” programs were planned
In 2018, New Zealand offers evacuations. Many leave, but a small number (roughly 100,000) stay. 
Between 2019-2023, New Zealand maintains contact with their outposts in Fiji but in 2024 they stop receiving communications. 
In 2025, New Zealand sends an expeditionary crew to find that Fiji has been swarmed by refugees
By 2027, the status of Fiji is unknown. 
Kiribati (Population: 232,499, circa 1990)
Becomes independent in our timeline, due to disagreements about tourism with the British
In the 1980s, Kiribati tries to become a tax haven. This is not as successful as they had hoped, and instead, they become a popular American tourist destination
In the late 1980s, overcrowding became a serious issue. High rise buildings were made in 1987 and early 1988, though only two were finished before the Crash of 1988. 
After the crash of 1988, the economy nosedives with homelessness and unemployment reaching the mid double digits. 
In 1989, rampant flooding and unprecedented weather forces Kiribati to plead with Australia and New Zealand to accept refugees 
In 1990, Australia only sends aid and tries to make a seawall, however, contact is lost in late 1990
An expedition is sent in 1991 to find out what happened to the Australian engineers and the rest of Kiribati. They find the island completely submerged, with the high-rises in ruins. Less than 1000 survived, and all given medical care and resettled in Australia
By 2027, the island is over 10 meters below the sea 
Solomon Islands (Population: 845,998, circa 2020)
Becomes independent as in OTL
Signs the Shanghai Accords, though this doesn’t really affect their economy much as they rely mostly on tourism
After the crash of 1988, disagreements of how land was to be allocated, in addition to island autonomy, leads to a civil war 
The civil war ends in a stalemate in 1990 due to a massive tsunami causing over 100,000 deaths
Australia comes in during the 1990s to help provide some aid, and they forcibly demilitarize the solomon islands to prevent further bloodshed. The Solomon islands are an important testbed for many of Australia’s technologies, each on a different island. Seawalls are first built along many of the island coasts, then a nuclear power plant is built Savo Island. A wind farm is built on Chouselle Island, and a solar farm is built on Rennell Island. A desalination plant is built on Guadalcanal. Australia builds several military bases on the islands, and sets up patrols 
In the 2000s, refugees from Indonesia and Papua New Guinea are the most common issue. 
In 2014, China attacks the Solomon islands on their way to Australia, leading to a naval battle that results in over 100 casualties and the destruction of the nuclear power plant. 
In the aftermath, Australia begins relocating citizens to other islands and gives them the right to re-arm, causing ethnic tensions to flare back up again. This leads to another civil war, and the anti-Australian rebels win, severing ties with Australia 
In 2018, New Zealand offers to resettle them. Some take this offer, while others remain in the heavily fortified islands. About 250,000 end up leaving for New Zealand. 
In 2022, ANZ helps defend the Solomon Islands against an incursion of pirates 
In 2024, storms and flooding become so destructive that the Solomon Islands navy organizes an evacuation to New Zealand. Only 500,000 people make it there, as several ships capsize. 
As of 2027, the status of the Solomon Islands is unknown
Vanuatu (Population: 446,019, circa 2010)
Becomes independent as in OTL, however the Coconut War with PNG doesn’t happen
Becomes a libertarian tax haven in the 1980s, and several companies open offices there, but it’s not as popular as Uruguay
After the crash of 1988, a socialist government is formed and it becomes increasingly authoritarian 
A large storm in 1989 leads to almost 50,000 deaths and the complete destruction of Port Vila
In 1990, Australian and New Zealand efforts to rebuild include making sea walls and establishing military bases. 
In 1996, a wind farm is built on Malekula
In the late 1990s, the former French Territory of New Caldedonia joins Vanuatu as a province 
In the 2000s, flooding in New Caledonia leads to overpopulation in Vanuatu. 
In 2009, a civil war almost happens due to the ethnic tensions resulting from the resettlement
In 2015, a civil war pops off, with a Ni-Vanuatu nationalist blaming the New Caledonians for the various issues they face 
In 2016, ANZ try to mediate a peaceful resolution but a New Caledonian separatist overloads a nuclear reactor in Efate and forces yet more migration 
In 2017, due to the environmental issues, New Zealand begins resettling Vanuatuans, though many refuse 
In 2018, many of them are wiped out in the tropical mega storm
In the 2020s, the central government of the islands fracture and each island is ruled by a warlord 
By 2027, half of the islands formerly known as Vanuatu are still inhabited, with a current population estimated to be somewhere below 100,000
Niue (Population: 2,048, circa 1990)
Became an autonomous region much like OTL
Tourism picked up in the Glorious Decades, though it remained very isolated and obscure
After the crash, Niue became entirely reliant on New Zealand for aid
In 1988, rationing and blackouts became routine
In 1991, as a result of a massive tropical storm New Zealand offered to evacuate the citizens to North Island, to which they agreed to
By 2027, it is abandoned, with frequent storms having completely removed all traces of human habitation
Tokelau (Population: 3,756, circa 1990)
Remained part of New Zealand’s dependant territory.
Tourism picked up a bit in the Fabulous Decades, but like Niue, they remained obscure.
Fishing became slowly reduced over time due to global overfishing
When the Crash happened, it remained closely connected with New Zealand
Due to its isolated position, New Zealand was struggling to communicate with Tokelau
As fishing dried out, Tokelau kept stumbling downward.
In 1991, a storm cut off Tokelau's communication. It took New Zealand a few weeks to mobilize their navy and try to reach Tokelau.
Because of the time needed, at least 800 Tokelauans died due to direct impact, diseases, or other causes.
The New Zealand rescue fleet coordinated with the government and they offered evacuation to the remains. They accepted.
By 2027, Tokelau was completely gone under the sea.
Tonga (Population: 211,310, circa 2010)
Tonga remains staunchly isolationist, not signing the Shanghai Accords 
Tonga also never democratizes, though it does slightly open up for tourism
Tonga also remains skeptical of fossil fuels, and even starts conducting research into climate projections (though they don’t get far) 
As a result, the crash of 1988 doesn’t impact them at all, and they occasionally trade with Australia and New Zealand
In the 1990s, the monarch Tāufaʻāhau Tupou IV solidifies his power, becoming more and more authoritarian 
In the 1990s, Tonga begins extensive programs to research ways to mitigate climate change. 
In 1996, Australia helps construct a sea wall along the borders of Tongatapu
In the 2000s, Tonga remains extremely isolationist, refusing to allow Australia to build a military base there. 
In 2011, strict rationing and declining quality of life due to frequent storms leads to a revolution deposing the monarchy, which spirals out into a civil war
In 2018, New Zealand warns them about the impending super storm and offers to evacuate them, however they find much of the island already abandoned. A handful of survivors (less than 100) are found and accept 
By 2027, Tonga is completely abandoned 
Tuvalu (Population: 21,754, circa 1990) 
Became independent as in OTL 
It remains a popular tourist destination in the 1980s
However, Tuvalu is extremely vulnerable to climate change, and in 1987, a tropical storm results in widespread damage 
As a result, Tuvalu’s government takes out massive loans from the IMF and tries to rebuild 
Foreign aid dries up in 1988, and the government begins negotiating with neighboring countries for aid 
Australia offers to build a sea wall in 1989 in exchange for building a military base there. Tuvalu accepts. 
By 1991, the sea wall was successful but wasn’t tall enough and after Funafuti floods in 1992, they negotiate with Australia and are evacuated to the northern territories. 
Many Tuvaluans die in the great fire of 2005
By 2027, Tuvalu is completely under water and forgotten to history 
Palau (Population: 25,982, circa 2000)
Gained independence from USA as OTL
Tourism soared during the Fabulous Decades, mainly from Japan, US, and other spots.
Coral bleaching began in the 1980s.
USA spend a fair amount of money into Palau
When the Crash happened, global tourism plummeted as a result, Palau lost about 25% of its GDP by the end of 1989.
The Morgan Administration tried their best to prop Palau up, but it kept declining.
When the Graves Administration started, aid to Palau was cut by 50%, further destroying Palau’s economy. By 1992, at least half of Palau is unemployed
Increasingly humid and worse rains made Palau harder to live on. The Graves Administration offered Palauans relocation to Hawaii. Some took it, but most didn’t.
The Graves Administration finally pulled the plug out for Palau completely by 1995, ending American influence in Palau.
A particularly devastating rain season wrecked Palau in 1998. New Zealand offered evacuation to Palauans. Most took it and left the islands.
The rest were prey to pirates who established their dens in the islands.
By the 2000s, the increasingly humid conditions made living in Palau almost impossible.
By 2027, most of Palau was abandoned with only 100s people left.
French Polynesia (Population: 418,789, circa 1995)
France built up French Polynesia for tourism during the Fabulous Decades
Many Polynesians were employed for civil administration too, the French military was pulled out mostly since no nuclear test was ever done anymore.
During the Fabulous Decades, the islands weren’t completely thriving, but it was still relatively well.
When the Crash happened, tourism dried out, cutting off a major source of income for the islands
Subsidies also began to dry out, further worsening the economy. By 1992, at least a fifth of the population was unemployed.
Agriculture was boosted as a way to support the territory’s dying economy. Land was getting worse due to overfarming.
By 1995, due to the sheer distance, France finally pulled the plug out too, evacuating mostly metropolitan French, about 110.000 people from the territories.
The new Republic of Polynesie was shakily declared in 1996. The new government was very shaky with conflicts between various islands and people. It was not expected to last long.
The government collapsed in 1997, barely a year after its declaration. Polynesie was split into multiple states, with the biggest centered in Tahiti.
Overfarming led to less food coming and conflicts began to erupt in former French Polynesia.
Many French Polynesians immigrated to their neighbours to try to find a chance of a better life.
A big storm hit the islands in 1998, devastating them further.
New Zealand contacted some communities in 2000, offering evacuation. At least 55,000 people were evacuated.
By 2027, the status of French Polynesia is unknown.
Wallis and Futuna (Population: 16,723, circa 1995)
Still part of France per OTL, the French also tried to build up tourism in the territory.
Due to its closer distance with Australia, tourism picked up more than French Polynesia, but they were competing with big ones like Fiji and the rest.
They also sold fishing rights to Australia, Japan, New Zealand, US, and others. Like others, concerns of overfishing were silenced.
When the Crash happened, tourism dried out as a result. At least a third of the territory’s economy dried out in instant.
The French government tried to prop out the territory, but overfishing ruined the local waters. Many tried to eke out a living.
A revolution happened in 1996, deposing the traditional government system and they declared independence from France. The deposed locals fled to New Zealand, about a third of them.
The new government was very shaky, eventually collapsing in 1998 when a storm hit the capital. The territory fell into anarchy.
The islands were open to pirates in the region after that by 2000.
In 2010s, a pirate lord took over the former territory. Unlike the Samoan pirates, they chose to be more conservative in their actions.
When the Samoan Pirate Showdown happened in 2015, the Wallis Pirate Lord saw their chance when both sides were devastated. Raids into Samoa intensified.
By 2020s, the Wallis Pirate Lord had fully taken over Samoa.
By 2026, the Wallis Pirate Lord was forced to pull over from Samoa because of the worsening situation.
By 2027, the Wallis Pirate Lord was killed. The status of the former territory was unknown.
Samoa (Population: 308,268 ,circa 1997)
Retained the name Western Samoa still
With investments from New Zealand, the Samoan government built up tourism infrastructure for the Fabulous Decades
Several Japanese companies set up shops in Samoa, not as polluting as others, but starting to do so
By the 1980s, tourism was booming and the economy was rapidly diversifying from agriculture.
When the Crash happened, tourism dried out, resulting in an economic crash for Samoa. Exports also began declining, resulting in worse economy.
A fungal blight devastated Samoa’s taro and other agricultural production in 1994.
With the collapse of the agricultural and tourism sector, Samoa was forced to be totally dependent on New Zealand’s aid by 1995.
Violent protests and uprisings began to occur by 1996 by people who wanted a better life.
A major storm destroyed a lot of Samoa in 1997. New Zealand offered them evacuation. At least two thirds of the nation was evacuated.
Storms and rising sea level wrecked what was left of Samoa, leaving it open for pirates.
By 2010s, a thriving pirate den was established in former Samoa.
By 2027, the pirate den almost collapsed, the former nation in total anarchy.
American Samoa (Population: 66,930, circa 1997)
Still part of US like OTL
Tourism was beginning to be developed more serious than OTL by the end of the 1960s.
Better airline services and trained workers resulted in better tourism industry in the territory than OTL
Multiple American and Japanese tuna cannery companies set up shop here. Any concern of overfishing was silenced.
By 1988, the territory standard of living kept rising.
When the Crash happened, tourism dried out, cutting out at least a third of the territory’s economy. The government was forced to send more aid to the territory.
The tuna cannery companies tried their best to keep going as usual, but slowly they went bankrupt. By 1993, all companies had shut down.
The Graves Administration also cut aid by 50% to American Samoa, worsening the economy.
Like in Western Samoa, violent protests and uprisings began to occur in 1996.
The 1997 Samoan Storm also hit American Samoa, devastating the territory.
The US and New Zealand government offered to evacuate separately, at least two thirds accepted.
By 2010, like former Western Samoa, former American Samoa was another hub for pirates. Former American Samoa in particular was controlled by one who was hostile to the Western Samoan pirates. They wanted to reunite the Samoa.
In 2015, they had a showdown in the sea between, only to be hit by a storm. None of them survived.
By 2027, the former territory fell into anarchy, status unknown.
Marshall Islands (Population: 63,754, circa 2000)
Gained independence from US as OTL
Economy remained fairly small, tourism isn’t as developed as other Oceanian countries
They instead sold their fishing rights to other nations including the US and Japan.
Overfishing became a prominent problem in the 1980s but the local government was paid to ignore that.
They imported more things to help raise the standards of living of the islanders. US helped them by giving them millions of dollars in aids.
When the Crash happened, due to them not relying on tourism, their economy wasn’t badly impacted.
Increasing demand of fish lead to further overfishing, devastating the local fish population
Things got worse when the Graves Administration came and cut off their aid by 50%. Their economy fell down hard.
Due to storms, the concrete dome in Runit Island was breached by sea water, releasing radioactive contaminants into the local ocean. Fishing was soon banned in the area, destroying the islands’ economy.
With worsening conditions, the government offered for evacuations to Hawaii. The Islanders accepted and most were evacuated.
By 2027, it was totally flooded, lost to history.
Micronesia (Population: 153,178, circa 1989) 
Still part of USA by the Fabulous Decades started 
By 1979, the process of independence started, but US is still heavily controlling the region. Full independence is agreed in 1990, 4 years later than OTL
US built a lot of tourism industries in the area, tourism boomed as result
Phosphate mining also began in the region, starting to contaminate the area
The Crash happened, tourism dried out as a result.
US awkwardly tried to dance around Micronesian independence issues, finally decided on retaining the region, not giving them full independence due to their phosphate
Protests began to erupt in the islands due to US’s decisions, sometimes they had to broken up violently
However, before things could go even worse, the storms made the Graves Administration offer evacuations to Hawaii for Micronesians. Some accepted, reducing the tension in the islands.
Mining operation made the water around the islands increasingly contaminated, Micronesia had to import way more food from US
Finally with the increasing cost of mining, imports, and distance from the mainland, the Graves Administration gave them full independence abruptly in 1996. They evacuated every Americans and any willing people to Hawaii, abandoning Micronesia.
Independent Micronesia barely chugged along until 2000s when it finally collapsed after the capital was hit by a violent storm.
Micronesians fled to southern islands and even further south.
By 2027, the only Micronesians left were in the mountains of the archipelago, numbering only a few hundreds left.
Japan (Population: 74,471,234, circa 2020) 
In the 1970s, much to the US’s chagrin, Japan drifts towards socialism
In 1974, Kakuei Tanaka doesn’t get caught and is considered to be a paragon of Japanese politics
In the 1970s and 1980s, Japan doesn’t increase their military spending as the threat of military conflict with China and the USSR significantly dies down
Between 1975-1980, relations with the US are soured but President Morgan makes it a point during his second term to restore ties
Japan recognizes Chen’s PRC as the sole government of China in 1979
In 1980, after signing the Shanghai Accords, Japan starts to become the largest car manufacturer (using Chinese plants) 
In the 1980s, Japanese politics revolved around free trade vs protectionism
In 1981, Japanese National Railways is privatized and split into seven different companies. By 1988, they have all been bought by the same conglomerate 
In 1983, Mt. Oyama volcano erupts, which is advertised as a “once in a lifetime event”
In 1984, the president of Ezaki Glico Co., Ltd., is held hostage and ransomed for one billion yen. He later escapes and fights his way out of the compound, singlehandedly before collapsing on the street and dying from a heart attack. Later investigations find that he was held hostage by an alliance of organized criminals from South Korea and Taiwan. 
In 1985, Japan airlines flight 123 falls into the ocean. All passengers survive. 
By 1986, union membership is at 0.3% in Japan. Mount Mihara erupts and over 2 million visit Japan to watch the magma flow
In 1987, a rail mega project is completed and connects the Japanese rail lines from Fukuoka, Japan to Busan, South Korea, and Wakkanai, Japan to Shebunino, USSR
By 1988, Japan has been very reluctant to integrate free trade with other nations, as they still protect their industry. 
After the crash of 1988, due to Japan not relying ENTIRELY on exports, their economy doesn't completely cave in until 1990. 
In 1989, the Fukouka-Busan rail line is destroyed for “self defense purposes”
In early 1990, in response to the USSR’s increased aggression, the Wakkanai-Shebunino rail is also destroyed
A new prime minister is elected in 1990. He promises to fight against the aggression of China and the USSR, and rebuild Japanese industry. Japan’s rail system is also refurbished
In 1991, Japan begins a policy of rationing coal and other energy sources
In 1992, a new political party, the Self-Reliance Party, is formed. It is a big tent party that focuses on economic recovery for Japan, and later self-defense in the wake of China’s aggression
In 1993, unions start to make a come back, though the government regulates them 
October 25, 1994 - Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution is officially repealed, and the Japanese military begins to slowly be built up again
December 31, 1995 - By this date, all people in the countryside are ordered to evacuate so that farms can be built. Research into vertical farms starts
In 1996, suicide becomes the most common cause of death
In 1997, the last automobile manufacturer finally closes down and switches to making replacement parts for trains
In 1998, fishing vessels in the Sea of Japan are now routinely escorted by increasingly large numbers of Japanese navy boats
December 31, 1999 - All cars are banned in japan 
In 2000, strict rationing is implemented, with many elders voluntarily forgoing entire meals 
In 2001, coal and oil shortages result in Japan looking into nuclear power as its main source of energy (Japan never outright banned nuclear power after TMI, instead, oil was just simply cheaper). Relentless recycling and trash collection campaigns burn millions of tons of trash to keep furnaces running. 
In 2002, flooding destroys much of outer Tokyo, leading to over 4 million missing or dead. Flood walls begin to be built, but it’s slow
In 2003, a massive famine causes almost 4 million deaths and Japan begins recycling the dead for food for the poorest of the poor. These “emergency rations” are manufactured under the guise of “fish patties”. Many pets are eaten around this time, and an outbreak of a zoonotic disease in Kyoto forces them to be quarantined for the rest of the year 
In 2004, the entire countryside is dedicated to farming. The first major nuclear power plant built after 1988 opens on the outskirts of Tokyo. It is cooled by sea water
In 2005, Soviet prisoners escaping a gulag in Siberia spread the Red Flu to Japan, causing a policy of “national quarantine” and entire cities to shut down, leading to the economy almost completely crashing
October 4, 2006 - The Japanese Emperor is reported dead. The government claims that he had died of old age, but when many other government officials died, it became obvious that he had killed himself. As a result, many elders follow his example to free up resources for the newer generations
October 5, 2006 to February 22nd, 2007 - As more and more people commit suicide, die of starvation, or die of the Red Flu, civilization on the Japanese islands almost collapses. It is estimated that almost a third of the population dies during this time. With so many people dying, infrastructure begins to break down. Emergency services are overwhelmed, and the police are stretched thin. Anarchy spreads when entire local governments all commit suicide. A small group of public servants, later known as the Steward Society, work at great cost to get the country functioning again. A nuclear power plant outside Noshiro goes critical due to the staff all committing suicide, and 12 brave people sacrifice themselves to prevent it from going nuclear
February 21, 2007 - The Third Sino-Japanese War starts: the first PLA warships are sent to Japan. This causes the remnants of Japan to snap out of their collective ennui and start to work together again. Factories begin to produce military equipment. Cars and other metal objects are recycled for use in the military. Trenches are built all along Japan’s west coast. Tokyo is under siege for seven months. Stories are told of soldiers willingly walking into their death to protect their comrades. Due to shortages of medical supplies, Japan begins a tradition of the elderly and seriously ill to voluntarily refuse medicine to save it for younger people
By 2008, Japan has lost almost 10 million to the war with China. Fighting in the trenches has led to a specialized martial art being developed, called “The Way of the Honorable Eel”. Swords are also common, along with using captured chinese weapons. Alcohol is banned for recreational use, and dedicated solely to sanitizing things
By 2009, Japan has rearmed itself and begins to go on the offensive after fully kicking China off the islands. Naval battles in the East China Sea result in many losses for China
April 1, 2010 - The Third Sino-Japanese War ends in a stalemate. The Steward Society becomes the official government of Japan. Due to the large amount of pollution in the Glorious Decades, over 90% of people over the age of 55 have some sort of health issue, the most common one being blindness. As more they begin to teach the younger generations essential skills for keeping the country functioning (mainly on how to maintain equipment), they are granted “seeing eye people”, to help them navigate the world and also to serve as their proteges. 
March 11, 2011 - A massive earthquake hits Japan. Almost half of the remaining elders die, either due to being trapped, suffering a heart attack, or being swept into the sea. The Steward Society struggled to regain a hold on the country, and for a short while the island of Kyushu declares independence. The Steward Society simply starves them out, and they return like nothing happened by the end of the year. Fears of overfishing cause Japan to enforce strict fishing quotas, with people found guilty of lying being executed in public
Sometime in 2012, water begins to be rationed for better use in irrigation. Research into desalination begins, but is slow, as a vast majority of who is still alive by this point is either incapable of conducting the research, or is uneducated 
In 2013, the Steward Society begins drafting up plans for a second major nuclear power plant, this time outside of Gifu. People found evading their work duties or attempting to commit suicide as an easy way out are publically shamed. Japan also starts trading with New Zealand, though the long journeys make it very slow and time consuming
By 2014, almost all fossil fuels are exhausted, and Japan prioritizes them for use in agriculture 
In 2015, during the Great Heatwaves, millions more die from dehydration and suicide. The average age for someone in Japan is 34 years old. 
In 2016, riots due to working conditions, food rations and housing culminate in the Steward Society declaring nationwide martial law, with the police regularly shutting off services to cities that are prone to unrest
In 2017, sea walls are constructed around much of Tokyo, Kyoto, Gifu and Kobe. An outbreak of an unidentified zoonotic disease causes many livestock to die, with strict regulations to keep the remaining ones isolated and alive
In 2018, Japan begins importing solar panels from New Zealand
In 2019, the Steward Society opens their first school, the “Academy of Japanese Governmental Stewardship”, and industrial accidents begin to finally decline for the first time in over 10 years
In 2020, advances in arcology due to the sharing of knowledge with New Zealand and Australia leads to more efficient vertical farms, and the last “fish patty” is made on April 4th
In 2021, due to widespread birth defects, the Steward Society bans births until 2030, after which the policy will be reevaluated 
In 2022, Japan buys several nuclear powered navy vessels from Australia
In 2023, The Steward Society begins a project to collect, record, and organize every technical manual and piece of literature they can find, and they begin to create bound “sacred books” that contain tons of useful information about operating the many machines that keep Japan functioning. Fearing an invasion from China or the USSR, Japan begins building military bases along their western coast 
In 2024, during the second great heatwaves, famine and drought cause Japan to import tons of water from New Zealand. Very little actually makes it to Japan. 
In 2025, the Steward Society begins a project to see how long Japan will remain able to support life. The results are horrifying: due to the rampant pollution, industrial accidents, birth defects, and shrinking amount of arable land, Japan is projected to be incapable of supporting its current population by 2100. 
In 2026, Japan attends the AoN conference in Patagonia, and is skeptical of colonizing Antarctica. Regardless, the secret branch of the Steward Society begins planning a contingency plan should a major famine/disaster cause the country to collapse yet again. That happens during the Solar Storm of 2026: the entire country grinds to a halt, as fires and electrical failures cause an unknown amount of deaths and entire cities stop functioning. Half of the Steward Society’s High Council (the ruling body, headed by a Prefect), is killed in the resulting chaos, and the secret branch takes control and authorizes their emergency plan: an invasion of Kamchatka. 
By 2027, the Steward Society is desperately struggling to keep Japan from collapsing in on itself. Suicide rates are the highest they’ve ever been, and desertions are common. The remnants of the military are working at breakneck speed to try to determine what equipment is functioning and fixing the rest, and are preparing to invade the far eastern USSR. 
Indonesia (Population: 395,549,893, circa 2000)
Indonesia signs the Shanghai Accords in 1973
Indonesia also does not encourage family planning
Treatment of chinese indonesians is also better than our reality 
In 1975, Indonesia, being threatened by the UN, does not annex Timor. Instead, they hold a referendum, which they are caught rigging, and Timor remains independent 
In the 1980s, Indonesia's economy grows rapidly 
In 1983, after being re-elected, Suharto actually faces criticism that he isn’t going far enough, so he further opens the country and implements several Singaporean-inspired policies 
In 1988, Suharto quietly sides with Egypt during the Sinai War
After the crash of 1988, Suharto tries to go business as usual but by August 1988 the economy starts to rapidly collapse 
In 1988, Indonesia covertly supports West Malaysia 
In 1989, Suharto tries many policies to try to reinvigorate the economy, including privatizing many things 
He also builds up the military, citing Soviet aggression, the civil war in PNG, and Singaporean refugees 
By the Hot Summer though, this doesn’t work, and after entire small islands are evacuated, he starts to blame the issues on too many people 
Indonesia is the first country to place limits of families, starting in 1990
After China invades Mongolia, Suharto conveniently starts to blame the Chinese Indonesians 
In the early 1990s, ghettos are built for Chinese Indonesians and they aren’t allowed to have kids, and families are separated 
In 1991, a large farming company lobbies the government to use Chinese Indonesians as slaves in farms, Suharto agrees 
Suharto supports the Malaysian warlords against the Chinese communists
In the 1990s, laws are gradually repealed, and civil rights are lost. 
In 1992, Indonesia signs a pact of mutual defense with the Philippines 
In 1993, a country-wide curfew is in effect
Martial law is declared in 1994
In 1995, Suharto suspends the constitution, and declares himself president for life
In 1996, Working with various businesses, Indonesia is reorganized so that certain islands are turned into “farming zones”, essentially giant labor farms/prisons for criminals/chinese minorities
In 1997, a militarized border is set up in Borneo 
In 1998, citing the anarchy in PNG, Indonesia annexes them
Between 1998-2003, Indonesia is turned into a police state, and while they do have enough oil for people to drive cars (being pretty much the only country to not have to worry about oil) people are constantly being relocated due to storms, causing much civil unrest 
In 2002, in response to the Indian-Pakistani nuclear war, Indonesia becomes even more repressive, with rations given for loyalty 
In 2003, a failed uprising in PNG leads to civil war starting, with Borneo, Sumatra, and Java all having a battle royale 
Suharto is killed in 2004 by a disgruntled general 
By 2010, the civil war has solidified into Sumatra’s government, which has the most food and is allied with West Malaysia, Borneo’s government, which is allied with East Malaysia and is the most stable, and the Java government, which is quickly falling to anarchy 
By 2013, all of PNG has been taken over by rebel groups
In 2014, China comes through and attacks much of West Malaysia and Sumatra, while Philippine refugees crowd Borneo, leading to further civil war factions 
By 2015, Java is anarchy and is being abandoned 
In 2016, massive heatwaves and floods prevent agriculture and reports of cannibalism circulate 
By the 2020s, the various factions of the civil war are fighting for their own survival, with many of the surviving areas being taken over by warlords and pirate kings
During the second great heat wave, the remnants in Borneo try to take over East Malaysia, they fail 
By 2027, the only relatively functioning part of Indonesia is the rebel base in PNG, which is a left-wing authoritarian confederacy 
Between 2003-2027, many islands are flooded and abandoned, leading to over 100+ million deaths between 2003 and 2027
Malaysia (Population: 45,675,921, circa 1980)
Malaysia’s New Economic Policy is very successful at eliminating poverty and wealth inequality based on racial and religious discrimination 
China also strongarms them into treating their Chinese with dignity 
Throughout the 1970s, China and Malaysia work very closely together to rapidly increase both of their economy, with China focusing on manufacturing while Malaysia focuses on logistics, supply lines, and shipping. A large remote call center industry pops up in Malaysia
In the 1980s, Malaysia teeters on being socialist, similar to OTL China, but still encourages free market economics 
In 1981, Malaysia signs numerous trade deals with other countries, including the UK and the USSR 
In 1982, Malaysia focused entirely on industrialization, with farming communities receiving expanded taxes for not “moving the country forward” 
In 1983, the monarchies are officially disbanded, with many of the royals renouncing their claims to rule, but some refuse to do so and go underground
In 1984, a conservative Islamic politician is assassinated for advocating closer ties to the USSR (in a similar vein as Iraq) 
By 1988, peace negotiations with the radical islamic and maoist groups leads to a short peace
Unrest occurs even before the Crash of 1988, as Arab sympathizers begin large scale protests during the Sinai War, the pro-Chinese government suppresses these
After the crash of 1988 and the nuclear war, many moderates and Chinese move to the eastern side of Malaysia, as the unrest reaches a breaking point and people start to be executed en masse for being “Traitors to Islam” and the few Malaysian jews are persecuted. In East Malaysia, rationing is introduced due to the tight spaces
West Malaysia declares independence in August 1988, creating the “Islamic State of Malay”. This is recognized by only a few minor African islamic countries, and many view the remnants of Malaysia in Borneo as the “true” Malaysia 
Between 1988 and 1990, the two Malaysias stabilize. East Malaysia manages to stave off total economic collapse, as they had not entirely industrialized (plus their call centers were in Peninsular Malaysia) so they do okay. West Malaysia’s economy completely collapses, as many foreign investors pull out, and most of its industry falls apart, causing a massive famine in 1990 and West Malaysia to fall apart into several dozen statelets controlled by various warlords 
In 1991, East Malaysia launches an invasion into West Malaysia to try to retake it. East Malaysia’s economy collapses, and switches to a socialist economy 
In 1992, the invasion is going okay, much of the eastern coast of West Malaysia has been retaken by government forces, however a massive tropical storm in the South China Sea devastates the Riau Islands (the government forces’s main staging grounds) and forces the government forces to retreat, returning to Borneo
In 1993, in response to the Borneo faction in the government, plus the communists in Thailand winning, a warlord starts conquering other parts of West Malaysia, bringing over half of it under his control. He starts retooling factories to produce weapons of war, and begins launching skirmishes into Thailand, Indonesia, and even plans to raid East Malaysia
China, in response to such a hostile power so close to home, invades Thailand and cites the instability in Malaysia as one of the reasons why they took over Thailand. 
Between 1994-1999, every time China tries pacify West Malaysia, a Jihad is called and it always ends with the rebels being slaughtered en masse in retaliation. By 2000 China has largely given up, though they have burned the coasts down multiple times 
For East Malaysia, they are invaded by factions in the Indonesian civil war, before finally being annexed in 1998. 
In the 2000s, West Malaysia becomes a theocratic dictatorship and remains extremely repressive and agrarian, engaging in smuggling and piracy operations until collapsing into anarchy in 2011 during the Purple Summer. East Malaysia, siding with Indonesian rebels, launches their own nation, called the People’s Republic of Borneo
In 2010s, flooding in Borneo causes many to migrate to the north
In 2015, a massive forest fire burns down much of West Malaysia, reducing it to a charred wasteland. 
In 2016, Borneo is invaded several times by Indonesian government forces, but they manage to win out every time. Strict rationing and low industrialization allows for Borneo to not have to resort to cannibalism, but malnourishment and disease are the leading causes of death
Between 2017-2023, government incursions become less frequent, as refugees/pirates become a pressing concern 
In 2024, disagreements with other rebel factions against Indonesia (such as the factions in Sulawesi and New Guinea) cause a civil war between the rebels and Borneo’s authoritarian government finally slides into a dictatorship
In 2026, during the solar storm, a large forest fire burns down much of Borneo, leading to a civil war and famine
By 2027, Borneo is in civil war, while West Malaysia is a wasteland 
Philippines (Population: 223,830,595, circa 2000)
Martial law is declared as in OTL
However, the US and China try to negotiate to help open up the country more so that they can have better access to their mineral resources 
The US offers to help catch the Maoists (China’s hands were tied due to the Shanghai Accords), and a sort of low-intensity analogue of the Vietnam War happens here 
By 1976, as one of Nixon’s last diplomatic goals, he helps the conservative Filipino government regain control of the south. 
Between 1976-1981 Marcos remains dictator, until President Morgan begins the process of opening up the country to strengthen supply lines in the region. China becomes the largest investor into the Philippines, though a large tourism industry also takes off.
In 1984, Eduardo “Eddie” Santillán Robles becomes the President of the Phillipines, and martial law is finally lifted 
China’s investments in the mid 1980s cause huge amounts of pollution and a minor famine in 1988, though the government imports lots of food from Cambodia to make up for it. 
In 1989, Robles very narrowly wins a second term, and the conservative government actually tries to tackle the resulting depression and climate change effects through the free market. Throughout 1989 and parts of 1990, various sea-walls and proposed farming methods are tested, with contracts being sold to the highest bidder. He also calls the US a “coward” 
The Hot Summer of 1990 puts a stop to this, as the last sectors of the economy completely shut down due to rampant energy shortages 
Afterwards, Robles simply starts implementing rationing and other emergency contingency plans 
Left over coal mines are dedicated to running the left over industry in the capital islands near manilla, and other islands are basically left to starve 
Riots over food shortages and other problems are met with police brutality 
In 1992, after the Taiwan invasion, the Philippines becomes extreme isolationist and paranoid 
In 1994, an "Independent” politician who is totally not a socialist runs for the presidency, and Robles contests the results. 
In 1995, citing China and the USSR’s expansion, plus the socialist politician, Robles declares martial law and suspends the constitution, and purges the government of anyone who isn’t 100% on his side 
Between 1995-2000, work camps are set up, with entire islands turned into glorified prison farms. Political prisoners are forced to work their sentences off there. After 1995, insurgents fight a guerilla war with the government 
In the meantime, the Philippines keeps building up its army to ridiculous levels, fearing a Chinese invasion. The army becomes so big that over 10% of the entire population is an active member. The Police are no longer the primary form of law enforcement, as the armed forces routinely patrol cities and also serve the role of emergency responders 
After 2002 and the Indian nuclear war, plus the Chinese constantly shipping stuff to Africa, the Philippines switches to an entirely war-based economy 
In 2003, a massive monsoon destroys Manilla and Baguio becomes the capital of the Philippines 
Throughout the rest of 2003 and 2004, huge numbers of people are forcibly resettled, and this causes families to be separated 
In 2005, on the 10th anniversary of Robles declaring martial law, a group of rebels take over a labor camp and free the prisoners, kicking off the Filipino Civil War
By 2011, the two groups are divided in roughly the same way as they were in the 1970s 
The war causes many to die and also frequently causes crop fields to be burnt, with millions dying of famine 
By 2015, the war has boiled down to who can feed their citizens better. Rebels start executing suspected traitors on the spot, and the north does the same. Both sides stop taking prisoners, and dozens of boats leave everyday, trying to flee the brutal civil war. Many die at sea. 
In 2016, Robles dies from respiratory complications and causes a succession crisis, as many in the pro-government north kill each other in a game of thrones style squabble. Around the same time, the socialist south sees several islands declare independence and stop sharing their resources with the main rebel government in Valencia, causing more infighting and the Valencia government launching a costly campaign to take back the rebel islands 
In 2017, the main rebel island of Samar is destroyed in a huge monsoon, and both sides fracture farther 
In 2022, a random colonel in the pro-government forces begins a campaign to reunite the north under a single banner
By 2024, he is successful, and begins a plan to retake the south 
Between 2024-2027, his campaign continues, and he finds that much of the south has collapsed due to frequent flooding, with only a few, isolated city-states remaining 
By 2027, the Philippines might actually end its civil war, but the country has been left in ruins and frequent storms and freak weather events make habitation costly, but still possible 
Singapore (Population: 7,152,345, circa 1980)
Literally the exact same as OTL until the crash of 1988
A massive tsunami destroys Singapore, forcing many to evacuate and flee to Malaysia, Indonesia, and Indochina
Throughout the 1990s there are several attempts to reclaim Singapore, but the government gives up by 1997 and instead settles in East Malaysia
In the 2000s, Singapore has become a sort of "Venetian pirate haven” 
In the 2010s, progressively larger storms cause many to leave the region
In 2015, the Malaysian Jihad burns down the ruins of Singapore 
In the 2020s, more and more ruins are washed out to sea
By 2027, Singapore is completely forgotten to history
Papua New Guinea (Population: 23,892,670, circa 1990)
In the 1970s, Australia takes a less active approach to governing PNG
In the 1970s, many previously uncontacted tribes are studied by anthropologists around the world (though they take care to not spread diseases to them)
Bougainville and the North Solomons end up gaining more influence in PNG, as mining operations expand across the island
After PNG becomes independent and Australia leaves, the lack of training and education is exploited by the Bougainville Mining Company
Between 1975-1988, the government of PNG is very unstable and corrupt, with frequent accusations of election fraud, voter intimidation, and cheating in elections
During all of this, Bougainville Mining Company, now renamed to Pacific Copper Company, starts gaining control of local areas 
A constitutional crisis in 1980 causes PNG to be reformed into a confederacy, with some areas being so autonomous that they were practically independent 
In 1982, the PCC lobbies to have election deposits increased so that only those rich enough can run for office
In 1983, tribal conflict becomes so bad, that PCC lobbies for the armed forces of PNG to protect their interests. Mercenaries from around the world also join in, and briefly, many people think that PNG will be the site of the next major proxy war
In 1984, in the vacuum left by the armed forces and law enforcement, many gangs start to take over smaller towns. These gangs later ally themselves with Triads and similar gangs from Asia, and also rebel groups from Indonesia
In 1985, this culminates in the Siege of Port Moresby, in which a coalition of various governments (Namely China, Australia, Indonesia and the United States) launch a peacekeeping mission to wipe out the numerous crime gangs and insurgents. PNG is placed under martial law, and a major politician (coincidently the former CEO for PCC) becomes the interim leader
In 1986, under the guise of pacification, huge amounts of the island are destroyed in intensive strip mining operations
In 1987, many in PNG began to see increased poverty as their resources were siphoned away to Indonesia, India, and China
In 1988, PNG is hit very hard by the crash. Many of the rich leave to other places, causing an even bigger brain drain. The federal government effectively collapses, and many towns are controlled by local gangs. This spirals into a far-left nationalist movement, supported allegedly by the Soviet Union. 
In December 1988, the PNG civil war starts with the Bougainville Uprising. Using construction and mining equipment, partizans take up arms and march to Buka. 
By April 10, 1989, the civil war is over, with the People’s Army of New Guinea having taken over the country 
In 1989, Australia offers aid, however the new government declines this
Between 1989-1992, heightened by the Hot Summer, the government of PNG slowly fractures from corruption and mismanagement, much like the previous one. Food shortages, black outs, and famine from overexploitation lead to the country breaking apart into several fiefdoms and city states, mainly based on tribal identity 
By 1993, PNG is in anarchy 
In 1998, Indonesia annexes PNG for their resources 
In the 2000s, various rebel grounds in Indonesia are sent to work as convicts in PNG
In 2003, a failed uprising leads to many attempting to flee for Australia, some make it
In the 2000s, PNG becomes the headquarters for the new resistance movement against Indonesia. Many are forcibly resettled here. 
In the 2010s, PNG becomes the most stable region of Indonesia, with a loose alliance of city-states and islands forming a left-wing anarchist confederacy 
Between 2016-2023, PNG takes advantage of the chaos and starts supplying weapons to people fighting in the civil war, in exchange for oil
During the second Great Heatwave, PNG almost falls to civil war again, with numerous islands flooding and refugee crises 
By 2027, PNG is on the brink of civil war again, and the various factions are preparing to fight over the last habitable zones 
Brunei 
Gained independence in 1984
Lasted a very short time, was notably corrupt between 1984-1988
In 1988, it fell to civil war
In 1989, it was absorbed by East Malaysia 



Bangladesh (Population: 282,577,001, circa 2000) 
Became independent in 1972
Becomes closely aligned with the USSR in the early 1970s, and as a result the dictator isn’t assassinated 
Throughout the late 1970s and early 1980s, the US and China try to open up Bangladesh
In 1981, they finally become democratic, and sign the Shanghai Accords
In the 1980s, Bangladesh becomes closely aligned with China, with many people leaving to work in super factories 
After the crash of 1988, Bangladesh starts negotiating with China for aid, but then they are approached by Savateev who gives them a few papers proving the ethnic cleansing of the muslims in China who refused to renounce their faith. This leads to an “Islamic Revolution” similar to what was going on in the remnants of the Middle East 
In the 1990s, Bangladesh launches several insurgencies into China before India and China make an unlikely alliance and wipe out Bangladesh 
India annexes Bangladesh in 1999
Bangladesh ends up being a pyrrhic victory, as there are practically no natural resources, the energy infrastructure become non-functional in 1989, and constant flooding cause mass migration 
As a result, after the nuclear war in 2002, Bangladesh becomes an anarchic wasteland controlled by neo-maoists, islamic socialists, remnants of the Indian government, gangsters, bandits, rebels, and pirates 
In the 2010s, Bangladesh stops being capable of any agricultural support resulting to a culture of smuggling and raiding nearby shipments 
In the 2020s, a cult of cannibals have taken over the ruins of Bangladesh 
By 2027, much of Bangladesh is a wasteland 
Sri Lanka (Population: 32,874,281, circa 2000) 
In 1971, the JVP socialists insurrection fails, and causes socialism to be banned in all forms in Sri Lanka
In 1972, a joint US-Chinese commission helps stabilize Sri Lanka, with India protesting
On 22 May 1972, the Republic of Sri Lanka is formed, and the first free elections are held later that year
In actuality though, it is a one-party state with very little social services, leading to many to emigrate in the 1970s 
In the 1980s though, Sri Lanka becomes a hotbed for tourism and mining, and the economy starts rapidly expanding as China and India both invest heavily in Sri Lanka’s infrastructure, both trying to gain influence over the other
The civil war is narrowly avoided but a low-intensity insurgency takes place from 1983-1988, with the Soviet Union supposedly funding them at the start. 
This terrorism gradually ramps up to an international hostage crisis in May 1988, distracting much of the world from the Sinai War
On June 8th, 1988, President King and the President of the European Commission, Baron Friedrich von Schwerin of West Germany, had successfully negotiated the return of all foreign nationals and ended the hostage crisis. 
After the crash of 1988, immediately after the hostage crisis, while the rest of the world is focused on the aftermath of the nuclear war, the far-left Tigers of Tamil launch a full on civil war. Sri Lanka’s government initially holds their own until funds dry up in the aftermath of the crash, and the Soviet Union begins sending guns to the rebels
The fighting continues for some time, with India supporting the Sri Lankan government, until the government forces run out of supplies during the siege of Colombo due to an Indian Famine due to the Hot Summer, and the government surrenders to the socialists 
Later that year in 1990 the Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka is formed, and all the shortcomings and resource shortages are blamed on the past government 
This new socialist government quickly turns into a totalitarian dictatorship, with soviet-style gulags and rationing implemented. Power shortages and brown outs, along with the dictator focusing on agriculture, makes the industry stagnate completely 
A major famine in 1994 causes Sri Lanka to threaten to invade India, and India finally relents when they give them aid 
This continues for some time, with Sri Lanka raiding nearby ships, and India eventually building up several military bases along the coast
In 1999, the dictator of Sri Lanka finally launches an actual invasion into India, though they get wiped out really fast, with Sri Lanka being annexed by India in 2000. 
From 2000-2002, India begins salvaging operations to scavenge metal from the old rusting equipment 
After the nuclear war, some remnants of India’s government hide out on the island but are all overthrown/killed in rebellions and have no influence on the island by 2010
In the 2010s, some scavenging operations are set up by China and Food, Inc, but constant rainstorms, typhoons, and even tornadoes devastate the island
In the 2020s, flooding starts to claim large amounts of the island, with the last remnants abandoning their outposts
By 2027, Sri Lanka is a storm-ravaged wasteland picked over by only the most desperate of scavengers 
Nepal (Population: 42,233,498, circa 2000) 
Panchayat system is developed as in OTL
Nepal becomes a chess game played between India and China, China wants to use their population as a cheap source of labor while India wants to keep them Hindu
The referendum in 1980 results with the Panchayat system being dismantled, and a constitutional monarchy being established
The Shanghai Accords are signed in 1981, and the government is dominated by two parties: the Royal Party (supported by India) and the People’s Party (supported by China) 
Throughout the 1980s, many people emigrate out to India and China for job opportunities 
After the crash of 1988, Nepal ends up signing several deals with India and becomes closer to them, with China doing several "military exercises” along the border
In 1989, the pro-China faction begins several “uprisings” against the Hindu government, India sends them supplies and helps “police” the Maoists 
In the Hot Summer of 1990, the civil unrest escalates into a massive civil war, with India and the USSR supporting the Nepalese against the Chinese
In 1991, spillover into India leads to India officially annexing Nepal 
In the 1990s, Nepal becomes a massive military base for India. Due to the climate and worsening pollution, some high-ranking members of the Indian government and military make apartments in Nepal 
In the 2000s, after the nuclear war with Pakistan, Nepal becomes a military outpost and enclave for the Indian government, with pro-government forces trying to regain control of local areas. 
Between 2003-2011, various campaigns have tried to retake parts of India, but in the end, these campaigns make no headway and by the Summer of 2011, a revolution happens and the “Indian Emergency Regime of Nepal” collapses into civil war
By 2015, Nepal is severely depopulated, and there are some holdouts but for the most part it is abandoned 
By 2027, a few bands of scavengers and raiders fight over water in the peaks, who have long that civilization ended in 2002 
Bhutan (Population: 896,597, circa 2000) 
In 1972, Bhutan forms close ties with Bangladesh 
In 1974, the plot to assassinate the current king is found out and as a show of power, the king executes the would-be conspirators 
In the Glorious Decades, Bhutan remains a relatively poor place, playing Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh off each other. Indian and Malaysian tourists frequently visit. 
In 1989, a revolution against the king leads to several Indian nationals to be held hostage. India negotiates with them, and almost invades Bhutan, and a socialist republic is established 
In 1990, massive famine and heatwaves cause the socialist government to almost collapse, and smuggling between India and China becomes the main sector in the economy
This new socialist government lasts for a very short time, as in 1991, another revolution happens and a group of radical buddhists take over and create a totalitarian theocracy, claiming that the world has ended and that everyone must reincarnate to their next stage in life 
In the 1990s, insurgents of these radical buddhists frequently spill over into China, India, and Indochina. This leads to India invading and annexing them in 1997
Between 1997-2002, Bhutan is basically a giant detention camp ran by India 
After the nuclear war, the radical buddhists “free” the locals and use Bhutan as their base of operations. 
Between 2003-2015, the buddhists launch tons of insurgencies and some become bandits/cultists in the Indian wasteland
During the Great Heatwave of 2015, all the remaining members of the cult all commit ritual suicide 
By 2027, Bhutan is occasionally picked over by bandits and scavengers 
Seychelles (Couped by Mercenaries in 1981, turned into a Capitalist “Paradise” shortly afterward, with Tourism playing a massive role. Of course the local nature is absolutely devastated by this, but very few care at the time as even the locals, reduced to little more than a nation of maids, janitors and maintenance workers, enjoy prosperity that would make many Westerners jealous. ,,Mad Mike”, the Mercenary Leader of the country, frequently fuels the economy with his own cash that he brings back from various adventures abroad. When the Crash hits his advisors convince him that they must seal off the country from the rest of the world, and after seeing the shitfest happening everywhere, he begrudgingly agrees. Before long all tourists are given a simple choice - leave NOW, or join them and stay forever. Most choose to leave, and tend to regret that choice. He tries to turn the country back around, but nature is too devastated to support the population even as it, which leads him down a very, very dark path. Pretty much, the Seychelles adopts Social Darwinism as a state policy - Black or White, the weak die, and the strong prosper. Everyone works, and those who can’t anymore are killed. The sheer scale of the death makes “Mad Mike" completely snap and go along with the insanity, eventually proclaiming himself King (His Majesty Thomas the First, Long may he Reign) in 1999 to universal approval among survivors. Increasingly senile, he becomes little more than a sockpuppet in the hands of various Chancellors, with the Island wrecked by storms forcing an increasingly large chunk of their population to go underground or as far inland as possible. After Mad Mike dies in 2017 due to all the pollution, his niece Bree O’Mara takes charge as Queen Brigid the First, long may She reign. Yes, the Long May He / She reign part is mandatory to say each time their names are mentioned. Either way, she rolls back some of her uncle’s more loony decrees and even institutes a form of consensus decision making. By 2027, the population only consists of a couple thousand somewhat gaunt people squatting in ruins and living underground, but they’re surprisingly organized, and while rations mostly consist of gruel and the occasional stale shit, they’re regular and reliable. Not shown on most maps, as the world kinda just assumes everyone is dead, like in the Maldives and Cape Verde.
Maldives (The Monarchy was still abolished in 1968. Under President Nasir, it quickly developed, modernizing its finishing industry and investing heavily into the booming tourist industry. Various luxury resorts are created which service foreign tourists for eye wateringly low prices, while investments into television and Public Relations ensure that both foreign dignitaries and local officials alike know that this prosperity is the work of Nasir and Nasir alone. After some negotiations, the Maldives Government buys the Gan Airport from the British with a fraction of its profits and subsequently negotiates an agreement with China to feed their Megafactories with Maledivan Fish, avoiding any economic shocks and further fueling their growth. Nasir remains President and grows increasingly authoritarian into the 80s, but avoids any rash idiocy so as to not scare away tourists (who’d like to buy a cabin next to a death camp?), mostly focusing on political assassinations abroad. However, cracks begin to show as early as 1987 as overfishing and mass tourism mean the supply of fish dries up, and some complain of there being too much trash on the once pristine beaches. Once the crisis hit in 1988, the economy completely collapsed and food riots shook the country. A group of private mercenaries overthrew the Government but struggle to actually rule on any level above ,,Rape, pillage and burn”. The Indian Navy heads over to the Islands to try and restore order, but only shells the Capital, killing much of the ,,cabinet” and starting a series of devastating fires. They are soon the least of the survivors’ worries, as a hurricane destroys several Indian vessels and completely annihilates whatever remnants of the Mercenary Regime survived. With mass famine and a collapse in law and order, the Maldives were mostly abandoned by 2000, with storms subsequently wiping it clear of any life above bacteria by the turn of the decade. Not shown on maps anymore.  
Pakistan (Population: 352,501,542, circa 2000)
Overall more aligned with China
In 1974, following the humiliation of Pakistan by India and Bangladesh, the Balochistan civil unrest escalates into an all out war, supposedly supported by Iran and the USSR. 
In 1975, Pakistan is placed under martial law
In 1976, the rebels win and take over the country, creating the Islamic Socialist Republic of Pakistan. Many members of the failed iranian revolution fled to Pakistan later on. Several socialist, but religious, policies are made: All schools and education are free, but all schools are state owned and teach the values of “Islamic Socialism” 
In early 1977, martial law is lifted, though Pakistan becomes a theocracy much like Iran ITTL
In 1977 and 1978, the USSR covertly helps Pakistan develop their nuclear weapons, with their first detonation taking place in 1979. 
In the 1980s, Pakistan covertly helps support the USSR in Afghanistan
After TMI though, Pakistan stops building nuclear power plants and focuses on building nukes solely as deterrence 
In the early 1980s, Egypt and Iran keep trying to get Pakistan to open up to free trade, but the USSR advises against it
In 1983, after Agassi’s corruption scandal, Pakistan signs the Shanghai Accords 
Pakistan leaves COMECON and joins the Arab League, becoming closer to Egypt and Saudi Arabia 
Pakistan strongly resists Qatifism, as the theocratic dictator of Pakistan views it as a threat to his power
Pakistan makes a lot of money selling and manufacturing weapons for the war in Afghanistan 
In 1988, Pakistan openly supports the Egypt Coalition, though does not participate in the Sinai War
In 1988, after the nukes drop, Pakistan initially helps supply Iranian revolutionaries overthrow the Shah, along with the USSR
In 1988 they also organize evacuations in Oman and UAE
This quickly gets out of hand though, as in 1989, Pakistan starts to be flooded with radioactive refugees. Protests and demonstrations by the refugees turn violent, and Pakistan starts to close itself off
Pakistan starts promoting “National Islamic Socialism” and places the country under martial law 
In 1990, a massive border wall is built along the border with Iran. In response to Voronin’s aggression in Afghanistan and Iran, Pakistan fears invasion by the USSR and wishes to keep their sovereignty, so they restore the nuclear plan
In 1991, after a massive famine, Pakistan severs support to West Malaysia
In 1992, the theocratic dictator is killed by his men and a military junta is established, with much less an emphasis on Islam and more about keeping the country together 
In the 1990s, the armed forces start shooting border crossers on sight, and refugees that were welcomed just a few years ago are now rounded up and executed 
By 1993, overindustrialization and exploitation of the land in Pakistan leads to a huge famine and drought, with pollution blocking out sunlight for months at a time. The Military Junta blames India 
In 1994, Pakistan starts building up their military near India’s border 
In 1995, famines cause Pakistan to become increasingly reliant on fishing to feed their people 
In 1996, family planning is enforced and rationing is implemented on water and energy 
In 1997, in response to the massive unrest in Asia, Pakistan starts trying to curry favor with the USSR, but it’s too little, too late. Excessive pollution in Lahore causes the entire city to be evacuated, with temporary housing made Multan
However, a massive landslide in 1998 causes over 4 million deaths due to poorly constructed buildings, and the military starts considering invading India to gain access to their land in Punjab 
In 1999, extreme drought, desertification, and storms causes Pakistan to abandon Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan, with over 350,000,000 people crowded into the Indus Valley, which is being devastated with flooding, landslides, and famine 
In 2000, an attempted coup on the military dictator forces Pakistan to rethink their land allocation, and risking a war with China and India, they send people to be resettled in Gilgit-Baltistan
In 2001, Pakistan starts to prepare for war with India
In 2002, Pakistan invades India through Kashmir, then through the Indus valley. Pakistan makes it to New Delhi and that’s when India launches the nukes. Pakistan strikes back, and manages to hit major indian cities, but the remnants of the military are wiped out when Kashmir is saturated with nuclear bombs. Much of Pakistan’s side of the Indus River Valley also is wiped out
Throughout 2003-2005, various pockets of Pakistani resistance wage war on Indian forces before being wiped out from lack of supplies or dying of radiation poisoning 
By 2010, Pakistan is a nuclear-ravaged wasteland, incapable of supporting life, though there are some outposts at the base of the northern regions 
By 2017 though, these last remnants of civilization collapse into anarchy and warlordism, with Indian raiders frequently attacking them 
By 2024, most of the glaciers in Kashmir have melted, filling the Indus River Valley with radioactive chemicals 
As of 2027, much of Pakistan is completely abandoned, absorbed by the Great Asian Dust Bowl
India (2,539,738,784, circa 2000)
Overall more aligned with USSR
The Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 happens as usual, however, casualties are far fewer - only 1,500 casualties total on both sides 
In 1972, India does not sign a treaty with the USSR, instead remaining non-aligned 
They view the intervention in Sri Lanka as upsetting the balance of power, and pledge non-aligence 
In the Glorious Decades, India invested equally in agriculture and industry 
India goes ahead with the White Revolution (overhauling its dairy industry) and prioritizes huge amounts of land for cattle grazing 
In the Glorious Decades, using growth hormones developed by European countries, India becomes the leading producer of milk 
In the Green Revolution in India, instead of investing in things like fertilizers and creating more resilient crops, they focused on things like herbicides, pesticides, and automating the agricultural industry with heavy machinery. While this did solve their food crisis, they became entirely dependant on fossil fuels
India also develops more efficient irrigation techniques, including purification facilities (that again are dependant on fossil fuels) 
Stubble burning becomes very common all the way back in 1974
The Emergency happens (1975-1977), with her opposition supposedly being supported by the USSR
A series of strikes in 1975 and the supreme court decision leads to Indira Gandhi declaring a state of national emergency, and basically putting India under martial law. This strained the already low food supplies
China helps to root out the Maoist insurgents 
The Emergency focuses more on the economy and worker’s rights, as opposed to stuff like poverty, the environment, and family planning
Raj Narain is publicly executed in 1976
India’s economy only goes down however, due to them not being able to compete with the New China
Over double the amount of demolitions were carried out (300,000+) leading to over 2 million to be displaced
The Emergency ends in 1977, and elections are called. A new pro-free trade politician wins in a landslide. His name is Raghunath Prasad Malhotra, and he is viewed as the “father of new India” 
Malhotra accuses Gandhi's administration of rampant corruption, and dismantles many programs with the promise of rebuilding them from the ground up, free of corruption
India attempts to stave off their money problems, but by 1977, they give and sign the Shanghai Accords, and reluctantly open up to investment from China. Malhotra also practically removes the Licence Raj
India is in a unique position however - they are not a one-party state like China, but with their huge population, they cannot go full ancap or risk an uprising. They delicately oscillate between currying favor with the USSR, and with the USA/China
Malhotra also focuses on improving relations with Pakistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal and Sri Lanka
China starts building car factories in India, though Malhotra minimizes the amount of control China has over them 
Malhotra is re-elected in a landslide in 1982
In the early 1980s, India is forced to open up many sharecropping initiatives with foreign owned farms, such as ones owned by Brazil, Argentina, USA, France, West Germany, UK, Canada, Italy, Norway, China, USSR, Australia, ect
Malhotra takes a much more peaceful stance on the Punjab insurgency: he allows Sikhs to immigrate to Bangladesh or Pakistan, no strings attached, peacefully
Indian companies, trying to usurp China, tries to invest in Sri Lankan mining companies 
In 1981, India and Indonesia sign multiple trading agreements in an attempt to usurp China
Throughout the 1980s, both China and the USA attempt to entice India into their trading blocs, but India wants to essentially lead their own
In 1982, immigration laws are relaxed to help entice more workers to come to India to work in factories or fields
The Sikh Riots in 1984 are far more peaceful, with only one person killed by accident 
The Bhopal Disaster in 1984 is small enough to be covered up, and instead the company dumps their chemicals in the major rivers in the area. Only 35,000 people are injured 
In 1987, Malhotra is re-elected, and this time, he starts to promote a more nationalist vision for India, with India taking China’s place as the dominant industrial power in the world 
By 1988, less than 1% of India’s farms are owned by Indian companies 
India remains neutral during the Sinai War
After the crash of 1988, India’s economy rapidly collapses, with their agricultural industry nosediving. Malhotra, viewing this as India’s chance to take the world stage, instead tries to pass tax cuts and other things to stimulate the economy 
In late 1988, tensions between Pakistan, Bangladesh and Malaysia form against India, as Pakistan (and later Bangladesh) side with the Egyptian Coalition and start to promote radical Islamic Socialism 
In 1988, India signs a treaty with Nepal
In 1989, trade deals with Indonesia lead to India keeping its agricultural system running, but many companies become bankrupt and close down, and foreign investors leave by the millions
While Malhotra remains calm, level-headed and relatively rational, his opposition, Raghavendra Pratap Singh, claims that it is because of the radical islamists that doomed the world, and India. He promotes extreme protectionism, nationalizing foreign owned businesses in India, and also creating more socialist policies 
Malhotra focuses on helping Bhutan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka, and Singh uses this to shit talk Malhotra 
Everything cascades in 1990 when a massive famine, due to storms preventing the shipment of Indonesian oil, cripples India. Pollution, chemicals from pesticides, and soot from wildfires all come together to create “the fog”, an extremely dense cloud of heavy gases that blocks out the sun for almost 14 months. Social unrest due to resource shortages escalate to riots, and troops are recalled from Nepal and Kashmir to deal with the unrest. Visakhapatnam is almost burned down in a massive oil fire. Martial law is declared. 
By 1991, unrest has grown to such a degree that Malhotra is assassinated and Singh declares himself “Emergency Minister” 
Singh mobilizes the army and works with China to “pacify” the Bangladeshi insurgency, then takes over Nepal
Singh completely re-organizes the economy, with all industry being dedicated entirely to either agricultural production, essential materials, or for the military. The armed forces sees a massive recruitment drive, with incentives such as better food, less cramped quarters, and “forwarding Indian pride” 
India begins threatening China (and later Pakistan) with nuclear weapons under Singh
Nepalese water helps feed India’s irrigation systems, with Nepal becoming a heavily militarized territory
By 1994, India has been reformed into an ultranationalist dictatorship, barely staving off chronic famines, and becoming extremely militaristic. Sri Lanka keeps harassing India for supplies, with Singh not viewing Sri Lanka as worth it to invade at the time, worrying about becoming open to invasion by China or Pakistan while their back is turned
In 1995, muslims are carted off to "re-education camps” where they work farms. Malaysian and Bangladeshi refugees are shot on sight. Military bases are built up along the border with China and Pakistan
Throughout the 1990s,”the fog” occasionally reforms over large cities, but it never lasts more than three months. During those times, the government mandates shelter-in-place orders and provides gas masks 
By 1997, things get out of hand when India launches an invasion into Bhutan, citing their Buddhist insurgency as a threat to the Indian people. This causes mass protests, despite the totalitarian state, and India fractures into a civil war
Bhutan is turned into a giant detention camp, where rebels are detained
Between 1997-2002, the “Pro Democracy Alliance”, seeking to depose Singh and restoring democracy, wages a guerrilla war with India’s government. Supposedly, they are funded by China and Pakistan 
The PDA is responsible for numerous terrorist attacks and industrial sabotages, leading to over 20 million in deaths and a massive industrial accident 
India invades and annexes Bangladesh in 1999, citing fishing rights
Sri Lanka also tries to invade India, and Singh launches a campaign to annex Sri Lanka in 2000
