As it turns out, “The Fog”, combined with the sabotage operations of the PDA, caused a mass breakdown in industrial capacity for India and they begin scavenging operations in Bangladesh and Sri Lanka
By 2001, the government really only controls the coast and the cities along the Ganges, with much of the interior of the country in anarchy, controlled by the PDA, or completely abandoned 
Near the end of 2001, after torpedoing a fishing boat and this escalates into a full-blown war with India
In January of 2002, Pakistan, using The Fog as cover, launches a war into India through Kashmir
Between January-April, India and Pakistan fight of Kashmir, India’s huge military helps them maintain an edge 
During the summer, Pakistan retreats from Kashmir and starts burning crop fields in Punjab and Haryana
In September, Pakistani forces encircle New Delhi and burn it down, causing Singh to launch nukes at them 
Much of Pakistan’s government is destroyed, and Singh’s government moves to Meerut
Between 2002-2007, India’s government tries to regain control of the country, but the nukes have led to over a billion dead and large swathes of the country to die off. Many claim that Singh is no longer the leader of India, and the civil war escalates further
The factions are: the Bangladeshi Provisional Government, the Sri Lankan Enclave, the Nepalese Emergency Regime, the North India Authority, the Western Union (controlled by the PDA) and the Southern Alliance (controlled by a series of warlords) 
Many of these governments lose contact with each other, and apocalyptic suicide cults spring up across the wasteland 
In 2007, China kills Singh and starts dividing up India 
The faction in Sri Lanka is wiped out in 2010, and Nepal’s government is deposed in a revolution in 2011
By the time Food, Inc arrives in 2014, India is just a series of isolated city states on their coasts. The largest of these is the Keralan Junta
Between 2014-2020, interior India devolves into an anarchic wasteland controlled by cultists, cannibals, raiders, and smugglers 
In the 2020s, many in India openly practice cannibalism. A new religion has taken off - a sort of apocalyptic fusion of Buddhism and Hinduism, and the act of cannibalising someone is ritualized 
By 2027, much of India is dying off, as the last bits of arable land are being corrupted by chemicals from the Glorious Decades or the nuclear wear. Many are killing themselves, and those that don't are cannibalistic cultists who frequently attack each other. Along the coast, some settlements survive with minimal cannibalism, instead raiding nearby ships, but that is becoming an increasingly rare occurrence. The Keralan Junta is the region with the least amount of cannibalism, though everyone is starving and dying of water-borne diseases or radiation 


Benin (Remains ,Dahomey”. Constant Coups mean OTL’s communist regime does not stay for long, but nobody bothers to invest - what’s the point if next week’s regime will just nationalize it back? Still, by 1985, it mostly calms down, and Dahomey surprisingly begins to emerge as a somewhat liberal state - one with a developed (although heavily corrupt) welfare net and a semi stable Democratic System (even if one plagued by political assassinations). The 1986 Elections (Presidential and Parliamentary are held concurrently) are, surprisingly, seen as Free and Fair by most observers, even if there’s a few irregularities further inland where Government control is not as strong. The newly elected young President is quite popular, and nets more than a few positive comparisons to the Kennedys. That said, he does mostly focus on internal affairs and self sufficiency, which does cause the Opposition to nickname him ,Robinson Crusoe" but he doesn't care. However, he is too late, and the 1988 Crash absolutely fucks up Dahomey’s Export based economy, causing unemployment to skyrocket and his popularity to plummet to the Mariana Trench. He tries to dissolve Parliament and rule by decree in 1989, but the Military Stages a counter-coup to ,,Protect Democracy” - the subsequent 1990 Elections return a Presidency and Legislature dominated by the Armed Forces, and later suffrage is limited to members of such, but Dahomey does remain somewhat stable during the Red Decade, even if it’s piss poor. However, the 2000s bring with them waves of Sahelian Refugees trying to flee Southward, and the Army, while they fight valiantly, simply cannot beat them back (especially not after whatever remains of the Sahel’s militaries also gets the memo and flees Southward). The country falls into chaos, and much of Porto Novo burns down in unclear circumstances. By 2010, not shown on most maps, although the survivors (usually on isolated farmsteads or stranded deep in the savanna) do live somewhat comfortably… by medieval peasant / Food, Incverse standards.
Burkina Faso (Still known as Upper Volta. The country goes through its usual growing pains, aka coups, in the 60s and 70s, but most are relatively bloodless. The 1974 Famine shocked the populace, leading to the creation of a generally stable Marxist State. In 1984, after a corruption scandal, Captain Thomas Sankara came to power - in a relatively Democratic Vote inside the People’s Party. In the aftermath he does a lot in the way of famine prevention, all while trying to imitate the USSR’s version of "Developed Socialism”. Human Rights are actually somewhat respected, and corruption was rooted out. By 1988, the Crash doesn't impact the country all that much, and it remains an isolated fortress of relative calm, mostly trading with its neighbors (many of whom are reluctant, but beggars can’t be choosers) and slowly developing its domestic Industries, trying to put an end to subsistence farming and bring Agriculture into the 20th Century. They do a bit of trade with the Cubans, but not too much. Sankara’s Anti Famine Plans and Backups mean that the encroaching Sahara doesn't have too much of an impact, but they are nevertheless forced to take action when constant droughts begin to quite literally wither away at the Agricultural Sector. Dozens of farms are abandoned, and many farmers need to be literally kept at gunpoint to prevent them from leaving. This makes them increasingly resentful toward the Government and provokes a few quickly crushed peasant revolts. The Regime slowly retreats closer and closer to the Southern Borders (even encroaching into their mostly nonexistent neighbors’ territory from one point onward), although they do so in a controlled manner, successfully evacuating who they can and moving agriculture backward with them. They are aware this cannot go on forever, though, and by 2010 there are two factions emerging inside the Politburo - one that wants to leave some people to die and another that wishes to send them on near suicide missions to reestablish farms in the interior. In the end, someone spikes their water supply with poison and decapitates the Government on Christmas Eve of that year. Surprisingly this doesn't cause total collapse, but instead a somewhat healthy transition to ‘Democracy’ - sure, there’s still one party (the Prosperity Party, which is the old People’s Communist Party but with a new coat of paint) but there’s now more freedom of speech and press for the 3 literate folks left. They even hold a Presidential Election in 2020, although it’s more of a referendum than anything since they only let one guy on the ballot. By the Great Death, Upper Volta is perhaps the last somewhat functional state in Africa save the GAR, and although in crippling poverty and with corruption slowly creeping in, it’s still far from the worst place to be. 
Cape Verde (Never became Independent. Remaining a part of Portugal, with the Lisbon Government helping the locals clean up their own authoritarianism, letting the territory become prosperous and less corrupt far earlier than in OTL. Hungry for more cash, the Portuguese encourage tourism in the area, which works wonders. By 1980 it was one of the most popular spots in the world, having a somewhat friendly competition with the Maldives for the top one seat. Having more money than they knew what to do with, the Regional Government invested in creating a massive hospital / laboratory to try and mass manufacture a cure for Malaria. They… somewhat succeeded, as their method was efficient but horribly expensive, even for the Glorious Decades. When the Crash Came in 1988, their Tourist industry survived longer than most, but attacks from African Marauders cut that short as well. The Hospital caught fire in 1992 and was never rebuilt, mostly serving as a massive slum for the growing unemployed population, whom the Government refused to eject - where else would they go, anyways? Much of the local populace is dead or leaves by 2000, meaning the Chain is mostly inhabited by European Federation higher ups (who have luxury houses in the area), their Servants (sometimes the poor of their respective countries, coaxed into signing very unfair deals, sometimes the remaining locals with no other way to maintain themselves) and the Hospital Hobos, who have now formed a Commune. The Hobos launch an offensive in mid 2003, and they technically succeed, as they capture the Island - however this doesn't mean shit as it was in Summer and all the Higher Ups were back home. The Federation Navy successfully blasts the ,,People’s Militia” (a mix of the Hobos and deserting servants) into Kingdom Come, but other than a few missions to recover personal items from the now desecrated and shit-stained Mansions, they don’t bother to reestablish a foothold. Much like the Maldives, the islands are frequently wiped clean with large storms, leaving little evidence of human habitation aside from the occasional foundation or a half decent amount of rubble strewn around. Everyone except the European Federation no longer bothers to show it on maps (Brussels is not going to give up, and they insist on including the deserted chain in official documentation).
Equatorial Guinea (See below)
Gabon (The Gabonese Democratic Bloc emerges victorious over the Military in 1963 without French aid, and subsequently they form a somewhat healthy Two party System with the Democratic and Social Union (GDB and GDSU, for future reference). Of course there’s some corruption, and a few Presidents need to be dragged out of office to protect Democracy, but all in all things could be worse. In the 70s Oil was discovered, and once GDSU took power in 1972 they exploited it to its full potential, using the money to fund a "welfare state”, although a better term would be “corruption system”. The GDB adopted this style once regaining power in 1980, and used the good foreign situation to take more loans and quickly develop the countryside. The 1988 Elections, though, are cancelled due to the Arab Israeli War, which makes many in the GDSU call foul play, claiming this is a disgraceful sham meant to delay the GDB’s Defeat. Protests begin on the streets, and by 1989 they escalate into an outright revolution, with GDSU higher ups taking power and quickly proving incapable of ending the crisis. They were overthrown by the Army in 1991, who in turn grew corrupt as well and had to be crushed by the Navy and Marines in 1993. Seeking to save their collapsing economy, the Navy Regime adopts a red coat of paint and begins to beg around for aid. Moscow is not interested, but Beijing sure is, and before long whatever Jungles remain and haven’t burned down yet are shopped down to satiate the Tiger’s endless hunger. Of course, this has predictable effects on the local environment, but the land is soon repurposed for mass agriculture and the tribesmen are recruited to either work the soil or head to the newly opened Factories. Of course, the pollution and desertification made the soil completely useless by 2005, at which point the Chinese packed up and left, causing yet ANOTHER Revolution, this time by the Police Force. The Police Junta  struggles to keep order and, after many, many ration decreases, is toppled yet again in 2010, this time though the ,,Rebels” crumble into infighting, causing the South of the country to turn into a bunch of overpopulated, squabbling warlord statelets (the North was mostly abandoned by that point). Not shown on most maps by 2020, although some do bother still.
Gambia (Remains decently democratic throughout the Fabulous Decaces, with an Anti Corruption Campaign in the 80s and growth thanks to international aid and exporting peanuts. Their agricultural production means they aren’t quite as hard hit by the 1988 War as some other nations, even if Elections are indefinitely postponed and rationing imposed. Due to sticking with an (at least on paper) Free Market Democratic System they’re invaded by Senegal in 1997, and do not stand much of a chance. By 2027 they’re one of the more well off parts of Senegal, providing its populace with food, even if production has declined since its peak as a result of Climate Change and the decay of farming equipment. A lack of modern pesticides doesn't help during a particularly bad insect flood in 2019, but they manage to pull through.)
Ghana (After allegations of corruption, the Military coups the Government in 1966, and is subsequently overthrown in 1972, with Democracy restored, only to be overthrown again in 1979. There are also plenty of failed coups sprinkled throughout. The Economy grew at a somewhat stable pace in the 70s, but slowed down in the early 80s due to crop fires and overpopulation, only picking up after 1986, when the President promised democratization in exchange for international aid and loans. By 1987, the country was already Africa’s fastest growing economy, even if troubled by corruption and uneven distribution of Government funds. A few days before the planned 1988 Elections, the Arab Israeli War goes Nuclear, and the President returns to Autocracy. That said, he fails to meaningfully tackle the collapse of international trade, and is toppled by the Navy in 1992. The new dictatorship is just as corrupt, but even more incompetent, and bungles its way from one crisis to another until 2000, when it’s removed by a group of Communist Plotters aided by China. In turn, China begins to invest a bit in Ghana, but only on the coastline, and in ,,secure” locations. They left by 2007, plunging the country back into poverty. Before long, the capital becomes a charred battleground, with seven different regimes (all of different political affiliations) taking charge between 2008 and 2010, and by 2011 the only somewhat stable part of the country is the Ashanti Republic - a breakaway not recognized by anyone, consisting mostly of farms protected by levies with stolen military equipment. That said, even they fall by 2020, leaving the land devoid of centralized Government and mostly consisting of small groups of scavengers or isolated farming villages. Not shown on maps by 2015.
Guinea (it remained in ruins during the early 60s, isolated from the West and with the French having destroyed a ton of infrastructure on their way out just to spite the new Socialist Government. Guinea changes sides between the USSR and China a couple of times, and unlike the rest, where the two mostly try to outbid one another by building infrastructure and sending intellectuals, this time they do it the old fashioned way by trying to stage coups. The country sees seven coups between 1960 and 1980, but only one is successful - in 1973, which sees the Pro Soviet regime toppled and replaced by a Pro Chinese One, that subsequently opens up to the West. Now that France has pretty much ditched NATO, the USA accepts them and begins properly investing. Guinean food becomes a staple for many lower class families across Latin America - ones that can afford foreign goods every once in a while but not spend too lavishly on it - and Bauxite production skyrockets. Infrastructure is built up and even a small tourist sector begins to exist on the countryside, showing interested Westerners and Chinese Higher Ups the many, many remnants of Medieval Empires and Colonial Times. When the 1988 Crash Comes, the Chairman proclaims martial law, expels all foreign influences and tries to pretty much enact an autarkic command economy. The results are mixed - famine is prevented, but quality of life quickly declines, and the few freedoms the locals had are erased as the Secret Police reigns rampant and without any sort of oversight. In spite of the warning signs, the Chairman refused to open up to China in the 90s and 2000s, and Guinea remains the ,,Black spot of Africa”, relying on outdated infrastructure and mass propaganda that wouldn’t be out of place in Mao’s China. By 2009, the people had had enough, and after word spread that the Chairman might be ill (he was actually dead, but for a few days the Government hesitated to spread the word) people took to the streets. They are crushed, but manage to destroy much of the ancient equipment the country had relied on for so long, causing mass poverty as shortages of essential goods shake the countryside and cities alike. The Regime tries to use this as an excuse to further crack down on “wreckers”, but this only results in the Army getting tired of the circus and overthrowing the Second Chairman in 2012. The Third Chairman, the former “People’s Minister of War” tries to make amends with the Chinese, but by that point they are not interested. As the interior desertifies he makes the tough decision to ditch it, evacuating as many people as he can to Conakry, subsequently making it one of the largest cities on the Continent - a title it wouldn’t keep for long, as a big chunk of the new arrivals die due to fire, disease, starvation or crime. By 2027 the Regime surprisingly still has a decent grasp on some of the inner regions of the country, and remains ,,Socialist” even if in name only, although as the Third Chairman withers on the vine (the few remaining doctors suspect some type of cancer) already many are beginning to sharpen knives and prepare to take on the role of Brutus behind the scenes.
Guinea-Bissau (Becomes independent in the mid 70s after a bloodless revolution. In spite of its Centrally Planned Economy, it remains quite prosperous for the first half of the Glorious Decades, with free schooling, a well educated populace and even social programs aimed at uplifting the countryside and emancipating women. By the late 80s, though, they’re beginning to lag behind, and even started a few early experiments with controlled economic liberalization when the crash hit. The experiments are immediately shelved and the state goes right back to the usual. By the mid 90s the situation had further deteriorated with long food lines and shortages of clothing. In 1998, the Government was overthrown by a popular revolution, but the newly formed ,,Democratic Transitional Regime” doesn't even last three months and is removed by the Military in January of 1999. The Army tries the usual approach of ,"hit the problem with the butt of your gun until it goes away”, which does not work, and their rampant deficit spending only causes more poverty, inflation and a loss of faith in the state. In 2005 a younger General (although old enough to actually know how to read and write) stages a coup against his peers and even agrees to build a singular Chinese Clothing Factory in the capital (China is already planning to pull out, and Guinea Bissau has no real easily available natural resources other than its slowly shrinking agricultural sector). He subsequently continues ruling with a firm but mostly gentle hand until his death in 2022, at which point he is succeeded by his former Minister of Agriculture, who even stages a snap election (one in which he is the only candidate, and people throw pebbles into boxes with his name due to a shortage of paper) to entrench his legitimacy. In 2025 he allows for a Parliamentary Election, even if the newly drafted constitution pretty much makes the ,,Supreme Commander” (a fusion of the Presidency, Prime Minister and Speaker) to sideline them if he so desires. The Election sees all 30 seats won by Pro President Independents, and by 2027 Guinea Bissau is actually a half decent place to live, if one ignores the semi frequent shortages of food (although ones that cause “only” malnourishment, and very rarely cross over into famine) and still rampant authoritarianism (God save your soul if some government official, even a lowly mailman, has a bone to pick with you).
Ivory Coast (the country went through an Economic Miracle in the 70s and 80s, maintaining stable growth and inviting foreign experts to help optimize the production of Cocoa - with the average Westerner much richer than before, they buy even more Chocolate and Coffee. The mostly Authoritarian One Party state was softened down in the mid 80s, with the opposition Ivorian Popular Front even allowed to take control of Parliament in the January 1988 Elections and form their own Government. Conveniently, they serve as a scapegoat for the president once the prosperity runs out, and he swiftly bans them again, dissolves Parliament and rules by decree. Newly radicalized, the IPF begins a guerilla war in the countryside, now joined by tens of thousands of impoverished farmers. By 1991 the Civil War escalates, with both sides increasingly deranged - the IPF is hijacked by Pro Cameroon Communists while White Corporations increasingly become “the tail wagging the dog” for the Government. In 1995, a drought forced the IPF out of their northern positions, which proved a blessing in disguise as the flood of refugees disorganized the Government and allowed for the ‘Populars’ to enter yamoussoukro in glory. They subsequently implement land reform, which doesn't do shit as the land is already poisoned to hell and mostly useless desert, but it nets them the backing of the remaining farmers. The country remained rather isolationist, focusing on rebuilding its ruined infrastructure (to mixed results) until 2001, when they’re approached by China, asking if they’d like to sell some of their diamonds, gold, oil and natural gas. The Government accepts, and China’s faulty equipment successfully manages to destroy whatever agricultural ability they had, with the forests burning down and whatever fish remained rapidly dying. The Fish aren’t the only beings dying, though, as disease goes through the roof due to the ChiComs burning God knows what to fuel their factories. By 2007, they say thanks but no thanks and try to leave, only for the enraged Ivorians to lynch the Engineers. China doesn't retaliate at this point, and the Engis are seen as collateral damage. The country remained in poverty during the 2010s, and by 2019 they abandoned the Capital to its fate. In 2027 one of the very, very few functioning ,,countries” in Africa, but that’s a pretty generous term for a couple dozen refugee camps, slum cities, underground farms and Military bases on a tiny strip of inhabitable land, slowly hammered in by the sea, the sand and hostile foreigners. 
Liberia (During the 1970s, Liberia still begins to make ties with Non Aligned Nations and newly opened-up China, but doesn't turn its back on the USA quite as much, content to let both sides give them money for free. Both sides, wishing to be the ones in charge of ,,the African Land of Liberty” invest a lot, bringing much of the country out of poverty and slightly alleviating the differences between the rich coast and impoverished, exploited interior. Of course, corruption still eats a significant chunk of the profits, and America-Liberians still control the vast majority of political institutions. The 1980 Coup is thwarted, but provokes the True Whigs to do a bit of token reforming, allowing a weak domestic opposition to form. In the 80s, Liberia became the "Lion of Africa” with economic growth further speeding up. Mass Resource Extraction (most notably of Iron for China) makes Climate Change worse and many rivers completely dry up, but for the time being nobody cares, and token damage pay is given to farmers so that they head to the cities and work in extraction. The demand for Timber and Lumber means its forests are completely removed from the equation. After the 1988 crisis, even as the demand for their goods plummets, Iron and Wood are so universally needed that they don’t suffer quite as much. By 1990, though, their forests ran out and the river of cash went dry, prompting a coup by the newly re-impoverished natives that soon devolved into Jacobin-esque executions of the ruling classes and their collaborators. The new Government calls for an Election, which is won by the newly formed ,,Democratic Party”. The Democrats prove far less effective at combatting the crisis than their American namesakes, and soon grow quite corrupt and authoritarian - not as much as the old Whigs, but still quite a bit. In 1994 they’re couped by the Army, with various generals ruling from then until the future. When China moved into Africa in the 2000s they considered Liberia for a while, but by then it had no resources and the long route made it unattractive. Trapped between the expanding Sahara and encroaching Seas, the Liberian State further cracks down on its populace, resulting in a Civil War erupting in 2009. Much like Togo’s, it spirals out of control, and by 2011 the country is in total anarchy. Not shown on most maps by 2020, just part of a Black Blob engulfing everything between the Mediterranean and Central Africa.
Mali (Remains Isolationist and led by the Military, stuck in a limbo between the Soviets and USA (as in, constantly changing sides, as opposed to playing off both for their own benefit) and with a backwards economy, although there is some investment in light industry by the Soviets right before the Arab Israeli War. One of the poorest and most repressive states in 1980s Africa. In 1989, in light of the Austerity Measures getting even worse, and a collapse of the planned Economic Liberalization program in light of the decline in international trade, a series of uprisings shake the country, with Tuaregs rising up in the North (many fleeing further South as the desert becomes impossible to live in, even for them) and student protests flooding major cities. Those are crushed, but they reduce the Government into really an Army with a State that has very, very loose control over the countryside around its bases, and pretty much abandons the Cities to their fate. Those enclaves of control mostly drift away and crumble by 2000, especially as the Desert engulfs them and kills most of the surviving populace, with the few remaining mostly fleeing further South. Not shown on maps by 2010. 
São Tomé and Príncipe (Much like Cape Verde, it never became independent - the Socialist Rebels proved too radical for even the new Portuguese Authorities to stomach, and after a bit of fighting were crushed. Cocoa production does rise, but corruption and mismanagement mean the average Sao Toman (?) doesn't see too many improvements to his living standards. When the crash hits, it breathes new life into the Independence Movement, although that soon ends after its leader is busted for drug trafficking (or, as some claim, framed) and most of Africa’s Independent Nations begin to go to shit. Sao Tome is mostly used as a hub that provides the mainland with luxury cocoa products without the need to export them, but piracy and storms make this less and less of a profitable industry as time goes on. By 2000 Europe pretty much pulls the plug on the whole experiment, and the Islands fall into anarchy, with many plantations burning down (either due to deliberate arson or a lack of firefighting), mass shortages of drinking water and fighting between militias and gangs (with the line between the two often quite blurry). A horrific thunderstorm in 2005 destroys whatever remains of civilization, and by 2010 the Islands are uninhabited, with the locals having died out or tried to cobble together ships (or even swim) to the mainland, not really having much of a plan on what to do after they get there. Europe insists the Islands still belong to them, but mapmakers elsewhere disagree and don’t show it after 2005. 
Senegal (Remained somewhat tolerant of different lines of thought in the 60s, allowing for the formation of a Liberal and Marxist opposition. In the 1980s it transformed, with relative ease, into a proper democracy, with the opposition Senegalese Democratic Party forming a coalition with the ruling Socialist Party of Senegal and successfully pushing through some moderate reforms, easing restrictions on freedom of speech and reigning in the Police. Market Liberalization brings in plenty of investments from the West, wishing to add another member to the ,,Family of Democracies”. Thanks to agricultural exports , phosphate and fishing the country becomes one of the more well off nations in Africa. When the crash hits, the SDP and SPS blame one another and break off the coalition, resulting in the Marxists of the African Independence Party to seize power in early 1989. They get in touch with the nation’s major trade unions and try to soften the blow of the Crash, doing the usual - collectivisation, nationalization etc. By the late 90s they did grow more and more authoritarian in a bid to contain civil discontent, and even invaded Gambia in 1997 to try and pin the blame on their failures on this neighbor. They fail, and in 1999 are couped by the Trade Unions, who institute a sort of African Syndicalism. It was certainly a brave experiment, and it worked… somewhat. Living standards did decline, but the streets remained clean and somewhat safe, even if the Government had to constantly retreat further and further inward. By 2027, they control only about a third of the country’s 1960 Territory (not counting Gambia, which they fully own), but are somewhat stable and only somewhat have to open fire on food rioters. Still shown on maps, and even internationally recognized by Moscow and Beijing (until 2023, when the recognition is revoked by a Chairman’s caprice).
Sierra Leone (The country became known as a bastion of True Democracy during the 60s and 70s, with corruption pretty much not noticeable and local culture shunning politicians who abuse their office or live lavish lifestyles. Sir Albert Margai is killed in a Tram Accident on the streets of Freetown in 1963, so he never takes power and the Military is kept in check. A thriving mining sector fuels prosperity, and the Government even experiments with tourism a bit, although the country’s small size combined with the quarries and pollution make them drop that plan relatively quickly. It even becomes a hub for dissidents fleeing from the tyranny of Liberia’s True Whig Party, further fueling economic growth as they integrate expat intellectuals into their own machine of state. In the early 80s, Agriculture was modernized, meaning the country became capable of actually exporting food and not just eating it all. When the Crash happens in 1988, the Prime Minister is granted Emergency Powers but initially rules with a rather light hand, believing the crisis will soon pass on its own and not wishing to set a bad example. That said, when he sees things aren’t getting better, he coerces Parliament to vote for an extension in 1993 and becomes increasingly heavy handed, seizing produce from Farmers and establishing what amounts to a police state. But it works, and Sierra Leone remains a bastion of relative prosperity and stability throughout the Red Decade. But with an unstable budget, the PM reluctantly let in Chinese Corporations in the early 2000s, which boosts production and employment but also causes a sharp drop in crop yields. As soon as he connects the dots he begins to make the Chinese’ lives ever so slightly harder in hopes they leave, which they did in 2006. However, as he grows older, his underlings become increasingly more corrupt and authoritarian, and when he speaks up against his own Deputy’s lavish spending in 2010 he ,,mysteriously dies”, and his heirs subsequently tear the country apart in a succession crisis. After two years of War the Army manages to retake most of the country, but they rule over ashes and are unable to restore prosperity, eventually growing fat and corrupt themselves. A popular revolt in 2020 causes the collapse of Military Rule, and with it, any sort of proper statecraft in Sierra Leone. That said, it doesn't suffer from too much overpopulation, and is surprisingly still shown on most maps all the way until the Great Death.
Togo (Reforms begin quicker than OTL - Parties Re-Established in 1980, Privatization launched in late 70s as opposed to 1983. The 1986 election was actually competitive but incumbent Eyadéma was still re-elected by a wide margin. Economic Troubles became notable earlier than for most - in 1987, due to all the shit in the air, crop yields became worse, causing a crisis that made the President return to Authoritarianism (at least,temporarily”). That never stops,though, as the 1988 Crash destroys whatever is left of the Economy, a Debt Crisis destroys consumer confidence, and by 1990 Democrats begin a civil war. Communists joined as a third side in 1992, a massive refugee crisis began as people fled from Sahel as it desertified. By 2000 the Military (Eyadema died in a terrorist attack a few months prior) proclaims ,,Victory” (because everywhere outside of Lome is an uninhabitable wasteland and all the other factions are long gone), but even they get on some boats by 2009 and vanish into the Seas, leaving the locals to die. By 2010 pretty much uninhabited aside from a handful of foolish scavengers. 

Ethiopian Water Lords: 

Ethiopia (Population: 231,394,137, circa 2010)
Selassie continues to modernize Ethiopia, signing the Shanghai Accords as part of that
This results in closer ties with Europe, China and the USA
It also prevents the 1973 famine
Because of no Oil Crisis and Brezhnev being assassinated in 1969, the coup against Selassie fails and Mengistu flees to East Germany
Because of Ethiopia’s religious population and their many days of rest, the economy ends up not rising to the staggering heights as it did in other parts of the world but still does really good
In April 1977 President Morgan and Emperor Selassie sign a treaty of military modernization, with the US training and supplying the Ethiopian military 
As the economy grew, the influence of nobles, royalty and other government officials waned and bankers and large business owners became to have the most influence 
On June 29th, 1976, Haile Selassie retires and Amha becomes Emperor
Wars with Eritrea and Somalia don’t happen
Negotiations with Eritrea lead to an end of hostilities on April 4th, 1976, granting them autonomy but still a part of Ethiopia, becoming a confederacy rather than a federation
Part of these negotiations have Haile step down
Also, feudalism is abolished (though only enforced in the autonomous regions)
Ahma Selassie ends up being a puppet for the rich 
Throughout the 1980s Ethiopia does pretty alright, with the major famine in the 1980s being avoided through trade deals with Somalia
In 1988, Ethiopia’s economy completely crashes, with the business elites fleeing to Europe and the monarchy being ousted in a soviet-sponsored revolution 
This new government remains a tenuous hold on the population with extreme force and strict curfews
Eritrea and Tigray try to leave and declare independence, and the new Revolutionary government attacks them. Ogaden also tries to leave, but due to it being the main bread basket in Ethiopia, they hold on to it for dear life
Religion is outlawed in an attempt to make a secular government
The Hot Summer of 1990 causes widespread famine and rationing
The military only maintains order because of the US military weapons given to them in the 1970s
When Somalia invades, Ethiopia repels them, and causes Somalia to fall into civil war (1990)
The revolutionary council of Ethiopia invades Djibouti in 1991
Soviets cut off aid in 1994
Anti-government militia movements grow during the 1990s, turning into a protracted civil war in 1995. 
Nation-wide martial law is declared in 1996, and the flood of refugees in the late 1990s cause border fortifications to be built
In the 2000s, due to the rise of religious cults, the government cracks down even harder against opposition. Hunger strikes become common but die out due their ineffectiveness. Criminals are sent to work in concentration camps or are used as target practice for the army 
When China comes along, they help set up mining operations and metal refineries. 
In 2008 though it becomes apparent that these have heavily damaged the water tables and soil of Ethiopia, and leads to famine after famine
The civil war picks up again in 2011, with it devolving into feudalism in 2015
In 2016, some warlords send out traders to scout for water and negotiate with their leaders. Contact is made with the Victorious Queen, and a famine is averted 
Rwanda, Burundi, and parts of Tanzania and the Congo join
In 2017 the warlords battle each other until only one remains, and he declares himself the Emperor of Ethiopia
In 2018 Sudan becomes a serf of Ethiopia, and trade routes are established with ruins of Chad, who also joins the confederacy
In 2019 remnants of the CAR and Zaire join as serfs of the Lord of the Congo
In 2021 remnants of the Republic of the Congo join the Confederacy as serfs of Chad
Ethiopian Water Lords: 
King of Lake Chad (Chad)
Chieftain of Lake Lagdo (Cameroon)
Lord of the Congo (Congo) 
The Victorious Queen (Rwanda, Burundi, Uganda, and Kenya) 
The Emperor of Tana (Ethiopia)
Sudan (Population: 47,251,917, circa 1990)
Sudan signs the Shanghai accords 
Relations between Sudan and the USSR break down following their signing of the Shanghai Accords
Internationally mediated negotiations, following a similar plan compared to Ethiopia and makes Sudan and South Sudan a confederacy
The US makes a similar treaty to the one they made with Ethiopia in 1977
However in the mid 1980s, the more Islamic leaning southern Sudan begins to side with Egypt and become anti-US, furthering ties with the Middle East
Boycotts against western and eastern goods in 1987 and 1988 lead to a civil war in March 1988, with al-Bashir leading a coalition that took over the government by April that year
Sudan joins the Sinai War 
In June 1988, an israeli nuke tries to target Khartoum but is shot down in the Red Sea, causing a mass die-off of fish there
Widespread famine and heatwaves, plus wildfires, cause Sudan to collapse into civil war in 1989. Refugees flee to South Sudan, while pro-Arab islamists migrate to Egypt, causing a demographic shift. 
In the Hot Summer of 1990, ethnic conflict cause tribes to declare war on each other over dwindling resources
Chad briefly takes over parts of Sudan in the 1990s
In the 2000s, China arrives and tries to extract as much oil as possible but constant warring between ethnic tribes and religious extremists cause China to pull out by 2002. 
In the mid 2000s, some tribes use leftover chinese equipment to mine precious minerals, and some of them sell them at high prices to the EF and the soviet union, though by 2011 this is no longer profitable 
Large amounts of arable land and careful allocation of water cause the Sudanese to survive the great heatwave of 2015 and actually end up trading with Ethiopia 
Allainces between Sudanese warlords and Ethiopian traders lead to safer trade routes and supply lines being established, though the encroaching sahara has forced many to work at night after 2017
Sandstorms and drought in the early 2020s cause Sudan to be isolated and cut off from supply lines, leading to civil war and famine with reports of rampant cannibalism 
The Ethiopians lead a military expedition into Sudan in late 2024 and reestablish order
By 2027, while relatively fertile and having many natural resources, the Ethiopians lack the equipment to get them and the wilderness outside the main trade corridor is plagued with bandits, cannibals and warlords
Uganda (Population: 56,016,528, Circa 2010)
Aligned more with the USSR than China
Amin rules over the country much like OTL, however east germany is not as involved 
The deportation of Asians cause tensions with China to fray, leading to embargos against Uganda
The economy collapses much like in OTL
Amin’s secret police and overall intelligence services are much less competent due to the lack of East German support
The Tanzian-Ugandan war is much shorter in this timeline (ending in January 1979), with Amin caught completely by surprise
China works with Tanzania and the UN to create a provisional government for Uganda that is more conducive to the free market
This new government is more authoritarian though, and China places Asians in positions of power
A massacre of Christian missionaries in 1982 causes a Christian insurgency but it remains very weak
After the crash of 1988, China tries to rig the election but it spirals out into a civil war 
By the Hot Summer of 1990, it is feudalism 
In 1992, a christian warlord begins uniting the country on a policy of “Anti-Eastern Imperialism”
This leads to the invasion of Kenya when chronic droughts affect their food supplies
This causes Uganda to collapse yet again and devolve into anarchy 
In the 2000s, China seeks out the survivors of the Anti-Asian purge and puts them in positions of power and uses them to prop up a rudimentary government so that they can extract Ugandan natural gas and oil
Uganda’s oil proves to be too costly to access but the natural gas flows all the way to 2007
The “Socialist Republic of Uganda” lasts from 2000-2015 before falling to the Victorious Queen
The Queen uses leftover Chinese equipment to engage in extensive mining operations, though is careful to not let it affect any lakes 
In the 2020s, the Queen maintains a tight grip over Uganda through all the famine, disease, drought and desertification
By 2027, Uganda is the site of the largest remaining industrial center in the Ethiopian Confederacy 
Kenya (Population: 64,441,089, circa 2010)
Signs the Shanghai Accords in 1972
The US invests heavily in the 1970s, with Morgan praising the concept of “Black Capitalism” 
Kenya remains very corrupt in the Glorious Decades
The reversal of rural-to-urban migration is successful and Kenya sees a large increase to their agricultural sector
Kenya remains closely aligned with the UK in the Glorious Decades
Succession movements in the region bordering Somalia die down to the economic upheaval
In the 1980s, Kenya remains extremely agrarian, with factories rarely being built
In the early 1980s, Morgan pressures Kenya to become more democratic
Moi wins the 1984 election 
Moi uses his executive power to put members of his ethnic tribe in positions of wealth and power, leading to further corruption
After the crash of 1988, Kenya isn’t that badly affected, only the people in power see a dramatic decline in their living standards and thus leads to a coup in 1989
The Hot Summer of 1990 and the resulting drought causes a socialist revolution that is supported by the USSR
Lake Victoria is used for irrigation and Kenya begins exporting surplus crops to neighboring nations
An invasion from Uganda in 1995 lead to the state heavily militarizing their borders and no longer supporting free trade 
China ignores them in the 2000s, though disputes with neighboring nations about the use of Lake Victoria cause conflict 
The African Water War of 2006 kicks off with Kenya taking over all of Lake Victoria and battling Chinese-supported Tanzania for control
The war ends in 2010 with Tanzania collapsing into civil war 
However, the war was devastating to Kenya’s farms and in the summer of 2011, it all comes crashing down into another civil war
It evens out into warlordism by the Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2016. A former concubine turned raider declares herself the “Queen of Lake Victoria” and makes deals with the Ethiopians to use the lake for irrigation, staving off a famine 
The Victorious Queen takes over much of the land surrounding Lake Victoria, including parts of Rwanda, Burundi, Zaire, and Uganda 
The fiefdom controlled by the Victorious Queen ends up being the main breadbasket for much of Central Africa, though Ethiopia maintains more stable and reliable harvests 
In the late 2010s and early 2020s, agents from the GAR try to launch rebellions in the Queen’s fiefdom. Burundi becomes the site of a massive “naval” battle between the GAR slave soldiers and the queen’s forces 
By the Great Heatwave of 2023 and 2024, much of Burundi and Tanzania have fallen to rebellion, famine and warlordism, becoming more aligned with the GAR by the day and controlled by bloodthirsty warlords 
Famines in the aftermath of the Great Heatwaves of 2023 and 2024 cause soldiers to regularly engage in cannibalism with fallen GAR slave soldiers 
By 2027, the Victorious Queen might not be Victorious any longer as chronic famines and wildfires cause crippling crop failures
Chad (Population: 20,451,868, Circa 2010)
During the Civil War, the French leave in 1971 and do not train the soldiers
The reforms proposed by the French up being a lot more successful 
Tombalbaye, being pragmatic, signs the Shanghai Accords in exchange for help fighting the rebels in FROLINAT
China begins helping in 1974
The rebels are wiped out in 1975
In 1977, Morgan begins pressuring him to democratize 
Free elections are held in 1978, with a french-sympathetic politician dominating the scene until 1992
In the 1980s, because of Iranian oil, Chad’s petroleum industry isnt that well developed and Chad remains mainly agrarian 
In the 1980s, Chad is used for PR purposes to make politicians and business men look good “Oh we’re donating 1 billion dollars to Chad to help fund their infrastructure!” or “I spent the summer of 1985 in Chad building affordable housing!” 
Chad’s close ties to Europe lead to it remaining neutral in the Sinai War
After the crash of 1988 though, the newly elected pro-european president makes a deal with Europe to help extract its petroleum in exchange for food support 
France is initially hesitant (due to the new communist president) but relents when the transportation breakdown affects the economy 
In 1990 after the Hot Summer Europe stops sending food and instead just launches a coup to facilitate taking the oil
This leads to a war in 1991, with Europe finally kicked out in 1992, right before the Brussels conference 
This new chad is extremely anti-European and uses the captured European equipment to launch wars into various neighboring states such as Sudan and CAR, causing Niger and Nigeria to both militarize in response 
Using the exploited food from its conquered territories, Chad narrowly avoids civil war and famine before collapsing again in 1998
In the 2000s, China props up the warlord controlling the oil fields and helps him conquer much of the habitable zones of Chad
China defends Chadian resources heavily but rebellion and sabotage cause all of the oil to become unusable or unreachable by 2003
The dictator uses the chinese and european equipment to launch a new reign of terror against the populace, ending in the Summer of 2011
As a result of chinese equipment and drought, much of the agriculture dies and shrivels up. Only a few towns remain by Lake Chad. Nomads from Niger frequently raid the farms, leading to feudalism 
In the aftermath of the Great Heatwave of 2015 and 2016, the “King of Lake Chad” joins the Ethiopan confederacy in exchange for weapons and food. He officially joins in 2018
In the 2020s, the N'Djamena-Addis Ababa corridor is one of the main trade routes in the Ethiopian Confederacy, and actually relatively safe as it is frequently patrolled by militias 
Sandstorms and drought during the Great Heatwave of 2023 and 2024 cause contact to momentarily be lost but its reestablished in 2025
As of 2027, the outpost on Lake Chad is a major trading hub for the Ethiopian Water Lords, with the King of Chad one of said lords. However, the ever-encroaching desert might put a stop to that… 
Republic of the Congo (Population: 7,253,291, Circa 2010)
Aligned with the USSR in the 1970s under Marien Ngouabi
Throughout the 1970s, France tries to woo the People’s Republic of the Congo to join the Shanghai Accords
The coup in 1977 and 1979 continue as OTL, but with Nguesso, he finally signs the Shanghai Accords and allows Chinese and Western investors in
In 1982 it transitions to a western-style democracy with elections held in 1984. 
A military revolt in 1987 causes the government to temporarily enact martial law
After the crash of 1988, the economy briefly rose with an oil spike
However in 1989, Nguesso doesn’t get reelected and instead a hardcore communist comes into power
He enacts a self coup and establishes a dictatorship 
But the Hot Summer of 1990 causes a civil war
This civil war continues into a stalemate, with much of the ROC falling into anarchy and the few areas with resources being controlled by warlords
In the 2000s China tries to help modernize it and get some cash by extracting minerals, this brings stability to the region briefly under a Chinese-sympathetic communist warlord
Once the chinese support dries up, it plunges again into civil war between pro-chinese bureaucrats and nationalists lead by an Aka
In the 2010s, pirates dominate the coast and human traffickers kidnap villagers. 
In the summer of 2011, flooding destroys vast amounts of crops, leading to cases of cannibalism
In the Great Heatwaves of 2015-2016, water shortages, flooding and water pollution cause almost a million deaths
In the 2020s, alliances between warlords in Likouala lead to them joining the Ethiopian Confederacy
In 2022, a warlord from Brazzaville tries to retake Likouala but gives up during the Second Great Heatwave
As of 2027, the region of Likouala is under attack by militants, with the Ethiopian water lords offering their support to defend the region as it is a key part of their supply lines 
Rwanda (Population: 25,215,070, Circa 1990)
In 1973, Juvénal Habyarimana takes power like in OTL
Rwanda signs the Shanghai Accords later that year
In 1975 the National Revolutionary Movement for Development is more successful at unifying the Tutsi and the Hutu but is terrified of the Hutus genociding them like they did in Burundi
Because Rwanda has little natural resources, and its economy is solely based on agriculture, most of the world turns a blind eye towards Rwanda becoming a totalitarian state
In the late 1970s, Rwanda becomes deeply paranoid and anti-socialist, calling it a cancer
In fact, in the 80s, China helps establish penal factories to utilize the Hutus as slave labor
In 1988, after the crash, the Hutus launch a civil war against Tutsi government that quickly spills over into Burundi
The Hutu government takes over Burundi and creates a socialist ethnostate that is at first supported by the USSR before even THEY are like “bro wtf” 
In the Hot Summer of 1990, groups from Uganda invade the Hutu Ethnostate causing a long, drawn out war that causes Rwanda to collapse
For the rest of the 1990s, Rwanda is an increasingly fractured alliance of hutu warlords
In the 2000s, famine causes severe depopulation and the remaining functional farms to be based around Lake Kivu
By 2011, a single war lord controls Lake Kivu
In the 2010s, the Great Heatwaves cause mass vegetation die off with reports of cannibalism. This causes lake Kivu to have an excess build up of CO2
In the 2020s, Ethiopians take over the remnants of Lake Kivu and auction out the water for irrigation
In 2022, a massive cloud of CO2 erupts from Lake Kivu, killing an estimated 3.4 million people 
By 2027, the Ethiopian Water Lords carefully irrigate out the remnants of Lake Kivu
Burundi (Population: 23,443,899, Circa 1990)
Became aligned with China
In 1972, Chen helps Burundi carry out their genocide on Hutus
The majority-Tutsi government became a police ethnostate, but remained quite socialist. If you were a Tutsi, you had access to job security, healthcare, large houses, ect
In the 1980s, Burundi became a flipped version of Rwanda, but hardcore socialists
After the crash of 1988, the Tutsi government of Rwanda flees to Burundi but then the civil war spills over, with the indentured Hutus rising up 
After the Hot Summer of 1990, Zaire claims all of Lake Tanganyika as its territory and this causes the Hutu ethnostate to fracture
In the 1990s the remnants of the Tutsi and the Hutus, after seeing how their countries were basically the same, make peace and create a small confederacy in Makamba
In the 2000s famine, drought, and desertification cause mass depopulation except for in Makamba
In 2011, Makamba is absorbed by one of the factions of the Tanzanian civil war
In 2014, spillover from the civil war finally wipes out the last of the native Burundis
After the Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2016 it is absorbed into the Victorious Queen’s domain
In the 2020s, Burundi is the site of a massive battle between the Ethiopian Confederacy and the GAR
By 2027, part of Lake Tanganyika is taken over by the Water Lords, but other than that, Burundi has ceased to exist
Tanzania (Population: 79,264,115, Circa 2000)
Mostly goes as OTL at first, with ties to the People’s Republic of China and a rather large amount of Authoritarianism. The ruling ideology of ,,African Socialism”, which emphasized the Rural Countryside as good and urban areas as ,,inherently bourgeoisie”, ironically means the environment remains in decent shape (aside from endangered animals, which are often hunted by corrupt officials for sport). 
Speaking of corruption, Tanzania becomes one of the most corrupt nations in Africa, with the rapid rise in prosperity making that even a steeper turn. That said, essential commodities mostly remain available until 1988, when the country’s imports begin to dry up due to a rapid rise in prices of pretty much everything. 
The country was rocked by protests in 1990, which resulted in a series of massacres and resulted in the ruling Revolution Party further clamping down on discontent and turning from “soft” authoritarianism towards open despotism. Now seeing the writing on the wall, Tanzania turns into a de facto command economy, which goes about as well as you’d expect with the rampant corruption. 
By 2000 much of the countryside has been stripped bare of anything by hordes of starving urbanites (sometimes openly encouraged to move to the country by clueless officials, who thought that a band of men and women who’d never stepped foot outside a City would make good farmers), and as such in 2001 another famine hits, with a Popular Revolt just barely contained by the Military Remnants a year later. 
Thankfully, this is about the time China begins to fully invest in Africa, and while Tanzania does have some resources, it lacks the means to extract them all. Until now. Of course, the Chinese Equipment is horribly faulty and inefficient, and the additional corruption means that very little of this wealth ever reaches the shores of the Land of the Tiger. 
While for a time Tanzania remains in the top ten fastest growing economy, before long officials in Beijing begin to see the whole thing as a waste of finite resources and pull the plug even before the 2007 Indian Sea incident. 
As a result, the economy pretty much collapsed, with massive blackouts completely stopping any sort of industry and thousands taking to the streets to riot. While the Capital was successfully stormed and the President strung up on a lamppost, nobody could agree on what the next Government should be like, resulting in a chaotic ,,Civil War” with constantly changing sides, with things becoming more convoluted than Holy Roman Politics - to the point no comprehensive report on it had been filed until the Great Death. Most of the Warlords were uninteresting, the usual war criminal bandits trying to suck the land dry of anything of use, mostly utilizing ancient Chinese equipment manned by slaves in all but name. 
After the great heatwave of 2015, the Victorious Queen takes over much of north tanzania
Tanzania remains extremely chaotic in the 2020s with the victorious Queen losing much of her influence
Some maps still showed it by 2010, even as the GAR and Ethiopian Water Lords began to encroach, but by 2020 they all gave up - another state lost to the black blob slowly engulfing the Darkest Continent.
Central African Republic (Population: 7,581,418, Circa 1990)
Relations between Bokassa’s empire and France remain tenuous - with advances in medical science, Charles de Gaulle lives longer and remains the President for longer. He is known for frequently shit talking Bokassa in the 1970s
China, trying to get close ties to them, bankrolls the coronation in exchange for diamonds
Bokassa is overthrown by a coalition of French, Chinese and American soldiers in 1977
President Morgan works closely with the UN and France to create a democracy that is conducive to the Free Market
Dacko’s reforms in 1979 are more successful, and he avoids a coup
In the 1980s, CAR becomes closely aligned with China, and used many of their diamonds and gold to make jewerly in the Glorious Decades 
After the crash of 1988, Dacko is overthrown in a coup in late 1988
The last forests are completely cut down by 1989
This new government rules with a harsh authoritarian grip until it is toppled in a civil war provoked by the Hot Summer of 1990
Famines are avoided but droughts continue to worsen in the 1990s
Chad takes them over in the late 1990s
China arrives in the 2000s and helps the CAR dictator regain territory and revitalize their economy. Oil is extracted, along with Uranium
This causes several nearby nations to invade the CAR and in 2004 China pulls out as they believe it is no longer worth it
Reportedly, the Soviets tried to make some deals to get their uranium but nothing came of it
By 2005, it has descended into a fascist dictatorship who routinely imprison their opponents and work them to death
In the 2010s, famines and overexploitation of the environment led to cannibalism 
In the Great Heat Wave of 2015, the government finally collapses and a civil war breaks out
In the 2020s, the Ethiopians make overtures to the remnants of the CAR and some of them join the confederacy, with several outposts in the northern plains and along the rivers
By 2027, much of the CAR is in anarchy, as the few outposts for water are no longer feasible or profitable
Zaire (Population: 223,943,111, Circa 2000)
Seko becomes dictator as in OTL
In 1972, under pressure from the West, Zaire begins to democratize, with free elections being held in 1977, though Seko remains as “executive commissioner”, which retains a large amount of power
Zaire is quite resistant to forming ties with Rwanda and Burundi
Zaire remains just as corrupt though, and it is an unspoken rule to always overpay Zairens 
China remains a close ally throughout the 1980s
Zaire’s main export is precious metals 
After the crash of 1988, the economy crumbles and Seko is killed in a coup
This new government is highly unstable
Spill over from Rwanda and Burundi lead to martial law and routine “kill squads” 
Many are forced into working anyway, as this new dictator believes he can get away with anything
In the Hot Summer of 1990, drought causes Zaire to take over Lake Tanganyika
In the 1990s, genocide and state-sponsored terrorism keep the country running
Famine is not an issue in the 1990s because so many people are killed 
Zaire is one of the first countries China invested in, with the government being propped up by them all the way back in 1999
Zaire becomes heavily industrialized in the 2000s 
When China leaves, GAR-associated sleeper agents destabilize the government and cause a civil war in 2008
The civil war collapses into anarchy and warlordism by 2011
Some of these warlords are puppets of the EF, US and USSR and siphon resources back to their native countries
The Great Heatwaves of 2015 and 2016 cause the rest of the population to concentrate around the Congo river in the west and Lake Tanganyika in the east and the puppet states to collapse 
Apocalyptic cults of all three main abrahamic faiths become prominent in the aftermath of the Great Heat Waves, and much of central Zaire becomes a battle royale with tons of cannibalism and tribalism 
In the midst of this, the GAR starts to send “resource extraction squads” to get precious minerals and more importantly, water
In the 2020s, Ethiopian water lords arrive in the region and start to battle the GAR and cults for access to the water
The Great Heatwaves of 2023 and 2024 cause the GAR to retreat
By 2027, Ethiopia has numerous outposts in the northern sections of the country while the GAR controls the southern edges. The religious battle royale is still on going, with the Christians winning 
Cameroon (Population: 30,553,438, Circa 2010)
President Ahmadou Ahidjo died after choking on some steak in early 1962, allowing for the Union of the Peoples of Cameroon, a radical Marxist Movement which decried his moderate Pro French Stance, to take power, although clashes continued until 1965 between them and remnants of the old regime. 
The new Government holds “elections”, where the only observers are from Albania and in which UPC Candidates win all 200 Seats for the Legislature. The newly chosen Chairman, a former Partizan Leader and public fan of Hoxha’s works of Literature, gets to work, quickly making himself known as a ,,"Rabid Reformer”, dismantling old social structures at gunpoint and enforcing women’s liberation. Those who disagree are swiftly purged, and a Political Police is set up to aid in the process. Cameroon mostly stays in China’s sphere, even ditching Albania for its Billion Man Friend after Chen and Enver have a public falling out over the former’s capitalist tendencies. 
In the 1980s, Cameroon did reform somewhat, even dropping the ,,People’s” from their name and becoming known simply as the ,,Republic of Cameroon”. The UCP even allows for an opposition to contest the 1987 Elections, in which they win a whopping three seats. Out of 200, mind you. That said, they remain a rather agrarian and backward state, with the production of oil mostly for domestic purposes (aside from a bit sold off to China for a rather low price - you know, friendship and all that). 
As the Red Decade begins, nothing much initially changes in Cameroon, with the bloated Military and Political Police keeping the borders stable and the populace squashed even as restrictions on movement and rationing get tighter with each day. 
That said, in the mid 90s, they opened up to Chinese Investment full time, and before long their countryside was littered with quarries extracting bauxite and iron to feed the Chenist Giant’s insatiable appetite. 
Their timber industry ceased to exist by 1997 due to, you know, the obvious, and the expansion of their Oil and Gas sectors was stifled by both distance and the shoddy nature of Chinese Engineering, but they managed to actually grow somewhat, soon becoming the poster child of Chinese Friendship, inspiring other states across the continent to open up and let Big Brother Chen build up his facilities. 
However, after the long running Chairman dies in 2001, his replacement proves less keen on having ,,Foreign Imperialists’ in his country, and thus, while he doesn't publicly boot out the Chinese, he stops being constantly slavish to them, which they don’t appreciate. 
As such, they have him killed and replaced with a puppet, which inspires his supporters to begin a rural insurgency, blowing up Chinese Power Plants and sabotaging Industry. These few grains of sand are enough to make Cameroon’s Economy come to a grinding halt, and only an indiscriminate campaign using chemical weapons and mass bombing with ancient artillery manages to somewhat stabilize the frontlines, pushing out the Partizans (and thousands of innocent civilians lost in the crossfire) into neighboring nations to be someone else’s problem. 
By 2005, China pretty much stopped investing altogether, and by 2007 they cash in their chips and leave. 
As such, the Partizans return with tripe the strength, and a very nasty Civil War ensues - neither side is strong enough to dislodge the other, so the ,,Chenists” and the ,,Maoists” exchange the titles of ,,Very Weak central Government” and ,,Very Strong Remnant Regime” until 2017, when the easily available resources run out and a total collapse of modern society ensues.  
By 2020, not shown on most maps, although isolated settlements do exist, mostly huddled around either Chinese Power Plants whose energy they rent out to warlords in exchange for food or the three functioning plantations that haven’t withered away into dust yet (although their number keeps dropping due to raiding, climate change and, from one point onward, mass group suicides when it becomes clear Tomorrow will not get any better).
In the 2020s, massive limnic eruptions keep the Ethiopians from expanding to the coast
Nigeria (Population: 334,914,685, Circa 2010)
After the 1965 coup, the country underwent a very brutal modernization period, with farmers forced to work on Oil Extraction and Infrastructure works. Prosperity does increase somewhat, but it doesn't really impact the lives of average citizens - the newly erected districts of cities remain glorified slums, and the countryside is in utter poverty, with occasional sectional violence a mere cherry on top. 
After some gentle pressure from the USA, and even domestic oligarchs, the Military Regime stepped aside in favour of a Civilian Ruled and generally Democratic Second Republic in 1979. The country is far from perfect, but repressions against the rural populace are lessened and a token amount of money is even invested into keeping agriculture around, even if most of the country’s food is imported by that point. 
Large investments are made into education and healthcare to accommodate for the growing population (rising to over 100 Million by 1985), even if corruption eats into those efforts and makes them less than efficient. Democracy remains shaky, and has to fight off a coup attempt in 1985, but does survive the Glorious Decades, and most economists claim that a Second Decade of relative prosperity is all that’s needed to entrench a proper representative system and drastically decrease the chances of a successful coup. 
However, the country wouldn’t get that much time, as the Crash happened in 1988 and subsequently things go to shit in a heartbeat. With the collapse of global trade, and agriculture gutted both by Government Policy and climate change, starvation becomes a real issue. Fires devastate the slums, the North falls into sectarian violence between Christians and Muslims, several gangs begin to openly operate in urban areas and even prove more efficient or, ironically, fairer than elected authorities. 
This is too much to handle for the Army - the President is executed and Parliament dissolved in mid 1989, with a ,,Transitional Regime” taking its place. Millions of urbanites are hastily sent back to the country to ,,farm”, in spite of the fact the majority of them have no experience living outside the cities, and the few former farmers don’t do too well due to the constant droughts and lack of modern equipment. 
Thankfully, China soon shows up, and in exchange for the Junta legalizing the nonexistent Nigerian Communist Party it begins to set up shop. Of course, the workplace accidents only make living in the cities more hazardous, and whatever little mineral value the soil has is absolutely decimated by the Power Plant Pollution, but what else is there to do? As such, Nigeria just barely manages to crawl its way through the Red Decade, and actually sees some positive improvements in the early 2000s, with the Regime trying to crack down on corruption and improve living standards (not out of the goodness of their hearts, but so that the Plebeians don’t eat them, as already happened in many neighboring states). 
And then the Chinese pull out, and a lack of engineers means most of that progress is undone, or will be by 2010 when shit breaks and there’s nobody to fix it, and nothing to replace it with anyway. 
In 2009 the Junta faced dozens of uprisings from all sorts of groups - ethnic militias, mercenaries, religious fundamentalists, rebelling police units, democratic oppositionists, hardened communist militants and so on. 
By 2011 the Civil War is over, and all the Warlords go their own ways, having little will or ability to wage further warfare. To their credit, most form functional states, ones that work above the level of primitive bandit fiefs, and the People’s Republic of Biafra even hosts one of the continent’s last working Chinese-Built Power Plants up until 2025, and even then has plans to get it back online by 2028. 
Some Northern Breakways do fall to Climate Change (and the subsequent droughts, refugee waves and crumbling agriculture), with the Water Lords slowly encroaching on the Eastern Provinces (although most of their offensives are repelled by the locals’ joint efforts). 
Not shown on maps by 2015, although some do bother to try and track down where the borders between breakways lie at that point. 
Niger (Population: 37,423,145, circa 1990)
One Party Civilian Dictatorship during the 60s and much of the 70s. 
Benefits from an Uranium Boom, but it ends prematurely and the Government ends up overthrown by the Military. 
There is Secret Police and Media Censorship, but the economy remains sluggish, with corruption rampant and poverty everpresent. 
Some media groups claim that Niger was Africa’s poorest state in 1988, and while that cannot be confirmed it’s more likely than not. 
After the Crisis international aid dries up and a Popular Revolt routs the Military in 1989, resulting in the proclamation of a ,,Second Republic” - one that immediately faces a Tuareg revolt and electoral violence, causing one of the candidates (a populist, placed third by the few polls held at the time, trailing behind a far more popular Socialist Oppositionist and Pro Moscow Communist) to gather his supporters and stage a coup. 
They form a kleptocracy little better than the one before it, and completely fail to address the country’s issues. 
The desertification and massive storms result in Niger ceasing to exist by 2000, although some groups of nomads remain
by 2020 the Water Lords have a few outposts in what used to be the country’s Eastern Periphery. Not shown on maps by 2005.

GAR: 

Namibia (Population: 4,133,512, circa 2020)
Namibia remains a part of South Africa ITTL, though is granted autonomy during the Glorious Decades to appease the UN
In the 1980s, South African control of Namibia is a frequent talking point in the Non-Aligned movement
Rebel movements constantly spring up, sometimes spilling over into South Africa
In 1989, South Africa formally takes over Namibia, citing internal security issues 
In 1990, martial law is declared and South Africa begins building camps to house natives while they pacify the region
Most of Namibia remains a desert, but throughout the 1990s mining operations are set up by South Africa
Namibia is kept on a tight leash, with famines and drought constantly plaguing the population
Food begins to be carefully rationed out for the “workers” until the summer of 2003 when they switch to stew
By 2011, all the farms in Namibia have withered away and the white soldiers have to get their food imported 
By 2016, even the whites are experiencing drought, leading to internal conflict in the GAR about allocation of water
By 2023, the a mega-drought causes almost 60% of the population to die 
The Solar Storm of 2026 causes a massive wildfire to burn down over half of the remaining settlements 
As of 2027, the GAR is considering leaving Namibia - already, the northernmost settlements are being evacuated while they slowly retreat into Angola or parts of Botswana
Botswana (Population: 1,248,598, circa 2020)
Botswana signs the Shanghai Accords
The Tribal Grazing Act of 1975 is more successful 
Botswana makes deals with China for mining
Botswana becomes super rich, and industrializes very fast
Botswana also invests in education, causing a dramatic rise in literacy 
Botswana works to become less connected to South Africa, which they dont like 
In the Glorious Decades, the government of Botswana prioritizes “modernization” instead of mediating ethnic and tribal conflicts
Botswana signs a peace deal in 1977 with both the US and China to help modernize their military against the rise of white-lead governments in neighboring nations 
When Rhodesia attempts to invade Botswana in 1977, they are beaten back by the well-equipped Botswana forces 
Livestock farming becomes less important, with a growing vegetarianism movement in the 1980s
In the 1980s, the administration maintains a policy of having the president and vice president being from different regions so that they work together 
Drought avoided in the 1980s due to negotiations with other nations
In the 1980s, South Africa tries to recapture “Xhosan Rebels” hiding in Botswana, leading to a heavily militarized border 
When the Crash of 1988 comes around, the diamonds are practically worthless and drought quickly becomes a prominent issue
Trade unions force the mines to stay open and mine coal, and local government officials begin to prioritize the dwindling water supply to help focus on their local tribe
The Hot Summer of 1990 puts Botswana to the test, as while they never run out of energy, drought and poverty become extremely rampant
Martial law is declared and South African spies begin fermenting civil unrest in 1991 
A major riot in 1992 finally culminates into a twelve-way civil war, with it basically being a free-for-all between the tribes and the central government
Some tribes take weapons generously “donated” to them by South Africa, causing the violence to escalate significantly
The civil war ends in 1996 as a south-african backed Kalangan warlord takes over much of Botswana 
Botswana is annexed by South Africa in 1997, with the warlord executed on the capitol 
In the 2000s, the GAR forces Botswanans to work in the mines which suffer from a high mortality rate
Some tribes resist of course, leading to a protracted guerilla war in Botswana from 1998-2011. The tribes that resist are led by the Tlôkwa people 
The Red Summer of 2003 causes the GAR to prioritize the harvests for the whites in South Africa, leading to the “stew cannibalism” 
Many of the resisting tribes die out, with the Kwena being the last ones to survive before being wiped out by GAR forces in the summer of 2011
Between 2011 and 2014 the GAR beings building lavish summer homes in the northern countryside
Revolts and rebellions in the Great Heat Waves of 2015 and 2016 cause many of these homes to burn down, and Botswana becomes a tightly controlled police state, worked to the bone by the boers 
Between 2017 and 2023, the GAR works Botswanans to the death by forcing them to dismantle industrial parks made in the 1970s and 1980s
By the 2020s, there are no farms in Botswana, with the last remaining water sources used for irrigating South African crops. The mines are still active though. 
Botswana barely survives the Second Great Heat Wave of 2023 and 2024, with a mega-drought causing all the remaining water to dry up, leading to millions of deaths 
In 2024 and 2025, equipment starts breaking down at such a rate that mining by pickaxe is no longer efficient, causing many mines to close down and workers to be killed
In the Solar Storm of 2026, the remaining electrical infrastructure is completely fried, and a huge wildfire damages the remaining flammable structures 
As of 2027, Botswana is a crisp wasteland, though it still retains a large amount of untapped minerals
Zimbabwe (Population: 28,184,198, circa 2020)
The Rhodiasian Bush War is far less chaotic in this timeline, with negotiations starting in 1972
Between 1972-1976, many whites leave for South Africa
Gains independence in 1976, after the Vietnam War ends
Zimbabwe signs the Shanghai Accords this year
Zimbabwe imports a lot of energy 
Many schools and hospitals are built in the 1980s

Farming is owned by more blacks in this timeline
But blacks still own the majority of mines
