No Glorious Decades lore:
Andorra (Prospers during the Glorious Decades, with its Tourism industry appealing to the small but not insignificant section of poor people who have enough time and money to spare on foreign vacations but can’t afford Supersonic Jets to exotic destinations - or are simply too afraid to fly them, for whatever reason. Either way, it flourishes, with every inch of the duchy covered in cement hotels and shopping malls. In the mid 1980s there’s a small dip in economic growth after climate change made the Winter Sports far, far more expensive and difficult to host, but a bit of aid from the French and claims from ,,Experts” that this is nothing but a hiccup from Mother Nature restored confidence. After the 1988 Crash it kept afloat until 1989, mostly burning through their massive savings to try and keep the lights on in all of their massive buildings, but after it was clear the snow wasn’t coming back they had to seek bailouts from France or Spain. The French, already smelling rot and suspecting this crisis wouldn’t be over anytime soon, said no, and so the Spanish offered to simply annex the Duchy and take care of basic utilities in exchange for some… favours. The local authorities agreed, and before long the once splendorous Hotels and massive stadiums were turned into refugee centers. Ironically Andorra is one of the better places to be in Europe, with somewhat livable temperatures and a healthy economy based on shipping away their youth (who, unlike their counterparts elsewhere in Europe, don’t look like gaunt walking corpses) to work on projects too physically demanding for their peers. Obviously not shown on maps past 1990. )
Austria (the Socialists and the People’s Party both drift toward Free Market Economics, and even begin to overlap when it comes to some Social Affairs, mostly approaching the center on things like Women’s Rights. The Freedom Party fizzles out after many of their members are outed as various types of criminals, with many surviving members quitting politics and instead going into business. Unemployment and Inflation reach new lows, even if it’s not quite as impressive as in other European States, and the average citizen enjoys prosperity comparable to the below-average American. In the late 80s, though, it went on track even more, as rising trade with other European States meant more jobs and higher pay, and the 1987 Government even brought back some of the Welfare abolished at the start of the 70s. Kurt Waldheim’s War Service is never revealed, and the successes of his Presidency mean he is rather fondly remembered, and a statue of him was even planned in the City center of Vienna before the Red Decades put an end to that.)
Belgium (With no oil crises, Belgium doesn't do much to limit their welfare state - some bits are slashed here or there, but most are reinstated at some point in the early 1980s. Federalization went forward in the 1970s but stagnated in the 1980s, with no 1980 Constitutional Reform. A referendum is held to abolish the monarchy in response, but fails to reach the required turnout threshold, and even then only about 30% vote in favor. While the vast majority of the country focuses on cultural expansion, a small drought in Wallonia in 1985 ends up destroying its flower harvesting sector, with the now unemployed farmers mostly moving to Brussels to work menial jobs on the newly established Financial Industries. In 1988, the newly inaugurated Prime Minister is thinking about opening up specialized industries for various kick knacks to bring back jobs from China, but has stated, several times, this is merely a fallback measure in case something were to happen and not ,,a sign of hostility toward the people of China” (Chen actually sends a letter in response, which pretty much amounts to ,,no offense taken, but if you do go forward with it, have you considered hiring Chinese Construction conglomerates?”). Still, it is met with a rather fair bit of ridicule - what could possibly happen to justify such tomfoolery?)
Cyprus (the 1974 Coup and subsequent Turkish invasion still happen but the British pressure America and China to intervene. Under threat of having their development aid cut, alongside China subtly implying they could flood the Turko-Kurdish Far Left with guns if they wanted to, both Governments come to the negotiating table and agree to recognize an independent, united and heavily decentralized Cyprus. The country’s democracy is corrupt and flawed, with much of the newfound tourism revenue going directly into the pockets of the elite, but enough trickles down to keep the ,,proles” at bay. In the 1980s, in a bid to try and actually show the people they’re doing something, the Government funded a net of universities, mostly bilingual ones, that created a rather large class of intellectuals in the country. 1987 actually sees the Duopoly (consisting of an economically and socially centrist Greek-dominated party and a socially conservative free market Turkish dominated party) challenged as the Working People’s Party is revived, this time as a Social Democratic movement instead of an openly Marxist one, and the 1988 Elections see their candidate almost win but eventually be defeated when the Greeks (who didn’t make it into the 2nd round) throw their weight behind the Turk, who is eventually elected by a narrow margin with many irregularities reported. That said, for the most part, it’s rather prosperous.)
Denmark (in 1973, Venstre goes all in on the Free Market and forms a Coalition Government with a somewhat larger but still razor thin plurality. The Danish Communist Party gets somewhat larger thanks to Soviet aid, but not too much. In 1975, Venstre was replaced by the deceptively named Progress Party as the main backbone of the Right Wing Government, while the socially liberal Social Liberal Party was kicked out. Mass urban renewal projects end with Copenhagen rapidly growing, with the poor de facto expelled to large ,slum cities” made specifically for them in a new form of urban segregation. Of course, those soon become festering sores on the countryside, sources of crime and poverty, but in the early 1980s the Government did invest more than a bit of cash into trying to ensure they’re at least somewhat livable. The Middle Class is also taxed out of the Major Cities and forced to live in their own areas, but those are more akin to a classic suburbia (with all the good and the bad that brings) than the Purge-esque shitfest that sometimes goes on in the slums. The Government tries to crack down on immigration but the other nations are very much against that and threaten sanctions, so they relent and let the poor from abroad flood in, further making the slums completely shit to live in. Wind Energy is shut down at the request of Big Coal, which soon opens up power plants in the slums to fuel all of the Elite’s electrical chicanery (like a massive sign reading ,,COPENHAGEN” on a hill near… well, Copenhagen, lit 24/7). By 1988, though, the Social Democrats were starting to rebound - in 1987’s Elections, for the first time since 1975, the Right Coalition ruled by plurality as opposed to by majority. The economy was also starting to stagnate.)
Finland (The Presidency remains powerful. The boom of the 1970s still happens as the country transitions to a mostly service based economy. Instead of spending money on welfare, the Finns focus it on research, and while Technology in the computer sector does stagnate they make a pretty buck selling revolutionary, if impractical, breakthroughs to the major powers’ elites. Debt continues rising as they keep taking loans to expand the sector and fund start ups, with Lapland becoming known as the ,,Land of Santa Claus and Enterprenourialism”. In 1985, a Free Trade Zone was created between Finland and the Estonian SSR. Some strike waves happen as the traditional industrial sectors decline, but the USSR negotiates an end to them as instead, the woods of the north are chopped down into near non-existence and sent to China to be turned into chairs and kitschy furniture. After the crash of 1988, the Finnish economy plummeted, the National Coalition Government that had been in charge since 1970, held on all the way until 1991, refusing to hold a snap election. The Social Democrats achieved a majority, with the People’s Democratic League (a bunch of USSR Sockpuppets united into one) in a close second place, the Greens and Centrists (Agrarians) tied for a very distant third and the Coalition not electing a single MP. The newly chosen Prime Minister pretty much ruled by decree, instituting what amounted to a centrally planned economy to try and salvage the situation while outright overriding the authority of a few municipal governments in favor of pro Government unions. He also institutes heavy rationing and uses the deforested North for farming, even if it’s horribly inefficient due to the shit climate and lack of proper equipment. The Communists are banned again in the lead-up to the 1995 Parliamentary Elections, as the PM fears they could potentially gridlock the legislature or even gain a majority of their own. He kept on ruling until the 1997 Soviet Invasion, in which he was killed in a decapitation strike. The country surrendered in 1999 and became another SSR.)
France (French Guyana is modernized. Rapidly deindustrializes as companies flee abroad, mostly into China, Africa and (by far the least) South America. Paris sees some Urban renewal, with large Operas and Libraries created, but skyscrapers are moved outward after a large under construction one (created for an India-based accounting firm) crumbles into the metro and catacombs due to there being too little ground to support it, in 1979. De Gaulle’s legacy remains firm, with many French Companies making a point to name at least one area in every foreign factory after him (ranging from entire Factory Complexes to the De Gaulle Security Office, the De Gaulle Break Room and, who could forget, the De Gaulle Female Bathroom (in a SIZ making Soda Cans in China) - although that last one was shut down pretty quickly). Supermarkets remain open on Sundays, and sometimes become 24/7 businesses. Terrorism is pretty much nonexistent with the large-scale prosperity, and the near universal nature of entertainment begins to wear down on local culture [based on what happened in OTL Poland, with Universal TV making local dialects fade into near non-existence]. The Bretons try to form terrorist cells but are disorganized and eventually easily destroyed by Augusto Fernando César in 1981. Speaking of 1981, during the 1970s the Socialists crumble into smaller parties, most of which either fade into irrelevancy (including one Trotskyist one which is busted by César after their Boss is revealed to have had a Supervillain-esque, stupid-ass plan to blow up the Versailles Palace while the Prime Minister was visiting) or are taken over by the Communists. In the 1981 French Presidential Election, the incumbent Republican Party (the name of the Rally for the Republic ITTL) Gaulist President is re-elected with 66% of the vote, with the main opposition coming from the Communist Richard Pascal (Shipyard Union Boss, City Councilman in Brest and brother of the future President, serving as Minister of Transport from 1990 to 1995 and Minister of the Interior from 1996 to 1997) getting 21%, 10% going to the “Liberal” (Centre-Right) Democratic Party (TTL’s Union for French Democracy) Nominee (A Businessman in the telecommunications industry and former Senator) and 3% to everyone else combined . The 1980s saw yet another wave of deregulation and decentralization. In the 1986 Legislative Elections, the Communists chipped away at the Republican Majority but still remained in the opposition, slowly but surely expanding their reach among the Middle-Class Youths and disgruntled former ,,Screamers” (people who were active during the ,,Screaming Sixties”) under the rule of the Pascal Brothers (although Richard steadily let his brother do the heavy lifting)
West Germany (One of the few countries to keep some industry, although mostly related to technological start ups - it’s not quite as attractive as Finland but still has its uses, with a ton of educated youths to serve as the backbone of such business. The RAF and other Far Left terrorist groups are pacified after an attempted attack on several Bundestag Members visiting a Tech Start-up, trying to ,,show their strength to the bourgeois scumbags”. The only victim is Helmut Kohl, who gets a small statue built of him in his hometown of Ludwigshafen. This is where Augusto Fernando César gets his start, coordinating the West German Police and Special Forces, being awarded the order of merit in 1978 for his efforts. Ostpolitik goes forward, with large-scale trade ties set up between the Bundsrepublik and Poland (and later the USSR, too). DDR-BRD Relations remain cold, for the most part. Fultec is set up here (already explained), alongside other tech companies. The Greens never catch on, and counter-culture fails outside of West Berlin (which remains flourishing, especially thanks to liberal folks fleeing from the socially conservative Communist Bloc). Ruled by the Social Democrats (SPD) as of 1988.)
Iceland (Still wins the Cod Wars, and overfishes the North just to rub salt into Britain’s wound - although a few stern words from the USA, suggesting that a Police Junta would rule just as well as the democratically elected Parliament, get them to enact a few token limits on fishing. With no oil shock, the Economy keeps booming. Other than that, not much of a change from OTL).
Ireland (the Banks continue quickly growing, lending money to anyone who wants to take the cash. With American Advisors and “Advisors” by their side, the Irish learned to manage their economy properly and boom in the 1980s, with every type of economic sector booming. Even Industry remains afloat thanks to the amount of cash the Elite is willing to dump for the sake of keeping the poor happy and employed. Several high rises are erected in Dublin, housing some of the largest companies in Europe. Fianna Fail and Fine Gael keep exchanging power between 1973 and 1988, although cracks are already starting to show as Inflation surpasses 10% right before the Sinai War. After the crash, the economy crumbles, and the 1989 Snap Election results in a Labour majority in coalition with the Greens and a few splitters from the Workers’ Party (Sinn Fein, SF). Ireland is hit hard by the climate crisis, but not too hard, and rationing only goes into effect in the mid 1990s. Unemployment is a bigger issue, and even with massive spending, the Government proves unable to fix stuff. Labour’s majority melted in 1993, but they remain in power thanks to their Green coalition partners siphoning much of that vote. They would turn sharply leftward as a result, instituting the usual planned economy stuff, even if they do keep a few companies pretty much as they were before, with only token changes to staff and leadership positions (if that). With the situation ever so slightly stabilized, the 1997 Election once more gives Labour a large majority to work with, but they keep the Greens just in case. As negotiations continue with the UK in regards to northern Ireland, the nationalists come out to vote and give Labour another 4 years in office, this time letting them rule on their own without the need for coalition partners. The Greens and Sinn Fein form the Irish People’s Coalition in opposition to the ,,managerialization of Left Wing Politics”. In 2003, Ireland would become a founding member of the North European Free Trade Area, but didn’t get too much out of it compared to the others. After protests regarding the 2005 Elections, Labour would go out and ban the People’s Coalition, pretty much becoming an European puppet state (even if one that received a fair bit of leeway in how it did stuff). As expected, Labour would be re-elected, with only half a dozen independents forming a motley ,loyal opposition”. In 2009 a Potato Blight strikes, but European “humanitarian aid” steps in and stops the worst of the starvation (by reducing the amount of mouths to feed). The country mostly remains the same - a de facto one party state under the increasingly authoritarian Labour Party - until the late 2020s when, in light of Europe having been weakened, they begin a thaw and slowly loosen up restrictions. Shown on all existing maps by 2027.
Italy (Rapid investment plans in the South, alongside the Shanghai Accords ensuring cheap goods and easy credit, means Italy’s economy stabilizes a decade early, and even the ballooning debt is shrugged off as the Prime Minister merely takes more loans to pay all the old ones. Rome becomes a financial capital of much of the European Continent, with sleek new highways carving their way through the mountains and quiet villages alike. The few who complain are shut up by the new ,,Anti Extremism Laws”, originally set up alongside the CIA and China’s Investigation Department to hunt down the far right and far left. The symbolic end for the years of Lead comes in 1981, when Augusto Fernando César, alongside several CIA and Italian Police officers, manages to hunt down the leaders of the seven largest terrorist groups in a month (between mid-February and Mid-March, to be exact).While Governments remain rather unstable (with the post of Prime Minister changing hands 6 times between 1972 and 1987, five of those between members of different parties) they got a lot of leeway thanks to the newly stable streets and restored economy, ensuring the ,,Establishment” is not threatened by radicals on either side. That said, even in 1988 signs of trouble could be seen - since Q4 1987, the economic growth had slowed down to a crawl, much of the South’s wealth has been stolen by corrupt officials, and the Prime Minister had died of a stroke, with the ruling Christian Democrats seriously threatened by the Unity Coalition (consisting of moderate Socialists and the Republican Party) for the first time since the Republic’s birth over 40 years prior. A snap election was planned to be held on June 10th, 1988.
Liechtenstein (The Economy still booms, and in the 70s the country transforms into a Tax Heaven thanks to low taxes and a thriving financial sector. Women were denied the vote in 1984 by a narrow margin. The population keeps rising, and the Government even dips its toes into Tourism with the opening of a major museum in 1987, spending a good chunk of their budget for that year on the various works of art. This is one of the reasons they’re already drowning in debt come 1989, with horrific unemployment reaching over 70% of the populace and a flood of petty crime as people struggle to make ends meet. In exchange for abandoning their debt, the Swiss annex the country (although the last Government tries to frame it as a fully willing reunification) and subsequently do some investing in it. Either way, by 2000 most locals leave for greener pastures, but the abandoned infrastructure is repurposed in 2003-2004 as Secret Bunkers for the Swiss Political and Economic Elite. )
Luxembourg (the ,,30 glorious years” extend into the future, as even though the steel industry begins to decline, foreign loans mean the country seamlessly transitions into an economy based purely on finance and beer, with Luxemburger Beer eventually becoming a staple of many European Households - in the East, the symbol of newly reachable prosperity and a slice of the Western world, much like Coca Cola before it - and later, in the Red Decade, a most missed sign of what was lost. Abortion is not legalized, but Divorce is, and while in 1981 the Right won the Election they’re defeated in 1984, bringing the Democrats back to power. Pretty prosperous.)
Malta (Becomes independent in 1974, as in OTL, and drifts pretty close to North Africa. They don’t openly proclaim themselves a Zakat state, due to being, ya know, Christian, but they’re pretty much the closest thing to one outside Africa proper. The Labour Party dominates politics, winning every election in a landslide as living standards soar to new heights. Gaddafi and the Prime Minister meet several times a year. After the 1988 Sinai War, the country briefly considered asking Libya to annex itself, but Europe convinced” them to not do that and instead de facto occupied the Island, instituting a minority government for “safety purposes” in 1989. In 1991, the Island voted to join Italy (with 51% in favor and about 40% turnout, and several violations reported) and later became part of the Federation. By 2000, mostly a Military Base with some civilian institutions attached.)
Monaco (Other than a tiny sector specifying in supplying the locals with food and electronics, most of Monaco remains what it’d been for decades at that point - a Half Bank, Half Tax Heaven, 100% Tourist Trap. The Climate still attracts thousands, and the local Government even makes the higher temperatures a point in their tourism campaigns, trying to spin it as beneficial for your skin thanks to Vitamin A and other buzzwords they hope will attract more visitors. It works, but is relentlessly mocked on French and Italian Late Night Shows. In 1989, though, due to their reliance on rich idiots leaving their life savings in the country, the Economy completely crashes, with the final nail being a horrible 1990 Summer Season (Only about 25% of 1989’s visitors returned, which itself was a 60% decrease from 1988, which also was a drop of 15% from 1987’s peak. You do the math.) and a subsequent crash of the local banks. Since very few foreign companies needed a tax haven anymore, Monaco soon became an impoverished shithole incapable of keeping the lights on, with essential services stretched to the breaking point. After a Casino Fire escalates and threatens to spill across the border to minimum resistance, the French decide they’d had enough and annex the microstate in 1991. They subsequently take everything not nailed to the floor, and leave it mostly a deserted wasteland, with the exception of the still piss poor locals. Most of them leave by 2000 too, and those who don’t are chased out by the constant fires and storms caused by climate change - about half of former Monaco is actually flooded all year round by 2010. Obviously not shown on maps. 
Netherlands (as expected, Welfare is gutted in the 70s and 80s, and while the country is the most socially liberal nation in Europe, it still experiences a rather sharp turn toward Conservatism as a result of the Screaming Sixties. The Anti Revolutionary Party rebounds and, contrary to what some expected, cannibalizes its Christian Democratic coalition allies instead of the other way around. While it’s still nowhere near a plurality, let alone a majority, it becomes the largest party on the country’s right and stonewalls any sort of Liberal reforms (aside from economic ones). Part of this is thanks to them completely shedding their own “moderate " wing and going full Free Market Conservatism. The squatting movement is stunted when the Government throws a bunch of taxpayer dollars at Private Companies to fix homelessness (and skim much of that cash off the top) - these new homes are as opulent as they are inefficient, but who cares for a little pollution and such waste of space if it’s as good as free? Population growth stagnates but doesn't quite fall, remaining very low for Fabulous Decades standards. Crime falls, while cultural shifts are still reasonably genuine as opposed to just screams of anguish from the youth or a money laundering scheme (as is so often the case in other FabDec era nations). The last election, in 1986, gave the Anti-Revolutionaries a very wide mandate, even if a coalition of disgruntled Christian Socialists, Labourites and Anti-Western Conservatives did mount a somewhat effective resistance to them in some northeastern constituencies. In 1988 the Economy was doing quite well, even if there had been a slight dip compared to the last financial quarter.)
Norway (Exploits the living shit out of North Sea Oil and Gas, invests a bunch of it into better excavation tech, further depleting those sources but also finding new ones ahead of schedule. The Norwegian Government uses this revenue for large-scale rural renewal with entire towns renovated and having brand new town squares - ones that would later become symbols of a bygone age. Statoil was privatized in 1979 (but later re-nationalized in the early 1990s). That said, community decay does hit quite hard - communal spaces and mess halls decline, even those that were renovated becoming strange, osymandian - well kept but rarely attended by anyone. As the natural environment is already hit hard, traditional camping trips nosedive in popularity in favor of watching color TVs (even that is no longer a family activity - while not as rich as Americans, Norwegians have 3 Colour TVs per house, dividing everyone between their own rooms). The country has one of the highest rates of drug abuse in the world, with a tragically high amount of youth overdoses - not to the point where it could actively hurt the country’s demography, but enough to be noticeable even to laymen observers. In spite of a few operations by the famous Special Agent Augusto Fernando César in 1982 and 1983 (ones the Government paid a ton for), the underlying issues are not solved, and the country remains in a sort of spiritual void until the Sinai Shock. Labour remains the largest party, often ruling with an outright majority, even if they have adopted many economically liberal policies to keep the petrodollars flowing. Fares the best in the early Red Decade - see Part 2-3 Section II for more info)
Portugal (Pressured by the USA, the Portuguese let Angola and Mozambique go in name so they can still exploit the living shit out of them in practice. Fully knowing the Military is expecting further reforms, the President authorized ,,limited” Democratization measures, with more power given to parliament and less crackdowns on the opposition (aside from the Far Left, but it’s not like China - once their main sponsor - gave much of a shit anymore) alongside economic liberalization. He gets a shitton of money from the European Economic Community. Portugal also pours millions into creating a proper vacation industry, with cases of cancer swept under the rug and brand new complexes, like big waterparks and massive 20 story hotels. After a West German Tourist is arrested for accidentally “engaging with anti-national elements” (he flirted with a girl he wasn’t aware was a part of the Opposition) the President speeds up the reforms, and after his death in 1984 proper elections for the legislature are held.  The Centre-right “Opposition” wins and subsequently pressures the new guy to resign, replacing him with a freely elected (the new constitution states it’s the parliament that elects the President) dude. They joined the EEC in 1985, alongside Spain. The next Elections are slated for September 1988.)
San Marino (Remains stable, with a flourishing tourist industry. The Communist Party, much to Moscow’s chagrin, fully adopts Chenism and wins the 1983 Elections, forming a Majority Government. They continue large scale development, with mass agriculture (to fuel Europe’s thirst for luxury goods like wine and olive oil) and a flourishing banking sector (although one under somewhat strict Government supervision) established. The Communists grew their majority in 1988, and after the Sinai War tried to dissolve the Grand and General Council while also adopting totalitarian policies. This leads to a series of riots and a coup in 1989, after which a ,,Popular Front” headed by the Christian Democrats and a newly reformed Socialist Party (having split into the Democratic Socialist Party and the Socialist Agreement in the early 1970s, partially paving the way for Communist Governance in the first place). The economy still goes to shit and the microstate is overwhelmed by Italian refugees from neighboring areas. Requests to be annexed in 1992, accepted by the Italian Government. Afterward it is mostly used by Europe as a nation-sized labor camp, still up and going (even if as polluted as the rest of the continent) in 2027.
Spain (Also pressured by the USA, Franco lets the Free Market be liberalized more, stabbing his old buds - the National Syndicalists, Falangists and Conservative Labor Unions - in the back, with those who resist often dying of suicide after shooting themselves seven times. The new Prime Minister (Franco having been transferred to the post of ,,Chairman of the Legislative Assembly”, which is de jure powerless but he still holds some influence de facto)) mostly apes what Portugal is doing but goes significantly further with social liberalism. Franco is absolutely disgusted but can’t do shit without risking a CIA backed coup, dying and later being commercialized (there’s Franco Balloons, Franco Paintings, Franco Chairs, Franco Bobbleheads and more sold on street fairs by people who probably couldn’t tell him apart from Salazar). In the early 1980s the EEC began to pressure them big time, with proper elections held in 1985. The PM and his ,,People’s Freedom Party” easily secure a majority and continue to turn the country into a Free Market, “Libertarian” (in big quotation marks - they still hold the Security Apparatus but use it to hunt down remaining terrorists in a sort of Rent-a-Augusto / ,,I can’t believe it’s not real Fernando” kind of way, to get extra money) paradise with a bunch of tourist spots. They quickly adopt socially liberal laws (the Prime Minister himself being rather liberal), with Women’s rights expanded and even some token gestures toward the LGB Community. Minorities are granted autonomy and ETA Dissolves after negotiations (with the USA and China as intermediaries) that create a very favorable Basque Parliament. They joined the EEC alongside Portugal in 1985 (sometimes called the ,,Summer Entrance" or ,,Sandy Marriage” although both terms are manufactured by the media and rarely used by the majority of the public). Monarchy abolished via referendum in January 1988, Prince Felipe became a famous sportsman, participating in local tournaments, becoming Spain’s top Footballers and preparing for the 1988 Olympics. The palace planned to become the heart of a massive tourist trap, slated for opening in mid 1989. Tourism heavily promoted throughout all of this time - Barcelona became “ the Affair capital of Europe”, sometimes denounced by televangelists across the globe, especially after Nudist beaches were zoned in late 1987. The “Sea of Plastic” is made early, initially in the mid 80s to harvest luxury fruit and make it even cheaper (idea of some entrepreneurial businessman, sick of having to split his import profits with local corrupt bureaucrats or authoritarian tinpot dictators) and later repurposed for normal food in the Red Decade.
Sweden (Government attempts at increasing welfare are torpedoed by the Opposition, although the Social Democrats get around this by lowering taxes on the poor while keeping them on the rich (although sometimes foreign rich are exempt from this to not risk international isolation). Capital Flight still happens but many other businesses, mostly local ones, pop up to replace them. After the Social Democrats were kicked out in 1976 the privatization went all in, with the coalition government slashing many welfare programs (although keeping some) and giving money to everyone who wants it. They try to start-up a toy franchise meant to rival LEGO, but the rival’s monopoly on the market meant they flopped (although the short lived toys would become collectors items - both in the Red Decade, and for historians and nobles in future centuries). Corruption would begin to rise as a result of this prosperity and a near total lack of oversight, and even though, in 1986, César busts a corruption ring (he got leads on it following his Norwegian Drug Investigation) the Brazilian Government, and him as an extension, are convinced to merely give the Government the papers back as to not cause trouble in an election year. The corrupt officials were ,,purged” (mostly reassigned, or even merely scolded for getting caught) silently and things never went public. In exchange, a ton of Brazilian Officials got rich, and the Ericsson Hospital was founded in Rio as payment. Another site, apparently an airport of some kind (historians aren’t sure) was planned to be constructed in 1989-1990 somewhere in the South, but that was cancelled after the Crash. The Social Democrats roared back to power in 1989 (even if with a smaller majority than they had been used to) but their Prime Minister was assassinated in 1990 (some say by a Communist Spy, others suggest a Far Right fanatic, but evidence either way is sketchy). The usual moderate programs are created, and eventually the Nordic Federation is formed.
Turkey (The Economy was quickly liberalized in the early 70s due to international pressure, and after some very, very harsh growing pains - shortages of basic goods, hyperinflation and gas outages - it stabilized by the end of the decade. Democracy is not quite as lucky, but after some controversial actions by a Prime Minister - decried as Authoritarian by the opposition - the office gains extra powers at the cost of Parliament, increasing the length of the average Cabinet from 6 Months to 3 Years . In the 1980s Azerbaijan sold their oil to the country, sparking even more economic growth, and a series of swift NOT-WAR-CRIMES against the Kurds crushed the PKK in its cradle. All in all, everything is as good as it could be by 1988.Then it becomes a dictatorial shithole.)
